column1: A/B Testing;"'''THIS ARTICLE IS STILL IN EDITING MODE'''

column2: also known as split testing or bucket testing
column3: is a method used to compare the performance of two versions of a product or content. This is done by randomly assigning similarly sized audiences to view either the control version (version A) or the treatment version (version B) over a set period of time and measuring their effect on a specific metric
column4: such as clicks
column5: conversions
column6: or engagement. This method is commonly used in the optimization of websites
column7: where the control version is the default version
column8: while the treatment version is changed in a single variable
column9: such as the content of text
column10: colors
column11: shapes
column12: size or positioning of elements on the website.

column1: An important advantage of A/B testing is its ability to establish causal relationships with a high degree of probability
column2: which can transform decision making from an intuitive process to a scientific
column3: evidence-based process. To ensure the trustworthiness of the results of A/B tests
column4: the scheme of [[Experiments and Hypothesis Testing|scientific experiments]] is followed
column5: consisting of a planning phase
column6: an execution phase
column7: and an evaluation phase.

column2: a goal and hypothesis are formulated
column3: and a study design is developed that specifies the sample size
column4: the duration of the study
column5: and the metrics to be measured. This phase is crucial for ensuring the reliability and validity of the test.

column1: The goal identifies problems or optimization potential to improve the software product. For example
column2: in the case of a website
column3: the goal could be to increase newsletter subscriptions or improve the conversion rate through changing parts of the website.

column1: To determine if a particular change is better than the default version
column2: a two-sample hypothesis test is conducted to determine if there are statistically significant differences between the two samples (version A and B). This involves stating the null hypothesis and the alternative hypothesis.

column1: From the perspective of an A/B test
column2: the null hypothesis states that there is no difference between the control and treatment group
column3: while the alternative hypothesis states that there is a difference between the two groups which is influenced by a non-random cause.

column2: it is not known a priori whether the discrepancy in the results between A and B is in favor of A or B. Therefore
column3: the alternative hypothesis should consider the possibility that both versions A and B have different levels of efficiency. In order to account for this
column4: a two-sided test is typically preferred for the subsequent evaluation.

column1: To fix the problem that there are hardly any subscriptions for my newsletter
column2: I will put the sign-up box higher up on the website.""

column1: Goal: Increase the newsletter subscriptions on the website.
H0: There are no significant changes in the number of new newsletter subscribers between the control and treatment versions.
H1: There are significant changes in the number of new newsletter subscribers between the control and treatment versions.
In order to obtain accurate results
column2: it is important to minimize confounding variables before the A/B test is conducted. This involves determining an appropriate sample size
column3: tracking the right users
column4: collecting the right metrics
column5: and ensuring that the randomization unit is adequate.

column1: The sample size is determined by the percentage of users included in the test variants (control and treatment) and the duration of the experiment. As the experiment runs for a longer period of time
column2: more visitors are exposed to the variants
column3: resulting in an increase in the sample size. Because many external factors vary over time
column4: it is important to randomize over time by running the control and treatment variants simultaneously at a fixed percentage throughout the experiment. Thereby the goal is to obtain adequate statistical power
column5: where the statistical power of an experiment is the probability of detecting a particular effect if it exists. In practice
column6: one can assign any percentages to the control and treatment
column7: but 50% gives the experiment maximum statistical power.

column2: it is important to analyze only the subset of the population/users that were potentially affected. For example
column3: in an A/B test aimed at optimizing newsletter subscriptions
column4: it would be appropriate to exclude individuals who were already subscribed to the newsletter
column5: as they would not have been affected by the changes made to the subscription form.

column2: the metrics used in the experiment should be carefully chosen based on their relevance to the hypotheses being tested. For example
column3: in the case of an e-commerce site
column4: metrics such as newsletter subscriptions and revenue per user may be of interest
column5: as they are directly related to the goal of the test. However
column6: it is important to avoid considering too many metrics at once
column7: as this can increase the risk of miscorrelation.

column1: The execution phase involves implementing the study design
column2: collecting data
column3: and monitoring the study to ensure it is conducted according to the plan. During this phase
column4: users are randomly assigned to the control or treatment group ensuring that the study is conducted in a controlled and unbiased manner.

column1: The evaluation phase involves analyzing the data collected during the study and interpreting the results. This phase is crucial for determining the statistical significance of the results and drawing valid conclusions about whether there was a statistical significant difference between the treatment group and the control group. One commonly used method is calculating the [[Designing_studies#P-value|p-value]] of the statistical test
column2: or by using [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9TDjifpGj-k Bayes' theorem] calculating the probability that the treatment had a positive effect based on the observed data and the prior beliefs about the treatment.

column1: Depending on the type of data being collected different [[Simple Statistical Tests|statistical tests]] should be considered. For example
column2: when dealing with discrete metrics such as click-through rate
column3: the [https://mathworld.wolfram.com/FishersExactTest.html Fisher exact test] can be used to calculate the exact p-value
column4: while the [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7_cs1YlZoug chi-squared test] may be more appropriate for larger sample sizes.

column1: In the case of continuous metrics
column2: such as average revenue per user
column3: the [[T-Test|t-test or Welch's t-test]] may be used to determine the significance of the treatment effect. However
column4: these tests assume that the data is normally distributed
column5: which may not always be the case. In cases where the data is not normally distributed
column6: nonparametric tests such as the [https://data.library.virginia.edu/the-wilcoxon-rank-sum-test/ Wilcoxon rank sum test] may be more appropriate.

column1: A/B testing has several advantages over traditional methods of evaluating the effectiveness of a product or design. First
column2: it allows for a more controlled and systematic comparison of the treatment and control version. Second
column3: it allows for the random assignment of users to the treatment and control groups
column4: reducing the potential for bias. Third
column5: it allows for the collection of data over a period of time
column6: which can provide valuable insights into the long-term effects of the treatment.

column2: A/B testing also has some limitations. For example
column3: it is only applicable to products or designs that can be easily compared in a controlled manner. In addition
column4: the results of an A/B test may not always be generalizable to the broader population
column5: as the sample used in the test may not be representative of the population as a whole. Furthermore
column6: it is not always applicable
column7: as it requires a clear separation between control and treatment
column8: and it may not be suitable for testing complex products or processes
column9: where the relationship between the control and treatment versions is not easily defined or cannot be isolated from other factors that may affect the outcome.

column2: A/B testing is a valuable tool for evaluating the effects of software or design changes. By setting up a controlled experiment and collecting data
column3: we can make evidence-based decisions about whether a change should be implemented.

column1: '''In short:''' The Analysis of Variance is a statistical method that allows to test differences of the mean values of groups within a sample.

column1: With a rise in knowledge during the [[History of Methods|Enlightenment]]
column2: it became apparent that the controlled setting of a [[Experiments|laboratory]] were not enough for experiments
column3: as it became obvious that more knowledge was there to be discovered in the [[Field experiments|real world]]. First in astronomy
column4: but then also in agriculture and other fields
column5: the notion became apparent that our reproducible settings may sometimes be hard to achieve within real world settings. Observations can be unreliable
column6: and errors in measurements in astronomy was a prevalent problem in the 18th and 19th century. Fisher equally recognised the mess - or variance - that nature forces onto a systematic experimenter (Rucci & Tweney 1980). The demand for more food due to the rise in population
column7: and the availability of potent seed varieties and fertiliser - both made possible thanks to scientific experimentation - raised the question how to conduct experiments under field conditions.

column2: building on the previous development of the [[Simple_Statistical_Tests#One_sample_t-test|t-test]]
column3: Fisher proposed the Analysis of Variance
column4: abbreviated as ANOVA (Rucci & Tweney 1980). '''It allowed for the comparison of variables from experimental settings
column5: comparing how a [[Data_formats#Continuous_data|continuous]] variable fared under different experimental settings.''' Doing experiments in the laboratory reached its limits
column6: as plant growth experiments were hard to conduct in the small confined spaces of a laboratory. It also became questionable whether the results were actually applicable in the real world. Hence experiments literally shifted into fields
column7: with a dramatic effect on their design
column8: conduct and outcome. While laboratory conditions aimed to minimise variance - ideally conducting experiments with a high confidence -
column9: the new field experiments increased sample size to tame the variability - or messiness - of factors that could not be controlled
column10: such as subtle changes in the soil or microclimate. Fisher and his ANOVA became the forefront of a new development of scientifically designed experiments
column11: which allowed for a systematic [[Experiments and Hypothesis Testing|testing of hypotheses]] under field conditions
column12: taming variance through replicates. '''The power of repeated samples allowed to account for the variance under field conditions
column13: and thus compare differences in [[Descriptive_statistics|mean]] values between different treatments.''' For instance
column14: it became possible to compare different levels of fertiliser to optimise plant growth.

column1: Establishing the field experiment became thus a step in the scientific development
column2: but also in the industrial capabilities associated to it. Science contributed directly to the efficiency of production
column3: for better or worse. Equally
column4: the systematic experiments translated into other domains of science
column5: such as psychology and medicine.

column1: The ANOVA is a deductive statistical method that allows to compare how a continuous variable differs under different treatments in a designed experiment. '''It is one of the most important statistical models
column2: and allows for an analysis of data gathered from designed experiments.''' In an ANOVA-designed experiment
column3: several categories are thus compared in terms of their mean value regarding a continuous variable. A classical example would be how a certain type of barley grows on different soil types
column4: with the three soil types loamy
column5: sandy and clay (Crawley 2007
column6: p. 449). If the majority of the data from one soil type differs from the majority of the data from the other soil type
column7: then these two types differ
column8: which can be tested by a t-test. The ANOVA is in principle comparable to the t-test
column9: but extends it: it can compare more than two groups
column10: hence allowing to compare data in more complex
column11: designed experiments.

column1: [[File:Yield.jpg|thumb|400px|left|Does the soil influence the yield? And how do I find out if there is any difference between clay
column2: loam and sand? Maybe try an ANOVA...(graph based on Crawley 2007

column1: Single factor analysis that are also called '[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nvAMVY2cmok one-way ANOVAs]' investigate one factor variable
column2: and all other variables are kept constant. Depending on the number of factor levels these demand a so called [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_square randomisation]
column3: which is necessary to compensate for instance for microclimatic differences under lab conditions.

column1: Designs with multiple factors or '[https://www.thoughtco.com/analysis-of-variance-anova-3026693 two way ANOVAs]' test for two or more factors
column2: which then demands to test for interactions as well. This increases the necessary sample size on a multiplicatory scale
column3: and the degrees of freedoms may dramatically increase depending on the number of factors levels and their interactions. An example of such an interaction effect might be an experiment where the effects of different watering levels and different amounts of fertiliser on plant growth are measured. While both increased water levels and higher amounts of fertiliser right increase plant growths slightly
column4: the increase of of both factors jointly might lead to a dramatic increase of plant growth.

column1: The data that is of relevance to ANOVAs can be ideally visualised in [[Introduction_to_statistical_figures#Boxplot|boxplots
column2: ]] which allows for an initial visualisation of the data distribution
column3: since the classical ANOVA builds on the [[Regression Analysis|regression model]]
column4: and thus demands data that is [[Data_distribution#The_normal_distribution|normally distributed]]. '''If one box within a boxplot is higher or lower than the median of another factor level
column5: then this is a good rule of thumb whether there is a significant difference.''' When making such a graphically informed assumption
column6: we have to be however really careful if the data is normally distributed
column7: as skewed distributions might tinker with this rule of thumb. The overarching guideline for the ANOVA are thus the p-values
column8: which give significance regarding the difference between the different factor levels.

column2: the original ANOVA builds on balanced designs
column3: which means that all categories are represented by an equal sample size. Extensions have been developed later on in this regard
column4: with the type 3 ANOVA allowing for the testing of unbalanced designs
column5: where sample sizes differ between different categories levels. The Analysis of Variance is implemented into all standard statistical software
column6: such as R and SPSS. However
column7: differences in the calculation may occur when it comes to the calculation of unbalanced designs.

column1: The ANOVA can be a powerful tool to tame the variance in field experiments or more complex laboratory experiments
column2: as it allows to account for variance in repeated experimental measures of experiments that are built around replicates. The ANOVA is thus the most robust method when it comes to the design of deductive experiments
column3: yet with the availability of more and more data
column4: also inductive data has increasingly been analysed by use of the ANOVA. This was certainly quite alien to the original idea of Fisher
column5: who believed in clear robust designs and rigid testing of hypotheses. The reproducibility crisis has proven that there are limits to deductive approaches
column6: or at least to the knowledge these experiments produce. The 20th century was certainly fuelled in its development by experimental designs that were at their heart analysed by the ANOVA. However
column7: we have to acknowledge that there are limits to the knowledge that can be produced
column8: and more complex analysis methods evolved with the wider availability of computers.

column2: the ANOVA is equally limited as the regression
column3: as both build on the [[Data_distribution#The_normal_distribution|normal distribution]]. Extensions of the ANOVA translated its analytical approach into the logic of [[Generalized Linear Models|generalised linear models]]
column4: enabling the implementation of other distributions as well. What unites all different approaches is the demand that the ANOVA has in terms of data
column5: and with increasing complexity
column6: the demands increase when it comes to the sample sizes. Within experimental settings
column7: this can be quite demanding
column8: which is why the ANOVA only allows to test very constructed settings of the world. All categories that are implemented as predictors in an ANOVA design represent a constructed worldview
column9: which can be very robust
column10: but is always a compromise. The ANOVA thus tries to approximate causality by creating more rigid designs. However
column11: we have to acknowledge that experimental designs are always compromises
column12: and more knowledge may become available later. Within clinical trials - most of which have an ANOVA design at their heart - great care is taken into account in terms of robustness and documentation
column13: and clinical trial stages are built on increasing sample sizes to minimise the harm on humans in these experiments.

column2: the ANOVA is one of the most relevant calculation tools to fuel the exponential growth that characterised the 20th century.''' Agricultural experiments and medical trials are widely built on the ANOVA
column3: yet we also increasingly recognise the limitations of this statistical model. Around the millennium
column4: new models emerged
column5: such as [[Mixed Effect Models|mixed effect models]]. But at its core
column6: the ANOVA is the basis of modern deductive statistical analysis.

column1: Designing an ANOVA-based design demands experience
column2: and knowledge of the previous literature. The deductive approach of an ANOVA is thus typically embedded into an incremental development in the literature. ANOVA-based designs are therefore more often than not part of the continuous development in normal science. However
column3: especially since the millennium
column4: other more advanced approaches gained momentum
column5: such as mixed effect models
column6: information theoretical approaches
column7: and structural equation models. The rigid root of the normal distribution and the basis of p-values is increasingly recognised as rigid if not outright flawed
column8: and model reduction in more complex ANOVA designs is far from coherent between different branches of sciences. Some areas of science reject p-driven statistics altogether
column9: while other branches of science are still publishing full models without any model reduction whatsoever. In addition
column10: the ANOVA is today also often used to analyse inductive datasets
column11: which is technically ok
column12: but can infer several problems from a statistical standpoint
column13: as well as based on a critical perspective rooted in a coherent theory of science.

column1: Hence the ANOVA became a swiss army knive for group comparison for a continuous variable
column2: and whenever different category levels need to be compared across a dependent variable
column3: the ANOVA is being pursued. Whether there is an [[Causality|actual question of dependency]] is often ignored
column4: let alone model assumptions and necessary preconditions. '''Science evolved
column5: and with it
column6: our questions became ever more complex
column7: as are the problems that we face in the world
column8: or that want to test.''' [[Agency
column9: Complexity and Emergence#Complexity|Complexity]] reigns
column10: and simple designs are more often than not questioned. The ANOVA remains as one of the two fundamental models of deductive statistics
column11: with [[Regression Analysis|regression]] being the other important line of thinking. As soon as rigid questions of dependence were conveniently ignored
column12: statisticians - or the researchers that applied statistics - basically dug the grave for these rigid yet robust approaches. There are still many cases where the ANOVA represents the most parsimonious and even adequate model. However
column13: as long as positivist scientists share a room with a view in their ivory tower and fail to clearly indicate the limitations of their ANOVA-based designs
column14: they undermine their [[Glossary|credibility]]
column15: and with it the [[Glossary|trust]] between science and society. The ANOVA is a testimony of how much statsicsi can serve society
column16: for better or worse. The ANOVA may serve as a sound approximations of knowledge
column17: yet at its worst it speaks of the arrogance of researchers who imply [[Causality|causality]] into mere patterns that can and will change once more knowledge becomes available.

column1: The Analysis of Variance was one of the most relevant contributions of statistics to the developments of the 20th century. By allowing for the systematic testing of hypotheses
column2: not only did a whole line of thinking of the theory of science evolve
column3: but whole disciplines were literally emerging. Lately
column4: frequentist statistics was increasingly critizised for its reliance on p-values. Also
column5: the reproducibility crisis highlights the limitations of ANOVA-based designs
column6: which are often not reproducible. Psychological research faces this challenge for instance by pre-registering studies
column7: indicating their statistical approach before approaching the data
column8: and other branches of science are also attempting to do more justice to the limitations of the knowledge of experiments. In addition
column9: new ways of experimentation of science evolve
column10: introducing a systematic approach to case studies and solution oriented approaches. This may open a more systematic approach to inductive experiments
column11: making documentation a key process in the creation of a canonised knowledge. Scientific experiments were at the forefront of developments that are seen more critically regarding their limitations. Taking more complexities into account
column12: ANOVAs become a basis for more advanced statistics
column13: and they can indeed serve as a robust basis if the limitations are clearly indicated
column14: and the ANOVA designs add to parts of a larger picture of knowledge.

column1: [https://www.britannica.com/science/probability/Risks-expectations-and-fair-contracts The concept of probability goes way back] to Arabian mathematicians and was initially strongly associated with cryptography. With rising recognition of preconditions that need to be met in order to discuss probability

column2: due to the discovery of the normal distribution.''' It allowed the feasible approach to link sample size of observations with an understanding of the likelihood how plausible these observations were. Again building on Sir Francis Bacon
column3: the theory of probability reached its final breakthrough once it was applied in statistical hypothesis testing. It is important to notice that this would throw modern statistics into an understanding through the lens of so-called [https://www.probabilisticworld.com/frequentist-bayesian-approaches-inferential-statistics/ frequentist statistics]. This line of thinking dominates up until today
column4: and is widely built on repeated samples to understand the distribution of probabilities across a phenomenon.

column5: Bayesian statistics build on the existing sample size; all calculations base on what is already there. Experts may excuse my dramatic simplification
column6: but one could say that frequentist statistics are top-down thinking
column7: while [https://365datascience.com/bayesian-vs-frequentist-approach/ Bayesian statistics] work bottom-up. The history of modern science is widely built on frequentist statistics

column1: Another perspective on the two approaches can be built around the question whether we design studies - or whether we base our analysis on the data we just have. This debate is the basis for the deeply entrenched conflicts you have in statistics up until today
column2: and was already the basis for the conflicts between Pearson and Fisher. From an epistemological perspective
column3: this can be associated with the question of inductive or [[Glossary|deductive reasoning]]
column4: although not many statisticians might not be too keen to explore this relation deeply

column6: but not both.

column1: '''While probability today can be seen as one of the core foundations of statistical testing
column2: probability as such is increasingly criticised.''' It would exceed this chapter to discuss this in depth
column3: but let me just highlight that without understanding probability
column4: much of the scientific literature building on quantitative methods is hard to understand. What is important to notice
column5: is that probability has trouble considering [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Why_statistics_matters#Occam.27s_razor Occam's razor]. This is related to the fact that probability can deal well with the chance of an event to a occur
column6: but it widely ignores the complexity that can influence such a likeliness. Modern statistics explore this thought further but let us just realise here: without learning probability we would have trouble reading the contemporary scientific literature.

The probability can be best explained with the [https://www.stat.colostate.edu/~vollmer/stat307pdfs/LN4_2017.pdf normal distribution]. The normal distribution basically tells us through probability how a certain value will add to an array of values. Take the example of the height of people
column2: or more specifically people who define themselves as males. Within a given population or country
column3: these have an average height. This means in other words
column4: that you have the highest chance to have this height when you are part of this population. You have a slightly lower chance to have a slightly smaller or larger height compared to the average height. And you have a very small chance to be much smaller or much taller compared to the average. In other words
column5: your probability is small to be very tall or very small. Hence the distribution of height follows a normal distribution
column6: and this normal distribution can be broken down into probabilities. In addition
column7: such a distribution can have a variance
column8: and these variances can be compared to other variances by using a so called [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FlIiYdHHpwU f test]. Take the example of height of people who define themselves as males. Now take the people who define themselves as females from the same population and compare just these two groups. You may realise that in most larger populations these two are comparable. This is quite relevant when you want to compare the income distribution between different countries. Many countries have [http://www.oecd.org/statistics/compare-your-income.htm different average incomes]
column9: but the distribution across the average as well as the very poor and the filthy rich can still be compared. In order to do this

column3: Complexity and Emergence (German)]]

column1: '''In short:''' This entry discusses three central elements of systems
column2: and how we can investigate them methodologically.
Complexity and Emergence are three concepts that can be understood as lenses through which we can see results that originate in theoretical considerations
column3: as well as information we access through empirical research. Since such [[Glossary|concepts]] are binding the two realms of scientific inquiry - theory and practice - I call the three concepts of agency
column4: complexity and emergence „boundary objects“. They are good examples of ideas that are most relevant within the philosophy of science. In addition
column5: they strongly determine our fundamental and normative view of the world as well as the consequences of the knowledge we gain from the world. If I have for instance the world view that no free will exists
column6: then this will also be a fundamental influence on how I interpret results from empirical inquiry of the actions of people. '''Many would agree that people have the potential to have free will
column7: just as all milk can be turned into butter.''' There are other concepts besides agency
column8: complexity and emergence that are worth pursuing form the perspective of philosophy of science
column9: but for the sake of simplicity and priority
column10: [[Big problems for later|we will only deal]] with these three boundary object here. Let us start with an attempt to show the diversity of definitions of these concepts.

column1: The most simple definition of agency that is widely considered to be most relevant from a methodological standpoint is that agency is defined as ''the capacity of an individual to act intentionally with the assumption of a causal outcome based on this action''. However
column2: within different discourses and disciplines there is a wide variety of approaches that consider broader or more narrow definitions of agency. There is a first disagreement whether an agent should have a mental state that is able to anticipate the outcome of the action
column3: and such diverse realms as neuroscience and philosophy disagree on that point already. For instance
column4: reflexes are instincts
column5: and it is very difficult to track down whether such actions are intentional and contain assumptions about the outcome. Therefore
column6: broader definitions of agency include the action-based adaptation of an agent to his
column7: her or its environment
column8: which includes also much of the animal kingdom. This broad definition of agency will be ignored here

column1: Many phenomena in nature are simple

column5: and as complex as necessary. Complex system theory strongly developed over the last decades
column6: and created ripples into all empirical science and beyond. '''What is however problematic is that no unified and universally accepted definition of complexity exists
column7: which is quite ironic.''' It seems that complexity in itself is complex. Here
column8: I will therefore focus on some of the main arguments and characteristics that are relevant from a methodological standpoint. First of all
column9: I will restrict all considerations to 'complex systems'. To this end
column10: I simply define [[System Thinking & Causal Loop Diagrams|„systems“]] as any number of individuals or elements that interact. Complex Systems
column11: then

column13: emergence

I would argue that these interactions become often unpredictable because they exceed our original assumptions about the dynamics that are possible in the given system. The complexity of such dynamics is then rooted in our own imperfect assumptions about such system dynamics.

column1: Another phenomenon in complex systems is the question of non-linearity. Non-linear behavior is - mechanically speaking - changes that occur strongly and suddenly at the same time
column2: and not gradually and continuously. Non-linear dynamics in systems are often occurring because the dynamics we observe are mediated by another factor. This additional and unknown factor or variable is the original trigger that in interaction with other parts of the system leads to non-linear system dynamics. The third characteristic in complex systems is related to spontaneous order. Spontaneous order relates to ""the spontaneous emergence of order out of seeming chaos"" (wikipedia)
column3: i.e. the creation of structures and order where it could not be anticipated. An example is the synchronisation of clapping noises in a crowd. Such spontaneous orders can often not be anticipated
column4: and provide thus a problem when considering agency of systems. A lack of possible anticipation of feedback loops and non-linear behavior can thus lead to a spontaneous order that highlights our own imperfections when understanding systems. Such system states can be called emergent.

you should do a t-test.'''

column5: which allows for a comparison of two different datasets or samples and tells you if the means of the two datasets differ significantly. The key R command for both types is t.test(). Check the entry on the [[Simple_Statistical_Tests#Most_relevant_simple_tests|t-Test]] to learn more.

column1: * Variance in the data is the measure of dispersion: how much the data spreads around the mean? Use an f-Test to check whether the variances of the two datasets are equal. The key R command for an f-test is var.test(). If the rest returns insignificant results (>0.05)
column2: we can assume equal variances. Check the [[Simple_Statistical_Tests#f-test|f-Test]] entry to learn more.

column1: * If the variances of your two datasets are equal

column4: which would require a Welch t-test. To do a Student t-test instead

column1: = Some general guidance on the use of statistics =
While it is hard to boil statistics down into some very few important generalities
column2: I try to give you here a final bucket list to consider when applying or reading statistics.
is the statistics the right approach to begin with?''' Statistics are quite established in science
column3: and much information is available in a form that allows you to conduct statistics. However
column4: will statistics be able to generate a piece of the puzzle you are looking at? Do you have an underlying theory that can be put into constructs that enable a statistical design? Or do you assume that a rather open research question can be approached through a broad inductive sampling? The publication landscape
column5: experienced researchers as well as pre-test may shed light on the question whether statistics can contribute solving your problem.

column1: 2) '''What are the efforts you need to put into the initial data gathering?''' If you decided that statistics would be valuable to be applied
column2: the question then would be
column3: how? To rephrase this statement: How exactly? Your sampling with all its constructs
column4: sample sizes and replicates decides about the fate of everything you going to do later. A flawed dataset or a small or biased sample will lead to failure
column5: or even worse
column6: wrong results. Play it safe in the beginning
column7: do not try to overplay your hand. Slowly edge your way into the application of statistics
column8: and always reflect with others about your sampling strategy.

column2: as implementing tests within a software is something that you learn best through repetition and practice.''' I suggest you to team up with other peers who decide to go deeper into statistical analysis. If you however decide against that
column3: try to find geeks that may help you with your data analysis. Modern research works in teams of complementary people
column4: thus start to think in these dimensions. If you chip in the topical expertise of the effort to do the sampling
column5: other people may be glad about the chance to analyse the data.

column1: 4) '''This is also true for the interpretation
column2: which most of all builds on experience.''' This is the point were a supervisor or a PhD student may be able to glance at a result and tell you which points are relevant
column3: and which are negotiable. Empirical research typically produces results where in my experience about 80 % are next to negliable. It takes time to learn the difference between a trivial and an innovative result. Building on knowledge of the literature helps again to this end
column4: but be patient as the interpretation of statistics is a skill that needs to ripen
column5: since context matters. It is not so much about the result itself
column6: but more about the whole context it is embedded in.

column1: 5) The last and most important point explores this thought further. '''What are the limitations of your results?''' Where can you see flaws
column2: and how does the multiverse of biases influence your results and interpretation? What are steps to be taken in future research? And what would we change if we could start over and do the whole thing again? All these questions are like ghosts that repeatedly come to haunt a researcher
column3: which is why we need to remember we look at pieces of the puzzle. Acknowledging this is I think very important
column4: as much of the negative connotation statistics often attracts is rooted in a lack of understanding. If people would have the privilege to learn about statistics
column5: they could learn about the power of statistics
column6: as wells its limitations.

column1: '''Never before did more people in the world have the chance to study statistics.''' While of course statistics can only offer a part of the puzzle
column2: I would still dare to say that this is reason for hope. If more people can learn to unlock this knowledge
column3: we might be able to move out of ignorance and more towards knowledge. I think it would be very helpful if in a controversial debate everybody could dig deep into the available information
column4: and make up their own mind
column5: without other people telling them what to believe. Learning about statistics is like learning about anything else
column6: it is lifelong learning. I believe that true masters never achieve mastership
column7: instead they never stop to thrive for it.

column1: Analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) is the statistical test that compares the means of more than two groups by taking under the control the ""noise"" caused by covariate variable that is not of experimental interest. This is done in order to see the true effect of the variable of interest on a dependent variable. Fundamental idea of ANCOVA is based on hypothesis testing
column2: its goal is to evaluate multiple mutually exclusive theories about our [[Glossary|data]]
column3: where null hypothesis claims that the means of the groups are equal
column4: and alternative [[Glossary|hypothesis]] rejects that based on p-value. Additionally
column5: it is important to highlight that ANCOVA also gives information on variables by means of Sum of Squares partitioning that shows the size of error or unexplained information in relation. Since ANCOVA historically comes from the combination of Linear regression and ANOVA
column6: one should meet the assumptions inherent from them as well as specific to ANCOVA before proceeding to the ANCOVA test.

column2: Lapply and Tapply;"'''In short:''' The functions of the ''apply()''-family are useful tools to go through slices of your data and repetitively perform operations on them. In more sophisticated terms
column3: these functions offer a concise and convenient way of implementing the SPLIT-APPLY-COMBINE-strategy of data analysis
column4: i.e. splitting up some data into smaller pieces
column5: applying a function to each piece and combining the results.

column1: One main advantage of the ''apply()''-functions is that they let you iterate over your data '''without having to use regular loops'''. While loops in R are '''not''' necessarily much slower than the apply()-collection
column2: their syntax is more complicated and redundant. The various apply()-functions offer a way of accessing specific elements of data in a convenient and simplified way.
in contrast to regular loops
column3: the apply()-functions take a '''top-down approach''' syntactically
column4: making them easier to read and understand. Where loops start from the smallest element (`for (i in x) ...`)
column5: with the actual operation possibly nested deep within the loop
column6: apply()-functions call the overlying structures first (matrices
column7: lists
column8: ...) before immediately *applying* a function that automatically runs over each element of the called object.

column2: vectorized functions like
column3: for example
column4: ''colmeans()'' still perform faster than variations of ''_apply(x
column5: mean)''. The great benefit of the ''apply()''-collection is their versatility
column6: as you can pass any function
column7: predefined or user-defined
column8: on to them.

column5: ''vapply()''

column8: ''mapply()''. Which one you use

Back of the envelope statistics;"'''In short:''' Back of the envelope statistics revolve around rough
column2: initial calculations that provide a first understanding of quantitative data. In this entry
column3: some approaches are presented.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-04-08 um 11.37.25.png|thumb|left|Back of the envelope calculations give you a first impression about your idea and where it can go to.]]
[https://www.investopedia.com/terms/b/back-of-the-envelope-calculation.asp Back of the envelope calculations] are rough estimates that are made on the small piece of paper
column2: hence the name. They are extremely helpful to get a quick estimate about the basic numbers for a given formula of principle
column3: thus enabling us to get a [https://www.stlouisfed.org/on-the-economy/2020/march/back-envelope-estimates-next-quarters-unemployment-rate quick calculation] that allows us either to check for the plausibility of an assumption
column4: or to derive a simple explanation for a complex issue. '''Back of the envelope statistics can be for instance helpful when you want to get a rough estimate about an idea that can be expressed in numbers.''' Prominent examples include the dominant character coding of the World Wide Web
column5: as well as the development of the laser. Back of the envelope calculations are fantastic within sustainability science
column6: because they can help us illustrate complex issues in a simple form
column7: and they can serve as a guideline for quick planning. Therefore
column8: they can be used within other more complex forms of methodological applications
column9: such as scenario planning. By quickly calculating different scenarios
column10: we can for instance apply a plausibility check and focus our approaches on-the-fly. I encourage you to learn back of the envelope calculations in your [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bAU1MLRwh7c everyday life]
column11: as many of us already do. A great app for this is [http://tydligapp.com/ ""Tydlig""]
column12: which unfortunately only exists for iOS devices. It is a great example however of how to break numbers down into overall estimates
column13: and make quick on-the-fly calculations.

column2: I provide you some simple examples of back of the envelope calculations
column3: which may help you gain some understanding on why these could be valuable.

column2: subtracting
column3: multiplying and dividing are part of the everyday language of mathematics
column4: and while we all should have learned these in school
column5: most of us are not versatile in applying them regularly. How do we divide the bill by three? What is 20 % of the bill to add as a tip? How many pieces of cake remain? How can I double this recipe? There is ample evidence that this can be intuitive to some
column6: yet most of us struggle. However
column7: I think it is extremely important to regularly practice
column8: and there are apps such as [https://brilliant.org/ ""Brilliant""] and games like Sudoku to improve our skills with numbers. Only if you learn the basics
column9: you will be able to master the supreme mathematics.

column1: We often hear numbers about probability and chances. While many of these are arbitrary
column2: such as the chances of winning the Lottery
column3: there are others probabilities that matter in our day-to-day life. For instance
column4: the chances of catching a COVID-19 infection outside is 19 times lower than inside. One common misconception is that the chances are 0 - they are not
column5: they are just lower
column6: but considerably so! Another misconception is the question of how low your chances of basically anything are in general. Quite often we cannot stop computing a chance calculation
column7: even though our chances are actually very low anyway. Will I win the Lottery? Probably not. Will I be diagnosed with a rare condition? Probably not. Still
column8: we think more about such things than necessary
column9: considering our actual chances. Then again
column10: spending some time on computing the real probability of a certain event happening may actually help us finish the thought once and for all
column11: and act accordingly. The COVID-19 crisis is a good example
column12: where a combination of several modes of action
column13: such as social distancing
column14: wearing masks or washing your hands
column15: can substantially lower your chances of catching the disease. Knowing about this makes a lot of sense. However
column16: it will be next to impossible to lower your chances to 0
column17: unless you would be willing to create harm to others or yourself in an extent that may
column18: in turn
column19: outweigh the low chances of catching the disease. '''Calculating probabilities can be a good exercise to be more clear about your chances.'''

column2: sometimes it is not the chances or probabilities that you are interested in
column3: but the actual numbers and what they mean
column4: and these two things differ. A chance of 1:100000 seems rather smallish
column5: yet if I tell you that this is the chance of a popular touristic attraction - a scenic cliff - that a tourist falls of the cliff while taking a selfie
column6: then you would agree to create safety measures. '''Numbers count.''' Probabilities or chances are good to put things into perspective
column7: and compare different risks or possibilities. However
column8: thinking about what a certain probability actually means can really make a difference when evaluating said probability. Sometimes
column9: it is worthwhile considering both sides of the coin. Then again
column10: when you are afraid of flying in a plane because the plane might crash
column11: knowing the chances of actually crashing will hardly help you to get over your fear because the image of what it means is too prevalent in your mind. On the other hand
column12: many smokers are aware of the healths risks and seemingly do not care
column13: and might be better off actually contextualizing these risks. I propose that we should more often calculate our chances - in other words
column14: the probability of something - and the actual meaning of being that one in a million. This might give us a more accurate picture of our conditions and circumstances
column15: and help us decide what to do
column16: and how to act.

column1: Another prominent example of back of the envelope calculations is knowledge about predictions. '''Unfortunately
column2: many predictions that we make based on rather small samples can be wrong.''' There are prominent examples of recent elections where much was at stake
column3: and it was ambiguous what would come out in the end. The US election in 2016 and 2020 are relevant examples
column4: which showcase how different samples in forecasts lead to changes in the outcome. For instance
column6: over the first day after the election
column7: the counting was leaning towards Trump
column8: yet with more and more counts coming in from the larger cities
column9: many states tilted towards Biden. Here
column10: the pre-counts were biased towards a more positive outcome for the Republicans. However
column11: looking at the counties
column12: and checking where most counts were still being counted
column13: gave a clear picture early on towards a shift to Biden. Such trend statistics can hence be rather advanced
column14: and knowledge about the context is crucial. More often than not
column15: this is however not respected. It is almost impossible to give an absolute minimum sample size that is reliable for any kind of calculation
column16: so we should be aware of a given sample's limits and contextualize our decisions accordingly.

column1: The case statistics of the early COVID-19 infections from Wuhan in Januar of 2020 showed an early picture in terms of the spread of this disease. With this rate of increase
column2: and the rate of mortality evolving with a few weeks lag
column3: the information that patients were spreading the disease before showing symptoms sealed the trend. We learned from this
column4: and from then on
column5: all trend calculations could be probed based on the initial development in Wuhan. Calculations about countermeasures or vaccines later were mere modifications of the same trend function. The numbers were big enough here to make plausible claims. Calculating percentage growth and then extrapolating further up until a maximum system saturation is reached is thus a common tool to understand what might happen. Looking at temporal trend data and understanding the [[Glossary|patterns]] is one of the most essential tools in these times of global change. Become versatile in reading [[Barplots
column6: _Histograms_and_Boxplots#Barplots|bar plots]]
column7: and learn to calculate trends both in absolute numbers as well as in percentage growth. If you practice this
column8: many developments will not come as a surprise to you.

column1: While there are advanced statistical tests to [[Simple Statistical Tests|compare groups]] and calculate differences between individual groups
column2: comparing mean values between groups is the most relevant calculation. While there is for instance a high variance in lactose intolerance across the globe
column3: people from certain regions should avoid milk probably more than people from other groups. Equally
column4: some groups are more prone to specific diseases than others. This may not say much about your individual risk
column5: but is still an initial prior that can translate into a different chance calculation (see above). '''Variance and mean values are not the same.''' We should be aware of this
column6: and ask how things vary between individuals
column7: and how much a mean value can really say about groups of these individuals. Consider the case of the enzyme breaking down alcohol
column8: which is missing in some people of Asian heritage
column9: leading to an overall lower mean value of Alcohol intolerance in this group. Still
column10: this might not help you in a drinking game
column11: since the variance regarding this enzyme is quite high. Another example is the soapy taste some people experience when eating corianthe. While indeed more Europeans than Asians experience a soapy taste
column12: this difference is remarkably small
column13: and our knowledge about this is based on a study that sampled many European participants
column14: and few participants of Asian heritage. Hence
column15: Back of the envelope statistics can not only help you to know certain patterns better
column16: but can equally help you to recognise flaws in other peoples [[Glossary|assumptions]] or calculations. It is indeed quite often the case that research highlight results that may be statistically significant
column17: but when you check out the actual patterns
column18: then these are quite small.

column1: The last approach I want to highlight are complex system calculations where several calculations are broken down based on various assumptions. A prominent calculation is the carbon footprint of a person. This can be a quite advanced endeavour demanding many calculations of supply chains and circular dynamics
column2: behavioral choices
column3: individual circumstances and external influences. Yet
column4: there are proxies that can allow you to make a rough estimation. The combination of your food choices
column5: travel distance and frequency - including commute habits - as well as heating and electricity usage can lead to severe changes in the carbon footprint of a person
column6: but we can often rely on general estimates to get a first useful insight. '''Approximating such crude measures can often be more transformative than advanced calculation
column7: and we better leave those to the professionals.''' Building your life choices on simple heuristics can be helpful for many people
column8: and Back of the envelope calculations can support such approaches.

column1: Histograms can become confusing depending on how the bin margin is put. As it is said in The [https://www.wiley.com/en-us/The+R+Book%2C+2nd+Edition-p-9781118448960 R Book
column2: p231] - “Wide bins produce one picture
column3: narrow bins produce a different picture
column4: unequal bins produce confusion.” Choice of number and width of bins techniques can heavily influence a histogram’s appearance
column5: and choice of bandwidth can heavily influence the appearance of a kernel density estimate. Therefore
column6: it is suggested that the bins stay in the same width and that the number of the bins is selected carefully to best display pattern in data.

Simple boxplots are not very useful at illustrating if the median values between the groups of sets of data are significantly different. Therefore
column2: we use boxplot with nothces to show the distribution of data points around the median and to see whether or not the median values are different between the groups. The notches are drawn as a ‘waist’ on either side of the median and are intended to give a rough impression of significance of the differences between two medians. Boxes in which the notches do not overlap are likely to prove to have significantly different medians under an appropriate statistical test ([https://www.wiley.com/en-us/The+R+Book%2C+2nd+Edition-p-9781118448960 The R Book

column1: The size of the notch increases with the magnitude of the interquartile range and declines with the square root of replication:

column2: and ‘n’ is the replication per sample. Notches are based on assumptions of asymptotic normality of the median and roughly equal sample sizes for two medians being compared and are said to be rather insensitive to the underlying distribution of the samples. The idea is to give roughly a 95% confidence interval for the difference of two medians. ([https://www.wiley.com/en-us/The+R+Book%2C+2nd+Edition-p-9781118448960 The R Book

'''In short:''' Bayesian Inference is a statistical line of thinking that derives calculations based on distributions derived from the currently available data.
[[File:Bayesian Inference.png|400px|thumb|right|'''SCOPUS hits per year for Bayesian Inference until 2020.''' Search terms: 'Bayesian' in Title
column2: Abstract
column3: Keywords. Source: own.]]

column1: '''The basic principles behind Bayesian methods can be attributed to the probability theorist and philosopher
column2: Thomas Bayes.''' His method was published posthumously by Richard Price in 1763. While at the time
column3: the approach did not gain that much attention
column4: it was also rediscovered and extended upon independently by Pierre Simon Laplace (1). Bayes' name only became associated with the method in the 1900s (3).

column1: * Bayesian approaches incorporate prior information into its analysis. This means that any past information one has can be used in a fruitful way.
* Bayesian approach provides a more intuitive and direct statement of the probability that the hypothesis is true
column2: as opposed to the frequentist approach where the interpretation of p-value is convoluted.

column1: * Even though the concept is intuitive to understand
column2: the mathematical formulation and definitions can be intimidating for beginners.

column1: * Identifying correct prior distribution can be very difficult in real life problems which are not based on careful experimental design.
* Solving complex models with Bayesian approach is still computationally expensive.
In contrast to a Frequentist approach
column2: the Bayesian approach allows researchers to think about events in experiments as dynamic phenomena whose probability figures can change and that change can be accounted for with new data that one receives continuously. Just like the examples presented above
column3: this has several flipsides of the same coin.

column2: Bayesian Inference can overall be understood as a deeply [[:Category:Inductive|inductive]] approach since any given dataset is only seen as a representation of the data it consists of. This has the clear benefit that a model based on a Bayesian approach is way more adaptable to changes in the dataset
column3: even if it is small. In addition
column4: the model can be subsequently updated if the dataset is growing over time. '''This makes modeling under dynamic and emerging conditions a truly superior approach if pursued through Bayes' theorem.''' In other words
column5: Bayesian statistics are better able to cope with changing condition in a continuous stream of data.

column1: This does however also represent a flip side of the Bayesian approach. After all
column2: many data sets follow a specific statistical [[Data distribution|distribution]]
column3: and this allows us to derive clear reasoning on why these data sets follow these distributions. Statistical distributions are often a key component of [[:Category:Deductive|deductive]] reasoning in the analysis and interpretation of statistical results
column4: something that is theoretically possible under Bayes' assumptions
column5: but the scientific community is certainly not very familiar with this line of thinking. This leads to yet another problem of Bayesian statistics: they became a growing hype over the last decades
column6: and many people are enthusiastic to use them
column7: but hardly anyone knows exactly why. Our culture is widely rigged towards a frequentist line of thinking
column8: and this seems to be easier to grasp for many people. In addition
column9: Bayesian approaches are way less implemented software-wise
column10: and also more intense concerning hardware demands.

column1: There is no doubt that Bayesian statistics surpass frequentists statistics in many aspects
column2: yet in the long run
column3: Bayesian statistics may be preferable for some situations and datasets
column4: while frequentists statistics are preferable under other circumstances. Especially for predictive modeling and small data problems
column5: Bayesian approaches should be preferred
column6: as well as for tough cases that defy the standard array of statistical distributions. Let us hope for a future where we surely know how to toss a coin. For more on this
column7: please refer to the entry on [[Non-equilibrium dynamics]].

column1: Bayesian methods have been central in a variety of domains where outcomes are probabilistic in nature; fields such as engineering
column2: medicine
column3: finance
column4: etc. heavily rely on Bayesian methods to make forecasts. Given that the computational resources have continued to get more capable and that the field of machine learning
column5: many methods of which also rely on Bayesian methods
column6: is getting more research interest
column7: one can predict that Bayesian methods will continue to be relevant in the future.

The Belbin Team Inventory is a '''role test for groups'''. The behavioral test developed by Meredith Belbin fosters effective teamwork and is based on personal questions that you answer online. As a result
column2: you receive an evaluation of your individual preferences regarding the following nine team roles: ''plants
column3: monitor evaluators
column4: specialists
column5: resource investigators
column6: co-ordinators
column7: team workers
column8: shapers
column9: implementers and completer-finishers''.

column2: diverse roles should be represented.''' Therefore
column3: it is recommended to do the test before forming groups. However
column4: existing groups can also use the test in order to gain a deeper understanding of [[Glossary|competencies]] and responsibilities. The ideal is of course a team in which all nine different roles are distributed. In reality
column5: however
column6: this is often not possible. If there are some roles that are not represented in your group
column7: you may want to talk about what skills you lack and how you would like to compensate them.

column1: '''Let's take a concrete example''' to show how the test allows groups to work more efficiently: Anna's seminar is planning a group work. As preparation
column2: all students do the Belbin test. Anna is assigned to the role called ''plant''. Based on the results of the whole seminar group
column3: teams are put together which have as many different roles as possible. Anna takes on the role of the ''plant'' in her group. Thus
column4: her team members know from the beginning that Anna is a very creative and open minded person and likes to think outside of the box. Therefore she takes over the creative tasks in the group and is available to everyone as a [[Glossary|brainstorming]] partner.

column1: '''There are some things to take care of:'''

column2: this method involves personal questions. Thus
column3: it is important to make sure that everyone feels comfortable in the process. Second
column4: the Belbin roles only refer to group work and therefore are not to be equated with character traits. And finally
column5: the roles should not be seen as fixed constructs. Team members can also take on different roles at the same time or change roles in the course of group work. The Belbin roles should rather be understood as a basis for an open discussion.

Bias and Critical Thinking;"'''Note:''' The German version of this entry can be found here: [[Bias and Critical Thinking (German)]]
'''Note:''' This entry revolves more generally around Bias in science. For more thoughts on Bias and its relation to statistics
column2: please refer to the entry on [[Bias in statistics]].

column1: '''In short:''' This entry discusses why science is never objective
column2: and what we can really know.

column1: The very concept of objective truth is fading out of the world."" - George Orwell
A bias is “the action of supporting or opposing a particular person or thing in an unfair way
column2: because of allowing personal opinions to influence your judgment” (Cambridge Dictionary). In other words
column3: bias clouds our judgment and often action in the sense that we act wrongly. We are all biased
column4: because we are individuals with individual experiences
column5: and are unconnected from other individuals and/or groups
column6: or at least think we are unconnected.

column1: Recognising bias in research is highly relevant
column2: because bias exposes the myth of objectivity of research and enables a better recognition and reflection of our flaws and errors. In addition
column3: one could add that understanding bias in science is relevant beyond the empirical
column4: since bias can also highlight flaws in our perceptions and actions as humans. To this end
column5: '''acknowledging bias is understanding the limitations of oneself.''' Prominent examples are gender bias and racial bias
column6: which are often rooted in our societies
column7: and can be deeply buried in our subconscious. To be critical researchers it is our responsibility to learn about the diverse biases we have
column8: yet it is [[Big problems for later|beyond this text]] to explore the subjective human bias we need to overcome. Just so much about the ethics of bias: many would argue that overcoming our biases requires the ability to learn and question our privileges. Within research we need to recognise that science has been severely and continuously biased against ethnic minorities
column9: women
column10: and many other groups. Institutional and systemic bias are part of the current reality of the system
column11: and we need to do our utmost to change this - there is a need for [[Glossary|debiasing]] science
column12: and our own actions. While it should not go unnoticed that institutions and systems did already change
column13: injustices and inequalities still exist. Most research is conducted in the global north
column14: posing a neo-colonialistic problem that we are far from solving. Much of academia is still far away from having a diverse understanding of people
column15: and systemic and institutional discrimination are parts of our daily reality. We are on the path of a very long journey
column16: and there is much to be done concerning bias in constructed institutions.

column2: let us shift our attention now to bias in empirical research. Here
column3: we show three different perspective in order to enable a more reflexive understanding of bias. The first is the understanding how different forms of biases relate to [[Design Criteria of Methods|design criteria]] of scientific methods. The second is the question which stage in the application of methods - data gathering
column4: data analysis
column5: and interpretation of results - is affected by which bias
column6: and how. Finally
column7: the third approach is to look at the three principal theories of Western philosophy
column8: namely reason
column9: social contract and utilitarianism - to try and dismantle which of the three can be related to which bias. Many methods are influenced by bias
column10: and recognising which bias affects which design criteria
column11: research stage and principal philosophical theory in the application of a method can help to make empirical research more reflexive.

column1: [[File:SchoolOfThought BiasesPoster A3-page-001.jpg|550px|thumb|center|'''An overview on biases'''. Source: [https://yourbias.is/ yourbias.is]]]
While [[:Category:Qualitative|qualitative research]] is often considered prone to many biases
column2: it is also often more reflexive in recognising its limitations. Many qualitative methods are defined by a strong subjective component - i.e. of the researcher - and a clear documentation can thus help to make an existing bias more transparent. Many [[:Category:Quantitative|quantitative approaches]] have a reflexive canon that focuses on specific biases relevant for a specific approach
column3: such as sampling bias or reporting bias. These are often less considered than in qualitative methods
column4: since quantitative methods are still – falsely - considered to be more objective. This is not true. While one could argue that the goal of reproducibility may lead to a better taming of a bias
column5: this is not necessarily so
column6: as the crisis in psychology clearly shows. Both quantitative and qualitative methods are potentially strongly affected by several cognitive biases
column7: as well as by bias in academia in general
column8: which includes for instance funding bias or the preference of open access articles. While all this is not surprising
column9: it is still all the much harder to solve.

column1: Another general differentiation can be made between [[:Category:Inductive|inductive]] and [[:Category:Deductive|deductive]] approaches. Many deductive approaches are affected by bias that is associated to sampling. Inductive approaches are more associated to bias during interpretation. Deductive approaches often build around designed experiments
column2: while the strongpoint of inductive approaches is being less bound by methodological designs
column3: which can also make bias more hidden and thus harder to detect. However
column4: this is why qualitative approaches often have an emphasis on a concise documentation.

column1: The connection between spatial scales and bias is rather straightforward
column2: since the [[:Category:Individual|individual]] focus is related to cognitive bias
column3: while [[:Category:System|system]] scales are more associated to prejudices
column4: bias in academia and statistical bias.

column1: While the impact of temporal bias is less explored
column2: forecast bias is a prominent example when it comes to [[:Category:Future|future predictions
column3: ]] and another error is applying our cultural views and values on [[:Category:Past|past]] humans
column4: which has yet to be clearly named as a bias.

column1: What can be clearly said about both spatial and temporal scales is that we are often irrationally biased towards very distant entities - in space or time - and even irrationally more than we should be. We are for instance inclined to reject the importance of a distant future scenario
column2: although it may widely follow the same odds to become a reality than a close future. For example
column3: almost everybody would like to win the lottery tomorrow rather than win the lottery in 20 years
column4: irrespective of your chances to live and see it happen
column5: or the longer time you may spend with your lottery prize for the (longer) time to come. Humans are most peculiar constructed beings
column6: and we are notorious to act irrationally. This is equally true for spatial distance. We may care irrationally more for people that are close to us as compared to people that are very distant
column7: even independent of joined experience (e.g with friends) or joined history (e.g. with family). Again
column8: this infers a bias which we can be aware of
column9: but which has to be named. No doubt the current social developments will increase our capacities to recognise our biases even more
column10: as all these phenomena also affect scientists.
