column2: analysing data and interpreting data ==

column1: The three steps of the application of a method are clearly worth investigating
column2: as it allows us to dismantle at which stage we may inflict a bias into our application of a method. Gathering data is strongly associated with cognitive bias
column3: yet also to statistical bias and partly even to some bias in academia. Bias associated to sampling can be linked to a subjective perspective as well as to systematic errors rooted in previous results. This can also affect the analysis of data
column4: yet here one has to highlight that quantitative methods are less affected by a bias through analysis than qualitative methods. This is not a normative judgement
column5: and can clearly be counter-measured by a sound documentation of the analytical steps. We should nevertheless not forget that there are even different assumptions about the steps of analysis in such an established field as statistics. Here
column6: different schools of thought constantly clash regarding the optimal approach of analysis
column7: sometimes even with different results. This exemplifies that methodological analysis can be quite normative
column8: underlining the need for a critical perspective. This is also the case in qualitative methods
column9: yet there it strongly depends on the specific methods
column10: as these methods are more diverse. Concerning the interpretation of scientific results
column11: the amount and diversity of biases is clearly the highest
column12: or in other words
column13: worst. While this is related to the cognition bias we have as individuals
column14: it is also related to prejudices
column15: bias in academia and statistical bias. Overall
column16: we need to recognise that some methods are less associated to certain biases because they are more established concerning the norms of their application
column17: while other methods are new and less tested by the academic community. When it comes to bias
column18: there can be at least a weak effect that safety - although not diversity - concerning methods comes in numbers. More and diverse methods may offer new insights on biases
column19: since one method may reveal a bias that another method cannot reveal. '''Methodological plurality may reduce bias.''' For a fully established method the understanding of its bias is often larger
column20: because the number of times it has been applied is larger. This is especially but not always true for the analysis step
column21: and in parts also for some methodological designs concerned with sampling. Clear documentation is however key to make bias more visible among the three stages.

column1: The last and by far most complex point is the root theories associated to bias. Reason
column2: social contract and utilitarianism are the three key theories of Western philosophy relevant for empiricism
column3: and all biases can be at least associated to one of these three foundational theories. Many cognitive bias are linked to reason or unreasonable behaviour. Much of bias relates to prejudices and society can be linked to the wide field of social contract. Lastly
column4: some bias is clearly associated with utilitarianism. Surprisingly
column5: utilitarianism is associated to a low amount of bias
column6: yet it should be noted that the problem of causality within economical analysis is still up for debate. Much of economic management is rooted in [[Causality and correlation|correlative]] understandings
column7: which are often mistaken for clear-cut causal relations. Psychology also clearly illustrates that investigating a bias is different from unconsciously inferring a bias into your research. '''Consciousness of bias is the basis for its recognition''': if you are not aware of bias
column8: you cannot take it into account regarding your knowledge production. While it thus seems not directly helpful to associate empirical research and its biases to the three general foundational theories of philosophy - reason
column9: social contract and utilitatrianism -
column10: we should still take this into account
column11: least of all at it leads us to one of the most important developments of the 20th century: Critical Theory.

column1: Out of the growing empiricism of the enlightenment there grew a concern which we came to call Critical Theory. At the heart of critical theory is the focus on critiquing and changing society as a whole
column2: in contrast to only observing or explaining it. Originating in Marx
column3: Critical Theory consists of a clear distancing from previous theories in philosophy - or associated with the social - that try to understand or explain. By embedding society in its historical context (Horkheimer) and by focussing on a continuous and interchanging critique (Benjamin) Critical Theory is a first and bold step towards a more holistic perspective in science. Remembering the Greeks and also some Eastern thinkers
column4: one could say it is the first step back to a holistic thinking. From a methodological perspective
column5: Critical Theory is radical because it seeks to distinguish itself not only from previously existing philosophy
column6: but more importantly from the widely dominating empiricism
column7: and its societal as well as scientific consequences. A Critical Theory should thus be explanatory
column8: practical and normative
column9: and what makes it more challenging
column10: it needs to be all these three things combined (Horkheimer). Through Habermas
column11: Critical Theory got an embedding in democracy
column12: yet with a critical view of what we could understand as globalisation and its complex realities. The reflexive [[Glossary|empowerment]] of the individual is as much as a clear goal as one would expect
column13: also because of the normative link to the political.

column1: '''Critical Theory is thus a vital step towards a wider integration of diverse philosophies
column2: ''' but also from a methodological standpoint it is essential since it allowed for the emergence of a true and holistic critique of everything empirical. While this may be valued as an attack
column3: is can also be interpreted as necessary step
column4: since the arrogance and the claim of truth in empiricism can be interpreted not only as a deep danger to methods. Popper does not offer a true solution to positivism
column5: and indeed he was very much hyped by many. His thought that the holy grail of knowledge can ultimately be never truly reached also generates certain problems. He can still be admired because he called for scientists to be radical
column6: while acknowledging that most scientists are not radical. In addition
column7: we could see it from a post-modernist perspective as a necessary step to prevent an influence of empiricism that might pose a threat to and by humankind itself
column8: may it be through nuclear destruction
column9: the unachievable and feeble goal of a growth economy (my wording)
column10: the naive and technocratic hoax of the eco modernists (also my wording) or any other [[Glossary|paradigm]] that is short-sighted or naive. In other words
column11: we look at the postmodern.

column1: Critical Theory to this end is now developing to connect to other facets of the discourse
column2: and some may argue that its focus onto the social science can be seen critical in itself
column3: or at least as a normative choice that is clearly anthropocentric
column4: has a problematic relationship with the empirical
column5: and has mixed relations with its diverse offspring that includes gender research
column6: critique of globalisation
column7: and many other normative domains that are increasingly explored today. Building on the three worlds of Popper (the physical world
column8: the mind world
column9: human knowledge)
column10: we should note another possibility
column11: that is Critical Realism. Roy Bhaskar proposed three ontological domains (''strata of knowledge''): the real (which is ''everything there is'')
column12: the actual (''everything we can grasp'')
column13: and the empirical (''everything we can observe''). During the last decade
column14: humankind unlocked ever more strata of knowledge
column15: hence much of the actual became empirical to us. We have to acknowledge that some strata of knowledge are hard to relate
column16: or may even be unrelatable
column17: which has consequences for our methodological understanding of the world. Some methods may unlock some strata of knowledge but not others. Some may be specific
column18: some vague. And some may only unlock new strata based on a novel combinations. What is most relevant to this end is however
column19: that we might look for causal links
column20: but need to be critical that new strata of knowledge may make them obsolete. Consequently
column21: there are no universal laws that we can thrive for
column22: but instead endless strata to explore.

column2: '''Critical Theory seems as an antidote to bias'''
column3: and some may argue Critical Realism even more so
column4: as it combines the criticality with a certain humbleness necessary when exploring the empirical and causal. The explanatory characteristic allowed by Critical Realism might be good enough for the pragmatist
column5: the practical may speak to the modern engagement of science with and for society
column6: and the normative is aware of – well - all things normative
column7: including the critical. Hence a door was opened to a new mode of science
column8: focussing on the situation and locatedness of research within the world. This was surely a head start with Kant
column9: who opened the globe to the world of methods. There is however a critical link in Habermas
column10: who highlighted the duality of the rational individual on a small scale and the role of global societies as part of the economy (Habermas 1987). This underlines a crucial link to the original three foundational theories in philosophy
column11: albeit in a dramatic and focused interpretation of modernity. Habermas himself was well aware of the tensions between these two approaches – the critical and the empirical -
column12: yet we owe it to Critical Theory and its continuations that a practical and reflexive knowledge production can be conducted within deeply normative systems such as modern democracies.

column1: Linking to the historical development of methods
column2: we can thus clearly claim that Critical Theory (and Critical Realism) opened a new domain or mode of thinking
column3: and its impact can be widely felt way beyond the social science and philosophy that it affected directly. However
column4: coming back to bias
column5: the answer to an almost universal rejection of empiricism will [[Big problems for later|not be followed here]]. Instead
column6: we need to come back to the three foundational theories of philosophy
column7: and need to acknowledge that reason
column8: social contract and utilitarianism are the foundation of the first empirical disciplines that are at their core normative (e.g. psychology
column9: social and political science
column10: and economics). Since bias can be partly related to these three theories
column11: and consequentially to specific empirical disciplines
column12: we need to recognise that there is an overarching methodological bias. This methodological bias has a signature rooted in specific design criteria
column13: which are in turn related to specific disciplines. Consequently
column14: this methodological bias is a disciplinary bias - even more so
column15: since methods may be shared among scientific disciplines
column16: but most disciplines claim either priority or superiority when it comes to the ownership of a method.

column1: The disciplinary bias of modern science thus creates a deeply normative methodological bias
column2: which some disciplines may try to take into account yet others clearly not. In other words
column3: the dogmatic selection of methods within disciplines has the potential to create deep flaws in empirical research
column4: and we need to be aware and reflexive about this. '''The largest bias concerning methods is the choice of methods per se.''' A critical perspective is thus not only of relevance from a perspective of societal responsibility
column5: but equally from a view on the empirical. Clear documentation and reproducibility of research are important but limited stepping stones in a critique of the methodological. This cannot replace a critical perspective
column6: but only amends it. Empirical knowledge will only look at parts - or strata according to Roy Bhaskar - of reality
column7: yet philosophy can offer a generalisable perspective or theory
column8: and Critical Theory
column9: Critical Realism as well as other current developments of philosophy can be seen as a thriving towards an integrated and holistic philosophy of science
column10: which may ultimately link to an overaching theory of ethics (Parfit). If the empirical and the critical inform us
column11: then both a philosophy of science and ethics may tell us how we may act based on our perceptions of reality.

column1: Bias in Interviews;"'''In short:''' This entry revolves around biases in Interview preparation and conduction. For more general insights on biases
column2: please refer to the entry on [[Bias and Critical Thinking]]. For more in Interview methodology in general
column3: please visit the [[Interviews]] page.

column1: A bias is “the action of supporting or opposing a particular person or thing in an unfair way
column2: because of allowing personal opinions to influence your judgment” (Cambridge Dictionary). You might know this already
column3: least from the entry on [[Bias and Critical Thinking]]. '''Researchers are humans
column4: and humans are always biased to some extent - therefore
column5: researchers are biased
column6: if they are aware of it or not.''' This understanding is rooted in our assumption that epistemological knowledge is subjective. It is however better to be aware of one's biases in order to be able to counteract them in one's research. So
column7: in this entry
column8: let us focus on the biases that influence your research that revolves around any form of Interviews. We will have a look at different biases
column9: and for which methods and situations they are especially relevant. For biases influencing the analysis of Interviews - which is the next step - please refer to [[Bias in Content Analysis]] and [[Bias in statistics]].

column2: Literature Research
column3: and Sampling ==

column1: In preparation to any form of Interview
column2: you may conduct a systematic literature review or some other form of literature-based theoretical preparation to be able to construct and conduct the Interviews. To this end
column3: you need to make a compromise between the broader literature that may be helpful to gain validity and follow common scientific norms when designing your study
column4: but also at more focused literature in order to have sufficient specificity regarding your interview questions. Here
column5: a '''Reporting / Publication Bias''' will influence your literature search
column6: which refers to the issue that [[Glossary|journals]] and researchers often only report specific types of information
column7: and leave out others. One of the main problem to this end is that most research is biased towards positive or dramatic results
column8: hence you will find few papers describing in detail on how many levels they struggled or failed. In addition
column9: journals often only publish what fits into its narrative
column10: making editors and journals the gatekeepers of science. This is not your fault - but you should be aware of it
column11: factor it into your theoretical assumptions
column12: and ideally try not contribute to these biases in the end by yourself.

column2: there is often a '''Full-Text-On-Net Bias'''
column3: which emerges from the limited access researchers may have to scientific journals and the fact that they thus often favor open access journals in the references. We are quite sure to have this bias here on this Wiki
column4: and you will also struggle with it. Open Access Journals are not necessarily worse than the ones you do not have access to - but by relying on them only
column5: you are missing out  from a large share of available research
column6: and you should try at least to get a hold of papers that are not accessible with one click.

column2: there are biases which is ultimately rooted in you as a researcher. There is the '''Academic Bias''' which highlights that researchers often let their beliefs and world views shape their research. Think about it: which topic are you investigating? Which assumptions are you making
column3: which hypotheses are you stating? Why do you do this research - is it purely because there is a need for it
column4: or do you maybe have a personal opinion or prejudice which you let guide your research design? We are all clouded by our subjective perspectives
column5: but you should question your research approach time after time to unveil such biases. These kinds of biases are especially relevant for rather deductive Interview approaches
column6: such as Surveys and Semi-structured Interviews.

column2: you might commit a '''Congruence Bias''' if you only test for their hypothesis directly but not for possible alternative hypotheses. There may be other explanations for a specific phenomenon
column3: and by limiting yourself to one perspective
column4: you are limiting your research results and the discourse around a given topic. A similar bias is the '''Confirmation Bias'''
column5: where researchers only confirm their expectations again and again by building on the same kind of design
column6: analysis or theories. You are not creating new or even novel knowledge by doing the same kind of research over and over. To find new solutions
column7: you should broaden your theoretical and methodological perspective. These biases are also mostly relevant for deductive designs.

column1: In the creation of a sample for any kind of Interview
column2: '''Sampling / Selection Bias''' is a most common problem. We might only sample data that we are aware of
column3: because we are aware of it
column4: thereby ignoring other data points that lack our recognition. In other words
column5: we are anchoring our very design and sampling already in our previous knowledge. This
column6: again
column7: will likely not create new knowledge. We might also choose an incorrect survey mode (digital
column8: face-to-face) for the intended population
column9: or simply address the wrong population overall. Examples are the exclusion of people who only have a limited Internet access when conducting an online survey or asking teachers instead of their students about an issue that students can provide more accurate information on. Biased samples are “unrepresentative of the intended population and hurt generalizability claims about inferences drawn” (Bhattacherjee
column11: p. 81) from it.

column1: It is difficult to create a representative sample for quantitative studies
column2: and to know which characteristics of research subjects (e.g. individuals) are of relevance to ensure representativity. The sampling strategy can heavily influence the gathered data
column3: with convenience sampling potentially inhibiting more diverse insights. Especially for more qualitative Interviews with smaller samples
column4: the selection of Interviewees needs to be well-reasoned and will shape the results.

column1: The '''non-response bias''' is relevant in Survey research
column2: and refers to the response rate of the targeted sample which – if too low – can negatively affect the validity as well as generalizability of the results. Here
column3: it can be important to investigate why the response rate is low in order to assess the impact this might have on the results or to eliminate the causes. (Bhattacherjee
column4: 2012) Besides
column5: the data can be weighted to account for the non-response and approximate “some known characteristics of the population” (Gideon

column1: While conducting an observation as part of our sampling you might have fallen under the '''Observer Bias:''' you (dis)favor one or more groups because of one reason or another
column2: thereby influencing your sample and thus your data subconsciously. Then of course
column3: there are '''Bribery
column4: Favoritism
column5: or Lobbying
column6: ''' which may influence your research design and your sampling strategy if you engage with them. We hope that it is more relevant for you to be aware of these when reading existing literature
column7: and to question who wrote something under the influence of whom
column8: and why. Lastly
column9: there are systemic problems
column10: which we can all only hope to counteract as much as possible
column11: but which are deeply entrenched into our societal and academic system. These are '''Racism
column12: Sexism
column13: Classism
column14: Lookism
column15: ''' and any bias that refers to us (sub)consciously assuming positive or negative traits
column16: or just any preconceived ideas
column17: about specific groups of people. Humans have the unfortunate tendency to create groups as constructs
column18: and our worldview - among many other things - creates a bias in this creation of constructs. This can limit the diversity of our sample
column19: even if we attempt stratified sampling. It is not always easy to detect these biases in your own work
column20: but we urge you to pay attention to them

column23: and you should consider their influence when reading publications from other researchers.

column2: we should mention the '''Dunning Kruger Effect'''. You might have heard of it - it refers to individuals that overestimate their competence and abilities
column3: and who think that they are the best at something

column6: and you should also be aware of this

column1: A bias is “the action of supporting or opposing a particular person or thing in an unfair way
column2: because of allowing personal opinions to influence your judgment”. In other words
column3: biases cloud our judgment and often action in the sense that we act wrong. [https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/basics/bias We are all biased]
column4: because we are individuals with individual experience
column5: and are unconnected from other individuals and/or groups
column6: or at least think we are unconnected.

column1: [[File:Francis Bacon Idols of the Mind.jpg|thumb|left|'''[https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Why_statistics_matters#The_scientific_method Francis Bacon]''' was also aware of biases
column2: categorised them as the four '''[https://fs.blog/2016/05/francis-bacon-four-idols-mind/ Idols of the Mind]''' (idola mentis).]]
mistakes happen and the world becomes more unfair or less objective. We are all biased. Therefore
column3: we need to learn of [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rf-fIpB4D50 consciously reflect our biases] if at all possible. Biases are abundantly investigated and discussed both in science and society. However
column4: we  only start to understand the complex mechanism behind the diverse sets of biases
column5: and how to cope with the different biases. In [https://statanalytica.com/blog/bias-in-statistics/ statistics]
column6: there are some biases that are more important than others. In addition
column7: statistics are a method that is often used to quantify many biases. Statistics are thus prone to bias
column8: but at the same time can be helpful to investigate biases. This is rooted in the fact that any statistics can only be as good as the person that applies it. If you have a strong bias in your worldview
column9: statistics may amplify this
column10: but statistics can also help you to understand some biases better.

column1: The number of biases becomes almost uncountable
column2: highlighting an increasing recognition of where we are biased and how this can be potentially explained. Let us look at the different steps that we have in a study that builds on the use of statistics to focus on the biases that are relevant here. Let us start with an overview on biases.

column1: There are a lot of biases. Within statistics '''sample bias''' and '''[https://data36.com/statistical-bias-types-explained/ selection bias]''' are among the most common problems that occur. Starting with the sampling of data we might have a distorted view of reality through selection bias: we might only sample data because we are aware of it
column2: thereby ignoring other data points that lack our recognition. In other words
column3: we are anchoring our very design and sampling already in our previous knowledge. Another prominent bias features the diversity of groups. We tend to create groups as constructs
column4: and our worldview - among many other things - creates a bias in this creation of constructs. One bias that I just have to mention because I think it's so fantastic is the '''[https://www.britannica.com/science/Dunning-Kruger-effect Dunning Kruger effect]'''. This bias highlights the tendency of some unskilled individuals to overestimate their competence and abilities. Dunning Kruger folks tend to think they are the best when they are actually the worst. Why do I highlight this while talking about statistics? I witnessed quite some people that already destroyed their dataset with their initial sample design
column5: however they consider themselves among the greatest statisticians of all time and advertised their design as the crowning achievement of our civilisation. While conducting an observation as part of our sampling we might have fallen under the '''observer bias'''
column6: thereby influencing our data subconsciously for instance by favoring one group in our sampling. We might have already observed a misrepresentation of the total sample through a '''selection bias'''
column7: where we favored certain groups in our selection of our sample
column8: and not by how we observed them. Even [[Glossary|hypothesis]] building might be influenced by a '''[https://psychology.wikia.org/wiki/Congruence_bias congruence bias]'''
column9: if researchers only test for their hypothesis directly but not for possible alternative hypotheses. To this end you can also add a '''confirmation bias''' for good measure
column10: where researchers only confirm their expectations again and again and again by building on the same statistical design and analysis.

column1: [[Glossary|Scientist]]s are notoriously prone to another bias
column2: the '''[https://www.investopedia.com/terms/h/hindsight-bias.asp hindsight bias]'''
column3: which highlights the omnipotence of scientists in general
column4: who are quite sure of themselves when it comes to analyzing their data.  Furthermore the '''[https://www.hbs.edu/faculty/Pages/item.aspx?num=41121 IKEA effect]''' might underline how brilliant our analysis is
column5: since we designed the whole study by ourselves. While we conduct an experiment we might have an '''observer expectancy effect''' thereby influencing our study by manipulating the experiment to generate the effects we were expecting after all. The analysis of data is often much like an '''automation bias'''. Most researchers rely on the same statistics again and again. But not to worry: we might have had a selection bias both in our sampling as well as our selective analysis of the data after all
column6: which may be corrected our results without us knowing that thanks to the '''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Positivity_effect positivity effect]'''. Through framing we might overestimate single samples within our dataset
column7: and often our initial design as well as the final interpretation of our analysis can be explained by such framing
column8: where we rely on single anecdotes or unrepresentative parts of our data.

column1: [https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/science-choice/201504/what-is-confirmation-bias Confirmation bias] is definitely the first bias that comes to mind.
But if our results are radical and new they might be ignored or rejected
column2: due to the '''""[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ignaz_Semmelweis Semmelweis reflex]""'''
column3: which states that new discoveries are always wrong. Based on our results

column1: Scientist often conduct a '''self-serving bias''' by interpreting their analysis in a positivistic sense

column1: So now that we heard some examples about biases
column2: what does this all mean? First of all there is ample research about biases. There is a huge knowledge database from the scientific community that can help us understand where a bias might occur and [https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/in-practice/201508/6-ways-overcome-your-biases-good how it affects us]. Psychology
column3: sociology and cultural studies are to name when it comes to the systematic investigation of biases in people. But there is more. A new forefront of researchers that try to investigate novel
column4: non-violent and reflexive settings where we can try to to minimize our biases. New group interaction formats emerge
column5: and research settings are slowly changing to a bold attempt of a research community that is more aware of their biases. Often these movements are at the outer fringe margins of science
column6: and mix up with new age flavors and self-help driven improvers. Still
column7: it is quite notable that such changes are slowly starting to emerge. Never before was more knowledge available to more people at greater speed. We might want to take it slow these days and focus on what connects us instead of becoming all accelerated but widely biased individuals.

column2: it can of course be interesting to investigate a bias as researchers. Biases can help us as they open a world of normativity in our brains. It is quite fascinating to build on theory e.g. from psychology and focus on one specific bias in order to understand how we can tackle these issues. There are other systematic approaches we can deal with biases. Let us break it down into several steps. First of all there are biases that tinker with our worldview. These biases are relevant as science can build on theories in order to derive hypotheses or generate specific research questions. Therefore it is necessary as scientists to be aware of the fact that we have a limited worldview and that for cultural gender or societal reasons among many other factors our view of the world is biased. This is in itself not problematic as long as we are aware of the fact our scientific knowledge production process is limited to our hemisphere
column3: our culture or specific aspects
column4: like our scientific discipline. Bias can help us to understand our limitations and errors in judgment as scientists better. We may never be best
column5: but we may thrive for it.

column1: Reporting biases in studies that utilise statistics can be roughly sorted into two groups: Biases that are at least indirectly related to statistics
column2: and biases that are widely unrelated to statistics as these are correctly utilised in the study.

column1: The first groups is the one we focus on in this text
column2: and the second group is what we basically need to focus on and become hopefully more conscious about during the rest of our life.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-06-08 um 17.26.32.png|450px|thumb|Gerrymandering is a practice from US politics and a common example for a geographical bias or segregation.]]
As part of the first group we can consider that whenever we report everything we made in the study in a transparent way
column2: then even if our result are influenced by some sort of bias
column3: then at least our results should be reproducible or the very least
column4: other researchers may be able to understand that we conducted our study in a way that inferred a bias. This happens all the time
column5: and it is often a matter of experience whether we are aware of a bias. Still
column6: some simple basics can also be taught regarding statistics that may help us to report information to understand a bias
column7: and then there are even some ways to minimise a bias.

column1: [https://catalogofbias.org/biases/wrong-sample-size-bias/ Sample size] as part of the design
column2: as well as sample selection are the first steps to minimise sampling bias. [https://www.khanacademy.org/math/ap-statistics/gathering-data-ap/sampling-methods/v/techniques-for-random-sampling-and-avoiding-bias Stratified designs] may ensure a more representative sampling
column3: as we often tend to make deliberate samples that inflict a certain bias. Being very systematic in your sampling may thus help to tame a sampling bias. Another example of a bias associated to sampling is a [https://diverseeducation.com/article/126527/ geographical bias]. Things that are close to each other are more similar than things that are distant from each other. The same can be true for people regarding some of their characteristics. Segregation is a complex phenomenon that would lead to a biased sample if we want to interview people in a city and then only interview participants from one neighbourhood. [https://www.britannica.com/topic/gerrymandering Gerrymandering] is an example of a utilisation of this knowledge
column4: often to influence election results or conduct other feeble minded [https://www.wnycstudios.org/podcasts/radiolabmoreperfect/episodes/whos-gerry-and-why-he-so-bad-drawing-maps manipulation of administrative borders]. Hence before we sample we need to ask ourselves how we might conduct a sample bias.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-06-08 um 17.29.33.png|450px|thumb|Open source is used frequently recently but one should also be aware that just because the data is accessible for free it is not free of bias or mistakes.]]
The second bias in statistics is the analysis bias. Here
column2: we should be aware that it can be beneficial to contact a statistician in order to inquiry which model would be best for our data. We need to apply the most parsimonious model
column3: yet also should report all results in a most unbiased and thus most reproducible fashion. Quite often one is able to publish details about the analysis in the online appendix of a paper. While this makes the work often more reproducible
column4: I am sorry to report that in the past it also led to some colleagues utilising the data and analysing it only partly or wrong
column5: hence effectively making a scientific misconduct. While this happens rarely
column6: I highlight it for the simple reason to raise awareness that with all the open source hype we currently face
column7: we did not think this through
column8: I believe. Quite often people use data then without being aware of the context
column9: escalating to wrong analysis and even bad science. Establishing standards for open source is a continuous challenge
column10: yet there are good examples out there to highlight that we are on a good way. We need to find reporting schemes that enable reproducibility
column11: which might then enable us detect bias in the future
column12: when more data
column13: better analysis or new concepts might have become available
column14: thereby evolving past results further. Reporting all necessary information on the result of a software or a statistical test or model is one essential step towards this goal. How good is a model fit? How significant is the reuse? How complex is the model? All these values are inevitable to put the results into a broader context of the statistics canon.

column1: Some disciplines tend to add disclaimers to the interruption of results
column2: and in some fields of science it is considered as good scientific practice to write about the [https://wordvice.com/how-to-present-study-limitations-and-alternatives/ limitations of the study]. While this is in theory a good idea
column3: these fields of science devalue their studies by adding such a section generically. I would argue
column4: that if such a section is added every time
column5: it should be added never
column6: since it is totally generic. Everyone with a firm understanding of statistics as well as theory of science knows that studies help to approximate facts
column7: and future insights might lead to different and more often to more precise results. More data might reveal even different patterns
column8: and everyone experienced in statistics knows how much trust can be put into results that are borderline significant
column9: or that are based in small or unrepresentative samples. This should be highlighted if it is really an issues
column10: which I consider to be good scientific practice. If it is highlighted every time
column11: people will not pay the necessary attention to it in the long run.

Hence I urge you to be transparent in showing your design. Be experienced in the analysis you choose

column1: {| class=""wikitable mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"" style=""width: 100%; background-color: white""
! Some thoughts on practical ethics #5 - Why optimism?
While any ""why"" question can easily be dismissed by a simple ""why not?""
column2: times have been hard for many
column3: and a general and individual pessimism is haunting many people these days. Indeed in my surrounding I recognise in many the focus on the general decreasing state of everything
column4: the pending apocalypse
column5: and the end of the world as we know it. I feel to be in a very privileged position indeed
column6: because I will remain a radical optimist until the end. Here are my arguments.

column1: Let us begin with the arguments against pessimism.
'''Pessimism has never made anything better.''' While this seems like a very easy line of argumentation
column2: it is actually not. Many people argue that pessimism can make people fearful
column3: and such a nudge will help people to recognise to change their behaviour. There is much research that nudges can actually change the behaviour of people. I would dispute this on two terms. How long does it work? What is the prize of a nudge? If a nudge would be catalytic
column4: then it could turn the behaviour of a person completely around. While this is potentially true
column5: there is less evidence of people changing their behaviour completely and long term because of a nudge. This is to some end empirically unfair
column6: because long term research is hard to get funded. Still
column7: I would dispute that there are many nudges that work on many people long term. On the other hand are the negative aspects of nudges only sparsely explored
column8: and this links to the second point. We could agree to utilise nudges if we think that the end justifies the means. Under this assumption
column9: nudges are not a means to an end
column10: but are a prize we choose to pay to achieve a certain end. My main criticism of this would be that nudges make people less free. Nudges can be interpreted as a way to manipulate people
column11: which will ultimately make them less happy. One could attempt to nudge people
column12: and then afterwards reveal the nudge
column13: yet it would be questionable if people would evaluate the act of nudging to be positive. I believe that many people would indeed evaluate the nudging to be not positive. Even worse
column14: what would happen if people would find out by themselves that they were nudged? This would build a growing mistrust within society
column15: and underlines how problematic it would be to upscale the strategy of nudging. Equally bad experience has been made with advertising
column16: showing how people perceive being manipulated by the media. For this reason
column17: the argument that pessimism helps us to ""wake people up"" is not a convincing argument. Many would argue that we do not need to do that
column18: and that the mere ""facts"" are grim enough. There is however a very important difference between presenting information as we perceive it
column19: and presenting it in a pessimistic narrative. I think this difference is extremely important
column20: and many people should try to restrict themselves to the information how they perceive it
column21: and also engage in exchange with others
column22: which may change our perceptions. We manipulate others through pessimistic views. We can equally manipulate others though optimistic worldviews. This brings us to the next point.

column1: Now let us continue with the arguments for pessimism. If we chose to have a pessimistic worldview
column2: then this would be clearly our normative choice. However many people have a pessimistic worldview which is rooted in their origin story or other emotional experiences. '''While it is understandable to have a grim worldview rooted in your biography
column3: it is still no justification for a pessimistic worldview
column4: but a mere explanation.''' After all
column5: pessimistic worldview influence others
column6: and especially people of power have to consider how they want to influence others. If our convincing of the powerful is rooted in fear
column7: then history will not judge kindly on us
column8: because it equally did not do so before. More importantly
column9: the world will surely not become a better place if people are motivated by their fears. While hence pessimism and negative experiences that are part of our identity are well understandable
column10: it is questionable if we need to pass this on to others. There are many positive examples where such endeavours led to a change for the better
column11: yet there are equally negative examples. I believe that if we would start counting if the optimistic or the pessimistic prevail
column12: it is already a lost cause.

column1: Other arguments for pessimism are of more existential nature. Many people have a pessimistic worldview because of all the ""bad"" in the world. I would again argue that this is an emotional argument
column2: and often a a biographical argument. In addition is it clear that people are not bad
column3: but actions are. '''Hence we may judge actions of people
column4: but I would clearly refrain from judging people.''' The world is not a fairytale
column5: where the morals are clear cut. We should never hold negative experience against anyone
column6: but instead try to help people to overcome their negative experiences if at all possible. It will otherwise be difficult to help people overcome their emotional arguments. Derek Parfit argued that the history of humankind could be like an unhappy childhood
column7: yet the overall life might have been -on the whole- worth it. He continued to argue that we cannot know how future people are going to be. This brings us to the next point- arguments for radical optimism.

column1: Radical optimism is just like any form of pessimism or optimism a normative choice. '''Martha Nussbaum rightly stated that hope is a practice
column2: and a choice.''' The question would be then
column3: if we can make this choice
column4: and if we should. It is clear that this normative choice is an effort
column5: and it is unclear who can actively make this choice
column6: and who may merely not have the capability to make that choice. Having a positive outlook in life is nothing people can always choose
column7: but depends on many diverse factors. People who have a generally negative outlook in life may try to seek professionally trained and educated helpers or programs
column8: if they want to seek help. The world of psychiatry has luckily developed more and diverse approaches over the last decades for people in need
column9: yet there is still much to be learned on how to help people with a generally negative outlook in life. Personally
column10: everybody who struggles has my deepest compassion. This is obviously very important
column11: not only for people who struggle
column12: but also for society as a whole. There are other people who may have the capacity within them to gain a general positive outlook. However
column13: shifting our eduction system further and enabling more parts of the educational aspects of society towards enabling a general positive outlook in people is a key challenge for the 21st century. If we would seize this opportunity

column1: Bootstrap Method;"'''In short:''' The bootstrap method is a resampling technique used to estimate statistics on a population by resampling a dataset with replacement.
The bootstrap was introduced by Brad Efron in the late 1970s. It is a computer-intensive method for approximating the sampling distribution of any statistic derived from a random sample.
A fundamental problem in statistics is assessing the variability of an estimate derived from sample data.
To test a [[Glossary|hypothesis]] researchers need to sample from population. For each sample results can be different
column2: therefore to estimate population properties researchers need to take many samples. This set of possible study results represents the sampling distribution. With it one can assess the variability in the real-sample estimate (e.g.
column3: attach a margin of error to it)
column4: and rigorously address questions.

column2: that it is costly to repeat studies
column3: and the set of possible estimates is never more than hypothetical. The solution to this dilemma
column4: before the widespread availability of fast computing
column5: was to derive the sampling distribution mathematically. This is easy to do for simple estimates such as the sample proportion
column6: but not so easy for more complicated statistics.

column1: Fast computing helps to resolve the problem and the main method is Efron’s bootstrap.

column2: the bootstrap is a computerbased technique that uses the core concept of random sampling from a set of numbers and thereby estimates the sampling distribution of virtually any statistic computed from the sample. The only way it differs from the hypothetical resampling is that the repeated samples are not drawn from the population
column3: but rather from the sample itself because the population is not accessible.[1]

column1: Bootstrapping is a type of statistical resampling applied to observed data. This method can be used to determine the sampling distribution of a summary statistic (mean
column2: median
column3: and standard deviation) or relationship (correlation and regression coefficient) when these sampling distributions are extremely difficult to obtain analytically.

column1: There are two main ways in which the bootstrap technique can be applied. In the ""parametric"" method
column2: a knowledge of the data’s distributional form (e.g. Gaussian and exponential) is required. When it is available
column3: such distributional information contributes to greater precision. In the more common ""nonparametric"" version of bootstrapping
column4: no distributional assumption is needed.

column1: Bootstrap methods are useful when inference is to be based on a complex procedure for which theoretical results are unavailable or not useful for the sample sizes met in practice
column2: where a standard model is suspect
column3: but it is unclear with what to replace it
column4: or where a ""quick and dirty"" answer is required. They can also be used to verify the usefulness of standard approximations for parametric models
column5: and to improve them if they seem to give inadequate inferences.

column1: Bootstrapping involves drawing a series of random samples from the original sample with replacement
column2: a large number of times. The statistic or relationship of interest is then calculated for each of the bootstrap samples. The resulting distribution of the calculated values then provides an estimate of the sampling distribution of the statistic or relationship of interest.

column1: Notice that the replacement allows the same value to be included multiple times in the same sample. This is why you can create many different samples.
This is the basic algorithm for resampling with replacement:
#Select an observation from the original sample randomly
#Add this observation to the new sample
#Repeat steps 1 and 2 till the new sample size is equal to the original.
The resulting sample of estimations often leads to a Gaussian distribution. And a confidence interval can be calculated to bound the estimator.

column2: such as that of mean and standard deviation

column1: A Bubble plot is a graphical representation of multivariate data table. One can think of it as an XY scatter plot with two additional variables. X and Y variables are numeric
column2: and two additional variables
column3: either continuous or categorical
column4: can be represented by the bubble colour and bubble size.

column1: This wiki entry will elaborate what a bubble plot is
column2: how to implement such a plot and how to customize your own bubble plot.

column1: A bubble plot is able to present up to four variables
column2: without actually being a four dimensional plot. We can first start with trying to plot three variables. For that the input data should be a triplet (Note: the data should be quantitative and non-categorical). One variable is represented by the x-axis
column3: another one by the y-axis and the third by the size of the data points. Therefore the data points differ in size which makes the plot look like an accumulation of bubbles. We will then incorporate the fourth variable as a color later in our example.

column1: A lot of bubble plot examples can be seen online in the Gapminder data tool [https://www.gapminder.org/tools/#$chart-type=bubbles&url=v1 Bubbles]. Check it out

Case studies and Natural experiments;"'''Note:''' This entry is a brief introduction to natural experiments. For more details on other types of experiments
column2: please refer to the entries on [[Experiments]]

column2: the impossibility of replication is a problem in the case of the Easter Island.]]

column1: Out of a diverse rooting in discussions about [[Glossary|complexity]]
column2: [https://learningforsustainability.net/systems-thinking/ system thinking] and the need to understand specific contexts more deeply
column3: the classic experimental setting did at some point become more and more challenged. What emerged out of the development of [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Interactions#The_field_experiment field experiments] was an almost exact opposite trend considering the reduction of complexity. What do we learn from singular cases? How do we deal with cases that are of pronounced importance
column4: yet cannot be replicated? And what can be inferred from the design of such case studies? A famous example from ethnographic studies is the [http://www.eisp.org/818/ Easter Island]. Why did the people there channel much of their resources into building gigantic statues
column5: thereby bringing their society to the brink of collapse? While this is a surely intriguing question
column6: there are no replicates of the Easter Islands. This is at a first glance a very specific and singular problem
column7: yet it is often considered to be an important example on how unsustainable behaviour led to a collapse of a while civilisation. Such settings are referred to as [https://www.britannica.com/science/natural-experiment Natural Experiments]. From a certain perspective
column8: our whole planet is a Natural Experiment
column9: and it is also from a statistical perspective a problem that we do not have any replicates
column10: besides other ramifications and unclarity that derives such single case studies
column11: which are however often increasingly relevant on a smaller scale as well. With a rise in qualitative methods both in diversity and abundance
column12: and an urge for understanding even [[Glossary|complex systems]] and cases
column13: there is clearly a demand for the integration of knowledge from Natural Experiments. '''From a statistical point of view
column14: such cases are difficult and challenging due to a lack of being reproducible
column15: yet the knowledge can still be relevant
column16: plausible and valid.''' To this end
column17: I proclaim the concept of the niche in order to illustrate and conceptualise how single cases can still contribute to the production and canon of knowledge.

column1: For example the [https://academic.oup.com/rcfs/article/4/2/155/1555737#113865691 financial crisis from 2007]
column2: where many [[Glossary|patterns]] where comparable to previous crisis
column3: but other factors were different. Hence this crisis is comparable to many previous factors and patterns regarding some layers of information
column4: but also novel and not transferable regarding other dynamics. We did however understand based on the single case of this financial crisis that certain constructs in our financial systems are corrupt if not broken. The contribution to develop the financial world further is hence undeniable
column5: even so far that many people agree that the changes that were being made are certainly not enough.

column1: '''Another prominent example of a single case or phenomena is the Covid pandemic that emerges further while I am writing these lines.''' While much was learned from previous pandemics
column2: this pandemic is different
column3: evolves different
column4: and creates different ramifications. The impact of our societies and the opportunity to learn from this pandemic is however undeniable. While classical experiments evolve knowledge like pawns in a chess game
column5: moving forward step by step
column6: a crisis such as the Covid pandemic is more like the horse in a chess game
column7: jumping over larger gaps
column8: being less predictable
column9: and certainly harder to master. The evolution of knowledge in an interconnected world often demands a rather singular approach as a starting point. This is especially important in normative sciences
column10: where for instance in conservation biology many researchers approach solutions through singular case studies. Hence the solution orientated agenda of sustainability science emerged to take this into account
column11: and further.

column2: [https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/0963662505050791 real world experiments] are the latest development in the diversification of the arena of experiments. These types of experiments are currently widely explored in the literature
column3: yet I do not recognise a coherent understanding of what real-world experiments are to date in the available literature. These experiments can however be seen as a continuation of the trend of natural experiments
column4: where a solution orientated agenda tries to generate one or several interventions
column5: the effects of which are tested often within singular cases
column6: but the evaluation criteria are clear before the study was conducted. Most studies to date have defined this with vigour; nevertheless
column7: the development of real-world experiments is only starting to emerge. For more info
column8: please refer to the entry on [[Living Labs & Real World Laboratories]].

column1: [[File:Lueneburg 2030.jpg|800px|thumb|center|'''A wonderful example for a bunch of real world experiments is the project Lüneburg 2030+.''' This map provides an overview of the different experiments.]]
Single case studies demand a clear documentation
column2: and by clear I do not mean an exhausting documentation. Where many disciplines relying on single case studies often fail is the right balance between the details and the general information
column3: or in other words
column4: getting the Occam’s razor into the documentation.

column1: In [https://www.pnas.org/content/108/49/19449.short sustainability science] we did not learn to date which information is vital
column2: and which one trivial. This is vastly different in medicine
column3: where much of the canon of knowledge has been consolidated into a system that allows for a clear presentation of singular case studies. Take for instance the New England Journal of Medicine
column4: one of the most prestigious scientific [[Glossary|journals]] on this planet. Regularily
column5: this journal publishes short case studies that provide either fundamentally new problems or even solutions that are recognised as important new knowledge in the respective field. Medicine is able to and actually demands such a presentation of knowledge
column6: since much of the previous knowledge is compiled into a system that allows for a clear integration of new knowledge. In sustainability science such an established system is still widely lacking. People talk of complexity and the importance of recognising the individual case
column7: yet I would argue that the world of medicine is equally complex. When people think that this is wrong
column8: I think they are wrong. I consider the complexity of a singular individual and the world as such as being comparable
column9: or at least equally complex.

column1: Sustainability science shall thus realize that making cases comparable is the key to coherent knowledge
column2: and ultimately a more systematic approach to new knowledge. Statistics will certainly not be the only contribution to this end
column3: but it is quite certain that it will contribute to a holistic understanding.

column1: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ztc7o0NzFrE Chess games] have certain openings. Most opening are known
column2: and while some are famous
column3: others are more obscure. Every chess player knows however the main 4-5 opening moves
column4: since they determine the continuation of the game. Around the 8-12 moves however
column5: something remarkable happens. We leave the range of known chess games
column6: and enter a game that has probably never been played on this planet. It is a completely new game
column7: and there are billions and billions of possibilities. This all then  boils quite often down to fewer and fewer pieces
column8: and if then two players are almost equally good
column9: we might enter the realms of endgames. Endgames can be calculated
column10: and here people that are good in thinking some moves ahead
column11: have a higher chance of winning. However
column12: in between the opening game and the endgame happens something that never happened before
column13: a new game
column14: which many consider to be complex. Here
column15: a friend of mine taught me that this is indeed not complex
column16: but instead builds on experience. He introduced me to the concept of board awareness. Ten thousand of games led in his head to a level of experience where when he would look at a middle game
column17: his brain would almost instinctively interpret the board into hot zones and cold zones. Building on previous experience he would recognise the constellation and could derive actions and possible moves
column18: and especially recognise which areas are prosperous for development through strategic moves
column19: and which ones are endangered and ought to be defended. Experience builds reduction in complexity.

column1: ====2. Look for mechanics you know from statistics====

Statistics offer a certain perspective on the world. It makes a difference whether I count something or construct it into another [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Data_formats data format]. Many patterns follow a [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Causality#Is_the_world_linear.3F linear trend]
column2: yet some few may not. Variables can be grouped. When looking at a single case we can look beyond the complexities by looking at the case through the lens of knowledge we have from statistics. While many people argue that this creates a flawed picture
column3: it might as well offer a more orderly view on the case. When working on a single case
column4: we can look at cause and effect
column5: we may look for predictive variables
column6: and we may consider interactions between these. Many singular cases are rich and diverse
column7: but also structured. We need to peel our way through the outer layer and understand the inner working of what we are looking at. Statistics is not only a method
column8: but also a specific perspective. If we get versatile in statistics
column9: it might help us to see something that we otherwise cannot see. As one of my first professors at University put it: “If you know more
column10: you can understand more”. Consider statistics as your perspective on a single case. Practice this perspective
column11: learn to see things through this lens.

column2: yet be suspicious====

column1: What if single cases are not complex but simple? Many single case studies are very simple. And even the more complicated
column2: some may have an inner working or a narrative. When looking at single case studies
column3: we ought to remember that there can be a [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Causality causal connection] in the world
column4: so there might be some in our case studies as well. Finding similarities between two things that have an effect on something else
column5: may be worthwhile if you consider attracting a diverse set of costumers. Therefore I suggest that the supposably complexity of single cases should not repel us but instead energise and motivate us to find reason and causality within the case. Of course we may not know if there is such a thing as true causality at work
column6: but based on previous cases and careful observation we may still infer new knowledge. Deciding that a case is complex does not help if we cannot say what is complex about it. To this end
column7: complexity became a buzzword that is often used in a sense of something being not understandable. To me
column8: it sometimes feels as if it is part of the zeitgeist to call something complex. Natural experiments should show us the value of single case studies
column9: the value of understanding
column10: and the value of creating new knowledge. I think it is our choice whether we want to seize this opportunity
column11: or not.

column1: [[File:Caspar David Friedrich - Der Wanderer über dem Nebelmeer.jpg|thumb|right|Although the ""Wander über dem Nebelmeer"" does not literally stand on the shoulders of giants
column2: the painting of Caspar David Friedrich is a good visualisation of the metaphor.]]

even not cases on islands. While some cases can be novel in their characteristics - take wicked problems for instance -; every case may contain components that are known from previous cases. While wicked problems are new in the combination of building blocks
column3: the building blocks themselves - i.e. parts of the problem - are maybe not new. The more you stand on the shoulders of giants
column4: the further you can see. We need to realize that science is build on failure and iteration. Only by knowing about previous failures but also successes
column5: and only by committing to the canon of knowledge
column6: can we contribute and create new knowledge.

column1: ==Natural experiments and statistics - a rough guide==
Several layers of information are to be considered when linking statistics to natural experiments. Contextualising natural experiments can be structured into at least 4 steps.
1) '''How is the case connected and embedded in the global context?'''
What are connections to other systems
column2: where are dependencies
column3: and where are gaps and missing links? A lot of information is available on a global scale
column4: and it is worthwhile embedding a case into the global information available. This may allow us to specify the setting of the case
column5: and to allow inference about how the results can be superimposed onto other systems. We hence acknowledge that this contextualisation is place based
column6: and places have boundaries and borders. While it is way beyond this text to discuss this issue

column1: '''Causality is one of the most misused and misunderstood concepts in statistics.''' All the while it is at the heart of the fact that all statistics are normative. While many things can be causally linked
column2: other things are not causally linked. The problem is that we dearly want certain things to be causally linked
column3: while we want other things not to be causally linked. This confusion has many roots
column4: and spans across such untameable arenas such as faith
column5: psychology
column6: culture
column7: social constructs and so on. Causality can be everything that is good about statistics
column8: and it can be equally everything that is wrong about statistics. To put it in other words
column9: it can be everything that is great about us humans
column10: but it can be equally the root cause of everything that is wrong with us.

column1: What is attractive about causality? People search for explanations
column2: and this constant search is probably one of the building blocks of our civilisation. Humans look for reasons to explain phenomena and [[Glossary|patterns]]
column3: often with the goal of prediction. If I understood a causal relation
column4: I may be able to know more about the future
column5: cashing in on being either prepared for this future
column6: or at least being able to react properly.

column1: The problem with causality is that different branches of science as well as different streams of philosophy have different explanations of causality
column2: and there exists an exciting diversity of theories about causality. Let us approach the topic systematically.

column1: ==== The high and low road of causality====
Let's take the first extreme case
column2: building on the theory that storks bring the babies. Obviously this is not true. Creating a causal link between these two is clearly a mistake. Now lets take the other extreme case
column3: you fall down a flight of stairs
column4: and in the fall break your leg. There is however some form of causal link between these two actions
column5: that is falling down the stairs caused you to break your leg. However
column6: this already demands a certain level of abstraction
column7: including the acceptance that it was you who did fall down the stairs
column8: you twisting your leg or hitting a stair with enough force
column9: you not being too weak to withstand the impact etc. There is
column10: hence
column11: a very detailed chain of events happening between you starting to lose your balance
column12: and you breaking your leg. Our mind simplifies this into “because I fell down the stairs
column13: I broke my leg”. Obviously
column14: we do not blame the person who built the stairs
column15: and we do not blame our parents for bringing us into this world
column16: where we then broke our leg. These things are not causally linked.

column2: imagine now that the construction worker did not construct the stairs the proper way
column3: and that one stair is slightly higher than the other stairs. We now claim that it is the fault of the construction worker. However
column4: how much higher does this one stair need to be so that we blame not ourselves
column5: but the construction worker? Do you get the point?

column1: '''Causality is a construction that is happening in our mind.''' We create an abstract view of the world
column2: and in this abstract view we come of with a version of reality that is simplified enough to explain for instance future events
column3: but it is not too simple
column4: since this would not allow us to explain anything specific or any smaller groups of events.

column3: and this is worth noticing. People today often think that the world is non-linear. Regime shifts
column4: disasters and crisis are thought to be prominent examples. I would argue
column5: that even these shifts follow linear patterns
column6: though on a smaller temporal scale. Take the last financial crisis. A lot was building up towards this crisis
column7: yet the collapse that happened in one day followed a linear pattern
column8: if only a strongly exponential one. Many supposably non-linear shifts are indeed linear
column9: they just happen very quickly.

column1: [[File:IslandTheoryBook.jpg|thumb|left|The book The Theory of Island Biogeography by MacArthur and Wilson tells you a lot about the relationship between island size and number of species.]]
Linear patterns describe something like a natural law. Within a certain reasonable data section
column2: you can often observe that one phenomena increases if another phenomena increases
column3: and this relation follows a linear pattern. If you make the oven more hot
column4: your veggies in there will be done quicker. However
column5: this linearity only works within a certain reasonable section of the data. It would be possible to put the oven on 100 °C and the veggies would cook much slower than at 150 °C. However
column6: this does not mean that a very long time at -30 °C in the freezer would boil your veggies in the long run as well.

column1: [[File:Linearity Ebola.png|thumb|right|This graph points out until which point the outbreak of the Ebola virus followed a linear pattern and at which point it increased exponentially.]]
[[File:WaterPhaseHeatDiagram.png|thumb|right|On this picture you can see an example for non-linearity. The graph shows you the phase changes of water with increasing temperature.]]
Another prominent example is the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Theory_of_Island_Biogeography Island Theory] from MacArthur and Wilson. They counted species on islands
column2: and found out that
column3: the larger islands are
column4: the more species they host. While this relation has a lot of complex underpinnings
column5: it is -on a logarithmic scale- totally linear. Larger islands contain more species
column6: with a clearly mathematical beauty.

column1: Phenomena that you can count are often linear on a log scale. Among coffee drinkers most coffee drinkers drink 1-2 cups per day
column2: but few drink 10
column3: which is probably good. Counting cup consumption per day in coffee drinker follows a log-linear distribution. The same hold for infections within an outbreak of a contagious disease. The Western African Ebola crisis was an incredibly complex and tragic event
column4: but when we investigated the early increase in cases
column5: the distribution is exponentially increasing -in this case-
column6: and this increase follows an almost cruel linear pattern.

column2: there are some truly non-linear shifts
column3: such as frost. Water is at -1 °C fundamentally different than at +1°C. This is a clear change governed by the laws of physics
column4: yet such non-linear shifts are rare in my experience. If they occur
column5: they are highly experimentally reproducible
column6: and can be explained by some fundamental underlying law. Therefore
column7: I would refrain from describing the complexity and wickedness of the modern world and its patterns and processes as non-linear. We are just not bright enough to understand the linearity in the data yet. I would advise you to seek linearity
column8: if only logarithmic or exponential one.

More details on Causality in cience can be found in the entry on [[Causality]]. More on Regressions can be found here: [[Regression Analysis]].
'''Correlations can tell us whether two variables are related.''' A correlation does not tell us however what this correlation means. This is important to note
column2: as there are many correlations being calculated
column3: but it is up to us to interpret these relations.

column1: It is potentially within our normative capacity to derive [[Experiments and Hypothesis Testing|hypotheses]]
column2: but it can also be powerful to not derive hypotheses and have a purely [[:Category:Inductive|inductive]] approach to a correlation. We live in a world of big data
column3: and increasingly so. There is a wealth of information out there
column4: and it is literally growing by the minute. While the [[History of Methods|Enlightenment and then the Modernity]] built a world of science based on the power of hypothesis
column5: this science was also limited. We know today that the powerful step of building a hypothesis offers only a part of the picture
column6: and powerful inventions and progress came from induction. Much progress in science was based on [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inductive_reasoning#History inductive approaches]. Consider [https://explorable.com/history-of-antibiotics antibiotics]
column7: whose discovery was a mere accident.

column1: With the predictive power of correlations and the rise of of [[Machine Learning|machine learning]] and the associated
column2: much more complex approaches
column3: a new world dawned upon us. Today
column4: predictions are based on simple correlations and the recognition of [[Glossary|power]] patterns in the wealth of data we face. Although much of the actual mathematics are much more complicated
column5: [https://www.repricerexpress.com/amazons-algorithm-a9/ suggestions of prominent online shops] on what you may want to buy next are - in principle - sophisticated elaborations of correlations. We do not understand why certain people that buy one thing buy also another thing
column6: but promiting this relation increases sales. Of course the world is more complicated
column7: and once more these models cannot luckily explain everything. As long as my [https://medium.com/s/story/spotifys-discover-weekly-how-machine-learning-finds-your-new-music-19a41ab76efe music service suggests me to listen to] Oasis - the worst insult to me - we are safe from the total prediction of the machines.

column2: with predictive power once more comes great responsibility
column3: and we shall see how correlations and their predictive power will allow us to derive more theories based on our inductive perspective on data. Much is to be learned through the digitalisation of data
column4: but it is still up to us to interpret correlations. This will be very hard to teach to a machine
column5: hence it is our responsibility to interpret data analysis through reasoning.

column1: Propelled through the general development of science during the Enlightenment
column2: numbers started piling up. The increasing technological possibilities to measure more and more information are slow to store this information
column3: and people started wondering whether these numbers could lead to something. The increasing numbers had diverse sources
column4: some were from science
column5: such as [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Least_squares#The_method Astronomy] or other branches of [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regression_toward_the_mean#History natural sciences]. Other prominent sources of numbers were from engineering
column6: and even other from economics
column7: such as [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bookkeeping#History double bookkeeping]. It was thanks to the tandem efforts of [https://www.britannica.com/biography/Adrien-Marie-Legendre Adrien-Marie Legendre] and [https://www.britannica.com/biography/Carl-Friedrich-Gauss Carl Friedrich Gauss] that mathematics offered the first approach to relate one line of data with another - the methods of least squares.

column1: '''How is one continuous variable related to another?''' Pandora's box was opened
column2: and questions started to emerge. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Econometrics Economists] were the first who utilised [[Regression Analysis|regression analysis]] at a larger scale
column3: relating all sorts of economical and social indicators with each other
column4: building an ever more complex controlling
column5: management and maybe even understanding of statistical relations. A regression implies a causal link between two continuous variables
column6: which makes it different from a correlation
column7: where two variables are related
column8: but not necessarily causally linked. (For more on regressions
column9: please refer to the entry on [[Regression Analysis]]. The [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/gdp.asp Gross domestic product] (GDP) became for quite some time kind of the [https://www.nature.com/news/development-time-to-leave-gdp-behind-1.14499 favorite] toy for many economists
column10: and growth became a core goal of many analyses to inform policy. What people basically did is ask themselves how one variable is related to another variable.
