There are some core questions related to the application and reading of correlations. These can be of interest whenever you have the correlation coefficient at hand - for example
column2: in a statistical software - or when you see a correlation plot.

column1: '''1) Is the relationship between two variables positive or negative?''' If one variable increases
column2: and the other one increases
column3: too
column4: we have  a positive (""+"") correlation. This is also true if both variables decrease. For instance
column5: being taller leads to a significant increase in [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3534609/ body weight]. On the other hand
column6: if one variable increases
column7: and the other decreases
column8: the correlation is negative (""-""): for example
column9: the relationship between 'pizza eaten' and 'pizza left' is negative. The more pizza slices are eaten
column10: the fewer slices are still there. This direction of the relationship tells you a lot about how two variables might be logically connected. The normative value of a positive or negative relation typically has strong implications
column11: especially if both directions are theoretically possible. Therefore it is vital to be able to interpret the direction of a correlative relationship.

column1: '''2) Is the correlation coefficient small or large?''' It can range from -1 to +1
column2: and is an important measure when we evaluate the strength of a statistical relationship. Data points may scatter widely in a [[Correlation_Plots#Scatter_Plot|scatter plot
column3: ]] or there may be a rather linear relationship - and everything in between. An example for a perfect positive correlation (with a correlation coefficient ''r'' of +1) is the relationship between temperature in [[To_Rule_And_To_Measure#Celsius_vs_Fahrenheit_vs_Kelvin|Celsius and Fahrenheit]]. This should not be surprising
column4: since Fahrenheit is defined as 32 + 1.8° C. Therefore
column5: their relationship is perfectly linear
column6: which results in such a strong correlation coefficient. We can thus say that 100% of the variation in temperature in Fahrenheit is explained by the temperature in Celsius.

column2: you might encounter data of two variables that is scattered all the way in a scatter plot and you cannot find a significant relationship. The correlation coefficient ''r'' might be around 0.1
column3: or 0.2. Here
column4: you can assume that there is no strong relationship between these two variables
column5: and that one variable does not explain the other one.

column1: The stronger the correlation coefficient of a relation is
column2: the more may these relations matter
column3: some may argue. If the points are distributed like stars in the sky
column4: then the relationship is probably not significant and interesting. Of course this is not entirely generalisable
column5: but it is definitely true that a neutral relation only tells you
column6: that the relation does not matter. At the same time
column7: even weaker relations may give important initial insights into the data
column8: and if two variables show any kind of relation
column9: it is good to know the strength. By practising to quickly grasp the strength of a correlation
column10: you become really fast in understanding relationships in data. Having this kind of skill is essential for anyone interested in approximating facts through quantitative data.

column1: '''3) What does the relationship between two variables explain?'''
This is already an advanced skill
column2: and is rather related to regression analysis. So if you have looked at the strength of a correlation
column3: and its direction
column4: you are good to go generally. But sometimes
column5: these measures change in different parts of the data.

column2: let us have a look at the example of the percentage of people working in [https://ourworldindata.org/employment-in-agriculture?source=post_page--------------------------- Agriculture] within individual countries. Across the world
column3: people at a low income (<5000 Dollar/year) have a high variability in terms of agricultural employment:  half of the population of the Chad work in agriculture
column4: while in Zimbabwe it is only 10 %. However
column5: at an income above 15000 Dollar/year
column6: there is hardly any variance in the percentage of people that work in agriculture: it is always very low. If you plotted this
column7: you would see that the data points are rather broadly spread in the lower x-values (with x as the income)
column8: but are more linearly spread in the higher income areas (= x values). This has reasons
column9: and there are probably one or several variables that explain this variability. Maybe there are other factors that have a stronger influence on the percentage of farmers in lower income groups than for higher incomes
column10: where the income is a good predictor.

column1: A correlation analysis helps us identify such variances in the data relationship
column2: and we should look at correlation coefficients and the direction of the relationship for different parts of the data. We often have a stronger relation across parts of the dataset
column3: and a weaker relation across other parts of the dataset. These differences are important
column4: as they hint at underlying influencing variables or factors that we did not understand yet.

column1: '''Causality is one of the most misused and misunderstood concepts in statistics.''' All the while
column2: it is at the heart of the fact that all statistics are normative. While many things can be causally linked
column3: many are not. The problem is that we dearly want certain things to be causally linked
column4: while we want other things not to be causally linked. This confusion has many roots
column5: and spans across such untameable arenas such as faith
column6: psychology
column7: culture
column8: social constructs and so on. Causality can be everything that is good about statistics
column9: and it can be equally everything that is wrong about statistics. To put it in other words: it can be everything that is great about us humans
column10: but it can be equally the root cause of everything that is wrong with us.

column1: What is attractive about causality? People search for explanations
column2: and this constant search is probably one of the building blocks of our civilisation. Humans look for reasons to explain phenomena and patterns
column3: often with the goal of prediction. If I understood a causal relation
column4: I may be able to know more about the future
column5: cashing in on being either prepared for this future
column6: or at least being able to react properly.

column1: The problem with causality is that different branches of science as well as different streams of philosophy have different explanations of causality
column2: and there exists an exciting diversity of theories about causality. Let us approach the topic systematically.

column1: ==== The high and the low road of causality ====

Let's take the first extreme case: the theory that storks bring the babies. Obviously this is not true. Creating a causal link between these two is obviously a mistake. Now lets take the other extreme case
column2: you fall down a flight of stairs
column3: and in the fall break your leg. There is obviously some form of causal link between these two actions
column4: that is falling down the stairs caused you to break your leg. However
column5: this already demands a certain level of abstraction
column6: including the acceptance that it was you who did fall down the stairs
column7: you twisting your leg or hitting a stair with enough force
column8: you not being too weak to withstand the impact etc. There is
column9: hence
column10: a very detailed chain of events happening between you starting to lose your balance
column11: and you breaking your leg. Our mind simplifies this into “because I fell down the stairs
column12: I broke my leg”. Obviously
column13: we do not blame the person who built the stairs
column14: and we do not blame our parents for bringing us into this world
column15: where we then broke our leg. These things are not causally linked.

column2: imagine now that the construction worker did not construct the stairs the proper way
column3: and that one stair is slightly higher than the other stairs. We now claim that it is the fault of the construction worker. However
column4: how much higher does this one stair need to be so that we blame not ourselves
column5: but the construction worker? You get the point.

column1: '''Causality is a construction that is happening in our mind.''' We create an abstract view of the world
column2: and in this abstract view we come up with a version of reality that is simplified enough to explain
column3: for instance
column4: future events
column5: but it is not too simple
column6: since this would not allow us to explain anything specific or any smaller groups of events.

column1: [[File:860-header-explainer-correlationchart.jpg|500px|thumb|left|'''Correlations can be deceitful'''. Source: [http://www.tylervigen.com/spurious-correlations Spurious Correlations]]]
Causality is hence an abstraction that follows [[Why_statistics_matters#Occam.27s_razor|''Occam's Razor'']]. And since we all have our own version of Occam's Razor in our head
column2: we often disagree when is comes to causality. this is merely related to the fact that everything dissolves under analysis. If we analyse any link between to events then the causal link can also be dissolved
column3: or can become irrelevant. Ultimately
column4: causality is a choice.

column1: Take the example of [https://sciencebasedmedicine.org/evidence-in-medicine-correlation-and-causation/ medical studies] where most studies build on a correlative design
column2: testing how
column3: for instance
column4: taking Ibuprofen may help against the common cold. If I have a headache
column5: and I take Ibuprofen
column6: in most cases it may help me. But do I understand how it helps me? I may understand some parts of it
column7: but I do not really understand it on a cellular level. There is again a certain level of abstraction.

column1: What is now most relevant for causality is the mere fact that one thing can be explained by another thing. We do not need to understand all the nitty-gritty details of everything
column2: and indeed this would be ultimately be very hard on us. Instead
column3: we need to understand whether taking one thing away prevents the other thing from happening. If I did not walk down the stairs
column4: I would have not broken my leg.

column1: Ever since Aristotle and his question ”What is its nature?”
column2: we are nagged by the nitty-grittiness of true causality or deep causality. I propose that there is a '''high road of causality'''
column3: and a '''low road of causality'''. The high road allows us to explain everything on how two things or phenomena are linked. While I reject this high road
column4: many schools of thought consider it to be very relevant. I for myself prefer the low road of causality: May one thing or phenomena be causally linked to another thing or phenomena; if I take one away
column5: will the other not happen? This automatically means that I have to make compromises of how much I understand about the world.

column1: it is clear we do not need to understand everything. Our ancestors did not truly understand why walking out in the dark without a torch and a weapon - or better even in a larger group - might result in death in an area with many predators. Just knowing that staying in at night would keep them safe was good enough for them. It is also good enough for me.
'''Let us try to understand causal relations step by step.''' To this end
column2: we may briefly differentiate two types of causal relations.

column1: Statistical correlations imply causality if one variable (A) is actively driven by a variable (B). If B is taken away or changed
column2: A changes as well or becomes non-existent. This relation is among the most abundantly known relation in statistics
column3: but it has certain problems. First and foremost
column4: two variables may be causally linked but the relation may be weak. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23775705 Zinc] may certainly help against the common cold
column5: but it is not guaranteed that Zinc will cure us. It is a weak causal correlation.

column2: a causal relation of variable A and B may interact with a variable C
column3: and further variables D
column4: E
column5: F etc. In this case
column6: many people speak of complex relations. Complex relations can be causal
column7: but they are still complex
column8: and this [[Agency
column9: Complexity and Emergence|complexity may confuse people]]. Lastly
column10: statistical relations may be inflicted by biases
column11: sample size restrictions
column12: and many other challenges statistics face. These challenges are known
column13: increasingly investigated
column14: but often not solvable.

column1: ==== Structure the chaos: Normativity and plausibility ====
[[File:Black swan.jpg|thumb|right|This is probably one of the most famous examples for a universal theory
column2: that can be disproven by one contradictory case. Are all swans white? It may seem trivial
column3: but the black swan is representative for [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XlFywEtLZ9w Karl Popper's Falsificationism]
column4: an important principle of scientific work.]]

column1: Building on the thought that our mind wanders to find causal relations
column2: and then having the scientific experiment as a powerful tool
column3: scientists started deriving and revising theories that were based on the experimental setups. Sometimes it was the other way around
column4: as many theories were only later proven by observation or scientific experiments. Having causality explained by scientific theories created a combination that led to physical laws
column5: societal paradigms and psychological models
column6: among many other things.

column1: Plausibility started its reign as a key criterion of modern science. Plausibility basically means that relations can only be causal if the relations are not only probable but also [https://justinhohn.typepad.com/blog/2013/01/milton-friedmans-thermostat-analogy.html reasonable]. Statistics takes care of the probability. But it is the human mind that derives reason out of data
column2: making causality a deeply normative act. Counterfactual theories may later disprove our causality
column3: which is why it was raised that we cannot know any truth
column4: but we can approximate it. Our assumptions may still be falsified later.

column2: so good. It is worth noting that Aristoteles had some interesting metaphysical approaches to causality
column3: as do Buddhists and Hindus. We will [[Big problems for later|ignore these here]] for the sake of simplicity.

column2: but a necessary condition for causality is temporal order''' (Neumann 2014
column3: pp.74-78). Temporal causal chains can be defined as relations where an effect has a cause. An event A may directly follow an action B. In other words
column4: A is caused by B. Quite often
column5: we think that we see such causal relations rooted in a temporal chain. The complex debate on [https://www.cdc.gov/vaccinesafety/concerns/autism.html vaccinations and autism] can be seen as such an example. The opponents of vaccinations think that the autism was caused by vaccination
column6: while medical doctors argue that the onset of autism merely happened at the same time as the vaccinations are being made as part of the necessary protection of our society. The temporal relation is in this case seen as a mere coincidence. Many such temporal relations are hence assumed
column7: but our mind often deceives us
column8: as we want to get fooled. We want order in the chaos
column9: and for many people causality is bliss. History often tries to find causalities
column10: yet as it was once claimed
column11: history is written by the victorious
column12: meaning it is subjective. Having a model that explains your reality is what many search for today and having some sort of a temporal causal chain seems to be one of the cravings of many human minds. Scientific experiments were invented to test such causalities
column13: and human society evolved. Today it seems next to impossible to not know about gravity - in a sense we all know
column14: yes - but the first physical experiments helped us prove the point. Hence did the scientific experiment help us to explore temporal causality
column15: and [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3835968/ medical trails] can be seen as one of the highest propelled continuation of these.

column1: We may however build on Hume
column2: who wrote in his treatise of human nature the three criteria mentioned below. Paraphrasing his words
column3: causality is contiguous in space and time
column4: the cause is prior to the effect
column5: and there is a constant union between cause and effect. It is worthwhile to consider the other criteria he mentioned.

column1: 1) Hume claims that the same cause always produces the same effect. In statistics
column2: this pinpoints at the criterion of reproducibility
column3: which is one of the backbones of the scientific experiment. This may be seen difficult in times of single case studies
column4: but all the while highlights that the value of such studies is clearly relevant
column5: but limited according to this criterion.

column2: if several objects create the same effect
column3: then there must be a uniting criterion among them causing the effect. A good example for this is weights on a balance. Several weights can be added up to have the same -counterbalancing- effect. One would need to pile a high number of feathers to get the same effect as
column4: let’s say
column5: 50 kg of weight (and it would be regrettable for the birds). Again
column6: this is highly relevant for modern science
column7: as looking for united criteria among is a key goal in the amounts of data we often analyse these days.

column1: 3) If two objects have a different effect
column2: there must be a reason that explains the difference. This third assumption of Hume is a direct consequence from the second one. What unites factors can be important
column3: but equally important can be what differentiates factors. This is often the reason why we think there is a causal link between two things
column4: when there clearly is not. Imagine some evil person gives you decaf coffee
column5: while you are used to caffeine. The effect might be severe
column6: and it is clear that the caffeine in the coffee that wakes you up differentiates this coffee from the decaffeinated one.

column2: causality is a mess in our brains. '''We are wrong about causality more often than we think
column3: our brain is hardwired to find connections and often gets fooled into assuming causality.''' Equally
column4: we often want to neglect causality
column5: when it is clearly a fact. We are thus wrong quite often. In case of doubt
column6: stick with [https://statisticsbyjim.com/basics/causation/ Hume] and the criteria mentioned above. Relying on these when analysing correlations
column7: ultimately
column8: demands practice.

column1: '''2) Ist der Korrelationskoeffizient klein oder groß?''' Der Korrelationskoeffizient kann zwischen -1 und +1 liegen und ist ein wichtiges Maß für die Bewertung der Stärke einer statistischen Beziehung. column2: Why & When ==

column1: A check-in at the beginning of each meeting
column2: workshop or seminar can help teams and groups to get a better understanding of each other's energy level
column3: personal environment or the status of work. You can basically use it with every group of people
column4: even your clique or your family. The check-out helps to summarize decisions
column5: distributed tasks and supports evaluating the atmosphere in the group. Both the check-in and check-out can become a habit for each meeting.

column1: * create understanding of each other's personal situation
* enhance empathy for the team members
* get updated on each other's work and tasks

column2: different questions can be answered which have to be defined by the moderator of the meeting. Usually
column3: at the beginning of the meeting
column4: as soon as everybody has arrived and settled
column5: the group sits in a circle. Then
column6: the moderator asks each person to share how they are feeling
column7: if something bothers them and invites them to answer a question such as ""The most inspiring thing I learned this week was..."". You should set a rough time limit to each answer
column8: e.g. three minutes
column9: to keep the check-in short. If somebody is rambling too long
column10: as a moderator
column11: you should remind them of the time limit.

column2: you can also modify the question according to the situation. Sometimes
column3: it's useful to ask what everybody has learned or what their take-home message is from the meeting. You can also ask whether there are any unanswered questions and how the energy level is. Further
column4: you can ask for a quick feedback on the meeting or the session.

column1: Both the check-in and check-out should not last longer than 20-30 minutes. If your group is too big
column2: you can split it up in smaller groups.

column1: * no commenting on each other's statements → comparable to the flashlight method
* you can go clockwise and if somebody does not want to say something
column2: it's also fine

column1: * check-ins and check-outs are a routine
column2: not a one time thing - try to establish it as the normal process of starting and finishing a meeting

column1: * this time belongs to personal insights and is not meant to complete tasks or make arrangements

It may happen that - especially in meetings in which the members do not know each other well - the members might not want to share their very personal stories or want to be honest about their current feelings. It can help that you as a moderator start the round and share a private insight if you like. Additionally
column2: you should mention that the members should only share what they feel comfortable with.

column1: Teams that work together for a longer time
column2: already know each other and had developed problems and arguments before
column3: might raise them in a check-in. Hence
column4: as a moderator of established teams
column5: always plan some back-up time to discuss challenges or arguments in the team.

column2: Why & When ==

column1: <big>'''Why'''</big>: Using correct citation is crucial for academic writing and the basis of all scholarly work. Therefore it is most important that you understand and apply the following rules. Whenever you research a topic
column2: you will read other people’s books and articles and use the information found there for your own interpretation of the subject. Therefore you need to make sure to respect other’s intellectual property and do not violate '''copyright''' laws. Moreover
column3: your statements become more credible if you can show that someone else has had similar results.

column1: <big>'''When'''</big>: Citations and references need to be used in all your academic works
column2: whether these are essays
column3: term papers
column4: presentations
column5: or your final thesis. Whenever you quote or paraphrase from another person’s text
column6: speech or medium
column7: you want to hint at a certain publication or passage
column8: or when you have taken information from another text you must credit your source.

column1: * Make the sources we used for our own work visible and trackable
column2: and our statements verifiable.

column1: * Give credit to the original author or creator of a text.

One of the difficulties of correct citation is that there are innumerable ways of doing it. Nearly every academic discipline and country has their own preference. The most important aspect here is that you '''stay consistent''' and do not mix several methods within one text (you can always ask your lecturers for their preferred style).
There are two prominent ways of referencing you can use within your text:
This first method has gained more popularity in the last years
column2: especially in international contexts
column3: but also in Germany. By using this method the reader can keep his attention on the main text without having to skip to the bottom of the page for references. Here
column4: a short reference in brackets is placed at the end of the respective sentence or paragraph
column5: usually in front of any punctuation marks.

column2: Page) → (Copeland 1997
Page) → (Copeland Money

column1: Using footnotes for any references is especially common in the traditional humanities. They are numbered and placed at the bottom of the page which is useful if you want to keep your text neat and easy to read. Creating a footnote is quite easy
column2: most writing programmes do it for you.

column1: → Make sure to end every footnote with a full stop!

At the end of your paper you need to compile all of your cited sources in a bibliography. This list should be ordered alphabetically using the authors’ surnames. Here you give the full bibliographic information of your source containing at least author
column2: title
column3: year and place of publication.

column1: In the bibliography we differentiate between monographies
column2: journal articles
column3: articles within anthologies
column4: websites etc. Each of these categories has to be referenced differently. You can find detailed instructions in the sources listed below
column5: but here are some examples:

'''In short:''' Citizen Science is the conduct of research by members of the general public
column2: usually in collaboration with
column3: or under the direction of
column4: professional researchers.

column1: [[File:ResultVisualisationCitizenScience.png|500px|thumb|right|Relative abundance of eastern phoebe (''Sayornis phoebe'') in the US between 2004 and 2007
column2: based on data gathered by observations of amateur birders. Source: Bonney et al. 2009 p.982]]

column1: The [[Glossary|concept]] Citizen Science publicly gained prominence by two different approaches. The most prominent approach in environmental science to this day goes back to the '''US ornithologist Rick Bonney''' from Cornell University who
column2: starting in the late 1990s
column3: framed Citizen Science as a form of public [[Glossary|participation]] in scientific activity
column4: especially in the form of data gathering done by amateurs (1
column5: 2). This understanding is rooted in the 1960s when Cornell researchers already included volunteers in ornithological research (1
column6: 5). Even before
column7: one could argue that the difference between scientists and amateurs was blurry
column8: as naturalists - for instance in the Victorian age - were often not trained scientists yet a vital source of data (8).

column1: A second famous approach is based on the work of '''UK sociologist Alan Irwin''' who
column2: in 1995 (see Key Publications)
column3: framed Citizen Science as ""developing concepts of scientific citizenship which foregrounds the necessity of opening up science and science policy processes to the public"" (Riesch & Potter 2014
column5: focusing on the role of citizens as stakeholders in informed [[Glossary|decision-making]] processes.

column1: [[File:Citizen Science.png|400px|thumb|right|'''SCOPUS hits per year for Citizen Science until 2019.''' Search term: 'Citizen Science' in Title
column2: Abstract
column3: Keywords. Source: own.]]

column1: Partly due to these different backgrounds of the concept
column2: “[t]he meaning of ""citizen science” is in fact not very clear
column3: particularly when formulated on a science policy level
column4: where it is often defined too broadly without making the distinctions that scientists work with” (Kullenberg & Kasperowski 2016
column5: p.2). Terms such as 'participatory science'
column6: 'civic science' or 'community-based monitoring' may also be understood as a form of Citizen Science (1).

column2: Citizen Science is frequently used in biology
column3: conservation and ecology (topics include e.g. birds
column4: insects or water quality)
column5: followed by geographic information research and epidemiology (1
column8: 8). It has also found other fields
column9: including Astronomy
column10: Agriculture
column11: Arts and Education (see for example [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6410884/ this agricultural study] and [https://www.aavso.org/variable-stars-main this participatory approach] in Astronomy.) Its presence in scientific publications has increased significantly since the early 2000s
column12: which may be attributed to an increased usage of digital platforms for citizen engagement (1).

column1: ''Annotation:'' While the following explanation of Citizen Science focuses on Rick Bonney's approach of amateurs gathering data
column2: the differences between the two predominant understandings will be addressed below.
Citizen Science describes '''a form of data gathering that is done by amateur enthusiasts''' in the field
column3: in cities or gardens. Observations are noted in data forms based on instructions in pre-determined protocols stating the how
column4: when and where of data gathering (4). The data are transmitted online to the researchers and can often be accessed in form of visualisations (e.g. maps) by the contributors afterwards. The intended outcome of a Citizen Science project can range from increasing general data availability and scientific outreach to solving specific local problems or promoting public interest and knowledge on a certain topic. (7)

column1: Citizen Science's unique characteristic is that it enables researchers to sample data across different scales - from regional up to global spatial scales - as well as repeated measurements spanning several years. This allows a scaling of data based on contribution of many participants
column2: allowing a broader and more holistic perspective that would be not possible solemnly on the workload of the researchers.  Bird-watching may take place in gardens of a smaller area for one season while the method can likewise integrate geographic information upscaled to a global scale over several years. Often
column3: the collected data is numeric
column4: e.g. number of birds counted
column5: and at which date. This allows to accumulate larger observations about bird migration.

column2: Alan Irwin states that ""Citizen Science tries to find a way through the usual monolithic representations of ‘science’ and the ‘public"" (Irwin 1995
column3: p.ix). To him
column4: ""such matters as policy are not merely 'applications' of academic analysis nor are they simply 'implementations' - instead the whole question of how interventions are made is a major issue in itself."" (Irwin 1995
column5: p.xi). His conceptualization addresses how public needs and knowledge can be implemented into scientific processes in order to open up the barriers between the two sub-systems. To him
column6: ''Citizen Science'' means ""a form of science developed and enacted by citizens themselves"" (Irwin 1995
column7: p.xi).

column2: on the other hand
column3: describes ''Citizen Science'' as a method that ""enlists the public in collecting large quantities of data across an array of habitats and locations over long spans of time"" (Bonney et al. 2009
column4: p.977). This understanding has a stronger methodological perspective on the approach as opposed to Irwin whose definition also refers to science policy.

column2: ''Citizen Science'' may be seen both as a form of data gathering conducted by amateurs but also concerns the analysis of data and
column3: even more so
column4: its interpretation and application in direct contact with public actors. Wiggins & Crowston (2011) summarize this diversity within the concept by defining ''Citizen Science'' as ""a form of research collaboration involving members of the public in scientific research projects to address real-world problems."" (Wiggins & Crowston 2011
column5: p.1). This combines the diverging perspectives and allows for a broader understanding of the concept's essentials. In a way
column6: the [[Glossary|emergence]] of [[Glossary|transdisciplinary]] research may be seen as a concession to Irwin: while ''Citizen Science'' is today predominantly applied in Bonney's way
column7: Irwin's idea of involving public actors into scientific processes is highly relevant - simply in a different methodological area.

column1: * Citizen Science allows for access to data that would otherwise be inaccessible (covering long periods of time and wide spatial arrays) (6
* There is an educational quality to Citizen Science: participants not only learn about the respective subjects but also about scientific work (see Normativity).
* The research questions addressed through Citizen Science (in form of amateur data gathering) must take into consideration that most contributors will not be able to assess complex data. Instead
column2: simple counting or observations can be expected (4). ""Projects demanding high skill levels from participants can be successfully developed
column3: but they require significant participant training and support materials such as training videos"" (Bonney et al. 2009

column1: * In the case of bird watching (but also similar data types)
column2: errors may result from participants confusing bird species. This must be addressed through additional information material for the amateur scientists. (4)

column1: * Citizen science always demands some sort of supra-infrastructure or project
column2: since the data cannot be analysed by the participating citizens.

column1: ==== Complexity of the method and the analysed data ====
* The research questions addressed through Citizen Science (in form of amateur data gathering) must take into consideration that most contributors will not be able to assess complex data. Instead

column1: ==== Everything normative related to this method ====
* A strong [[Bias and Critical Thinking|bias]] may be imposed on the data due to divergent understandings of the data gathering procedure in the respective amateur individuals
column2: diminishing the objectivity
column3: reliability & validity of the process. This (alleged) lack of quality in the data gathered by amateurs has led to dispute over the validity of the method for scientific investigation and publication
column4: which is to date an ongoing debate (6). A sample error can be minimized
column5: for instance through additional information material
column6: training and understandable
column7: precise protocols for data collection (4
column9: 8). Moreover
column10: to assess the diverse kinds of impacts that citizen science can generate
column11: a large set of different methods has developed over the last years. Therefore
column12: Wehn et al. (2021) present a set of guiding principles for a consolidated approach on impact assessments of citizen science (9).

column1: * While researchers gain data through Citizen Science
column2: the involved citizens get involved in scientific processes
column3: strengthening their scientific literacy and learning about the subjects their are participating in (4
column4: 7). This can also lead to positive social impacts
column5: enabling communities to address local issues in a scientific manner and providing [[Agency
column6: Complexity and Emergence|agency]] or even empowerment‚ to the respective actors (6).

column1: * Citizen Science is a method of transdisciplinary research since it includes public actors into research processes. This element induces some normative notions that are addressed in the wiki entry on transdisciplinarity.
* The diversity of terms and lack of precise definition should be overcome in the future to improve the application of Citizen Science (6
* The same is stated with regards to the redundancy in Citizen Science projects. Instead of designing new projects from the ground
column2: functioning projects should be applied to new areas of interest (6).

column1: ==== Possible future developments - thoughts about the future of the method ====

* ""Citizen Science (...) has over the past decade become a very influential and widely discussed concept with many scientists and commentators seeing it as the future of genuine interactive and inclusive science engagement (...)"" (Riesch & Potter 2014
column2: p.107). As new areas of academia develop participatory research designs
column3: the potential of these approaches are becoming more and more visible (8). Therefore
column4: after years of development and despite a lack of definite conceptualization
column5: Citizen Science should be taken seriously and supported from more areas within academia (8).

column1: * The spreading of Citizen Science approaches to local communities may support the incorporation of traditional knowledge into science policy and improve the science-society relationship in the future (6).
* The growing global availability of internet access improves amateurs' access to Citizen Science projects and increases the potential availability of data for researchers (7).

column1: Cluster analysis shares history in various fields such as anthropology
column2: psychology
column3: biology
column4: medicine
column5: business
column6: computer science
column7: and social science.

column1: It originated in anthropology when Driver and Kroeber published Quantitative Expression of Cultural Relationships in 1932 where they sought to clusters of [[Glossary|culture]] based on different culture elements. Then
column2: the method was introduced to psychology in the late 1930s.

column1: Clustering is a method of grouping unlabeled data based on a certain metric
column2: often referred to as ''similarity measure'' or ''distance measure''
column3: such that the data points within each cluster are similar to each other
column4: and any points that lie in separate cluster are dissimilar. Clustering is a statistical method that falls under a class of [[Machine Learning]] algorithms named ""unsupervised learning""
column5: although clustering is also performed in many other fields such as data compression
column6: pattern recognition
column7: etc. Finally
column8: the term ""clustering"" does not refer to a specific algorithm
column9: but rather a family of algorithms; the similarity measure employed to perform clustering depends on specific clustering model.

column1: While there are many clustering methods
column2: two common approaches are discussed in this article.

column1: The k-means clustering method assigns '''n''' examples to one of '''k''' clusters
column2: where '''n''' is the sample size and  '''k'''
column3: which needs to be chosen before the algorithm is implemented
column4: is the number of clusters. This clustering method falls under a clustering model called centroid model where centroid of a cluster is defined as the mean of all the points in the cluster. K-means Clustering algorithm aims to choose centroids that minimize the within-cluster sum-of-squares criterion based on the following formula:

column1: The in-cluster sum-of-squares is also called inertia in some literature.
# The number of cluster '''k''' is chosen by the data analyst
# The algorithm randomly picks '''k''' centroids and assigns each point to the closest centroid to get '''k''' initial clusters
# The algorithm recalculates the centroid by taking average of all points in each cluster and updates the centroids and re-assigns the points to the closest centroid.
# The algorithm repeats Step 3 until all points stop changing clusters.
To get an intuitive sense of how this k-means clustering algorithm works

==== Strengths and Weaknesses of k-Means Clustering ====
* It is relatively easy to implement.
* It adapts to new data points and guarantees convergence.
* The number of clusters ''k'' has to be chosen manually.
* The vanilla k-Means algorithm cannot accommodate cases with a high number of clusters (high ''k'').
* The k-Means clustering algorithm clusters ''all'' the data points. As a result
column2: the centroids are affected by outliers.

column1: * As the dimension of the dataset increases
column2: the performance of the algorithm starts to deteriorate.

column2: Why & When ==

column1: '''What''': The Code of Conduct is a written statement used in different circumstances to formalize the working procedures and expectations of individuals in a specific team. ""A code of conduct is a set of [[Glossary|rules]] outlining the norms
column2: rules
column3: and responsibilities or proper practices of an individual party or an organisation (Wikipedia).""

column1: '''Why''':  It is oftentimes used in companies to set out certain rules and the respective responsibilities of their employers and employees and can be used to hold both [[Glossary|accountable]] for their actions. It is usually laid out in a written format.
'''When''': Ideally a Code of Conduct is created before the intentional formation of a specific team. This helps to explicitly clarify the expectations
column2: roles and responsibilities of each individual. As many organizations change over time this Code of Conduct should be iterated frequently to prove if it still fits the purpose of the team.

column1: Long term working environments benefit the most from a Code of Conduct (e.g. PhD-Supervision
column2: Work in an association
column3: Employee contracts
column4: long term student assistants
column5: long term group work)

column1: As the creation and maintenance of a formalized code of conduct takes a lot of time and effort
column2: it is questionable if it is needed for every form of group endeavour (e.g. group essays
column3: non-regularly meetings). However
column4: it is still valuable to think in terms of code of conducts as every individual should be held accountable for their actions.

column1: A Code of Conduct provides clear Statements on how individuals want to work together in a specific organization. The Goal of the Code of Conduct can be summarized under the following three aspects: '''(1) Unity (2) Standards (3) Direction'''
'''1. Unity:''' Certain ethical rules should be abided by everyone (e.g. letting everyone be heard
column2: respecting each others arguments
column3: being accountable)

column1: '''2. Standards:''' It should be clarified what the ethical standards and procedures within an organization should be in order to provide every individual with explicit procedures on how to behave.
'''3. Direction:''' Should provide each individual about the purposes and goals of the organization to provide guidance on each respective role within that collective endeavor.
The creation of a Code of Conduct should incorporate two aspects. (1) The topical points (2) procedural points
'''1. Topical points to include in your Code of Conduct'''
* ethical principles - includes workplace behaviour and respect for all people

column2: unbiased and unprejudiced work environment

column1: * [[Glossary|accountability]] - includes taking responsibility for your own actions
column2: ensuring appropriate use of information
column3: exercising diligence and duty of care obligations and avoiding conflicts of interest

column1: * standard of conduct - includes complying with the job description
column2: commitment to the organisation and proper computer
column3: internet and email usage

column1: * standard of practice - includes current policies and procedures and business operational manual
* disciplinary actions - includes complaints handling and specific penalties for any violation of the code.
'''2. procedural points for creating and iterating your Code of Conduct'''
Make sure everyone within the organization is able to express their opinion on roles
column2: responsibilities and expectations. These questions could help for starting an open discussion about organizational values and how to formalize them:

column1: * What does ethics mean to you?
* How effectively does the business put its values into practice?
* Can we improve our ethical performance?
* What do you think of the draft ethical guidelines?
* Would this code of conduct help you make decisions?
* How could it be more helpful?
* Is there anything else we should include?

column2: see link below)

column1: All groups are sooner or later riddled by by challenges when collaborating as a group. At Leuphana University
column2: group works are from the very first semester part of the DNA of our teaching
column3: since group work is indeed a realistic setting for later work reality. There are clearly positive and negative aspects one wants to cover when working on out a code of conduct. Let us start with all factors that make working in a group great
column4: as collected from our students:

column2: different backgrounds and experience
column3: reliability and splitting of the workload
column4: giving each other critical feedback and emotional support are mentioned when people perceive group work to be positive. However
column5: all these experience can be flipped into loosing time to gain coherence
column6: endless feedback loops
column7: lack of trust
column8: unreliable work ethics
column9: loss of energy due to repetitions
column10: and the whole array of negative emotions we humans are capable of. This includes people's egos dominating the group
column11: unbalanced speaking time
column12: and lack of inclusion. Power does indeed quite often play a major role in group works
column13: and this is also difficult to get rid of. The best way to start getting a great group together is obviously to start with yourself. How much do you listen to other? Do you give others appropriate space? How are your moderating skills? Do you make a conscious effort of integration? Can you uplift the spirits in the groups. Do you provide structure and are reliable? Are there specific behaviours of others that trigger you
column14: and can you get rid of this counter-behaviour? Do you make an active effort to learn from the other? This list can go on for a long time
column15: and is one of the best arguments why a code of conduct only works if you are committed to it. You cannot expect others to honour something that you ignore. We all make mistakes
column16: yet keeping a research diary and learning how to serve a group best is a lifelong goal. A code of conduct is like a list of virtue driven guidelines that you may built in your life in order to facilitate yourself within groups. In academia many people are impatient
column17: a trait probably all of us shared at times. Yet trying to push other people around will not help in the long run. Perfecting patience is hence a key skill. If you add reliability and awareness of your own insecurities -which are often the root cause of your triggers- then you are already halfway there. Almost the whole rest concerning group work is about trust
column18: and this can only be built or earned
column19: but not planned.

'''In short:''' A Cohort Study is a form of quantitative data analysis where two or more groups are tracked over time from a specific exposure to an outcome.
[[File:Cohort Study SCOPUS.png|400px|thumb|right|'''SCOPUS hits for Cohort Study until 2019.''' Search terms: 'Cohort Study'
column2: 'Cohort Analysis' in Title
column3: Abstract
column4: Keywords. Source: own.]]

column1: The term 'cohort' historically refers to a 300-600 man unit in the Roman army (3). It found its way into scientific research thanks to Wade Hampton Frost
column2: a medical doctor from the US
column3: who invented the Cohort study method after his pioneering work in the field of epidemiology in the early 20th Century. In a study that was published after his death in 1938
column4: he focused on the mortality rates of tuberculosis patients in Massachusetts and - presumably for the first time - assessed not only differences between age groups in any given year
column5: but also in the development of each cohort over time.

column1: The method and the term 'cohort' were subsequently adapted by the social sciences
column2: mostly focusing on the role of ""generations"" in historical developments as well as in demography (4). Social sciences and epidemiology remain the most important applications fields of Cohort Studies to this day (2). However
column3: cohorts are no more only defined based on their birth year
column4: but determined based on any shared characteristic of interest (e.g. the experience of a specific event) within a defined time interval (4). It is worthwhile noting that the original term 'cohort analysis' today relates to a big data approach used for business analytics. The scientific method used in statistics and epidemiology today is referred to as 'cohort study' (2). More appropriate synonyms of the cohort study include incidence
column5: longitudinal
column6: forward-looking
column7: follow-up
column8: concurrent or prospective studies (3).

column1: *""A cohort study tracks two or more groups forward from exposure to outcome. In its simplest form
column2: a cohort study compares the experience of a group exposed to some factor with another group not exposed to the factor. If the former group has a higher or lower frequency of an outcome than the unexposed
column3: then an association between exposure and outcome is evident."" (3
column4: p.341). The exposure must be clearly defined
column5: with the option of defining several degrees of exposure (e.g. light and heavy smokers compared to non-smokers) (3). The cohorts may be tracked over years
column6: but also over decades
column7: depending on the research question.

column1: * '''A Cohort Study is a form of quantitative data analysis.''' There are two main types: ''prospective'' (following cohorts into the future with original data gathering) and ''retrospective'' (following cohorts up to the present based on existent data). A third type
column2: ''ambidirectional''
column3: involves both data from the past and data gathered from the present on which is useful for studies that focus on both short-term and long-term outcomes of certain events or exposures (3).

column1: [[File:ResultVisualisationCohortStudy.png|300px|thumb|left|A table from Frost's original study. Source: Comstock 2001
This table from Frost's original paper (see Key Publications) illustrates the mortality of tuberculosis patients (a both infectious and chronic disease)
column2: with the year of death in the columns and the age-group of the patients in the lines. '''When analyzed per year
column3: this table suggests the highest mortality among infants
column4: followed by a peak in the 20-29 year group and another increase for the elderly. However
column5: the death rates for one cohort - seen diagonally over time - only indicates a high mortality for infants and 20-29 year olds
column6: while the mortality rate decreases after that.''' By analyzing the temporal development of the cohort
column7: Frost was able to reject the previous assumption that especially elderly people are at risk. Instead
column8: he concluded that the high death rates in this age group are residuals from even higher death rates of this cohort in earlier years (1).

column1: * Cohort studies are ""(...) the best way to identify incidence and natural history of a disease
column2: and can be used to examine multiple outcomes after a single exposure"" (3
column3: p.341). In addition
column4: they are useful when studying rare exposures that happen in limited numbers of environments (e.g. a factory). They can reduce the risk of survivor [[Bias and Critical Thinking|bias]] when studying diseases that are rapidly fatal
column5: and they allow for the calculation of incidence rates
column6: relative risks
column7: and confidence intervals (3

column2: Cohort Studies are less useful for diseases and outcomes that are very rare or take a long time to develop (3). Also
column3: loss to follow-up can be an issue with prospective Cohort Studies
column4: especially for longitudinal studies that span over years or decades. In addition
column5: the exposure status of the subjects may change over time (3).

column2: it is difficult to find control groups that share the exact same characteristics as the analyzed group(s) except for the exposure. Attempts to compensate for this can lead to biases in the analysis (3).

column1: * Since several outcomes may be attributed to the original exposure
column2: researchers might focus on those outcomes that are significant or supportive of a certain assumption
column3: instead of transparently communicating all outcomes (3).

column1: * The increasing wealth of data that become available in recent years through the internet an other sources led to many opportunities
column2: however
column3: now some studies are indicated to be cohort studies
column4: when i fact they only use available data
column5: but do not design a methodological sampling.

column2: Why & When ==

column1: Concept Maps are a '''form of visually organizing information''' for groups and individuals. Conceptual terms or short statements are presented in boxes or bubbles and interlinked with other terms through commented arrows
column2: resulting in a hierarchical network-like structure that provides an overview on a topic.

column1: * Organize '''conceptual knowledge''' in a visual form to identify learning processes and knowledge gaps.

column2: ideas and solutions by '''arranging information in a structured manner''' around a focus question
column3: topic
column4: or problem.

column1: [[File:Concept Maps - Example 1.png|500px|thumb|right|'''An example for a Concept Map on the knowledge structure required for understanding why we have seasons.''' . Source: [http://cmap.ihmc.us/docs/theory-of-concept-maps.php Novak & Cañas 2008
column2: Cmap]]]

column1: Concept Maps result from the work of '''Joseph Novak and colleagues at Cornell University in the 1970s''' in the field of education
column2: and have since been applied in this area and beyond. The original underlying idea was to analyze how children learn
column3: assuming that they do so by assimilating new concepts and positioning these in a cognitive conceptual framework. The idea of Concept Maps emerged from the demand for a form of assessing these conceptual understandings.

column2: while Concept Maps are often applied in research
column3: teaching or planning
column4: they should not be confused with the mixed methods approach of [[Group Concept Mapping]]. The latter emerged based on Concept Maps in the 1980s
column5: but is a more structured
column6: multi-step process. A Concept Map further differs from a [[Mindmap]] in that the latter are spontaneous
column7: unstructured visualisations of ideas and information around one central topic
column8: without a hierarchy or linguistic homogeneity
column9: and do not necessarily include labeled information on how conceptual elements relate to each other.

column1: Concept Maps '''help identify a current state of knowledge''' and show gaps within this knowledge
column2: e.g. a lack of understanding on which elements are of importance to a question or topic
column3: and how concepts are interrelated. Identifying these gaps helps fill knowledge gaps. Therefore
column4: they can be a helpful tool for students or anyone learning a new topic to monitor one's own progress and understanding of the topic
column5: and how this changes as learning units continue.

column2: Concept Maps can be '''a way of approaching a specific question''' or problem and support a systematic solution-development process. The visual representation of all relevant elements nconcerning a specific topic can thus help create new knowledge. There are even more imaginable purposes of the approach
column3: including management and planning
column4: creative idea-generation and more.

column2: p.178) shows how a student's conceptual understanding of a topic develops over time.''' It illustrates how Concept Maps can help identify knowledge gaps or flaws (which are existent still in the map below)
column3: how much (and what kind of) learning process was made over time
column4: and what to focus on in future learning. Source: Novak 2016

column1: [[File:Concept Map - Step by Step 1.png|400px|thumb|right|'''A list of concepts (left) and a ""string map"" that focuses on cross-links between concepts
column2: as a groundwork for the concept map.''' Source: [http://cmap.ihmc.us/docs/theory-of-concept-maps.php CMap]]]

column1: # When learning to work with Concept Maps
column2: Novak & Canas (2008) recommend to '''start with a domain of knowledge that one is familiar with'''. Here
column3: the learner should focus on a specific focus question and/or text item
column4: activity
column5: or problem to structure the presented elements and hierarchies around
column6: and to contextualize the map by. As the authors highlight
column7: often
column8: ""learners tend to deviate from the focus question and build a concept map that may be related to the domain
column9: but which does not answer the question. It is often stated that the first step to learning about something is to ask the right questions"".

column1: # After defining the domain of knowledge and focus question or problem
column2: 15-25 '''key concepts should be identified and ranked''' according to their specificity. In a concept map
column3: more general
column4: broad concepts are on the top of the map
column5: while more specific concepts are found below
column6: resulting in a hierarchy from top to bottom. So the concepts should be ordered accordingly in a list first.

column2: a preliminary concept map is created
column3: either digitally (with the 'official' IHMC CmapTools software
column4: see below) or by using Post-Its and a whiteboard. Concepts can and should be moved around iteratively. Propositions  - connections between concepts with text - are added to the map to highlight and explain relationships between concepts. When a first good draft exists
column5: one identifies cross-links
column6: which are relationships between separate areas of the map
column7: to further highlight conceptual linkages. Lastly
column8: '''constant revision is applied''' and concepts can be re-positioned to further improve the map.

column2: Why & When ==
as we like to call them - are [[Glossary|visualisations]] that do not represent data itself
column3: but help illustrate a theoretical idea or a methodological design. They are often relevant for scientific publications
column4: and can help improve presentations and pitches by making an idea or approach more understandable for the audience.

column1: * Create better figures to explain concepts or methodological designs
* Expand on your text through visualisations
'''Here are some initial recommendable ideas on how to make this type of figure:'''

1) '''Follow Ockham's razor''': just like for research designs - and much of life - Ockham's razor can guide your approach to developing a conceptual figure. It should include as much information as necessary
column2: but as little as possible. Useless information that the figure does not benefit from should be avoided. Also
column3: the information provided in the figure should be complementary to the text
column4: not (entirely) identical
column5: which would render the figure itself redundant. Good figures help us better understand the text that we read already
column6: but do not take up space without providing anything new.

column1: 2) '''Make your figures intuitive to understand.''' A figure with a lot of complex information usually overwhelms the reader. You want your figure to stimulate further engagement with what it shows. A good figure is graspable at first sight
column2: at least in terms of the core elements. This also means that there should usually be no more than 3 - 5 five core elements within the figure
column3: although there can be accompanying smaller elements around those. It should be clear right away what is shown
column4: and how parts of the figure relate to each other. Then
column5: the information that lies within the figure should be easily accessible
column6: even if it takes some time to engage with everything that is shown. Be aware that people (at least in Western culture) usually scan figures from the top-left to the bottom right - build your figures accordingly.

column1: 3) '''Avoid empty spaces or disbalances'''. A lot of blank space
column2: or an unbalanced distribution of visual elements just feels off.

column1: 4) '''Use clear fonts and a balanced color palette'''. Fonts are certainly a matter of taste
column2: but some fonts are just more adequate for scientific publications or presentations than others. The text should be readable at first glance (see 2)
column3: so choose a font that is easy to decipher and ideally fits to the rest of the document. We recommend sans serif fonts like Ariel or Courier
column4: but you should find your own preference or get inspired by other publications. Colors
column5: then
column6: should first make a figure more visually appealing. This can be done by using colors that fit together
column7: for example by relying on a Wes-Anderson-Color-Palette
column8: which is obviously the best set of colors. However
column9: the use of certain signal colors can help guide the audience's attention to specific details. Colors can also hold information. For example
column10: a color gradient can represent a decrease or increase of some value
column11: or different categories of things. Also
column12: colors can be used recurringly
column13: for example when a certain color represents a specific actor
column14: element
column15: topic or place in one figure
column16: and the same color represents the same element in another figure
column17: which supports continuity in your design and guides the reader through the document.

column2: and the figure as a narrative'''. A good figure can stand on its own
column3: and represent something. It is alright if the full picture of the figure is only understandable with the help of the original text it expands upon. However
column4: if you can show the figure to someone and (s)he'll understand what it is about
column5: you are on the right track. For this
column6: it is important to include all information necessary to understand what is shown (see 1). More importantly
column7: a figure can give the reader information on how things relate to each other - focusing on temporal order
column8: most commonly through the use of arrows or a timeline
column9: or causal relations
column10: often also done with arrows
column11: although many more approaches are conceivable. What happens when
column12: and what is a solution to
column13: or consequence of
column14: what? Also
column15: proportions of information can contain information: if an element is smaller than others
column16: it is maybe not as important.

column2: and develop your own style'''. It is okay to steal from others. There are lots of great conceptual figures in science
column3: and studying them with a focus on what makes them great - or not great - can help find ideas to improve your own design. Of course
column4: you shouldn't simply adapt other people's figures
column5: but take parts or approaches that might fit your own needs.

column1: * Decide on one software solution to implement your figure in
column2: and learn what it can do.

column1: * Acknowledge the expectations of your audience
column2: or deliberately decide to break with their expectations when appropriate.

column1: * Always keep in mind how your figure relates to the character and content of the document it is placed in.
* Follow your intuition: we all have our own ideas about what looks good
column2: and we do our best work when we are convinced of what we are doing ourselves.
however
column3: get feedback from peers when in doubt. They will be able to tell you if everything is understandable
column4: and overcome the tunnel vision that you might develop when you are deep in a topic.

column1: [[File:Conceptual Figures.png|800px|frameless|center|'''A conceptual figure on conceptual figures.''' Source: own.]]

column2: however
column3: our main recommendation remains to '''keep it simple'''. Don't overburden the reader with information
column4: but focus on what is really important. For more helpful tips on visualisations
column5: please refer to the entry on Statistical Figures and Poster Design.

column1: [[File:Conceptual Figures - Doughnut Economics.png|400px|thumb|left|'''The Doughnut Economics concept.''' Source: [https://doughnuteconomics.org/about-doughnut-economics Doughnut Economics Lab]]]
The famous Doughnut Economics figure is a good example for a great conceptual figure.
* It is understandable at first sight
column2: with the doughnut itself limiting itself to three elements ''(ecological ceiling
column3: social foundation
column4: the safe and just space for humanity''). This is what our eyes fall onto at first glance.

column2: due to the underlying planetary boundary concept
column3: is akin to the shape of the globe
column4: which is recognizable
column5: and the arrows tell the main narrative of the figure.

column1: * There is a lot of information here
column2: but it is clearly divided into categories (social necessities
column3: environmental boundaries) and rather easy to read
column4: despite the cyclical arrangement.

column1: * The colors support the narrative: red is a problem
column2: dark green is okay
column3: light green is ideal.

column1: * The doughnut works as a figure on its own
column2: despite it being part of a larger book that explains it in more detail (Doughnut Economics by Kate Raworth). It is a narrative by itself
column3: and helps communicate an idea.

The Sustainable Development Goals are another good example of how a visualisation can hold a lot of information
column2: but still be understandable and - what is very important here - recognizable.

column1: * Each piece of text is amended through a fitting picture
column2: and has a number
column3: which provides structure at first sight. Also
column4: the 18 square panels provide order
column5: which is necessary considering the busy individual icons.

column1: * The SDGs have a distinct coloring palette
column2: which is used again in the shortened circular version (bottom right corner). Wherever you go
column3: the SDGs will be recognizable. Interestingly
column4: they still work when used individually
column5: which speaks for the strong narrative of the arrangement.

column1: * The font is easily readable and limited to the title of each goal
column2: although there is (a lot) more information beneath.
