''' In short:''' Content Analysis relies on the summarizing of data (most commonly text) into content categories based on pre-determined rules and the analysis of the ""coded"" data.
[[File:Content Analysis SCOPUS.png|400px|thumb|right|'''SCOPUS hits for Content Analysis until 2019.''' Search term: 'content analysis' in Title
column2: Abstract
column3: Keywords. Source: own.]]

column1: Early approaches to text analysis can be found in Hermeneutics
column2: but quantitative Content Analysis itself emerged during the 1930s based on the sociological work of Lazarsfeld and Lasswell in the USA (4). The method prospered in the study of mass communications in the 1950s (2). [[History of Methods|Starting in the 1960s]]
column3: the method was subsequently adapted to the specific needs of diverse disciplines
column4: with the Qualitative Content Analysis emerging from a critique on the lack of communicative contextualization in the earlier purely quantitative approaches (4). Today
column5: the method is applied in a wide range of social sciences and humanities
column6: including communicative science
column7: anthropology
column8: political sciences
column9: psychology
column10: education
column11: and literature
column12: among others (1

column2: replicable technique for compressing many words of text into fewer content categories based on explicit rules of coding"" (Stemler 2000
column3: p.1). However
column4: the method entails more than mere word-counting. Instead
column5: Content Analysis relies on the interpretation of the [[Glossary|data]] on behalf of the researcher. The mostly qualitative data material is assessed by creating a category system relevant to the material
column6: and attributing parts of the content to individual categories (Schreier 2014). Not only the content of a source is evaluated
column7: but also formal aspects as well as contextual psychological
column8: institutional
column9: and cultural elements of the communication process (1
column10: 4). ""[Content Analysis] seeks to analyze data within a specific context in view of the meanings someone - a group or a culture - attributes to them."" (Krippendorff 1989
column11: p.403). Because of this
column12: Content Analysis is a potent method to identify trends and patterns in (text) sources
column13: to determine authorship
column14: or to monitor (public) opinions on a specific topic (3).

column2: a diverse set of data can be analyzed using Content Analysis. ""Anything that occurs in sufficient numbers and has reasonably stable meanings for a specific group of people may be subjected to content analysis."" (Krippendorff 1989
column3: p.404). The data must convey a message to the receiver and be durable (2
column4: 3). Often
column5: Content Analysis focuses on data that are difficult or impossible to interpret with other methods (3). The data may exist 'naturally' and be publicly available
column6: for example verbal discourse
column7: written documents
column8: or visual representations from mass media (newspapers
column9: books
column10: films
column11: comics etc.); or be rather unavailable to the public
column12: such as personal letters or witness accounts. The data may also be generated for the research purpose (e.g. interview transcripts) (1

column1: While there is a wide range of qualitative Content Analysis approaches
column2: this entry will focus on joint characteristics of these. For more information on the different variations
column3: please refer to Schreier (2014) in the Key Publications.

column1: * Any Content Analysis starts with the ''Design Phase'' in which the research questions are defined
column2: the potential sources are gathered
column3: and the analytical constructs are established that connect the prospective data to the general target of the analysis. These constructs can be based on existing theories or practices
column4: the experience and knowledge of experts
column5: or previous research (2).

column2: the ''Unitizing'' is done
column3: i.e. the definition of analysis units. It may be distinguished between sampling units (= sources of data
column4: e.g. newspaper articles
column5: interviews) and analysis units (= units of data that are coded and analyzed
column6: e.g. single words or broader messages)
column7: with different approaches to identifying both (see Krippendorff 2004).

column2: the ''sampling'' method is determined and the sample is drawn.

the ''Coding Scheme'' - or 'Codebook' - is developed and the data are coded. 'Coding' generally describes the transfer of the available data into more abstract groups. A code is a label that represents a group of words that share a similar meaning (3). Codes may also be grouped into categories if they thematically belong together. There are two typical approaches to developing the coding scheme: a rather theory-driven and a rather data-driven approach. In a theory-driven approach
column3: codes are developed based on theoretical constructs
column4: research questions and elements such as an interview guide
column5: which leads to a rather deductive coding procedure. In a data-driven approach
column6: the coding system is developed as the researcher openly scans subsamples of the available material and develops codes based on these initial insights
column7: which is a rather inductive process. Often
column8: both approaches are combined
column9: with an initial set of codes being derived from theory
column10: and then iteratively adapted through a first analysis of the available material.

column1: * With the coding scheme at hand
column2: the researcher reads (repeatedly) through the data material and assigns each analysis unit to one of the codes. The ''coding process'' may be conducted by humans
column3: or - if sufficiently explicit coding instructions are possible - by a computer. In order to provide reliability
column4: the codes should be intersubjective
column5: i.e. every researcher should be able to code similarly
column6: which is why the codes must be exhaustive in terms of the overarching construct
column7: mutually exclusive
column8: clearly defined
column9: have unambiguous examples as well as exclusion criteria.

column2: the coded data are ''analyzed and interpreted'' whilst taking into account the theoretical constructs that underlie the research. Inferences are drawn
column3: which - according to Mayring (2000) - may focus on the communicator
column4: the message itself
column5: the socio-cultural context of the message
column6: or on the message's effect. The learnings may be validated in the face of other information sources
column7: which is often difficult when Content Analysis is used in cases where there is no other possibility to access this knowledge. Finally
column8: new hypotheses may also be formulated (all from 1

column1: [[File:Example Content Analysis (1).jpg|500px|thumb|right|'''An exemplary interview transcript from a person that was admitted to an emergency center.''' Source: Erlingsson & Brysiewicz 2017.]]
[[File:Example Content Analysis (2).png|500px|thumb|right|'''The coding results for statements from the interview transcript above
column2: grouped into one of several themes.''' Source: Erlingsson & Brysiewicz 2017.]]

column1: Qualitative Content Analysis is a rather inductive process. The process is guided by the research questions - hypotheses may be tested
column2: but this is not the main goal. As with much of qualitative research
column3: this method attempts to understand the (subjective) meaning behind the analyzed data and to draw conclusions from there. Its purpose is to get hold of the 'bigger picture'
column4: including the communicative context surrounding the genesis of the data. The qualitative Content Analysis is a very iterative process. The coding scheme is often not determined prior to the coding process. Instead
column5: its development is guided by the research questions and done in close contact to the data
column6: e.g. by reading through all data first and identifying relevant themes. The codes are then re-defined iteratively as the researcher applies them to the data. As an example
column7: the comparative analysis of two texts can be mentioned
column8: where codes are developed based on the first text
column9: re-iterated by reading through the second text
column10: then jointly applied to the first text again. Also
column11: new research questions may be added during the analysis if the first insights into the data raise them. This approach is closely related to the methodological concept of [[Grounded Theory]] approaches.

column1: With regards to the coding process
column2: the analysis units are assigned to the codes but not statistically analysed. There is an exemption to this - the evaluative content analysis
column3: where statements are evaluated on a nominal or ordinal scale
column4: which makes simple quantitative (statistical) analyses possible. However
column5: for most forms of qualitative Content Analysis
column6: the assigned items per code are interpreted qualitatively and conclusions are inferred from these interpretations. Examples and quotes may be used to illustrate the findings. Overall
column7: in this approach
column8: a deep understanding of the data and their meaning is relevant
column9: as is a proper description of specific cases
column10: and possibly a triangulation with other data sources on the same subject.

column1: * Content Analysis counteracts biases because it ""(...) assures not only that all units of analysis receive equal treatment
column2: whether they are entered at the beginning or at the end of an analysis but also that the process is objective in that it does not matter who performs the analysis or where and when."" (see Normativity) (Krippendorff 1989
column3: p.404). In this case
column4: 'objective' refers to 'intersubjective'. Yet
column5: biases cannot be entirely prevented
column6: e.g. in the sampling process
column7: the development of the coding scheme
column8: or the interpretation and evaluation of the coded data.

column1: * Content Analysis allows for researchers to apply their own social-scientific constructs ""by which texts may become meaningful in ways that a culture may not be aware of."" (Krippendorff 1989

column2: especially in case of qualitative analysis of smaller data sample sizes
column3: the theory and hypotheses derived from data cannot be generalized beyond this data (1). Triangulation
column4: i.e. the comparison of the findings to other knowledge on the same topic
column5: may provide more validity to the conclusions (see Normativity).

column1: * Reliability is difficult to maintain in the Content Analysis. A clear and unambiguous definition of codes as well as testings for inter-coder reliability represent attempts to ensure inter-subjectivity and thus stability and reproducibility (3
column2: 4). However
column3: the ambiguous nature of the data demands an interpretative analysis process - especially in the qualitative approach. This interpretation process of the texts or contents may interfere with the intended inter-coder reliability.

column1: * Validity of the inferred results - i.e. the fitting of the results to the intended kind of knowledge - may be reached a) through the researchers' knowledge of contextual factors of the data and b) through validation with other sources
column2: e.g. by the means of triangulation. However
column3: the latter can be difficult to do due to the uniqueness of the data (1-3). Any content analysis is a reduction of the data
column4: which should be acknowledged critically
column5: and which is why the coding scheme should be precise and include the aforementioned explanation
column6: examples and exclusion criteria.

column1: * Since verbal discourse is an important data source for Content Analysis
column2: the latter is often used as an analysis method of transcripts of standardized
column3: [[Open Interview|open]]
column4: or [[Semi-structured Interview|semi-structured interviews]].

column1: * Content Analysis is one form of textual analysis. The latter also includes other approaches such as discourse analysis
column2: rhetorical analysis
column3: or [[Ethnography|ethnographic]] analysis (2). However
column4: Content Analysis differs from these methods in terms of methodological elements and the kinds of questions it addresses (2).

column1: * The usage of automated coding with the use of computers may be seen as one important future direction of the method (1
column2: 5). To date
column3: the human interpretation of ambiguous language imposes a high validity of the results which cannot (yet) be provided by a computer. Alas
column4: the development of an appropriate algorithm and text recognition software pose a challenge. The meaning of words changes in different contexts and several expressions may mean the same. Especially in terms of qualitative analyses
column5: this currently makes human coders indispensable. Yet
column6: the emergence of big data
column7: Artificial Intelligence and [[Machine Learning]] might make it possible in the foreseeable future to use automated coding more regularly and with a high validity.

column1: * Another relevant direction is the shift from text to visual and audio data as a primary form of data (5). With ever-increasing amounts of pictures
column2: video and audio files on the internet
column3: future studies may refer to these kinds of sources more often.

column2: Why & When ==

column1: The contents of this entry are meant to provide you with support in psychologically challenging times. We'll give you a structured way of getting help as well as provide tips on what you can do for yourself.
This article is based solely on our own experience and research. When using the first person singular below
column2: it is the authors own experience
column3: whereas ‘we’ means that the Wiki team sprinkled in their experiences. Thus
column4: this page can and should not be a substitute for professional support. Nonetheless
column5: we hope to provide you with some valuable resources that can provide some help in challenging times. It is also mainly written for students in Lüneburg
column6: and therefore has local context. We hope it might still be helpful to others.

column1: If you have urgent and acute psychological problems
column2: please contact one of the professional points of contact below!
changes beyond our own control can impact our mental well-being to the extent that we are unable to cope with it just by ourselves. Many of us have never been taught how to cope with mental hardship
column3: and societal norms of individualism and toughness can make it hard to acknowledge that at some point
column4: we can simply not carry on with our lives using our usual coping mechanisms.

column1: The pandemic amplified these issues manyfold
column2: and we know how many students are currently struggling with their mental health
column3: especially when university
column4: jobs and life are still setting high demands on our ability to ""function"". We know this is for many parts a societal problem. Nevertheless
column5: if you feel depressed
column6: anxious or overwhelmed at any one moment
column7: you have little options but to start with yourself. This is why we want to provide this article: as a means to help you get through difficult times.

column1: The first is a guide on how to get professional help. From our experience
column2: this can be one of the hardest things to do when you're already down
column3: and the existing health care systems don't make it easier to actually find support. Here
column4: we tried to collect resources and mould them into a step-by-step instruction to help you find professional help as straightforwardly as possible.

column1: The second is a set of practices and perspectives we found helpful to cope with mental issues ourselves
column2: which you can start implementing right now. This is important for two reasons. For one
column3: they can help you get a little better. Additionally
column4: they may help you to find the strength which you need to get professional help.

column2: and it might feel a bit awkward to use university resources for this. We can't really circumvent that
column3: but still hope that this might provide you with some kind of help. We wish you all the best!

column1: Getting professional help is by no means easy
column2: but it is very possible. Below
column3: we tried to draw an overview on how this can work. The truth is that the medical system is messy and reality might be a little different. Still
column4: sticking to some form of structured process should help you in getting professional support. Here's an overview:

column1: There’s three things you can do besides going for a full therapy which may already help:
A) Finding a frame for yourself to better understand that having a mental illness is not your responsibility or fault.
B) Getting psychological counselling from the Studierendenwerk (if you’re a student in Lüneburg)
C) Talking to your doctor. He or she will be able to talk you through the process as well
column2: and give you a recipee which can help you to find a therapist faster.

column1: ==== A) Find a frame for yourself ====
The first thing besides all the technical and organisational stuff is finding a way to think about this that doesn't make you feel worse about your situation than it needs to. For me personally

column1: === IV) What you can do on your own ===

column2: there are a few things that can help you to lift yourself out of the worst phases. Here’s what we found helpful.

column1: '''Meditation''' can help you get out of negative thought spirals and liften your mood. If you haven’t tried meditation yet
column2: it might be easiest to download an app or listen to guided meditations on YouTube. Apps we tried out and found helpful are [https://www.headspace.com/ Headspace] and [https://www.tenpercent.com/ 10% Happier]. You can try them for free!

column1: An '''appreciation journal''' might also be helpful in lightening your mood. It’s rather trivial: just take a few minutes everyday to write down what you’re thankful for. This might feel awkward
column2: or stupid
column3: and you might find it hard to find things you’re sincerely thankful for. But with time
column4: you might be able to direct your focus to the things that are actually good
column5: even if they are comparably small.

column1: '''Journalling''' might also generally be helpful to get thoughts out of your head and onto a piece of (digital) paper. Just sit down every evening for 10 minutes or so and write down whatever is going through your head. If you find it hard to start
column2: just write down what happened on that day.

column1: '''Confide in people you trust.''' It might be hard at first
column2: but our experience is that not only does it help to explicate your thoughts and feelings
column3: but also to understand that you are not alone in how you feel.

column1: A friend once called these lifestyle choices the “Kleines 1x1 der Psychohygiene” (Psychological Hygiene 101):
# '''Sleep regularly and long enough.''' For most people
column2: this means at least 7 and no more than 9 hours of sleep every day
column3: at the same time. From personal experience I would say this makes all the difference in the world.

column1: # '''Eat & drink regularly.''' Try to eat good
column2: healthy food
column3: and drink at least 2 litres of water per day.

column2: whatever it is. Walking for 30 mins
column3: jogging
column4: climbing
column5: doing Yoga
column6: going to the Gym
column7: doing jumping jacks. Whatever it is
column8: it’s almost certainly helpful.

column1: # '''Regularity.''' This is a big one. Structures help a lot. If you have to study or work
column2: try to do it at a place outside of your home
column3: every day at the same time. The place does not really matter as long as it is not your own room
column4: be it the university or a café or a friends place.

column2: and they certainly do not solve any underlying causes of whatever problem you might have. They do however help to get out of the hole and into a state where you can actually do something about your situation
column3: and that is incredibly important.

column1: === The student perspective on lifestyle choices ===

column2: this can be especially frustrating. People might be partying and you don’t want to leave at 11 to go to bed. After all
column3: this is supposed to be the time of your life. Everyone else might seem like they just live into their day and do whatever feels right at the moment
column4: and having a structured everyday life might prevent you from doing the same. What might help you is to think about this as a transitional phase: you’re not going to do this forever. It’s a phase you need in order to get back up on your feet and enjoy life again. It might suck
column5: but it won’t suck forever.

column1: '''A note on calculating the correlation coefficient:'''

column2: there are three main methods to calculate the correlation coefficient: Pearson's correlation coefficient
column3: Spearman's rank correlation coefficient and Kendall's rank coefficient.

column1: '''Pearson's correlation coefficient''' is the most popular among them. This measure only allows the input of continuous data and is sensitive to linear relationships.
While Pearson's correlation coefficient is a parametric measure
column2: the other two are non-parametric methods based on ranks. Therefore
column3: they are more sensitive to non-linear relationships and measure the monotonic association - either positive or negative. '''Spearman's rank correlation''' coefficient calculates the rank order of the variables' values using a monotonic function whereas '''Kendall's rank correlation coefficient''' computes the degree of similarity between two sets of ranks introducing concordant and discordant pairs.

column1: Since Pearson's correlation coefficient is the most frequently used one among the correlation coefficients

column1: A line chart can help show how quantitative values for different categories have changed over time. They are typically structured around a temporal x-axis with equal intervals from the earliest to latest point in time. Quantitative values are plotted using joined-up lines that effectively connect consecutive points positioned along a y-axis. The resulting slopes formed between the two ends of each line provide an indication of the local trends between points in time. As this sequence is extended to plot all values across the time frame it forms an overall line representative of the quantitative change over time story for a single categorical value.
Multiple categories can be displayed in the same view
column2: each represented by a unique line. Sometimes a point (circle/dot) is also used to substantiate the visibility of individual values. The lines used in a line chart will generally be straight. However
column3: sometimes curved line interpolation may be used as a method of estimating values between known data points. This approach can be useful to help emphasise a general trend. While this might slightly compromise the visual accuracy of discrete values if you already have approximations
column4: this will have less impact.

'''In short:''' Correlation analysis examines the statistical relationship between two continuous variables. For R examples on Correlations
column2: please refer to [[Correlation Plots]].

column1: Karl Pearson is considered to be the founding father of mathematical statistics; hence it is no surprise that one of the central methods in statistics - to test the relationship between two continuous variables - was invented by him at the brink of the 20th century (see Karl Pearson's ""Notes on regression and inheritance in the case of two parents"" from 1895). His contribution was based on work from Francis Galton and Auguste Bravais. With more data becoming available and the need for an “exact science” as part of the industrialization and the rise of modern science
column2: the Pearson correlation paved the road to modern statistics at the beginning of the 20th century. While other approaches such as the t-test or the Analysis of Variance ([[ANOVA]]) by Pearson's arch-enemy Fisher demanded an experimental approach
column3: the correlation simply required data with a continuous measurement level. Hence it appealed to the demand for an analysis that could be conducted based solely on measurements done in engineering
column4: or on counting as in economics
column5: without being preoccupied too deeply with the reasoning on why variables correlated. '''Pearson recognized the predictive power of his discovery
column6: and the correlation analysis became one of the most abundantly used statistical approaches in diverse disciplines such as economics
column7: ecology
column8: psychology and social sciences.''' Later came the ​regression analysis
column9: which implies a causal link between two continuous variables. This makes it different from a correlation
column10: where two variables are related
column11: but not necessarily causally linked. This article focuses on correlation analysis and only touches upon regressions. For more
column12: please refer to the entry on [[Regression Analysis]].)

column1: Correlation analysis examines the relationship between two [[Data formats|continuous variables]]
column2: and test whether the relation is statistically significant. For this
column3: correlation analysis takes the sample size and the strength of the relation between the two variables into account. The so-called ''correlation coefficient'' indicates the strength of the relation
column4: and ranges from -1 to 1. A coefficient close to 0 indicates a weak correlation. A coefficient close to 1 indicates a strong positive correlation
column5: and a coefficient close to -1 indicates a strong negative correlation.

column1: Correlations can be applied to all kinds of quantitative continuous data from all spatial and temporal scales
column2: from diverse methodological origins including [[Survey]]s and Census data
column3: ecological measurements
column4: economical measurements
column5: GIS and more. Correlations are also used in both inductive and deductive approaches. This versatility makes correlation analysis one of the most frequently used quantitative methods to date.

column1: '''There are different forms of correlation analysis.''' The Pearson correlation is usually applied to normally distributed data
column2: or more precisely
column3: data that shows a [https://365datascience.com/students-t-distribution/ Student's t-distribution]. Alternative correlation measures like [https://www.statisticssolutions.com/kendalls-tau-and-spearmans-rank-correlation-coefficient/ Kendall's tau and Spearman's rho] are usually applied to variables that are not normally distributed. I recommend you just look them up
column4: and keep as a rule of thumb that Spearman's rho is the most robust correlation measure when it comes to non-normally distributed data.

column1: The formula to calculate [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2B_UW-RweSE a Pearson correlation coefficient] is fairly simple. You just need to keep in mind that you have two variables or samples
column2: called x and y
column3: and their respective means (m).

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-05-02 um 09.46.54.png|400px|center|thumb|This is the formula for calculating the Pearson correlation coefficient r.]]
There are some core questions related to the application and reading of correlations. These can be of interest whenever you have the correlation coefficient at hand - for example
column2: in a statistical software - or when you see a correlation plot.

column1: '''1) Is the relationship between two variables positive or negative?''' If one variable increases
column2: and the other one increases
column3: too
column4: we have  a positive (""+"") correlation. This is also true if both variables decrease. For instance
column5: being taller leads to a significant increase in [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3534609/ body weight]. On the other hand
column6: if one variable increases
column7: and the other decreases
column8: the correlation is negative (""-""): for example
column9: the relationship between 'pizza eaten' and 'pizza left' is negative. The more pizza slices are eaten
column10: the fewer slices are still there. This direction of the relationship tells you a lot about how two variables might be logically connected. The normative value of a positive or negative relation typically has strong implications
column11: especially if both directions are theoretically possible. Therefore it is vital to be able to interpret the direction of a correlative relationship.

column1: '''2) Is the correlation coefficient small or large?''' It can range from -1 to +1
column2: and is an important measure when we evaluate the strength of a statistical relationship. Data points may scatter widely in a [[Correlation_Plots#Scatter_Plot|scatter plot
column3: ]] or there may be a rather linear relationship - and everything in between. An example for a perfect positive correlation (with a correlation coefficient ''r'' of +1) is the relationship between temperature in [[To_Rule_And_To_Measure#Celsius_vs_Fahrenheit_vs_Kelvin|Celsius and Fahrenheit]]. This should not be surprising
column4: since Fahrenheit is defined as 32 + 1.8° C. Therefore
column5: their relationship is perfectly linear
column6: which results in such a strong correlation coefficient. We can thus say that 100% of the variation in temperature in Fahrenheit is explained by the temperature in Celsius.

column2: you might encounter data of two variables that is scattered all the way in a scatter plot and you cannot find a significant relationship. The correlation coefficient ''r'' might be around 0.1
column3: or 0.2. Here
column4: you can assume that there is no strong relationship between these two variables
column5: and that one variable does not explain the other one.

column1: The stronger the correlation coefficient of a relation is
column2: the more may these relations matter
column3: some may argue. If the points are distributed like stars in the sky
column4: then the relationship is probably not significant and interesting. Of course this is not entirely generalisable
column5: but it is definitely true that a neutral relation only tells you
column6: that the relation does not matter. At the same time
column7: even weaker relations may give important initial insights into the data
column8: and if two variables show any kind of relation
column9: it is good to know the strength. By practising to quickly grasp the strength of a correlation
column10: you become really fast in understanding relationships in data. Having this kind of skill is essential for anyone interested in approximating facts through quantitative data.

column1: '''3) What does the relationship between two variables explain?'''
This is already an advanced skill
column2: and is rather related to regression analysis. So if you have looked at the strength of a correlation
column3: and its direction
column4: you are good to go generally. But sometimes
column5: these measures change in different parts of the data.

column2: let us have a look at the example of the percentage of people working in [https://ourworldindata.org/employment-in-agriculture?source=post_page--------------------------- Agriculture] within individual countries. Across the world
column3: people at a low income (<5000 Dollar/year) have a high variability in terms of agricultural employment:  half of the population of the Chad work in agriculture
column4: while in Zimbabwe it is only 10 %. However
column5: at an income above 15000 Dollar/year
column6: there is hardly any variance in the percentage of people that work in agriculture: it is always very low. If you plotted this
column7: you would see that the data points are rather broadly spread in the lower x-values (with x as the income)
column8: but are more linearly spread in the higher income areas (= x values). This has reasons
column9: and there are probably one or several variables that explain this variability. Maybe there are other factors that have a stronger influence on the percentage of farmers in lower income groups than for higher incomes
column10: where the income is a good predictor.

column1: A correlation analysis helps us identify such variances in the data relationship
column2: and we should look at correlation coefficients and the direction of the relationship for different parts of the data. We often have a stronger relation across parts of the dataset
column3: and a weaker relation across other parts of the dataset. These differences are important
column4: as they hint at underlying influencing variables or factors that we did not understand yet.

=== A quick introduction to regression lines ===

column2: '''correlation analysis is first and foremost a matter of identifying ''if'' and ''how'' two variables are related.''' We do not necessarily assume that we can predict the value of one variable based on the value of the other variable - we only see how they are related. People often show a correlation in a scatter plot - the x-axis is one variable
column3: the y-axis the other one. You can see this in the example below. Then
column4: they put a line on the data. This line - the ""regression line"" - represents the correlation coefficient. It is the best approximation for all data points. This means that this line has the minimum distance to all data points. If all data points are exactly on the line
column5: we have a correlation of +1 or -1 (depending on the direction of the line). However
column6: the further the data points are from the line
column7: the closer the correlation coefficient is to 0
column8: and the less meaningful the correlation is.

column1: [[File:Correlation coefficient examples.png|600px|thumb|center|'''Examples for the correlation coefficient.''' Source: Wikipedia
column2: Kiatdd
column3: CC BY-SA 3.0]]

column1: '''It is however important to know two things:'''

1) Do not confuse the slope of this line (the 'regression coefficient') - i.e. the number of y-values that the regression line steps per x-value - with the correlation coefficient. They are not the same
column2: and this often leads to confusion. The regression coefficient of the line can easily be 5 or 10
column3: but the correlation coefficient will always be between -1 and +1.

column1: 2) Regressions only really make sense if there is some kind of causal explanation for the relationship. We can create a regression line for all correlations of all pairs of two variables
column2: but we might end up suggesting a causal relationship when there really is none. As an example
column3: have a look at the correlation below. There is no regression line here
column4: but the visualisation implies that there is some connection
column5: right? However
column6: it does not really make sense that the divorce rate in Maine and the margarine consumption are related
column7: even though their correlation coefficient is obviously quite high! So you should always question correlations
column8: and ask yourself which kinds of variables are tested for their relationship
column9: and if you can derive meaningful results from doing so.

column1: [[File:860-header-explainer-correlationchart.jpg|500px|thumb|center|'''Correlations can be deceitful'''. Source: [http://www.tylervigen.com/spurious-correlations Spurious Correlations]]]
* Correlation analysis can be a powerful tool both for inductive reasoning
column2: without a theoretical foundation; or deductive reasoning
column3: which is based on theory. This makes it versatile and has enabled new discoveries as well as the support of existing theories.

column1: * The versatility of the method expands over all spatial and temporal scales
column2: and basically any discipline that uses continuous data. This makes it clear why correlation analysis has become such a powerhorse for many researchers over time
column3: and is so prevalent also in public debates.

column1: * Correlations are rather easy to apply
column2: and most software allows to derive simple scatterplots that can then be analyzed using correlations. However
column3: you need some minimal knowledge about data distribution
column4: since for instance the Pearson correlation is based on data that is normally distributed.

column1: * With the power of correlations comes a great responsibility for the researcher. It can be tempting to infer causality and a logical relatoinship between two variables purely from the results of correlations. Economics and other fields have a long history of causal interpretation based on observed associations from the results of correlation analyses. However
column2: researchers should always question whether there is a plausible connection between two variables
column3: even if - or especially when - the correlation seems so clear. A regression analysis
column4: that allows for the prediction of data beyond what can be observed
column5: should especially only be done if there is a logical underlying connection. Keep in mind that regression = correlation + causality. For more thoughts on the connection between correlations and causality
column6: have a look at this entry: [[Causality and correlation]].

column1: * Another normative problem of correlations is rooted in so called statistical fishing. With more and more data becoming available
column2: there is an increasing chance that certain correlations are just significant by chance
column3: for which there is a corrective procedure available called [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HLzS5wPqWR0 Bonferroni correction]. However
column4: this is seldom applied. Today
column5: p-value-driven statistics are increasingly seen critical
column6: and the resulting correlations should be seen as no more than an initial form of a mostly inductive analysis. With some practice
column7: p-value-driven statistics can be a robust tool to compare statistical relations in continuous data
column8: but more complex methods may be useful to better understand the relationships in the data.

column1: * There is an endless debate about what constitutes a meaninful
column2: strong correlation. Yet
column3: this depends widely on the context and the field of research - for some disciplines
column4: topics
column5: or research questions
column6: a correlation of +0.4 may be meaningful
column7: while it is mostly irrelevant in others. It is a matter of experience and contextualisation how much meaning we infer on correlation coefficients. Furthermore
column8: finding no correlation between two variables is an important statistical result
column9: too.

column1: Correlations are among the foundational pillars of frequentist statistics. Nonetheless
column2: with science engaging in more complex designs and analysis
column3: correlations will increasingly become less important. As a robust working horse for initial analysis
column4: however
column5: they will remain a good starting point for many datasets. Time will tell whether other approaches - such as [[Bayesian Inference|Bayesian statistics]] and [[Machine Learning|machine learning]] - will ultimately become more abundant. Correlations may benefit from a clear comparison to results based on Bayesian statistics. Until then
column6: we should all be aware of the possibilities and limits of correlations
column7: and what they can - and cannot - tell us about data and its underlying relationships.

column2: point counts and line transects are key methods for counting birds. They are suitable for many different groups and species of birds. Additional methods can be found in Sutherland (1996).

column1: '''Table 1. The use of the methods territory mapping
column2: point counts and line transects for different groups of birds (modified after Sutherland 1996).''' These methods were selected because they can be applied to most bird species.
'''+'''=method often applicable.

column1: | || Territory Mapping|| Line transects|| Point counts
'''Creating a map of all sampling points for each occasion'''
Territory mapping is a method used to study populations of territorial breeding species such as some ducks
column2: gamebirds
column3: raptors and most passerines. These species are territorial during the breeding season.  Males sing in their territory and defend the borders of their territory by disputes. Therefore
column4: the breeding territory is used as a census unit. Territory mapping determines the number of territories of each species in a given area. Multiple species can be mapped during one visit (1).

column2: the land cover of the study plot is mapped at a scale of commonly 1:2500. Then
column3: obvious features of the plot
column4: such as houses
column5: isolated trees
column6: hedges
column7: ponds etc. are marked on the map. In closed habitats such as temperate woodlands plot sizes of 15-20 ha are often sufficient. In a tropical forest
column8: even half of this area could already be suitable. However
column9: in more open habitats
column10: an area of 60-80 ha is needed (1).

column1: The length of the plot borders should be kept as short as possible by not selecting a long
column2: thin area. This is because many bird territories would be overlapping if the plot boundary was long. To determine if a territory belongs to the plot or not might be difficult in some cases. Therefore
column3: round or square plots should be preferred. Species-rich features such as hedges should also not be located at the plot boundary (1).

column2: 10 sampling visits per breeding season are recommended. In temperate open habitats
column3: 5 visits may already be sufficient. To cover both early and late breeding species
column4: the visits should be equally distributed throughout the whole breeding season. For songbirds
column5: the census should usually be started after the first hour of dawn and continue no longer than midday. The first hour after dawn may commonly be omitted because most birds are then singing
column6: which might be confusing in areas with high bird densities. After midday
column7: most birds stop singing which usually makes this time frame unsuitable as well. Each visit to a plot can be completed during a morning (1).

column2: in the beginning of the breeding season
column3: several plot maps are produced
column4: one for each visit. The map is attached to a clipboard that can be covered with a large polyethylene bag in case of rain. By walking at a slow pace
column5: the plot is covered with several routes in parallel with a 50 m distance in between the routes. Each bird that was heard or observed is marked at the location with a species code. Comments are made for evidence of nesting such as nests or birds carrying nesting material (1).

column1: If only a certain group of birds
column2: such as raptors
column3: is censused
column4: the same area can be covered much faster by ignoring all other species and mapping at a bigger scale (e.g.

column1: After the end of the breeding season
column2: the results for each species in each single-visit map are transferred to a species map covering all visits. This is done by marking each observation for visit 1 with an A on the species map
column3: for visit 2 with a B
column4: and so on. After the map is finished for each species
column5: circles are drawn around clusters of observations. Each cluster should contain at least two registrations for 5-7 visits and at least three for 8-10 visits. Each nest is automatically considered to be a cluster. There are different methods to deal with edge territories (1). We suggest considering a cluster to be within the plot if more than 50% of its registrations lie within the plot.

column1: Territory mapping is a very work-intensive method
column2: that requires good skills in bird identification by the observer. It cannot be applied to species that are colonial or live in loose groups. However
column3: due to the longer time spent in the field compared to line transects and point counts
column4: there is a lower impact of environmental variation such as the weather or the time of visit (1).

column1: Point counts are suitable for assessing the relative abundance of vocal or at least highly visible bird species such as passerines. They can be applied in a wide variety of habitats and at any time of the year
column2: not restricted to the breeding season. Fixed counting stations are placed across the study area
column3: either in a grid or in a random manner. From these locations
column4: birds are observed for a fixed time period
column5: usually between 3 and 10 minutes. Often
column6: five minutes are adequate (3).

column1: The distance between the counting stations should at least be 200 m to prevent counting the same individual twice. If the distance between the points is too large
column2: it takes too much time to travel from one counting station to the next. Per study plot
column3: at least 20 counting stations should be installed. To keep the minimum distance of 200 m in between the points
column4: the plot should not be too small (1).

column1: After arriving at the counting station
column2: wait a few minutes for the birds to resume their normal behavior. Then
column3: during the observation time
column4: all birds seen or heard are counted. As most of the birds will be counted in the first few minutes
column5: spending more than 10 minutes is usually inefficient and may lead to increased double counting. Only in areas with very rich bird fauna or where species are especially hard to detect
column6: spending more than 10 minutes might be necessary.

column2: the approximate location of every bird can be noted on a page of a notebook (1). The page can
column3: for example
column4: be divided into four quarters and birds recorded in these quarters (i.e. front-left
column5: front-right
column6: behind-left and behind-right).

column2: birds may be counted irrespective of the distance to the observer. Such approach is not suited
column3: though
column4: if comparisons are to be made between species and/or different habitats. To determine bird densities
column5: a “near belt” and a “far belt” are established. The near belt is usually 25 m (in closed habitats such as forests) or 50 m (in open habitats) around the counting station. Beyond this distance is the “far belt”. For each individual
column6: the observer notes if it was first seen in the near belt or in the far belt (1). Formulae for easy calculation of bird density based on this assessment can be found in (4) and (5).

column2: at least two observations should be conducted
column3: one in the beginning and one in the end of the period that should be covered
column4: e.g. the breeding season. For each plot
column5: the time of the day should be noted as this influences the activity and detectability of birds (1).

column1: Point counts are suitable for quickly collecting large amounts of data
column2: even outside of the breeding season. This method can be applied for all birds that can easily be detected by song. The observer
column3: however
column4: needs to have a high level of experience in determining different bird species by song. Compared to territory mapping
column5: counting stations can be distributed relatively easily in a random pattern (1).

column1: Since point counts often rely on the birds singing (or sometimes detecting them by eye)
column2: this method is unsuitable for less detectable species. The approach may also not be suited for open habitats where birds are likely to flee from the observer (1).

column1: Line transects are a method for counting birds of extensive open habitats. It is suitable for shrub-steppe
column2: moorland
column3: offshore seabirds and waterbirds. The observer moves freely through the land
column4: sea or air. Observers move along a route and note down all birds they see on either side. In the first step
column5: a route is determined that should be followed. This route should be positioned relatively randomly. It should not follow a path
column6: hedge
column7: stream
column8: road or similar features as the results obtained here may strongly differ from the surrounding area. Moreover
column9: counting seabirds from fishing trawlers should be prevented as they may attract birds (1).

column1: A transect route does not have to be straight
column2: but can also be rectangular allowing the observer to end at the starting point. The route should be planned so that following it during subsequent visits is as easy as possible. Therefore
column3: circular routes are not recommended (1).

column1: It is recommended to split the total length of the transect into smaller distances. These can directly continue into each other or they can be separated. If several transects should be undertaken
column2: they should be at least 150 m apart in closed habitats and at least 250 m apart in open habitats to prevent the observer from counting the same individual twice. Additionally
column3: the observers need to decide how often they want to visit the transects. It makes sense to complete the same transect several times as species detectability varies seasonally (1).

column2: to determine bird density
column3: a “near belt” and a “far belt” may need to be established for line transects. Commonly
column4: the near belt is 25 m to either side of the transect line. Beyond this distance is the “far belt”. For each individual
column5: the observer notes if it was first seen in the near belt or in the far belt. Formulae for easy calculation of bird density based on this assessment can be found in (4) and (5).

column1: Walking speed should be around 1 km (forests) to 2 km (open habitats) per hour. In a notebook with the schematic representation of the transect including the near belt and the far belt
column2: the location where the bird was first seen is recorded. Birds landing or singing overhead are recorded in the central belt while birds flying over are recorded in the far belt (1).

column1: Line transects are especially useful for large areas of homogenous habitat and areas where bird populations occur at low density. It is possible to calculate estimates of density. The costs for this method depend on the habitat. Terrestrial habitats can be censused relatively cheaply whereas sea habitats are more expensive as a ship is needed (1).
Territory mapping has a slight bias towards under-estimating the number of breeding pairs as paired males of some species sing less than unpaired males (6). The assumption of this method
column2: that birds live in pairs in non-overlapping territories
column3: is false for some species such as polygynous species and polyterritorial species. As there is a large proportion of subjectivity involved even when a standard protocol is used
column4: inter-observer variation can be an issue (1).

column1: The main bias for point counts is that the length of time spent in the field is rather short. Therefore
column2: the results can be strongly influenced by weather conditions. For this reason
column3: strong winds
column4: rain or cold weather are unsuitable for point counts (1). Moreover
column5: the presence of the observer might repel or attract birds that are close to the observer which can seriously impact calculations of bird density
column6: as the area sampled by a point count increases geometrically with the distance from the observer (7).

column1: Bird densities that are calculated based on line transects can be biased by several factors. For instance
column2: birds can easily be missed by walking too fast or counted twice by walking too slowly. Furthermore
column3: errors in the estimate of distances have a strong impact on the calculation of bird densities. Also
column4: it might happen that one bird is not detected because of being alarmed by other birds. This highlights that this method relies on assumptions that are
column5: in practice
column6: often not met (1).

column1: The development of bird census data sets is increasingly impacted by the growing movement of citizen science. Especially during the Covid-19 pandemic where many other leisure activities were not available due to restrictions
column2: many people turned to outdoor activities such as bird watching.

column1: This trend in citizen participation is supported by technical development making bird identification easier through the usage of identification apps. Smartphone apps such as “eBirds” help to identify species and also upload photos and the location where the individual was observed. This leads to a growing global online-community of bird watchers who create new data points in observation databases that scientists and environmentalists can make use of for conservation research or planning. For instance
column2: in Canada
column3: the number of people submitting photos to eBirds increased by 30% between 2019 and 2020 (8).

column1: Because many bird watchers are novices
column2: bird identification is not always carried out correctly. This is a general problem of citizen science. In the case of eBirds
column3: bird experts volunteer as reviewers who check photos for correct determination
column4: especially in the case of rare species that are uncommon in a certain area. This increases the quality of the data (8). However
column5: a study conducted in the UK has shown that citizen science data may be reliable only for widespread and common species
column6: even with many data points and a good coverage of the area (9).

column1: Scientists hope that [[Citizen_Science|citizen science]] data may fill data gaps
column2: for instance in the tropics. However
column3: comparisons to data from Bird Life International have shown that the bird abundances for rare species in the tropics are strongly over-estimated. A likely reason is that bird observers are very determined to find these rare species and thereby overlook or under-record more common species and focus on rare ones (10).

column2: as technology progresses
column3: identification apps are becoming better and easier to use. Moreover
column4: scientists are working on new approaches to include such data into their research in meaningful ways. This trend of increasing citizen participation is thus likely to continue.

column1: Telemetry is another method that was further developed in recent years
column2: although it has been used already for decades in wildlife ecology. Telemetry is “the system of determining information about an animal through the use of radio signals from or to a device carried by the animal” (11). For birds
column3: this method can be applied in areas ranging in size from restricted breeding territories of resident bird species to movement patterns of international migratory species. Also
column4: the distribution patterns of infectious diseases of migratory species can be tracked (11). However
column5: for some birds
column6: negative effects on nesting behavior were observed (12).

Cronbach's Alpha;"'''In short:''' Cronbach’s alpha is a measure used to estimate the reliability
column2: or internal consistency
column3: of a composite score or test items. It is calculated by correlating the score for each scale item with the total score for each observation (usually individual test takers)
column4: and then comparing that to the variance for all individual item scores.

column1: In the context of test-reliability Cronbach's Alpha is one way of measuring the extent to which a given measurement is a consistent measure of a [[Glossary|concept]]. The concept of Internal consistency can be connected to the interrelatedness of a set of items. It describes the extent to which all items in a test measure the same concept; it is connected to the inter-relatedness of the items within the test.

Imagine an individual takes a Happiness Survey. Your calculated happiness score would be highly reliable (consistent) if your test produces a similar result when the same individual re-takes the survey
column2: under the same conditions. However
column3: the measure would not be reliable at all if an individual at the same level of real happiness takes the Survey twice back-to-back and receives one high and one low happiness score. Cronbach's Alpha is sed under the assumption that you have multiple items measuring the same underlying construct. In this context you might have five questions asking different things
column4: but when combined
column5: could be said to measure overall happiness.

The first column contains the value for Cronbach's Alpha for the total scale (in this case 0.81)
The first column (raw_alpha) lists the scale's internal consistency if it does not contain the specific item.
The smaller this value is compared to the internal consistency for the total scale

N explains the number of valid values for each item. The columns mean (average) and sd (standard deviation) can be used as an indicator for the difficulty of the items.
The higher the mean of an item
column2: the easier it is to agree with this item. Items with very high or very low mean values should not be included in the scale because they are too easy or too difficult
column3: respectively.

column1: * The resulting alpha coefficient ranges from 0 to 1
* ''α = 0'' if all the items share no covariance and are not correlated which means that all the scale items are entirely independent from one another
* ''α will approach 1'' if the items have high covariances and are highly correlated. The higher the coefficient the more the items probably measure the same underlying concept
* ''Negative values for α'' indicate problems within your data e.g. you may have forgotten to reverse score some items.
When interpreting Cronbach's Alpha understandings for what makes a 'good' coefficient may differ according to your application field and depend on one's theoretical knowledge.
Most often methodologists recommend a minimum coefficient between ''0.65'' and ''0.8''. Values above 0.8 are considered as best in many cases where values less than 0.5 are unacceptable.

'''In short''': This entry introduces different data formats.
The format of your data influences everything else you do further down the road. To paraphrase a proverb
column2: data is in a format
column3: and the format is the data. Therefore
column4: it is essential to know which [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hZxnzfnt5v8 different data formats] exist
column5: and how these may be beneficial
column6: and where you may encounter pitfalls. For more information on different means of measurement
column7: please refer to the [[To Rule And To Measure|'To Rule And To Measure' entry.]]

column1: The most important difference is between quantitative data and qualitative data. Quantitative data can consist of integers and discrete data
column2: while qualitative data can be factorial -meaning in truely different categories- nominal or [[Data_formats#Ordinal_data|ordinal]]
column3: with the latter two providing a link to quantitative data. However
column4: within different areas of science
column5: the nomenclature for data formats widely differs
column6: and to be honest
column7: it is a mess. Here
column8: we try to be consistent
column9: yet please be aware that these names are not consistent across science.

column1: [[File:DataFormatsDiet.png|thumb|right|Tracking your diet is just one of many examples how you can approach different data formats.]]
Imagine you want to track your diet. Many people do this today
column2: there are diet books and advice everywhere
column3: much information has become available. Now you want to start and become more familiar with what you eat. How would you start? Counting calories? Differentiating between carbs
column4: fat and greens? Maybe you just count every time you ate a Pizza? Or ice cream? Or too much? There are many ways to measure your diet. And these measurement can be in different data formats.

column1: Most data formats can be transformed into other data formats
column2: which is often confusing for many people. For instance nominal data can be counted repeatedly
column3: you may for instance count the quite diverse and different cups of coffee you drink every day
column4: such as a Flat-white
column5: an American
column6: and two Espressi. The numbers of cups would then add up to cups of coffee
column7: which would represent discrete data. A different example would be temperature
column8: which could be represented as continuous data in degrees Celsius (never mind the Fahrenheit). While this can be represented in numbers
column9: it could also be represented in frosty temperature or temperature above 0°C.

column1: '''Quantitative data (numeric) is data that is expressed in numbers which can be used in a numerical sense
column2: ''' i.e. the numbers can be used to do calculations. There are three types of quantitative data: Continuous
column3: discrete and interval data.

column1: '''Continuous data is numerical data that cannot be counted because it exists on a finite or infinite number line.''' We are all familiar with continuous numbers. Much of our society is ruled by these numbers
column2: and thus much of data analysed in statistics is represented by continuous numbers. Since much of modern measurement is automated within a given predefined system
column3: we often do not have to worry too much how data looks like. Take for instance weight or size. Within [https://www.factmonster.com/math-science/weights-measures/metric-weights-and-measures Central Europe]
column4: this is clearly measured in Grams or Kilograms
column5: and in Centimeters or Meters
column6: respectively. However
column7: if you move to the US
column8: it becomes a whole different story
column9: because of the [[To Rule And To Measure|metric system
column10: or the lack thereof.]] Suddenly you are some feet tall
column11: and you may weigh some ""stones"". Many [https://www.factmonster.com/math-science/weights-measures/the-international-system-metric diverse measurement systems] exist
column12: and one has to be aware of how these were measured. Hence these systems are constructs
column13: and these constructs build on continuous numbers. Continuous numbers are widely used to express data
column14: but we have to be aware that this then still represents normative information.

column1: Continuous data has a true zero. A true zero is defined as a total absence of something that can be represented in numbers. Although a weight of 0 kg or a length of 0 m is abstract
column2: the values represent the absence of weight and length
column3: respectively.

column1: - typical weight of a naked mole-rat: 30 grams
- the height of the Empire State Building: 443
column2: 2m

column1: '''Discrete data is numeric data that can be counted because it only exists as natural numbers''' (1
column4: 4...). Examples of this are students in a lecture
column5: where the use a fraction numbers is not helpful. Of course
column6: you can think of an halved apple
column7: but usually
column8: if we count apples or birds or students
column9: we consider them as complete units and stick to natural numbers. Discrete data is often also referred to as 'abundance' or 'counting' data
column10: and within the R language it is called ""integer"".

column1: Discrete data also has a true zero. Take again the number of students in a statistics lecture. Although the lecture is good
column2: for example because it includes songs of Sesame Street
column3: there might be no students in the lecture. 0 students in a lecture – there you got your true zero.

column1: '''Interval data consists of measured or counted values
column2: but it does not have a true zero.''' Also
column3: the difference between two data points is equal no matter where on the scale you look. The best example is temperature if measured in °C. The difference between 30°C and 40°C is equal to the difference between 100°C and 110°C. However
column4: there is no true zero to the Celsius scale: 0°C does not mean that there is no temperature. Rather
column5: 0°C represents a specific value on the temperature scale. Therefore
column6: you can subtract and add up temperature data
column7: but you cannot meaningfully multiply or divide with it. In addition
column8: the lack of a real zero means that 40°C is not twice as much energy as 20°C
column9: although the value is twice as high.

column1: '''Qualitative (categorical) data in a statistical sense is data that can be stored in labeled categories which are independent from each other.''' Such categories are typically constructed
column2: and thus contain information that is deeply normative or designed. An example would be hair color
column3: which can be in human perceptions of colours
column4: yet is often also described with different names when it comes to professional hair products. Within statistics
column5: categories are often designed so that within a scientific experiment
column6: categories are constructed in a sense that allows for a meaningful testing of the hypothesis
column7: and meaningful is then in the eye of the beholder. Different levels of fertiliser would be such an example
column8: and the categories would often be built around previous knowledge or pre-tests. Categories are thus of particular importance when it comes to the reduction of the complexity of the world
column9: as it would not be possible to test all sorts of different levels of fertiliser in an experiment. Instead
column10: you might go with ""little""
column11: ""moderate""
column12: ""much"" and ""very much"" fertilizer. Nevertheless
column13: this demands a clear recognition that and how categories are constructed
column14: and deeply normative.

column1: There are two types of qualitative data: ordinal data and nominal data - and then there is binary data
column2: which is basically also nominal.

column1: [[File: Ordinal Data.jpg|thumb|right|'''School grades are an example of ordinal data.''']]
'''Ordinal data is categorical data that can be ranked
column2: but not calculated with
column3: even if it is represented in numbers'''. Remember your school grades? A ""1"" is the best grade in the German grading system
column4: but is it twice as good than a ""2""? Hardly. Such grades are [http://intellspot.com/nominal-vs-ordinal-data/ ordinal numbers]. These are a system of numbers that are ranked in some sense
column5: but the numbers per se do not necessarily reflect a numeric system. In other words
column6: they are highly normative and contested. A ""2"" might be a good grade for some
column7: and a disaster for others. Ordinal formats are often clearly defined scales that allow people to grade
column8: evaluate or rank certain information. One of the most prominent examples is the [[Likert Scale|Likert scale]] that is often used in Psychology. In this case
column9: the scaling is often not reflected in numbers at all
column10: but in levels such as ""Strongly Agree"" or ""Rather Disagree"". Such constructed scales may make a true statistician very unhappy
column11: since these scales are hard to analyse
column12: yet there is hardly any alternative since it also does not make any sense to ask: ""How happy are you on a scale from 1 to 100?"". Therefore
column13: ordinal scales are often relevant in order to create a scaling system that allows for wide comparability or even becomes a norm
column14: such as school grades. My advise would be to [https://sciencing.com/advantages-disadvantages-using-ordinal-measurement-12043783.html use ordinal scales] when this is common practise in this branch of science. Read other studies in the field
column15: and then decide. These are highly constructed scales
column16: hence there needs to be clear reasoning on why you want to use them.

column1: [[File: Gummy Bears.jpg|thumb|right|'''Gummy bears are a nice example for data formats.''' You can classify them by color
column2: which would be nominal data. But if you weigh them
column3: you get continuous data again.]]

column1: '''Whenever you have categorical data that cannot be ranked
column2: it is called [https://formpl.us/blog/nominal-data nominal data]'''. An example would be different ethnicities
column3: countries of birth
column4: or different types of gender. This already highlights that we are here confronted by often completely different worldviews
column5: thus nominal data represents a stark case of a normative view of the world. Gender is a prominent example
column6: since some people still define gender by a biological stereotype (Female/Male) and thus binary (see below)
column7: which according to my worldview is clearly wrong
column8: and I see Gender as nominal with more than two categories. Nominal data formats hence demand an even clearer reflection than ordinal data
column9: where at least you may say that a certain school grade is higher than another one. This is not the case for nominal data. Therefore
column10: one has to be extra careful about the implications
column11: that a specific constructed scale may imply.

column1: '''Binary data is the most reduced data format
column2: which basically consists of two levels: 1 and 0.''' It is
column3: strictly speaking
column4: nominal data
column5: but nominal data that only exists in two versions which can be translated into 1 and 0: On / Off
column6: Yes / No. In [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ewokFOSxabs computer science] binary data is used directly as simple 0 and 1
column7: but the great breakthrough of that dataset was early on in the insurance business as well as in medicine
column8: where 'dead' or 'alive' are often the most fundamental questions. Binary information is clearly simplistic
column9: but quite often this matches with a certain view of reality. Take the example of being able to play an instrument. If somebody asks you whether you can play the piano
column10: you will probably say ''yes'' or ''no''. You may most likely not qualify your answer by saying ""I play better than a monkey
column11: but worse than Horowitz"". Some modest folks may say ""I can play a bit""
column12: or ""I am not very good""
column13: or ""I used to be better""
column14: but very often people answer ''yes'' or ''no''. Hence binary data allows for a simple view of reality
column15: and this may often match with the world how we perceive it. But be aware: Other people may have a less simple view.

column1: You may wonder now how to choose the right data format for your data gathering. The answer to that is quite simple. '''Any data format should be as simple as possible
column2: and as complex as necessary.''' Follow Occam's razor
column3: and you will be fine. Of course this sounds appealing
column4: but how to know what is too simple
column5: and what is too complex? Here
column6: I suggest you build on the available literature. Read other publications that examined a certain phenomenon before
column7: these papers may guide you in choosing the right scale.

Deconstruction;"'''In short:''' Deconstruction is a practice of reading texts that revolves around the (in)stability of linguistic signs and their meaning.

column2: which emerged at the beginning of the 20th century
column3: reached its peak in France in the 1960s. Structuralism
column4: grounded in the theory of signs by the Swiss linguist Ferdinand de Saussure (3)
column5: is particularly concerned with the assumption that there are underlying structures to everything that produce objective
column6: definitive meaning and provide the framework within which actions can be performed. Poststructuralism
column7: which began to emerge in the mid-1960s
column8: called into question the existence of such structures. It was now necessary to break up the previously assumed stable structures and let them collapse (3). '''An important approach to this was deconstruction
column9: which goes back to the French philosopher Jacques Derrida (1930-2004).''' He first spoke of deconstruction in his book ""Of grammatology""
column10: published in 1967.

column1: [[File:Deconstruction Image.jpg|400px|thumb|right|'''Linguistic sign „tree“ according to Saussure’s sign system.''' Source: own.]]

column2: Derrida criticized structuralism and illustrated this with the example of Saussure's sign system (7). '''Fundamental to Saussure's sign system is the assumption that a linguistic sign always consists of a signified  (e.g.
column3: an object)
column4: and a signifier (e.g.
column5: a word for this object).''' The figure on the right exemplifies the linguistic sign ""tree"" with its two components - the content level (signified) and the expression level (signifier). According to Saussure
column6: a signifier is assigned - arbitrarily but nevertheless unambiguously - to a signified
column7: and the meaning of the signified results from the demarcation of the signifier from other signifiers - often as binary opposites (3
column8: 6). The idea is that the tree  - the signified - can be unambiguously explained by the word „tree“ – the signifier - because the word „tree“ can clearly be differentiated from other words.

column1: Derrida saw a problem in this unambiguous assignment and the resulting binary opposition structure. '''For Derrida
column2: signifier and signified do not stand in an unambiguous relationship'''; rather
column3: their positions in the system can change. That is
column4: a signified can become a signifier and vice versa. For the example of ""tree"" this can be explained as follows: If the sign ""tree"" is unknown in its meaning
column5: one can look up the signifier  T R E E and receive a (simplified) meaning
column6: i.e. the signified
column7: ""plant"". At the same time
column8: ""plant"" in this case is also another linguistic sign. If one now also does not know the meaning of the sign ""plant""
column9: one again looks up the signifier P L A N T. This way
column10: ""plant""
column11: which was originally the signified for the sign „tree“ becomes the signifier of another sign with ist own signified. Consequently
column12: the previously assumed/existing structure of the sign is not rigid and unambiguous
column13: but unstable and movable (3).

column2: '''Derrida assumed that an unambiguous meaning could never be achieved'''
column3: since every sign with its signifier always refers to other signs that either precede or follow it
column4: and accordingly deconstructs and shifts its own meaning (7). He therefore introduced the neologism ‚différance‘. Différance describes the never-ending shift in meaning that results from the instability and ambiguity of concepts. It highlights that a term can have several meanings or its meaning can be shifted
column5: depending on the context in which it exists and is read (5).

column2: a sign is to be understood as a construct and deconstruction offers a possibility to deal with it (5). The main point is to emphasize the non-naturalness
column3: the non-originality of a term and to show the external influences that have shaped it in the course of time (5). That is
column4: terms can never depict absolutely unambiguously and universally what they try to depict
column5: since they usually once held a completely different - or at least slightly shifted - meaning. Thus
column6: they unconsciously always say more or something else than they want to say. '''With deconstruction
column7: this historicity - Derrida spoke of ‚trace‘ - of concepts is to be uncovered and made visible.''' It shall be shown that there is neither a first
column8: original nor a last
column9: final meaning (5).

column2: binary opposition structures of structuralism (e.g. language/writing
column3: man/woman
column4: reason/madness
column5: heterosexuality/homosexuality) are supposed to be broken up with the help of deconstruction. Derrida perceived this in its strict hierarchy of values as not neutral and consequently not logical (3). Due to the hierarchical structure
column6: one part would always be perceived as original/""normal""/superior
column7: while the other part would be seen as derivative and thus less valuable. However
column8: Derrida's goal in deconstruction was not to completely abandon the concepts or to reverse the hierarchy of values
column9: because in his opinion the concepts depend on each other and constitute each other in the first place. Instead
column10: deconstruction should shift the entire system
column11: which with its rigid structures enables the formation of such hierarchies
column12: by making visible the instability and ambiguity of the individual concepts (2).

column2: however
column3: was conceived by Derrida less as ""a method or some tool that you apply to something from the outside"" (Derrida & Caputo 2020
column4: p.9). While scientific methods are seen as ""settled and stable"" (Feustel 2015
column6: deconstruction instead emphasizes the instability not only of the respective object
column7: but also of one's own approach and goal (5). '''Accordingly
column8: deconstruction is to be seen more as an art of reading
column9: of shifting meaning
column10: which occurs from within but must be made visible''' (4).

column2: especially in the USA
column3: the so-called Yale School
column4: whose representatives included Paul de Man
column5: Harold Bloom
column6: Geoffrey Hartman and Hillis Miller. They conceived of deconstruction as a poststructuralist reading for the analysis and critique of texts
column7: and developed it further in their own work (1).

column1: Deconstruction is also drawn upon in gender and queer studies. Deconstruction is particularly prominently linked to gender theory in the work of the US philo-sopher Judith Butler. Butler questions and deconstructs the sex-gender distinction by hypothesizing that not only social sex (gender) but also biological sex (sex) is only constituted by the - partly socially enforced - constant repetition of certain practices and thus cannot be assumed as natural (2). Other representatives of deconstructive feminist theory include Hélène Cixous
column2: Luce Irigaray
column3: and Gayatri Chakravorty Spivak.

'''In short:''' The Delphi Method is an interactive form of data gathering in which expert opinions are summarized and consensus is facilitated.
The Delphi method originates from work at RAND Corporation
column2: a US think-tank that advises the US military
column3: in the late 1940s and 1950s (2
column5: 5). RAND developed ""Project Delphi"" as a mean of obtaining ""(...) the most reliable consensus of opinion of a group of experts."" (Dalkey & Helmer 1963
column6: p.1). At the time
column7: the alternative - extensive gathering and analysis of quantitative data as a basis for forecasting and deliberating on future issues - was not technologically feasible (4
column8: 5). Instead
column9: experts were invited and asked for their opinions - and Delphi was born (see (1)).

column1: [[File:Delphi Method SCOPUS.png|400px|thumb|right|'''SCOPUS hits for the Delphi method until 2019.''' Search terms: 'Delphi Panel'
