column4: 'Delphi Study'
column5: 'Delphi Survey' in Title
column6: Abstract
column7: Keywords. Source: own.]]

column2: a RAND report from Gordon & Helmer brought the method to attention for a wider audience outside the military defense field (4
column3: 5). Subsequently
column4: Delphi became a prominent method in technological forecasting; it was also adapted in management; in fields such as drug policy
column5: education
column6: urban planning; and applied in order to understand economic and social phenomena (2
column8: 5). An important field today is the healthcare sector (7). While during the first decade of its use the Delphi method was mostly about forecasting future scenarios
column9: a second form was developed later that focused on concept & [[Glossary|framework]] development (3).

column1: Delphi was first applied in these non-scientific fields before it reached academia (4). Here
column2: it can be a beneficial method to identify topics
column3: questions
column4: terminologies
column5: constructs or theoretical perspectives for research endeavours (3).

column1: The Delphi method is ""(...) a systematic and interactive research technique for obtaining the judgment of a panel of independent experts on a specific topics"" (Hallowell & Gambatese 2010
column2: p.99). It is used ""(...) to obtain
column3: exchange
column4: and develop informed opinion on a particular topic"" and shall provide ""(...) a constructive forum in which consensus may occur"" (Rayens & Hahn 2000
column5: p.309). Put simply
column6: experts on a topic are gathered and asked in a systematic process what they think about the future
column7: until consensus is found.

column1: [[File:ResultVisualisationDelphi.png|400px|thumb|right|Questionnaire results for the original RAND study
column2: asking for an estimate of bomb requirements. The estimated numbers per participant converge over the course of the Delphi procedure. Source: Dalkey & Helmer 1963

column1: '''A Delphi process typically undergoes four phases''' (see (4)
1. A group of experts / stakeholders on a specific issue is identified and invited as participants for the Delphi. These participants represent different backgrounds: academics
column2: government and non-government officials as wel
column3: as practitioners. They should have a diverse set of perspectives and profound knowledge on the discussed issues. They may be grouped based on their organizations
column4: skills
column5: disciplines or qualifications (3). Their number typically ranges from 10 up to 30
column6: depending on the complexity of the issue (2

column1: The researchers then develop a questionnaire. It is informed by previous research as well as input from external experts (not the participants) who are asked to contribute knowledge and potential questions on the pertinent issue (2
column2: 5). The amount of [[Glossary|consultation]] depends on the expertise of the researchers on the respective issue (2).

column1: 2. The questionnaire is used to ask for the participants' opinions and positions related to the underlying issue. The questions often take a 'ranking-type' (3): they ask about the likelihood of potential future situations
column2: the desirability of certain goals
column3: the importance of specific issues and the feasibility of potential policy options. Participants may be asked to rank the answer options
column4: e.g. from least to most desirable
column5: least to most feasible etc. (2). Participants may also be asked yes/no questions
column6: or to provide an estimate as a number. They can provide further information on their answers in written form. (8)

column1: The questioning is most commonly conducted in form of a questionnaire but has more recently also been realized as individual
column2: group
column3: phone or digital interview sessions (2
column4: 5). Digital questioning allows for real-time assessments of the answers and thus a quicker process. However
column5: a step-by-step procedure provides more time for the researchers to analyze the responses (4).

column2: the participants' answers are analyzed both in terms of tendency and variability. The questionnaire is adapted to the new insights: questions that already indicated consensus on a specific aspect of the issue are abandoned while disagreements are further included. 'Consensus' may be defined based on a certain percentage of participants agreeing to one option
column3: the median of the responses or a degree of standard deviation
column4: among other definitions (2
column7: 7). New questions may be added to the questionnaire and existing questions may be rephrased based on the first set of answers (4).

column2: the experts are again asked for their opinions on the newly adapted set of questions. This time
column3: the summarized but - this is important - anonymous group results from the first round are communicated to them. This feedback is crucial in the Delphi method. It incentivizes the participants to revise their previous responses based on their new knowledge on the group's positions and thus facilitates consensus. The participants may also provide reasons for their positions (5
column4: 6). Again
column5: the results are analyzed. The process continues in several rounds (typically 2-5) until a satisfactory degree of consensus among all participants is reached (2-6).

column2: the results of the process are summarized and evaluated for all participants (4).

column1: The literature indicates a variety of benefits that the Delphi method offers.
* Delphi originally emerged due to a lack of data that would have been necessary for traditional forecasting methods. To this day
column2: such a lack of empirical data or theoretical foundations to approach a problem remains a reason to choose Delphi. Delphi may also be an appropriate choice if the collective subjective judgment by the experts is beneficial to the problem-solving process (2

column1: * Delphi can be used as a form of group counseling when other forms
column2: such as face-to-face interactions between multiple stakeholders
column3: are not feasible or even detrimental to the process due to counterproductive group dynamics (4

column1: * The value of the Delphi method is that it reveals clearly those ideas that are the reason for disagreements between stakeholders
column2: and those that are consensual (5).

column1: * Delphi can be ""(...) a highly motivating experience for participants"" (Rayens & Hahn 2000
column2: p.309) due to the feedback on the group's opinions that is provided in subsequent questioning stages.

column1: * The Delphi method with its feedback characteristic has advantages over direct confrontation of the experts
column2: which ""(...) all too often induces the hasty formulation of preconceived notions
column3: an inclination to close one's mind to novel ideas
column4: a tendency to defend a stand once taken
column5: or
column6: alternatively and sometimes alternately
column7: a predisposition to be swayed by persuasively stated opinions of others."" (Okoli & Pawlowski 2004
column9: after Dalkey & Helmer)

column2: Delphi provides several advantages over traditional surveys:

column1: ** Studies have shown that averages of group responses are superior to averages of individual responses. (3)
** Non-response and drop-out of participants is low in Delphi processes. (3)

** The availability of the experts involved allows for the researchers to (a) get their precognitions on the issue verified by the participating experts and to (b) gain further qualitative data after the Delphi process. (3)

column2: several potential pitfalls and challenges may arise during the Delphi process:

column1: * Delphi should not be used as a surrogate for every other type of communication - it is not feasible for every issue (4
* A specific Delphi format that was useful in one study must not work as well in another context. Instead
column2: the process must be adapted to the research design and underlying problem (4).

column1: * The proper selection of participating experts constitutes a major challenge for Delphi processes (3
column4: 6). In addition
column5: the researchers should be aware that any expert is likely to forecast based on their specific sub-system perspective and might neglect other factors (4).

column1: * The monitor (= researcher) must not impose their own preconceptions upon the respondents when developing the questionnaire but be open for contributions from the participants. The questions should be concise and understandable and should not incentivise the participant to ""get the job over with"" (Linstone & Turoff 1975
* Diverse forms of [[Glossary|bias]] might occur on the part of the participants that need to be anticipated by the researcher. These include discount of the future
column2: over-optimism / over-pessimism
column3: misinterpretations with regard to the complexity and uncertainty involved in forecasting the future as well as other forms of bias that may be imposed through the feedback process (4

column1: * The responses must be adequately summarized
column2: analyzed and presented to the participants (see the variety of measures for 'consensus' in What the method does)). ""Agreement about a recommendation
column3: future event
column4: or potential decision does not disclose whether the individuals agreeing did so for the same underlying reasons. Failure to pursue these reasons can lead to dangerously false results."" (Linstone & Turoff 1975

column1: * Disagreements between participants should be explored instead of being ignored so that the final consensus is not artificial (4).
* The participants should be recompensated for their demanding task (4)
* While Delphi is a common forecasting method
column2: backcasting methods (such as [[Visioning & Backcasting|Visioning]]) or [[Scenario Planning]] may also be applied in order to evaluate potential future scenarios without tapping into some of the issues associated with forecasting (see more in the [[Visioning|Visioning]] entry)
and the conceptual insights gathered during the process
column3: can be a starting point for subsequent research processes.

column1: * Delphi can be combined with qualitative or quantitative methods beforehand (to gain deeper insights into the problem to be discussed) and afterwards (to gather further data).
==== Everything normative related to this method ====
* The Delphi method is highly normative because it revolves around the subjective opinions of stakeholders.
* The selection of the participating experts is a normative endeavour and must be done carefully so as to ensure a variety of perspectives.

* Delphi is an instrument of [[Transdisciplinarity|transdisciplinary]] research that may be used both to find potential policy options as well as to further academic proceedings. Normativity is deeply rooted in this connection between academia and the 'real-world'.
* The diverse fields in which the Delphi method was applied has diversified and thus potentially confounded its methodological homogeneity
column2: raising the need for a more comparable application and reporting of the method (6

column1: [[File:Delphi - Exemplary study Kauko & Palmroos 2014 title.png|600px|frameless|center|The title of the exemplary study for Delphi method. Source: kauko & Palmroos 2014]]

column2: Kauko & Palmroos present their results from a Delphi process with financial experts in Finland. They held a Delphi session with five individuals from the Bank of Finland
column3: and the Financial Supervisory Authority of Finland
column4: each. Every individual was anonymized with a self-chosen pseudonym so that the researchers could track the development of their responses. '''The participants were asked questions in a questionnaire that revolved around the close future of domestic financial markets.''' Specifically
column5: the participants were asked to numerically forecast 15 different variables (e.g. stock market turnover
column6: interest in corporate loans
column7: banks' foreign net assets etc.) with simple point estimates. These variables were chosen to ""fall within the field of expertise of the respondents
column8: and at the same time be as independent of each other as possible."" (p.316). The participants were provided with information on the past developments of each of these variables.

column1: The researchers decided to go with three rounds until consensus should be reached. For the first round
column2: questionnaires were distributed by mail
column3: and the participants had one week to answer them. The second and third round were held on the same day after this one-week period. '''The responses from the respective previous round were re-distributed to the participants''' (each individual answer including additional comments
column4: as well as the group average and the median for each variable). The participants were asked to consider this information
column5: and answer all 15 questions - i.e.
column6: forecast all 15 variables - again.

column2: the participants were additionally asked to fill out survey questions on a 1-5 [[Likert Scale]] about how reliable their considered their own forecasts
column3: and how much attention they had paid to the others' forecasts and comments when these were re-distributed
column4: both regarding each variable individually. This was done to better understand each individual's thought process.

column1: [[File:Delphi - Exemplary study Kauko & Palmroos 2014 results.png|800px|thumb|center|'''The results for the Delphi process.''' It shows that the mean estimates of the group became better over time
column2: and were most often quite close to the actual realisation. Source: Kauko & Palmroos 2014

column1: The forecasting results from the Delphi process could be verified or falsified with the real developments over the next months and years
column2: so that the researchers were able to check whether the responses actually got better during the Delphi process. '''They found that the individual responses did indeed converge over the Delphi process
column3: and that the ""Delphi group improved between rounds 1 and 3 in 13 of the questions.""''' (p.320). They also found that ""[d]isagreeing with the rest of the group increased the probability of adopting a new opinion
column4: which was usually an improvement"" (p.322) and that the Delphi process ""clearly outperformed simple trend extrapolations based on the assumption that the growth rates observed in the past will continue in the future""
column5: which they had calculated prior to the Delphi (p.324). Based on the post-Delphi survey answers
column6: and the results for the 15 variables
column7: the researchers further inferred that ""paying attention to each others' answers made the forecasts more accurate"" (p.320)
column8: and that the participants were well able to assess the accuracy of their own estimates. The researchers calculated many more measures and a comparison to a non-Delphi forecasting round
column9: which you can read more about in the publication. Overall
column10: this example shows that the Delphi method works in that it leads to more accurate results over time
column11: and that the process itself helps individuals better forecast than traditional forecasts would.

'''In short:''' Dendrochronology is concerned with the analysis of tree rings
column2: whose chronological sequence can be used to date wood samples and infer information on environmental conditions
column3: stressors and their effects on the plant species.

column1: [[File:ResultVisualisationDENDROCHRONOLOGY.png|450px|thumb|left|Figure 1: modern dendrochronology lab with software for measuring and cross-dating rings and a scanner (1)]]
[[File:Figure3 CrosssectionDENDROCHRONOLOGY.png|thumb|right|Figure 3: cross section of tree with pith
column2: cambium
column3: xylem
column4: phloem and bark (4).]]

column1: [[File:Figure4 CrosssectionDENDROCHRONOLOGY.png|thumb|right|Figure 4: Cross section of basswood stained and 40x magnified (Tilia). (a) One year old stem. (b) Two years old stem. (c) Three years old stem. Numbers in figures b and c indicate the growth rings (based on (5)
Various scientists had been aware of tree rings and their connection to climate for several centuries already
column2: however the term ‘dendrochronology’ was coined by A. E. Douglass from the University of Arizona in 1929. He used the method of tree-ring dating to determine the age of ancient indigenous buildings
column3: which helped the Navajo peoples’ compensatory claims to succeed (2).

column1: Tree ring analysis or dendrochronology is applied in many disciplines like climatology
column2: archaeology
column3: biology
column4: hydrology and forestry. It can be applied to any plant species that has a woody growth type (including shrubs) and any woody parts of the plants (including branches
column5: twigs and roots). Seasonal growth
column6: the number of growth rings and the ring widths
column7: is determined by the interaction of genetic and environmental factors. For example
column8: a poplar forms wider rings than a bilberry growing under the same climatic conditions (3). Furthermore
column9: in order to analyse seasonal growth rings only one environmental factor must dominate in limiting the growth. This limiting factor can be precipitation in arid
column10: semi-arid or tropical parts of the world or temperature like in the temperate regions (e. g. dry and wet season in tropical forests
column11: winter and summer in temperate forests).

column1: The structure we see as rings is a sequence of earlywood and latewood in the secondary xylem tissue of a stem. Secondary growth reflects an increase in thickness
column2: or lateral additions of new tissue
column3: and essentially this secondary xylem is an important resource known as wood. The xylem is the water and nutrient conducting tissue in vascular plants. Cells for the secondary xylem are generated by the cambium layer. The cambium is a zone of undifferentiated cells that produce cells of the xylem to the centre of the stem and cells of phloem to the outer part of the stem. The phloem is the plant tissue for transport of sugars (assimilates). Xylem and phloem together form the vascular system of plants throughout the stems
column4: branches and roots. For every vegetation period
column5: governed by one limiting environmental factor
column6: the cambium generates xylem to the inside of the stem and phloem to the outside. The cambium will generate more secondary xylem than phloem and old outer phloem tissue will be crushed and eventually become bark. This is why woody species accumulate more and more secondary xylem each year and not secondary phloem. The oldest rings are close to the centre of the tree stem
column7: the youngest near the cambium and bark (Fig. 3).

column1: Growth rings can be recognized because in the beginning of the vegetation period earlywood is being produced with larger
column2: thin-walled cells
column3: whereas at the end of the vegetation period latewood with smaller
column4: thick-walled cells is produced that appears darker. The abrupt change between latewood and earlywood cells is the annual growth boundary that can be usually also recognized without magnification (Fig. 4).

column1: [[File:Figure5 CrossdatingDENDROCHRONOLOGY.png|300px|thumb|right|Figure 5: Cuts of two specimen that have been correctly cross-dated (2)]]
Dendrochronologists are interested in the chronological sequence of growth rings. In order to establish a dendrochronology of a certain area
column2: scientists compare tree rings of individuals of one species. For this purpose
column3: this species must only add one ring per growing season
column4: the growth-limiting climatic factor must vary in intensity from year to year
column5: and should be uniformly effective over a large geographic area (i. e. the relative annual difference in intensity is similar throughout the macroclimatic region). The variation in the growth-limiting factor must be reflected in the width of the tree rings. If these conditions are fulfilled scientists can recognize specific sequences that are of use for cross-dating or matching ring patterns between specimens (see (2) for an introduction and Fig. 5). Which species makes most sense to study depends on many factors
column6: like the research objective
column7: conditions in the study area
column8: abundance and properties of the species.

column1: Dendrochronology is a method of data gathering and analysis. The findings can then be interpreted
column2: for instance in regards to tree wellbeing or climate. To collect the data
column3: core sampling of living trees is performed with an increment borer (Fig 6). The increment borer consists of a handle
column4: a borer and an extraction spoon. This tool removes a sample from the stem leaving a hole of about 5 mm wide half the stem diameter deep. This hole quickly fills with sap; however
column5: it is still an invasive method that could allow parasites or fungi to enter the bore hole. Therefore
column6: the tool should be cleaned after each usage and sampling should be done with care and only when it is necessary.

column1: Selection of sampling sites and individual trees depends on the research question. Usually
column2: researchers are interested in investigating variability within years. To this end
column3: trees that do not have underground water access are sampled. Trees growing under these conditions will have so called sensitive ring sequences useful for dating
column4: in contrast to trees with underground water access
column5: that will have so called complacent ring sequences with equally narrow or wide rings. Core samples are therefore preferably taken from trees growing on the top of the slope. The increment borer is placed at a 90° angle on the stem facing the side slope. This means neither facing uphill nor downhill to avoid areas where the ring patterns are likely to be distorted

column1: It is important to take field notes on the immediate environment of the sampled tree
column2: since this information on growth-affecting parameters will be necessary for interpretation later (e. g. Table 1). When possible
column3: samples are taken well below the first branch facing the side of the slope. After choosing a suitable area on the stem
column4: put beeswax on the borer tip and place the tip of the increment borer at a 90° angle on the stem. Turn the handle clockwise to drill into the tree. Aim the borer at the pith. After the borer has reached the desired depth (middle of the stem)
column5: insert the extraction spoon into the borer from the handle end. When the extraction spoon is fully inserted between the wood core and the metal sides of the borer
column6: give the borer a full turn counter clockwise. Remove the extraction spoon with the sample from the borer. Place the sample in the envelope or mount (most recent rings orientated to the right side of the mount). Remove the borer from the tree by turning it counter clockwise. Clean the inside with WD 40.

column1: The core sample will shrink and bend while drying. Therefore
column2: place the core sample in a slotted mount and fixate with pushpins for air drying. After drying for about one week
column3: cut off the core top with a core microtome to create a smooth straight surface (Fig. 7).

column1: The visual inspection is done on a measuring table with a resolution of 0.01 mm and a microscope. Values are then digitalised
column2: plotted and analysed with computer software (e. g. IML Software T-Tools Pro
column3: Instrumenta Mechanik Labor GmbH). The number of rings and any distinct patterns (frequency of narrow or wide rings) are often what to look out for in this step.

column1: An advantage of this method is
column2: that it can be applied to all woody (parts of) plants. One can sample the living organisms by taking only a small-diameter core sample. After dendrochronologically analysing a representative amount of the population
column3: one can statistically calculate an estimate
column4: which allows the researcher to assume the age of other branches/roots/etc. from that population based on their diameter without sampling them. The method can also be applied to tree stumps of logged trees or wood used as building material and charcoal samples to date an archaeological site.

column1: Picking a representative sample of plants to account for the natural variability as well as taking the necessary number of samples can be difficult
column2: for example in steep terrain. The high pressure from competition in dense plant coverage and also injuries and diseases can affect a plants growth and obscure the influence of the climatic factor. Decayed wood is not useful for dendrochronological analysis. One should also consider the hardness of the wood of the species of interest. Bore holes are more difficult to drill into certain species
column3: like Hornbeam and Robinia.

column1: Distinguishing the growth rings is another challenge of varying difficulty depending on the species. Coniferous trees tend to have very clear growth rings. With oak and beech
column2: the rings usually also are fairly clear
column3: whereas the growth rings of hornbeam are way less easy to see.

column2: abnormalities can occur in the ring patterns
column3: which one has to be aware of when cross dating several samples. The ring of a year with extremely little growth could be locally absent at the sampled point of the stem. It is not missing on the whole stem
column4: widths of rings vary lightly across the stem of a tree. Similarly
column5: double or false rings can form in parts of the stem
column6: meaning that there are two dark bands from one year. Causes for this are not well understood yet. Taking two samples of the same tree decreases the chance that any such irregularity is missed in analysis.

column1: Although the bore hole is relatively small in diameter
column2: this method still is invasive and pathogens could enter the plant system through the wound caused by the borer
column3: potentially leading to disease or even death of the plant due to the research. As a guiding principle for ecological sampling
column4: researchers should cause as little disturbance as possible. One should therefore consider alternatives and choose the least invasive method applicable and accessible.

column1: Uncertainty results from the subjective experience and view of the researcher. The quality and clarity of the core samples depends on the experience of the researcher with taking and preparing samples. At the analysis step
column2: different people might count the growth rings differently. Especially if multiple researchers are working on the same project
column3: it thus is necessary to agree on and document how is counted
column4: in order to ensure comparability and reproducibility.

column1: One practical application of dendrochronology was the Navajo Land Claim Project. For 18 years from 1951 onwards
column2: the University of Arizona’s Laboratory of Tree-Ring Research and the Navajo Tribe worked together
column3: closely linking science and society. They took thousands of samples from living trees and old Navajo hogans in and around the Navajo Reservation. Cross-dating the samples provided evidence
column4: that the Navajo peoples had formerly occupied areas outside their reservation
column5: which they had been evicted from (10). Therefore
column6: the United States Land Claims Commission acknowledged the tribe to be eligible for compensation (2).

column1: Tree ring analysis is also applied to determine the health status of individuals or forests and effects of climate change (dendroclimatology). Based on the growth of these long-lived species one can interfere with past environmental conditions and current stressors. Due to climate change
column2: years with droughts increase but on the other hand the length of growing seasons also increases. How this affects different species and forest composition can be investigated through tree ring analysis. Thus
column3: dendrochronology can help foresters in making their woods future-proof and sustainable. It could also play a role in the selection and management of city trees. On a local or regional scale
column4: insights gained from tree ring analysis might inform climate adaptation measures which involve plants.

column2: less invasive tools are being developed for collecting data on growth rings of living trees. In forestry
column3: even thinner borers are in use already
column4: reducing the possible negative impacts on plant health.

'''Descriptive stats are what most people think stats are all about.''' Many people believe that the simple observation of ''more'' or ''less''
column2: or the mere calculation of an average value
column3: is what statistics are all about. Of course
column4: this is not the case - statistics is more than descriptive statistics
column5: or whimsical [[Introduction to statistical figures|bar plots or even pie charts]]. Still
column6: knowing the basics is important
column7: and most of you probably already calculated things like mean and median in school. So let us have another look to refresh your memory.

column2: mode and median explain regarding a dataset.]]

column1: The [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mk8tOD0t8M0 mean] is the average of numbers you can simply calculate by adding up all the numbers and then divide them by how many numbers there are in total.
The median is the middle number in a sorted set of numbers. It can be substantially different from the mean value
column2: for instance when you have large gaps or cover wide ranges within your [[Glossary|data]]. Therefore
column3: it is more robust against outliers.

column1: The mode is the value that appears most often. It can be helpful in large datasets or when you have a lot of repetitions within the dataset.
The range is simply the difference between the lowest and the highest value and consequently it can also be calculated like this.
[[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-03-28 um 15.51.31.png|thumb|right|This graph shows how the standard deviation is spread from the mean.]]

The standard deviation is calculated as the square root of variance by determining the variation between each data point relative to the mean. It is a measure of how spread out your numbers are. If the data points are further from the mean
column2: there is a higher deviation within the data set. The higher the standard deviation
column3: the more spread out the data.

'''In short:''' This entry provides a critical overview and understanding of the methodological canon of science. It presents the underlying conceptualisation of scientific methods that guides the categorisation of [[Methods|the presented methods]] on this Wiki.
== Why change the perspective on methods? ==
A strong reasoning why we need a different way to think about scientific methods is actually rooted in the history of science
column2: and how the way we think about methods in the future should be different from these past developments. [https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_S._Kuhn Kuhn] talks about revolution and [[Glossary|paradigm]] shifts in scientific thinking
column3: and many would firmly argue that such a paradigm shift is immanent right now. Actually
column4: it is already happening.

column1: The entry on the [https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/epistemology/ ''epistemology''] of scientific methods outlines in detail how we came to the current situation
column2: and explains why our thinking about scientific methods - and with it our thinking about science in general - will shift due to and compared to the past. For now
column3: let us focus on the present
column4: and even more importantly
column5: the future. For the epistemology please refer you to the [[History of Methods|respective article]]
column6: since much is rooted in the history of science
column7: and humankind as such.

column2: we face unprecedented challenges in terms of magnitude and complexity.''' While some problems are still easy to solve
column3: others are not. Due to the complex phenomena of globalisation we now face challenges that are truly spanning across the globe
column4: and may as well affect the whole globe. Globalisation once started with the promise of a creation of a united and connected humankind. This is of course a very naive worldview and
column5: as we see today
column6: has failed in many regards. Instead
column7: we see a rise in global inequality in terms of many indicators
column8: among them [https://www.gapminder.org/tools/#$chart-type=bubbles global wealth distribution]. Climate change
column9: biodiversity loss and ocean acidification showcase that the challenges are severe
column10: and may as well lead to an end of the world as we know it
column11: if you are a pessimist. If your are not a pessimist
column12: then stewing in a grim scenario of our future demise will not help us to prevent this from happening. Instead
column13: [https://www.pnas.org/content/108/49/19449 sustainability science] and many other branches of science opted for a solution orientated agenda
column14: which proclaims that instead of merely describing problems
column15: and despite the strong urge to complain about it
column16: we need to work together and find solutions for these wicked problems. Over the last few decades
column17: science inched its way slowly out of its ''ivory towers''
column18: and the necessity of science and society [[Transdisciplinarity| working together]] emerged. While this will often bring us closer to potential solutions that ideally serve more and more people
column19: science is still stuck in a mode that is often arrogant
column20: resource driven and anachronistic. While this is surely a harsh word
column21: some people call this ""normal science"". However
column22: the current challenges demand a new mode of science; one that is radical yet rooted in long traditions
column23: collaborative yet able to focus deeply on specific parts of knowledge
column24: solution orientated yet not naive
column25: and peaceful instead of confrontational and resource-focussed.

column1: Science has long realised that due to globalisation
column2: shared and joined perspectives between disciplines and the benefits of modern communication
column3: we - scientists from all disciplinary and cultural backgrounds - often have a shared interest in specific topics. For every topic
column4: there are different scientific disciplines that focus on it
column5: albeit from different perspectives. Take climate change
column6: where many disciplines offer their five cent to the debate. '''Will any of the singular scientific disciplines solve the problems alone? Most likely not.''' Werewolves may be killed by silver bullets
column7: yet for most problems we currently face
column8: there is no silver bullet. We will have to think of more complex solutions
column9: often working in unisono across different disciplines
column10: and together with society.

column2: most disciplines have established specific traditions when it comes to the methods that are being used. While these traditions guarantee experience
column3: they may not allow us to solve the problem we currently face. Some methods are exclusive for certain disciplines
column4: yet most methods are used by several disciplines. Sometimes these methods co-evolved
column5: but more often than not the methods departed from a joined starting point and then become more specific in the respective context of the particular branch of science. For instance
column6: [[Open Interview|interviews]] are widely used in many areas of science
column7: yet the implementation is often very diverse
column8: and specific branches of sciences typically favour specific types of interviews. This gets us stuck if we want to share insights
column9: work together and combine knowledge gathered in different disciplines. Undisputedly
column10: modern science increasingly builds on a canon of diverse approaches
column11: and there is a clear necessity to unpack the ‘silos’ that methods are currently packed in. While nothing can be said against deep methodological expertise
column12: some disciplines have the tendency to rely on their methods
column13: and declare their approaches as the most valid ones. However
column14: we all look at the Universe from different perspectives
column15: through different lenses
column16: and create different models. '''The choice of the scientific method strongly determines the outcome of our research.''' If someone insist on a specific method
column17: then this person will receive the specific knowledge that this method is able to unlock. However
column18: other parts of knowledge may be impossible to be unlocked through this method
column19: and there is not a single method that can unlock all knowledge.

column1: '''We need to choose and apply methods depending on the type of knowledge we aim to create
column2: regardless of the disciplinary background or tradition.''' We should aim to become more and more experienced and empowered to use the method that is most ideal for each research purpose and not rely solely on what our discipline has always been doing. In order to achieve this
column3: design criteria of methods can help to create a conceptualization of the nature of methods. In other words: what are the underlying principles that guide the available scientific methods? First
column4: we need to start with the most fundamental question:

column2: ''scientific methods create knowledge''. This knowledge creation process follows certain principles and has a certain rigour. Knowledge that is created through scientific methods should be ideally [https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/scientific-reproducibility/ ''reproducible'']
column3: which means that someone else under the given circumstances would come up with the same insights when using the same respective methods. This is insofar important
column4: as other people would maybe create different data under a similar setting
column5: but all the data should answer research questions or hypotheses in the same way. However
column6: there are some methods that may create different knowledge patterns
column7: which is why documentation is pivotal in the application of scientific methods. Some forms of knowledge
column8: such as the perception of individuals
column9: cannot be reproduced
column10: because these are singular perspectives. '''Knowledge created through scientific methods hence either follows a systematic application of methods
column11: or a systematic documentation of the application of methods'''. Reproducible approaches create the same knowledge
column12: and other approaches should be equally well documented to safeguard that for all steps taken it can be understood what was being done precisely.

column1: Another possibility to define methods concerns the different stages of research in which they are applied. '''Methods are about gathering data
column2: analysing data
column3: and interpreting data.''' Not all methods do all of these three steps
column4: in fact most methods are even exclusive to one or two of these steps. For instance
column5: one may analyse [[Semi-structured Interview|structured interviews]] - which are one way to gather data - with statistical tests
column6: which are a form of analysis. The interpretation of the results is then built around the design of the interviews
column7: and there are norms and much experience concerning the interpretation of statistical tests. Hence
column8: gathering data
column9: analysing it
column10: and then interpreting the results are part of a process that we call ''design criteria of methods''. Established methods often follow certain more or less established norms
column11: and the norms can be broken down into the main design criteria of methods. Let us have a look at these.

column1: '''One of the strongest discourses regarding the classification of methods revolves around the question whether a method is quantitative or qualitative'''. [[:Category:Quantitative|''Quantitative'']] methods focus on the measurement
column2: counting and constructed generalisation
column3: linking the statistical or mathematical analysis of data
column4: as well as the interpretation of data that consists of numbers to extract [[Glossary|patterns]] or support theories. Simply spoken
column5: quantitative methods are about numbers. [[:Category:Qualitative|''Qualitative'']] methods
column6: on the other hand
column7: focus on the human dimensions of the observable or conceptual reality
column8: often linking observational data or interpretation of existing data directly to [[Glossary|theory]] or concepts
column9: allowing for deep contextual understanding. Both quantitative and qualitative methods are ''[[Normativity of Methods|normative]]''. These two generally different lines of thinking are increasingly linked in recent decades
column10: yet the majority of research - and more importantly
column11: disciplines - are dominated by either qualitative or quantitative methods. While this is perfectly fine per se
column12: there is a deep ideological trench between these two approaches
column13: and much judgement is passed on which approach is more valid. This can be misleading if not wrong
column14: and propose instead to choose the appropriate approach depending on the intended knowledge. However
column15: there is one caveat: much of the scientific canon of the last decades was dominated by research building on quantitative approaches. However
column16: new exciting methods emerge especially in qualitative research. Since novel solutions are necessary for the problems we currently face
column17: it seems necessary that the amount as well as the proportion of qualitative research increases in the future.

column1: [[File:deductiveinductive_danielmiessler.png|thumb|left|'''Deductive vs. Inductive Reasoning'''. Source: [https://danielmiessler.com/images/Screen-Shot-2016-07-15-at-9.57.07-AM.png Daniel Miessler]]]

'''Methods can further be distinguished into whether they are inductive or deductive'''. [[:Category:Deductive|''Deductive'']] reasoning builds on statements or theories that are confirmed by observation or can be confirmed by logic. This is rooted deeply in the tradition of [https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/francis-bacon/ Francis Bacon] and has become an important baseline of especially the natural sciences and research utilising quantitative methods. While Bacon can be clearly seen as being more leaning towards the inductive
column2: he paved the road towards a clearer distinction between the inductive and the deductive. If there is such a thing as the scientific method at all
column3: we owe much of the systematic behind it to Bacon. [[:Category:Inductive|''Inductive'']] methods draw conclusions based on data or observations. Many argue that these inferences are only approximations of a probable truth. Deriving the knowledge from data and not from [[Glossary|theory]] in inductive research can be seen as a counterpoint to hypothesis-driven deductive reasoning
column4: although this is not always the case. While research even today is mostly stated to be clearly either inductive or deductive
column5: this is often a hoax. You have many folks using large datasets and stating clear hypotheses. If these folks were honest
column6: it would become clear that they analysed the data until they had these hypotheses
column7: yet they publish the results with hypotheses they pretend they had from the very beginning. This is a clear indicator of scientific tradition getting back at us which
column8: up until today
column9: is often built on a culture that demands hypothesis building. Then again
column10: other research is equally dogmatic in demanding an inductive approach
column11: widely rejecting any deduction. Here we will not discuss [[Big problems for later|the merits of inductive reasoning]] here
column12: but will only highlight that its openness and urge to avoid being deterministic provides an important and relevant counterpoint to deductive research. Just as in the realms of quantitative and qualitative methods
column13: there is a deep trench between inductive and deductive research. One possibility to overcome this in an honest and valuable approach would be abductive reasoning
column14: which consists of iterations between data and theory. Modern research is actually framed and conducted in such a way with a constant exchange between data and theory. Considering the complexity of modern research
column15: this also makes sense: on the one hand
column16: not all research can be broken down into small ""hypothesisable"" units
column17: and on the other hand
column18: so much knowledge already exists
column19: which is why much research builds on previous theories and knowledge. Still
column20: today
column21: and for years to come
column22: we will have to acknowledge that much of modern research to date will fall into the traditionally established inductive or deductive category. It is therefore not surprising that [[Different_paths_to_knowledge#Critical_Theory_.26_Bias|critical theory]] and other approaches cast doubt over these rigid criteria
column23: and the knowledge they produce. Nevertheless
column24: they represent an important categorisation for the current state of the art of many areas of science
column25: and therefore deserve critical attention
column26: least because many methods imply either one or the other approach.

column1: '''Different scientific methods are focussing on or even restricted to certain spatial [[Glossary|scales]]
column2: yet others may span across scales'''. Some methods are operationalised on a global scale
column3: while others focus on the individual. For instance
column4: a statistical correlation analysis can be applied on data about individuals gathered in a survey
column5: but also be applied to global economic data. A ''global'' spatial scale of sampling is defined by data that covers the whole globe
column6: or a non-deliberately chosen part of the globe. Such global analyses are of increasing importance
column7: as they allow us to have a truly united understanding of societal and natural phenomena that concern the global scale. An ''individual'' scale of sampling is a scale that focuses on individual objects
column8: which includes people and other living entities. The individual scale can give us deep insight into living beings
column9: with a pronounced focus on research on humans. Since our concepts of humans are diverse
column10: there are also many diverse approaches found here
column11: and many branches of science focus on the individual. This scale certainly gained importance over the last decades
column12: and we are only starting to understand the diversity of knowledge that an individual scale has to offer.

column2: there is a huge void that can have different names in different domains of science - ‘landscapes’
column3: ‘systems’
column4: ‘institutions’
column5: ‘catchments’
column6: and others. Different branches of science focus on different mid-scales
column7: yet this is often considered to be one of the most abundantly investigated scales
column8: since it can generate a great diversity of data. We will call it the ‘system scale’. A ''system'' scale of sampling is defined by any scale that contains several individual objects that interact or are embedded in a wider matrix surrounding. Regarding our understanding of systems
column9: this is a relevant methodological scale
column10: because it can generate a great diversity of empirical data
column11: and many diverse methods are applied at this scale. In addition
column12: it is also quite a relevant scale in terms of normativity because it can generate knowledge about change in systems which can be operationalised with the goal to foster or hinder such change. Hence
column13: this system scale can be quite relevant in terms of knowledge that focuses on policy. Changing the globe takes certainly longer
column14: and understanding change in people has many deeper theoretical foundations and frameworks.

column1: '''The last criterion to conceptualise methods concerns time.''' The vast majority of empirical studies look at one slice of time (the ''present'')
column2: and this makes the studies that try to understand the past or make the bold attempt to understand more about the future all the more precious. Analysis of the ''past'' can be greatly diverse
column3: from quantitative longitudinal data analysis to deep [[Hermeneutics|hermeneutical]] text analysis and interpretation of writers long gone. There are many windows into the past
column4: and we only start to unravel many of the most fascinating perspectives
column5: as much of the treasures available are only now investigated by science. Still
column6: there is a long tradition in history studies
column7: cultural studies
column8: and many more branches of sciences that prove how much we can learn from the past. With the utilisation of predictive models
column9: the development of scenarios about the ''future'' and many other available approaches
column10: science also attempts to generate more knowledge about what might become. The very concept of the future is a human privilege that science increasingly focuses on because of the many challenges we face. New approaches emerged over the last decades
column11: and our knowledge about the future certainly grows. To date
column12: we have to acknowledge that these studies are still all too rare
column13: and much of our empirical knowledge builds on snapshots of a certain point in time. If you want to learn more about the design criterion of time
column14: please refer to the entry on [[Time]].

column1: Try to understand how methods can be operationalised in view of these criteria. Some methods only tick one option per criterion
column2: and others may span across many different combinations of criteria. Out of the [[Methods|great diversity of methods]]
column3: this categorization gives you a first positioning of each specific method. There are literally hundreds of methods out there. Instead of understanding all of them
column4: try to understand the criteria that unite and differentiate them. Only through an understanding of these methodological design criteria may you be able to choose the method that creates the knowledge that may be needed.

column1: Design Criteria of Methods in Sustainability Science;"'''Note:''' This entry focuses especially on Methods of Sustainability Science. For a more general conceptual view on Methods
column2: please refer to the entry on the [[Design Criteria of Methods]].
you will find out more about how we can distinguish and design our methodological approaches in Sustainability Science.

column1: The [[Design Criteria of Methods|design criteria of methods]] that I propose for all methods - quantitative vs. qualitative
column2: inductive vs. deductive
column3: spatial and temporal scales - are like the usual suspects of scientific methods. Within normal science
column4: these design criteria are what most scientists may agree upon to be central for the current debate and development about methods. Consequently
column5: '''it is important to know these ''normal science'' design criteria also when engaging with sustainability science.''' However
column6: some arenas in science depart from the current paradigm of science - ''sensu strictu'' [https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/thomas-kuhn/#DeveScie Kuhn] - and this means also that they depart potentially from the design criteria of the normal sciences.

column1: The knowledge science currently produces is not enough to solve the problems we currently face. In order to arrive at new solutions
column2: we need to re-consider
column3: adapt and innovative the current raster of methods in science. Many methods that are long established are valuable
column4: and all scientific methods have their [[History of Methods|history and origin]]
column5: and thus are important. Nevertheless
column6: it becomes more and more clear that in order to arrive at solutions for the problems we currently face
column7: we need to consider if we need methodological innovation. In the past
column8: methodological innovation worked in one of these ways:

column1: # new combinations of methods were attempted
# and methods were re-designed to be applied in a novel context where they had never been used before.
While all this is fascinating in itself
column2: here I present a different approach towards an amendment of the methodological canon
column3: for one simple reason: Developing the methodological canon of science takes experience in the application of scientific methods
column4: and ideally also contextual experience in diverse methodological approaches. While I am personally deeply critical about scientific disciplines
column5: this is a good argument that in order to become versatile in scientific methods
column6: you may need to channel your development towards being versatile in scientific methods based on textbook knowledge. Normal sciences have textbooks to teach their methodological canon
column7: and while I think we need to be critical of these methodological approaches
column8: they can have a lot of value. If you ask why
column9: the I would say simply
column10: because you cannot re-apply methods in a different context or attempt recombinations of methods if you are not experienced in the application of methods. To this end
column11: it is important to highlight that these methods only look at parts of reality
column12: which is the main reason for being critical. [[Bias and Critical Thinking|Bias]] and the fact that accompanying [[Levels of Theory|paradigms and theoretical viewpoints]] of specific methods restrict the validity of specific methods makes me even more critical. Nevertheless
column13: there is no alternative to building experience than through applying methods within active research. You need to get your hands dirty to get experience. Here
column14: I propose that we start with the knowledge we want to produce
column15: and the goal we aim at to produce this knowledge. If we want to empower stakeholders
column16: we need to be aware which methods out of the existing canon might help us
column17: and how we may need to combine these methods in order to produce the knowledge we aim at. Therefore
column18: we present three types of design criteria that serve as a basis for reflection of what knowledge we want to produce.

column2: Wiek et al. analyzed the prevalent literature and presented five Key Competencies that students of Sustainability Science should strive for. This is an excellent scheme to be reflexive about the [[Glossary|competencies]] you want to gain
column3: and to get a better understanding on which competencies can be aimed at through specific methods. These competencies are as follows:

column1: * ''Systems Thinking'': Systems Thinking competency is the ability to analyze and understand [[Glossary|complex systems]] including the dynamics in the interrelation of their parts. Systems thinking integrates different domains (society
column2: environment
column3: economy
column4: etc.) as well as different scales (from local to global).

column1: * ''Anticipatory'': Anticipatory competency describes the ability to develop realistic scenarios of future trajectories within complex systems
column2: including positive (e.g. a carbon-neutral city) and negative (e.g. flooding stemming from climate change) developments. This may include rigorous concepts as well as convincing narratives and visions.

column1: * ''Normative'': Normative competency refers to the ability to evaluate
column2: discuss and apply (sustainability) values. It is based on the acquisition of normative knowledge such as concepts of justice or equality.
this competence is about being able to ""get things done"". Strategic competency is the capability to develop and implement comprehensive strategies (i.e. interventions
column3: projects
column4: measures) that lead to sustainable future states across different societal domains (social
column5: economic
column6: ecologic
column7: ...) and scales (local to global). It requires an intimate understanding of strategic concepts such as path dependencies
column8: barriers and alliances as well as knowledge about viability
column9: feasibility
column10: effectiveness and efficiency of systemic interventions as well as potential of unintended consequences.

column1: * ''Interpersonal'': Interpersonal competence is the ability to motivate
column2: enable
column3: and facilitate collaborative and participatory sustainability research and problem solving. This capacity includes advanced skills in communicating
column4: deliberating and negotiating
column5: collaborating
column6: [[Glossary|leadership]]
column7: pluralistic and trans-cultural thinking and empathy.

column1: [[File:SustainabilityCompetencies.png|750px|thumb|center|'''Key Competencies for Sustainability.''' Source: Wiek et al. 2011
The criteria from Wiek et al are outstanding in the capacity to serve as boundary object
column2: since I do not see these categories as mutually exclusive
column3: but instead strongly interwoven with each other. I can whole-heartedly recommend to return to these criteria then and again
column4: and to reflect on yourself through the lense of these criteria.

column1: Scientific methods can engage with non-scientific actors on diverse levels
column2: depending on the extent of their involvement in the process of scientific inquiry. Interaction with stakeholder may be especially relevant in [[Transdisciplinarity|transdisciplinary]] research.
we refer to four levels of interaction:'''

column1: * ''Information'': Stakeholders are informed about scientific insights
column2: possibly in form of policy recommendations that make the knowledge actionable. This is the most common form of science-society cooperation.

column1: * ''Consultation'': A one-directional information flow from practice actors (stakeholders) to academia
column2: most commonly in form of questionnaires and interviews
column3: which provides input or feedback to proposed or active research. Stakeholders provide information
column4: which is of interest to the researchers
column5: but are not actively involved in the research process.

column2: e.g. through one of the aforementioned methods
column3: in order to jointly frame and solve a distinct issue.

column1: * ''Empowerment'': The highest form of involvement of non-scientific actors in research
column2: where marginalized or suppressed stakeholders are given authority and ownership to solve problems themselves
column3: and/or are directly involved in the decision-making process at the collaboration level. Empowerment surpasses mere collaboration since stakeholders are enabled to engage with existing problems themselves
column4: rather than relying on research for each individual issue anew.

'''In short:''' Design Thinking is a process for creative problem solving and [[Glossary|innovation]] which focuses on understanding the target user and which differs from other creative problem-solving processes by developing and testing prototypes of potential solutions.

column2: Why & When ==

column1: * Design Thinking is a creative process in product or service design with a user-centered perspective. It helps empathise with others
column2: understand their perspectives and develop solutions to their problems. This way
column3: it prevents you from creating a solution when there is no problem.

column1: * Disclaimer: Design Thinking does not necessarily help you to compromise and balance different interests on the same resource e.g. clean air.
* It is an iterative process of [[Glossary|brainstorming]]
column2: [[Persona Building|persona building]]
column3: prototyping and testing. A Design Thinking team should not be larger than five individuals
column4: but several teams can work on the same problem at once. The length of the process is expandable (up to a week)
column5: but may also be squeezed into a 3-hour workshop

column2: you have to decide under which conditions you want to host a Design Thinking session. What is the '''topic or the problem''' you want to work on? Which '''participants
column3: perspectives and skills''' do you need to go through the process? It is recommendable to not work in larger groups than five
column4: if you are more participants
column5: you can split up in smaller teams and find out with what kind of solutions you come up with. Define a workshop facilitator who guides the process
column6: and create an agenda. Find a room and organize the '''material and resources''' that you need (paper
column7: pen
column8: post-its
column9: whiteboard etc.)

column2: you need to communicate what you expect from the participants: Time
column3: energy
column4: attention. Try to make use that every participant is actually committed as one team member less is easier to work with than somebody dropping in and out.

column1: In the first phase of the process
column2: you try to change your perspective from your own to the user that you want to focus on. Define your target/ user group and research about their background. You can make use of [[Persona Building|persona building]] to visualize your target group. A look into demographics can be of help to understand the specific situation of your target group. Maybe you'll also want to have a look at the [https://www.sinus-institut.de/sinus-milieus SINUS group] approach. Do all you can to understand the life that your target group is living. Your goal is to be able to think and feel like the person or group of persons you want to empathize with.
you want to define your problem from the perspective of the user. What are the needs and wishes? What are their daily problems? Where do they need help?

column1: This is the wild phase of Design Thinking. You throw all ideas you have into the discussion
column2: for which you can use different methods such as [[Glossary|brainstorming]]
column3: brainwriting
column4: a written discussion
column5: who-writes-the-most-ideas-on-post-its and more. The goal is to broaden your view - no idea is too big or too far out of the box. Everything is allowed at this point
column6: no matter how unrealistic it seems. Don't restrict yourself
column7: this comes later. Try to challenge general [[Glossary|assumptions]] - this leads to the best
column8: unforeseen solutions.

column1: Now you are allowed to criticise. The goal of this phase is to identify one solution out of the many that seems to be most promising
column2: and design a prototype for it. Decide on the solution as a group
column3: and weigh all your options. Why do you think this option seems to be the best? What makes it stand out? Why and how does it best address your target groups needs? The prototype can take any form or shape
column4: it can be a drawing
column5: a mock-up of an application
column6: a [[Glossary|framework]]
column7: a staged situation - anything that helps you visualize and communicate your solution quickly to anyone. It should be understandable and not be too detailled yet.

column2: you try to get feedback from the user group. The feedback should come from 'real' users - so you can call your colleagues
column3: friends
column4: ask people on the street or even reach out to people who might actually be your target group. You need to collect reactions on your prototype. After that
column5: depending on the feedback
column6: you iterate and get back to another earlier step in the process. If your users mirror you that your prototype is far from what is needed
column7: you should start at understanding your user group again. If only little tweaks are missing
column8: you can work on your prototype some more and test it again more quickly. As soon as their are only minor critical comments from your target group
column9: you are ready to realize the solution.

column2: the [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-MKT3yLDkqk p-value] or probability value is the probability of obtaining the test results as extreme as the actual results
column3: assuming that the null hypothesis is correct. In essence
column4: the p-value is the percentage probability the observed results occurred by chance.

column1: Probability is one of the most important concepts in modern statistics. The question whether a relation between two variables is purely by chance
column2: or following a pattern with a certain probability is the basis of all probability statistics (surprise!). In the case of linear relation
column3: another quantification is of central relevance
column4: namely the question how much variance is explained by the model. Between these two numbers -the amount of variance explained by a linear model
column5: and the fact that two variables are not randomly related- are related at least to some amount.

column1: If a model is highly significant
column2: it typically shows a high r<sup>2</sup> value. If a model is marginally significant
column3: then the r<sup>2</sup> value is typically also low. This relation is however also influenced by the sample size. Linear models and the related p-value describing the model are highly sensitive to sample size. You need at least a handful of points to get a significant relation
column4: while the r<sup>2</sup> value in this same small sample sized model may be already high. Hence the relation between sample size
column5: r<sup>2</sup> and p-value is central to understand how meaningful models are.

column1: In Fisher's example of a [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lgs7d5saFFc lady tasting tea]
column2: a lady claimed to be able to tell whether tea or milk was added first to a cup. Fisher gave her 8 cups
column3: 4 of each variety
column4: in random order. One could then ask what the probability was for her getting the specific number of cups she identified correct
column5: but just by chance. Using the combination formula
column6: where n (total of cups) = 8 and k (cups chosen) = 4
column7: there are 8!/4!(8-4)! = 70 possible combinations. In this scenario
column8: the lady would have a 1.42% chance of correctly guessing the contents of 4 out of 8 cups. If the lady is able to consistently identify the contents of the cups
column9: one could say her results are statistically significant.
