Different paths to knowledge;"The course '''Scientific methods - Different paths to knowledge''' introduces the learner to the fundamentals of scientific work. It summarizes key developments in science and introduces vital concepts and considerations for academic inquiry. It also engages with thoughts on the future of science in view of the challenges of our time. Each chapter includes some general thoughts on the respective topic as well as relevant Wiki entries.
The initial lecture presents a rough overview of the history of science on a shoestring
column2: focussing both on philosophy as well as - more specifically - philosophy of science. Starting with the ancients we focus on the earliest preconditions that paved the way towards the historical development of scientific methods.

column1: '''Critique of the historical development and our status quo'''
We have to recognise that modern science is a [[Glossary|system]] that provides a singular and non-holistic worldview
column2: and is widely built on oppression and inequalities. Consequently
column3: the scientific system per se is flawed as its foundations are morally questionable
column4: and often lack the necessary link between the empirical and the ethical consequences of science. Critical theory and ethics are hence the necessary precondition we need to engage with as researchers continuously.

column1: '''Interaction of scientific methods with philosophy and society'''
Science is challenged: while our scientific knowledge is ever-increasing
column2: this knowledge is often kept in silos
column3: which neither interact with other silos nor with society at large. Scientific disciplines should not only orientate their wider focus and daily interaction more strongly towards society
column4: but also need to reintegrate the humanities in order to enable researchers to consider the ethical conduct and consequences of their research.

column1: A great diversity of methods exists in science
column2: and no overview that is independent from a disciplinary bias exists to date. One can get closer to this by building on the core design criteria of scientific methods.

column1: The main differentiation within the methodological canon is often between quantitative and qualitative methods. This difference is often the root cause of the deep entrenchment between different disciplines and subdisciplines. Numbers do count
column2: but they can only tell you so much. There is a clear difference between the knowledge that is created by either qualitative or qualitative methods
column3: hence the question of better or worse is not relevant. Instead it is more important to ask which knowledge would help to create the most necessary knowledge under the given circumstances.

column1: Some branches of science try to verify or falsify hypotheses
column2: while other branches of science are open towards the knowledge being created primarily from the data. Hence the difference between a method that derives [[Glossary|theory]] from data
column3: or one that tests a theory with data
column4: is often exclusive to specific branches of science. To this end
column5: out of the larger availability of data and the already existing knowledge we built on so far
column6: there is a third way called abductive reasoning. This approach links the strengths of both [[Glossary|induction]] and [[Glossary|deduction]] and is certainly much closer to the way how much of modern research is actually conducted.

column1: Certain scientific methods can transcend spatial and temporal scales
column2: while others are rather exclusive to a specific partial or temporal scale. While again this does not make one method better than another
column3: it is certainly relevant since certain disciplines almost focus exclusively on specific parts of scales. For instance
column4: psychology or population ecology are mostly preoccupied with the individual
column5: while macro-economics widely work on a global scale. Regarding time there is an ever increasing wealth of past information
column6: and a growing interest in knowledge about the future. This presents a shift from a time when most research focused on the presence.

column1: The rise of empiricism and many other developments of society created critical theory
column2: which questioned the scientific [[Glossary|paradigm]]
column3: the governance of systems as well as democracy
column4: and ultimately the norms and truths not only of society
column5: but more importantly of science. This paved the road to a new form of scientific practice
column6: which can be deeply normative
column7: and ultimately even transformative.

column1: Critical theory raised the alarm to question empirical inquiry
column2: leading to an emerging recognition of bias across many different branches of science. With a bias being
column3: broadly speaking
column4: a tendency for or against a specific construct (cultural group
column5: social group etc.)
column6: various different forms of bias may flaw our recognition
column7: analysis or interpretation
column8: and many forms of bias are often deeply contextual
column9: highlighting the presence or dominance of constructed groups or knowledge.

column2: and with a clear recognition of bias
column3: science(s) need to transform into a reflexive
column4: inclusive and solution-oriented domain that creates knowledge jointly with and in service of society. The current scientific paradigms are hence strongly questioned
column5: reflecting the need for new societal paradigms.

column1: The testing of a [[Glossary|hypothesis]] was a breakthrough in scientific thinking. Another breakthrough came with Francis Bacon who proclaimed the importance of observation to derive conclusions. This paved the road for repeated observation under conditions of manipulation
column2: which in consequence led to carefully planned systematic methodological designs.

column1: Often based on previous knowledge or distinct higher laws or assumptions
column2: the formulation of hypotheses became an important step towards systematic inquiry and carefully designed experiments that still constitute the baseline of modern medicine
column3: psychology
column4: ecology and many other fields. Understanding the formulation of hypotheses and how they can be falsified or confirmed is central for large parts of science. Hypotheses can be tested
column5: are ideally parsimonious - thus build an existing knowledge - and the results should be reproducible and transferable.

column1: These criteria of hypotheses showcase that despite allowing for a systematic and - some would say - ‘causal’ form of knowledge
column2: hypotheses are rigid at best
column3: and offer a rather static worldview at their worst. Theories explored in hypothesis testing should be able to match the structures of experiments. Therefore
column4: the underlying data is constructed
column5: which limits the possibilities of this knowledge production approach.

column1: Building on the criteria from David Hume
column2: we define causality through temporal links (""if this - then this"")
column3: as well as through similarities and dissimilarities. If A and B cause C
column4: then there must be some characteristic that makes A and B similar
column5: and this similarity causes C. If A causes C
column6: but B does not cause C
column7: then there must be a dissimilarity between A and B. Causal links can be clearly defined
column8: and it is our responsibility as scientists to build on this understanding
column9: and understand its limitations.

column1: '''Understanding correlations''' Correlations statistically test the relation between two continuous variables. A relation that - following probability - is not a coincidence but from a statistical standpoint meaningful
column2: can be called a significant correlation.

column1: With increasing statistical analysis being conducted
column2: we sometimes may find significant correlations that are non-causal. Disentangling causal form correlative relations is deeply normative and needs to acknowledge that we often build science based on deeply constructed ontologies.

column1: Scientific methods partly dealt with the necessary approaches to enable a flourishing yet often abusive trade
column2: work out solutions for mechanisation
column3: and develop modern agriculture based on systematic inquiry. Modern medicine - or better medical research - is one example of a framing of knowledge production on and around scientifc method.

column1: Equally did society drive a demand onto scientific inquiry
column2: demanding solutions from science
column3: and thereby often [[Glossary|funding]] science as a means to an end. Consequently did science often act morally wrong
column4: or failed to offer the deep [[Glossary|leverage points]] that could drive transformational change. Such a critical view on science emerged partly out of society
column5: and specifically did a view on empirical approaches emerge out of philosophy.

column1: '''The grand abduction of science and society'''

column2: science and society have been in a continuous spiralling movement around each other. While scientific methods are shaped by their time
column3: the times are also shaped by scientific methodology. What is however necessary is the close and mutual interaction between empirical inquiry and the question how we ought to act based on our growing knowledge.

column2: complexity and emergence'''

column1: System thinking gained prominence during the last century
column2: allowing to take interactions and interdependencies into account when investigating a system. To this end
column3: a ‘system’ stands for something that is in the focus of the investigation
column4: such as a catchment area
column5: a business enterprise
column6: a social institution
column7: or a population of wasps. Such systems show signs of [[Glossary|complexity]]
column8: which means that the interactions of smaller entities in the system may be unpredictable or chaotic
column9: which makes systems more than the sum of their parts. Under this definition
column10: solving problems within a system is often the greatest challenge: while the [[Glossary|system dynamics]] may be understandable
column11: the solutions for an emerging problem are not instantly available. Consequently
column12: solutions for complex problems emerge
column13: and this demands a new line of thinking about systems.

column2: Complexity and Emergence]]
Complexity and Emergence (German)]]

column1: The increasing availability of data offers many new possibilities
column2: and the emergence of new ways of getting data through the internet poses not only opportunities
column3: but also - among others - ethical challenges. All the while
column4: ever more diversity of data becomes available to people
column5: leading to an even larger wealth of qualitative data. Again
column6: this poses many ethical questions
column7: and imposes an all new agenda onto many methodological approaches
column8: including data security
column9: picture rights
column10: normative interpretations and even culture wars.

column1: While technology has surely changed the way we live our lives
column2: it has certainly also changed the way we do science. We should however recognise that technology cannot produce knowledge
column3: and therefore can only be a means to an end
column4: but not an end in itself.

column1: Methods need to acknowledge the increasing diversity but also the new challenges that emerge from the exponential growth of science. Interactions between different disciplines are strongly increasing
column2: and the core goal for science will be how to facilitate this through suitable [[Glossary|communication]] and additional resources.

column1: The new challenges we face demand the production of new knowledge to approximate solutions. Scientific collaboration is therefore necessary in order to open up domains that were previously sealed and oftentimes arrogant.
Methods are often characterized by a specific language
column2: which is why a lot of time needs to be invested into understanding each other. In addition
column3: experts in one method are often deeply invested in their specific focus
column4: which is why interdisciplinary collaboration is mainly built on [[Glossary|trust]].

column1: Methods are not like cooking recipes that anyone with the right recipe can unlock. Instead
column2: methods evolve
column3: just as the harmonisation of methods evolves. A mixed methods approach is thus not like a mere recipe
column4: but should be approached as something new
column5: and only time will tell how we may become more experienced and systematic in the combination of different methods.

column2: scientific disciplines existed alongside each other and separated from the rest of society
column3: using the world as an object of inquiry and gathering data all the while. However
column4: the state of our world does not allow for such separation anymore. We need a new collaboration within science and between science and society in order to find solutions to urgent challenges.

column1: '''A new contract between science and society'''
Transdisciplinary research is built on the premise of scientific and non-scientific actors from diverse backgrounds jointly framing
column2: understanding and solving societally relevant problems. [[Glossary|Transdisciplinarity]] is reflexive
column3: participatory and holistic and able to develop mutually beneficial approaches to complex and normative issues.

column1: Despite the rather recent emergence of transdisciplinary research
column2: a lot has been developed in terms of appropriate research modes
column3: methods and surroundings. Examples of this are [[Visioning & Backcasting|Visioning]]
column4: Scenario Planning and Living Labs. More is yet to come
column5: but the foundations have been set.

column1: Retaining results is one of the most important yet overlooked parts of workshops that can get lost in the heat of the moment. Here's some suggestions on how to not go down that road:
* Make sure you '''have a slot in the agenda''' for reflection and wrap-up
* Have a common file share or workspace to which all participants have access
* Do the equivalent of a photo protocoll in a PowerPoint (or something similar)

* Leave some room for open questions. Remember that it is important to give this at least a few minutes of time as questions have to start building up. You can play music in the background if you can't stand the silence.
* Do a poll at the end: What did people learn? What did you get out of the event?
* Don't forget to brush up the results and provide them to your participants!

column1: '''Disney Method is a fairly simple (group) [[Glossary|brainstorming]] technique''' that revolves around the application of different perspectives to any given topic. One person or a group comes up with ideas
column2: then envisions their implementation and finally reflects upon their feasibility in a circular process. The Disney Method may be used to come up with ideas for projects or products
column3: to solve problems and conflicts
column4: to develop strategies and to make decisions. The method was invented by Walt Disney who thought of a movie not only as a director
column5: but also as an audience member and a producer to come up with the best possible result.

column1: The Disney method process is circular. A group of people (ideally five or six) is split into three different roles: the Dreamers
column2: the Realists
column3: the Critics.

column1: * try to come up with new ideas
* are creative and imaginative and do not set themselves any limits
* Guiding questions: ''Which ideas come to mind? What would be an ideal solution to the problem?''
* think about what needs to be done to implement the ideas
* Guiding Questions: ''How does the idea feel? How could it be implemented? Who should do it and at what cost?''
* look at the idea objectively and try to identify crucial mistakes

column2: but constructive - they do not want to destroy the ideas
column3: but improve them constructively.

column1: * Guiding Questions: ''What was neglected by the Dreamers and Realists? What can be improved
column2: what will not work? Which risks exist?''

column1: Each role receives a specific area within a room
column2: or even dedicated rooms or locations
column3: that may also be decorated according to the respective role. '''The process starts with the Dreamers
column4: who then pass on their ideas to the Realists
column5: who pass their thoughts on to the Critics.''' Each phase should be approx. 20 minutes long
column6: and each phase is equivalently important.

column2: the Critics pass back the feedback to the ideas to the Dreamers
column3: who continue thinking about new solutions based on the feedback they got. Every participant should switch the role throughout the process (with short breaks to 'neutralize' their minds) in order to understand the other roles' perspectives. The process goes on for as long as it takes
column4: until the Dreamers are happy about the ideas
column5: the Realists are confident about their feasibility and the Critics do not have any more remarks.

column1: A fourth role (the neutral moderator) may be added if the process demands it. He/she is then responsible for starting and ending the process and moderating the discussions. The method may also be applied by an individual who goes through the process individually.
[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XQOnsVSg5VQ YouTube MTTM Animations - The Disney Strategy]

column2: with dreamy guitar music) explains the method.

column1: A '''dummy variable''' is a variable that is created in regression analysis to represent a given qualitative variable through a quantitative one
column2: which takes one of two values: zero or one.

column1: Typically we use quantitative variables for [[Regression_Analysis|linear regression model]] equations. These can be a specific size of an object
column2: age of an individual
column3: population size
column4: etc. But sometimes the predictor variables can be qualitative. Those are variables that do not have a numeric value associated with them
column5: e.g. gender
column6: country of origin
column7: marital status. Since machine learning algorithms including regression rely on numeric values
column8: these qualitative values have to be converted.

column1: Some qualitative variables have a natural idea of order and can be easily converted to a numeric value accordingly
column2: e.g. number of the month instead of its name
column3: such as 3 instead of “March”. But it is not possible for nominal variables. However
column4: this can be a common trap when preparing one’s dataset for the regression analysis. For the linear model converting ordinal values to numeric ones would not make much sense
column5: as the model assumes the change between each value to be constant. What is usually done instead is a series of binary variables to capture the different levels of the qualitative variable.

column2: which is also known as a factor
column3: has only two levels
column4: then integrating it into a regression model is very simple: we need to use dummy variables. For example
column5: our variable can describe if a given individual smokes or does not:

column1: If a qualitative variable has more than two levels
column2: a single dummy variable cannot represent all possible values. In this case we create additional dummy variables. The general rule that applies here
column3: is the following: ''If you have k unique terms
column4: you use k - 1 dummy variables to represent.''

column1: Let’s consider a variable representing one’s marital status. Possible values are “single”
column2: “divorced” or “married”. In this case we create two dummy variables.
for example
column3: our model helps us predict an individual’s average insurance rate
column4: then ''β<sub>0</sub>'' can be interpreted as the average insurance rate for a single person
column5: ''β<sub>1</sub>'' can be interpreted as the difference in the average insurance rate between a single person and a married one
column6: and ''β<sub>2</sub>'' can be interpreted as the difference in the average insurance rate between a single person and a divorced one. As mentioned before
column7: there will always be one fewer dummy variable than the number of levels. Here
column8: the level with no dummy variable is “single”
column9: also known as the baseline.

column1: The Elevator Pitch is a precise and short (30-120 second) presentation format. Its name originates from the attempt of salesmen to enthuse potential customers and investors during the duration of an elevator ride - which seldomly took longer than 60 seconds. However
column2: it can be used to 'sell' basically anything - an idea
column3: a product
column4: a company
column5: or one's self. This does not have to happen in a seller-customer-relationship
column6: but can also be of help when you want to make an impression on job interviewers or new acquaintances. It also applies to research
column7: when an idea has to be 'sold' to potential supporters or to colleagues.

column1: * Make someone exicted about what you have to offer and make them remember you.
* Learn to describe your idea or person concisely - find out what is most important about it.
An Elevator Pitch is not done spontaneously. Instead
column2: it should be well prepared and rehearsed so that it can be acted out whenever necessary.

column1: The structure of the Elevator Pitch may follow the ''AIDA'' scheme:

column2: for example with an innovative introduction
column3: a question
column4: a controversial statement or a joke.

column1: # ''Interest'': raise Interest by highlighting your professional experiences
column2: the product's qualities or the idea's USP. What about your offer is of interest to the listener?

column1: # ''Desire'': Make the listener want what you have to offer. Illustrate the benefits of them hiring you or supporting your idea.
# ''Action'': A good Elevator Pitch should yield results
column2: so you have to build up to these. Sketch the next steps
column3: include a Call-To-Action and make sure that there is a follow-up conversation to the pitch.

column1: '''Some general tips on how to pitch include:'''
* Have a first sentence that immediately raises attention and present it with self-confidence.
* Prioritize what you say - focus on what is important.
* Relate to the interests of who you want to persuade.
* Allow for the other to react to what you said.
* Rehearse the pitch so that you're prepared to present it whenever necessary.

column1: (Active) Empathetic listening is a skill that helps to understand a [[Glossary|dialogue]] partner on a deeper level. It strengthens the bond between conversation partners
column2: soothes the work atmosphere during stressful phases
column3: prevents the reproduction of injustice
column4: and enriches creative thinking. This ability can become especially useful during [[Open Interview|qualitative interviews]]
column5: customer/client/patient conversations
column6: and conversations between co-workers
column7: e.g. [[Transdisciplinarity|(trans)disciplinary]] researchers
column8: or co-workers in any other field of work. It is best performed without time pressure.

column1: (Active) Empathetic listening exceeds mere punctual information gathering
column2: and even effective listening which enables to actively read a more complete image of what is being said. Through empathetic listening
column3: emotional information - which includes experiences being told or preferences being shared - is not only listened to but empathetically engaged with. It involves a set of other skills that must and will be acquired throughout its training.

column1: It all starts with the setting. It is best to create a quiet and comfortable atmosphere
column2: although this may no longer be neccessary with rising experience with the skill. A comfortable atmosphere enhances the concentration on what is being said. Also
column3: visual distractions
column4: fidgeting or eating
column5: and drinking should be held to a minimum. A setting free of distraction also includes taking enough time for the conversation
column6: so that nothing must be rushed through and consequently enough patience to not only sit out the meeting but actively participate as the listener.

column2: your positioning towards the speaker is fundamental. This includes for one your actual pose and your body language
column3: which should be open
column4: genuine
column5: and neither too neutral nor too emotionally charged with your own emotions. This also includes your actual positioning as a person. First
column6: take yourself back. It is very important to be selfless and genuinely interested in the other. This creates the key element of what makes somebody ''listen to'' - and not only ''hear'' - others. To enhance your interest and show it to your dialogue partner
column7: try to think of open-ended questions. You can also paraphrase the speaker’s perspective to remember and internalize better what has been said.

column2: it becomes easier to actively imagine the other one’s experiences
column3: ideas
column4: and emotions. Since emotionally charged topics might come up
column5: being emotionally available and tolerant is another key [[Glossary|competence]]. This must exclude interruption of the speaker and may exclude criticism if the speaker does not precisely ask for it. Also
column6: filling the silence with your own words instead of giving time for the speaker to think thoroughly and continue the talk is not desirable. At the end of the conversation
column7: you may want to ask for a follow-up conversation
column8: especially if time unexpectedly runs short or the topic was complex or emotionally challenging. Remember the well-being of the speaker is of the utmost importance. If no follow-up conversation is wished for
column9: do not pressure the speaker for one.

column2: comfortable
column3: and non-distracting environment to be “in” the moment.

but actually be interested. Remember you can learn from anybody and anything. Ask open-ended questions.

column1: # Imagine and remember what is being told.
# Paraphrase what has been said to remember better.

column2: the practice of empathetic listening does not only depend on these competencies but they are also trained throughout the act of empathetic listening.

Ethics and Statistics;"[[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-06-22 um 08.25.14.png|400px|thumb|right|'''Derek parfit is one of the most famous philosophers of the 20th and early 21st century.''' His thesis on normative ethics can be seen as his most important work.]]

column2: ethics can be defined as ''the world how it ought to be''. Derek Parfit argued that if philosophy be a mountain
column3: Western philosophy climbs it from three sides:

column2: which is widely preoccupied with the question how we can evaluate the outcome of an action. The most ethical choice would be the action that creates the most good for the largest amount of people.
which can be understood as the human capability to reflect what one is ought to do. Kant said much to this end
column3: and Parfit associated it to the individual
column4: or better
column5: the reasonable individual.

column1: * The third side of the mountain is the social contract
column2: which states that a range of moral obligations are agreed upon in societies
column3: a thought that was strongly developed by Locke. Parfit associated this even wider
column4: referring to the whole society in his triple theory.

column2: I think ethics matters deeply for statistics. Let me try to convince you.

column1: Looking at the epistemology of statistics
column2: we learned that much of modern civilisation is built on statistical approaches
column3: such as the design and analysis of [[Experiments]] or the [[Correlations|correlation]] of two continuous variables. Statistics propelled much of the exponential growth in our [[Scientific methods and societal paradigms|society]]
column4: and Statistics is responsible for many of the problems we currently face through our unsustainable behaviour. After all
column5: Statistics was willing to utilize means and accomplish goals that led us more into the direction of a more unsustainable path. Many would argue now that if statistics were a weapon
column6: itself would not kill. Instead
column7: it would be the human hand that uses it. This is insofar true as statistics would not exist without us
column8: just as weapons were forged by us. However
column9: I would argue that statistics are still deeply [[Normativity of Methods|normative]]
column10: as they are associated with our culture
column11: society
column12: social strata
column13: economies and so much more. This is why we should embrace a critical perspective on statistics. Much in our society depends on statistics
column14: and many decisions are taken because of statistics. As we have learned
column15: some of these statistics might be problematic or even wrong
column16: and consequently
column17: this can render the decisions wrong as well. More strangely
column18: our statistics can be correct
column19: but as we have learned
column20: statistics can even then contribute to our downfall
column21: for instance when they contribute to a process that leads to unsustainable production processes. '''We may calculate something correctly
column22: but the result can be morally wrong.''' Ideally
column23: our statistics would always be correct
column24: and the moral implications that follow out of our actions that are informed by statistics are also right.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-06-22 um 08.35.42.png|600px|left|thumb|'''GDP is a good example of a construct used in statistics which influences our daily life and especially politics to a huge extent.''']]

column2: statistics is more often than not seen as something that is not normative
column3: and some people consider statistics to create objective knowledge.''' This is rooted in the deep traditions and norms of the disciplines where statistics are an established methodological approach
column4: and in the history and theory of science that governs our research. Many scientists are regrettably still [[Bias and Critical Thinking|positivists]]
column5: and often consider the knowledge they create to be objective. More often than not
column6: this is not a conscious choice
column7: but the combination of unreflected teachers in some education system in general.  Today
column8: obvious moral dilemmas and ambiguities are generally part of complex ethical pre-checks in many study designs
column9: for which medicine provides the gold standard. Here
column10: preventing blunders was established early on
column11: and is now part of the canon of many disciplines
column12: with medicine leading the way. Such problems often deal with questions of sample size
column13: randomisation and the question when a successful treatment should be given to all participants. These are indirect reflections on validity and plausibility within the study design
column14: acknowledging that failures or flaws in these elements may lead to biased or even plain wrong results of the study.

column1: What is however widely lacking within the broader debates in science is how the utilisation of statistics can have wider normative consequences
column2: both during the application of statistics
column3: but also due to the consequences that arise out of results that were propelled by statistics. In her book ""Making comparisons count""
column4: Ruth Chang explores one example of such relations
column5: but the gap between ethics and statistics is so large
column6: we might define it altogether as widely undiscovered country. More will need to be done to overcome the gap between ethics and statistics
column7: and a connection is hampered by the fact that both fields are widely unclear in terms of the overall accepted norms. While many statistical textbooks exist
column8: these are more often than not disciplinary
column9: and consolidating the field of ethics this diversity is certainly no small endeavour. Creating connections between statistics and ethics is a challenge
column10: because there is a long history of flaws in this connection that triggered blurred
column11: if not wrong decisions. We will therefore look at specific examples from both directions
column12: starting with a view on ethics from the perspective of statistics.

column1: [[File:Food-supply-kcal.png|600px|right|thumb|[https://slides.ourworldindata.org/hunger-and-food-provision/#/kcalcapitaday-by-world-regions-mg-png '''Our World in Data] provides plenty information'''
column2: for example on how the worldwide food provision changed over the last decades.]]

column1: When looking at the relation between ethics and statistics from the perspective of statistics
column2: there are several items which can help us understand their interactions. First and foremost
column3: the concept of validity can be considered to be highly normative. Two extreme lines of thinking come into mind: One technical
column4: orientating on mathematical formulas; and the other line of thinking
column5: being informed actually by the content. Both are normative
column6: but of course there is a large difference between a model being correct in terms of a statistical validation
column7: and a model approximating a reality that is valid. Empirical research makes compromises by looking at pieces of the puzzle of reality. Following [[Bias and Critical Thinking|critical realism]]
column8: we may be able to unlock the strata of everything we can observe (the ‘empirical’
column9: as compared to the ‘real’ and the ‘actual’)
column10: but ultimately this will always be a subjective perspective. Hence empirical research will always have to compromise as we choose versions of reality in our pursuit for knowledge.

column1: If there is such a thing as general truth
column2: you may find it in philosophy and probably thus also in ethics. Interestingly
column3: philosophy originally served to generate criteria for validity in empirical research. '''However
column4: knowledge in philosophy itself will never be empirical
column5: at least not if it equally fulfils the criterion of being generally applicable.''' Through empirical research
column6: we can observe and understand and thus generate knowledge
column7: while philosophy is about the higher norms
column8: principles and mechanism that transcend the empirical. Statistics is able to generate such empirical knowledge
column9: and philosophy originally served to generate criteria for validity of this empirical process. Philosophy and empirical branches of science were vividly interacting in the [[History of Methods|Antique]]
column10: they started to separate with the Enlightenment. The three concepts that (Western?) philosophy is preoccupied with - utilitarianism
column11: reason and social contract - dissolved into scientific disciplines as economics
column12: psychology
column13: social science or political science. These disciplines subsequently tried to bridge the void between philosophy and empirical research
column14: yet often had to settle for compromises when integrating the empirical versions of reality with higher theories from philosophy. An example would be the Friedman doctrine in economics
column15: which was originally postulated with good intentions
column16: but its empirical translation into policies wreaked havoc for whole nations.

column1: Statistics did however indirectly contribute to altering our moral values. Take utilitarianism. It depends deeply on our moral values how we calculate utility
column2: and hence how we manage our systems through such calculations. Statistics in itself could be argued to be non-normative if it dealt with totally arbitrary data that has no connection to any reality. However
column3: as soon as statistics deals with data of any version of reality
column4: we make Statistics normative by looking at these versions of reality. '''It is our subjective views that make statistics no longer objective.''' One might argue that physics would be an exception
column5: and it probably is. It is more than clear however that social sciences
column6: economics
column7: ecology and psychology offer subjective epistemological knowledge
column8: at least from a viewpoint of critical realism. The numbers are clear
column9: yet our view of them is not. Consider for instance that on the one hand
column10: world hunger decreased over the last decades and more people get education or medical help than ever before. At the same time
column11: other measures propose that inequality increases
column12: for instance income inequality. While ethics can compare two statistical values in terms of their meaning for people
column13: statistics can generate the baseline for this. Statistics provides the methodological design
column14: mathematical calculations and experience in interpretation that we need to make ethical decisions. This brings us to plausibility.

column1: '''Statistics builds on plausibility: a good model should be both probable and reasonable.''' While statistics focuses predominantly on probability
column2: this is already a normative concept
column3: as the significance level α is arbitrary (although the common level of .05 is more often than not relatively robust). However
column4: p-values are partly prone to statistical fishing
column5: which is why probability in statistics is widely established but still often prone to flaws and errors. For more on this
column6: have a look at the entry on [[Bias in statistics]].

column1: Statistical calculations can also differ in terms of the model choice
column2: which is deeply normative and a case of disciplinary schools of thinking. Many models build on the precondition of a [[Data distribution|normal distribution]]
column3: which is however not always the case. This illustrates that assumed preconditions are often violated
column4: and hence that statistical rigor can be subjective or normative. Different people have different experiences
column5: and some parts of science are more rigorous than others. Non-normal distribution may matter deeply
column6: for instance when it is about income inequalities and associated policies
column7: and statistics shall not evade the responsibility that is implied in such an analysis.

column1: Another example is the question of [[Non-equilibrium dynamics|non-linearity]]. Preferring non-linear relationships to linear relationships is something that has become more important especially recently due to the wish to have a higher predictive power
column2: to understand non-linear shifts
column3: or for other reasons. Bending models - mechanically speaking - into a situation that allows to increase the model fit (that is
column4: how much the model can predict) comes with the price that we sacrifice any possibility of [[Causality|causal]] understanding
column5: since the zig-zag relations of non-linear models are often harder to match with our theories. While of course there are some examples of rapid shifts in systems
column6: this has next to nothing to do with [[Glossary|non-linearity]] that is assumed in many modern statistical analysis schemes and the predictive algorithms whose data power over us governs wide parts of our societies. '''Many disciplines gravitated towards non-linear statistics in the last decades
column7: sacrificing explainable relationships for an ever increasing model fit.''' Hence the clear demarcation between [[:Category:Deductive|deductive]] and [[:Category:Inductive|inductive]] research became blurry
column8: adding an epistemological/ontological burden on research. In many papers
column9: the question of plausibility and validity has been deeply affected by this issue
column10: and I would argue that this casts a shadow on the reputation of science. Philosophy alone cannot solve this problem
column11: since it looks at the general side of reality. Only by teaming up with empirical research
column12: we may arrive at measures of validity that are not on a high horse
column13: but also can be connected to the real world. To this end
column14: I would currently trust critical realism the most
column15: yet time will tell where theory of science will lead us in the future.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-06-22 um 08.46.28.png|400px|left|thumb|'''The [[Likert Scale]] is one example of a construct coming from the discipline of psychology.''' Today it is very often used also in surveys from other disciplines as you for sure also already came in touch with it.]]
Another obvious example regarding the normativity of statistical analysis are constructs. [[To Rule And To Measure|Constructs]] are deeply normative
column2: and often associated to existing norms within a discipline
column3: and may even transcend whole world views. The Likert Scale in psychology is such an example. The obvious benefit of that scale is that it may unlock perceptions form a really diverse array of people
column4: which is a positive aspect of such a scaling. Hence it became part of the established body of knowledge
column5: and much experience is available on the benefits and drawbacks of this scaling
column6: yet it is a normative choice whether we use it or not. '''Often
column7: scales are even part of the tacit signature of cultural and social norms
column8: and these indirectly influence the science that is conducted in this setting.''' An example would be the continuous Arabian numbering that dominates much of Western thinking
column9: and that many of us grow into these days. Philosophy and especially cultural studies have engaged in such questions increasingly in the last decades
column10: often focusing on isolated constructs or underlying fundamental aspects such as racism
column11: colonialism and privilege. It will be challenging to link these important and timely concepts directly to the flaws of empirical research. These days
column12: luckily
column13: I recognize a greater awareness among empirical researchers to avoid errors implemented through such constructs. Much needs to be done
column14: but I conceive reason for hope as well. Personally
column15: I believe that constructs will always be associated to personal identity and thus pose a problem for a general acceptance. Time will tell if and how this gap can be bridged.

column1: == Looking at statistics from philosophy of science ==
'''Science often claims to create objective knowledge.''' Famously
column2: Karl Popper and others stated that this claim is false - or should at least be questioned. Still
column3: it is not only perceived by many people that science is de facto objective
column4: but more importantly
column5: many scientists often claim that the knowledge they produce is objective. Large parts of academia like to spread an air of superiority and arrogance
column6: which is one of many explanations for the science-society-gap. When scientists should talk about potential facts
column7: they often just talk about ‘facts’. When they could highlight our inability as scientists to grasp the true nature of reality
column8: they instead present their version of reality to be the best or maybe even the only version of reality. Of course
column9: this is not only their fault
column10: since society increasingly demands easy explanations. A philosopher would be probably deeply disturbed if they understood how statistics are applied today
column11: but even more disturbed if this philosopher saw how statistics are being interpreted and marketed. Precision and clarity in communicating results
column12: as well as information on bias and caveats
column13: are missing more often that we should hope for.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-06-23 um 16.42.31.png|400px|right|thumb|'''The maxim ''Publish or Perish'' is dominating most of the scientific world today.''' Especially universities and scientific journals play an important role in this.]]
There are many facets that could be highlighted under such a provocative heading. Since Larry Laudan
column2: it has become clear that the assumption that developments of science which are initiated by scientists are reasonable
column3: is a myth at best. Take the example of one dominating [[Glossary|paradigm]] in science right now: Publish or perish. This paradigm highlights the current culture dominating most parts of science. If you do not produce a large amount of peer-reviewed publications
column4: your career will not continue. This created quite a demand on statistics as well
column5: and the urge to arrive at significant results that probably created frequent violations of Occam's razor (that is
column6: things should be as complex as necessary
column7: but as simple as possible). The reproducibility crisis in psychology is one example of these developments
column8: yet all other disciplines building on statistics struggle to this end
column9: too. Another problem is the fact that with this [[Questioning the status quo in methods|ever-increasing demand for ""scientific innovation""]]
column10: models evolve
column11: and it is hard to catch up. '''Thus
column12: instead of having robust and parsimonious models
column13: there are more and more unsuitable and overcomplicated models.''' The level of statistics at an average certainly increased. There are counter-examples where this is not necessarily the case
column14: and rightly so. In medicine
column15: for instance
column16: the canon of statistics is fairly established and solidified for large parts of the research landscape. Thus
column17: while many innovative publications are exploring new ways of statistics
column18: and a highly innovative to this end
column19: there is always a well-defined set of statistical methods that research can default on. Within many other branches of science
column20: however
column21: there is a certain increase in errors or at least slippery slopes. Statistics are part of the publish or perish
column22: and with this pressure still rising
column23: unreasonable actions in the application of statistics may still increase. Many other examples exist to this end
column24: but this should highlight that statistics is not only still developing further
column25: but statistics should also keep evolving
column26: otherwise we may not be able the diversity of epistemological knowledge it can offer.

column2: let us look at the three pillars of Western ethics and how these are intertwined with statistics. We all discuss how we act reasonable
column3: how we can maximize our happiness and how we live together as people. Hence reason
column4: utilitarianism and the social contract are all connected to statistics in one way or the other. While this complicated relation may in the future be explored in more than a short wiki entry
column5: lets focus on some examples here.

column1: One could say that utilitarianism created the single largest job boost for the profession of statisticians. From predicting economic development
column2: to calculating engineering problems
column3: to finding the right lever to tilt elections
column4: statistics are dominating in almost all aspects of modern society. '''Calculating the maximisation of utility is one of the large drivers of change in our globalised economy.''' But it does not stop there. Followers on social media and reply time to messages are two of many factors how to measure success in life these day
column5: often draining their direct human interactions in the process
column6: and leading to distraction or even torment. Philosophy is deeply engaged in discussing these conditions and dynamics
column7: yet statistics needs to embed these topics
column8: which are strongly related to ethics
column9: more into their curriculum. If we become mercenaries for people with questionable goals
column10: then we follow a long string of people that maximised utility for better or worse. History teaches us of the horrors that were conducted in the process of utility maximisation
column11: and we need to end this string of willing aids to illegitimate goals. Instead
column12: statistics should not only be about numbers
column13: but also about the fact that these numbers have meaning. Numbers are not abstract representations of the world
column14: but can have different meanings for different people. Hence numbers can add information that is missing
column15: and can serve as a starting point for an often necessary deeper reflection.

column1: Another problem that emerges out of statistics as seen from a perspective of ethics is the inability to accept different versions of reality. Statistics often arrives at a specific construction of reality
column2: which is the confirmed or rejected. After all
column3: most applications and interpretations in statistics are still from a standpoint of positivism. At best
column4: such a version of reality becomes then more and more refined
column5: until it becomes ultimately the accepted reality. Today
column6: more people would agree that versions of reality are mere snapshots and are probable to change in the future. Linking our empirical snapshots or reality with ethical concepts I possible but challenging. Hedonism would be one example where statistics can serve as a blunt and unreflected tool
column7: with the hedonist being the center of the universe. However
column8: personal identity is increasingly questioned
column9: and may play a different role in the future than it does today. We have to acknowledge that statistics is about epistemological knowledge
column10: while ethics can be about ontological truths. Statistics may thus build a refined version of reality
column11: while ethics can claim and alter between different realities that allow for the reflection of higher concepts or principles that transcend subjective realities and are thus non-empirical in a sense that these principles may be able to integrate all empirical realities. While this is one of the most daring endeavors in philosophy that emerged over the last decades
column12: it builds on the premise that ethics can start lines of thinking outside of empirical realities. This freedom in ethics i.e.
column13: through [[Thought Experiments]]
column14: is not possible in statistics. '''In Statistics
column15: the empirical nature requires a high workload and time effort
column16: which creates a penalty that ultimately makes statistics less able to compromise or integrate different versions of ethics.''' Future considerations need to clearly indicate what the limitations of statistics are
column17: and how this problem of linking to other lines of thinking i.e. ethicscan be solved
column18: even if such other worldviews violate statistical results or assumptions that characterize empirical realities. In other words
column19: you can consider your subjective perspective as your epistemological reality
column20: and I would argue that experience in statistics can enable you to develop a potentially better version of your epistemological reality. This may even change your ontological reality
column21: as it can interact with your ontological principles
column22: i.e. your moral views and ethical standpoints.

column1: '''A famous thought experiment from Derek Parfit is about 50 people dying of thirst in the desert.''' Imagine you could give them one glass of water
column2: leaving a few drops for each person. This would not prevent them from dying
column3: but it would still make a difference. You tried to help
column4: and some would even argue
column5: that if these people die
column6: they still die with the knowledge that somebody tried to help them. Hence your actions may matter even if they are ultimately futile
column7: yet classical ethics do not manage to account for such imperceptible consequences of our actions. Equally would a utilitarian statistician tell you that calculating the number of drops for each person is not only hard to measure
column8: but would probably anyway evaporate before the people could sip it.

column1: '''Another example is the tragic question of triage.''' Based on previous data and experience
column2: it is sometimes necessary to prioritize patients with the highest chance of survival
column3: for instance in the aftermath of a catastrophe. This has severe ethical ramifications and is known to put a severe emotional burden on medical personnel. While this follows a utilitarian approach
column4: there are wider consequences that fall within the realms of medical ethics.

column1: '''A third example is the repugnant conclusion.''' Are many quite happy people comparable to few very happy people? This question is widely considered to be a paradox
column2: which is also known as the mere addition problem. We cannot ‘objectively’ measure happiness
column3: and much less calculate it. What this teaches us is that it is difficult for us to judge whether a life is happy and worth living
column4: even if we personally do not consider it to be this way. People can have fulfilled lives without us understanding this. Here
column5: statistics fail once more

column1: '''In short:''' Ethnography encompasses diverse methodological approaches to gathering field data on social structures and phenomena.

column1: '''Ethnography can be regarded one of the most important qualitative research methods''' that looks back on a long tradition but also many transitions. The foundations of modern Ethnography reach back about a hundred years. Until 1900
column2: ethnographic information mostly originated from the collection of anthropological artifacts and descriptions of indigenous communities that were collected and reported by amateurs
column3: e.g. missionaries or travellers
column4: and subsequently evaluated by 'armchair' anthropologists. By the beginning of the 20th Century
column5: then
column6: anthropologists began to go into the field and get in contact with people themselves instead of relying on second-hand information (1).

column1: An influential figure for the subsequent development of Ethnography was '''Bronislaw Malinowski'''
column2: a Polish anthropologist who is considered to be the founder of fieldwork and participant observation methods relevant to Ethnography to this day (1
column3: 8). He invested himself in 'classical' ethnographic work
column4: spending months with a Melanesian community and gathering insights that he published in his 1922 work ""Argonauts of the Western Pacific"". He systematically recorded and later taught his approach to fieldwork
column5: which heavily furthered the methodological foundations of anthropology (1).

column3: and furthered the methodological groundwork for the field this way (1).

column2: Ethnography is historically and practically most closely related to the discipline of Anthropology and constitutes a defining method of this discipline (8). Still
column3: the theoretical reflections and methodological approaches also apply to research endeavours in other Social Sciences. Today

column4: but also a set of theoretical considerations on how to apply these methods (1). Ethnography attempts to understand the social world and actions of human beings in a specific cultural and societal surrounding of interest to the researcher (8). The researcher intends to systematically describe this [[Glossary|culture]] and understand another way of life from the 'native point of view' (Spradley (2)
column5: p.3). ""Rather than studying people
column6: ethnography means learning from people."" (Spradley
column7: p.3). According to Malinowski

column9: traditions
column10: institutions
column11: structures); what they actually do; and typical ways of thinking and feeling associated with these elements (1). The latter may be expressed directly by the studied individuals
column12: but may also be ''[[Glossary|tacit knowledge]]''
column13: i.e. knowledge that is inherent to the culture but taken for granted and communicated only indirectly through word and action (Spradley (2)
column14: p.5). Ethnographic research attempts to infer this knowledge by listening carefully
column15: observing and studying the culture in detail (2

column2: Ethnography is special due to its focus on field work
column3: i.e. gathering data within the context that is to be studied. It is important here that ethnographers immerse themselves in the daily praxis of the context they are studying to gain a 'native' perspective (1). Ethnographers immerse themselves in the social situations they study
column4: and attempt to openly engage with the activities of the daily lives of the individuals of interest while asking them questions
column5: observing

column19: 3). (Learning and) speaking the native language is an important part of the participation process (8). '''Participant observation is the primary method''' throughout this process. The researcher systematically observes situations according to his/her (current) research questions and takes mental and written notes (10). A diary may be kept to reflect upon the research experiences. Since it is not always clear from the beginning which information may be of interest
column20: the researcher needs to find a balance between noting everything worthwhile and still finding sufficient time to actually conduct the research (1).

column1: '''Observations are often supplemented by qualitative ethnographic interviews''' to gain a deeper understanding into previously observed situations. These are a form of [[Open Interview|open interview]] that focus on how the interviewees classify and describe their experiences and positions concerning their social context. Interviews may take place in-between observations
column2: or in dedicated
column3: set-up interview situations
column4: and also with groups of interviewees (1). The Interviewees may be asked about broad or specific situations. Elements that may be learned about are: people involved
column5: places used
column6: individual acts
column7: groups of acts that combine into activities or routines
column8: events
column9: objects
column10: goals
column11: time and feelings (4). The ethnographic interview differs from standard open interviews in that it tries not to impose any pre-conceived notions and structures on how the interviewee might view
column12: define or classify these elements according to his/her worldview. Instead
column13: the questions are formulated so that the interview is almost entirely guided by the interviewee's responses (1
column14: 5). This way
column15: the researcher may be able to extract insight into ""(...) contextual understandings
column16: shared assumptions and common knowledge upon which a respondent's answers are based (...). Ethnographic questions are used to elicit the perceptions and knowledge that guide behavior
column17: while discouraging individuals from translating this information into a form corresponding to the researcher's revealed understanding and language."" (Johnston et al. 1995
column18: p.57f). In such an interview
column19: the power relation between researcher and interviewee is shifted

column21: but the interviewee has all the information to offer that is of interest to the researcher. Therefore
column22: a trustful relationship between the researcher and the interviewee is of special importance (4

column1: '''Ethnography is thus a very open and inductive process'''
column2: with the researcher acting like an explorer who does not rely on strictly pre-defined questions leading his/her research

column14: the observations are rather descriptive

column1: The focus of Ethnography on gathering data in the 'natural' context is crucial for the quality of the results. Being in the very situation and watching what people do and learning about their thoughts on the situation as it happens allows for more insightful conclusions. The alternative - having individuals report in a dedicated
column2: external setting
column3: before or after the situation happening - might be biased since people do not always do what they say they do (1). For further challenges

column1: * Ethnography can be seen as a powerful tool to inform people about other people's lifeworlds

column1: * O'Reilly (1) discusses implications of ethical field work. For ethical reasons
column2: the researcher should not disguise his/her presence but be open about his/her role and research intent. Consent should be given by all individuals studied and disclosure on the subsequent usage of the data as well as confidentiality should be provided. At the same time
column3: being too open and transparent might complicate the immersion of the researcher in the studied situation
column4: thus negatively affect the data gathered
column5: or even make it impossible due to the iteractive nature of the research process. The researcher should attempt to balance openness so that no harm is done
column6: but not constantly remind everyone of his/her role as a researcher in order to ensure useful research results. For further elaborations on ethical considerations
column7: refer to O'Reilly (1).

column1: * Malinowski emphasized that the observations done in the field should not be conducted randomly
column2: but systematically. They should not only focus on the extraordinary elements of each situation
column3: but rather provide a comprehensive collection of all individual elements. This also involves the detailed
column4: written description of the context and setting as well as the methods of the observation (1).

column1: * Time is a crucial factor for observation since it takes some time for the researcher
column2: being an outsider to the analyzed context
column3: to get acquainted with the situation and gain a feeling of the people's perspective (8). This also reduces the risk of the people behaving differently than they usually would due to the researcher's presence
column4: since they get used to his/her presence after some time. Additionally
column5: spending a sufficient amount of time with the situation of interest allows for the researcher to change the directions of the research and narrow down the research focus after first conclusions emerge (see What the method does) (1).

column1: * Participation is an important element of ethnographic fieldwork. Instead of relying only on external observations
column2: the researcher should join the observed people and get in contact with the respective situations to get a better feel for an insider's perspectives. However
column3: this participation might influence the 'objectivity' of the observation (1).

Experiments describe the systematic and reproducible design to test specific hypothesis.

Starting with [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Why_statistics_matters#The_scientific_method Francis Bacon] there was the theoretical foundation to shift previously widely un-systematic experiments into a more structured form. With the rise of disciplines in the [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Why_statistics_matters#A_very_short_history_of_statistics enlightenment] experiments thrived
column2: also thanks to an increasing amount of resources available in Europe due to the Victorian age and other effects of colonialism. Deviating from more observational studies in physics
column3: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_experiments#Galileo_Galilei astronomy]
column4: biology and other fields
column5: experiments opened the door to the wide testing of hypothesis. All the while Mill and others build on Bacon to derive the necessary basic debates about so called facts
column6: building the theoretical basis to evaluate the merit of experiments. Hence these systematic experimental approaches aided many fields such as botany
column7: chemistry
column8: zoology
column9: physics and [http://www.academia.dk/Blog/wp-content/uploads/KlinLab-Hist/LabHistory1.pdf much more]
column10: but what was even more important
column11: these fields created a body of knowledge that kickstarted many fields of research
column12: and even solidified others. The value of systematic experiments
column13: and consequently systematic knowledge created a direct link to practical application of that knowledge. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UdQreBq6MOY The scientific method] -called with the ignorant recognition of no other methods beside systematic experimental hypothesis testing as well as standardisation in engineering- hence became the motor of both the late enlightenment as well as the industrialisation
column14: proving a crucial link between basically enlightenment and modernity.

column4: meaning ideally with a 100 % confidence. Laboratory conditions thus aimed at creating constant conditions and manipulating ideally only one or few parameters
column5: which were then manipulated and therefore tested systematically. Necessary repetitions were conducted as well

column1: ==Key concepts of laboratory experiments – sampling data in experimental designs==

The number of treatments or '''factor levels''' defines the '''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Cm0vFoGVMB8 degrees of freedom]''' of an experiment. The more levels are tested

column9: which can be calculated based on the experimental design. Therefore

column1: '''The [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/a/anova.asp ANOVA] is one key analysis tool of [[Experiments|laboratory experiments]]''' - but also other experiments as we shall see later. This statistical test is - mechanically speaking - comparing the means of more than two groups by extending the restriction of the [[Simple_Statistical_Tests#Two_sample_t-test|t-test]]. Comparing different groups became thus a highly important procedure in the design of experiments
column2: which is
column3: apart from laboratories
column4: also highly relevant in greenhouse experiments in ecology
column5: where conditions are kept stable through a controlled environment.

column1: The general principle of the ANOVA is rooted in [[Experiments and Hypothesis Testing|hypothesis testing]]. An idealized null hypothesis is formulated against which the data is being tested. If the ANOVA gives a significant result
column2: then the null hypothesis is rejected
column3: hence it is statistically unlikely that the data confirms the null hypothesis. As one gets an overall p-value
column4: it can be thus confirmed whether the different groups differ overall. Furthermore
column5: the ANOVA allows for a measure beyond the p-value through the '''sum of squares calculations''' which derive how much is explained by the data
column6: and how large in relation the residual or unexplained information is.

column1: Regarding the preconditions of the [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oOuu8IBd-yo ANOVA]
column2: it is important to realize that the data should ideally be '''normally distributed''' on all levels
column3: which however is often violated due to small sample sizes. Since a non-normal distribution may influence the outcome of the test
column4: boxplots are a helpful visual aid
column5: as these allow for a simple detection tool of non-normal distribution levels.

column1: Equally should ideally the variance be comparable across all levels
column2: which is called '''[https://blog.minitab.com/blog/statistics-and-quality-data-analysis/dont-be-a-victim-of-statistical-hippopotomonstrosesquipedaliophobia homoscedastic]'''. What is also important is the criteria of '''independence'''
column3: meaning that samples of factor levels should not influence each other. For this reason are for instance in ecological experiments plants typically planted in individual pots. In addition does the classical ANOVA assume a '''balanced design'''
column4: which means that all factor levels have an equal sample size. If some factor levels have less samples than others
column5: this might pose interactions in terms of normals distribution and variance
column6: but there is another effect at play. Larger sample sizes on one factor level may create a disbalance
column7: where factor levels with larger samples pose a larger influence on the overall model result.

column1: Single factor analysis that are also called '[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nvAMVY2cmok one-way ANOVAs]' investigate one factor variable
column2: and all other variables are kept constant. Depending on the number of factor levels these demand a so called [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_square randomisation]
column3: which is necessary to compensate for instance for microclimatic differences under lab conditions.

column1: Designs with multiple factors or '[https://www.thoughtco.com/analysis-of-variance-anova-3026693 two way ANOVAs]' test for two or more factors
column2: which then demands to test for interactions as well. This increases the necessary sample size on a multiplicatory scale
column3: and the degrees of freedoms may dramatically increase depending on the number of factors levels and their interactions. An example of such an interaction effect might be an experiment where the effects of different watering levels and different amounts of fertiliser on plant growth are measured. While both increased water levels and higher amounts of fertiliser right increase plant growths slightly
column4: the increase of of both factors jointly might lead to a dramatic increase of plant growth.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-05-15 um 14.13.34.png|thumb|These boxplots are from the R dataset ToothGrowth. The boxplots which you can see here differ significantly.]]

Boxplots provide a first visual clue to whether certain factor levels might be significantly different within an ANOVA analysis. If one box within a boxplot is higher or lower than the median of another factor level
column2: then this is a good rule of thumb whether there is a significant difference. When making such a graphically informed assumption
column3: we have to be however really careful if the data is normally distributed
column4: as skewed distributions might tinker with this rule of thumb. The overarching guideline for the ANOVA are thus the p-values
column5: which give significance regarding the difference between the different factor levels.

column1: It can however also be relevant to compare the difference between specific groups
column2: which is made by a '''[https://www.statisticshowto.com/post-hoc/ posthoc test]'''. A prominent example is the [https://sciencing.com/what-is-the-tukey-hsd-test-12751748.html Tukey Test]
column3: where two factor levels are compared
column4: and this is done iteratively for all factor level combinations. Since this poses a problem of multiple testing
column5: there is a demand for a [https://www.statisticshowto.com/post-hoc/ Bonferonni correction] to adjust the p-value. Mechanically speaking
column6: this is comparable to conducting several t-tests between two factor level combinations
column7: and adjusting the p-values to consider the effects of multiple testing.

column1: The ANOVA builds on a constructed world
column2: where factor levels are like all variables constructs
column3: which might be prone to errors or misconceptions. We should therefore realize that a non-significant result might also be related to the factor level construction. Yet a potential flaw can also range beyond implausible results
column4: since ANOVAs do not necessarily create valid knowledge. If the underlying theory is imperfect
column5: then we might confirm a hypothesis that is overall wrong. Hence the strong benefit of the ANOVA - the systematic testing of hypothesis - may equally be also its weakest point
column6: as science develops
column7: and previous hypothesis might have been imperfect if not wrong.

column2: many researchers use the ANOVA today in an inductive sense. With more and more data becoming available
column3: even from completely undersigned sampling sources
column4: the ANOVA becomes the analysis of choice if the difference between different factor levels is investigated for a continuous variable. Due to the [[Glossary|emergence]] of big data
column5: these applications could be seen critical
column6: since no real hypothesis are being tested. Instead
column7: the statistician becomes a gold digger
column8: searching the vastness of the available data for patterns
column9: [[Causality#Correlation_is_not_Causality|may these be causal or not]]. While there are numerous benefits
column10: this is also a source of problems. Non-designed datasets will for instance not be able to test for the impact a drug might have on a certain diseases. This is a problem
column11: as systematic knowledge production is almost assumed within the ANOVA
column12: but its application these days is far away from it. The inductive and the deductive world become intertwined
column13: and this poses a risk for the validity of scientific results.

column1: '''At this point it is important to know that there are two types of hypotheses.''' Let us imagine that you assume
column2: there are not only white swans in the world
column3: but also black swans.

column1: The null hypothesis (H0) states that this is not the case - everything is as we assumed before you came around the corner with your crazy claim. Therfore
column2: the null hypothesis would be: all swans are white. The alternative hypothesis (H1) now challenges this null hypothesis: there are also black swans. This is what you claimed in the first place. We do not assume however right away that whatever you came up with is true
column3: so we make it the alternative hypothesis. The idea is now to determine whether there is enough evidence to support the alternative hypothesis. To do so
column4: we test the likelihood of the H0 being true in order to decide whether to accept the H0
column5: or if we reject it and rather accept the H1. Both go together - when we accept one of both hypotheses
column6: we simultaneously reject the other hypothesis
column7: and vice-versa. Caution: Hypotheses can only be rejected
column8: they cannot be verified based on data. When it is said that a hypothesis is 'accepted' or 'verified' or 'proven'
column9: this only means that the alternative cannot be supported
column10: and we therefore stick to the more probable hypothesis.
