column1: Validity is derived from the Latin word ""validus"" which translates as ""strong"". It is thus a [https://explorable.com/statistical-validity central concept within hypothesis testing]
column2: as it qualifies to which extent a hypothesis is true. Its meaning should not be confused with reliability which indicates whether certain results are consistent
column3: or in other words reproducible. Validity instead indicates the extent to which a hypothesis can be confirmed. As a consequence
column4: it is central for the deductive approach in science; in other words: it should not be misused beyond that line of thinking. Validity is therefore strongly associated with reasoning
column5: which is why it indicates the overall strength of the outcome of a statistical result.

column1: We should however be aware that validity encompasses the [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F6LGa8jsdjo whole process of the application of statistics]. '''Validity spans from the postulation of the original hypothesis over the methodological design
column2: the choice of analysis and finally the interpretation.''' Validity is hence not an ''all or nothing''. Instead we need to learn the diverse approaches and flavours of validity
column3: and only experience across diverse datasets and situations will allow us to judge whether a result is valid or not. This is one of the situations where statistics and philosophy are maybe the closest. In philosophy it is very hard to define reason
column4: and much of Western philosophy has been indeed devoted to reason. While it is much easier to define unreasonable acts (and rationality is altogether a different issue)
column5: reason in itself is more complex
column6: many would argue. Consequently
column7: validity of the question whether the confirmation of a hypothesis is reasonable
column8: is much harder to answer. Take your time to learn about validity
column9: and take even more time to gain experience on wether a result is valid.

column1: [https://www.scribbr.com/methodology/reliability-vs-validity/ Reliability] is one of the key concepts of statistics. It is defined as the consistency of a specific measure. '''A reliable measure is hence producing comparable results under the same conditions.''' Reliability gives you an idea whether your analysis is accurate under the given conditions and also reproducible. We already learned that most
column2: if not all
column3: measures in statistics are constructed. Reliability is central since we can check whether our constructed measures bring us on the right track. In other words
column4: reliability allows us to understand if our constructed measures are working.

column1: The question of [https://explorable.com/statistical-reliability reproducibility] which is associated to reliability is a [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m0W8nnupcUk central aspect of modern science]. Reliability is hence the concept that contains at least several components.

1. The extent and complexity of the measure that we include in our analysis. While it cannot be generally assumed that [[To Rule And To Measure|extremely constructed measures such as GDP or IQ]] are less reliable than less constructed ones
column2: we should still consider Occam's razor when thinking about the reliability of measures
column3: i.e. keep your constructs short and simple.

column1: 2. Relevant for reliability is the question of our [[sampling|sample]]. If external conditions of the sample change then
column2: due to new information
column3: reliability might decrease. An easy example would again be swans. If we state that there are just white swans
column4: this hypothesis is reliable as long as there are just white swans sampled. But when the external conditions change - for example when we discover black swans in Australia - the reliability of our first hypothesis decreases.

column2: sampling can also be affected. If sampling is done by several observers then a reduction in reliability may be explained by the differences of the respective observers.

column1: 4. We have to recognise that different methodological approaches - or more specifically in our case
column2: statistical tests - may consist of different measures of reliability. Hence the statistical model of our analysis might directly translate into different reliabilities. An easy example to explain this a bit better is the one sample test with a perfect coin. This test should work but it does not work anymore when the coin is biased. Then we have to consider a new method/model to explain this (namely the ""two sample test""). The important thing to remember is: The choice of your method/model has an impact on your test results.

column1: 5. The last aspect of reliability is related to our theoretical foundation itself. If our underlying theory is revised or changed
column2: then this might tinker with the overall reliability of our results. This is important to highlight
column3: since we might have an overall better theoretical foundation within a given statistical analysis
column4: however the statistical measure of reliability might be lower. This is a source of continuous confusion among apprentices in statistics.

column1: The question how reliable statistical analysis or better the result of a scientific study is
column2: is in my experience the source of endless debates. There is no [https://www.statisticssolutions.com/directory-of-statistical-analyses-reliability-analysis/ measure of reliability] that is accepted by everybody. Instead
column3: statistics are still evolving
column4: and measures of reliability change. While this seems confusing at first
column5: we should differentiate between results that are extremely reliable and results that are lower in terms of reliability. [https://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/05/17/how-reliable-are-the-social-sciences/ Results from hard science] such as physics often show a high reliability when it comes to statistical testing
column6: while soft science such as psychology and economics can be found at the lower end of reliability. There is no normative judgement employed here
column7: since modern medicine often produces results that are reliable
column8: but only just so. Consider research in cancer. Most current breakthroughs change the lives of a few percentages of patients and there is hardly a breakthrough that can affect a larger proportion of patients. We thus have to accept reliability in statistics as a moving target
column9: and it depends very much on the context whether a result is having a high or low reliability.

column2: Why & When ==

column1: ''Teaching is the best way to learn.''

column2: named after famous physician Richard Feynman
column3: is a learning technique that builds on the idea that explaining a topic to someone is the best way to learn it. This approach helps us better understand what we are learning
column4: and not just memorize technical terms. This way
column5: we can more easily transfer our new knowledge to unknown situations.

column1: * Obtain a profound understanding of any topic.
* Learn more quickly and with more depth.
* Become able to explain any given topic to anyone.
The Feynman method is a simple
column2: circular process:

column1: # '''Select the topic you want to learn more about.''' This can be something you need to learn for an exam
column2: or something you are just interested in knowing more about. Don't go to broad - focus on a specific topic. You will not be able to explain ""Economics"" or ""Physics"" in one go.
this person does not know anything about this topic. If you don't have someone to talk to
column3: you can also just speak out loud to yourself
column4: or write your presentation down. Start explaining the topic in simple terms.

column1: # '''Make notes.''' You will quickly realize yourself which parts of the topic you are not able to explain
column2: and/or have not understood yourself. You might feel bad for a moment
column3: but this step is important - it prevents you from pretending to yourself that you understood everything
column4: when in fact you did not. Write down what you do not understand sufficiently! If you get feedback on which parts you did not properly explain
column5: write this down
column6: too. Lastly
column7: write down where you used very technical
column8: specific terms
column9: even if your audience might have understood them. Someone else might not
column10: and you should be able to do without them.

column1: # '''Have a look at your notes and try to find more information.''' Read scientific publications
column2: Wikipedia entries or dedicated books; watch documentaries or YouTube videos - have a look at everything that may help you better understand the topic
column3: and fill your knowledge gaps. Pay attention to the technical terms that you used
column4: and find better ways to explain these things without relying on the terms.

column1: # '''Now explain the topic again.''' Possibly you can speak to the same person as previously. Did they understood you better now? Were you able to explain also those parts that you could not properly explain before? There will likely still be some gaps
column2: or unclear spots in your explanation. This is why the Feynman method is circular: go back to the second step of taking notes
column3: and repeat until you can confidently explain the topic to anyone
column4: and they will understand it. Now you have also understood it. Congratulations!

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-05-21 um 15.46.03.png|thumb|Field experiments were as you may could guess first conducted in agriculture.]]

column2: it became apparent that the controlled setting of a laboratory was not enough. First in astronomy
column3: but then also in agriculture and other fields the notion became apparent that our [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Experiments#History_of_laboratory_experiments reproducible settings may sometimes be hard to achieve]. Observations can be unreliable
column4: and error of measurements in astronomy was a prevalent problem in the 18th and 19th century. Fisher equally recognised the mess - or variance - that nature forces onto a systematic experimenter. The demand for more food due to the rise in population
column5: and the availability of potent seed varieties and fertiliser - both made possible thanks to scientific experimentation - raised the question how to conduct [https://explorable.com/field-experiments experiments under field conditions]. Making experiments in the laboratory reached its outer borders
column6: as plant growth experiments were hard to conduct in the small confined spaces of a laboratory
column7: and it was questioned whether the results were actually applicable in the real world. Hence experiments literally shifted into fields
column8: with a [https://www.tutor2u.net/psychology/reference/field-experimentsme dramatic effect on their design
column9: conduct and outcome]. While laboratory conditions aimed to minimise variance - ideally conducting experiments with a high confidence -
column10: the new field experiments increased sample size to tame the variability - or messiness - of factors that could not be controlled
column11: such as subtle changes in the soil or microclimate. [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_experiment#Examples Establishing the field experiment] became thus a step in the scientific development
column12: but also in the industrial development. Science contributed directly to the efficiency of production
column13: for better or worse.

column1: ==Key concepts in the application of field experiments==
[[File:Hypothesis Testing überarbeitet.png|thumb|You are probably already familiar with this type of overview but it is one of the most commen research designs.]]
The analyis of variance was actually inspired widely by field experiments
column2: as Fisher was working with crop data which proved as a valuable playground to develop and test his statistical approaches. It is remarkable that the p-value was actually chosen by him and did not follow any wider thinking within a community. Probably not since Linne or Darwin did a whole century of researchers commit their merits to a principle derived by one person
column3: as scientific success and whole careers are build on results measured by the p-value. It should however be noted that the work needed to generate enough replicates to measure probability with Fishers measure of 0.05 was actually severe within crop experiments when compared to lab settings. In a lab you can have a few hundred Petri dishes or plant pots and these can be checked by a lab technician. Replicates in an agricultural field are more space and labour intense
column4: while of course lab space is more expensive per square meter. In order to design field experiments where enough replicates were made
column5: in order to enable testing at an appropriate significance level
column6: demanded nothing less than a revolution in the planning of studies. With all its imperfections and criticism
column7: Fishers use of the p-value can probably be credited for increasing sample number in experiments towards a sensible and sufficient level. [https://conjointly.com/kb/experimental-design/ Study designs] became the new norm
column8: and are an essential part of science ever since.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-05-21 um 15.54.10.png|thumb|Field experiments are often divided into quadrangles
column2: and these then represent a certain treatment or treatment combination. In a randomized experiment
column3: a study sample is then randomly divided into treatment and control groups.]]

column1: Field experiments try to compensate for gradients that infer variance within a sample design by increasing the number of samples. However
column2: in order to uncouple the effects of underlying variance
column3: [https://isps.yale.edu/node/16697 randomisation] is central. Take the example of an agricultural field that has more sandy soils on one end
column4: and more loamy soils on the other end. If now all samples of one treatment would be on the loamy end of the field
column5: and all samples of another treatment would be at the sandy end of the field
column6: then the treatment effect would contain an artefact of the soil gradient. Randomisation in fields is hence essential to maximize independence of the treatment effect from the underlying variance. A classical chessboard illustrates the design step of randomisation quite nicely
column7: since field experiments are often divided into quadrangles
column8: and these then represent a certain treatment or treatment combination. Especially in [https://www.sare.org/Learning-Center/Bulletins/How-to-Conduct-Research-on-Your-Farm-or-Ranch/Text-Version/Basics-of-Experimental-Design agricultural fields]
column9: such an approach was also following a certain pragmatism
column10: since neighbouring quadrangles might have a tendency to influence each other
column11: i.e. through root competition. While this error is often hard to take into account
column12: it is quite relevant to notice that enough replicates might at least allow to tame this problem
column13: and make the error introduced by such interactions less relevant overall. Just as we should apply randomisation when sampling for instance a representative sample from a population
column14: the same approach is applied in the design of experiments.

column1: [[File:Block Experiments.jpg|thumb|Designing an experiment using block effects.]]
In order to tame the variance of the real world
column2: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=10ikXret7Lk blocking] was a plausible approach. By basically introducing agricultural fields as [https://www.ndsu.edu/faculty/horsley/RCBD.pdf blocks]
column3: the variance from individual blocks can be tamed. This was one of the breakthroughs
column4: as the question of what we want to know i.e. hypothesis testing
column5: was statistically uncoupled from the question what we do not want to know
column6: i.e. the variance inferred from individual blocks. Consequently
column7: the samples and treatment combinations need to be randomised within the different blocks
column8: or can be alternatively replicated within these blocks. This has become established as a standard approach in the designing of experiments
column9: often for rather pragmatic reasons. For instance are [https://www.sare.org/Learning-Center/Bulletins/How-to-Conduct-Research-on-Your-Farm-or-Ranch/Text-Version/Basics-of-Experimental-Design/Common-Research-Designs-for-Farmers agricultural fields] often showing local characteristics in terms of soil and microclimate
column10: and these should be tamed by the clear designation of blocks and enough blocks in total within the experiment. The last point is central when thinking in terms of variance
column11: since it would naturally be very hard to think in terms of variance regarding e.g. only two blocks. A higher number of blocks allow to better tame the block effect. This underlines the effort that often needs to go into designing experiments
column12: since a sufficient number of blocks would basically mean that the effort can be multiplied by the number of blocks that are part of the design. Ten blocks means ten times as much work
column13: and maybe with the result that there is no variance among the blocks overall.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-05-21 um 17.06.05.png|thumb|A nested design is used for experiments in which there is an interest in a set of treatments and the experimental units are sub-sampled.]]

column2: one factor is often nested within another factor. The [https://www.theanalysisfactor.com/the-difference-between-crossed-and-nested-factors/ principle of nestedness] works generally like the principle of Russian dolls: Smaller ones are encapsulated within larger ones. For instance can a block be seen as the largest Russian doll
column3: and the treatments are then nested in the block
column4: meaning each treatment is encapsulated within each block. This allows for a testing where the variance of the block effect can be minimised
column5: and the variance of the treatment levels can be statistically compared. Quite often the variance across different levels of nestedness is a relevant information in itself
column6: meaning for instance how much variance is explained by a different factor. Especially spatially [https://www.ohio.edu/plantbio/staff/mccarthy/quantmet/lectures/ANOVA-III.pdf nested designs] can have such a hierarchical structure
column7: such as neighbourhoods within cities
column8: streets within neighbourhoods and houses in streets. The nested structure would in this case be Cities/neighbourhoods/streets/houses. Just as with blocks
column9: a nested structure demands a clear designing of an experiment
column10: and greatly increase the sample size. Hence such a design should be implemented after much reflection
column11: based on experience
column12: and ideally by [[Glossary|consultation]] with experts both in statistics as well as the given system.

column1: [[File:Farm-fields-crops-green.jpg|thumb|left|How to grow our plants best? If we simplify our model and eliminate nonsignificant treatments
column2: we may find out.]]

column1: The analysis of field experiments demands great care
column2: since this is mostly a deductive approach where equal emphasis is put on what we understand
column3: and what we do not understand. Alternatively
column4: we could highlight that rejection of the hypothesis is the most vital step of any experiment. In statistical terms the question of explained vs. unexplained variance is essential.

column1: The first step is however checking the p-value. Which treatments are significant
column2: and which ones are not? When it comes to two-way [[ANOVA]]s
column3: we may need to reduce the model to obtain a minimum adequate model. This basically equals a reduction of the full model into the most parsimonious version
column4: following Occam's razor. While some researchers tend to report the full model
column5: with all non-significant treatments and treatment combinations
column6: I think this is wrong. If we reduce the model
column7: the p-values change. This can make the difference between a treatment that is significant
column8: and a non-significant model. Therefore
column9: [https://support.minitab.com/en-us/minitab/18/help-and-how-to/modeling-statistics/regression/supporting-topics/regression-models/model-reduction/ model reduction] is being advised for. For the sake of simplicity
column10: this can be done by first reducing the highest level interactions that are not significant. However
column11: the single effects always need to be included
column12: as the single effects are demanded if interactions of a treatment are part of the model
column13: even if these single effects are not significant. An example of such a procedure would be the NPK dataset in R - it contains information about the effect of nitrogen
column14: phosphate and potassium on the growth of peas. There
column15: a full model can be constructed
column16: and then the non-significant treatments and treatment interactions are subsequently removed to arrive at the minimum adequate model
column17: which is the most parsimonious model. This illustrates that Occam's razor is not only a theoretical principle
column18: but has direct application in statistics.

column1: Once we have a minimum adequate model
column2: we might want to check the explained variance as well as the unexplained variance. Within a block experiment we may want to check how much variance is explained on a block level. In a nested experiment
column3: the explained variance among all levels should be preferably checked.

column2: it could be beneficial to check the residuals across all factor levels. While this is often hampered by a smaller sample size
column3: it might be helpful to understand the behaviour of the model
column4: especially when initial inspection in a boxplot showed flaws or skews in the distribution.

column1: [[File:Smoking trooper.jpg|thumb|right|If smoking is a fixed or a random effect depends on the study design]]

column2: the question whether a variable is a [https://web.ma.utexas.edu/users/mks/statmistakes/fixedvsrandom.html fixed or a random] factor is often difficult to consider. Generally
column3: fixed effects are about what we want to find out
column4: while random effects are about aspects which variance we explicitly want to ignore
column5: or better
column6: get rid of. However
column7: it is our choice and part of our design whether a factor is random or fixed. Within most medical trials the information whether someone smokes or not is a random factor
column8: since it is known that smoking influences much of what these studies might be focusing about. This is of course different if these studies focus explicitly on the effects of smoking. Then smoking would be a fixed factor
column9: and the fact whether someone smokes or not is part of the research. Typically
column10: factors that are part of a block design are random factors
column11: and variables that are constructs relating to our hypothesis are fixed variables. To this end
column12: it is helpful to consult existing studies to differentiate between [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vb0GvznHf8U random and fixed factors]. Current medical trials may consider many variables
column13: and have to take even more random factors into account. Testing the impact of random factors on the raw data is often a first step when looking at initial data
column14: yet this does not help if it is a purely deductive design. In this case
column15: simplified pre-tests are often a first step to make initial attempts to understand the system and also check whether variables - both fixed or random - are feasible and can be utilised in the respective design. Initial pre-tests at such smaller scales are a typical approach in medical research
column16: yet other branches of research reject them as being too unsystematic. Fisher himself championed small sample designs
column17: and we would encourage pre-tests in field experiments if at all possible. Later flaws and errors in the design can be prevented
column18: although form a statistical standpoint the value of such pre-tests may be limited at best.

column1: [[File:Karl Popper.jpg|thumb|left|Karl Popper emphasised that facts can only be approximated
column2: i.e. are only considered to be true as long as they are not falsified.]]

column1: [[File:Ronald Fisher.jpg|thumb|right|Fisher's approach of considering the variance of the real world in statistics can be seen as perfectly complementary to Popper's epistemological reflections.]]
Acknowledging unexplained variance was a breakthrough in modern science
column2: as we should acknowledge that understanding a phenomena fairly well now is better than understanding something perfectly
column3: but never. In a sense was the statistical developing of uncertainty reflected in philosophical theory
column4: as [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Hypothesis_building#Testing_of_hypothesis Karl Popper] highlighted the imperfection of experiments in testing or falsification of theories. Understanding the limitations of the scientific endeavour thus became an important baseline
column5: and the scientific experiments tried partly to take this into account through recognising the limitations of the result. What is however often confused is whether the theory is basically imperfect - hence the results are invalid or implausible - or whether the experiment was conducted in an imperfect sense
column6: making the results unreliable. The imperfection to understand the difference between flaws in theory and flaws in conducting the experiment is a continuous challenge of modern science. When looking at unexplained variance
column7: we always have to consider that our knowledge can be limited through theory and empirical conduct
column8: and these two flaws are not clearly separated. Consequently
column9: unexplained variance remains a blank in our knowledge
column10: and should always be highlighted as such. As much as it is important to acknowledge what we know
column11: it is at least equally important to highlight what we do not know.

column1: Interpreting results from field experiments demands experience. First of all
column2: we shall interpret the p-value
column3: and check which treatments and interactions are significant. Here
column4: many researchers argue that we should report the full model
column5: yet I would disagree. P-values in ANOVA summaries differ between the so called full models -which include all predictors- and minimum adequate models -which thrive to be the most parsimonious models. Model reduction is essential
column6: as the changing p-values may make a difference between models that are reporting true results
column7: or flawed probabilities that vaporize once the non-significant terms are subsequently reduced. Therefore
column8: one by one we need to minimize the model in its complexity
column9: and reduce the model until it only contains significant interaction terms as well as the maybe even non-significant single terms
column10: which we have to include if the interaction is significant. This will give us a clear idea which treatments have a significant effect on the dependent variable.

column2: when expecting model results we should interpret the sum of squares
column3: thereby evaluating how much of the respective treatment is explain the effect of the dependent variable. While this is partly related to the p-value
column4: it is also important to note how much variance is explained by potential block factors. In addition
column5: it is also important to notice how much remains unexplained in total
column6: as this residual variance indicates how much we do not understand using this experimental approach. This is extremely related to the specific context
column7: and we need to be aware that knowledge of previous studies may aid us in understanding the value of our contribution.

column2: we need to take further flaws into our considerations when interpreting results from field experiments. Are there extreme outliers. How do the residuals look like? Is any treatment level showing signs of an uneven distribution or gaps? Do the results seem to be representative? We need to be very critical of our own results
column3: and always consider that the results reflect only a part of reality.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-05-21 um 17.10.27.png|thumb|One famous example from the discipline of psychology is the Milgram shock experiment carried out by Stanley Milgram a professor from the Yale University in 1963.]]
Field experiments became a revolution for many scientific fields. The systematic testing of hypotheses allowed first for [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Fisher#Rothamsted_Experimental_Station
column2: _1919%E2%80%931933 agriculture] and [https://revisesociology.com/2016/01/17/field-experiments-sociology/ other fields] of production to thrive
column3: but then also did medicine
column4: [https://www.simplypsychology.org/milgram.html psychology]
column5: ecology and even [https://www.nature.com/articles/s41599-019-0372-0 economics] use experimental approaches to test specific questions. This systematic generation of knowledge triggered a revolution in science
column6: as knowledge became subsequently more specific and detailed. Take antibiotics
column7: where a wide array of remedies was successively developed and tested. This triggered the cascading effects of antibiotic resistance
column8: demanding new and updated versions to keep track with the bacteria that are likewise constantly evolving. This showcases that while the field experiment led to many positive developments
column9: it also created ripples that are hard to anticipate. There is an overall crisis in complex experiments that is called replication crisis. What is basically meant by that is that some possibilities to replicate the results of studies -often also of landmark papers- failed spectacularly. In other words
column10: a substantial proportion of modern research cannot be reproduced. This crisis affects many arenas in sciences
column11: among them psychology
column12: medicine
column13: and economics. While much can be said about the roots and reasons of this crisis
column14: let us look at it from a statistical standpoint. First of all
column15: at a threshold of p=0.05
column16: a certain arbitrary amount of models can be expected to be significant purely by chance. Second
column17: studies are often flawed through the connection between theory and methodological design
column18: where for instance much of the dull results remains unpublished
column19: and statistical designs can biased towards a specific results. Third
column20: statistics slowly eroded into a culture where more complex models and the rate of statistical fishing increased. Here
column21: a preregistration of your design can help
column22: which is often done now in psychology and medicine. Researchers submit their study design to an external platform before they conduct their study
column23: thereby safeguarding from later manipulation. Much can be said to this end
column24: and we are only starting to explore this possibility in other arenas. However
column25: we need to be aware that also when we add complexity to our research designs
column26: especially in field experiments the possibility of replication diminished
column27: since we may not take factors into account that we are unaware of. In other words
column28: we sacrifice robustness with our ever increasing wish for more complicated designs in statistics. Our ambition in modern research thus came with a price
column29: and a clear documentation is one antidote how we might cure the flaws we introduced through  our ever more complicated experiments. Consider Occam’s razor also when designing a study.

column2: Why & When ==

column1: '''A Fishbowl is a medium-length dialogue format for large groups
column2: lead by a moderator'''. Four to five people discuss a question or topic while being surrounded by a typically much bigger audience
column3: which is enabled to participate in the discussion by taking one of the chairs in the discussion group. The Fish Bowl format can be used for teaching (e.g. group discussions in seminars)
column4: for workshops (e.g. in work environments
column5: events
column6: organisational activities)
column7: or for stage discussions (e.g. on conferences). Depending on the context
column8: the lenght of a fishbowl discussion can range from 15-20 minute sessions to more than an hour
column9: with 30-45 minutes being rather typical.

column1: * Engage the whole audience in a discussion in an active and structured manner
column2: which makes the discussion more interesting
column3: lively and and richer in perspectives.

column2: four to five chairs are arranged in a circle
column3: with a larger number of chairs forming another circle around them. In a variation
column4: only two chairs may be placed for a face-to-face conversation. Participants for the discussions
column5: including one moderator
column6: occupy the chairs
column7: with the audience filling the surrounding chairs. This arrangement (see visualisation) gives the Fishbowl its name. The discussants should be rather heterogenous to allow for an interesting and potentially controversial discussion.

column1: * '''There are two different forms of the Fishbowl:'''

column2: where one chair is left empty and any audience member may
column3: at any time of the discussion
column4: enter the discussion circle
column5: take the chair and thus force one of the discussants to leave his/her own chair and go back into the audience. Instead of leaving one chair unoccupied
column6: the audience members may also tap one participant on the shoulder to indicate them to leave.

column2: where an audience member may only enter the stage when one of the discussants leaves after a pre-determined amount of time.

column1: * The audience member that takes the free chair immediately receives the right to speak. In general
column2: only one person is allowed to speak at a time
column3: with the moderator ensuring a respectful discussion. The amount of audience members that participate in the discussion depends on the size of the audience
column4: the purpose of the discussion and the time budget. (commonly 30-45 minutes).

column1: * The discussion should be led by the moderator in a way that makes everybody feel like they can contribute. Questions should not be too specific or complex for the general audience to understand and the moderator (as well as the other discussants) should provide a feeling of welcoming all opinions and levels of expertise.
* A challenge with the Fishbowl format is that shy people are often not joining the discussion as much as people who feel like they have a lot to say. In a classroom setting
column2: this may be solved both by splitting the students into groups and thus limiting the size of the audience
column3: as well as through time limits for each discussant so that all students have to participate at some point.

column1: The flashlight method is used during sessions to get an immediate picture and evaluation of where the group members stand in relation to a specific question
column2: the general course of discussion
column3: or how they personally feel at that moment.

column1: Have a quick (and maybe fun) interlude to identify:
''Are there important issues that have been neglected so far?''
''Is there an elephant in the room?''
* Flashlight rounds can be initiated by the team leader or a team member.
* Everyone is asked to share their opinion in a short 2-3 sentence statement.
* During the flashlight round everyone is listening and only questions for clarification are allowed. Arising issues can be discussed after the flashlight round ended.
* The flashlight can be used as a starting round or energizer in between.
* The team leader should be aware of good timing
column2: usefulness at this point
column3: and the setting for the flashlight.

column1: * The method is quick and efficient
column2: and allows every participant to voice their own point without interruption. This especially benefits the usually quiet and shy voices to be heard. On the downside
column3: especially the quiet and shy participants can feel uncomfortable being forced to talk to the whole group. Knowing the group dynamics is key to having successful flashlight rounds in small and big groups.

column1: * The request to keep ones own statement short and concise may distract people from listening carefully
column2: because everyone is crafting their statements in their heads instead. To avoid that distraction
column3: start by giving the question and let everyone think for 1-2 minutes.

column1: * Flashlights in groups with 30+ participants can work well
column2: however
column3: the rounds get very long
column4: and depending on the flashed topic can also get inefficient. Breaking into smaller groups with a subsequent sysnthesis should be considered.

column1:
* To create a relaxed atmosphere try creative questions like:
''What song would you choose to characterize the current state of discussion
column2:
and why?''

column2: Why & When ==

column1: '''A Flipped Classroom is a teaching concept that flips the classical structure of in-class vs out-of-class.''' Teaching material is provided for the students (e.g. digitally) to engage with at home
column2: while the in-class sessions presuppose knowledge of the material and are then used for interactive discussions and exercises.

column1: * Change the structure of your class to support different learning types and schedules

column2: engaging and effective

column1: '''There is no unified conceptual approach to the *Flipped Classroom* as the concept is rather new.''' However
column2: there are general elements that all approaches share.
the flipped classroom elements can be categorized two-fold: structurally and didactically.
the flipped classroom can be split into in-class and out-of-class activities.''' The ''out-of-class'' activities provide the students with a range of learning material
column3: such as pre-recorded lectures
column4: online tests
column5: reading material
column6: homework exercises
column7: additional videos
column8: podcasts etc. The students receive this material
column9: preferably digitally via a learning platform
column10: and can generally engage with the material whenever they like. However
column11: the instructor may expect the students to know the content of the material when the in-class session starts
column12: and may check this knowledge at the beginning of the session. In presence (= ''in-class'')
column13: the students are not faced with more frontal learning
column14: but instead
column15: these sessions are structured around active learning exercises. These may include group discussions
column16: group exercises
column17: Q&A sessions or interactive tests (for example via Mentimeter)
column18: challenges
column19: panel discussions etc. The students should not receive (much) new content
column20: but rather consolidate their knowledge in these sessions and actively engage with the topics in their peer groups.

column1: [[File:Flipped Classroom.png|800px|thumb|center|'''A comparison between traditional and flipped classroom structures.''' Here
column2: out-of-class content is limited to videos and assessments
column3: but more formats are imaginable. Source: Velegol et al. 2015

column2: the teacher (professor) assumes a different role in Flipped Classrooms compared to traditional lectures''': (s)he is no longer only an information provider
column3: but rather becomes a learning guide to support active learning. To this end
column4: the Flipped Classroom intends to put an emphasis on student-centered learning theories such as active learning
column5: peer-assisted learning and collaborative learning (Akçayır & Akçayır
column7: p. 335). This changes the atmosphere of the sessions
column8: and allows for the students to engage with the content of the lecture from more diverse perspectives
column9: which may support different learning types.

column1: == Advantages and Challenges of Flipped Classroom approaches ==
Akçayır & Akçayır (2018) provide a range of hypothesized advantages and disadvantages which they base on a systematic literature review. These include improved learning outcomes
column2: higher student satisfaction
column3: enjoyment and engagement
column4: better student-student and student-instructor interaction and more efficient use of class time. On the other hand
column5: challenges include higher workloads for both students and instructors
column6: a subsequent lack of preparedness for the in-class sessions and technical issues. Since Flipped Classrooms are a rather young concept
column7: there is not much evidence on its effectiveness. Still
column8: the existing literature indicates positive outcomes compared to traditional lecturing styles. It may be noted that the benefits of the concept may vary depending on the topic of the class
column9: as well as other factors such as class size. Just as any other learning format are flipped classroom settings context dependent
column10: and need to be adapted to the respective settings.

'''In short:''' Focus Groups are a specific type of group discussion with which qualitative data on the participants’ viewpoints concerning a topic of focus is gathered by making use of the group interaction and dynamics. For more Interview forms
column2: and more on Interview methodology in general
column3: please refer to the [[Interviews||Interview overview page]].

column1: '''The first use of Focus Groups can be dated back to market research the 1920s''' and later to the 1950s when scientists of the Columbia University studied the effect that the governments’ war propaganda on the radio had on citizens (1
column2: 7). In the latter
column3: the scientists had initially started out with a quantified approach where the participants pressed red and green buttons depending on how they felt about the radio reports they heard
column4: until one researcher of the team
column5: Robert Merton
column6: proposed to instead follow a qualitative technique that he had developed for this project. More precisely
column7: the participants would be interviewed as a group to discover their “subjective reactions” (Bloor et al. 2001
column8: p. 2) to the radio clips. Together with a team of scientists
column9: Merton devised “a fairly standardized set of procedures for these interviews” (Bloor et al. 2001
column10: p. 2) and published them together with Patricia Kendall in the American Journal of Sociology under the title “The focused interview” in 1946 (1).

column1: While the Focus Group methodology as such did not find much further use in sociology at first
column2: its “commercial potential” for marketing and advertising continued to be apparent
column3: so that Focus Groups started to be used increasingly in commercial market research from the 1960s onwards (1).

column1: '''Seeing the successful application of Focus Groups by private marketing companies
column2: organizations of the public sector started to adopt the method''' to e.g. examine the impact of state-run campaigns. However
column3: the use of Focus Groups differs between the public and the private sector. This divergence is mostly a consequence of costs being kept low in the private sector and relates to a less rigorous analysis of the data then in the public sector as well as academia (1).

column2: Focus Groups were considered a “mainstream method” (Bloor et al. 2001
column3: p. 17) which enable access to norms and meanings of “increasingly privatised societies which are less open to observational methods” (Bloor et al. 2001
column4: p. 17). Even though Focus Groups can be used as a stand-alone method
column5: they are usually applied “to complement
column6: prepare for
column7: or extend” other methods (Bloor et al. 2001
column8: p. 18). Further
column9: Focus Groups can be used as a means to “democratize the research process by functioning as a forum for public participation” (Bloor et al. 2001

column1: '''Focus Groups are a specific type of group discussion held in a rather informal setting''' (3
column2: 5). The ''focus'' in Focus Groups refers to a specific topic or a set of topics being discussed
column3: or an activity being undertaken by the participants during the focus group session (3

column1: Focus Groups clearly differ from group interviews
column2: as the moderator does not just aim to gather answers from the participants but to achieve group interaction (5
column3: 7). It is not just of interest what participants say
column4: but also how they say it
column5: and how they react to what others say. The objective lies also in understanding “the meanings and norms which underlie those group answers” (Bloor et al.
column6: p. 43) and to “draw out the cognitive structures which previously have been unarticulated” (Kitzinger

column1: [[File:Focus Group example.png|500px|thumb|right|'''Exemplary Focusing Exercise in order to stimulate attention and discussion among the Focus Group participants on the topic of interest'''. Source: Bloor et al. 2001
The types of data gathered during a Focus Group concern individual
column2: group as well as group interaction data (5
column3: 4). More precisely
column4: the interest lays “not solely in what people thought but in ''how'' they thought and ''why'' they thought as they did” (Kitzinger

column1: Concerning the composition of Focus Groups
column2: one can choose to recruit either pre-existing groups “who already [know] each other through living
column3: working or socialising together“ (Kitzinger
column5: or to organize people into newly formed groups “that the researcher constructs by selecting members either randomly or
column6: much more commonly
column7: via [other] […] sampling techniques” (Onwuegbuzie
column8: p. 4). The benefits of choosing pre-existing groups are that one might “tap into fragments of interactions which approximated to 'naturally occurring' data” (Kitzinger
column9: p. 105) as people are used to converse with one another on a regular basis and that the participants can “relate each other's comments to actual incidents in their shared daily lives” (Kitzinger

column2: one distinguishes between complementary and argumentative interaction'''
column3: which refers to the similarities and differences between the Focus Group participants. A group composed of people with similar experiences might make participants feel comfortable voicing and explaining their viewpoints and perceptions
column4: which “may be particularly useful when one wishes to gain access to critical comments from groups” (Kitzinger
column5: p. 112). A diverse group composition on the other hand “ensures that people are forced to explain the reasoning behind their thinking” (Kitzinger
column6: p. 113) to the other participants and allows the facilitator to study the differences of opinion as well as their roots together with the group (3). However
column7: a group can never be fully homogeneous
column8: and both the complementary as well as the argumentative interaction are important for the data collection process (3).

column1: '''The data gathered during Focus Groups – i.e. audiotapes
column2: notes on non-verbal data
column3: and items recalled – can be analyzed with a [[Content Analysis]]''' (4
column4: 5). However
column5: several aspects unique to Focus Group data should be additionally considered
column6: e.g. regarding the relative contribution of single participants to the discussion
column7: social factors affecting the degree of [[Glossary|participation]]
column8: the group and temporal context of statements and opinions as well as their potential alteration throughout the discussion as well as measures of dominance (e.g. the number of interventions and words spoken by different participants and their impact on the course of the discussion) (5).

column2: i.e. the number of participants per Focus Group
column3: should allow for enough information and viewpoints on the given topic while at the same time ensuring a comfortable atmosphere and enough opportunities for everyone to express themselves (4
column4: 6). Around four to twelve participants can serve as a guide for the Focus Group size (4
column5: 6). Over-recruiting the Focus Groups to factor in participants who do not show up is recommended (4). As opposed to the Focus Group size
column6: the sample size is the number of Focus Groups conducted to answer the research question (2). The number of Focus Groups should ideally be based on the point of data or theoretical saturation (4
column7: 2). However
column8: financial and time constraints often become the cornerstone of decision-making in this regard (2).

column2: a short questionnaire may be handed out to the potential participants of the Focus Group. The filled-out questionnaires can help in composing the Focus Groups along criteria such as gender
column3: age
column4: and other factors important to the research (5).

column1: As group interaction in Focus Groups is crucial
column2: '''the role of the researcher is rather peripheral''' and consists of the moderation and [[Glossary|facilitation]] of the group discussion. '''What counts are the group dynamics and the interpersonal relationships between the participants''' (5). The facilitator should thus “encourage people to engage with one another” (Kitzinger
column3: p. 106) and to animate the discussion (5). This is usually achieved by asking open-ended questions (5). Further
column4: group exercises can be included into the Focus Group session. Besides encouraging interaction among the participants
column5: those exercises are meant to draw the participants' attention away from the facilitator and towards the other participants and topic of interest
column6: and to make them feel comfortable in the group. Further
column7: such exercises can evoke physical reactions (such as twitching when a card is put into the ‘wrong’ category) which may hint towards approval or disagreement within the group and can then be explored further (3). The figure above shows an exemplary focusing exercise (Bloor et al. 2001

column2: an assistant moderator is suggested who is responsible for “recording the session (i.e.
column3: whether by audio- or videotape)
column4: taking notes
column5: creating an environment that is conducive for group discussion (e.g.
column6: dealing with latecomers
column7: being sure everyone has a seat
column8: arranging for refreshments)
column9: providing verification of data
column10: and helping the researcher/moderator to analyze and/or interpret the focus group data” (Onwuegbuzie
column11: p. 4). The duration of Focus Groups commonly ranges between one to two hours (4). One and the same Focus Group can be invited a single or multiple times depending on the research objective (4).

column1: * Focus Groups allow to explore people’s views in a social context: “We learn about the 'meaning' of AIDS
column2: (or sex
column3: or health or food or cigarettes) through talking with and observing other people
column4: through conversations at home or at work; and we act (or fail to act) on that knowledge in a social context. When researchers want to explore people's understandings
column5: or to influence them
column6: it makes sense to employ methods which actively encourage the examination of these social processes in action.” (Kitzinger
column7: p. 117). As Säynäjoki et al. (2014
column8: p.6625) highlight: ""Focus groups are particularly useful in studies where the researcher seeks to uncover attitudes
column9: perceptions and beliefs.""

column2: the group atmosphere makes many participants feel more at ease and encourages them to share their thoughts and perceptions.
Focus Groups are a way to gather data from several people at a time and are thus considered to be cost-effective and timesaving (4).

column1: * A challenge one needs to be aware of when conducting and analyzing Focus Groups is the censorship of certain – e.g. minority or marginalized – viewpoints
column2: which can arise from the group composition (3). As Parker and Tritter (2006
column3: p. 31) note: “At the collective level
column4: what often emerges from a focus group discussion is a number of positions or views that capture the majority of the participants’ standpoints. Focus group discussions rarely generate consensus but they do tend to create a number of views which different proportions of the group support.""

column2: considering the effect group dynamics have on the viewpoints expressed by the participants is important
column3: as the same people might answer differently in an individual interview. Depending on the focus of the study
column4: either a Focus Group
column5: an individual interview or a combination of both might be appropriate (3).

column1: * Last but not least - and as with other qualitative research methods - Focus Groups do not necessarily aim for representativeness but for an in-depth understanding of the perspectives studied (3). However
column2: “as the number of focus groups in the overall sample increases and their composition broadens
column3: there is an extent to which the representativeness of their findings might be viewed as more acceptable and valid.” (Parker

column2: Bloor et al. (2001) see the necessity to employ more resources and effort regarding “group composition
column3: recruitment
column4: planning
column5: conduct
column6: transcription and analysis” (p. 89) for Focus Groups to fulfill the requirements on methods used in the field of academic social research (in comparison to pure market research for example).

column2: future publications of studies which applied Focus Groups should place more focus on the impact the recruitment and the sampling process had on the collection
column3: analysis
column4: and interpretation of the data. Thus
column5: more information on how Focus Group participants were sampled or on which basis a certain sample size (i.e. number of groups) was chosen should be provided
column6: and their implications on the interaction among the participants as well as the data analysis and interpretation should be discussed (5

column1: Given the complexity of Focus Group data
column2: also the development of further methodologies for data analysis should be continued (5

'''Säynäjoki et al (2014) used Focus Groups to investigate how Finnish urban planners perceive the potential positive impact of their field on environmental sustainability.''' Focus Groups were chosen since ""the focus of the study was not solely on what people think but on how they articulate
column2: rationalise
column3: challenge each other's views"" (p.6625). The researchers invited 32 urban planning specialists to a workshop
column4: including individuals ""from fourteen Finnish cities
column5: the Finnish environment ministry
column6: two architectural firms
column7: four consulting companies
column8: one of Finland’s largest energy companies
column9: a market leading construction company
column10: the Green Building Council Finland and the Finnish Association of Building Owners and Construction Clients (RAKLI)"" (p.6626).

column1: '''The researchers asked this group three questions as a prompt to the subsequent focus group sessions:'''
* ""Why is environmental sustainability assessed in urban planning?""
* ""How does environmental assessment steer decision-making in urban planning?""
* ""What is the role of urban planning in environmental sustainability?""

column2: the 32 participants were divided into three groups of 11
column3: 11 and 10 participants
column4: respectively
column5: with one moderating researcher each.''' All moderators were provided with the same guideline
column6: and their role was ""to enhance interaction and to ensure that all participants had an equal chance to contribute."" However
column7: ""[w]ithin these limits
column8: much of the discussion was left to the participants in order to learn what they found interesting and important. Nevertheless
column9: occasionally the moderators attempted to develop the discourses by encouraging the participants to explain their views
column10: or even through discreet provocation. The group discussions
column11: each approximately an hour in length
column12: were audio-recorded and manually transcribed and also video-recorded. In parallel with the recordings
column13: the moderators made notes concerning mainly the atmosphere
column14: the interaction and the participants’ reactions."" (p.6627). Importantly
column15: in addition to the three questions that were posed prior to the focus groups
column16: two further questions guided the moderators' actions:

column1: * ""How is the power of urban planners to promote environmental sustainability limited?""
* ""How is urban density considered in terms of environmentally sustainable land use?""

column2: i.e. the transcribed recordings and notes
column3: was done thematically in accordance with Guest et al. (2012).''' This means that not every statement was assessed
column4: but that the researchers focused on ""on identifying and describing themes"" in the data (p.6626). For this
column5: all parts of the transcripts were marked with codes representing the five guiding questions. All data for each code was grouped
column6: and each group of data was then categorized more specifically until ""conclusions could be drawn"" (p.6628). The researchers' notes as well as the recording were used to contextualize the data.

column2: all transcript data was separated into ''articulated'' data
column3: which is found in participants' direct responses to the moderator's questions
column4: and ''attributional'' data

Framing a research question;"'''In short:''' This entry provides an introduction on how to frame a research question.

Framing a research question is exactly how the wording already prescribes: You surround just as a you frame a painting with some parts of wood that allow you to basically differentiate a picture from its surrounding. You ask a question
column2: and this question is about research. These are the three parameters
column3: frame
column4: research
column5: question. Now let us break these three components down point by point and let us see how we can frame our research question best.

column1: We all stand on the shoulders of giants. Any given research question is based on previous research. No research is an island. Whatever we do as researchers
column2: we have to start with what was done before. Reading is the most essential skill of any person new to research. Balance is key to this end. If you read everything there is on a specific topic
column3: then you are in for a long ride. Otherwise
column4: if you miss something important that has been published before
column5: you basically reinvent the wheel
column6: which is a waste of your times and the time of your readers. Hence
column7: make sure that you get the main approaches that have been attempted before
column8: and the main knowledge that has been gained. You will eventually have to make a cut at some point
column9: otherwise you would basically read everything there is
column10: since almost everything is connected. Hence try to focus on what is specific for your topic and for the area you focus on
column11: thereby gaining some insights about the respective context. Context knowledge matters to this end
column12: because only if you know the context of the specific topic
column13: it allows you to aim with the right ratio of focus and distance. Why both? If you look too close
column14: your knowledge is too singular
column15: too specific
column16: or just beyond the point
column17: or any point at all. If it is too broad
column18: it may be generic
column19: trivial
column20: and thus again beyond any point whatsoever once more. Ideally
column21: you work in a specific system. This may be a group of people
column22: and institution
column23: or any other constructed entity. This allows you to add specificity to your research topic. You aim at creating knowledge about this system
column24: people or entity. Hence your framing can be about a specific topic
column25: an entity or institution
column26: but also about a theory. What matters to this end is to have the right angle. Did you ever try to look at a painting from the side? Basically
column27: this does not work
column28: because the framing will block the view
column29: and you do not see the picture. In framing your research
column30: this is basically the same. You need to have the same angle
column33: we often look at a topic or problem through a certain theory. While testing a theory is restricted to deductive research
column34: regarding a research question our framing and viewpoint is more open minded. It is thus not restricted to the yes/no categories of a hypothesis
column35: but instead allows us to ask a broader question that allows us to create contextual and novel knowledge.

column1: Our research question may start with a ""How""
column2: thereby examining explanations of dynamics or patterns. ""Where"" questions will typically try to spatially locate phenomena
column3: while ""when"" questions examine dimensions of temporality. ""Why"" questions try often to go deeper into reasonings and examine patterns that may in one extreme be pretty foundational
column4: yet can in other extreme cases be borderline trivial. ""What"" question are one last example of research question that can either be rather procedural or again end up being vague. Some research question may avoid such question formats altogether
column5: which is for instance true for much of the realms of descriptive research. Yet another example is critical research
column6: which may not be occupied with questions at all
column7: but instead offer a critical reflection or specific viewpoint.

column1: What should however be clear is that research questions can be at least partly answered
column2: or we may conclude that based on the current design and data the research question cannot be answered. This is perfectly ok
column3: and a part of scientific research. However
column4: research is often biased towards positive or even potentially exciting research
column5: while research rarely report that they could not find anything out at all
column6: and the their initial research question remains unanswered.

column1: Testability and rejection is actually a key criteria that should differentiate knowledge gained through science from mere opinions
column2: because we can have all sorts of opinions
column3: but scientific empirical knowledge can be tested and can also be falsified
column4: refined or changed if it turns out to be wrong. Hence wrong facts can be debunked
column5: while it is really hard to debunk a conspiracy theory that is based on mere opinions. In addition to the process of testing or examining within the framework of research it is possible and indeed perfectly normal that our knowledge evolves; this is actually what science is all about. Consequently
column6: the question we try to examine should represent a scientific process that can be handled by us. We cannot come up with a research question that is perfect in terms of everything but the fact that it is impossible to conduct it.

column1: Our research question does not need to be  a breakthrough that changes the whole world
column2: but more often than not it is a stepping stone in the bigger picture that is our united research working to unravel. Our framing is a piece of what we call reality
column3: and building on a respective theory or theoretical foundation may help us to focus our research and create knowledge that is specific and not generic. Equally can a contextual focus or specification help within a research question to understand what we work about
column4: or where our sample entity is located or rooted in. All this is part of our framing. Naturally
column5: the framing also needs to be clear. If your wording or different parts of the frame are too many
column6: then other researchers will not be able to follow. Hence we need to make sure to use fewer words instead of too many
column7: and each word should be chosen carefully.

column2: we may indeed ask questions in our research questions
column3: but these should be specifically frames
column4: state the respective context
column5: root deeply in previous research and knowledge
column6: be neither generic nor hyper-specific
column7: need to be feasible
column8: and allow for a scientific conduct that can be documented
column9: reproduced
column10: or both. Specific theories allow for refined viewpoints
column11: and empirical research may benefit from stating where it is conducted. The most difficult challenge in framing a research question is then to decide what to include and what to exclude. Researchers make choices
column12: and need to focus. Creating a research question demands to keep the most important information
column13: and omit all that is not central to the initial question. It takes practice to get good at framing research questions. Be patient
column14: and keep going.

This Wiki article aims at giving a first and basic introduction to the topic of gender. Our intention is to offer some helpful tools and advice on how gender is important to consider in everyday life at university. We hope that students and teachers find helpful information and suggestions of how to act more aware regarding gender.

As this is meant to be a gender first aid kit we start this article by offering some practical advice on how to use gender neutral language and different pronouns as well as reflect on one’s own talking behaviour. After that we will describe the history of the concept of gender and thereby highlighting to you the most important information on the topic from our point of view. In the end
column2: we will point out the relation of institutions such as universities with gender and explain why it is one important factor to consider while studying or working in an institution.

During this article we will refer to and write about BIPoC (Black
column2: Indigenous and People of Colour). We decided to rather use the term non-white people as this is more descriptive
column3: and BIPoC is often used as empowering self-designation
column4: which is why we as only white authors do not want to claim that. Furthermore
column5: we are aware of our own privileged position regarding gender identity
column6: social and academic background.

column1: This section will provide a brief historical outline of how the concept of '''sex'''
column2: and later '''gender'''
column3: came into being from the 18th century onward until today. This is by no means a complete historical account but rather tries to give an introduction to the topic. The further links we provide might be a good starting point to deepen your knowledge if interested.  We will mainly focus on the Enlightenment period in which natural sciences such as anthropology and biology emerged to explain the development of the sex binary and the differentiation of humans in races. After that
column4: there will be a short summary of the four waves of feminism focusing on each’s main claims and developments regarding sex and gender. Furthermore
column5: this historical section refers to the German/European/Western history of sex and gender and cannot be generalized to other societies
column6: cultures and regions of the world.

column1: Society in the 18th century was widely built upon a hierarchical system rooted in gender and race
column2: which constructed social positions based on gender and racial differences. This separation of society into women and men and white and non-white people emerged during the Enlightenment which was an intellectual movement in the 18th century that strived for objective answers based on reason.
the previous focus of society on religion and culture was tried to be replaced by reason. Based on the idea that all people are equal by nature
column3: social
column4: civil and universal human rights slowly evolved. An early example of these developments were the demands of European women for more rights
column5: thereby questioning long-established social arrangements with respect to women’s rights and duties. This is now considered the first wave of feminism. The demands of women at the time raised the question of whether and how such changes in rights would be justified. In addition
column6: it was unclear whether males of different skin colour had equal property rights and
column7: in the course of this

column13: biological sexism and racism emerged
column14: paving the way to biological determinism.

column1: ===The gender binary as a colonial object===
Since Colonisation was a multi-faceted process
column2: main actors were not just statesmen who executed their orders from their European home countries. It was also missionaries who enforced a process of Christianisation in the colonies. Christian missionaries fulfilled the task of education on colonised land. The school often functioned as the church also was a place where the culture should be transformed to align with European values. Especially the family system was targeted with a focus on polygamy. “For the missionaries
column3: having multiple wives was not only primitive but against God's law: polygamy was adultery
column4: pure and simple” (Oyewumi 1997: 137). So the Christian education focused on conveying Western gender roles that were in their eyes more ‘civilised’. Besides learning to read the Bible children were taught skills and behaviour that suited their respective gender roles and expectations.

column2: it must also be pointed out that Christianity was and is not the only religion that transported and exported certain ideas of gender
column3: gender roles and sexuality with its spread. For example during the expansion of Islam starting around 800 throughout the Middle East and North Africa

column5: India
column6: sub-Saharan Africa

''“Gender-neutral language is a generic term covering the use of '''non-sexist''' language
column2: '''inclusive''' language or '''gender-fair''' language. The purpose of gender-neutral language is to avoid word choices which may be interpreted as biased
column3: discriminatory or demeaning by implying that one sex or social gender is the norm.“'' (European Parliament 2018)

column1: ===How is it used in different languages?===
There are different strategies for using gender neutral language
column2: depending on which language is spoken. In English
column3: but also in some Scandinavian languages
column4: many nouns are already '''gender neutral'''. The easiest strategy would be to reduce gender-specific terms as much as possible and thus to neutralise them. The European Parliament provides some examples of this: words that are not gender-specific and refer to people in general
column5: with no reference to the person's gender (‘chairwoman’ or “chairman” is replaced by ‘Chair’ or ‘chairperson’
column6: ‘policeman’ or ‘policewoman’ by ‘police officer’
column7: ‘spokesman’ or “spokeswoman” by ‘spokesperson’
column8: ‘stewardess’ or “steward” by ‘flight attendant’
column9: ‘headmaster’ or ‘headmistress’ by ‘director’ or ‘principal’
column10: etc.)” (European Parliament

column2: in German
column3: but also in other Romance languages
column4: it is not quite so simple as every noun has a grammatical gender and therefore gender-specific article. This in itself is random and not necessarily problematic. However
column5: regarding nouns referring to people or job descriptions
column6: the '''generic masculine''' has established itself as the norm since money-earning jobs were historically performed by men and job descriptions stem from that time. This means that the masculine version of job or person related titles are used to describe people of all genders
column7: for example Schüler
column8: Bürger and Maler. Many people do not question the generic masculine and accept it as 'normal' and 'correct'. However
column9: it can be perceived as discriminatory by people who do not feel addressed and included by this generic.

column2: psycho-lingual studies have shown that the way we phrase our sentences and what words we use shape our reality. For example
column3: when using only the generic masculine form to describe occupational titles
column4: people imagine a male worker. This effect is especially crucial for children and their own perception of job status and self-efficacy (Vervecken & Hannover 2015). Thus
column5: language is a tool to reinforce or counteract sexist
column6: binary
column7: and discriminatory structures and hence crucial to use carefully and with intent.

column1: A variant of gender-neutral language or gender-sensitive language would be
column2: on the one hand
column3: to find a gender-neutral word for that noun
column4: such as Studierende
column5: Lehrpersonen
column6: etc.
column7: or to gender it. There are now some well-known variants and various institutions already use them. For example
column8: the generic masculine is no longer used
column9: and there is no longer talk of Schüler and Studenten
column10: but of Schüler*innen and Student*innen (other variants are
column11: for example
column12: with a ‘:’ or ‘_’ i.e.
column13: Schüler:innen or Student_innen). The advantage '''“des Gendern”''' and the use of gender-neutral terms over another strategy
column14: namely the use of the feminine and masculine form such as Schüler and Schülerinnen or Studentinnen und Studenten
column15: is that not only persons of the feminine and masculine gender are addressed
column16: but also people that do not identify with one of the two binary genders.

column1: ===What are pronouns? Why do they matter?===
Pronouns are a way to refer to a person in a conversation besides using their name. Therefore
column2: they are often intertwined with '''gender identity'''. Using the right pronouns when talking about another person acknowledges and validates their identity and shows acceptance and respect for the other person.

column1: There are different pronouns commonly used
column2: for example she/her
column3: he/him or they/them. However
column4: pronouns are not limited to just these terms. People can use multiple sets of pronouns (e.g.
column5: she/they)
column6: which shall be used interchangeably when referring to this person. Additionally
column7: '''neopronouns''' e.g. xe
column8: thon
column9: ens or dey (in German) have been on the rise especially for '''non-binary''' and '''genderqueer''' people. Learning how to use and conjugate them is a way of showing that you care. In the German language
column10: there is no established gender neutral pronoun yet. Thus
column11: using no pronouns and simply being addressed by one’s name is common.

column1: It is important to remember that '''gender expression''' is not the same as gender identity. The way a person presents (for example by wearing certain clothes or make-up) does not say anything about what pronouns they use and what their gender identity is
column2: meaning you cannot visually tell what a person's gender is. Hence
column3: a person can present in a traditionally feminine way and identify as non-binary and use they/them pronouns.

column2: an easy way to let people know your pronouns is by introducing yourself with your name and your pronouns (e.g. Hello! My name is ... and I use .../... pronouns. Nice to meet you.). It may feel a little weird and unfamiliar at first
column3: but the more you do it the more it will become normal and natural. Furthermore
column4: it often leads to the other person introducing them with their pronouns as well. If not
column5: you can kindly ask for it (""What pronouns do you use?"").

column2: introducing oneself with pronouns is a good sign of showing awareness and being an '''ally''' to '''transgender'''/genderqueer/non-binary people since it contributes to normalising this process and helps to reduce assuming pronouns based on appearance.

column1: If you have already met a person but are unsure of their pronouns it is okay to ask for them again or at a later point. It might be convenient to do so in a more private setting and not in front of a group to take away pressure. This applies to the usage of pronouns you don't know as well. It is always better to ask for clarification respectfully than to assume and/or use wrong pronouns.

column2: what pronouns or names people want to be addressed with may vary due to contexts and feelings of safety. If possible
column3: ask people beforehand.

column1: If you accidentally use the wrong pronoun for a person
column2: it is important to '''correct yourself'''. This shows your respect for the other person and their identity. A correction and a short apology may look like this: ""“He likes – I’m sorry
column3: they like noodles more than rice."" Making excuses however can be frustrating - therefore avoid doing so. We propose a similar approach when someone else corrects you: thank them for doing so and move on with your sentence using the correct pronoun - don’t react offended if someone informs you that you have used the wrong pronouns.

column1: If you notice another person using wrong pronouns
column2: speaking up is a good way to show '''solidarity''' and awareness. However
column3: it is important to keep in mind that this should be at the comfort of the affected person.

column1: If you know a name or pronoun a person has previously used
column2: keep it to yourself. Try to avoid situations
column3: especially in public
column4: where a person is pressured to reveal their '''“dead name”''' (=old name)

column7: IDs ...
