the legal status concerning gender is focusing on inequalities related to the differences between women and men. These societal constructed categories are for sure not the only categories that create inequalities and injustices (see '''Intersectionality''')
column3: but most constructed institutions to this day unfortunately focus on these specific inequalities and injustices. There are other legal changes currently happening in some countries that take other viewpoints and a more diverse understanding into account
column4: yet these changes are slow
column5: often singular
column6: and by a lack of implementation even a backlash. Since 1st January 2019
column7: ‘divers’ has been a third positive gender entry in German civil status law alongside ‘female’ and ‘male’. In addition
column8: it is also possible to have ‘no gender’ registered. However
column9: this change of gender entry is currently only available to intersex persons. This also expands the understanding of gender that institutions base their gender equality work on. But there are also other developments happening creating a backlash in LGBTQ+ rights. A couple of weeks ago the state of Florida in the US passed a law titled ‘Parental laws in Education’. In the media it got popular with the name ‘Don’t say gay bill’. The new law seeks to ban discussion of gender and sexuality issues from schools. A separate analysis by the CNN journalist Giselle Rhoden found that in the current legislative session around 150 anti-LGBT bills have been introduced at the state level. They range from restricting access to gender-affirming health care for minors to excluding transgender children from athletics.

column1: The structures and mechanisms in constructed institutions -such as universities- are often slow to adapt to societal changes. And yet
column2: universities as center for innovation
column3: should lead the way also to this end. What is however often happening is that the legal situation became more and more complex over time
column4: and the adaptability decreased. This should not be the case
column5: and it is clear to recognize that we are part of a continuous change where we have already come a long way. However
column6: even within diverse institutions the legal ramifications are lacking behind what we perceive to be the baseline of societal change. An example of this is the dgti supplementary ID. The dgti supplementary ID is a standardised identity document that documents all self-selected personal data and shows a current passport photo. This is helpful because for trans* people the official identity documents do not match their own gender identity before the official change of name and/or civil status. Similarly
column7: this can also be the case with external appearance. This often leads to unpleasant
column8: stressful and humiliating questions or even dangerous situations during a personal check. The dgti ID card is already known and accepted by some banks
column9: universities
column10: insurance companies and others but not everywhere since it is voluntary and not obligatory to accept it.

column1: It is not ok that the people who live this change are reduced to their specific identity

column1: Being baffled by the restrictions of regressions that rely on the normal distribution
column2: John Nelder and Robert Wedderburn developed Generalized Linear Models (GLMs) in the 1960s to encompass different statistical distributions. Just as Ronald Fisher
column3: both worked at the Rothamsted Experimental Station
column4: seemingly a breeding ground not only in agriculture
column5: but also for statisticians willing to push the envelope of statistics. Nelder and Wadderburn extended [https://www.probabilisticworld.com/frequentist-bayesian-approaches-inferential-statistics/ Frequentist] statistics beyond the normal distribution
column6: thereby unlocking new spheres of knowledge that rely on distributions such as Poisson and Binomial. '''Nelder's and Wedderburn's work allowed for statistical analyses that were often much closer to real world datasets
column7: and the array of distributions and the robustness and diversity of the approaches unlocked new worlds of data for statisticians.''' The insurance business
column8: econometrics and ecology are only a few examples of disciplines that heavily rely on Generalized Linear Models. GLMs paved the road for even more complex models such as additive models and generalised [[Mixed Effect Models|mixed effect models]]. Today
column9: Generalized Linear Models can be considered to be part of the standard repertoire of researchers with advanced knowledge in statistics.

column1: Generalized Linear Models are statistical analyses
column2: yet the dependencies of these models often translate into specific sampling designs that make these statistical approaches already a part of an inherent and often [[Glossary|deductive]] methodological approach. Such advanced designs are among the highest art of quantitative deductive research designs
column3: yet Generalized Linear Models are used to initially check/inspect data within inductive analysis as well. Generalized Linear Models calculate dependent variables that can consist of count data
column4: binary data
column5: and are also able to calculate data that represents proportions. '''Mechanically speaking
column6: Generalized Linear Models are able to calculate relations between continuous variables where the dependent variable deviates from the normal distribution'''. The calculation of GLMs is possible with many common statistical software solutions such as R and SPSS. Generalized Linear Models thus represent a powerful means of calculation that can be seen as a necessary part of the toolbox of an advanced statistician.

column1: '''Generalized Linear Models allow powerful calculations in a messy and thus often not normally distributed world.''' Many datasets violate the assumption of the normal distribution
column2: and this is where GLMs take over and clearly allow for an analysis of datasets that are often closer to dynamics found in the real world
column3: particularly [[Experiments_and_Hypothesis_Testing#The_history_of_the_field_experiment | outside of designed studies]]. GLMs thus represented a breakthrough in the analysis of datasets that are skewed or imperfect
column4: may it be because of the nature of the data itself
column5: or because of imperfections and flaws in data sampling.

column2: GLMs allow to investigate different and more precise questions compared to analyses built on the normal distribution. For instance
column3: methodological designs that investigate the survival in the insurance business
column4: or the diversity of plant or animal species
column5: are often building on GLMs. In comparison
column6: simple regression approaches are often not only flawed within regression schemes
column7: but outright wrong.

column1: Since not all researchers build their analysis on a deep understanding of diverse statistical distributions
column2: GLMs can also be seen as an educational means that enable a deeper understanding of the diversity of approaches

Preprocessing: It entails changing the data in a variety of ways before entering it into the GIS. Data format conversion and methodically locating objects in the source data are two of the main responsibilities of preprocessing. Extracting data from maps

column3: and printed records (such demographic reports) and then entering it in a computer database are common methods for changing the format of the original data. Data manipulation consists of working with the database contents to derive new information.

column2: Why & When ==

column1: Have you ever accidentally overwritten or deleted your teammates’ code in a Google Drive? Ever wanted to go back to a previous version of your script because your bug fixing just created more problems? Ever struggled to combine different snippets of code that were collected through email or even WhatsApp hours before the deadline?

column2: because this article will introduce you to GitHub and help manage the above issues with ease.

column1: Git is an open-source distributed version control (DVCS) and source code management (SCM) system that was initiated by Linus Torvalds – the same guy who played a major role in the creation of the Linux operation system. Git manages changes made to a code repository
column2: allowing developers to go back to previous versions
column3: duplicate the code to other environments and merge the work of different developers.

column1: GitHub is a web-based hosting service that gives a graphical user interface to the underlying functionality of git and extends it by many more features that '''facilitate collaboration between developers'''. These functionalities include user and access management
column2: bug tracking
column3: continuous integration and many more.

column1: Almost every company that is involved with software development uses GitHub
column2: making GitHub not only the largest host of source code in the world but also a basic skill for every developer
column3: engineer or data scientist.

column2: the basic functionalities of git and GitHub will be described. Hopefully
column3: this helps to streamline your efforts to deliver the best team reports every submitted in Software for Analyzing Data.

column1: Repositories (‘repos’) are the central object of git that contains the actual code files of a project together with each file’s revision history.

column2: Teams & People====

column1: The Users of GitHub are called people on the site. They can be members of a team
column2: which then can be part of a larger organization. Teams can also be nested inside each other
column3: depicting the organizational structure of your company. Your belonging to a team or organization is relevant for your access to their repositories.

column1: Issues is the build in bug tracking function on GitHub. You can directly mark
column2: discuss and assign bugs and other problems with the code on the platform.

column1: Projects is the build in project management solution of GitHub. You can use Management frameworks like Kanban to assign tasks to team members and review their completion.
Since working with GitHub usually is a team effort
column2: everybody develops their own style or model to using it over time. Different teams will make different agreements on how to use the functionalities of git in order to best meet their needs. Some might use a shared repository model where you branch & merge your development efforts while others might prefer a Fork & Pull model.
the different functions of git will be described along a generic workflow that could serve as a starting point to develop a more refined process.

column1: When you are working on a project and want to implement new ideas
column2: a branch should be created. The branch will be a duplicate of the main project at the time of its inception and enable you to work on your ideas without affecting the main branch inside a safe “sandbox” environment. Using separate branches enables a team to work simultaneously on the same project. You could then clone the branch to your local system to make changes to its files.

column1: An alternative to branching could be forking the repository. A branch stays within the same repository and only saves the changed files that can later be merged into the main branch
column2: whereas a fork is an independent hard copy of the entire repository that can be united by way of a pull request. It depends on your style and the organization’s agreement
column3: which model is applied. In this case
column4: we are assuming shared repository model with branching as the main method.

column1: After completing a small increment or milestone in your development
column2: a commit saves this state as a revertible snapshot in the project’s history. Every feature or change should be committed individually in order to be able to retrace the development process and revert if necessary. The changes made should be described in the commit message to make it easier to follow along.

column1: Pull Requests are designed to start a discussion and encourage feedback of your code. A pull request lets you compare two branches of a repository and initiates a discussion about the changed features. If you were developing on a forked project
column2: the pull request will notify the original maintainers of the project repository to review and consider your changes.
issues and review====
other collaborators can discuss and review the changes with you or even add follow-up commits before you merge your changes into the main branch.

column1: To test your changes in the production system
column2: it is usually deployed to a test environment before merging into the main branch. This is not always the case and depends on the specific usage of your team.
you can publish your branch by pushing it to the server. Only then
column3: the committed changes are made publicly available. The changes can then be merged into the main branch
column4: bringing together your work with potential other adaptations made through different branches at the same time.

'''In short:''' Grounded Theory is the inductive approach of developing concepts or theories from observed data without pre-determined assumptions

empirical social science was stuck between a rock and a hard place. The critique of positivism was at its peak
column3: all the while the recognition of social science as an empirical science was dominated by a lack of suitable methodological approaches. Classical surveys and other methodological approaches were criticised by the anti-positivists
column4: and the lack of methods led to a problematic view of on social science form other disciplines. This problem can be strongly associated to the dominating reign of [[Glossary|deductive]] approaches during this time
column5: which was a suitable line of thinking in psychology
column6: physics
column7: agricultural research
column8: biology or other fields
column9: yet did not only pose an epistemological shortcoming
column10: but was in addition not suitable for parts of science and knowledge production that built on inductive reasoning. '''In this context of the history and theory of science
column11: the proposal of Grounded Theory can be seen as nothing short of a revolution.'''

column1: Following the increasing focus on the individual
column2: Grounded Theory can be seen as a main stepping stone for a science that is interactive with non-scientists
column3: and even can be interactive even within itself. From the perspective of philosophy of science
column4: this is a clear commitment to the fact that there are branches of knowledge that do not build on theories
column5: but instead derive theories from observation. This concluded a pendulum swing from Bacon and the inductive approach to the positivists and back
column6: enabling a more pluralistic and diverse science that could approach new frontiers. What is more important
column7: this approach paved the road for a thinking in science that was less absolute and pretending to be objective
column8: but instead acknowledged that scientists look at parts of the picture
column9: which are highly important
column10: but should not be seen as objective facts.

column1: Grounded Theory is a systematic approach to derive hypotheses and theories that are open and more general
column2: starting with research questions that may lead to the development of theories
column3: often through qualitative analysis and coding. '''Researchers utilising the Grounded Theory approach thus typically formulate broad research questions that are widely unaimed at specifics
column4: but instead try to observe and generate new insights.''' This is often done in a systematic sense through coding of information
column5: thereby allowing for code items that are similar or at least allow for certain similarities to be identified and to be grouped in clusters. In the next step
column6: such clusters of code items allow for the conceptualisation or formulation of a theory. More specifically
column7: the Grounded Theory approach involves three main steps of coding: open coding
column8: axial coding
column9: and selective coding (Images from [https://delvetool.com/blog/openaxialselective DELVE]).

column2: all the available data - e.g. interview transcripts - is broken down into smaller units such as sentences. All of these data units are then labelled as individual ""codes"" that summarize the data in a more abstract way. Two data units that belong to the same topic
column3: idea
column4: person or place receive the same code. This coding step may be influenced by what the researcher assumes might be relevant for the data
column5: for example based on previous knowledge or available literature
column6: but generally
column7: this step should be done as openly as possible so that no bias is imposed by the researcher's assumptions.

column2: all codes that have been created in the first step are now aggregated into overarching categories. This is done by reading the data and the codes again and again
column3: and searching for connections between the codes
column4: based on which they are organized by the researcher. These connections may be causal relations between codes
column5: or additional context that one code provides for another code
column6: and all codes are categorized accordingly. The researcher verifies the emerging categories by checking them against the data repeatedly to make sure that the categorization is true to the data. In the end
column7: the original data has been reduced to overarching
column8: interrelated categories
column9: to which the original codes are now sub-categories.

column2: in '''Selective Coding'''
column3: all categories are again abstracted so that one encompassing result emerges. This result can be a new theory
column4: or an alteration of an existing theory. In any case
column5: all categories and codes should be combined to one final narrative that explains all data. To do so
column6: the researcher repeatedly considers all the connections between all the categories and codes
column7: inductively develops new conceptualizations
column8: and deductively verifies these in view of the original data.

column1: An important tool in these three steps are '''memos'''. Memos are small notes that the researcher writes during the coding process. They can contain information about any kinds of issues the researcher encountered with the data
column2: or their thoughts on the coding process
column3: and notes for results of this process. The memos are an essential source of knowledge in the iterative and abductive process of Grounded Theory
column4: where conceptual ideas are developed and neglected again and again. By checking previously written memos during later stages of the process
column5: the researcher makes sure not to forget thoughts that they had initially. To this end
column6: memos can be extended through diagrams that visually help make sense of and organize the codes and categories during the coding procedure.

column1: This inductive coding approach can be seen as methodologically diverse
column2: as it can build and integrate both quantitative and qualitative information. '''To this end
column3: Grounded Theory is not really a clear and rigid regime on how to approach data gathering and analysis
column4: but closer to a mode of research.''' Grounded Theory demands openness and being undetermined from previous assumptions. Instead it puts the test subjects into the center of the initial research question
column5: and allows for an open minded conceptualisation of the data itself. While this takes experience
column6: as it is widely building on the coding skills and generalisation choices of the [[Glossary|researcher]]
column7: it surely proves a counterpoint to the rigid [[Glossary|hypothesis]]-driven deductive research approaches. A strong emphasis in Grounded Theory is on the documentation of the research process itself
column8: as it is clear that the coding process is potentially rooted in preconcious recognition of the researcher.

column1: The coding process in Grounded Theory-driven research strongly builds on the experience of the researcher
column2: for better or worse. Very experienced researchers may look for mere confirmations of preconscious ideas and concepts
column3: and may even [[Bias and Critical Thinking|flaw]] the coding process altogether. This criticism is also deeply rooted in the minds of many positivists

column1: Another source of criticism on Grounded Theory is that it is not a rigid and transparent method

column4: who proclaim they know the best approach.

column1: Yet another criticism could already be anticipated: We are not independent of pre-existing theories. The original postulation of Grounded Theory was well aware of that

column3: in turn
column4: is of course hard to do if we are not aware of our own shortcomings. The positivist deducers consider this to be a severe flaw

column1: The greatest achievement of Grounded Theory is the opening up of the rigid tracks of positivism to a more inductive line of thinking. Grounded Theory is surely one step towards a more open scientific world beyond the often arrogant and expectation-driven deductive approaches that are laced with theories. In terms of history of science

column1: [[File:Grounded Theory - exemplary study Kornilaki & Font (2019) - Title.png|600px|frameless|center|The exemplary study on Grounded Theory by Kornilaki & Font (2019)]]

Kornilaki & Font (2019) used (Straussian) Grounded Theory to identify and explain ""how socio-cultural and industrial norms influence the intentions and behavious towards sustainability of owner-managers of small tourism firms"" in Crete
column2: Greece (p.2). Grounded Theory was chosen since the inductive approach promised novelty in the theoretical perspectives on the topic
column3: and in order to be more flexible to adapt to the responses by the participants in the study.

column1: '''In a first step - and ongoing throughout the process -
column2: the researchers consulted literature''' on the topic to ""enhance their theoretical sensitivity and to compare the emerging theory with other work in the field"" (p.184). '''Then
column3: they selected 23 owner-managers from small tourism companies to engage with in an [[Open Interview]]'''. After a first broad analysis of the gathered data
column4: key issues were identified
column5: upon which another 16 partipants
column6: including 14 of the first selection
column7: were chosen for a '''second round of open interviews'''.

column1: The interviews were recorded and transcribed
column2: and key words or sentences were highlighted in the transcripts. Based on these key items
column3: codes were developed openly and iteratively (open coding). The codes were then abstracted by grouping them into categories
column4: with relationships emerging between the categories and codes (axial coding)
column5: which led to the development of hypotheses (selective coding).

column2: the researchers claim that ""[t]hrough constant comparisons of the data and of incidents
column3: the researchers were able to see variations in the owner-managers’ behaviour depending on their circumstances
column4: the environment
column5: their different prioritisation of actions and strategic responses to events and problems
column6: and the different consequences of those actions."" (p.6). Participants were categorised based on their behavioral profiles
column7: and the researchers were able to infer ""a nuanced account of how social influence and social norms affect human behavior in relation to sustainability actions"" (p.9).

column2: the Grounded Theory approach provided in-depth insights into the owner-managers' perceptions of their own and others' behavior
column3: and helped the researchers identify which influences determine this behavior.

column1: The general idea of Concept Mapping was developed by Joseph Novak and colleagues at Cornell University in the 1970s (Brown). The idea was to structure and visualize knowledge about a topic in an educational context. Concept Mapping is typically still used in education until today. '''In 1989
column2: William M.K. Trochim
column3: also from Cornell University
column4: expanded on this idea and introduced Group Concept Mapping''' as a structured methodological approach (Trochim 1989). He originally presented it as a way to create conceptual frameworks for planning and evaluation purposes. At the same time
column5: the results of a Group Concept Mapping process provide insights into specific topics that are of strong interest to scientific research
column6: which is why the method may be seen by some researchers as both a research method and a planning and evaluation tool (cf. Dare & Nowicki 2019
column7: p.3). Thematically
column8: the method can find application in any field and is '''often used in health and social work''' (see for example McCaffrey et al. 2019
column9: Trochim et al. 1994
column10: Trochim et al. 2003)

column2: linear group-based approach of gathering conceptual elements
column3: arranging and rating them
column4: and creating visual representations'''. The end result is typically a map or similar form of visual representation
column5: which displays the ideas and how they relate to each other. This visualisation
column6: as suggested by Trochim 1989
column7: can serve as a baseline for a subsequent planning or evaluation process. An important feature is the focus on the group of actors who create the concept map on their own
column8: supported by the methodological process and a facilitator. The end result is based on their own contributions
column9: represents their own understanding of the issue at hand
column10: and can thus more easily be used by them for the following processes.

column1: === Differences to Concept Mapping and Mindmaps ===
[[Concept Maps]] refer to visual representations of conceptual ideas
column2: as introduced by Novak and colleagues in the 1970s (Trochim 1989). Information (words or short sentences) is put into boxes or circles
column3: which are connected in a network-like structure through arrows. This is in a way comparable to a mindmap. However
column4: [[Mindmap|Mindmaps]] do not serve the purpose of presenting a final
column5: comprehensive overview over a specific focus on a topic
column6: but rather an unstructured
column7: spontaneous collection of general related ideas around one key term. Both processes - Concept Maps and Mindmaps - can be done by a single person or in a group. For example
column8: Brown (2003) shows how group-based creation of a concept map can enhance biology teaching.

column2: '''Group Concept Mapping is not a mere group-based creation of a Concept Map'''
column3: but an established methodological approach which includes qualitative and quantitative elements
column4: and can be seen as a mixed methods approach in itself
column5: with both elements of data gathering and analysis. It is a structured form of framework development
column6: in which ideas
column7: thoughts
column8: goals
column9: needs and resources relevant to a specific topic are collected
column10: conceptually linked
column11: quantitatively evaluated and presented in a map-like visualisation.

column1: === The process of Group Concept Mapping ===
Group Concept Mapping typically consists of six linear steps (see figure): Preparation
column2: Statement Generation
column3: Structuring
column4: Representation
column5: Interpretation
column6: Utilization. Below
column7: we will elaborate on each step based on the original methodological design by Trochim (1989)
column8: and present the process as done in the exemplary study by McCaffrey et al. (2019)
column9: who attempted to generate a conceptual model of good health care from the perspective of patients.

column1: [[File:Group Concept Mapping - Visualisation-2.png|600px|thumb|center|'''The process of Group Concept Mapping'''. Source: adapted from Trochim 1989

column2: first
column3: '''the group of actors is gathered''' that will contribute to the process. The individuals are selected by the facilitator
column4: who can be a member of the relevant group itself
column5: or an outsider. The selected group
column6: ""[d]epending on the situation
column7: (...) might consist of the administrators
column8: staff or members of the board of an organization; community leaders (...); academicians or members of the policy making community; (...) representatives of relevant client populations"" or other individuals that are relevant to the topic at hand
column9: and whose perspectives should be included in the resulting framework visualisation (Trochim 1989
column10: 2). When selecting the participants
column11: ""[b]road heterogeneous participation helps to insure that a wide variety of viewpoints will be considered and encourages a broader range of people to ""buy into"" the conceptual framework which results"". (Trochim 1989
column12: 3). Individuals may be selected by hand
column13: or by the use of stratified or purposive sampling. Trochim (1989) recommends a group to include 10-20 individuals
column14: but larger or smaller groups are still imaginable. Further
column15: it is possible for the group size to vary in the different steps of the process
column16: whereas continuity along all steps of the process might support a better understanding of the result for all participants (Trochim 1989).

column1: In the second part of the preparation
column2: the underlying ""rules"" of the process are constituted. This involves
column3: first
column4: the creation of clearly defined
column5: mutually agreed-upon '''prompts or questions which define the thematical focus of the latter brainstorming''' (in Step 2). The brainstorming might be intended to revolve around goals
column6: outcomes
column7: involved individuals or activities
column8: problems
column9: or other conceptual elements
column10: and so the prompts or questions should target these. Whatever the group decides to focus on
column11: the sentences or questions resulting from this first step should clearly define which kind of ideas and elements are gathered later
column12: and every involved participant should agree on them.

column2: but not necessarily
column3: a rating scheme can be developed. For this
column4: the group decides on '''dimensions along which the collected ideas and elements from the brainstorming will be rated''' (in Step 3). This rating can revolve around the statements' importance
column5: complexity
column6: likeliness or such
column7: and the group decides which kind of scale will be used to rate these elements. (Trochim 1989). For example
column8: if we take the question of reasons for students to enroll
column9: it could be reasonable to rate these reasons according to their importance on a 1-5 Likert Scale. As a second example
column10: it could be interesting to rate how easy or likely the problems of the youth in the neighborhood might be to solve.

column7: all matrices are combined into one so that the number in each field represents how many participants combined a given pair of statements. This way
column8: it can be identified which similitude or relationship the group assigns to the gathered statements. Today

'''every participant is asked to rate each statement on the pre-defined rating dimensions'''. This is typically be done using a 1-5 or 1-7 Likert Scale. The means are calculated and assigned to the statements.

column1: * Group Concept Mapping is a systematic and highly structured process with clear procedural steps
column2: that helps a diverse group of people gather and structure their thoughts into a coherent and consensual set of maps.

column1: * '''The process of Group Concept Mapping is empowering''': all content that is included in
column2: and leads to the final maps is created by the group itself
column3: in their own language and based on their own perspectives. The participants will feel more ownership for the conceptual framework that results from the process
column4: and the framework is more likely to be actively used by all involved actors than a framework that is imposed without involvement.

column1: * The end result of the process is a visual representation which introduces all important ideas at a glance in a structured manner. '''The maps can be easily communicated''' and presented without any knowledge about the methodological process.
* Group Concept Mapping is versatile in that it can work with all kinds of statements
column2: gathered from workshop sessions as presented above
column3: or from documents
column4: organisational structures etc. As Jackson and Trochim (2002) present
column5: it can also be a useful approach to analyze open-ended survey responses
column6: which are transformed into single statements and sorted by the researchers. Then
column7: they can be analyzed using the multidimensional scaling and cluster analysis steps as presented above.

column1: * A challenge lies in the organisation of the process. For example

column3: the number of statements that are gathered
column4: the way they are reduced if necessary
column5: as well as the number of clusters are in the hands of the researchers. These decisions shape the end results and require thoughtful consideration of the topic and data at hand.

column2: actively engage with an issue and (research) question
column3: and it empowers them to approach the problem with the self-developed conceptual framework.

column1: * The method is an interesting mix of qualitative research

Handling Missing Values in Python;"'''THIS ARTICLE IS STILL IN EDITING MODE'''
Missing values are a common problem in many datasets. They can occur for a variety of reasons
column2: such as data not being collected or recorded accurately
column3: data being excluded because it was deemed irrelevant
column4: or respondents being unable or unwilling to provide answers to certain questions (Tsikriktsis 2005

column2: we will explore the different types of missing values and their distributions and discuss the implications for data analysis.

column1: There are two main types of missing values: unit nonresponse and item nonresponse missing values. Item nonresponse occurs when an individual respondent is unable to provide an answer to a specific question on a survey or questionnaire (Schafer and Graham 2002
Unit nonresponse occurs when an entire unit
column2: such as a household or business
column3: is unable to provide answers to a survey or questionnaire (ibid.).

column2: we will look at how missing values can be distributed and what the implications of such distributions are. Generally
column3: both types of missing values can occur in any distribution.

column1: The distribution of missing values in a dataset can be either random or non-random. This can have a significant impact on the analysis and conclusions drawn from the data. Three common distributions of missing values are missing completely at random (MCAR)
column2: missing at random (MAR)
column3: and missing not at random (MNAR) (Tsikriktsis 2005

column1: Missing completely at random (MCAR) is a type of missing data where the missing values are not related to any other variables in the dataset
column2: and they do not follow any particular pattern or trend. In other words
column3: the missing values are completely random and do not contain any necessary information (Tsikriktsis 2005

column1: The implications of MCAR for data analysis are relatively straightforward. Because the missing values are completely random
column2: they do not introduce any bias into the analysis. Therefore
column3: it is generally safe to impute the missing values using statistical methods
column4: such as mean imputation or multiple imputations. However
column5: even if the missing values are MCAR
column6: there may still be other factors that can affect the analysis. It is important to consider the number and proportion of missing values (Scheffer 2002
column7: 156). The larger the proportion of missing values in your overall dataset the less reliable is the use of the data. Imagine you had many unit nonresponse missing values across many different individuals
column8: which results in having no variable without any missing value. This might affect the quality of your dataset. If and how this is the case
column9: needs to be decided case by case.

column1: Missing at random (MAR) is a type of missing data where the missing values are not related to the missing values themselves
column2: but they might be to other variables in the dataset. In other words
column3: the missing values are not completely random
column4: but they are not systematically related to the true value of the missing values either (Tsikriktsis 2005
column5: 55). For example
column6: imagine you conduct a survey to analyze the relationship between education and income and there are missing values concerning income. If the missing values depend on education
column7: then these missing values are missing at random. If they would depend on their actual income
column8: they would not.

column1: The implications of MAR for data analysis are more complex than those for MCAR. Because the missing values are not completely random
column2: they may introduce bias into the analysis if they are not properly accounted for. Therefore
column3: it is important to carefully consider the underlying reasons for the missing data and take these into account when imputing the missing values. One common approach to dealing with MAR missing values is to use regression or other statistical methods to model the relationship between the missing values and the other variables in the dataset (Tsikriktsis 2005
column4: 56). Once the relationship is clear
column5: other methods can be used to approximate to correct the variables for the bias due to the missing values missing at random.

column1: Missing not at random (MNAR) is a type of missing data that is related to both the observed and unobserved data. This means that the missing data are not random and are instead influenced by some underlying factor. This can lead to biased results if the missing data are not properly accounted for in the analysis (Tsikriktsis 2005
The implications of MNAR for data analysis are more complex than those for MCAR or MAR. Because the missing values are systematically related to the true values of the missing data
column2: they can introduce bias into the analysis if they are not properly accounted for. In some cases
column3: this bias may be difficult or impossible to correct
column4: even with advanced statistical methods (Tsikriktsis 2005

column1: There are two common methods to determine the randomness of missing data. The first method involves forming two groups: one with missing data for a single variable and one with valid values for that variable. If significant differences are found between the two groups regarding their relationship to other variables of interest
column2: it may indicate a non-random missing data process. The second method involves assessing the correlation of missing data for any pair of variables. If low correlations are found between pairs of variables
column3: it may indicate complete randomness in the missing data (MCAR). However
column4: if significant correlations are found between some pairs of variables
column5: it may be necessary to assume that the data are only missing at random (MAR) (Tsikriktsis 2005

column2: the treatment of missing values should be tailored to the specific distribution of missing values in the dataset. It is important to carefully consider the underlying reasons for the missing data and take appropriate steps to address them in order to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the analysis.

column1: A heatmap is a graphical representation of data where the individual numerical values are substituted with colored cells. In other words
column2: it is a table with colors in place of numbers. As in the regular table
column3: in the heatmap
column4: each column is a feature and each row is an observation.

column1: Heatmaps are useful to get an overall understanding of the data. While it can be hard to look at the table of numbers it is much easier to perceive the colors. Thus it can be easily seen which value is larger or smaller in comparison to others and how they are generally distributed.

The principle by which the colors in a heatmap are assigned is that all the values of the table are ranked from the highest to lowest and then segregated into bins. Each bin is then assigned a particular color. However
column2: in the case of the small datasets
column3: colors might be assigned based on the values themselves and not on the bins. Usually
column4: for higher value
column5: the color is more intense or darker
column6: and for the smaller is paler or lighter
column7: depending on which color palette is chosen.

column1: It is important to remember that since each feature in a dataset does not always have the same scale of measurement
column2: usually the normalization (scaling) of data is required. The goal of normalization is to change the values of numeric rows and/or columns in the dataset to a common scale
column3: without distorting differences in the ranges of values.

column1: It also means that if our data are not normalized
column2: we can compare each value with any other by color across the whole heatmap. However
column3: if the data are normalized
column4: then the color is assigned based on the relative values in the row or column
column5: and therefore each value can be compared with others only in their corresponding row or column
column6: while the same color in a different row/column will not have the same value behind it or belong to the same bin.

column1: * <syntaxhighlight lang=""R"" inline>Colv = NA</syntaxhighlight> and <syntaxhighlight lang=""R"" inline>Rowv = NA</syntaxhighlight> are used to remove the dendrograms from rows and columns. A dendrogram is a diagram that shows the hierarchical relationship between objects and is added on top of the heatmap by default if the argument is not specified. The main reason for removing it here is that it is a different method of data visualisation which is not mandatory for the heatmap representation and requires a separate article to review it fully.
* <syntaxhighlight lang=""R"" inline>scale = “column”</syntaxhighlight> is used to normalize the columns of the matrix (to absorb the variation between columns). As it was stated previously

column6: for example

It only means that the relative values of each of these cells in corresponding columns are the same or are in the same bin.

column1: The choice of color for the heatmap is one of the most important aspects of creating an understandable and nice-looking representation of the data. If you do not specify the color (as in the example above) then the default color palette will be applied. However

column2: Hermeneutics describes the process of analyzing and interpreting written text and imagery to understand the text and the creator's underlying intentions.

column1: The roots of Hermeneutics reach back to antiquity. The word 'Hermeneutics' derives from the Greek word ''hermeneuein''
column2: which basically means “to explain”. The messenger-god Hermes brought messages from the gods to the humans and explained their meaning to them (4). There has been a highly developed practice of interpretation in Greek antiquity
column3: aiming at diverse interpretanda like oracles
column4: dreams
column5: myths
column6: philosophical and poetical works
column7: but also laws and contracts. The beginning of ancient Hermeneutics as a more systematic activity
column8: however
column9: goes back to the exegesis of the Homeric epics.

column1: Hermeneutics was further developed in the Middle Ages: ""In its earliest modern forms
column2: hermeneutics developed primarily as a discipline for the analysis of biblical texts. It represented a body of accepted principles and practices for interpreting an author's intended (and inspired) meaning
column3: as well as providing the proper means of investigating a text's socio-historical context."" (5). Then
column4: ""Hermeneutics took on a new and widening importance in the early modern period with the application of philological techniques for the validation and authentication of classical texts. With the Reformation
column5: hermeneutic approaches were further deployed in intense exegetial exercises devoted to the resolution of contested meanings in scriptural texts."" (4) The ambition of early modern hermeneuts was to assign correct meanings to a text and generate 'truth'. These aspects remained the focus of Hermeneutics until the period of Enlightenment.

column1: During the last decades and centuries
column2: Hermeneutics has emerged into a field of philosophy

column1: These three steps are a basic guideline of the hermeneutic process:

analysing and understanding the given object

column1: The qualitative empirical research method of [https://www.objective-hermeneutics.com/ ''Objective Hermeneutics''] was introduced by Ulrich Oevermann. It is currently one the most prominent approaches in qualitative research in German-speaking countries (6). Objective hermeneutics
column2: in contrast to conventional hermeneutics
column3: tries to work out not only the psychologically unconscious
column4: but above all the socially unconscious in language. In this context Oevermann speaks of ""latent social structures of meaning"". In the objective-hermeneutic interpretation the interpreter compares the extent to which his own expectations of a linguistic interaction
column5: based on everyday [[Glossary|communication]] structures
column6: apply or differ from those presented in the text or interview.

column1: Here are five of the core principles or rules of Objective Hermeneutics (7):

* Context-freedom: The initial interpretation of a text should not be influenced by its context. The interpretor should create his own contextual image based on the text only and can compare this image with the context afterwards and then reevaluate it.

* Literality: The text speaks for itself and should not be judged at first (e.g. do not judge spelling or grammar mistakes as 'wrong' - they might have been made consciously to convey a specific message).
* Sequentiality: A text should be analysed chronologically without skipping passages or jumping back and forth between chapters.
* Extensivity: The extensivity principle makes clear that every little detail of a text must be included in the interpretation
column2: no matter how irrelevant it seems.

column1: * Frugality: This requires the interpreter to only create readings that are enforced by the text and
column2: accordingly
column3: to only allow case structure hypotheses that can be proven using the text.

column1: The term ""Hermeneutic Circle"" was coined by Friedrich Ast
column2: Wilhelm Dilthey and Georg Gadamer and is one of the key terms of Hermeneutics. The principle means that a whole text can only be understood if you understand its individual parts
column3: while the individual parts can only be understood if you understand the whole. This shapes the process of interpretation into a circular structure.

column1: The theory of the Hermeneutic Circle identifies three stages and one preliminary stage (8):
* Preliminary stage: development of a pre-understanding
column2: mastery of the language
column3: idea of the external conditions of a text

column1: * The hermeneutical draft (first stage): The horizon of understanding and the horizon of meaning merge
* The hermeneutic experience (second stage): pre-understanding is expanded and corrected
* The improved draft (third stage): deeper understanding
column2: maturation of the prior understanding
the process of understanding can be restarted so that the previous stages are run through again. In principle
column3: this circle can be repeated endlessly. Other theories choose the term ""hermeneutic spiral"" instead or reject the concept altogether.

column1: * The different hermeneutic approaches and principles can be applied to studies in almost all disciplines - especially all Humanities
column2: Social and Natural sciences - which makes it a universial method of understanding.

column1: == ''The History of Methods in Sustainability Science'' ==

column1: Originating in the [https://www.wissenschaft.de/umwelt-natur/die-entdeckung-der-nachhaltigkeit-3/ long-term perspective of forest management]
column2: many cultures had recognized sustainability in its original meaning since a long time. With the rise of colonialism and the industrialisation
column3: the impact of human societies onto the environment propelled into previously unseen dimensions
column4: and the negative effects of pollution were an early indicator that modern factories and coal plants were not only drivers of economic growth
column5: but equally harming livelihoods and the environment. First accounts of the environmental damage were localised
column6: and Carson‘s [https://www.britannica.com/topic/Silent-Spring ""Silent Spring""] is an early account of a systematic yet widely descriptive account of the negative impact that human activities had on the environment. This localised perspective was quickly altered onto a global scale through the [https://clubofrome.org/publication/the-limits-to-growth/ Club of Rome]. Their discourse around Climate Change was a first step from a problem-orientated perspective (Reports 1-3) to a solution-oriented perspective. The [https://www.millenniumassessment.org/en/index.html Millennium Ecosystem Assessments] were equally hinting at the shift from describing the system towards a more transformative agenda by the follow-up institution [https://ipbes.net/ IBPES]. These global reports also outlined a pronounced shift in the focus towards a regional agenda
column7: while the scientific landscape of Sustainability Science increasingly explored case studies. While these were increasingly rooted in the recognition and description of local aspects of a crisis

column1: How long do you store data?;"'''10 years.''' This is the most common answer I  get whenever I ask someone what they think is an appropriate amount of time for data storage.

column2: there are no set rules for how long you should store [[Glossary|data]] for — there are only rules of thumb. While 10 years might seem a very long period of time
column3: the decision on the duration for storage of data requires some consideration. Below is a non-exhaustive list of factors that should be considered.

column1: As data plays an increasingly important role in our day-to-day life not only as researchers but also as individuals
column2: the issue regarding data privacy and security has become more sensitive. As such
column3: governing bodies (of countries or union of countries) have been taking more active steps to address this issue. Specifically in EU (as of November 2019) GDPR mandates that in case of personal data only the dataset that is immediately usable is stored
column4: and only for the duration of time that the data is used for. There are further intricacies that are important to have in mind. As such
column5: keeping yourself aware of the data privacy and security laws of the area where you and/or your stakeholders operate in is very important.

column1: Some organizations have a strict policy that determines how long the data should be stored for. These policies generally already account for the current legal landscape and hence make deciding how long to store data for quite straightforward — you store the data for as long as the organization mandates that you store them for.
=== Nature of Research and Data Set ===
Some researches are more sensitive than others. For examples
column2: consider that you are performing research in medicine industry where you work with patients' data. In this case
column3: the data you have access to
column4: what you do with that data
column5: and the next steps your organization takes based on your work are all incredibly sensitive. Compare that to another situation where you are an engineer that wants to learn some process and are work with simulated data. Here too
column6: your work is important and carries real consequences in the future. However
column7: one of the biggest differences in the two aforementioned contexts is the data involved. You would naturally have to treat data on peoples' health issues and behaviors more importantly than you would a simulated data.

column1: If you can ensure that you can keep the data you use for your research private and secure for however long you have to store the data for
column2: then adhering to the organizational policy (if available) or the 10-years-long heuristic (if no other guidelines are available) are fine. However
column3: if you lack skills or resources to ensure data privacy and security
column4: then you should reconsider long-term storage of data. Either you have to use services that ensure data security for you
column5: or you will have to purge the data as soon as its purpose has been fulfilled (which is not ideal).

column2: there might be more factors that one needs to consider depending on the situation.
