'''In short:''' This entry provides guidance for anyone who's planning or already engaging in a doctorate position
column2: based on experiences made by Prof. von Wehrden throughout the last years and decades.

column1: == I - To PhD or not to PhD? ==

column2: it is difficult to know whether you really want to become a PhD student.''' Back in the day
column3: I did not want to do a PhD. I was basically done with University. Then my future supervisors gave me a call
column4: with the words: ""This is a call from fate"". I feel he was totally on point
column5: spot on. For me
column6: doing a PhD was serendipity. Not everybody is always totally clear whether doing a PhD is the right way. Others are clear about it already while doing their Bachelor
column7: and always claim they want to do a PhD. Consequently they do not need to ponder much about it. What is however tricky is the group of people who do not really know what to do in general
column8: and just do a PhD
column9: because
column10: why not? While it is save to say that everybody needs to find their way in doing a PhD
column11: it is difficult if you start a PhD because you do not have any alternatives. Do not misunderstand me: many of the best PhDs will come out of this group of people who lack alternatives. However
column12: some will realise halfway that maybe a PhD is not the main goal in their life. This is perfectly alright. However
column13: ideally you should make up your mind as early as possible. I wish I could offer some suggestion on who should ideally opt for doing a PhD
column14: yet I feel that academia is built on diversity
column15: and hence there is no universal recipe for a PhD
column16: let alone for a successful PhD student
column17: that is.

column1: What is however relevant for your decision to do a PhD is that you get [[Glossary|funding]]. If you apply for a project position
column2: you will have funding
column3: but there is also a clear expectation of what you are supposed to be working on. Quite often
column4: you are part of a bigger team
column5: and this demands not only a will to cooperate
column6: but also a clear responsibility and reliability towards your other fellows. In my experience
column7: there are quite some positions out there in exciting projects
column8: but the collaboration in such projects is then part of your PhD
column9: and you will constantly have to negotiate between your goals
column10: and the goals of the team. While this sounds easy in theory
column11: it is often a hole in which many work hours are buried under a pile of emotions. On the other hand
column12: you may be the only PhD in a team working on a specific topic. There are for instance quite some scholarships available
column13: and while I never understood the decisions about which PhDs get funding
column14: and which are not funded
column15: these scholarships have at least some sort of a stochastic chance to gain you funding. These scholarships are more independent
column16: which then becomes a problem down the road. Many people believe that academia is about being part of a larger team. While this is in some sense true
column17: because academics can work in teams
column18: this exchange in teams will not take away the necessity that it is you who needs to shoulder the bulk of the workload. This workload is at the heart of any PhD
column19: even if you want to contribute to a larger narrative
column20: you will have to mostly work alone. This is something that almost all PhDs struggle with: to accept that it is them who will have to do the work
column21: and no one else. As a supervisor
column22: I am willing to go all the way with you
column23: but I cannot go the way for you. You have to learn to walk this path alone
column24: a supervisor is just for the general direction. '''A PhD is ultimately about learning to overcome yourself
column25: not for others to help you overcome yourself.''' Others - your fellow students and supervisors - may be catalystic
column26: but the learning is all yours. Embrace this early on. Everybody struggles with it
column27: so I felt it is only fair if I tell you this early on.

column1: ==== What makes a successful PhD student? ====

column2: there are some character traits that I observed in the past that created successful cases. First and foremost
column3: I think that previous PhDs I know were often thrilled and excited about their research. This showed in many different appearances
column4: but overall
column5: many of these folks were basically quite driven in terms of their focus. You know it when you see it as an external observer. However
column6: you do not know it if you are one of those driven people themselves. Instead
column7: most potential PhD students are full of doubts
column8: focus on their wannabe limitations
column9: and are often never sure whether they are on the right track. Therefore
column10: it is often a good indicator if successful researchers consider it a good choice for you to pursue a PhD
column11: and are willing to support you. A PhD is more about what you could become compared to what you are. Learning is relative. Taken together
column12: if an experienced researcher is willing to support you
column13: and you feel you want to commit the next years of your life to work deeply on one topic
column14: and mostly for yourself
column15: then you may be the right person for a PhD. This brings us to the next point.

column2: you do not find a supervisor
column3: ideally you find each other. I feel that a good supervisor knows that you are the right choice
column4: or how my PhD supervisor summarised our first encounter: ""At this point
column5: I knew I would not get rid of him"". I believe
column6: doing a PhD is about learning
column7: and equally is the supervision of a PhD about learning
column8: that is
column9: learning for the supervisor. There are several steps that you can take to pursue your academic life so that you and your future supervisor have an encounter leading to a PhD. First and foremost
column10: leaving a good impression in a course is always a good idea. Many of my PhD students were students in our Bachelor or Master programs beforehand. Memories of good students are always vivid
column11: and in my experience I can tell quite quickly whether a person is a good fit for our team
column12: and a PhD. However
column13: I also frequently hire external PhD students
column14: and finding a way from outside is a bit harder. I believe that most of my colleagues and me get several dozen PhD applications form external students per year
column15: often from foreign countries and with the question for a position. Unfortunately
column16: this is not possible as most positions are related to specific projects
column17: where there exist already clear ideas about the focus and goals of the projects
column18: and positions are written out that people can apply for. In this case
column19: you apply for a very specific context
column20: and you should be clear what is expected from you.

column1: While I personally encourage my PhD students to give a position their own specific touch
column2: there are clear exceptions from funding bodies and other project partners
column3: with time frames
column4: deliverables and milestones. If you apply for a position
column5: try to learn about these things
column6: and also learn about the team that you apply for. How are interactions facilitated
column7: what about joint identity
column8: and how is the supervision organised? All these things are valuable to know
column9: and need to match your expectations. '''Many potential PhD students envision that they will sit with their professor all day
column10: and will discuss things that sound important
column11: and somewhat scientifically.''' This is not how reality looks like
column12: I think it is closer to a cognitive apprenticeship
column13: with a higher frequency of exchange in the beginning. In most cases
column14: professors have ideas
column15: and want their PhD students to pursue these ideas concretely. There may be regular interactions
column16: but as long as you are not the only PhD student
column17: there will be hardly daily active exchanges. People I admire meet their team on a weekly basis
column18: yet professors have teaching duties
column19: admin work and after all often apply for the next funding
column20: and also have larger teams beside you. Finding a supervisor is hence often about managing your own expectations. However
column21: in my experience
column22: there is more.

column1: '''I think the most important thing a supervisor can do is to motivate and to inspire.''' I have been very inspired by my supervisors and mentors. I think to me it was most important that my supervisors gave me direction and advice
column2: not necessarily general advice
column3: but more tailor-made for me. I have a rather old-fashioned idea of a supervisor being like the teacher in a Kung-Fu monastery: relaxed
column4: effortless
column5: but incredibly versatile if challenged. An inspirational supervisor makes mastery look easy
column6: effortless and incredibly elegant. The moment of bafflement when the learner attempts to do the same is the main inspiration
column7: challenging you to become a better version of yourself. Beside this inspiration a supervisor also provides a role model when it comes to structure in life (or at least that happened for me). More experienced people somewhat got their life quite in order
column8: and the mixture of experience plus more structure and established habits is a big boost for productivity. I admire experienced researchers and teachers in how they make much look effortless
column9: while especially today it seems like a badge of honor that people are busy. It was my supervisors and my idols that showed me that most people are not super-busy
column10: but badly structured and unable to focus.

column1: The last but not least thing a supervisor can bring to your development is specific advice. We all have our little twerks and insecurities we need to adjust
column2: and there may be even bigger hurdles to overcome. My first professor basically took one good look at me and addressed my biggest flaw
column3: quite bluntly. I am still thankful to him - at the time it certainly was not easy
column4: but necessary. My supervisor was equally directly showing me not only flaws and blunders in my thinking
column5: but also explained the academic system to me. Understanding hierarchies
column6: norms and structures in academia takes quite some time. Young people are often impatient
column7: yet it is also highly relevant and overdue to change the academic circus. A progressive supervisor will know how to help you on this path
column8: but equally realise that the main goal of supervision is to aid not only your students to become better
column9: but for the whole academic system to become better.

column1: Most people these days are driven by topics
column2: and want to make a difference with their work. While this is understandable and admirable
column3: I think it is only a secondary goal compared to the main goal of any given PhD
column4: and that is overcoming yourself. Looking back at my PhD
column5: I loved my topic; it was about conservation
column6: rangeland dynamics
column7: and the Gobi desert. It was incredibly cool to do
column8: and even had a real impact on the ground. I loved my PhD topic. But coming to think of it
column9: my PhD was mainly about learning to overcome myself
column10: and to learn key academic skills
column11: which were in my case revolving around methods. I had interest in my topic
column12: and my supervisors and colleagues were pivtotal to this end as well. But looking back at it 10 years later
column13: it was more about learning to work deeply on a topic
column14: any topic. Ever since
column15: my focus has shifted. Many researchers continue to work on their PhD topics for their whole careers
column16: which is kind of standard in the old days and in the normal sciences. Today
column17: this seems to be vastly different. Your PhD may ramp up your live goal
column18: but more often than not
column19: people change their focus
column20: sometimes repeatedly.

column2: you should try to find your way into the limelight of a supervisor early
column3: and try to find for yourself what you expect from a supervisor
column4: and what a supervisor can expect from you. In this way
column5: you get a clear understanding about roles and expectations. These will change later on for sure
column6: but can be an important door opener in an interview
column7: and may enable you to find your way in a new role as a PhD student. '''Earning a PhD is among the greatest privileges of academia
column8: and is for me only surpassed by the privilege to supervise a PhD.''' A PhD is about years of a life of a person
column9: and that investment of a person counts for something
column10: and then some
column11: I would say.

column2: but instead all research is standing on the shoulders of giants. We are part of a multiverse and a continuum
column3: and no matter how small our own contribution may be
column4: it is part of a bigger picture. This is the most important point of departure for any PhD
column5: because it highlights the importance of reading the literature your work is built upon. ''What are the foundations of the topic? Who are central figures in the debate? What are the central theories of your work?'' All this you should read up upon
column6: because it is expected that you become the expert on this small turf of current research. The goal of a PhD is to become an expert in one very specific part of current research
column7: and to move it forward. '''This is a problem for many
column8: because I believe that you hardly ever feel like an expert.''' I certainly do not feel an expert in anything
column9: and most PhDs feel that they are predominately gigantic experts in procrastination. We have all been there.

column2: consider the topic and theories that you read your way into
column3: and try a little visualisation technique. Image a circle around you
column4: maybe of about 100 kilometres. How many people would you think are surpassing your expertise regarding the very specific topic? Coming to think of it
column5: quite few
column6: probably. You become an expert. I for once became an expert about the vegetation of the southern Mongolian Gobi
column7: and its dynamics. Granted
column8: a very singular area of expertise
column9: but there are a few handful of experts to this end
column10: and I had to learn to acknowledge this in my PhD. More importantly
column11: one needs to own it
column12: and this takes time. Try to develop a strategy how you read papers
column13: make a plan
column14: and first and foremost try to learn to crossroad papers fast. You need to become able to grasp the main points of a paper quickly
column15: especially the points that are important for you. Learning to get an overview of a field of research is a pivotal skill for any researcher.

column1: Learning to read is a means to an end
column2: and this end is to inform your own research direction and design. By building on previous knowledge you learn to identify gaps
column3: and become able to verbalise existing questions that remain unanswered. Then
column4: you can start to frame what you want to do and how you want to do that correctly. No one is an island. Other people will have done some parts of what you want to do before - it is often the recombination of information that is the really new and innovative step. Try to understand where the frontier is in your research area
column5: and be bold enough to push this frontier a bit further. I often advise people that if your topic is innovative
column6: you may want to have your underlying theory and the methods you utilise to be maybe not on the bold end of the spectrum. If the theory is bold
column7: maybe a solid topical foundation can make it more tangible. If everything about your research is the unexplored country - to build on Shakespeare - then it will be very hard to build something tangible. In order to be bold and innovative in some parts of your research
column8: I often feel it is helpful if other parts are solid and somewhat established. In a PhD
column9: it can be good to depart from the state-of-the-art
column10: and then progressively move this forward. The next section will deal with the potential architecture of your thesis.

column1: == IV - Getting the first paper done ==
The first paper is the hardest
column2: always. I remember how much effort I put into my first paper
column3: and it felt as if it would never be done. I feel that here the supervisor can potentially help a bit more
column4: while towards the end of a thesis the candidate should ideally become more independent. What is safe to say from my viewpoint is that we all need help at some point.

column1: '''I think all PhDs need three types of skills: Getting data
column2: analysing data
column3: and interpreting the results.''' Ideally
column4: a PhD is more or less able to master at least two of these steps
column5: and may need a bit more support by one of the other steps. Most PhDs are excited about getting data
column6: a step that is often easy to begin and hard to end. This is why it is helpful to have clear designs and to fixate these in more or less binding written outlines. Writing a clear structure of your thesis in the beginning is helpful. This outline and structure will often be altered
column7: but in my experience is it helpful to force your way through this
column8: and this comes from someone who did not do this
column9: which was clearly a mistake. I would say give it a try
column10: have it critiqued
column11: and then be open-minded to change it. But see it like a band aid: you want to rip this off fast.

column1: This brings you to the first paper. In many institutions it is vital to have at least one paper published
column2: and the typical three years you have for a PhD fly past fast. Since peer-review takes time
column3: it is vital to get the first paper done rather quickly
column4: and submit it. It may circulate for some months
column5: or in severe cases even more than a year at the journal with editors and reviewers
column6: so go figure what that means for the three year timeline of your PhD. Therefore
column7: I often recommend that the first paper could be a [[Systematic Literature Review|systematic review]]. You anyway have to read all the available literature
column8: so why not do that in a systematic sense. I acknowledge that I like reviews a lot
column9: and approach many topics through reviews
column10: yet in your PhD it also has the benefit that no one can take all this knowledge away from you. It can be quite comfortable to stand on the shoulders of giants
column11: and in your defense you will be able to have references woven into your replies with ease
column12: which people will appreciate. I also think it is quite helpful to write a systematic review to define your point of departure. All things considered
column13: the outlook of the review may ramp up your agenda for the PhD.

column1: An alternative way is to make a pilot study or a pretest of you next paper
column2: and make this a small but precious first paper in your PhD. Such a small empirical paper can be an equally good starting point
column3: as it is often quite easy to structure such a paper
column4: and to get into a flow in terms of writing it. Here again
column5: an outline is ideal
column6: because many people are tempted to make such a paper more than it actually is. Remember that you start
column7: and more can be pursued in the next papers.

column1: '''What is also important to consider for your first paper is to identify a target journal.''' ''Which journals harbour the most literature on the topic you are working on? Which journals seem appealing in terms of the style
column2: focus and audience?'' And maybe you want to consider a small gambit
column3: and aim a bit higher? Depending on your time line
column4: you might make the first submission a little bit higher
column5: knowing that you have a sure shot at another journal that is slightly less prestigious? To this end
column6: it is good to rely on the experience of your supervisor
column7: and fellow PhDs and other colleagues. Some [[Glossary|journals]] demand a specific format and structure
column8: and this should be considered early on.

column2: in order to get this first paper done
column3: you need to develop a mindset where you want to get this paper done. This is what the first paper is all about: starting to learn to overcome yourself. Try to keep it simple
column4: try to establish writing as a habit
column5: and also try to gain experience. At this state
column6: many people claim to be bad at writing. I think this is simply not true
column7: they are only untrained in writing. Writing takes practice
column8: and I am not only talking about putting words on paper. I am talking about creating a structure and taking decisions. Writers take decisions. Hence you will need to practice
column9: and this is what the first paper is for. You will have to learn to get your work into smaller chunks. If you write a quarter of the introduction of a paper in a day
column10: then you should be done in two weeks if you keep up the pace. Since structure and momentum are key challenges
column11: try to make a bullet point outline
column12: or discuss the structure of the paper with your supervisors or your peers. If you ask me
column13: try not to focus on the flaws
column14: but try to get a full first version onto the paper. This is the hardest thing
column15: but being in the limbo of iterations is something that will happen anyway
column16: so try to write the first version with your heart
column17: and then try to get it criticised. This is not about being perfect. This is about finding a way to start
column18: which is exactly what the first paper should focus on.

column1: == V - The empirical gap and/or trap ==
While reading and designing the potential studies is one vital first step for any given PhD
column2: getting empirical data (or engaging with conceptual depth in case of a non-empirical PhD) is the real deal. Time to get your hands dirty. The key challenge for any empirical work is that there are some things that can be planned and designed
column3: and some other things where you have to embrace a healthy form of improvisation. The gap between these two is the source of endless stories of countless researchers across the globe. Planning what you want to work on needs to build widely on experience and previous research
column4: hence consulting expert researchers
column5: discussing your design with your supervisor
column6: and first and foremost reading the relevant literature is the most important basis.

column1: Now imagine you started gathering data
column2: for example you are interviewing actors in a system. In my experience
column3: most researchers will now enter the ''what if'' stage
column4: where they either start to amend their design with all sorts of additional modifications
column5: or where they start beating themselves up about what they could have done differently
column6: or what they would do differently next time. This is normal. First of all
column7: negative results are also a scientific results
column8: although of course this is way less thrilling
column9: and most research is biased toward positive results. Second
column10: no results explain 100 %
column11: a model or outcome that explains everything is certainly flawed. It is in the very nature of empirical research that it has flaws
column12: and variance and complexity add to lessen the results. Within qualitative research
column13: it may surface that with more samples - for instance more interviews - the results may be different
column14: and many researchers frame this different as ""better"" in their heads. Again
column15: this is only partly true
column16: as we have to acknowledge that any type of empirical research is only looking at parts of reality. Still
column17: I sometimes wonder whether most empirical researchers beat themselves up about their data approximately as long as it took them to gather the respective data. This process is sometimes refered to as ""analysis"". While experts in methodology would agree that proper analysis of empirical data - both quantitive and qualitative - takes as long as the data gathering
column18: most of this time is dominated by doubts
column19: regrets and the predominant wish to be able to travel back in time to do everything again. Learning that your data is flawed and could have been better is an important lesson
column20: and the lesson is not as much about improving your knowledge to avoid this specific mistake in the future. '''Instead
column21: this is about learning to live with the imperfections of the empirical'''. For conceptual work
column22: this can be equally framed. Often
column23: you discover the most important source towards the end
column24: or even better
column25: after you finished your work. Conceptual work has its own demons
column26: and I think it is overall much easier to work empirical first
column27: and with a focus on conceptual contributions later
column28: but here I may be mistaken. As a philosopher
column29: you will probably work conceptually from the very beginning. I admire this work
column30: but is demands a high level of coherence
column31: which is why it can be relevant for any given PhD student - including empirical workers - to derive a glossary of your most important words early on in your PhD. I wish I would have done this
column32: as it would have saved me from iterations and inconsistencies. Better to reflect about a term once and deeply
column33: and then settling on a compromise that you stick to for the rest of your thesis. Building such consistency is I think an underrated skill in most PhD works.

column2: you should consult experts on your empirical design
column3: because nothing is worse than a failed design. However
column4: do not expect something magic out of that: empirical sampling is work
column5: harder work
column6: and failing. Just try to get at it
column7: and enjoy it while you can. The head of my PhD lab always claimed what a privilege we all had
column8: since us PhD students only focus on one thing
column9: and one thing only. I think this is so incredibly true coming to think about it now
column10: but at the time it did not feel like it. Life as a PhD students is often stressful
column11: but always remember that is serves as a basis for great stories later in your life. Glorious days!

column1: Now let us assume you have your data
column2: you are on your way towards results
column3: and then you get stuck. What if you make just another round of fieldwork? How about one more campaign - a short one - just for a few more interviews? And did you see this great summer school that was advertised? It is not exactly your focus
column4: but it sure sounds exciting
column5: right? Maybe it would help you to gain some friction on your analysis
column6: and then you could already join this years round of conferences to present some results. The one in Prague sounded really interesting! '''Welcome to the world of procrastination.''' May this stage be a short one
column7: but it never is. You kind of started
column8: technically you know what to do
column9: and now you feel there are so many exiting opportunities that you need to seize as a researchers. And there are some plants that seem to need watering as well
column10: right? Or how about a little snack?

column1: I believe that the [[Glossary|creativity]] of most researchers I admire is maxed out when they try to procrastinate. I have been there
column2: and I am still there
column3: sometimes. The world is full of exciting alternative opportunities when you should be actually writing your PhD thesis. What is most important now is that you learn to manage yourself
column4: and this form of self-improvement starts with building consistent habits. Try to develop a daily rhythm that works for you. Me
column5: I like starting rather early
column6: doing some Yoga
column7: writing the first text before 8
column8: making it a rather energetic morning
column9: taking a break at midday
column10: preferring a nap for a lunch break
column11: and setting meetings into the afternoon when energy levels are lower. In the evening
column12: I might take another round of concentrated writing for some hours
column13: or maybe some sort of mechanical tinkering such as some statistical analysis. My day was not always like this
column14: but today it is planned down to 15 minute blocks
column15: focussing on balancing my energy levels
column16: and trying to build a pendulum between motivation for challenging tasks vs gratification with some of the nicer tasks. Keeping my energy levels constant is I think my main goal these days
column17: preferring to avoid both extreme peaks as well as total slumber. '''Gaining flow in writing is a great challenge
column18: and takes livelong practice.''' I like to start with a clear designation that I start writing in this moment. Either I make myself a coffee
column19: have a location change
column20: or I have the time clearly designated in my calendars (a trick I only learned recently). Most writers have deeply ritualised habits
column21: and are often working to improve them even further. For a long time now
column22: I have been writing with music or background sounds. I have almost a dozen nature sound apps on my phone
column23: and Philip Glass
column24: Dawn of Midi and Max Richter are my staples when writing. These days I get hardly distracted by this music
column25: but instead is actively prevents my mind from wandering
column26: and allows me to create text for long stretches of time. Another helpful step is to carve out the general structure
column27: and then fill this up. Me
column28: I like to structure my texts in bits of about 200-300 words. Everything more detailed is taking too long
column29: and everything less detailed does not to justice to catching the overall structure. I encourage you to try things out and to try to develop your own habits and strategies.

column1: In order to be able to do this
column2: you need to practice. Writing and gaining flow at your work is not something that you learned in school
column3: I guess
column4: and most people have not produced a few hundred thousand words yet in their life. Academia communicates widely through writing
column5: and learning to structure your thoughts in writing is one of the essential goals in a PhD. If you start by writing about 1000 words per day
column6: you will see how this can ultimately bring you into a state where you are quickly able to structure your thoughts and fixate them on paper. Many prefer actual paper
column7: yet most use their computer. I learned that a comfortable hour in a garden chair with my mobile phone can well produce 2000 words that propel me up for a good start. I often write a lot in the very early hours of the day
column8: just as now. Late at night is another sweet spot
column9: as there are less distractions. Find these niche spots
column10: and write. Get at it. You are not a bad writer
column11: you are just an untrained writer. '''No one would expect to grab a musical instrument for the first time
column12: and play music right away.''' You need to practice in all you do
column13: but I think the reason why the hurdle is higher in writing is because the actual form of scientific papers seems somewhat distant from us and our everyday life. Yet in order to do a PhD
column14: and to gain recognition for your future career path
column15: you need to ''publish or perish''. There is - in the current system - no way around it
column16: and in my experience PhD students who question this simple path dependency are literally doomed to perish. To spin it less dramatic: I would argue that other people deserve to read your work. You are being paid to do research
column17: and your results should contribute to the greater good of science. Typically
column18: your salary is not so bad - if you write 3-4 papers in your PhD
column19: consider the costs of one of those papers. Scientific papers are certainly not cheap
column20: but they are necessary to make your work transparent
column21: and to enable other researchers as well as society to learn form your insights. I think it is safe to say that peer reviewed publications will be the baseline of science for quite some time to come
column22: hence they should be the baseline of your PhD as well.

column1: This bring us to the next point: the role of your team. Most PhD students are part of a team
column2: and that is a good thing. While I already said that it is you who is writing your PhD
column3: and no one else
column4: I think that getting feedback from your fellow PhDs
column5: and learning how you can collaborate with others
column6: is actually a core academic skill. Still
column7: I think every paper should have someone who is in control
column8: literally leading the others. The skill of mastering a multi-authored paper is not about others taking the workload from you
column9: but you designating smaller parts to people with a complementary expertise
column10: and you integrating their chunks. The bulk of the workload is with the lead author. Equally
column11: a paper you co-author can be no excuse to not work on your papers first and foremost. Your papers should always be your main focus and only when these are done you can shift your energy to something else. '''Focus!''' I know it is so tempting to work on something else
column12: but you may want to consider to have a clear plan how to divide your energy. Working for four days on your PhD and one day on a co-authored paper would be a reasonable division of your label force. Then the co-authored paper can become a reward
column13: but make no mistake: You will have to shoulder the hardest part of your work by yourself
column14: there is no way around it. Learning to gain flow in your own work is an essential academic skill. Try to put yourself in the shoes of your supervisor. I for once had to learn how to gain flow in my work in order to become able to try and inspire others
column15: and to help them on the way. I can only write these lines now
column16: because I learned to focus on my work at some point. In order to be able to supervise and inspire others in the future
column17: you need to become able to gain flow and to prioritise your work above all else. In order to achieve this
column18: focus is pivotal
column19: which brings us to the next points.

column2: right? You read all the literature. You are pondering about all sorts of theories and frameworks
column3: and then some. You learned your system inside out. The model of your working area that is in your head is at leats ten times as complex as reality itself. No other human has ever comprehended what you learned about all this during the first part of your PhD. Now you need to explain it to others.

column1: Those who know me understand how fond I am of Occam's razor. ''Everything needs to be as simple as possible and as complex as necessary.'' Empirical research is about models of reality. Hence it is your work to reduce the full model of your results into a tangible version to follows Occam's razor. Every piece of information that you reduce is like a small death
column2: to give this line of thinking a dramatic spin. What is important
column3: what is not important? You are the judge. Whoever made you the judge will not be there to help you
column4: because no one is supposed to understand this stuff as good as you. You are the expert
column5: yet you feel a million miles away from understanding anything. How to proceed
column6: you ask? Let us go through it point by point.

column2: paradigms
column3: framworks or concepts. While all these operate on different levels
column4: it is still common that you identify one or several conceptual foundations that your work resolves around. Most PhD students are quickly falling in love with several concepts
column5: and encounter problems when deciding which concepts are valuable for their work
column6: and which concepts are less important. Theories are simplifications of reality
column7: and hence imperfect. If you deductively try to falsify or confirm a theory
column8: the theoretical foundation is very simplified
column9: but easier to handle. Research over the last decades has had a general tendency to be more inductively
column10: or even abductive. To this end
column11: a theoretical foundation may give clear boundaries within which you work inductively. Take for instance the stakeholder theory
column12: which you can test in all sorts of different settings or systems
column13: but you always integrate a resource-based as well as a market-based view in your research. '''What is sure about theoretical foundations to this end is that several of them together are difficult to integrate.''' If you work on ecosystem services
column14: focussing on biodiversity
column15: building on neutral theory
column16: investigating resilience
column17: to investigate climate change adaptation
column18: then you got yourself into a deep mess. Theoretical foundations have a tendency to exponentiate each other. If you have two theoretical foundations
column19: you may get a vague one concrete
column20: if the other one is concrete. Personally
column21: I would leave integration of more theoretical foundations to philosophers
column22: or at least to conceptual papers. In empirical research
column23: more than two theoretical foundations are more often than not confusing. Still
column24: many PhDs have some sort of a fear of missing out concerning theoretical foundations
column25: the more the merrier seems to be where many get stuck. Never forget
column26: they they are all only models of reality
column27: and equally you will have to compromise which theoretical foundation(s) work best in your case.

column2: and now you dug yourself a hole in the world of analysis. May it be the never ending coding in a [[Content Analysis|content analysis]]
column3: or a statistical abyss - there is a long tradition to bury yourself in your own empirical results and their analysis. '''Remember that you are looking for the most important information now.''' Not everything
column4: but the main patterns. What do you think the world can learn from your data. Many will iterate themselves though all stages
column5: from ''do I got anything at all''
column6: ''how can I every make sense of this mess''
column7: ''it is dead
column8: Jim''
column9: ''A New Hope'' to finally ''how about I leave it like that and hate myself forever for it?''.

column1: '''Empirical research is messy.''' There is no mincing words here. Yet it is learnable. You can learn to live with it. Experience in empirical research almost never feels good
column2: I think. It is either a total challenge
column3: or being absolutely bored. Strangely
column4: there is hardly anything in between
column5: only the feeling of being totally overwhelmed
column6: or the weird querkiness of thinking that is just cannot be that simple
column7: and all this is super trivial. Get over it. What you should learn in the long run is that you may want to embrace your results
column8: but still be critical. Results may vary. Even patterns are hard to be reproduced these days. Remember that we unlock [[Bias and Critical Thinking|parts of reality]]. Stand by what your data can do
column9: but always keep an open mind to the simple truth that it will change probably in the (very) long run
column10: because hardly anything is constant. You work is a contribution in the here and now
column11: and I feel this should be enough to get it done in the here and now.

column1: ==== The contribution to the topic and the state of the art ====

column2: much of science is driven by topics. People want to make a difference. To me
column3: topics are mere samples. Do not misunderstand me:  some topics are timely
column4: and some are more important than others. But when you look at your PhD one or two decades later
column5: you will know what I mean. Your interest will necessarily shift
column6: yet what will remain is the skills your learned and the experience you gained. Taking your thesis to find your way into a proper Philosophy of Science is something that will surely stick. Developing your work ethic will surely stick. But this section is not about all that. It is about your topic. You have to become the expert on the respective topic
column7: so much we already agreed upon. You will be the expert
column8: and you need to break the topic down in order for others to understand it. What are the most important pieces of information that build as much as a whole picture? How can you frame your knowledge into a narrative? Do you have an [[Elevator Pitch|elevator pitch]] to tell someone the really short version of your thesis? And what if you get stuck in an elevator with the president of your University
column9: do you also have a longer version? Developing all this takes time
column10: but you need to get at it
column11: and test your expertise then and again.

column2: are you also able to share your excitement about your PhD with people outside of academia? Many people within academia will measure your impact by the journals you publish in
column3: but these days impact is measured in many facets
column4: and driving change in society is of growing importance
column5: and rightly so. What is however difficult to grasp are the outer margins of your topic. Try to work hard to define what you are working on
column6: and what you are not working on. Many people get dragged into a rabbit hole where they try to shoulder everything
column7: but it is equally important to know what you are not working own
column8: as to know what you are working on. Ideally
column9: you can choose and reframe along the way. The typical PhD student changes their concrete focus quite a lot along the way. What is always sad to observe is how PhD students are continuously worried that someone did exactly what they did
column10: but half a year before. While this can be the case in some cutting edge branches of medicine or genetics
column11: where the trajectories are following a clearer path
column12: I hardly encountered that somebody really did exactly the same thing as you were planning to do in your branch of soft science. There are always differences
column13: and quite often pretty substantial ones. Just be relaxed
column14: in the end it is all going to be alright. And because no one will relax about this point any day soon
column15: let us move to the next point
column16: and quickly.

column1: At this stage you have your data
column2: you have a vague idea how you are going to contribute to your specific part of science
column3: and you have a menu of what theories you can utilise in your thesis. This is the stage where many struggle to master their spirit and get instead lost in self-doubt and endless questioning everything inbetween the smaller details and - well - everything. The best way to countermeasure this is to start early to have a structure that allows you to have early success with your first paper. Building on Ali Abdaal here
column4: we got motivation mixed up. It is not our ideas that motivate us
column5: but instead smaller success that motivates us towards larger challenges that lead to larger success
column6: and so on. If you do not manage to reach early success
column7: the larger challenges of work will become impossible to overcome. This is why I think that you need to learn writing first
column8: and then use this skill to write what you actually want to write about. Writers block is an altogether different story
column9: I think. Many people who think they have writers block have either not even started to learn how to write
column10: and are just lacking a routine
column11: or are living in the believe that writing should feel great. Science made a dramatic mistake when is starting selling itself as a ''Heureka''-generating euphoria - that simply does not match reality. Writing in science is hard work
column12: and in any other field of labour
column13: if nothing else will work
column14: ''work will work''. The other challenge is taking decision
column15: which I extensively outlined above. Again this takes practice
column16: you need to learn to become constant in your life habits. There are too many things beyond your control that you need to take into account
column17: hence the more stability you can add to the process
column18: the better.

column2: your supervisor ====

column1: Try to establish a clear protocol early on. What is expected from you
column2: and what would you like your supervisor to do? Remember that your supervisor could probably write your thesis in a matter of months if not weeks
column3: but this is not what it is all about. Some things you can only learn by yourself. Yet if there is one thing that was absolutely fantastic during my PhD
column4: it was the fact that the door of my supervisor was always open. Whenever I had a question
column5: I could ask him. Looking back at it
column6: I do not know how he managed this
column7: and coming to think of it
column8: much must have been quite annoying. I can consider myself lucky that I had a supervisor with an incredibly high level of patience. Looking back today
column9: I think that I can be grateful
column10: yet as a supervisor I would clarify the roles clearer
column11: which is another nod to the patience of my supervisor. It is however the role of a supervisor to give a frank and honest evaluation of the current stage of the thesis
column12: and to motivate the student if need be. This is easier said then done
column13: because this is different for every PhD student. Therefore
column14: I think the most important thing one should try to develop is [[Glossary|trust]]. There is no magic portion or spell that can help tu to develop trust
column15: but it should be the goal from both sides
column16: I feel.

column2: your co-authors ====

column1: Managing co-authors is a pivotal academic skill
column2: and most PhD students learn hardly more than under these constellations. I exclude the supervisor here
column3: as I dealt with this relation before. The rest of the co-authors can be divided into three groups: The Peers
column4: the superiors
column5: and the minions.

column1: The peers are the most important group for you. Find peers with a similar interest and work ethic. And with 'interest' I do not mean 'topic'. It is not important what they work on
column2: this can be different
column3: but how they work on it should be allowing to build a link
column4: and the means of their work should be to allow for the creation of a reflexive space. You learn the most about yourself through the reflection of your peers. Working together with peers can give you energy
column5: and help you to master hurdles together. Yet make no mistake: Your peers will not write your thesis
column6: and in the end you will have to take the decisions they cannot take for you. I had three fantastic peers during my PhD
column7: and a wonderful wider team at our institute. The closer peers - and later also some other fellows - were active collaborators. This was highly relevant for me
column8: because I learned about methods through the data of other people. I think that it is ideal if you can use a peer-to-peer exchange to develop yourself. The wider circle is important as a social buffer
column9: where you can share the experience of academia
column10: and lighten the load of the smaller and larger challenges all PhDs face. This is after all also a time one should enjoy.

column1: Publishing with other superiors is a privilege. If someone with less time than you is available to you wants to commit their dense schedule to your work
column2: then you should try to leave a positive impression. Be clear in your communication
column3: discuss openly who is doing which tasks
column4: but try to have the others maybe first outline their role
column5: and then try to match it. Peer-review also led to the rise of some opportunists
column6: but remember that the line between a real contribution and some helpful thoughts is a blurry one. Still
column7: for a PhD it is often difficult to access the contributions of a professor or postdoc
column8: hence ideally you rely on your supervisor
column9: who may decide together with your supervisor which contribution merits which authorship. I had the honour of having many co-authors as a PhD that were on a much higher level
column10: both in hierarchy as well as experience
column11: and I learned very much from them
column12: and for this I am truly grateful.

column1: If on the other hand you have minions working for you
column2: and by that I mean student or technical assistants
column3: then you should extend the same learning experience and gratitude to the people that you work with. Students will look at you for inspiration
column4: and you could be a mentor for them through which you learn in turn as well. Working well with technicians will help you to learn about their specific expertise
column5: and in my experience there is hardly anyone more motivated and kind than a technician who feels valued. Again
column6: with students and technicians it is important to cleary communicate your expectations and make sure that everybody is on the same page. Try to lead by example
column7: if you are hard working and committed
column8: the others will be motivated and empowered.

column2: peer review ====

column1: The system of peer review is better than its reputation. Impressions of reviews are highly reproducible
column2: and the system creates hundreds of thousand of papers every year. However
column3: sometimes it takes some patience
column4: and it has some challenges the one needs to learn. The first rejection will feel like a total devastation
column5: and it will be hard not to take the comments of reviewers and editors personal
column6: especially if these comments are at the lesser end of the spectrum. Yet peer-review is not about every little detail
column7: but it is more of a lump sum process. Some comments are less important than others. It is more about the general pattern of a review
column8: and not you escalating yourself about piecemeal. Yet
column9: peer review takes time. Submitting a paper
column10: hearing back
column11: then submitting it elsewhere after a rejection or working on a revision takes months
column12: and for each step a few months easily adds up to a year. Learn to see this as a process that is established - criticising it will help you very little. You may want to ask your supervisor if you could do a review of a paper
column13: given that you are up for it
column14: then you will learn that reviewers are also people. Peer-review is something that you learn
column15: and this principle works for both receiving criticsm
column16: but also for handing it out.

column1: == IX - You have to let go ==
You did your empirical work and analysis
column2: you have your papers happening
column3: maybe presented at a conference
column4: and you can see a light at the end of the tunnel. Or so you should. For many PhDs
column5: the final phase is dense
column6: stressful
column7: just an altogether twice-baked turmoil lacking any sugar coating. After the papers you should start early on the red tape
column8: which is the overall part of the thesis that in the end will have woven all parts together. This will be hard for most
column9: because it means that your time as PhD student will end. You have to decide that it is done. You will have to accept that you become a part of the academic merit that so many passed before you. You will have to acknowledge that you did what you could. You have to stand up to your supervisor
column10: your peers
column11: the whole institute. You should see this as a part of a process that is overall well established. Why should your case be any different? In my experience it helps to make a rather clear structure of the steps you have to take to finalise your PhD
column12: and to stick by this list. Try to share it with others and build up peer pressure. Discuss it with your supervisor. '''And most importantly
column13: build a continuous timeline of the phase after your PhD.''' What do you want to do? If you do not get this right
column14: at least in terms of the general direction
column15: than you will probably procrastinate. You do not need to have a postdoc position waiting for you
column16: but you should know which next steps you want to pursue.

column2: try not to be obsessive about finalising your thesis in terms of typesetting and layout. Try to learn the necessary skills early
column3: I certainly failed this lesson. Become a Word ''pro''. Maybe this is not the most exciting skill
column4: but surely helpful when you need to set up a few hundred pages of text
column5: you text
column6: your thesis. Get help
column7: if you need it. Have people read the pre-final version
column8: the penultimate version
column9: and help you with the printout. Once the whole thing is handed in
column10: never look at it again. Ever. There will be flaws and mistakes. Most people will not recognise them
column11: even your reviewers may not find them. Hence you may want to keep this opportunity to harvest anxiety out of your defence preparation.

column2: the day of your thesis defence is approaching. You need to start your presentation slides. How could you ever boil down all these papers into the few minutes you have?! You need to choose
column3: maybe you drop one paper altogether. You need to focus on the main points. Try to attend defenses early on
column4: learn what is expected
column5: who did well
column6: and why? Learn about the questions the committee asks
column7: and try to prepare yourself mentally for similar settings. Practice way early by presenting at some conferences or in front of your peers. Have your slides critiqued by your peers. Build a narrative. '''It should not be magic
column8: it should be robust
column9: and it should follow the existing conventions'''. Giving at least some mockup presentations is crucial
column10: as you need to learn the timing and the drama of the whole thing. Do not worry about being repetitive: once the real thing happens
column11: adrenalin will kick in
column12: and whip you through the whole thing in no time.

column1: To prepare for a defense means that everything that can be asked was already in your head once. You need to become so deeply embedded into your stuff
column2: that you become everything that can be asked. In my experience
column3: this is mostly not about knowledge
column4: but about confidence and structure. You need to overcome the doubts you have
column5: listen to the questions people may ask
column6: breath once - shortly
column7: to think - and then give a crisp answer. Do not ramble.  Say the most important things
column8: and then find an endpoint. Just like in writing
column9: you need to take a decision.

column1: A good friend once told me that an outstanding PhD student to him is someone
column2: who can afterwards independently conduct research in the respective field alone
column3: or as a supervisor. I think this is what you should be thriving for. This is what a PhD is about. You follow a path of learning that many went on before. You become part of an academic tradition
column4: and the key goal of this tradition is that you become an innovator. You learn to overcome yourself
column5: and become an academic. Depending how you go on
column6: you can become an expert in civil society
column7: do research in society or academia
column8: and in academia you may later educate others and inspire them to follow in your footsteps. To me
column9: this is my greatest privilege I have as an academic. Thank you very much for this.

column1: The end of any successful PhD is a celebration. Personally
column2: I am very bad at celebrating
column3: but it is part of the academic circus. For most people the celebration is important
column4: and it is clear that it is well deserved. You have to give a speech. Hardly any surprises ever happened at such speeches
column5: as it is widely scripted by the circumstances. There is often food and drinks. Your supervisor will probably talk with your parents
column6: always the greatest pleasure for me
column7: and almost always an embarrassment for the PhD student. This is a moment of true emancipation of the PhD student
column8: both from the parents and the supervisor(s). The PhD student is however often too shellshocked to process anything that is happening. Often it is quite a turmoil of emotions
column9: and it will take days to realize that it is done. '''From then on
column10: you will go into a phase of reflection that will take years.''' I closely follow when my fellow professors talk about their supervisors
column11: you often hear gratitude
column12: subtle criticism
column13: or even downright tendencies of Stockholm syndrome. This is all perfectly normal. Coming to think of it
column14: there are hardly any relationships in life outside of our family and partners that are closer. Also
column15: learning can be stressful. I know that all I am in academia was seeded by my mentors and supervisors
column16: and their patience and experience. It took me years to figure this out
column17: since we do not only learn how to do things
column18: but also how to do things our way. Academia is about development
column19: and doing a PhD is about personal transformation.  You engage in a journey that technically ends with your defense
column20: but actually it never ended. The latest stepping stone I reached was when I understood that I am not a teacher
column21: but a learner. Having passed the rites of a PhD and now being a professor
column22: the whole endeavor is about learning and teaching
column23: intertwined
column24: woven
column25: twisting. This is what I came to love the most about academia
column26: as I know that academia has a lifetime of learning to offer to me.

How to dean;"{|class=""wikitable"" style=""text-align: center; width: 100%""

'''In short:''' This entry provides guidance for anyone who's planning or already engaging to be a dean
column2: and might also help others to understand the position of a dean better
column3: and how academia might work in general. Naturally
column4: this is the perspective of one person only.

column1: '''Being the Dean – a manifesto reflected and revised'''
In this post I will reflect about the time of being the dean of the Faculty of Sustainability. After some thinking and recent events
column2: I wrote down 10 rules in the very beginning that I consider relevant to me. You might wonder now
column3: why you should read them. Are you a dean? Do you consider becoming a dean? Even if not
column4: the following might be of relevance for you
column5: maybe not to learn something I learned
column6: but to learn something about the academic system
column7: and your part in it. I can say I learned some lessons. The guidelines I defined early on are written in bold. The revisiting of the guidelines six months into the deanship is written in plain text. The revisiting of these texts 2 months after my six year term as a dean are also highlighted accordingly. This is a highly personal account
column8: obviously. However
column9: since I am not aware of such a knowledge resource being available quite often
column10: I felt it might still give people some value.

column1: '''The dean works on the coherent triangle of management of the Faculty
column2: research in the Faculty and teaching of the Faculty
column3: together with the other deans.'''

column1: Many consider that management is the central theme of being the dean. It is simply boring admin
column2: and why would a true researcher or teacher bother at all? Well
column3: it is admin work
column4: I will not fool you here
column5: but maybe we can change the admin system
column6: if only step by step. I learned a lot about admin tricks during the last 6 months
column7: but more importantly
column8: I altered the mode of admin surrounding me. How I did that you ask? First
column9: I observed for 2-3 months. During this time
column10: only emergency changes were made
column11: beside that
column12: I sticked quite to the structure I found
column13: which was after all very good.

column2: I increasingly asked people
column3: what they would change. Then I took the ratio and rational out of the intel and started implementing changes. It was actually fun
column4: not only for me
column5: but also (I hope) for others. Fact is
column6: that most people want responsibility and trust. I think it is vital to help people reach their peak
column7: and through the efforts of my tremendous surrounding
column8: I actually feel I get closer to my own peak. Admin is actually much much much better than its reputation. I think people do take the time to reflect on how good the system actually is. If baffled by admin and procedures
column9: it is best -I learned- to take a step back and look at the whole picture. With some context
column10: I believe to have learned that hardly anyone is harmful
column11: and no one is evil in admin. People are just overworked and misunderstood. Structured and solution-orientated suggestions for improvement are what’s working best.

column1: Management within constructed institutions means playing a long game. If you want to change things
column2: negative emotions or pressure will bring you nowhere. You need to work with the system
column3: not against it. In my experience
column4: the vast majority of the people working in administration and management are doing a tremendous job. Those few who seemingly bother you actually may have the most challenging job in the whole institution
column5: as they need to enforce principles or mechanisms that they did not choose. We are at a point in time where „the machine“ tries to control any given outlier point through a new rule. To this end
column6: we pile rules and rules on top of each other. In my experience this is not specific for any given institution
column7: but simply the Zeitgeist. Only time will tell how we can change this. However
column8: we can only do this together
column9: because the machine with its mechanisms and principles is quite tight. We should never forget that we came a long way
column10: and I can personally say that I feel to be in a very privileged situation. Also
column11: I am in a very powerful situation
column12: there are no mincing words there. To this end
column13: it should be ok that there are some underlying mechanisms that control our power. However
column14: there are definitely parts of the management that need changing. After Utilitarianism widely failed due to the rightful complaints of minorities the protection of smaller groups now often outweighs the needs of the many
column15: yet this protection of minorities is of the most utmost importance
column16: and should be. Consequently
column17: we need time and patience
column18: because there is no doubt that the rights of minorities need to be protected. All this is directly related to the management of constructed institutions. In my experience
column19: we need to be open and clear in our communication
column20: yet always consider why certain people in the administration enforce specific rules
column21: and how this helps and protects people.

column1: Leuphana University is a tremendous place
column2: I think. We have some truly inspiring research happening
column3: and it is among the duties of the dean to aid the creation of a coherent and bold research narrative. This is really fun
column4: since it is a true team effort. There are so many inspiring and fascinating researchers at our Faculty and university and beyond
column5: and it is very nice to be one of the central hubs in this structure. I surely still have my own interests and research (I hope)
column6: but creating ties between an array of people is challenging yet fun. What I think is even more fascinating is the mode we can have as a dynamic and thriving Faculty. Whenever a new research call comes in
column7: we are prepared
column8: and as a team can consider the best options to approach a potential project. In addition
column9: we build on a tremendous experience from the wider University
column10: especially from the leaders of the University.

column1: Having an overview concerning the research happening at the Faculty is essential in order to tell the story of the Faculty. This is a tremendous challenge in a Faculty of Sustainability
column2: where you have many diverse backgrounds focussing on different aspects of research. While this is on the one hand a challenge
column3: it is naturally also an opportunity. Research collaboration in such a diverse place needs to build on a higher level of integration as well as trust. At the Faculty level
column4: broad coherence is the biggest obstacle. You need a coherent recognition in terms of research in order to work in a joined direction. Much good if not excellent research is built on joined experience
column5: which is basically researchers collaborating together and learning from each other. This is a bigger struggle if the backgrounds are more diverse. What is more
column6: having different goals is a huge barrier. Imagine someone is strongly focused on English peer-reviewed publications
column7: while another researcher only publishes books? How can these two collaborate
column8: do they write both
column9: or each their individual publications? Working towards joined goals is one of the biggest obstacles to gain coherence. In an interdisciplinary setting
column10: and with a transdisciplinary ambition
column11: the trade-offs can be huge
column12: hence it is best to have an early joined reflection on the goals within a research project. What is more
column13: in my experience it is best to work within larger collaborative research projects
column14: because this gives you a good level of experience on where the other people are standing.

column1: The reason why I started at Leuphana
column2: to begin with
column3: was that a position with teaching seemed more attractive as compared to a pure research position. Still
column4: teaching seems somewhat to play a smaller role in today’s academia. I think this is wrong
column5: and as the dean I can often add to the discussion and strategic planning of the teaching program. Just as with research
column6: we have a great portfolio of people
column7: and designing and improving such cutting-edge programs (no kidding) as ours is surely fun. Also
column8: the exchange with the student representatives as a dean is a real pleasure
column9: as you get great feedback that you can implement. Most importantly
column10: sustainability is a surely dynamic field
