column2: as no one can always avoid being corrupt. What does it mean to me to be corrupt? I think whenever you misuse your power to gain a benefit for yourself or someone else close to you
column3: you are corrupt. Consequently
column4: no one would claim to be corrupt. All people would argue that they only had the best intentions
column5: or were even true altruists. Following this thought
column6: can we truly judge whether we have been corrupt? I think not
column7: at least not if we are personally involved in the matter. Others need to be the judge
column8: and these people need to be independent and as objective as possible. In a world that is interdependent
column9: this is hard to achieve. However
column10: I think this is what we have governance systems for
column11: and there need to be institutions within these systems that can judge whether a certain act or decision might be seen as corrupt. Still
column12: it does not end there. If corruption is the benefit certain people claim
column13: then corruption is also about the negative and biased effects one can have on other people. I think that in any case of doubt a potential bias needs to be checked. I dare say that I have been observing corruption in the past
column14: and often it is a quite slippery slope. I grew up with it
column15: hence I know it when I see it. This is why I often insist on checking whether actions are corrupt or not. Still
column16: I also know that some people consider some of my actions to be corrupt
column17: though I dare say these are not many. I am aware that people sometimes perceive reality in this way
column18: also since we all may have different perceptions of reality. Often
column19: this different perception is rooted in a lack of information
column20: which is typical in hierarchical systems
column21: and communication may resolve the issue. Nevertheless
column22: in rare cases opinions can differ. I think on these occasions it can be hard to convince people of my perception of reality. It may not work
column23: and may not be possible. Sometimes
column24: when people think you act wrong
column25: it is very hard to make them understand that you act right. In these cases
column26: I think it is best to try to continue to act right
column27: or at least not corrupted. Long term
column28: the person might reconsider
column29: and only time will tell whether some truths may be reflected in a different light in the future.

column1: '''2022 revisit:''' Power corrupts. This insight should be the guiding principle for anyone holding an office. There is no way how the human mind cannot be compromised by power because it is this taking of the office that leads to one's own mind being corrupted. This corruption can only be broken by knowing that there is this corruption on the one end
column2: and by everybody else having full trust in their elected leaders. However
column3: such philosopher-kings are not only a rare breed but also more of a ghost of the past than something we should thrive for. Still
column4: I have the greatest respect for all leaders in this world
column5: because their critics may never know how lonely the office can make a person. Yet these are all lofty goals
column6: and the reality is often worse. Many people try to compromise the integrity of the system
column7: as they are corrupt themselves
column8: and try to bribe or otherwise compromise elected leaders. This is a bad action indeed
column9: and a direct attack on the whole system. Some people do this for their own good
column10: some for their respective group of people
column11: yet I believe all these are deceived. Again
column12: no one gets up and decides to act in an evil way. Just as only everybody can liberate themselves
column13: people also corrupt themselves. A dean or any other leader needs to be aware of that
column14: and make these misdeeds transparent. After all
column15: this is the only way to face a wrong action
column16: by making the actor aware of your perception
column17: thereby rejecting it. Even if these people then disagree with you
column18: you may have to move on. Just as I mentioned before
column19: I still believe that often you cannot convince people that you believe that your action is right
column20: and that they are wrong. This is perfectly alright. We cannot convince everybody of everything
column21: and this is again a hard lesson learned for me. Some people seem to have no other goal than to corrupt the system
column22: and they do this proudly. While we may never understand why these people do that
column23: they often have a regrettable existence
column24: because these are the most lonely ones. They cannot even fall back on power
column25: because the only power they have is to question the power of others
column26: yet everybody else may become increasingly annoyed by this. If we continue to ridicule ourselves by these power games
column27: we will continue to be wasteful and not worthy of understanding each other. Therefore leaders sometimes need to lead the way
column28: yet not all may follow. Systems are often governed by majorities
column29: and not by everybody agreeing. While this is a trivial detail of democracy
column30: it is still a lesson learned. Making sure that all voices are heard is the most important conduct one has to safeguard.

column1: '''The dean is a representative of the Faculty. The dean is glad to represent the Faculty
column2: however
column3: due to his role being focussed on a wide array of tasks please realise that the dean cannot stay for longer time stretches at all events where he is representing the Faculty. The dean often has to leave for other tasks.'''

column1: It is a large honour to represent the Faculty as a dean. While honour is hard to quantify
column2: I am constantly aware that currently
column3: I am there for the Faculty
column4: whenever a face
column5: a speech or a welcoming is needed. Knowing as much as possible about the Faculty's facts
column6: all the while having these lined up in a nice canvas of stories and anecdotes is essential to connect to others and explain the Faculty to them. In my case
column7: I am very glad that this honour is shared among other people
column8: hence I am currently focussing on representing the Faculty within Leuphana. Representing the Faculty has to be balanced
column9: for at least two reasons. First
column10: there is a high number of requests
column11: asking for you - or better the Faculty- to be represented somewhere. Here one needs to focus
column12: and only attend the ones which are most necessary and helpful to a high number of people. While the dean can welcome or integrate people or give a larger perspective
column13: the dean certainly has also time constraints and cannot participate in time-intense activities that are relevant to a smaller circle of people. Where to draw this line
column14: you ask? I do not know. This is the time when you can give the position your very own tone and style. I try to walk the fine line between diversity and utility. The second reason why representing the Faculty can get out of hand is the ego. It is not about you
column15: it is about the office and the Faculty. When representing one should as much as possible step out of your own ego
column16: since power enables
column17: but also corrupts. This is again the point to realise how much power people associate with the office. However
column18: I think this has next to nothing to do with me as a person. Another thing that is worth noticing is that some occasions are closer to my interest than others. Here
column19: one should remember the bigger picture in balancing the Faculty. I sometimes wonder whether all time representing is well spent
column20: even when I know I have to be there. On some occasions
column21: the dean is a bit like a Jack-in-the-box
column22: being put somewhere to represent. Still
column23: I think that this is not only a necessity in constructed institutions but an honour. By now I enjoy these occasions
column24: as there is always something to be learnt. When being a dean
column25: you have to be the Jack-in-the-box you want to see in the world and make this role come to life. Evolve your style
column26: and try to become good at it. The constructed function of the dean demands you to serve in this role.

column1: '''2022 revisit:''' Many people consider representational work to be a charade
column2: yet we should remember it is an honour. A dean represents the whole faculty
column3: which is quite a burden
column4: but also a great responsibility. This highlights once more the importance to have a code of conduct and be transparent about it. In addition
column5: you need to be able to integrate the diverse aspects of the different people in the Faculty and use the most suitable information at the respective moment. Often this is closely associated to diplomacy
column6: because you need to anticipate your audience. To this end
column7: it is vital to find your own voice and to generate a bag of narratives that you can use at the respective appropriate time. This is almost like a small repertoire of magic tricks that you need to rehearse and practise. Me
column8: I build several narratives that worked over time
column9: and thus you can adapt more and more to the context of any given situation. Still
column10: while much can be improvised
column11: preparation is key. Ideally
column12: you pre-prepare a short script which you then if possible adapt to the atmosphere of the room shortly before your presentation. I always tune into the room and try to feel the vibes
column13: but also to build on information that was shared before. What I still consider to be most important is to make all representation work about the office
column14: and not about your own interests. All professors can surely talk a lot about their own focus
column15: but the challenge in representing the Faculty is to be impartial in your work. While this is a great idea in theory and in practice probably impossible
column16: I believe still one needs to thrive for it. Nothing devalues an office more than the respective leader misusing their power for their own good. However
column17: this principle can also be trouble in the other direction. Very often when you need to represent the Faculty as a dean
column18: many people assume that after a welcome speech you can just stay for the whole day because everything is so exciting and interesting. This is indeed a very naive assumption
column19: since the daily schedule of a dean may hold well more than a dozen appointments and schedules meetings. During peak times
column20: this may easily double
column21: plus additional phone calls and constant chat communication. Hence it is best to make clear from the beginning that you are glad to represent the Faculty
column22: yet then have to leave for other duties. Some people may still be baffled
column23: but most people appreciate clear communication. Always remember what an honour it is to meet so many people who are interested in the Faculty.

column1: ==The Dean is a hub of information==

'''The dean is a hub of information.  Please bring everything you consider relevant for the Faculty to my attention. The dean will try and communicate information to the necessary people in order to approximate solutions.'''
I think that while knowing builds understanding
column2: ignorance may breed suffering. Therefore
column3: it is the role of the dean to bring information together to understand the Faculty best
column4: and to explain the Faculty and all his decisions to others. Many people now wonder what best can actually mean. I think we can try to have the best knowledge at any given point in time
column5: to base our decisions on. Things change
column6: this is trivial. However
column7: at some point in time
column8: we should try to get all relevant information together. This is especially important to help others understand. In my experience
column9: this is sadly not always possible. This wealth of information is needed to take especially controversial decisions. All people are biased by their own view of things. As the dean -hence as a head of a constructed institution- it is important to try to have a view on the diversity of opinions
column10: and then look at all the checks and balances. However if people would know all the diversity of opinions and information about the Faculty
column11: I think most decisions would neither be bold nor controversial. I like to think that most are mere path dependencies intermingled with innovations. And this is what I mean by best. All the diversity of information is often leading to several pathways
column12: one of which is best. Many people criticise this best
column13: but I am a true believer in Occam‘s razor (surprise!). However
column14: within a constructed society
column15: some information is also confidential. These secrets are necessary -often for legal reasons- or also since some people trust the dean with information they do not want to share with everybody. While I think that the smallest part of information I receive is confidential
column16: it is very important to me that this information is a well-kept secret that can still be influential in my decisions. Funnily
column17: many people also share confidential information with me that they also share with many others. While I still guard this information
column18: it is amusing to hear confidential hush-hush information from many different sources. Anyway. If you want to understand something about the Faculty that is not confidential
column19: I say ask the dean. He might know
column20: or is glad to hear what he does not know
column21: and will make efforts to improve his knowledge. Thank you for your contribution!

column1: '''2022 revisit:''' The stream of information you need to integrate as a dean can be at times overwhelming
column2: yet I can clearly say that integrating all the diverse information was one of the greatest learning points for me personally. The key about information as a dean is indeed diversity. There are many different forms of information. Some important
column3: some maybe less so. Some very confidential
column4: some best spread widely. Yet most important
column5: there is a strong information monopole
column6: where much information arrives at the dean
column7: but also much more information needs to find its way back to the Faculty. Explaining is a key trade as a dean
column8: and often people want to somewhat connect the dots themselves. Hence spreading information while allowing people to gain deeper insights into the connection of information is a key goal for a dean
column9: I think. Perfecting patience is a virtue not to be taken lightly
column10: because once you start to see patterns much information can be indeed anticipated. Warning people about immanent problems might feel difficult if all people believe that your assessment is wrong. This is yet another point concerning information
column11: I feel the office is served best once you reached a stage where not a lot of information is able to surprise you. This was for me a certain feeling of safety
column12: because this was when I understood how reliable the system actually is. It works mostly like a clock
column13: with clear precision and mechanism that can indeed be understood. The last point I would like to share when it comes to information is confidentiality. Never break a vow of confidentiality unless the information is spread from somewhere else. What was given to you in confidence stays in confidence. Only if the information starts dripping through other channels
column14: you can start spreading the information elsewhere. To this end
column15: it is however highly relevant that within the team of the deans office
column16: even such information needs to be shared if preparations need to be done to deal with changes. I had a very good experience with the team being well able to deal with different levels of confidentiality. Alas
column17: information travels fast in any constructed institution. Usually one does not need to worry about this
column18: because it seems that spreading confidential information is a key human trait. Still
column19: within our deans team we were always very clear and explicit about which information stays within our meetings
column20: and which can travel far and wide. I had equally good experiences with the presidential floor and other people of power in our institution. Outsiders often assume backroom agendas and restriction of information as a means of power
column21: yet I can say with confidence that this is hardly ever a fact of reality. Instead
column22: I believe that all leaders I know are confident where it is needed
column23: yet open-minded and willing to share information if this is helpful. I am indeed impressed by how well the spread of information works at our institution.

column1: ==How to feel about being the dean==
'''I am grateful to be the dean.'''

column2: how glad I am to be the dean. Being the dean is the greatest honour of my work life. To me
column3: the position is not about power
column4: but about trust. The Faculty trusts me to do my work best. I am so happy for this trust
column5: as it brings me to the current setting closest to my main goal in life
column6: which is helping others. Being responsible for 1000 students
column7: some 150 Faculty staff
column8: some 140 PhDs and our about 28 professors -right now- is fantastic. Being the dean to me basically means opening a box of duct tape every morning and start wrapping duct tape around problems. In the evening the box is empty
column9: and there is a box for the next day already waiting. Duct tape is very versatile
column10: you see. The first Moon lander was mainly built out of duct tape. Duct tape holds things together
column11: blocks leaks
column12: seals surfaces
column13: it can soundproof
column14: it is fantastic stuff. WD40 helps as well. And a hammer comes in handy at times. Every day the office holds something new
column15: this is what I learned early on. Indeed
column16: this office is the best learning opportunity ever. This is also due to the splendid team in the deans office
column17: who catch problems to solve them really swiftly. These people are a constant influx of the most versatile solutions and approaches
column18: that they never cease to amaze me
column19: what a great team! Hence the core of the office for me is not about giving
column20: it is instead a non-stopping flow of learning opportunities. In private life the greatest honour to me was becoming and being the father of my children
column21: as I also learn so much from them. But as a dean the learning is -almost- equally amazing. However
column22: with the office as a dean there are many constructed roles and traditional expectations. It is so great to learn these
column23: and at times to change these. The role of the dean in general needs to shift from a role of power to a role of trust
column24: I think. I saw many deans -also at Leuphana- being on this very same track. Being a dean you are the head of a completely constructed institution
column25: an institution that is made by people. Hence I see the position as an opportunity to change the institution of the dean
column26: and also to change the institution per se through this. This is the most wonderful thing about this office - it is all about driving change. I am so glad to be the dean. I thank you so much for this opportunity!

column1: '''2022 revisit:''' Being the dean was the greatest honour of my life
column2: with the only exception of being the father of my children. The learning experience of being the dean can not be overstated. I learned so much about institutions
column3: other people
column4: but first and foremost about myself. I was glad to serve the Faculty and the University. Staying calm under stress is one of the biggest lessons learned out of the office
column5: and a lesson indeed learned several times through failure. I count five occasions. Learning to act under pressure and to remain calm in front of violence is yet another key take-home message. Integrating diversity and thriving to minimise injustices coherently is yet another challenge. While I cannot claim that I did not fail regularly considering all these deeds
column6: I would have never thought that my thinking on these terms would have gotten ever that far
column7: and hopefully also some of my actions. Yet the best thing was working in a team
column8: with my fellow deans
column9: the whole dean team
column10: the presidential floor
column11: and basically the whole university
column12: and beyond. I believe that often I was trusted
column13: but more importantly
column14: I trusted other people. This is the greatest achievement one can have in any constructed institution
column15: and I will always look back at my six years as a dean with the fondness of being trusted
column16: and having trusted other people.

'''In short:''' This entry provides tips on how to read an empirical
column2: scientific paper.
reading scientific papers is a matter of practice'''. When I started reading scientific papers
column3: it took me hours to get through one paper
column4: and I can very safely assume from my perspective today that I understood next to nothing back then. In between 'beginning to engage with science' and the position I find myself in today
column5: there is a long but continuous journey of learning and gaining experience. I cannot tell you exactly how to learn to read scientific papers
column6: but here are some suggestions that may help you in the beginning. These tips focus on empirical papers - for conceptual papers however
column7: much is similar
column8: and you will realize the differences as you read more papers of all kinds.

column1: 1) '''Read the abstract first.''' The abstract is a systematic from to condense information
column2: and what the authors feel is most important. Therfore
column3: grasping the abstract should reveal what the paper is all about. Reading the abstract twice can be a good first step to learn what is interesting about the paper.

column2: it leads to the research questions or hypotheses. However
column3: it often contains deep knowledge that is not necessary to understand the bigger picture. Also
column4: do not go down the rabbit hole of following the referenced literature for now - you may come back to it when you've gotten the bigger picture. First
column5: take it step by step.

column1: 3) '''Do not try to understand every word.''' In the beginning
column2: much is overwhelming
column3: because much is new. Try to hold on to what you understand. Each discipline has its own words
column4: and sometimes different words even mean the same in different scientific cultures. Over time you will learn more of these big words
column5: and what begins as a puzzle will form a picture.

column1: 4) '''Note down the main points''' that the paper is focussing on. Many papers are well structured
column2: and you can easily trace down the structure throughout the text. Your notes will reveal the methodological and theoretical logic of the paper
column3: which is a good thing to come back to when you feel lost in the details.

column1: 5) '''Do not preoccupy yourself with undressing the methods''' if you have no knowledge about these methods. Peer-review should have usually safeguarded that the applied methods are OK. So if you have no knowledge about the specifics of these methods
column2: just accept that something was done
column3: and try to understand what you can.

column1: 6) '''The results are the heart of every paper.''' Read these in detail
column2: and try to write down the main points. Also
column3: be on the lookout how the authors qualify the individual results. Is a result more generalisable
column4: or rather specific?

column2: '''look for the mentioning of limitations''' of the results. Then
column3: try to see how the authors connect their specific results to the wider research picture. Lastly
column4: check whether the authors give some recommendations for future research.

column1: 8) '''Learning to read papers takes time.''' In the beginning
column2: read a lot
column3: but be patient with yourself. You may understand very little. The first 100 papers are more about familiarising yourself with the general form
column4: not the content as such. Reading papers needs to become a habit
column5: not a pain.

column1: 9) Last piece of advice: '''Make your peace before reading.''' Instead of dreading towards the time where you feel you have to have to have to read the paper
column2: just take one or two minutes
column3: breathing in
column4: and breathing out. Clear your mind
column5: to prepare it for reading
column6: just like you would stretch a bit before going running.

column2: and use peer pressure to your advantage. If you sit together and read
column3: and then discuss what you got from the paper
column4: then you can learn to understand how other people read papers
column5: which can be quite a beneficial skill. Learn together
column6: and nudge  yourselves through the papers. You can do it.

The following entry shall guide you through the process of writing your Bachelor's or Master's thesis - or any bigger research endeavour
column2: really. Reading it takes some time
column3: but so does writing your thesis
column4: right?

column2: a thesis is the largest piece of work they ever created in their life
column3: although there can be exceptions. '''Writing your thesis can be stressful
column4: ''' which is why it is helpful to start with a clear orientation phase that allows you to plan your timeline
column5: get the right tools
column6: align topic
column7: method and theory and - last but not least - get your work mode in order. I would argue that the last point is the most important one. From my perspective
column8: I want people to write a thesis to learn to structure themselves and overcome all barriers to create a contribution to the scientific community and ideally to society as well. In the broader context
column9: the latter parts are very important to most students. Yet
column10: as a teacher
column11: I should highlight that from a purely educational perspective
column12: the goal to catalystically learn to structure yourself and create such a thesis is more important than the content itself. As a researcher
column13: I can however clearly state that it is not only very desirable
column14: but also rewarding if a thesis contributes to the wider development of science
column15: if only as a small contribution. Being a sustainability scientist
column16: I would like to say that it is our privilege to study
column17: and hence we should see it as our responsibility to contribute to society as well.

column1: Here are some concrete steps that may help you to orientate yourself in order to start with your thesis:

column2: theories and/or methods are you interested in? Which courses got you motivated to engage deeply with something
column3: triggered a lasting motivation and interest
column4: and enabled you to become versatile within this branch of science? The best starting point to me is to go through your past academic life
column5: and see which parts thrilled you or kept resonating in your head. If you ask me
column6: it is not a particularly good idea to search for something that is not tangible within the setting and environment you are in. If you want to make a topic because you feel that this particular topic was never touched upon in your study program
column7: you may have difficulty finding a supervisor. I think it is equally a challenge to work on something where next to no references exists. Do not misunderstand me: I think it is good to look for engaging and energising topics
column8: ideally linked to creating an impact beyond science. Even very specific cases or settings that are white spots on the landscape of science can be looked upon in a specific sense or be approached in a specific mode
column9: may it be as a [[Glossary|transdisciplinary]] approach
column10: a case study setting
column11: or through the testing of a specific theory. If however your peers and potential supervisors do not seem to resonate with this specific topic you are so eager to engage with
column12: maybe you could find something else? Remember that no human is an island
column13: and science depends on peer exchange
column14: and may benefit from a supervisor who is able to give you feedback. I suggest
column15: you do not work on a topic that you literally work on completely alone.

column1: [[File:Obi-wan-qui-gon-padawan.jpg||thumb|right|'''Many people have wrong assumptions about their supervisors''' Source: [https://www.starwars.com/news/what-is-a-padawan]]]
Can you identify a specific gap in knowledge or contribution to existing research that resonated with you
column2: and made you return to it again and again? Who from the faculty raised this to you
column3: or may supervise it? Since not everybody can come up with a topic by themselves
column4: maybe a suggestion of a potential supervisor might help. The more structured you approach your potential supervisor with your request
column5: the happier they will be to help
column6: at least in my experience. People are often inspired by projects that potential supervisors conduct
column7: and would like to integrate their thesis into the large project. To this end
column8: I would give some cautionary and sobering advise: Most projects that exist are already underway
column9: and most of the time a thesis is an add-on
column10: and not exactly a pivotal part of the project. This should not be a reason to feel that the work is irrelevant. More often than not additional questions arise through your contribution to a project. Yet
column11: you might need to acknowledge that the project was designed a long time ago by someone who probably was not you. Hence the demand in such a project is often quite precise and the questions are already rather specific
column12: and I would suggest that you are clear about what is expected from you. However
column13: this may be a good opportunity to be under the wing of a PhD or somebody else in the project
column14: and get a closer interaction that you would get with most supervisors.

column1: Take stock of your previous work. Which setting worked best
column2: where were you stuck? Analyse your past work systematically in order to make an informed decision to commit to a specific approach in this phase in your life. Try to understand which parts of these great things stuck with you. Sometimes it was not the topic at all
column3: but the way it was discussed in the group. Try to analyse what specific part resonated with you. Make a mind map of the different components you see in past parts of science that resonated with you. Also
column4: these days many people are guided by joy. I think overall
column5: this is a good thing. However
column6: we have to acknowledge that in science not everything is always joyful. While I enjoy writing these lines
column7: writing my own thesis was certainly not joyful all the time. I think this is important to remember
column8: since I would question whether we really want to maximise our joy
column9: or whether we want to balance it. This is for each and every single one of us to decide.

column2: how do you need to adapt your life to enable a committed focus to a thesis? We are talking about hundreds of hours of your life
column3: and you may need to harmonise this with other interests and duties in your life. The head of the lab where I did my PhD always said how nice it is to focus only on one thing
column4: i.e. your thesis. While from her perspective I think this is very true
column5: this singular focus is often also a curse
column6: as you may get stuck. This is why I think her remark was so clever. Design your life that your thesis is in focus
column7: but you also have enough distraction in order to stay continuously motivated. This may include getting a desk
column8: or a committed workspace that was previously unnecessary. I never had a desk at home
column9: but the COVID-19 crisis changed that. I sit on this desk right now
column10: writing these lines. My first mentor had the slogan: ''„If a cluttered desk represents a cluttered head
column11: what does an empty desk represent”'' written on the side of his desk. His place was a mess
column12: but it was his mess
column13: and he thrived in it. Design your space how you can work best.

column1: Assemble a team. How did previous students orientate themselves? Ask around in your peer-group
column2: and start to engage early with people who write their thesis. The insights and experience that they already have may allow you to orientate yourself on a different level later. You need to find people that are either complementary to or aligned with your work style and ethics. This is the most important point since you need to exchange with peers on a very regular basis. This is not so much about the goals
column3: but more about the way. Peers can become an important reflexive space
column4: with more time than your supervisors
column5: and more knowledge of your specific needs. In addition
column6: your peers can help you to think out loud on the progressive track that you are ideally on and give you emotional support. This is what friends are for. Most people we know as scientific geniuses were embedded into a larger group
column7: and exchanged frequently and regularly with their peers. Peers often share a similar set of goals (i.e. writing a thesis)
column8: and also a comparable rhythm.

column1: This is the time when you use the broader topical aim that you have

column1: ==== Create an outline that you get critiqued ====

A German proverb reads ""''Paper is patient''"". Writing what you want to do is hence vastly different from telling someone what you want to do. While talking you can adapt to the reactions of the other person
column2: but writings need to be clear
column3: concise and consistent. Therefore
column4: writing an outline is one of the most pivotal steps of any emerging research. Experienced researchers may take a shortcut after they wrote dozens of papers
column5: but I think that anyone with less experience under their belt should start with an outline. This also has the benefit that you can approach your peers or people you trust to give you honest [[Giving Feedback|feedback]]. When writing an outline
column6: I build on a blueprint that I have used in years. Many people used it before
column7: and it has proven valuable over time. '''You can find this blueprint here:''' [[File:Outline blueprint - Henrik von Wehrden.pdf|thumb|This is Henrik von Wehrden's blueprint for a scientific research outline.]]. It includes some remarks on typical pitfalls for each section.

column1: ==== Have a bin next to your desk ====
What is sadly relevant when developing your research is having a bin readily standing next to your desk. More often than not
column2: initial ideas do not translate into a definitive scientific result. Most ideas die even before they are even tested
column3: or to quote Thomas Edison: ""''I got a thousand ideas that did not work out.""'' This is truly the case in my own research as well. I create most ideas for the bin
column4: by a rough estimate I would say that one out of hundred ideas becomes my actual active research. Everything else is illogical
column5: flawed
column6: dull
column7: impossible or gets swamped away by the tides of everything else. Research is iteration
column8: and failure. This is probably the reason why many researchers I admire have a rather stoic attitude when it comes to failure - most of them failed at an uncountable rate. The question is now: Is this truth depressing? Some would certainly say yes
column9: but - and I am transcending Derek Parfit here - I think it is liberating. You just need to learn this art of iteration
column10: and not get too deeply attached to an early idea. Just like art
column11: science often thrives as an almost never-ending pursuit
column12: and learning to translate an initial idea into a clear outline is an art that you should practice. Do not feel bad because your pile of unused ideas is growing! I am often joyful when I see that someone had the same idea that landed in my bin
column13: but instead made it into something wonderful. Is it not great to know that you had great ideas
column14: and that other great people made these into a reality? It took me a while to figure this out
column15: but I think today that this is a good thing indeed if more knowledge is out there. It is nice to know that these ideas became real contributions - though from somebody else - to the scientific community and society as a whole. We are all in this together
column16: after all.

column1: [[File:How To Write A Thesis Outline.jpeg|thumb|Thesis Outline Source: www.thesishelper.com]] An outline gives an overview of what you want to do. Ideally you have an idea which theory you are building on or which conceptual approach you use
column2: which methods you want to utilise
column3: and what your thesis is all about - roughly. The design is where you want to develop all the precise details on how you want to conduct your research. This is the time when people often drown in papers and want to combine about 70 ideas and approaches from previous papers while ideally avoiding roughly 200 errors from other previous studies. Here
column4: '''the main question is what is really important for your case'''
column5: and you need to learn to ignore what could be ''potentially'' important for your case. Remember the tree in the forest that no one is there to hear? This is the time when you should not hear this tree falling when you are not there. This is the tree right now. Can you hear it? No? Then move on!

column2: and in research it is almost essential to do prototyping whenever possible. Whether it is checking if interview questions work
column3: make a test run of a workshop to see if the time would be well-balanced

column5: or even better parts of it

column8: trying different settings and check how you make progress. Your peers are the ideal reflexive space to test your prototype. Team up early with people that share a similar interest and work ethic
column9: and exchange about each others' theses. You may find that their thesis is a welcoming distraction from your thesis

column1: Theory and the conceptual basis of the thesis are often the maelstrom that drags people down into limbo. The first and foremost rookie mistake I observe frequently - and that I made myself - is to try to combine too many concepts in one thesis. Working on ecosystem services
column2: focusing on biodiversity
column3: building on resilience while focusing on climate change adaptation? This is not going to work. Ideally
column4: you build on one concept
column5: [[Glossary|framework]] of theory. You may work on two
column6: but then one of the two needs to be super concrete to tackle the other rather vague. I know how happy you are about all the deeper insights you gained over the last years concerning all sorts of concepts
column7: and I know that our safe haven or bubble of sustainability science is only emerging
column8: and hence tinkering with quite many concepts. In much of current research
column9: theory plays a central role. There are approaches such as data science that explicitly do not focus on theory but instead on data
column10: and this showcases that we live in exciting times. Still
column11: I advise you to be rather conservative in your conceptual design
column12: and to not bring yourself into a theoretical orbit from which you will never make it down to the ground on mother earth. After all
column13: we should not forget that theory is helpful to construct a specific model of the world. Models are defined by compromises and imperfections
column14: and we sometimes tend to forget this if we are all exited in the midst of it.

column1: Another word to all of you who consider to write a conceptual work. From my specific perspective I would say: Don't! Do not write a conceptual work. While it may be exiting and some consider it feels very scientific to write a conceptual work
column2: you need to be sure that your education and your personality allows you to do this. If you are a philosopher
column3: or come from the wider circle of this hemisphere
column4: then your education may be the foundation for a conceptual work. If you then also feel that in the past you were able to conceptualise complicated thoughts into an analytical and coherent line of thinking
column5: fine. But do not underestimate the slumber you can basically build for yourself if you get entrenched in often century old debates about this theory or that concept. Many people in the past thought a conceptual work is easy
column6: and learned the hard way that this is not true. Also
column7: do not underestimate the experience of a solid empirical contribution. This may be your first scientific paper
column8: if only in a smaller journal - it can be a start. Your results may matter deeply to a specific case
column9: and thus contribute to bridge the gap between science and society. Last but not least
column10: I have the hypothesis that empirical work trains you to see the world through the specific sense of your work: a precise focus
column11: a defined perspective
column12: a compromise in your field of view. The experience of empirical work should not be underestimated
column13: as it can teach you how to look at something through a specific theory or conceptual framework.

column1: I often prototype my sampling designs in [[Lego Serious Play|Lego]]

Thinking things through with the haptic power of Lego always helps me to visualise the bigger picture and allow for interactions with iterations I attempt when revising the methodological design. A more conventional approach to visualise and iterate a sample design is a whiteboard. I urge you to get a whiteboard by all means

Remember that each of these papers has a history and a context. Do not be fooled by the assumption that all this is hyper-objective and super-reproducible. Recent trends in research advice us to be careful to this end

column1: I am truly fascinated by the context
column2: setting and design in which famous people worked. Albert Einstein managed to pull off his best work as a patent officer. Maryam Mirzakhani's impact was short but stellar in so many ways. Franz Kafka wrote while working in the insurance business. In comparison

column7: I just flapped my computer open. Now I learned that having a desk at home can be helpful in times of Covid 19. However
column8: sometimes I change the setting

do not work into the night no matter how cool you feel (no

* ''[[Research Diary|Journal]] and/or write on paper''. Or better

you should start to develop a narrative. If your research is very hypothesis-driven

column2: and on your supervisor only when necessary ====

column1: There is an almost general misconception of the role of a supervisor. Supervisors could make all the research you do probably in a blink of an eye. Any problem you might want to solve
column2: they could solve
column3: and much faster. If they would do that

column5: and yes
column6: they are called supervisors. To me

column9: I think

column11: albeit for your peers. Building tolerance

Most people look at the thesis a day after they printed it

column1: The best way to prepare for a defense is to cumbersome '''anticipate which open questions arise from your work'''
column2: especially from the view of your supervisors. You typically need to give a short and concise summary of your work
column3: focusing on the more interesting aspects
column4: but also giving the necessary overview. Many consider the 10-15 minutes you have to be not enough. I understand this
column5: but then again consider that most Ted talks are equally long (or short). Be brief and to the point. Also
column6: prepare lots of additional slides that anticipate potential questions
column7: and master your repertoire. Many people feel that practicing the presentation too often feels kind of dull
column8: but do not worry: The adrenaline during the real thing will up your pulse
column9: and ideally also up your game.

column1: You need to be to the point. Do not have too many slides. No text deserts. Self explanatory figures. Do not talk too fast. Try to look at your audience. Get the essence of your work
column2: but also be critical. You need to present the main results and discuss these. There is so much things to consider. The most important one: Find your own voice. Try to get inspired by others
column3: and tinker with the way you present things. This ideally leads you to developing your own genuine presentation mode
column4: which should be your best in this situation.

column1: Many supervisors have a lot of questions
column2: hence you should be prepared. Always think for a second before you answer
column3: or best while the question you are being asked is elaborated on. There are many rhetorical tricks how to answer. The most common mistake is that people answer too long and build in too many caveats. Be brief
column4: but to the point. Also be positive
column5: and ideally energized. People should feel that you are confident
column6: which you can be
column7: but not arrogant. Most importantly
column8: do not be thrown off balance by a super hard question. Many supervisors push the limit
column9: including me. You need to stand by your work
column10: but also see its limitations. There is a difference between these two things. Understanding this is at the heart of the academic agenda
column11: and often also a good defense.

column1: Supervisors may differ in grading but are typically at least internally consistent. Hence
column2: I would suggest to be confident that the grade you get is the one you deserve. I had counterexamples as a student
column3: but even then
column4: I could not do anything about it. Hence
column5: I advise you to accept the grade you get. More often than not
column6: you deserve it
column7: and hopefully can be glad about it. Celebrate it.

column1: I often witness peers throwing a small party after the defense right in front of my office. Such testimony of friendship is very moving
column2: yet the person being celebrated often looks shell-shocked
column3: even with the best grades. Quite often they do not feel like celebrating. Yet I think
column4: having such a small party is not only a nice academic tradition
column5: but also demarks a good starting point to move on.

column1: I would also encourage you to celebrate at graduation day
column2: as this is an important academic tradition
column3: and as a professor I have to say that it is quite an honor to meet the parents of the students that often grew so dear to my heart. I think having this exchange is an important commitment and opportunity for both sides
column4: as these brief encounters seal the trust that could hopefully be built between parents and the teachers through their children. I owe so much to my parents and my academic teachers and think that a meeting of them really ended my PhD officially. The students are often slightly ashamed by what is being said
column5: which is quite entertaining
column6: I have to say. Endure it
column7: these will become nice memories
column8: I hope
column9: and an important steppingstone in your coming-of-age.

column1: What is most relevant is to '''look back at that experience and take stock'''. If you are done with your thesis
column2: then you should not only celebrate with the outside world. Be cheerful
column3: you made something remarkable for yourself
column4: and contributed if only a wee bit to something so much larger. Personally
column5: I remember how long ago I finished my Diploma thesis
column6: and how many helped me along the way. Looking back at it
column7: it seems like a small step now
column8: but it was a big step then. As my supervisor said when I had my thesis handed in: “''A small step for you
column9: but a big step for [hu]mankind''.”

column2: Iconology works as a three-step model through which different questions are formulated and the according insights are put together subsequently in a complex manner (10). The three steps are: the pre-iconographic step
column3: the step of interpretation (or iconography) and the iconological synthesis (10). Panofsky advised to not consider the steps as absolutely separated
column4: because the verbal articulation of the artwork can only really be usefully read in its complete meaning after the analysis and interpretation (7).

column7: because it can situate the analysis historically and culturally and lead to fruitful insights for the analysis itself and for foreign or future audiences.

It is important to not only state why a feeling about the artwork occurs but to make assumptions about why this feeling occurs. Contemporary iconological analysis also often refers to assumptions made about how one’s own culture and generation might react to the object. It is very important to state that any universalizing claim is clearly formulated as an assumption or probability (10).

column1: The iconographic turn is an attempt of some postmodern thinkers to redefine the way in which images are understood (2). Other than Panofsky’s approach

column2: there is the issue that Iconology often leads to different and even opposing findings than other art research methods of which Iconology is always the more traditional approach (3). One prominent attempt to widen Panofsky’s method was William Mitchells “aim […] to further generalize the interpretive ambitions of Iconology by asking it to consider the idea of the image as such” (5). He thus asked two key questions: ""What is an image?"" and ""What is the difference between images and word?” (1). He continues by defining an image generally as a thing that represents objects in the world with a certain “likeness”

=== How to find the right Interview method ===
You may have decided that you want to ask people things for your research
column2: but you don't quite know which approach to choose.
and we decided that in the end
column3: it comes down to two things:'''

column1: * ''Do you want qualitative or quantitative insights?''
** Qualitative means that you plan to go into depth with fewer individuals
column2: and understand their worldviews. Qualiltative Interviews lead to results that are hard to compare
column3: but can be of great help when a topic shall be openly and inductively investigated.

column1: ** Quantitative means that you are interested in larger numbers of responses which you can calculate with
column2: or in gathering quantitative responses right away
column3: e.g. on a Likert Scale. Quantitative Interviews typically lead to more comparable results
column4: and are often useful for more deductive approaches when your theoretical assumptions are clear.

column1: * ''Do you want interactive or non-interactive Interviews?''
** Interactive means that you maintain control over the Interview conduction
column2: with pre-determined questions and a strong impact on the questions that individuals respond to.

column1: ** Non-interactive means that you rather observe and listen. You have some things you are interested in
column2: but you also want to let the Interviewees speak freely.

column1: The easiest way to represent count information are basically '''barplots'''. They are a bit over simplistic if they contain only one level of information such as three groups and their abundance
column2: and can be more advanced if they contain two levels of information such as in stacked barplots. These can be shown as either absolute numbers or proportions
column3: which may make a dramatic difference for the analysis or interpretation.

column1: '''Correlation plots''' ('xyplots') are the next staple in statistical graphics and most often the graphical representation of a correlation. Further
column2: often also a regression is implemented to show effect strengths and variance. Fitting a [[Regression Analysis|regression]] line is often the most important visual aid to showcase the trend. Through point size or color can another information level be added
column3: making this a really powerful tool
column4: where one needs to keep a keen eye on the relation between correlation and causality. Such plots may also serve to show fluctuations in data over time
column5: showing trends within data as well as harmonic patterns.

column1: '''Boxplots''' are the last in what I would call the trinity of statistical figures. Showing the variance of continuous data across different factor levels is what these plots are made of. While histograms reveal more details and information
column2: boxplots are a solid graphical representation of the Analysis of Variance. A rule of thumb is that if one box is higher or lower than the median (the black line) of the other box
column3: the difference may be signifiant.

== Graphical etiquette – a rough guide how to make scientific quantitative figures ==
There is an almost uncountable amount of scientific figures out there. While diversity is great
column2: it can often be overwhelming to consider which graphics to do with data
column3: and which other types of figures can be beneficial. In addition
column4: there are some general norms and conventions to consider when making graphics. Let us start with these. While these are mere suggestions
column5: and reflect my own style and experience
column6: they may serve as a reflection basis for others.

column1: '''1) Only show data in a figure that contains enough information to justify a figure'''
Many barplots I have seen contain 2 values. Could these not be fit into a sub-sentence? A graphic is to this end downright trivial
column2: and wastes a lot of space. The same is also true for a piechart
column3: but even worse
column4: because it can look like a Pacman
column5: and pie-charts are just generally misleading. Hence consider how many values you want to show
column6: and if these really justify the journal space.

column1: '''2) One should not show plots that violate the statistics'''
A common example are barplots. There can be good reasons to show barplots with error bars
column2: however the majority of data is better represented by a boxplot. Boxplots show more values
column3: and are sensible for data that contains a range of integers. A typical borderline case is the [[Likert Scale]]
column4: which is often shown in boxplots. While this is not entirely wrong
column5: it is a bit strange
column6: as the scale contains five values
column7: and a boxplot is constructed of five parts at least.  Another example is the standard fitted [https://www.statisticshowto.com/lowess-smoothing/ loess line] in a ggplot. If you show non-linear statistics
column8: there should be a reason for it. Some of these trends show nothing at all
column9: and follow no assumption beside adding some graphical interest. Scientific figures are however not only about aesthetics
column10: but also about soundness and validity.

column1: '''3) Avoid empty spaces in plots. After all
column2: your graphics are no Zen garden'''
your plots should be balanced
column3: and should not contain open spaces. Try to set the x and y axes in a way that empty space is avoided. Such space could be ideal for a legend
column4: or maybe some other additional information. Often people use weird short names in the legend
column5: and then explain them in the figure caption. This should be avoided at all costs. Try to create legends that are self-explanatory. Make sure that the density of the information that is being shown is balanced
column6: at least as long as the data and analysis allows for this. If figures contain much open space you can still definitely try to make them smaller
column7: and maybe even combine several of these in a panel plot. In certain graphics such as clearcut correlations empty space is hard to avoid. This is a good indicator that maybe this figure is not needed at all
column8: but instead can be replaced by some relevant values (e.g. p-value
column9: R<sup>2</sup> ) in the text.

column2: but also non-confusing colours'''
so I am in the privileged position to judge on the diversity of colours in a plot. Actually
column3: no test ever picked up any colour blindness
column4: but I definitely have some problem there. Hence I would say that colours should be diverse
column5: and ideally brightness and hue allow also to differentiate groups. Figures become problematic if there are too many colours
column6: and I define this threshold for me at around 8. In addition
column7: consider using colours that have proven their value when combined. I can endorse weandersonpalette as a really cool package that gives you a pleasing combination of colours.

column1: '''5) Label orientation goes a long way'''
Most label orientations in most plots are wrong. Try to bring your labels -if space permit- into a horizontal orientation. quite often tables are too densely packed on the x-axis then
column2: yet you could also consider making them in a 45 ° fashion. As much as a 90 ° label orientation can offer a little stretch for the neck
column3: it is also a one-sided exercise. Hence consider flipping the labels whenever possible.

column1: '''6) Compose the figure right to its intended size'''
One of the most common mistakes in the creation of figures is the proportion of different parts of the figure. Often the axes labels are really small
column2: but the heading is massive. Ideally when designing a figure
column3: one should consider to size with which this figure should be printed. If you know that a figure is only 6x6 centimetres
column4: you need to make the labels sufficiently large and sparse to be readable
column5: and orderly. A larger figure has different proportions. Hence design your figures in the right composition interns of the different text sizes.

column2: font types are like borderline religion
column3: but still I guess we can all agree that one should only use one font in a figure. If you want to make a typesetter cry you may use one font with serifs and another one without serifs
column4: but otherwise do not do that. It can make sense to use a narrow font (iei. Arial narrow) if you do not have enough space in your figure.

column1: '''8) Occam's razor applies to scientific figures
column2: too'''
and ideally contains as much information as possible
column3: but not more. You can however also decide to make figures that contain more information
column4: and are borderline like mandalas. This is really cool if you have complex information to show for
column5: and maybe the result basically says that it's complex. Other figures may be graspable in a split second
column6: which is very cool if you want people to understand something quickly. In between is the Occam's razor sweet spot
column7: where you need a few seconds with the figure
column8: but then you kind of got it. To this send
column9: let it be known that this sweet spot is different for different people.

column2: when you have an exam coming up 😉 However
column3: most of the ideas below are generally targeted at learning
column4: be it in academic or non-academic settings.

column1: * Spend your learning time efficiently & effectively

Learning for exams is a vast field. The following can thereby only be a fraction of possible insights on the topic and is not meant to be completely exhaustive or 100% scientific. It is however largely backed by scientific evidence and the personal experience of the author. If you think anything is inaccurate or missing
column2: do feel free to contact us.

column1: The following is structured into separate paragraphs
column2: starting with a more general note on learning approaches before diving deeper into techniques which you may find helpful. Furthermore
column3: a section on what is usually '''not''' effective when learning and some general tips are included. The body of reference is meant to give you the opportunity to dive deeper into selected topics
column4: yet if you follow what is collected below
column5: you should be very much good to go.

column1: The first thing to note is that exam success hardly depends on the few weeks before the exam itself
column2: but rather on your whole semester. Starting to learn early and consistently will
column3: in the long run
column4: save you a lot of time and stress and will also improve your exam success.

column1: Part of this is having a more or less clear overview on what is going to be covered or assessed and what it is you want to learn. This should also include a clear idea on what is not interesting or too important
column2: either for yourself or the exam. Try to get an overview of topics and contents via the syllabus or ask the teacher / lecturer for it.

column1: Another part is always being more or less up to date with lectures or seminars. It doesn't take more than 30 minutes after a lecture for you to forget most of what you just heard. If at all possible
column2: take 10 to 15 minutes after each session to work with your notes
column3: reformulate them and throw them into your knowledge base (whatever that is). A good idea is also to directly transfer them to a flashcard tool such as Anki (see below).

column1: There are several learning techniques that have been scientifically proven to yield better results than what is commonly used by many students and learners. Try to stick to these as you learn!
One important concept is spaced repetition. This means that you should repeat content in increasingly longer intervals to ensure long-term retention. So
column2: concretely
column3: if you've just learned something
column4: repeat it first on the next day
column5: then after 3 days
column6: after 7 days
column7: after two weeks
column8: and so on. Repetition intervals should depend on how well you were able to remember something on a given day (e.g. when you had lots of trouble after 7 days
column9: maybe throw in another repetition 2 days later). The aforementioned overview of learning content can be combined with this
column10: i.e. you can make a table with all the content for a given course and track when you repeated which topic to help you keep an overview.

column1: Active Recall means recapitulating everything you know on a topic or question you are learning '''without checking your notes or sources'''. There is a significant learning edge to this over re-reading notes or trying to immediately fill in your gaps. Try to remember everything you know for as hard as possible until you are certain that you will not remember anything else. Only then should you check back with your notes to see if you have forgotten anything. This will then subsequently show you on which gaps you need to focus more.
Useful tools can be using MindMaps or SpiderDiagrams
column2: but also writing down bullet points
column3: full texts or talking to a friend about it. If you happen to have an interim outage of friends
column4: it is absolutely fine to talk to your chair or any other attentive listener that can't escape.

column1: Elaboration is the act of thoughtfully laying out a topic
column2: talking about associations
column3: explaining concepts
column4: drawing connections to other knowledge and in general being very verbose about answering a question or talking about a topic. This can very much be combined with active recall (i.e. not using your notes for recapitulation).

column1: Interleaving means to disperse the learning you're doing in a certain amount of time across several topics. It has been shown that this can lead to better learning outcomes than block or massed learning. As an example
column2: you might be inclined to learn one whole week for one topic
column3: another whole week for another topic and so on. Research indicates that interleaving those topics over two weeks can be more effective. Of course
column4: you should not overdo it and switch topics every thirty minutes. Try to find some balance that works for you!

column1: Probably the most important and undervalued in learning (and work in general)! '''Take. Breaks.''' A lot.
Your ability to understand and retain information will benefit from you being on top of your game
column2: and you will likely be more on top of it if you take breaks. A good rule of thumb is to take a 5 minute break every 25 minutes when learning (as that has been shown to be the average time a student can fully concentrate). Of course
column3: this will vary from person to person
column4: but do remember that people are generally pretty bad at accurately assessing their concentration level and learning effectiveness at a given point in time. If in doubt
column5: take the break.

column2: '''several shorter breaks are way more effective than fewer long breaks'''. Studying for two and a halve hours and taking a thirty minute break will typically be much worse than doing six 25/5 blocks - especially if you plan to continue after the initial three hours.
see e.g. [https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2011/02/110208131529.htm Ariga & LLeras (2011)]

column1: A really good tool for active recall and spaced repetition! A small app available for Computers
column2: Macs
column3: iPhones and Android Smartphones
column4: giving you all the things you would want from a flashcard app and having a really good spaced repetition algorithm. Alternatives can be [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leitner_system analogue flashcard boxes] or [https://quizlet.com/latest quizlet].

column1: The huge benefit of Anki is that you'll have it with you all the time. Waiting for the bus? Answer a few cards. Bored before going to sleep? Answer a few cards!
Going hand in hand with the planning section above
column2: it can be very useful to pour your learning plan into a table or worksheet
column3: e.g. in Excel or Word. Any other software such as Libre Office or Google Docs will do just as well!

column1: Try to write down the topics you have to learn in a [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MECE_principle MECE way] (mutually exclusive
column2: collectively exhaustive) so you have everything neatly in front of you. You can now
column3: at every point in time
column4: write down an assessment of your perceived learning strength per topic
column5: keep an overview of when you learned which topic last or when you'll learn it next (see ""Spaced Repetition"" above) and so on. If you're lucky
column6: your lecturer will provide you with something that you can use as a solid base for this - asking for it also doesn't hurt!

column1: All of this can of course also be done on paper or in a notebook - it might just get messy if you're not very disciplined.

column2: but can also be largely ineffective. If you gather 5 people who know next to nothing about a topic
column3: there is very little chance you'll create insight from nothing just by being together. Try to have a clear idea on what you want out of your group work and assign or rotate roles accordingly. One idea is to
column4: each week
column5: have one person in the group explain a recent topic to everyone else (see also ""Elaboration"" and ""Active Recall""). You can also have sessions within which one person tries to actively recall and elaborate on a topic
column6: and the other(s) ask questions regarding gaps they might be seeing or remark inaccuracies. This combines active recall
column7: elaboration and having an incredible amount of fun together! 🥳

column1: It can be a good idea to make use of your environment. Build in cues into your rooms
column2: have different stations for different topics
column3: and so on. Maybe hang a mindmap of your learning topics next to your bathroom mirror so you can recap 1 or 2 topics while brushing your teeth. Throw up sticky notes with central questions around your house.

column2: it can be very useful to have a dedicated place for your learning activities. Don't learn in your bed
column3: don't learn at your dining room table. If both happen to be the same thing
column4: try to have something around that you can alter when you start learning and switch back as you stop learning. The easiest way to do this is getting a Learning Lamp that you only turn on while learning!

column1: Smartphones can be useful for learning (see Anki)
column2: but they are also distracting. It has been shown that only keeping a smartphone in the same room without direct eye contact messes with your concentration level (cf. [https://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/abs/10.1086/691462 Ward et al.
column4: when learning
column5: shut it off and get it as far away from you as possible!

column1: There's a persistent belief that people have different learning types
column2: e.g. being a Visual
column3: Aural
column4: Read/Write or Kinesthetic (VARK) learner. As of today
column5: we know of no research that supports this thesis (cf. [https://anatomypubs.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/ase.1777 Husmann et al.
column6: 2018] / [https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27620075/ Knoll et al.
column7: 2017]). What is true however is that using multiple types of media and modes supports understanding and retention. So don't stick to only watching videos because ""you're a visual learner""
column8: but do switch it up - it's also more fun!

column1: These are several techniques that are widely used by learners that are pretty ineffective. Typically
column2: you'll want to avoid these.

column1: There's almost no learning effect when summarizing slides
column2: syllabi or textbooks while having them openly available next to you. Of course
column3: if you're doing it with Active Recall
column4: you're good to go! It might nevertheless be helpful to reformulate concepts in your own words to improve understanding.

column1: Typical study technique - next to no effect. As long as you just use it to underline/highlight important passages without recapitulating them later by memory
column2: you can stop doing this.

column1: Re-Reading is probably the opposite of active recall. Don't do it
column2: it will only make you feel as if you get things better (because you get better at recognizing the content)
column3: yet will do next to no good in terms of application and recall in exams.

column1: This goes hand in hand with taking breaks and interleaving. Don't spend massive amounts of time without taking breaks or looking into other topics every once in a while!
* [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ukLnPbIffxE Ali Abdaal - How to study for exams]: There are numerous videos and guidelines on how to study effectively. Yet
column2: Ali Abdaal has managed to narrow it down to the essentials that have scientific backing.
Study Smart]: An entertaining yet insightful overview of pitfalls and useful techniques for studying effectively.

'''Annotation''': Due to the special role of Law as a scientific discipline
column2: this entry will focus more on legal research as a whole as opposed to one specific method.

column1: '''In short:''' Legal Research subsumes different approaches to understand and interpret legal documents and/or cases.
The field of Law has a long-standing history. ""Roman legal doctrine developed since the second century before Christ
column2: and reached a very high level as from the third century after Christ. Its rediscovery and renewed study in Bologna in the eleventh century was the start for the creation of universities."" (van Hoecke 2011
column3: p.1). The emergence of Law and its eventual [[Glossary|institutionalisation]] as a scientific discipline was fundamentally based on the reading and interpretation of (Roman) legal documents (2). ""During the whole of the Middle-Ages
column4: legal doctrine was highly thought of and considered as a 'scientific discipline'
column5: as in those times 'authoritative interpretation'
column6: not 'empirical research'
column7: was the main criterion for the scientific status of a discipline."" (van Hoecke 2011
column8: p.1). '''The discipline subsequently spread from the first universities in Italy throughout Europe''' (2). In this time
column9: legal work was mostly restricted to each national context due to the differences in the respective legal systems (2). This early approach to Law as a scientific discipline represents the so-called 'doctrinal approach' which is still the most common understanding of legal work (see What the method does).

column2: a second approach developed from the 17th Century on
column3: but mainly from the 19th Century until today. With [[History of Methods|the rise of positivism]] - which implies that the only valid knowledge arises from scientific inquiry and falsification of scientific theory -
column4: a new understanding of science emerged. Here
column5: the use of empirical data
column6: the testing of hypotheses and the development of theories
column7: independent from geographical limitations
column8: became the new scientific ideal. In consequence
column9: Law as a scientific discipline changed (van Hoecke 2011
column10: p.1). '''The research focus in Law partly shifted
column11: both in terms of research questions and methodology''': ""[i]n the 1960s and 1970s
column12: legal realists and socio-legal scholars started the law and society movement
column13: and pointed to the importance of understanding the gap between 'law in books' and 'law in action'
column14: and the operation of law in society. They were interested in examining the legal system in terms of whether legal reform brings about beneficial social effects and protects the interests of the public. Similarly
column15: in the 1980s critical legal studies integrated ideas and methods found in disciplines such as sociology
column16: anthropology and literary theory."" (McConville & Chui 2007
column17: p.5). With Law being a discipline between the Sciences and the Humanities
column18: this new movement borrowed heavily from the Social Sciences in terms of methodology. New adjacent disciplines emerged
column19: including legal sociology
column20: legal psychology and law and economics
column21: among others (2
column22: 5). This 'Law in context' - also called 'socio-legal' - approach includes new topics and methodological directions with a stronger focus on empirical research and theory building and has been universally taken up in academic institutions.

column1: From this contextualized approach to Law
column2: research emerged on the relationship between Law and Society and questions of power relations
column3: more specificially on aspects such as gender
column4: social class
column5: ethnicity and religion (5). ''''Socio-legal research' may be seen as an alternative or a supplement
column6: but not necessarily as a substitute to traditional legal analysis''' (2
column7: 5). The openness towards a contextualization of Law acknowledges the fact that Law is influenced by thoughts and discourses from other disciplines such as sociology
column8: economics
column9: political science
column10: history and psychology (4
column11: 7). In addition
column12: ""understanding of the modern patent law

column1: '''Let us take the example of §17 Animal welfare act:''' ""Anyone killing a vertebrate without a reasonable ground shall be punished with up to three years imprisonment or a fine"".
* The ''A'' - the elements of the norm - would be ""anyone killing a vertebrate without a reasonable ground"". Actually
column2: there are four elements here: The ""anyone""
column3: the ""killing''
column4: the ""vertebrate""
column5: and the ""without a reasonable ground"". All of these elements will need to be considered when assessing whether the situation ''C'' fulfills ''A''.

column2: ''B'' - the legal consequence - would be ""shall be punished with up to three years imprisonment or a fine"".
we look at our case ''C'' - let's say
column3: a man kills a cow with a knife. It is rather straightforward to see that the ""anyone"" and the ""vertebrate"" are fulfilled. The ""killing"" might be a matter of debate
column4: but if it is clear that the man actively caused the cow's death by using the knife
column5: this is also quite clear. But the ""without a reasonable ground"" is a matter of interpretation. The legal scholar needs to give meaning to this element so that they are able to decide whether it is fulfilled.

column1: In order to give meaning to ""reasonable ground""
column2: legal research typically uses four different methods of interpretation:

column1: * the actual meaning of individual legal terms (grammatical interpretation);
* the historical background of the text (historical interpretation)
* the systemic position of the legal provision
column2: for example when several adjacent laws have to be seen in connection to make sense of each (systematic interpretation);

column1: * and the object and purpose of the text (object and purpose interpretation)

column2: the interpretation of the documents is supported ''argumentatively''; the analysed laws are ''explained'' by the existence of a higher norm or general principle based on real-world contexts; the texts can be analyzed ''axiomatically'' and ''logically'' and there are ''normative'' elements in understanding the underlying norms of the law as well as normative positions to take during their interpretation (3).

column1: So let us apply these four main steps to our example of ""reasonable ground"":
* a grammatical interpretation would translate it as a sensible or acceptable reason for acting
* a systematic interpretation would show that other adjacent laws further define what is  unreasonable behavior towards animals
column2: which makes it clearer what is ""reasonable""

column1: * a historical interpretation would highlight that there has been increasingly more attention towards the rights and protection of living creatures
column2: and therefore increasingly narrow margins for ""reasonable killing""
column3: and

column1: * the object and purpose of the law state that there are circumstances under which humans need to kill vertebrates (e.g. for food production)
column2: and others where they don't need to.

these four steps do not point to one clear definition of what is a ""reasonable ground"". So the situation can be analyzed in light of a higher law. This happened in Germany when it was discussed whether male chicks should be allowed to be killed during the production of chickens. The German Federal Constitutional Court stated that the economic purpose of killing male chicks does not (anymore) outweigh the responsibility towards animal life
column3: so it was banned.
