column2: Why & When ==

column1: Lego can be a tool in a [[Design Thinking]] approach to prototype research ideas
column2: haptically test setups and explore team settings and interactions. The strength of Lego Serious Play lies in group settings
column3: where Lego can serve as a [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0921800914001219?via%3Dihub boundary object] to allow team members to interact
column4: allowing for a reflexive interaction. '''Lego is playful
column5: many remember it from childhood
column6: and it can trigger people to challenge their underlying assumptions.''' Through the haptic interaction people are enabled to interact more than if they would be just talking. Originating in management
column7: Lego Serious Play can be used in any sort of research setting
column8: and is suitable for disciplinary design settings yet particularly helpful in transdisciplinary research modes. The structure of Lego can help structure the research. Lego can be thus be used as a catalyst for a team to develop research together.

column1: Lego Serious Play can be seen more as a way and not a goal. The goal can be bluntly put to
1) facilitate people to brainstorm in a smaller (3-15) group setting about research
2) integrate knowledge in a room in a non-hierarchical and enabling space

column2: workshop settings or the architecture of larger research projects.

column1: The goal to this end is not so much the final Lego model
column2: but more the way that leads to it.
you need some Lego. Personally
column3: I think the Lego Serious Play sets are not really necessary. Instead
column4: any collection of Lego will do
column5: as long as you do not have a Lego expert who will be missing this specific piece from his childhood. Find a large table or a clean ground space (blanket?) where everybody can sit comfortably for a long time. '''Put the Lego in the center
column6: and make it clear
column7: that everybody can and should be equally engaged.''' Ideally
column8: there is a moderator who only intervenes in times of crisis or may engage people by asking specific questions. The process is still often led by hierarchies
column9: yet this should ideally be avoided.

column1: Here I present three approach show I used Lego in the past in research settings.
==== Example 1: Lego to build a better business ====
The first example shows how Lego can be used in a Team setting
column2: for instance in management. The original Lego Serious Play approach focuses on business settings
column3: where hierarchical management structures
column4: habitual thinking and rigid systems often prevent change. Lego Serious Play has proven to be valuable to transform such [[Glossary|systems]] in a playful way. It serves both as a prototyping tool as well as a reflexive setting
column5: allowing for system change and the [[Glossary|empowerment]] of the individual.

column1: A good starting point follows three steps (in accord with Kristiansen and Rasmussen 2014):
1) Get the knowledge from the room. Everybody should contribute their perspective
column2: along other to understand their knowledge and perspective.

column1: 2) Construct a system. Try to bring the different parts of the knowledge together
column2: so that people will jointly construct a model of the system
column3: showing what is relevant and where connections and interactions are.

column1: 3) Link the system and the individual. By trying to create a connection between the individual perspective and the system a new team hierarchy as well a a reflection of the role of individuals in the team or system can be created.
This approach was the original proposal of Lego Serious Play
column2: and aims to build better business. More concretely
column3: it is about creating more reflexive and interactive settings in the world of business.

column1: [[File:Lego Serious Play.jpg|300px|thumb|right|'''Lego can bring people together in a non-hierarchical manner.''' Source: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2TbTa31ACB4 seriousplayeducation
column2: YouTube]]]

column1: The second example builds on the creation of a research design for a larger project.
Large research projects often contain several PhD students
column2: which within most empirical research - as an example - write at least three scientific papers. Hence a project with three PhD students creates in a utilitarian calculation knowledge in the form of nine papers. Of course
column3: other forms of knowledge will also be created
column4: but this is at Leuphana in the Faculty of Sustainability what students have to deliver to be able to hand in their dissertation.

column1: I typically build two models in such a setting. One model for the PhDs
column2: where each color represents one PhD student. There
column3: links can be created between different papers of the PhDs
column4: visualising where interaction are
column5: and how the larger project may make sense. I would consider a project where you have three stacks of bricks that are completely unconnected a failure. There should be a justification and logic on why these PhDs are together in a larger project.

column1: The second model I often create differentiates between data
column2: analysis and interpretation
column3: showing a methodological differentiation. This is helpful if certain data feedbacks into later papers
column4: or if two papers use the same analysis
column5: but with different data. This can help to identify synergies in the project. Creating such models of projects can especially be also good at the beginning of a project to create a joint recognition of the different milestones - or Lego bricks - of the project.

column1: ==== Example 3: Lego to create a research design ====
The third example is for planning one specific sampling within a research project. [[Stakeholder Mapping]] can be aided by Lego figures
column2: and out of such a stakeholder system
column3: several bricks can be located to show how many interviews are conducted
column4: and where. These bricks can then be combined
column5: and the interview campaign can be logistically planned. This can also be amended by a prototyping of the analysis
column6: checking whether the sample number is large enough and if the knowledge saturates are a specific point. The Lego bricks can thus also represent units of knowledge
column7: that can be integrated into a three dimensional plots during the interview campaign to visualise not only the process
column8: but also the progress and the information that was already gathered.

column1: Lego can be a serious boundary object within research settings
column2: and can help to reflect within a team
column3: and integrate the knowledge and perspectives in the team. It is important that the team agree that they want to try this out
column4: thus that people do not feel pressured into this format. In addition
column5: it has to be acknowledged that this approach creates a [[Bias and Critical Thinking|bias]] towards people that are familiar with Lego
column6: which is why an inclusive and encouraging [[Glossary|facilitation]] is relevant. The possibilities of the Lego Serious Play approach are endless
column7: and it is up to the team members how Lego is being utilised. Try it out!

Levels of Theory;"'''In short:''' This entry structures 'Theory' and how its levels relate to each other.
'''[[Glossary|Theory]] is at the heart of science.''' Scientists come up with theories
column2: test them
column3: confirm them
column4: falsify them
column5: derive them from observation - theories are one of the staples of science. Hence
column6: many scientists love discussing theories. Within the following lines
column7: I want to show you a conceptualisation of different levels of theory
column8: building on examples and common definitions of the respective terms.

column1: When reading a book about inequalities
column2: I was at some point getting the feeling that this different forms of inequalities were like an enumeration to me. While each and every one of these inequality had a clear footing in reality
column3: they felt more like a composite of examples of inequality. What was lacking to me was a more general level of thinking about inequality. Hence I derived a system of levels within theory
column4: which I will present here. As the quoted definitions highlight
column5: there is often not one single understanding for these terms despite their utter importance in scientific discourse.

column1: 'Theory' is not so much the first level as it is the general idea of the following terms. Theory is defined as a ""systematic ideational structure of broad scope
column2: conceived by the human imagination
column3: that encompasses a family of empirical (experiential) laws regarding regularities existing in objects and events
column4: both observed and posited. A scientific theory is a structure suggested by these laws and is devised to explain them in a scientifically rational manner."" (Britannica). Wikipedia understands it as ""an explanation of an aspect of the natural world that can be repeatedly tested and verified in accordance with the scientific method
column5: using accepted protocols of observation
column6: measurement
column7: and evaluation of results."" Theories can be tested either through experiments or through principles of abductive reasoning. An example of a theory would be the theory of evolution
column8: which has been tested empirically and abductively so often that we came to call it accepted knowledge on how this part of the world works. In theory
column9: however
column10: this theory could be rejected
column11: and a recent epigenetic renaissance in Lamarkism proves that such theories are continuously explored.

column2: 'Concepts' are understood as mental representations of the world. Wikipedia defines them as ""abstract ideas or general notions that occur in the mind
column3: in speech
column4: or in thought. They are understood to be the fundamental building blocks of thoughts and beliefs"". According to Merriam-Webster
column5: a concept is ""an abstract or generic idea generalized from particular instances"". Concepts are the highest unit of theoretical thought. Our mind develops concepts to make sense of more specific elements of the world
column6: such as the concept of 'nations' that helps subsume different groups of people and enables us to speak about these on a more generalized level. Other examples are Reason
column7: Logic or Justice
column8: which are abstract ideas of how a variety of elements from the world may be aligned
column9: and related to each other. Philosophy is most relevant for this level of theory
column10: and it is most relevant to generalisable knowledge.

column2: the term 'Paradigm' was coined by Kuhn in the 1960s. Kuhn described scientific paradigms as ""universally recognized scientific achievements that
column3: for a time
column4: provide model problems and solutions for a community of practitioners"". A paradigm includes the concepts and theories
column5: laws and thought patterns
column6: generalizations and assumptions
column7: and basically guidelines and standards on how to conduct research in the respective scientific school or discipline (Merriam-Webster
column8: Wikipedia). Kuhn called the successive transition from one paradigm to the next the maturation process of science. You may have heard the term 'Paradigmenwechsel' in German public discourse - it means that everthing that was assumed about a field of knowledge is questioned and re-developed. The [[Glossary|emergence]] of sustainability itself may be seen as such a paradigm shift because it changed the way we think about scientific and societal sub-systems. In this regard
column9: paradigms are composites or connections of several concepts: sustainability connects topics such as justice and equality
column10: livelihoods
column11: resources and other things
column12: and by doing so influences the way we think about
column13: work with and research these topics. Gender equality is another example
column14: which consists of two combined concepts. Paradigms make concepts graspable. Not everybody is a philosopher
column15: but paradigms can represent and encompass the large narratives that build and drive societies and cultures. Paradigms are thus more tangible
column16: yet with enough blurriness to keep you thinking.

column1: A 'Framework' is a real or conceptual basic structure that supports or guides practical applications (Merriam-Webster
column2: whatis.com). Frameworks pave the road to connect paradigms to the real world. The [https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/sustainable-development-goals/ 17 Sustainable Development Goals] are an example
column3: or the [http://www.dpi.inpe.br/gilberto/cursos/cst-317/papers/ostrom_sustainability.pdf Ostrom framework]. Frameworks imply
column4: explore or test causality between their single elements or have the explicit focus to make paradigms applicable in planning and management. Hence frameworks link science to the real world.

column1: The '''4th level''' are Cases. Cases are simply the bread and butter of empirical work
column2: allowing us to apply frameworks. On the '''5th level''' you have actors. Actors are diverse
column3: may be together part of institutions
column4: and thus typically have identities
column5: knowledge - ideally - and -finally - they act. No actor is an island. Actors are connected and interacting through actor-networks. Lastly
column6: actors are non-static
column7: they are changeable in space and time.

column1: Now many discussions you see and hear start on one level. You have the occasional discussion about sustainability. Somebody says: „to me it is about justice“
column2: so you find yourself on the concept level. Then suddenly somebody says „but what about the vegan Amish“
column3: and you go down quite some levels to the cases. Within the debate
column4: you make a jump from a very high to a very low level. This often creates confection and unconnectedness in the debates. All world religions revolve around paradigms. Take the Holy Trinity or the Four Noble Truths
column5: which are paradigms
column6: but then find their way into frameworks
column7: for instance through the Ten Commandments or the Noble Eightfold Path. These were ideas about early frameworks
column8: but one could have a hard time to take such frameworks all to literal
column9: since they are more guidelines than actual rules
column10: just as in [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6GMkuPiIZ2k Pirates of the Caribbean].

column2: it is quite good to understand where you have the strongest footing.''' Few today are philosophers
column3: many work with the conceptual linkages of paradigms

column5: but also the level on which a discussion is running
column6: or jumping. Paradigms and Frameworks often get taxed by a lack of clarity on the conceptual level. Only by verbalising these problems
column7: we shall be able to move our theoretical thinking forward to this end.

column2: or Life Cycle Assessment (LCA)
column3: dates back to the late 1960s/early 1970s when the first (partial) LCAs were conducted: ""The scope of these studies was initially limited to energy analyses but was later broadened to encompass resource requirements
column4: emission loadings and generated waste. LCA studies in this period mainly focused on packaging alternatives."" (Guinée 2011
column5: p.9; 5) Here
column6: a study done for the Coca-Cola company set the foundation for subsequent life cycle analyses (4). Yet
column7: the method was not unified at all
column8: but existed as a broad variety of theoretical frameworks and methodological approaches. This led to a lack of comparability between the results and hindered the method from becoming an accepted analytical tool until the 1980s (1).

column2: the Green Movement in Europe strengthened public interest in the method (4). In the 1990s
column3: its image and usefulness improved through the engagement of SETAC (Society of Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry) and ISO (International Organization for Standardization) in the harmonization and standardization of LCAs. At this time
column4: the method also first appeared in scientific publications (1).

column2: LCAs have been increasingly adopted by policy actors (such as the EU
column3: US and UN). Alongside a publicly increasing role of life-cycle-thinking
column4: more diverse forms of the LCA have been been developed that differ in terms of their system boundaries
column5: allocation methods and the considered impacts (1).

column2: the Life Cycle Sustainability Assessment (LCSA) has been suggested to better connect LCAs with the sustainability discourse. The LCSA broadens the scope of the LCA both in terms of criteria involved (from purely environmental to economic
column3: environmental and social impacts) and regional scope (from the product to the industry) while deepening the perspective on the elements involved in the Life Cycle (1
column5: 3). While this approach is still in development
column6: it may be seen as one/the future of the Life Cycle approach (see Outlook).

column1: The underlying idea of the Life Cycle Analysis is that the environmental impact of a product. activity or process is not to be found in the use
column2: but (mostly) in the production
column3: transportation and disposal of this product. '''The LCA thus attempts to gather a quantitative overview on the resources used and the waste / emissions produced during the whole 'life' of any given product''' - 'from cradle to grave' - to provide a more accurate account of its environmental footprint (1
column5: 5). Based on this
column6: comparisons between similar products may be made or a company (or policy-maker) is enabled to decide which [[Glossary|processes]] or materials might reasonably minimize the environmental impact of a product in order to subsequently act on these insights (4
column7: 5). A LCA is also often conducted internally for a company to learn about potential energy - and thus cost - savings and in order to substantiate marketing claims about the environmental compatibility of a product (4).

column1: [[File:LCA Elements.png|600px|thumb|center|'''Life Cycle of a product.''' Source: (Ciambrone 1997

column2: the '''scope of the analysis''' is defined. This includes the elements (processes
column3: inputs and outputs) that are to be considered and the boundaries of the analysis (see Figure 3). The boundaries are crucial
column4: since they do not only define what is to be studied
column5: but also which elements are left out of the analysis - e.g. socio-economic impacts of the product (4). Each LCA may define the system's boundaries and individual steps differently
column6: which is why the proper documentation of the specific system definition is relevant to allow for comparability with other studies (4). The same is true for the in- and outputs which need to be defined according to specific standards (5; see Further Information for ISO standardization). This harmonization and unambiguous definition and documentation further assures a valid interpretation of the data (4).

column1: [[File:LCA Input Output.png|500px|thumb|right|'''The Inventory step of the LCA.''' Source: (Ciambrone 1997

column2: the '''inventory analysis'''. During this step
column3: quantitative data on the direct and indirect in- and outputs that arise during the life-cycle of the analyzed product are gathered (materials
column4: energy
column5: emissions
column6: waste). Caution is advised in many aspects of this step to properly synthesize the data (see Strengths & Challenges).

column2: the '''impact analysis'''. This includes first the selection of categories for the environmental impacts - e.g. climate change
column3: ecotoxicology - of the analyzed product with appropriate indicators - e.g. occurrence of natural disasters
column4: quality of aquatic life. This is followed by the assignment of the inventory results to these impact categories
column5: and concluded with the calculation of the environmental impacts (7). The latter is done by multiplying the inventory emission of a specific compound (e.g. CO2 per unit of measurement) with a characterisation factor that is provided in the literature or an official database. The product of this multiplication represents the impact of this emission on the specific category indicator. As an example
column6: the amount of carbon dioxide emitted in the life cycle of a product can be converted (by the use of the characterisation factor) into a level of contribution to climate change as measured by the increased occurrence of natural disasters.

column2: the '''improvement analysis''' which highlights the possible changes to be made by policy actors or companies to the life-cycle processes of the product. These actors may use the conclusions of this step to prioritize their potential future decisions.

column1: * LCAs can also be a powerful tool for policy-making and the development of new technologies and products

column2: but based on company-internal data
column3: the question of confidentiality must be addressed (4). Confidential data may be erroneous and can hardly be verified by external readers
column4: which may disguise analytical errors (5).

column1: * The appropriate use of inventory data is of special importance for the LCA
column2: and a variety of pitfalls may arise in the inventory phase.

column1: ** The researcher must ensure the recentness of the data and take into the account the (temporal) specificity of the data as opposed to average numbers. A sufficiently long time period of data is advisable to smooth out individual variations (4).
** The researcher must make sure that the data is normalized for each product (4).
** Some data may not be obtainable
column2: in which case it is interesting to ask why it is not
column3: and how important this data is to the overall LCA results. If an emission is not (easily) measurable
column4: a qualitative discussion of its amount might be reasonable
column5: which should then be properly reflected upon (4).

column1: ** When analyzing and synthesizing the data from individual steps of the life cycle
column2: the researcher must be aware of uncertainty of the respective datasets. If the uncertainty of one - or several combined - datasets becomes too high
column3: the overall result might not be valid enough to serve the intended purpose. In this case
column4: a test for sensitivity of the overall result with regards to the exclusion or inclusion of said data is advisable to check the relevance of the data for the general conclusion (4).

column2: the researcher must be aware of potential differing conditions within an industry (deviating regulations and standards
column3: other technologies
column4: materials and processes) if the purpose of the LCA is a product comparison (4).

column1: * quantitative data that is synthesizable and comparable to the results of other LCAs
* a scientific approach to the data gathering and analysis
* a comprehensive assessment of all significant resources and emissions

* peer-reviewed quality assurance in case of public use and
* usefulness of the results for further integration.

column1: * It should be noted that the results of LCAs can serve not only as information on how to decrease manufacturing costs of a product
column2: but also as marketing material for companies. These two elements of the LCA are market-related side effects of the environmental impact reduction that is - or should be - the main goal of the LCA. Therefore
column3: when reading a company-led publication of LCA results
column4: one should be aware of potential selectivity in the data that is intended to proclaim a specific image of the company or product (4).

column2: knowledge about the environmental (and/or social) footprint of any product has potential implications for consumer behaviour. A good example for this is the plastic vs paper bag discussion
column3: which acknowledges the carbon footprint during the production of both products as well as the environmental consequences of their (inappropriate) disposal
column4: indicating a differentiated perspective on the issue (see (4)). Another example is the discussion of electric vs non-electric vehicles

column6: but also the social costs of battery manufacturing. The assessment of all relevant impacts of the product and thus the (non-)purchase decision is in the hands of the consumer. In this regard

Likert Scale;"'''In short:''' Likert Scales are categorical ordinal scales that are used in surveys to measure attitude. They are widely used in Social Sciences
column2: but also in employee surveys when asking about satisfaction in the job or in customer surveys where products/services can be rated.

column1: The name of the scale comes from the American psychologist Rensis Likert. In 1932
column2: Likert developed a 7-point agreement scale out of interest in measuring people’s opinions and attitudes. His initial scale is very similar to the ones used today.

column1: == What do Likert Scales look like? ==
The most common Likert Scale asks for attitude on 5 different levels: Strongly Agree
column2: Agree
column3: Neutral/Undecided
column4: Disagree
column5: and Strongly Disagree. Other options include 3 or 7 answer options. Odd numbers are commonly used to include a neutral or undecided option in the middle. If no such neutral option is added
column6: we call the scale a forced-choice method
column7: because respondents are forced to decide if they are leaning more against the agree or disagree side of the scale. Sometimes
column8: opt-out responses are also used
column9: such as “I don’t know” or “Not applicable”. Those are then placed outside the scale.

column2: Likert scales can also be used to measure other variations such as quality
column3: frequency or likelihood to give some examples. In online surveys
column4: a variant with a kind of slider has been used more and more recently: In this variant
column5: respondents can indicate their answer on a scale from zero (minimum) to 100 (maximum).

column2: there is a huge debate on how to analyze these scales correctly. The biggest point of conflict in the discussion is whether the scale can be considered ordinal or interval. While Likert Scales technically are ordinal data
column3: because there clearly is a grading: ""Strongly Agree"" is graded higher than ""Agree""
column4: strictly speaking
column5: the assumption of equal distance between categories is not valid. That is
column6: the distance between “Agree” and “Neutral” theoretically is not the same as the distance between “Neutral” and “Not Agree”. That is why
column7: we would strictly not consider Likert Scales as interval scaled
column8: where each distance should be equal.

column2: in some areas
column3: it is accepted to apply parametric statistics for Likert Scales
column4: such as calculating a mean
column5: doing an [[ANOVA]] or [[Simple_Statistical_Tests#One_sample_t-test|t-test]]
column6: which means treating them as an interval. Cases in which Likert Scales can be treated as intervals are if there are a high number of response options per question
column7: when response options are assumed to be equally spaced
column8: or when respondents mark their answer on a line so that the precise location of the mark can be measured. Making a decision about which method to apply
column9: one should look at the literature of its discipline
column10: reflect the assumption for each method and apply the method which is widely accepted in its field.

column2: any parametric test ([[ANOVA]]
column3: [[Regression Analysis|Linear Regression]]

column2: the dependent variable is ordinal in the regression. The ordinal package in R provides a powerful and flexible [[Glossary|framework]] for ordinal regression. It can handle a wide variety of experimental designs
column3: including those with paired or repeated observations. Look [https://www.r-bloggers.com/2019/06/how-to-perform-ordinal-logistic-regression-in-r/ here] for more on Ordinal Regressions in R.

column1: Tests for ordinal data are arranged in a contingency table form. These include the linear-by-linear test
column2: which is a test of association between two ordinal variables
column3: or the Cochran-Armitage test. This is a test of association between an ordinal variable and a nominal variable. One has to consider though
column4: that these tests are limited to data arranged in a two-dimensional table and they require spacing between ordinal categories. More information can be found [https://rcompanion.org/handbook/H_09.html here].

column1: One can use the coin package in R to run permutation tests with ordinal dependent variables. It can handle models analogous to a one-way analysis of variance with stratification blocks
column2: including paired or repeated observations. For more information on these tests visit this [https://rcompanion.org/handbook/K_01.html link].

column3: and “Strongly Disagree” and “Disagree” to another category and dropping the neutral response. In this case

Limitations of Statistics;"'''In short:''' This entry revolves around what Statistics cannot do
column2: and where its limits are - if you are interested in what Statistics CAN do
column3: have a look at the [[Statistics]] overview page. You might also be interested in the topic of [[Bias in statistics]].

column1: == Statistics and the where it may fail us ==
[[Statistics]] provide a specific viewpoint with which you can look at the world
column2: and it can help you understand parts of what you're seeing. '''If more people understood statistics and the insights we can gain through it
column3: these people would become more empowered to make their decisions based on their own analysis and insight.''' However
column4: we do not only need to recognise the benefits that can be gained through statistics
column5: but we also need to be aware of the limitations of statistics. After all
column6: it is a view through numbers and models
column7: and can therefore only offer parts of the complete picture. In addition
column8: we have to accept that statistics are also riddled by diverse biases
column9: which we also have to take into our focus and conscious recognition as much as possible. More about [[Bias in statistics]] can be found here.

column1: Beyond problems directly associated to statistics as such
column2: there are also problems associated to the relative position of statistics within science. Statistics were feeling the flame of positivism
column3: and a critical perspective on statistics is beyond a doubt of pivotal importance for the recognition of the role that statistics can play to produce knowledge
column4: but also to understand where statistics may fail us. '''In other words
column5: we need to be clear about what statistics can do for us as scientists
column6: and what it cannot do.''' The other major problem that statistics face within science is the normativity of statistics. There are diverse norms and schools of thinking that got established over time
column7: and within this entry we will take a look at some examples on how differences
column8: co-evolutions and interchanges influence the role of statistics within science. To this end
column9: a third point may also be a historical perspective
column10: which can be by no means exhaustive
column11: but should enable us to once more to a look at the role of statistics in science.

column1: The question of the limitations of statistics in the current societal debates - and the possibilities and opportunities which statistics may offer for the great transformation - are in the focus of the last part of this entry. Why are many societal debates so disconnected from available results derived through statistics? And how can we improve the literacyy regarding statistics within society? Lastly
column2: we want to examine with a critical eye how the limitations of statistics may contribute to some of the problems we face in society today
column3: and how we may ultimately overcome these.

column1: Limitations of statistics can be divided into several parts.

column2: and many would argue most importantly
column3: are the questions of plausibility and validity. Are the questions we are testing plausible
column4: and are the predictors we use to access these models valid? We often test constructs: for instance
column5: GDP is commonly used as a proxy for many other things. While this had some surely some merits in the past
column6: it also draws an increasing amount of criticism. Another example would be the Intelligence Quotient
column7: which may tell you something about people
column8: but more often than not is misleading and judgmental. Have a look at the entry [[To Rule And To Measure]] to learn more
column9: and also remember the role that [[Data_distribution | data distributions]] can play.

column2: predictors may vary in their [[Experiments_and_Hypothesis_Testing#Validity | validity and reliability]]. This may be related to the way the predictors are measured
column3: how constructed specific predictors are
column4: or if they can actually serve as proxies to answer the questions we want to answer. Money can be a predictor for happiness
column5: but it has clearly its limitations
column6: and the amount of money needed to have a decent life may differ between countries. Also remember that different [[Data_formats | data formats]] are highly relevant in order to understand the nature of your data.

column1: This brings us to the next factor that can affect our model validity. There are many things we might want to know when creating a statistical model
column2: but there may also be things that we do not want to know. Statistically speaking
column3: these are ''random factors'' or ''random variables''. Regarding these
column4: we explicitly exclude the variance that is created by these parts of the dataset
column5: because we want to minimise their effects. An example would be a medical study that wants to investigate the effect of a certain drug on the recovery rate of some diseased patients. In such studies
column6: the information whether a patient is a smoker or not is often included as a random factor
column7: because smoking negatively affects many diseases and the respective recovery rates. We know that smoking makes many things worse (from a medical standpoint) and this is why such variables are excluded. More on random factors can be found [[ Field_experiments#Fixed_effects_vs._Random_effects | here]].

column1: The next part of a [[An_initial_path_towards_statistical_analysis | statistical model]] that needs to be examined when discussing the limitations of statistics is the statistical test or model itself. Models differ in terms of their mathematical foundations. This can lead to some models being more complicated than others
column2: relying on different measures of model performance
column3: and are also sometimes differently utilised within different scientific communities or disciplines. Data visualisations showcase how different branches of sciences have different ways to approach how to [[Introduction_to_statistical_figures | show data in figures]]
column4: which can be diverse and often follow specific norms within different scientific disciplines.

column1: This is difficult to explain in a nutshell
column2: but let me try: basically
column3: different historical developments in the diverse disciplines
column4: as well as the specific relation of a discipline towards the respective theory and topics
column5: enable differences in how statistics are being utilised by different disciplines. Yet
column6: there are also examples of exchanges and even coevolutionary patterns. For instance
column7: the [[ANOVA]] started within agricultural science
column8: but equally unleashed its potential in psychology
column9: medicine and ecology
column10: as these all rely strongly on the [[Experiments and Hypothesis Testing|testing of hypotheses.]] Econometrics and engineering build more strongly on [[Correlations | correlative]] testing
column11: which is again related to the specifics of these disciplines. Most simple tests are [[Simple_Statistical_Tests#Normativity | hardly being used these days]]
column12: a phenomena that unites almost all disciplines
column13: yet sometimes even very [[Back_of_the_envelope_statistics | simple calculations]] can offer robust answers. However
column14: the difference between scientific disciplines regarding their statistical use does not always make sense
column15: and is not necessarily rooted in reasonable decisions.

column1: '''Equally grave (and not necessarily always meaningful) is the [[Design Criteria of Methods|great divide]] between quantitative and qualitative branches within science.''' While we should acknowledge that there are clear limitations of knowledge driven from statistics
column2: it is equally difficult to reject knowledge derived from quantitative methods altogether. It is well deserved that with the rise of positivism - which widely cemented its reign through quantitative methods and particularly statistics - a qualitative counter-culture established itself. However
column3: this does by far not do justice to the highly creative and so desperately needed deeper unlocking of qualitative dimensions in research. [[Interviews]]
column4: [[Grounded Theory]]
column5: [[Ethnography|Ethnographic Observations]] and [[Content Analysis]] are examples of important methods being established that go way beyond previous methods
column6: and some of these approaches have a [[History of Methods|long history]] of highly relevant applications in science. However
column7: statistics is nevertheless embedded into a judgemental perspective
column8: creating a dichotomy that has not always been of benefit for science. Some would argue that the positivist wars - and the subsequent science war and culture war - are on a long chain of interwoven conflicts that may have been solved by [[Bias and Critical Thinking|critical realism]].

column1: '''We have to acknowledge that the knowledge we create is subjective'''
column2: which one of the main claims of critical realisms. Still
column3: our way of using this knowledge to make sense of the world and derive heuristics and concepts that tell us how we ought to act may be objective. For instance
column4: I might acknowledge that our knowledge about the validity of a vaccine to prevent me from getting a certain disease is a snapshot in time
column5: and governed by conservative and robust norms in research. Hence I might decide to trust this knowledge in order to not only protect myself
column6: but also to contribute to the protection of society. The decision to protect myself can be seen as hedonism

column1: '''This brings us to the complicated relationship between statistics and society.''' Through its contribution to agricultural science
column2: medicine
column3: economics and many other fields
column4: statistics have served as one of the main methoetodological approaches to [[Scientific methods and societal paradigms|contribute to a growth-focused economy]]. It can be clearly argued that this led to manifold benefits
column5: but also to problems
column6: including destruction
column7: degradation and inequalities. All the while
column8: science became increasingly glorified in the middle of the 20th century. However
column9: due to the many negative effects that statistics indirectly contributed to
column10: a critical perspective on statistics increased within the societal debate. What in the past was perceived as factual knowledge was increasingly questioned
column11: and even altogether rejected.

column1: '''It is clear that the knowledge derived from statistics has value
column2: but also limitations for societal discourse.''' Within an increasing rise of dichotomies as part of the culture wars
column3: science was often called out
column4: or simply taken as an emotional counterpoint. The debate on climate change showcases that both sides argue strongly from an emotional perspective (if we think in terms of the extreme points within the debate). At the same time
column5: both sides also make selective arguments
column6: having different focus points in terms of the goals they are trying to achieve. Climate change activists try to argue based on scientific evidence to protect the planet. Climate change deniers often take a limited or blurry understanding of bits and pieces of information to create a counterpoint that focuses
column7: for instance
column8: on the rights of some few people to continue their current strategies. Both sides seemingly argue about so-called 'facts'
column9: which showcases the deep entrenchment and differences that currently riddle societal debates. Statistics
column10: to this end
column11: is often devalued by one side or the other
column12: and becomes a collateral due to criticism that emerges from false understandings or implausible claims.

column1: '''This highlights that statistics in itself may not be normative if all people share the same understanding about it.''' Sadly
column2: this is not the case
column3: and hence the limitations of statistics within societal debates are not much more than a mirror of the lack of education and ignorance that many people have to endure. Statistics is thus a privilege that some people can benefit from
column4: but to use this educational effort as a devaluation of people who do not share this privilege is a difficult point. It would be naive to say that if all people shared the same knowledge
column5: we'd all come to the same conclusions. But would it not be wonderful if this was the case?

column1: I believe that ''power to the people'' is still one of the best idea we ever had. Yet
column2: with it comes the responsibility to provide an education that enables all people to use their [[Glossary|power]] to take decisions. Ethics suggests that these decisions ought to be rooted in principles. These principles can be informed by information that can originate from - among many other sources - [[Why_statistics_matters | statistics]]. During the pandemic
column3: for instance
column4: the interest in numbers increased among the broader public. At the same time
column5: it also became clear that different numbers and changes in these numbers represented different aspects of the pandemic at different times. Sometimes it was the amount of spread of the disease (r-value)
column6: sometimes the number of occupied hospital beds
column7: at other times the mortality
column8: and sometimes the increase in cases. This created confusion
column9: and even the experts were not agreeing which number was relevant at different times
column10: or which combination of values. This showcases that statistics are still emerging
column11: especially when it comes to taming wicked problems
column12: and also highlights the gap between science and society. It does not make any sense to blame people that were never educated in statistics for not understanding it. It becomes clear that science still has a long way to go to explain knowledge from statistics in a sense that it becomes a contribution to the great transformation
column13: yet statistics should seize this opportunity and learn to contribute in a critical way.

column1: The Living Lab (LL) started outside of academia

column4: focusing on information and communication technologies and institutionalizing the concept (6

column1: The concept of Real-World Laboratories ('Reallabore') emerged around the same time

A broad set of RWLs have been set up in and supported by the German state of Baden-Württemberg since 2015 (14).

'''In short:''' Machine Learning subsumes methods in which computers are trained to learn rules in order to autonomously analyze data.
[[File:Machine learning.png|thumb|400px|right|'''SCOPUS hits per year for Machine Learning until 2019.''' Search term: 'Machine Learning' in Title
column2: Abstract
column3: Keywords. Source: own.]]

column1: Traditionally in the fields of computer science and mathematics
column2: you have some input and some rule in form of a function. You feed the input into the rule and get some output. In this setting
column3: you '''need''' to know the rule exactly in order to create a system that gives you the outputs that you need. This works quite well in many situations where the nature of inputs and/or the nature of the outputs is well understood.

column2: in situations where the inputs can be ''noisy'' or the outputs are expected to be different in each case
column3: you cannot hand-craft the ""[[Glossary|rules]]"" that account for ''every'' type of inputs or for every type of output imaginable. In such a scenario
column4: another powerful approach can be applied: '''Machine Learning'''. The core idea behind Machine Learning is that instead of being required to hand-craft ''all'' the rules that take inputs and provide outputs in a fairly accurate manner
column5: you can ''train'' the machine to ''learn'' the rules based on the inputs and outputs that you provide.

column1: The trained models have their foundations in the fields of mathematics and computer science. As computers of various types (from servers
column2: desktops and laptops to smartphones
column3: and sensors integrated in microwaves
column4: robots and even washing machines) have become ubiquitous over the past two decades
column5: the amount of data that could be used to train Machine Learning models have become more accessible and readily available. The advances in the field of computer science have made working with large volumes of data very efficient. As the computational resources have increased exponentially over the past decades
column6: we are now able to train more complex models that are able to perform specific tasks with astonishing results; so much so that it almost seems magical.

column1: This article presents the different types of Machine Learning tasks and the different Machine Learning approaches in brief. If you are interested in learning more about Machine Learning
column2: you are directed to Russel and Norvig [2] or Mitchell [3].

column1: The term ""Machine Learning"" does not refer to one specific method. Rather
column2: there are three main groups of methods that fall under the term Machine Learning: supervised learning
column3: unsupervised learning
column4: and reinforcement learning.

column1: This family of Machine Learning methods rely on input-output pairs to ""learn"" rules. This means that the data that you have to provide can be represented as <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>(X
column2: y)</syntaxhighlight> pairs where <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>X = (x_1
column5: x_n)</syntaxhighlight> is the input data (in the form of vectors or matrices) and <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>y = (y_1
column8: y_n)</syntaxhighlight> is the output (in the form of vectors with numbers or categories that correspond to each input)
column9: also called ''true label''.

column1: Once you successfully train a model using the input-output pair <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>(X
column2: y)</syntaxhighlight> and one of the many ''training algorithms''
column3: you can use the model with new data <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>(X_new)</syntaxhighlight> to make predictions <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>(y_hat)</syntaxhighlight> in the future.

column1: In the heart of supervised Machine Learning lies the [[Glossary|concept]] of ""learning from data"" and from the data entirely. This begs the question what exactly is learning. In the case of computational analysis
column2: ""a computer program is said to learn from experience '''E''' with respect to some class of tasks '''T''' and performance measure '''P'''
column3: if its performance at tasks in '''T'''
column4: as measured by '''P'''
column5: improves with experience '''E'''.""[3]

column2: here is what you have:

column1: * '''Task (T)''' is what we want the Machine Learning algorithm to be able to perform once the learning process has finished. Usually
column2: this boils down to predicting a value ([[Regression Analysis|regression]])
column3: deciding in which category or group a given data falls into (classification/clustering)
column4: or solve problems in an adaptive way (reinforcement learning).

column1: * '''Experience (E)''' is represented by the data on which the learning is to be based. The data can either be structured - in a tabular format (eg. excel files) - or unstructured - images
column2: audio files
column3: etc.

column2: or a set of metrics
column3: that is used to evaluate the efficacy of the learning process and the ""learned"" algorithm. Usually
column4: we want the learning process to take as little time as possible (i.e. we want training time time to be low)
column5: we want the learned algorithm to give us an output as soon as possible (i.e. we want prediction time to be low)
column6: and we want the error of prediction to be as low as possible.

column1: The following figure from the seminal book ""Learning from Data"" by Yaser Abu Mostafa [1] summarizes  the process of supervised learning summarizes the concept in a succinct manner:
[[File:Mostafa Supervised Learning.png|thumb|The Learning Diagram from ""Learning from Data"" by Abu-Mostafa
column2: Magdon-Ismail

column1: The ''target function'' is assumed to be unknown and the training data is assumed to be based on the target function that is to be estimated. The models that are trained based on the training data are assessed on some error measures (called ''metrics'') which guide the strategy for improving upon the Machine Learning algorithm that was ""learned"" in the previous steps. If you have enough data
column2: and adopted a good Machine Learning strategies
column3: you can expect the learned algorithm to perform quite well with new input data in the future.

column1: '''Supervised learning tasks can be broadly sub-categorized into ''regression learning'' and ''classification learning''.'''

column2: the objective is to predict a particular value when certain input data is given to the algorithm. An example of a regression learning task is predicting the price of a house when certain features of the house (eg. PLZ/ZIP code
column3: no. of bedrooms
column4: no. of bathrooms
column5: garage size
column6: energy raging
column7: etc.) are given as an input to the Machine Learning algorithm that has been trained for this specific task.

column2: the objective is to predict which ''class'' (or ''category'') a given observation/sample falls under given the characteristics of the observation. There are 2 specific classification learning tasks: ''binary classification'' and ''multiclass classification''. As their names suggest
column3: in binary classification
column4: a given observation falls under one of the two classes (eg. classifying whether an email is spam or not)
column5: and in multiclass classification
column6: a given observation falls under one of many classes (eg. in ''digit recognition'' task
column7: the class for a picture of a given hand-written digit can range from 0 to 9; there are 10 classes).

column1: Whereas supervised learning is based on pairs of input and output data
column2: unsupervised learning algorithms function based only on the inputs: <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>X = (x_1
column5: x_n)</syntaxhighlight> and are rather used for recognizing patterns than for predicting specific value or class.

column1: Some of the methods that are categorized under unsupervised learning are ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principal_component_analysis Principal Component Analysis]''
column2: ''[[Clustering_Methods|Clustering Methods]]''
column3: ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_filtering Collaborative Filtering]''
column4: ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hidden_Markov_model Hidden Markov Models]''
column5: ''[https://brilliant.org/wiki/gaussian-mixture-model/ Gaussian Mixture Models]''
column6: etc.

column1: The idea behind reinforcement learning is that the ""machine"" learns from experiences much like a human or an animal would [1
column2: 2]. As such
column3: the input data ""does not contain the target output
column4: but instead contains some possible output together with a measure of how good that output is"" [1]. As such
column5: the data looks like: <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>(X
column6: y
column7: c)</syntaxhighlight> where <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>X = (x_1
column10: x_n)</syntaxhighlight> is the input
column11: <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>y = (y_1
column14: y_n)</syntaxhighlight> is the list of corresponding labels
column15: and <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>c = (c_1
column18: c_n)</syntaxhighlight> is the list of corresponding scores for each input-label pair. The objective of the machine is to perform such that the overall score is maximized.

column1: === Approaches to Training Machine Learning Algorithms ===

column2: also called ''offline learning''
column3: is the most common approach to Machine Learning. In this approach
column4: a Machine Learning model is built from the entire dataset in one go.

column1: The main disadvantage of this approach is that depending on the computational infrastructure being used
column2: the data might not fit into the memory and/or the training process can take a long time. Additionally
column3: models based on batch learning need to be retrained on a semi-regular basis with new training examples in order for them to keep performing well.

column1: Some examples of batch learning algorithms are ''[http://pages.cs.wisc.edu/~jerryzhu/cs540/handouts/dt.pdf Decision Trees]''(C4.5
column2: ID3
column3: CART)
column4: ''[https://www.datacamp.com/community/tutorials/support-vector-machines-r Support Vector Machines]''
column5: etc.*

column2: data is ordered and fed into the training algorithm in a sequential order instead of training on the entire data set at once. This approach is adopted when the dataset is so large that batch learning is infeasible
column3: or when the nature of the data makes it so that more data is available over time (eg. stock prices
column4: sales data
column5: etc.)

column1: Some examples of online learning algorithms are ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perceptron Perceptron Learning Algorithm]''
column2: ''[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_gradient_descent stochastic gradient descent] based classifiers and regressors''
column3: etc.

column1: Neural networks are a specific approach to Machine Learning that can be adapted to solve tasks many different settings. As a result
column2: they have been used for detecting spams in emails
column3: identifying different objects in images
column4: beating humans at games like Chess and Go
column5: grouping customers based on their preferences and so on. In addition
column6: neural networks can be used in all three types of Machine Learning tasks mentioned above - supervised
column7: unsupervised
column8: and reinforcement learning.

column1: Please refer to this [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aircAruvnKk&list=PLZHQObOWTQDNU6R1_67000Dx_ZCJB-3pi video series from 3blue1brown] for more on Neural Networks.
* Machine Learning techniques perform very well - sometimes better than humans- on variety of tasks (eg. detecting cancer from x-ray images
column2: playing chess
column3: art authentication
column4: etc.)

column1: * In a variety of situations where outcomes are noisy
column2: Machine Learning models perform better than rule-based models.

column1: * Even though many methods in the field of Machine Learning have been researched quite extensively
column2: the techniques still suffer from a lack of interpretability and explainability.

column1: * Reproducibility crisis is a big problem in the field of Machine Learning research as highlighted in [6].
* Machine Learning approaches have been criticized as being a ""brute force"" approach of solving tasks.
* Machine Learning techniques only perform well when the dataset size is large. With large data sets
column2: training a ML model takes a large computational resources that can be costly in terms of time and money.

column1: Machine Learning gets criticized for not being as thorough as traditional statistical methods are. However
column2: in their essence
column3: Machine Learning techniques are not that different from statistical methods as both of them are based on rigorous mathematics and computer science. The main difference between the two fields is the fact that most of statistics is based on careful experimental design (including hypothesis setting and testing)
column4: the field of Machine Learning does not emphasize this as much as the focus is placed more on modeling the algorithm (find a function <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>f(x)</syntaxhighlight> that predicts <syntaxhighlight lang=""text"" inline>y</syntaxhighlight>) rather than on the experimental settings and assumptions about data to fit theories [4].

column2: there is nothing stopping researchers from embedding Machine Learning techniques to their research design. In fact
column3: a lot of methods that are categorized under the umbrella of the term Machine Learning have been used by statisticians and other researchers for a long time; for instance
column4: ''k-means clustering''
column5: ''hierarchical clustering''
column6: various approaches to performing ''regression''
column7: ''principle component analysis'' etc.

column2: scientists also question how Machine Learning methods
column3: which are getting more powerful in their predictive abilities
column4: will be governed and used for the benefit (or harm) of the society. Jordan and Mitchell (2015) highlight that the society lacks a set of data privacy related rules that prevent nefarious actors from potentially using the data that exists publicly or that they own can be used with powerful Machine Learning methods for their personal gain at the other' expense [7].

column1: The ubiquity of Machine Learning empowered technologies have made concerns about individual privacy and social security more relevant. Refer to Dwork [8] to learn about a concept called ''Differential Privacy'' that is closely related to data privacy in data governed world.
The field of Machine Learning is going to continue to flourish in the future as the technologies that harness Machine Learning techniques are becoming more accessible over time. As such
column2: academic research in Machine Learning techniques and their performances continue to be attractive in many areas of research moving forward.

column1: There is no question that the field of Machine Learning has been able to produce powerful models with great data processing and prediction capabilities. As a result
column2: it has produced powerful tools that governments
column3: private companies
column4: and researches alike use to further advance their objectives. In light of this
column5: Jordan and Mitchell [7] conclude that Machine Learning is likely to be one of the most transformative technologies of the 21st century.

column2: kick sampling and taking benthic cores are methods for collecting macroinvertebrate samples to obtain information about the water quality of a river
column3: lake or pond.

column1: | '''Speed of water'''|| slow|| fast-flowing|| still or slow-moving

column2: deep (tow nets)|| shallow|| shallow/ deep (using a boat)

column1: [[File:Fig1 TeichkescherMACROINVERTEBRATES.jpg|thumb|right|Figure 1. Pond net for catching invertebrates. It is important that the collecting bag is long enough to throw it over the brim to prevent invertebrates from escaping. Source: https://www.der-gartenteich.com/teichkescher-klappbar-art.nr.-84296?sPartner=google-de-ts&c=172&gclid=Cj0KCQiA1sucBhDgARIsAFoytUvZORDGHrnxv01LJzM4d4JWxv9RoA5PRK0qP6bboR64KUU2WktN_dgaArTnEALw_wcB ]]
To standardize pond netting to enable comparisons between different sites or different times at the same site
column2: two points in the water are marked with canes and the net is moved in between the poles for a certain number of times at a constant speed.

the net is emptied into a white tray such as a photographic developing tray. The net should be washed very carefully to remove all the specimens. Some specimens such as nymphs often strongly cling to the net.
a net is pulled behind a driving boat to estimate the number of zooplankton in open water. While driving the boat
column3: it is important to keep the opening of the net perpendicular to the water surface to keep the opening of the net at the same size throughout each tow. To measure the distance of towing
column4: it is helpful to add a flowmeter to the net. After towing
column5: the content of the collecting bottle is emptied into a container. To wash off all the zooplankton from the inside of the net
column6: water is splashed from the outside. It can take a considerable amount of time to transfer all the invertebrates from the net into the container. The sample is preserved with 95% ethanol.

column1: Pond nets can be used for quick surveys of the species that occur in a pond or stream. Within only three minutes of netting
column2: you can find 62% of families and 50% of species that you can catch during 18 minutes of netting (Furse et al. 1981). However
column3: this method is hard to standardize as the net-hauls always need to have the same length and the same speed and these are hard to keep up. This means that this method can be used to get an overview on the number of species
column4: but not to compare species richness and abundances between different sites or points in time.

column1: Tow nets can be used in deep
column2: open and weed-free waters. They are suitable for large areas of water
column3: especially for watching zooplankton as this is often distributed in patches. They require more work as at least two people are needed
column4: of which one steers the boat and the other one looks after the net. A major problem is to drive the boat with constant speed to standardize the method. Moreover
column5: turbulence caused by the boat might disturb the position of the net. The nets can become clogged by sediment and phytoplankton
column6: so that they lose their catching efficiency.

column1: [[File:Fig2 KicksamplingMACROINVETEBRATES.jpg|thumb|right|Figure 2. A student kick-samples a river stretch. Foto: John Rostron. Source: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/04/Sampling_in_the_River_Roding_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1430581.jpg]]
Kick sampling is a method that is applied to collect invertebrates from fast-flowing streams
column2: especially from riffles
column3: to assess the water quality. Therefore
column4: a net is held on the ground of the river with its opening facing towards the water flow direction. The substrate is disturbed by kicking and the invertebrates are dislodged and collected in the net a short distance downstream (Figure 2).

column1: The standardized version of this method consists of sampling all the micro-habitats within a stretch of a stream by kick-sampling for a total of three minutes by using a 0.9-mm-mesh pond net.
Invertebrates are stored in a white tray. The sample can be preserved with 95% ethanol. After determination of the taxa
column2: individual scores are calculated that are based on the tolerance towards oxygen depletion of each taxon. These scores are summed up to produce a biotic score for this section of the river. This score gives an estimate on the oxygen content of the river stretch and therefore
column3: of its water quality.

column1: Kick-sampling is a quick and straight-forward method to collect invertebrates from rivers. Moreover
column2: it is standardized and allows to calculate a score that can be used to estimate the water quality. However
column3: only a small proportion of invertebrates from a streambed are caught
column4: so that it cannot be used to calculate population densities.

column1: [[File:Fig3 WormsMACROINVERTEBRATES.png|thumb|right|Figure 3. a) Polychaete worm. b) Oligochaete worm. Sources: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Polychaeta_%28no%29_2.jpg https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Oligochaeta.jpg]]
Taking benthic cores is a simple way to collect invertebrates such as polychaete and oligochaete worms (Figure 3).

column2: a corer (Figure 4) is sunk into the substrate. If the substrate is firm
column3: the corer is simply pulled from the substrate. If the substrate is soft
column4: a thin piece of metal is slid across the opening of the corer to prevent the sand from falling out.

column1: The same method can be conducted in deep water as well
column2: using a boat. In this case
column3: the corer need to be longer and have a bung that fits tightly into its top end. The corer is pushed into the substrate and the bung is pushed into the top end of the corer. This creates a vacuum that prevents the substrate from falling out. The depth of the corer should be around 10 to 15 cm for a sample of 5 cm depth. The corer is then pulled out of the substrate. The benthos is then slowly removed from the corer to not injure the invertebrates. The unwanted part of the sample can be discarded now.

column2: invertebrates are extracted by wet sieving with meshes of e.g. the sizes 2 mm
column3: 1 mm and 0.5 mm for invertebrates of down to 1 mm length. To make the sorting process quicker and more efficient
column4: a 1% solution of Rose Bengal dye might be added to stain the translucent invertebrates pink. If the sorting process should take place later on
column5: the sample can be preserved with 95% ethanol.

column2: this is a relatively quick and easy method to sample benthos. However
column3: sampling in deep water is more challenging as a boat is needed.In this case
column4: the main challenge is to steer the boat into the correct position.

column1: Kick sampling underestimates the number of invertebrates attached to stones as these might not let go of the stones and therefore
column2: are not caught in the net. This applies for instance to caddisflies. While taking benthic cores
column3: some larger invertebrates might detect the disturbance in the ground and therefore
column4: retreat deeper into the ground. Other invertebrates such as chironomids might be lost from the corer during sampling (Euliss et al. 1990). In both cases
column5: some taxa get lost from the sample which causes a bias towards other taxa.

column1: The taxa that are caught by netting will be strongly determined by the speed of the net. Slow netting causes fast swimming macroinvertebrates to avoid the net whereas fast netting pushes the water in front of the net which also causes some invertebrates to not get caught in the net. Moreover
column2: invertebrate fauna differs with the depth of the water and it might be hard to always keep the net on the same depth during different rounds of netting. This makes catches from nets hard to compare. As netting tends to underestimate benthic invertebrates
column3: it is suggested to combine this method with taking benthic cores.

column1: Kick sampling and taking benthic cores can be easily standardized by taking the same number of kicks or cores at different locations. For netting
column2: this is more difficult as the taxa caught in the net strongly depend on the depth of the water and keeping the net at the same height each time can be difficult .

column1: All these methods for sampling macroinvertebrates are relatively quick and straight-forward. The time-consuming part is to afterwards sort the individuals into taxa and to determine each individual as far as possible/ needed. At the moment
column2: it is still the standard procedure to determine macroinvertebrates using an identification key and a binocular microscope.

molecular methods for species determination of macroinvertebrates are recently getting more and more precise. DNA metabarcoding enables species determination based on characteristic DNA sections without sorting the sample into taxa. The advantages are that this method is less time-consuming and enables determination up until species level. It prevents typical mistakes that come from sorting and determining individuals (2). As experts for certain groups of macroinvertebrates are rare and their work is expensive
column3: meta-barcoding can even help to save money as it is expected to get cheaper in the future (3).

column1: Preserving and storing the samples for metabarcoding does not require special treatment. Samples are still suitable for DNA metabarcoding even after one year of storage in 95% ethanol (4). Nichols et al. (2020) show that all of the more abundant macroinvertebrate families that were identified by morphological examination were also detected through metabarcoding. However
column2: the authors were unable to assign all macroinvertebrates to species as there is still a great lack of reference DNA barcodes in the DNA barcode libraries. As a result
column3: more individual barcoding is required to fill the gaps in these libraries before metabarcoding is ready to be widely used in practical applications (3).
