Making a research design;"'''In short:''' This entry revolves around the basics of a methodological design when planning empirical research.

A methodological design is one of the three central stages of any scientific endeavor that builds on a methodological approach. While analysis and interpretation are conducted after the empirical data has been gathered
column2: designing a study is what hardwires the type of knowledge that is being gathered
column3: and thus creates a path dependency on the overall scientific output
column4: for better or worse. It is next to impossible to reduce the essence of all the diversity of different approaches to methodological designs into a text
column5: yet there are some common challenges scientists face
column6: and also mistakes that are made frequently to this day. Hence nothing written here can serve as one size fits all solution
column7: yet it may serve as a starting point or safeguarding in order to get most empirical research on track. Let us start with the basics.

column1: Any given research builds on what happened so far. In order to create a tangible and tested design
column2: you need to read the literature within the specific branch of science. Read the highly cited papers
column3: and the ones that match your specific context most precisely
column4: and build on a ration from there. While many people start with textbooks
column5: this should only be done by absolute beginners. Methodological textbooks are usually too static and constructed to do justice to the specific context of your research
column6: yet they may be a good starting point. The examples in textbooks are however often rather lifeless and hard to connect to what you actually want to do. This is why you need to read papers that connect more clearly with your specific research project. If you believe that no one focussed on this specific part of knowledge
column7: then you are probably mistaken. Other researchers may not have worked within your specific location
column8: but they may have worked within systems that are comparable regarding the patterns and dynamics you want to investigate. Context matters. Try to find research that is comparable in the respective context
column9: or at least embeds your context into their approaches and results. This is a craft that takes time to master. Beginners in the craft of science usually need quite some time to read papers
column10: which is mainly because everything is new and they read all of it. With time
column11: knowledge becomes familiar and you will learn to read papers faster. However you can only create a proper scientific design if you build on previous literature. If other researchers point out that your research is flawed because you ignored or missed previous research
column12: then all is in vain. This brings us to the next point.

column1: == Stand on the shoulders of giants ==

It is perfectly normal if you do not know how to approach the design of a complex research design. There are however several workarounds. The most simple one is to start with a simple research design. Not all research needs to be complex or complicated
column2: and indeed many questions that we have towards new knowledge are based on simple methodological designs. Hence it can be more than enough to start with a simple and tested research design that you find well established within science. Take the example of interviews: We can probably agree that science has not asked enough people yet in order to integrate the knowledge they have. There are exiting opportunities out there to ask actors and stakeholders about their knowledge and experience.

column1: The next workaround is obvious: Ask an expert. The most important advise to this end is to be well prepared
column2: honor the time of the expert
column3: and trust in their opinion. People with expertise in research mounted usually thousands or hour of experience
column4: and are knowledge brokers that are quite in demand. Hence
column5: make sure to be to the point and also be aware that you may have to read up on what the researcher pinpoints you at. Yet asking experienced researchers only makes sense if your design is advanced enough to merit the input of an experienced researcher. If such an expert explains to you a robust yet simple approach
column6: go for it. Such a talk may not take longer than 10 minutes
column7: hence do not expect two hours of your time if the matter is solved with simple solutions. Be trustful
column8: remember that they usually had all the troubles you faced already
column9: if not worse. This brings us to the next point.

column1: We create scientific designs in order to make sure that our gathering of data ultimately works and produces the knowledge we potentially want to analyze and interpret. Hence
column2: we create our design based on past experience of research and researchers. We need to be realistic concerning the potential problems we may face. There are often aspects within research that are prone to errors or unforeseen circumstances and a good research design creates a certain failsafe and guard-rails against unforeseen circumstances. A low rollback in an interview campaign or moulded samples in a soil chemistry lab are a known example where your research faces challenges that a good design should fortify you against. Thus
column3: a research design is not only about what can go right and how it is done
column4: but also about what could go wrong and how do you deal with unforeseen circumstances. This is nothing to obsess about
column5: but indeed something that we should simply implement in order to be prepared and ready if all else fails. Research is often failure
column6: and then we pick ourselves up. Yet there are also more concrete safeguards.

column1: When you have enough information on a given empirical phenomenon and more sampling does not add more knowledge
column2: one can speak of saturation. We have to be aware that from a philosophy of science standpoint
column3: this type of knowledge saturation is impossible
column4: because nothing is permanent and just like this
column5: new knowledge may emerge and replace old knowledge. Yet
column6: for a snapshot in time
column7: within a given system
column8: and considering that maybe not all systems change dramatically within one and the same day
column9: or the time frame of our research
column10: saturation is a helpful concept. If you kept for example interviewing people
column11: yet did not gain more knowledge since several interviews
column12: then you probably reached saturation. Within quantitative science this is easier to achieve
column13: which is why within qualitative branches of science saturation is also a question of experience. However
column14: within a research design process
column15: saturation is useful because it allows you to plan your maximum sample
column16: yet of course then one has to consider also the absolute minimum that is necessary.

column1: An important factor in any given scientific research design is the sample size in relation to the effort and resource put into the consequential research. To this end
column2: one has to be careful not to waste resources due to sampling or analysis that do not add the knowledge we are looking for. Anticipating the resources needed for a certain research project can also simply boil down to such a simple factor as time. Will we be able to conduct qualitative interviews with thousands of people? Probably not
column3: at least not if you do not have a massive number of interviewers at your disposal. Hence
column4: a sampling is always a fine balance between anticipated knowledge and available resources. Yet
column5: for most research methods there is ample experience not only how to sample
column6: but also how much to sample.

column2: the experience concerning sample intensity is often rather clear
column3: because new research always adds a piece of the puzzle to already existing knowledge. Since deductive approaches test a specific hypothesis and are usually designed to be reproducible
column4: such research is clearly more easy to plan. What sounds like a benefit is likewise also the biggest criticism
column5: at least from a stance of philosophy of science. What seems robust can also be static
column6: and instead of adding knowledge is merely the same knowledge added
column7: or maybe becoming more precise. It is beyond this text to discuss this criticism in depth
column8: yet this underlines that part of any deductive design has always to be a discussion of the biases and limitations. This is equally true for inductive research
column9: yet at a different scale and focus. Inductive designs are more about modes and conduct than about sample size and variance. An example is the setting and preparation of a qualitative interview
column10: including ethical guidelines and clear guidelines concerning bias. Inductive research is less concerned with being reproducible which makes documentation a key issue. Especially within qualitative research an extensive documentation is key in order to enable that the path from raw data to interpreted knowledge is understandable. Since inductive research is less static
column11: a clear documentation can also contain information that is not clearly relevant from the get-go
column12: which may especially be important if other researchers re-examine inductive research later on.

column1: Yet both inductive and deductive researchers should already be aware of the initial design of the sampling and how the research is going to proceed into analysis
column2: this is also were the [[Framing a research question|framing of a research question]] becomes important. Most methodological approaches used in analysis -both concerning quantitative and qualitative approaches- have been used hundreds if not thousand of times. There is research that can pinpoint you on how to plan your analysis. Again
column3: it is central to strike a balance between a critical perspective and knowledge that is well established. Mayring is a typical example of a methodological approach that has proven its worth concerning myriads of analysis
column4: yet is also notoriously underestimated concerning the necessary experience a researcher needs. Reading up on studies applying Mayring is a good starting point
column5: yet it does not stop there
column6: since you additionally should read up the major criticism that exists concerning Mayring. Otherwise you will not be able to defend your research against known problems that could also affect your specific approach and context. Another example would be an ecological green house experiment. In such a case a respective sample and manipulation design automatically translates into the respective statistical analysis. This leads so far that in quantitative deductive research such as in much of psychology
column7: medicine or ecology the sample design is completely determined by the statistical analysis
column8: and vice versa. Such methods are well established and
column9: for the respective knowledge they produce
column10: have stood the test of time.

column2: be conservative
column3: yet test bold methods with established topics ==

column1: Conservative methods can be indeed helpful for the case of of bold topics
column2: because bold topics are often deeply contested and not yet deeply investigated. Hence
column3: a robust method can help to add credibility and robustness to an overall research design. However some research also advances methods and develops these further. In these cases tested topics can help to maintain an element of stability if a method is developed or developed further. Hence the methodological design within scientific research strongly depends on the topic as well as the underlying theories or concepts. To this end
column4: it is clear that the interplay of these three components is a matter of deep experience
column5: which is why it is so important to not only rely on the literature
column6: but also build on the expertise of experienced researchers. Therefore
column7: early career scientists may consider to build on more established procedures
column8: while it does not come as a surprise that most scientific innovations are created by already emerging or established researchers. While one would wonder if more bold ideas emerge at a younger age and evolvements based on deeper experience originate later in life
column9: this remains to be tested. Still
column10: command of the literature is vital in order to move a specific branch of science forward or even evolve a new one.

column1: == Methodological designs as a critical part of reality ==

Knowledge of the current state of the art is a precondition in order to move a specific part of science forward. Empirical reality presents an imperfect reality to us that we will probably never fully understand from an epistemological stance. Consequently
column2: research adds pieces to a puzzle
column3: yet we have to be aware that we may never see a full-blown epistemological reality as a whole. Reality is messy
column4: imperfect and deceives us. Consequently
column5: a critical perspective is a vital prerequisite for any given empirical researcher. This in turn demands a clear recognition of the literature
column6: both concerning the empirical approaches that were being utilized
column7: but also how the respective knowledge is limited in a broader stance. A critical perspective can hence range from simple and known biases towards broader questions of philosophy of science. Usually more established branches and procedures in science are more tamed when it comes to biases
column8: while more emerging areas in science often contain new challenges. Interactions with stakeholders are a good example of research that is hard to tame in a rigid methodological design
column9: and right now we rely heavily on this horizon evolving in order to gain the knowledge necessary for deep transformations. Our epistemological research being pieces of the puzzle means also that our research is a small contribution
column10: and we should never forget this. Our piece of the puzzle will hardly be a big contribution
column11: because after all
column12: what is this? Yet sometimes
column13: in rare occasions
column14: when you have a piece of the puzzle in your hand
column15: you know exactly where it fits
column16: and it snugs right into the empty space connecting all the surrounding pieces. Just as one gains from practice and experience in a puzzle
column17: one can equally gain from experience in research designs.

The distribution describes how the means of small samples of a normal distribution are distributed around the distributions true mean. T-tests can be used to investigate whether there is a significant difference between two groups regarding a mean value (two-sample t-test) or the mean in one group compared to a fixed value (one-sample t-test).

column1: Statistician Karl Pearson had a strong focus on openly integrating knowledge into overarching results
column2: and in this spirit he created one of the first systematic Meta-Analyses by integrating results from several comparable studies on typhoid into one of the first Meta-Analyses in 1904 (1
column3: 2). It was more than 35 years later that within psychology the next relevant Meta-Analysis was published: the book-length ""Extrasensory Perception After Sixty Years""
column4: authored by Pratt et al. in 1940
column5: summarizing experimental results from 1882 to 1939 (1). Despite some few studies being compiled over the next decades (most based on clinical research)
column6: more sophisticated statistical analysis tools emerging after WW2 ultimately sealed the breakthrough of the method. In the 1970s
column7: Gene V. Glass - together with many other statisticians - developed what he called the 'analysis of the analyses' (2). By integrating statistical results into a meta-analytical frame
column8: it became possible to combine results from the at the time already rising number of publications. Another key development was the availability of modern computers
column9: which allowed for the conducting pf the more sophisticated analyses
column10: along with more studies becoming available online with the rise of the Internet. Meta-analysis thus represents a method where the demand for knowledge of a different order became possible because the general data basis increased
column11: and advanced analyses were made possible by developments in statistics and the wider availability of technology. Today
column12: the method is widely established within all branches of normal science
column13: and generates knowledge way beyond individual studies
column14: yet new challenges emerge concerning which studies can be integrated
column15: and how.

column2: it is important to note that meta-analyses are deductive
column3: as they try to integrate and test results from designed studies. While these results are clearly
column4: quantitative
column5: it is important to notice that there is a trend of so called qualitative meta-analysis
column6: which we will not include here. The spatial scale depends on the scale of the studies that are integrated here. While hence a meta-analysis can be global in its focus
column7: more often than not do the studies that a meta-analysis is based on an individual scale
column8: such as in medicine and psychology. It is a matter of debate whether meta-analyses are a snapshot of the current state of the art
column9: or a look into the past. To this end
column10: it is important to recognize that the development or changes over time can be implemented into the analysis
column11: and thus be a relevant part of the hypothesis.

column1: The Meta-Analysis is a well established method that revolves around the systematic identification of relevant studies
column2: integration into a meta-analytical design
column3: and interpretation based on established norms. This process is most established within medical research and psychological science
column4: with extensive protocols being available
column5: while in other scientific disciplines the procedures are more diverse. Meta-Analyses most commonly take place in a [[Systematic Literature Review]]
column6: allowing for a quantitative analysis of the results of the gathered publications. The Meta-Analysis is thus not the same as a Systematic Literature Review
column7: but the quantitative process of integrating data within such a process.

column2: a Meta-Analysis summarizes statistics from scientific studies
column3: with estimates
column4: sample size and levels of significance as an important basis for the meta-analytical [[Glossary|framework]]. Meta-Analyses are thus able to correct for different sample sizes from the respective studies. Equally
column5: other information can be included
column6: such as different sub-groups or random factors. For instance
column7: a meta-analytical scheme in medicine is able to differentiate between studies that included children
column8: adults
column9: or both. Through such random factors
column10: a Meta-Analysis can hence include and integrate information that was not analyzed in the original studies
column11: but that only emerges from the wider analysis of multiple studies. Typical models for such an analysis are [[Mixed Effect Models]]
column12: and [[Statistics|many advanced statistical software solutions (R
column13: SPSS)]] are able to conduct a Meta-Analysis. Another important staple of Meta-Analyses are summarizing tables or figures that give an overview of the diversity of studies that were included
column14: as well as both overall effects and mean effects for sub-groups.

column1: Meta-Analyses are at least as strong (and weak) as the multiple studies that they are based on. Great care needs to be taken when identifying studies that are suitable for a meta-analytical approach
column2: since all studies should be as comparable as possible in terms of their study design. In other words
column3: unexplained variance between studies because of factors that are not taken into account should be avoided.

column1: The analysis of data within a Meta-Analysis demands a clear utilization of both the available data and the usage of a proper statistical approach. Many scientific disciplines have established standards that are robust
column2: but can also be rigid. In the long run
column3: a greater exchange of knowledge on the available approaches would be helpful.

column2: Meta-Analysis can serve as a framework to integrate quantitative results. However
column3: it remains a challenge to take more qualitative aspects of research into account in these kinds of analyses. In addition
column4: the integration of [[:Category:Inductive|inductive]] studies is often a challenge
column5: as Meta-Analyses build on comparability of studies above all else. However
column6: many Meta-Analyses are not rigid to this end
column7: and there is a tendency to not build on clear hypotheses
column8: but instead apply an inductive statistical data crunching ''post hoc'' which is subsequently translated into a pseudo-deductive pretending. Such abductive approaches are clearly a challenge and question the quality of the research in some areas of science. Meta-Analyses need to be safeguarded against scientific misconduct
column9: as these few bad examples endanger the reputation of this method
column10: and science in general.

column1: Regarding the interpretation of the results of a Meta-Analysis
column2: many studies are often somewhat prone to not properly indicate the extent and limitations of their results. While this is again a standard in some disciplines
column3: other disciplines integrate studies that are not based on comparable designs
column4: and thus create a [[Bias and Critical Thinking|Type I error]] by integrating studies that are not based on the same assumptions. It is less often that studies are excluded that should be included (Type II error)
column5: and this is also less relevant since it does not increase the error in the meta-analytical result. The main challenge of Meta-Analysis is hence that the overall procedure is not careful enough
column6: and many Meta-Analyses literally compare apples with oranges. Since the method is considered to be relevant
column7: allowing for the integration of knowledge
column8: studies using Meta-Analyses are increasingly published. It remains to be seen if the knowledge that is thus created is always sound
column9: and whether some branches of science did not overplay their hand. After all
column10: the origins of this method lie in psychology and medicine
column11: where study designs are often more comparable
column12: although the reproducibility crisis psychology even calls this into question.

column1: The prestige of a meta-analytical study is often well rooted in the long-standing career of an expert researcher
column2: and this is probably an ideal case. If an expert in a branch of research oversees the integration of knowledge in a Meta-Analysis
column3: then the balanced and nuanced evaluation of the results is safeguarded. However
column4: sometimes Meta-Analyses are more opportunistic and lack expertise that is traded off for a highly cited paper. Ideally
column5: experts on a topic and statisticians should team up to jointly create a blended piece of work that combines the long experience about a topic with the experience in the application of statistical analysis. Recognizing [[Glossary|bias]] and relevant categories in the baseline studies and taking it into account in the analysis are both of importance
column6: as this decides more than anything about the quality of a Meta-Analysis.

column2: meta-analytical approaches protruded into diverse branches of research. Recognizing the context of individual studies and integrating them into a proper meta-analytical framework and analysis scheme is probably one of the key challenges of science in the 21st Century. The availability of more and more studies
column3: and the development of analysis schemes in statistics call for larger and more diverse research groups that can cover all aspects needed when conducting a Meta-Analysis. Taking the context of individual studies into account is an already recognized challenge in Meta-Analysis
column4: and with the availability of more and more studies as well as data
column5: meta-analytical approaches are likely to grow both in terms of their extent and complexity of the analysis and interpretation in the future.

column1: After an early hype in many quantitative branches of science
column2: sobering revision should try to focus on rigor both in terms of comparability of studies as well as statistical analysis. Meta-Analysis will play a pivotal role in the integration of knowledge in the future
column3: yet if the results are flawed and the wish for a meta-analytical framework is larger than the actual data that can be included
column4: then the research landscape will suffer in the long run. Since Meta-Analyses inform future research and thus play a vital role in terms of agenda setting of future research
column5: the highest ethical standards need to be upheld
column6: as the results and responsibility of a Meta-Analysis can emerge way beyond the sum of the studies that are included. Just as medical research continuously updates the meta-analytical knowledge on relevant topics
column7: this may become a standard procedure in other areas of science as well. Establishing standards in reporting schemes
column8: safeguarding comparability in analysis
column9: and creating the norms that are needed for nuanced interpretations will take a long time. This highlights the importance of a higher level of research way beyond the ever-finer atomization of scientific disciplines. If future research is interconnected
column10: Meta-Analysis can become a guiding principle for knowledge integration.

column2: scientific methods produce knowledge.
scientific methods can be either '''reproducible''' and '''learnable'''; can be '''documented''' and are '''learnable'''; or are '''reproducible'''
column3: can be '''documented'''
column4: and are '''learnable'''.

column2: methods are approaches that help us '''gather''' data
column3: '''analyse''' data
column4: and/or '''interpret''' it. Most methods refer to either one or two of these steps
column5: and few methods refer to all three steps.

column1: * Many specific methods can be differentiated into different schools of thinking
column2: and many methods have finer differentiations or specifications in an often hierarchical fashion. These two factors make a fine but systematic overview of all methods an almost Herculean task
column3: yet on a broader scale it is quite possible to gain an overview of the methodological canon of science within a few years
column4: if you put some efforts into it. This Wiki tries to develop the baseline material for such an overview
column5: yet can of course not replace practical application of methods and the continuous exploring of empirical studies within the scientific literature.

column1: Let's start with some things you never ever want to do. Like
column2: really
column3: never.

column2: do not
column3: under any circumstances
column4: manually format any piece of text
column5: table or picture in your document. Always
column6: always use Word Styles (""Formatvorlagen""). There are many reasons why it is a good idea
column7: but the main one is that you are guaranteed to miss some font style change that happened due to you copy/pasting stuff in and you will spend roughly 3 weeks in your document to try and spot where your font style changed. Use styles instead
column8: and adjust those when necessary.

column2: do not ever use multiple line-breaks to get to the next page. You can either circumvent this with styles (see below) or at least use the CTRL+Enter shortcut to insert a pagebreak. This will prevent things from going all wonky when you change something above the page where you foolishly tried to page-break in the first place.
do not play around with picture or table formatting before your work is finished (see ""Process"" above). If you want to insert such elements during writing
column3: paste them
column4: let them stay where they are in a normal line and don't try fancy stuff such as having text float around it. You will with 100% certainty change something above or below the picture and mess up the page design. Do this only once you're done writing.

column2: now that we got these out of the way
column3: let's concern ourselves with what you should do.

column2: styles. Styles (or ""Formatvorlagen"" in the elegant German language) are a way of telling Word how a block of text should be formatted
column3: and to apply that formatting to all blocks of text that share the same type of content. They usually appear to the top right of your Word document. You can think of them as instructing Word to always treat different kinds of content (e.g. normal text
column4: headings
column5: quotations
column6: subheadings) differently
column7: and once you tell word that a block of text belongs to some category
column8: it knows how to format that block of text. This will also give you the flexibility to change the formatting of all same kinds of text in an instant throughout the whole document.

column1: One of the most important aspects of this is using **heading styles**. This allows you to automatically generate a table of contents
column2: navigate within your document more quickly and have an array of options to better format your document. For example
column3: you can tell Word to always insert a page break before your level 1 headings
column4: which is saving you the trouble of either putting in a dozen line-breaks (which you should never ever do) or using CTRL+Enter (which is better but sometimes still suboptimal). If you use heading styles
column5: you can easily insert an **automatically generated table of contents** by going to ""References"" → ""Table of Contents"" and select one of the options.

column1: You can also use this to quickly navigate your document through using Word's **navigation bar**. Go to ""View"" (""Ansicht"") and look for the checkbox ""Navigation bar"" (""Navigationsbereich""). This might seem minute but is a big comfort plus when working with larger documents like a thesis.
Another aspect comes into play when you copy in external content. Always make sure that you only **copy the text
column2: not the formatting**. Word gives you that option when you paste something in: a little box appears next to the pasted text
column3: where you can select to only paste the text without formatting. This will automatically format the pasted text into default style and save you the trouble of manually formatting it.

column1: You should definitely familiarize yourself with the inner workings of the ""track changes"" and ""comment"" functions of word. They allow you to clarify changes between versions as well as give and receive feedback in a way that is clearly intelligible and does not mess with your documents. To find these in Word
column2: go to ""Review"" (""Überprüfen""). You will find the comment button
column3: as well as the option to activate ""track changes"". Track changes will highlight all the changes you have done while it is active
column4: and will allow you or others to either accept or decline them.

column2: with Mindfulness being the seventh practice.''' Source: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Noble_Eightfold_Path Wikipedia]

column1: Mindfulness is a [[Glossary|concept]] with diverse facets. In principle
column2: it aims at clearing your mind to be in the here and now
column3: independent of the normative [[Glossary|assumptions]] that typically form our train of thought. Most people that practice mindfulness have a routine and regular rhythm
column4: and often follow one of the several schools of thinking that exist. Mindfulness has been practiced since thousands of years
column5: already starting before the rise of Buddhism
column6: and in the context of many diverse but often religious schools of thinking.

column1: Since the goal of mindfulness is basically having ""no mind""
column2: it is counterintuitive to approach the practice with any clear goal. Pragmatically speaking
column3: one could say that mindfulness practices are known to help people balance feelings of anxiety
column4: stress and unhappiness. Many psychological challenges thus seem to show positive developments due to mindfulness practice. Traditionally
column5: mindfulness is the seventh of the eight parts of the buddhist practice aiming to become free.

column1: The easiest form of mindfulness is to sit in an upright position
column2: and to breathe in
column3: and breathe out. Counting your breath and trying to breathe deeply and calmly is the most fundamental mindfulness exercises. As part of the noble eightfold path in Buddhism
column4: mindfulness became a key practice in Eastern monastic cultures ranging across Asia. Zazen – sitting meditation – is a key approach in Zen Buddhism
column5: whereas other schools of Buddhism have different approaches. Common approaches try to explore the origins of our thoughts and emotions
column6: or our interconnectedness with other people.

column1: [[File:Headspace - Mindfulness.png|300px|thumb|left|'''[https://www.headspace.com/de Headspace] is an app that can help you meditate'''
column2: which may be a way of practicing Mindfulness for you. Source: Headspace]]

column1: During the last decades mindfulness took a strong tooting in the western world
column2: and the commercialisation of the principle of mindfulness led to the development of several approaches and even apps
column3: like Headspace
column4: that can introduce lay people to a regular practice. The Internet contains many resources
column5: yet it should be stressed that such approaches are often far away from the original starting point of mindfulness.

column1: Mindfulness has been hyped as yet another self-optimisation tool. However
column2: mindfulness is not an end in itself
column3: but can be seen as a practice of a calm mind. Sweeping the floor is a common metaphor for emptying your mind. Our mind is constantly rambling around – often referred to as the monkey mind –
column4: but there are several steps to recognise
column5: interact with
column6: train and finally calm your monkey mind (for tips on how to quiet the monkey mind
column7: have a look at [https://www.forbes.com/sites/alicegwalton/2017/02/28/8-science-based-tricks-for-quieting-the-monkey-mind/#6596e6a51af6 this article]). Just like sports
column8: mindfulness exercises are a practice where one gets better over time.

column1: If you want to establish a mindfulness practice for yourself
column2: you could try out the app Headspace or the aforementioned breathing exercises. Other ideas that you can find online include journaling
column3: doing a body scan
column4: or even Yoga. You could also start by going on a walk by yourself in nature without any technical distractions – just observing what you can see
column5: hear
column6: or smell. Mindfulness is a practice you can implement in everyday activities like doing the dishes
column7: cleaning
column8: or eating a meal as well. The goal here is to stay in the present moment without seeking distractions or judging situations. Another common mindfulness practice is writing a gratitude journal
column9: which can help you to become more aware of the things we can be grateful for in live. This practice has proven to increase the well being of many people
column10: and is a good mindfulness approach for people that do not want to get into a mediation. Yoga
column11: Tai Chi and other physical body exercises can have strong components of mindfulness as well. You will find that a regular mindfulness practice helps you relieve stress and fear
column12: can increase feelings of peace and gratitude
column13: and generally makes you feel more calm and focused. Try it out!

column1: '''Mindmapping is a tool for the visual organisation of information'''
column2: showing ideas
column3: words
column4: names and more in relation to a central topic and to each other. The focus is on structuring information in a way that provides a good overview of a topic and supports [[Glossary|communication]] and [[Glossary|creativity.]]

column1: * Visualise information in an intuitive structure for a good overview of key elements of a topic.
* Better communicate and structure information for individual and team work.
Although this claim is not fully supported by research
column2: the underlying idea of a Mindmap is to mimick the way the brain structures information by creating a map of words
column3: hence the name. Yet indeed
column4: research has indicated that this approach to structuring information is an efficient way of memorizing and understanding information. The Mindmap was created and propagated in the 1970s by Tony Buzan.

column1: [[File:Mindmap Example 2.jpg|600px|thumb|right|'''MindMaps can take the form of trees
column2: with the words on the branches
column3: or clusters/bubbles
column4: as in this example.''' They can also be visually improved not only through the usage of colors
column5: but also by varying the thickness and length of ties
column6: and using symbols. Source: [https://www.thetutorteam.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/shutterstock_712786150.jpg thetutorteam.com]]]

column1: '''A Mindmap enables the visual arrangement of various types of information
column2: including tasks
column3: key concepts
column4: important topics
column5: names and more.''' It allows for a quick overview of all relevant information items on a topic at a glance. It helps keeping track of important elements of a topic
column6: and may support communication of information to other people
column7: for example in meetings. A Mindmap can also be a good tool for a [[Glossary|brainstorming]] process
column8: since it does not focus too much on the exact relationships between the visualised elements
column9: but revolves around a more intuitive approach of arranging information.

column1: The central topic is written into the center of the [[Glossary|visualisation]] (e.g. a whiteboard
column2: with a digital tool
column3: or a large horizontally arranged sheet of paper). '''This central topic can be see as a city center on a city map
column4: and all relevant information items then are arranged around it like different districts of the city.''' The information items should focus on the most important terms and data
column5: and omit any unncessary details. These elements may be connected to the central topic through lines
column6: like streets
column7: or branches
column8: resulting in a web structure. '''Elements may be subordinate to other elements
column9: indicating nestedness of the information.''' Colors
column10: symbols and images may be used to further structure the differences and similaritiess between different areas of the map
column11: and the length thickness of the connections may be varied to indicate the importance of connections.

Mixed Effect Models;"[[File:ConceptMixedEffectModels.png|450px|frameless|left|[[Sustainability Methods:About|Method categorization]] for [[Mixed Effect Models]]]]
'''In short:''' Mixed Effect Models are stastistical approaches that contain both fixed and random effects
column2: i.e. models that analyse linear relations while decreasing the variance of other factors.

column1: [[File:Mixed Effects Model.png|400px|thumb|right|'''SCOPUS hits per year for Mixed Effects Models until 2020.''' Search terms: 'Mixed Effects Model' in Title
column2: Abstract
column3: Keywords. Source: own.]]

column1: Mixed Effect Models were a continuation of Fisher's introduction of random factors into the Analysis of Variance. Fisher saw the necessity not only to focus on what we want to know in a statistical design
column2: but also what information we likely want to minimize in terms of their impact on the results. Fisher's experiments on agricultural fields focused on taming variance within experiments through the use of replicates
column3: yet he was strongly aware that underlying factors such as different agricultural fields and their unique combinations of environmental factors would inadvertedly impact the results. He thus developed the random factor implementation
column4: and Charles Roy Henderson took this to the next level by creating the necessary calculations to allow for linear unbiased estimates. These approaches allowed for the development of previously unmatched designs in terms of the complexity of hypotheses that could be tested
column5: and also opened the door to the analysis of complex datasets that are beyond the sphere of purely deductively designed datasets. It is thus not surprising that Mixed Effect Models rose to prominence in such diverse disciplines as psychology
column6: social science
column7: physics
column8: and ecology.

column1: Mixed Effect Models are - mechanically speaking - one step further with regards to the combination of [[Regression Analysis|regression analysis]] and Analysis of Variance
column2: as they can combine the strengths of both these approaches: '''Mixed Effects Models are able to incorporate both [[Data formats|categorical and/or continuous]] independent variables'''. Since Mixed Effect Models were further developed into [[Generalized Linear Models|Generalized Linear Mixed Effect Models]]
column3: they are also able to incorporate different distributions concerning the dependent variable.

column2: the diverse algorithmic foundations to calculate Mixed Effect Models (such as maximum likelihood and restricted maximum likelihood) allow for more statistical power
column3: which is why Mixed Effect Models often work slightly better compared to standard regressions. The main strength of Mixed Effect Models is however not how they can deal with fixed effects
column4: but that they are able to incorporate random effects as well. '''The combination of these possibilities makes (generalised) Mixed Effect Models the swiss army knife of univariate statistics.''' No statistical model to date is able to analyse a broader range of data
column5: and Mixed Effect Models are the gold standard in deductive designs.

column2: these models serve as a baseline for the whole scheme of analysis
column3: and thus already help researchers to design and plan their whole data campaign. Naturally
column4: then
column5: these models are the heart of the analysis
column6: and depending on the discipline
column7: the interpretation can range from widely established norms (e.g. in medicine) to pushing the envelope in those parts of science where it is still unclear which variance is being tamed
column8: and which cannot be tamed. Basically
column9: all sorts of quantitative data can inform Mixed Effect Models
column10: and software applications such as R
column11: Python and SARS offer broad arrays of analysis solutions
column12: which are still continuously developed. Mixed Effect Models are not easy to learn
column13: and they are often hard to tame. Within such advanced statistical analysis
column14: experience is key
column15: and practice is essential in order to become versatile in the application of (generalised) Mixed Effect Models.

column1: '''The biggest strength of Mixed Effect Models is how versatile they are.''' There is hardly any part of univariate statistics that can not be done by Mixed Effect Models
column2: or to rephrase it
column3: there is hardly any part of advanced statistics that - even if it can be made by other models - cannot be done ''better'' by Mixed Effect Models. They surpass the Analyis of Variance in terms of statistical power
column4: eclipse Regressions by being better able to consider the complexities of real world datasets
column5: and allow for a planning and understanding of random variance that brings science one step closer to acknowledge that there are things that we want to know
column6: and things we do not want to know.

column1: Take the example of many studies in medicine that investigate how a certain drug works on people to cure a disease. To this end
column2: you want to know the effect the drug has on the prognosis of the patients. What you do not want to know is whether people are worse off if they are older
column3: have a lack of exercise or an unhealthy diet. All these single effects do not matter for you
column4: because it is well known that the prognosis often gets worse with higher age
column5: and factors such as lack of exercise and unhealthy diet choices. What you may want to know
column6: is whether the drug works better or worse in people that have unhealthy diet choice
column7: are older or lack regular exercise. These interaction can be meaningfully investigated by Mixed Effect Models. '''All positive factors' variance is minimised
column8: while the effect of the drug as well as its interactions with the other factors can be tested.''' This makes Mixed Effect Models so powerful
column9: as you can implement them in a way that allows to investigate quite complex hypotheses or questions.

column1: The greatest disadvantage of Mixed Effect Models is the level of experience that is necessary to implement them in a meaningful way. Designing studies takes a lot of experience
column2: and the current form of peer-review does often not allow to present the complex thinking that goes into the design of advanced studies (Paper BEF China design). There is hence a discrepancy in how people implement studies
column3: and how other researchers can understand and emulate these approaches. Mixed Effect Models are also an example where textbook knowledge is not saturated yet
column4: hence books are rather quickly outdated
column5: and also often do not offer exhausting examples to real life problems researchers may face when designing studies. Medicine and psychology are offering growing resources to this end
column6: since here the preregistration of studies due to the reproducibility crisis offers a glimpse in the design of scientific studies.

column1: The lack of experience in how to design and conduct Mixed Effect Models-driven studies leads to the critical reality that more often than not
column2: there are flaws in the application of the method. While this got gradually less bad over time
column3: it is still a matter of debate whether every published study with these models does justice to the original idea. Especially around the millennium
column4: there was almost a hype in some branches of science regarding how fancy Mixed Effect Models were considered
column5: and not all applications were sound and necessary. Mixed Effect Models can also make the world more complicated than it is: sometimes a regression is just a regression is just a regression.

column1: Mixed Effect Models are the gold standard when it comes to reducing complexities into constructs
column2: for better or worse. All variables that go into a Mixed Effect Model are normative choices
column3: and these choices matter deeply. First of all
column4: many people struggle to decide which variables are about fixed variance
column5: and which variables are relevant as random variance. Second
column6: how are these variables constructed - are they continuous or categorical
column7: and if the latter
column8: what is the reasoning behind the category levels? Designing Mixed Effect Modell studies is thus definitely a part of advanced statistics
column9: and this is even harder when it comes to integrating non-designed datasets into a Mixed Effect Model [[Glossary|framework]]. Care and experience are needed to evaluate sample sizes
column10: variance across levels and variables. This brings us to the most crucial point: Model inspection.

column1: '''Mixed Effect Models are built on a litany of preconditions
column2: most of which most researchers choose to conveniently ignore.''' In my experience
column3: this is more often than not ok
column4: because it does not matter. Mixed Effect Models are - bless the maximum likelihood estimation - very sturdy. It is hard to find a model that does not have some predictive or explanatory value
column5: even if hardly any pre-conditions are met. Still
column6: this does not mean that we should ignore these. In order to sleep safe and sound at night
column7: I am almost obsessed with model inspection
column8: checking variance across levels
column9: looking at the residuals
column10: and looking for gaps and flaws in the model's fit. We should be really conservative to this end
column11: because by focusing on fixed and random variance
column12: we potentiate things that could go wrong. As I said
column13: more often than not
column14: this is not the case
column15: but I propose to be super conservative when it comes to your model outcome. In order to get there
column16: we need yet another thing: Model simplification.

column1: Mixed Effect Models lead the forefront of statistics
column2: and this might be the reason why the implementation of AIC (Akaike Information Criterion) as a parsimony-based evaluation criterion is more abundant here when compared to other statistical approaches. P-values fell widely out of fashion in many branches of science
column3: as did the reporting of full models. Instead
column4: model reduction based on information criteria approaches is on the rise
column5: reporting parsimonious models that honour [[Why_statistics_matters#Occam.27s_razor | Occam's razor]]. Starting with the maximum model
column6: these approaches reduce the model until it is the minimum adequate model - in other words
column7: the model that is as simple as possible
column8: but as complex as necessary. The AIC is about the equivalent of a p-value of 0.12
column9: depending on the sample size
column10: hence beware that the main question may be the difference from the null model. In other words
column11: a model that is better from the Null model
column12: but only just so based on the AIC
column13: may not be significant because the p-value would be around 0.12. This links to the next point: Explanatory power.

column1: There has been some sort of a revival of r<sup>2</sup> values lately
column2: mainly based on the suggestion of r<sup>2</sup> values that can be utilised for Mixed Effect Models. I deeply reject these approaches. First of all
column3: Mixed Effect Models are not about how much the model explains
column4: but whether the results are meaningfully different from the null model. I can understand that in a cancer study I would want to know how much my model may help people
column5: hence an occasional glance of the fitted value against the original values may do no harm. However
column6: r<sup>2</sup> in Mixed Effect Models is - to me - a step into the bad old days when we evaluated the worth of a model because of its ability to explain variance. This led to a lot of feeble discussions
column7: of which I only mention here the debate on how good a model needs to be in terms of these values to be not bad
column8: and vice versa. This is obviously a problem
column9: and such normative judgements are a reason why statistics have such a bad reputation. Second
column10: people are starting again to actually report their models based on the r<sup>2</sup>  value
column11: and even have their model selection not independent of the r<sup>2</sup> value. This is something that should be bygone
column12: yet it is not. '''Beware of the r<sup>2</sup> value
column13: it is only deceiving you in Mixed Effect Models.''' Third
column14: r<sup>2</sup> values in Mixed Effect Models are deeply problematic because they cannot take the complexity of the random variance into account. Hence
column15: r<sup>2</sup> values in Mixed Effect Models make us go back to the other good old days
column16: when mean values were ruling the outcomes of science. Today
column17: we are closer to an understanding where variance matters
column18: and why would we embrace that. Ok
column19: it comes with a longer learning curve
column20: but I think that the good old reduction to the mean was nothing but mean.

column1: Another very important point regarding Mixed Effect Models is that they - probably more than any statistical method - remark the point where experts in one method (say for example interviews) now needed to learn how to conduct interviews as a scientific method
column2: but also needed to learn advanced statistics in the form of Mixed Effect Models. This creates a double burden
column3: and while learning several methods can be good to embrace a more diverse understanding
column4: it is also challenging
column5: and highlights a new development. Today
column6: statistical analysis are increasingly outsourced to experts
column7: and I consider this to be a generally good development. In my own experience
column8: it takes a few thousand hours to become versatile at Mixed Effect Models
column9: and modern science is increasingly built on collaboration.

column1: In terms of Mixed Effect Models
column2: language barriers and the norms of specific disciplines are rather strong. Explaining the basics of these advanced statistics to colleagues is an art in itself
column3: just as the experience of researchers being versatile in [[Semi-structured Interview|Interview]]s cannot be reduced into a few hours of learning. Education in science needs to tackle this head on
column4: and stop teaching statistics that are outdated and hardly published. I suggest that at least on a Master's level
column5: in the long run
column6: all students from the quantitative domain should be able to understand the preconditions and benefits of Mixed Effect Models
column7: but this is something for the distant future. Today
column8: PhD students being versatile in Mixed Effect Models are still outliers. Let us all hope that this statement will be outdated rather sooner than later. Mixed Effect Models are surely powerful and quite adaptable
column9: and are increasingly becoming a part of normal science. Honouring the complexity of the world while still deriving value statements based on statistical analyses has never been more advanced on a broader scale. '''Still
column10: statisticians need to recognize the limitations of real world data
column11: and researchers utilising these need to honour the preconditions and pitfalls of these analyses'''. Current science is in my perception far away from reporting reproducible analyses
column12: meaning that one and the same dataset will be differently analysed by Mixed Effect Model approaches
column13: partly based on experience
column14: partly based on differences between disciplines
column15: and probably also because of many other factors. Mixed Effect Models need to be consolidated and unified
column16: which would make normale science probably better than ever.

column1: The [[Table of Contributors|author]] of this entry is Henrik von Wehrden."
Mixed Methods;"'''Note:''' The German version of this entry can be found here: [[Mixed Methods (German)]].
'''Note:''' This entry revolves around mixed methods in general. For examples of mixed methods research designs
column2: have a look at [[Mixed Methods Examples]]. For more on mixed methods and statistics
column3: please refer to the entry on [[Statistics and mixed methods]].

column1: '''In short:''' This entry revolves around the combination of scientific methods and what to be aware of when doing so.

Mixed Methods refers in the broadest sense to the combination of elements of a qualitative and a quantitative research approach within one investigation or several investigations related to each other. The combination can refer to the underlying scientific theoretical position and the research question
column2: to the methods of data collection or analysis
column3: or to the procedures of interpretation and quality assurance"" (Schreier & Odag
column5: definition based on Johnson
column6: Onwuegbuzie & Turner 2007

column1: Mixed methods have become almost like a standard reply to any given problem that researchers define to be outside of the domain of normal science. These days
column2: mixed methods are almost like a mantra
column3: a testimony of beliefs
column4: a confirmation of openness and the recognition of diversity. One could speak of a confusion concerning mixed methods
column5: where researchers speak about ontology (how we make sense of what we know about the world)
column6: when they should actually speak about epistemology (what we know about the world and how we create this knowledge); the talk of mixed methods is drifting into a category mistake that then becomes a categorical mistake. Mixed methods are one of the moon shots of modern science
column7: they are proclaimed
column8: envisioned and continuously highlighted
column9: but the question is now: ''How do we get to the moon of mixed methods?''

column1: The first set of challenges when trying to bring mixed methods into reality are epistemological problems. Among the most profane yet widely unsolved questions is the integration of different data formats. While we can code data into qualitative and quantitative information into tables
column2: this can hardly do justice to the diversity of knowledge within science. Even the integration of data within tables poses many unsolved problems. For instance
column3: different methods can have not only a different understanding but also diverging indications of validity and plausibility. While these are pivotal in the realms of quantitative data but also in logic
column4: validity and plausibility may be totally wrong criteria regarding much knowledge from qualitative domains where context and transferability - or the lack thereof - are more relevant. Some forms of knowledge are important to many
column5: while other forms of knowledge are important to few. Yet
column6: these forms of knowledge are still important
column7: and science often ignores diversity more strongly than we should.

column1: While this is a trivial statement as such

column1: == Facilitation - the gap between the epistemological and the ontological ==
In order to enable successful integration and bridge the epistemological challenges with the ontological problems
column2: facilitation becomes a key part of mixed method research. This demands first and foremost the willingness to be critical about one's own positionality and reflection concerning the critical positioning in the [[History of Methods|history of science]]. Otherwise
column3: the limitations of the knowledge in the respective area of science is often ignored
column4: leading to a wrong recognition of these limitations. '''Many conflicts between different disciplines and their methodological epistemologies are nothing but an unreflected rejection of the unknown.''' Consequently
column5: it takes time and effort to not only locate yourself within the canon of knowledge production
column6: but to also value and appreciate other forms of knowledge. A simple division into a ''better or worse'' highlights the shortcomings of our understanding concerning the [[Normativity of Methods|normativity of methods]].

column1: An example of a tangible problem when facilitating diverse researchers that use different scientific methods is language. Misunderstanding is sometimes simply rooted in a lack of understanding
column2: quite literally in the wording and jargon. In extreme cases
column3: some disciplines even use the same methods but do not even realise this
column4: because the individual methodological developments led to different wordings for the same details of the respective methodologies. Imagine how these challenges are growing exponentially if you even talk about different methodologies. This leads to the most important point in facilitation: [[Glossary|trust]]. If everyone wanted to understand every method that every branch of science utilises
column5: this would be at a tremendous cost of resources. Consequently
column6: a lack of understanding can alternatively be overcome by trust
column7: which is often rooted in joint experience. There is currently an increasing recognition of the importance of facilitation
column8: yet this also needs to recognise the ontological challenges scientists face when attempting research built on mixed methods approaches.

column1: Much of current research is embedded into specific theories of science
column2: and many scientists are not even aware to which theory of science they are counted. Despite a growing [[Bias and Critical Thinking|criticism of positivism]]
column3: most of the current knowledge production still falls into this domain
column4: and this creates also problems of mixed methods research. Positivism does not only create a ranking where some forms of science are - at least indirectly - considered of different value. Positivism also claims to generate objective truths
column5: which - not surprisingly - creates a problem if other domains of science also claim to create objective truths about the very same mechanisms
column6: entities and patterns. Modern science needs to integrate an active and reflexive theory of science
column7: and some would argue that this demands an integration of ethics as well. How else would we evaluate the knowledge that science produces if we do not try to evaluate through different ontological lenses if it actually makes sense? '''There is a pronounced disconnection between the scientific knowledge production and how we make sense of it.''' Recent claims highlighted that there are some dimensions of knowledge that may be restricted to ethics
column8: which could be seen as an argumentation that we need active knowledge about ethics in order to claim responsibility for our research results. Empirical research is currently mostly far away from claiming ethical responsibility for its research results
column9: let alone the consequences of these. Time will tell if the disconnection between the epistemological and the ontological may be overcome. To this end
column10: mixed methods research may pose a vital and effective cornerstone
column11: as it can facilitate reflection through active research. By using research as a boundary object to bridge diverse domains of science
column12: we may overcome our differences
column13: and focus instead on our joint goals. We will have to see how quickly this may emerge.

column1: One of the nicest metaphors of interlinking methods is the Japanese word ''Bokeh''. ''Bokeh'' means basically 'depth of field'
column2: which is the effect when you have a really beautiful camera lens
column3: and keep the aperture - the opening of the lens - very wide. Photographs made in this setting typically have a laser sharp foreground
column4: and a beautifully blurry background. You have one very crisp level of distance
column5: and the other level is like a washed watercolour matrix. A pro photographer or tech geek will appreciate such a photo with a ""Whoa
column6: nice Bokeh"". Mixed method designs can be set up in a similar way. '''While you have one method focusing on something in the foreground
column7: other methods can give you a blurry understanding of the background.''' Negotiating and designing each method's role in a mixed method setting is central in order to clarify which method demands which depth and focus

column14: and what is in the background. Statistics may give you some general information about a case study setting and its background

column1: The project focuses on the Trans Mongolian Railroad Corridor (TMR) between Ulaanbaatar and Erenhot
column2: where fenced railroad - a consequence of a growing mining sector - creates a barrier for nomands and their herds
column3: leads to habitat fragmentation for the movement of wildlife
column4: and imposes a danger to both. This '''conflict between infrastructure
column5: local populations and animals''' is in the center of this research proposal. Two research proposals are presented here
column6: which both revolve around the idea of identifying potential spots for railway crossings for wildlife and nomads. Landsat [[Geographical Information Systems|'''GIS''']] data
column7: as well as wildlife movement GIS data from previous studies
column8: are proposed be analyzed to examine topographical preconditions for railway crossings
column9: as well as vegetation changes and gazelle migration patterns to identify relevant spots for local wildlife. In addition
column10: data from [[Semi-structured Interview|'''semi-structured interviews''']] with ten nomad herders shall be gathered and analyzed to assess if
column11: and where
column12: they would be interested in also using railway crossings in accordance with their traditional and personal requirements. In combination
column13: the gathered data shall help identify potential spots for railway crossings
column14: which can be installed subsequently.

column1: Model reduction;"== '''Starting to engage with model reduction - an initial approach''' ==
The diverse approaches of model reduction
column2: model comparison and model simplification within univariate statistics are more or less stuck between deep dogmas of specific schools of thought and modes of conduct that are closer to alchemy as it lacks transparency
column3: reproducibility and transferable procedures. Methodology therefore actively contributes to the diverse crises in different branches of science that struggle to generate reproducible results
column4: coherent designs or transferable knowledge. The main challenge in the hemisphere of model treatments (including comparison
column5: reduction and simplification) are the diverse approaches available and the almost uncountable control measures and parameters. It would indeed take at least dozens of example to reach some sort of saturation in knowledge to to justice to any given dataset using univariate statistics alone. Still
column6: there are approaches that are staples and that need to be applied under any given circumstances. In addition
column7: the general tendency of any given form of model reduction is clear: Negotiating the point between complexity and simplicity. Occam's razor is thus at the heart of the overall philosophy of model reduction
column8: and it will be up to any given analysis to honour this approach within a given analysis. Within this living document
column9: we try to develop a learning curve to create an analytical framework that can aid an initial analysis of any given dataset within the hemisphere of univariate statistics.

column2: we will understand model reduction always as some form of model simplification
column3: making the latter term futile. Model comparison is thus a means to an end
column4: because if you have a deductive approach i.e. clear and testable hypotheses
column5: you compare the different models that represent these hypotheses. Model reduction is thus the ultimate and best term to describe the wider hemisphere that is Occam's razor in practise. We have a somewhat maximum model
column6: which at its worst are all variables and maybe even their respective combinations. This maximum model has several problems. First of all
column7: variables may be redundant
column8: explain partly the same
column9: and fall under the fallacy of multicollinearity. The second problem of a maximum model is that it is very difficult to interpret
column10: because it may -depending on the dataset-contain a lot of variables and associated statistical results. Interpreting such results can be a challenge
column11: and does not exactly help to come to pragmatic information that may inform decision or policy. Lastly
column12: statistical analysis based on probabilities has a flawed if not altogether boring view on maximum models
column13: since probabilities change with increasing model reduction. Hence maximum models are nothing but a starting point. These may be informed by previous knowledge
column14: since clear hypotheses are usually already more specific than brute force approaches.

column1: The most blunt approach to any form of model reduction of a maximum model is a stepwise procedure. Based on p-values or other criteria such as AIC
column2: a stepwise procedure allow to boil down any given model until only significant or otherwise statistically meaningful variables remain. While you can start from a maximum model that is boiled down which equals a backward selection
column3: and a model starting with one predictor that subsequently adds more and more predictor variables and is named a forward selection
column4: there is even a combination of these two. Stepwise procedures and not smart but brute force approaches that are only based on statistical evaluations
column5: yet not necessarily very good ones. No experience or preconceived knowledge is included
column6: hence such stepwise procedures are nothing but buckshot approaches that boil any given dataset down
column7: and are not prone against many of the errors that may happen along the way. Hence stepwise procedures should be avoided at all costs
column8: or at least be seen as the non-smart brute force tool they are.

column2: one should always inspect all data initially regarding the statistical distributions and prevalences. Concretely
column3: one should check the datasets for outliers
column4: extremely skewed distributions or larger gaps as well as other potentially problematic representations. All sorts of qualitative data needs to be checked for a sufficient sample size across all factor levels. Equally
column5: missing values need to be either replaced by averages or respective data lines be excluded. There is no rule of thumb on how to reduce a dataset riddled with missing values. Ideally
column6: one should check the whole dataset and filter for redundancies. Redundant variables can be traded off to exclude variables that re redundant and contain more NAs
column7: and keep the ones that have a similar explanatory power but less missing values.

column1: The simplest approach to look for redundancies are correlations. Pearson correlation even do not demand a normal distribution
column2: hence these can be thrown onto any given combination of continuous variables and allow for identifying which variables explain fairly similar information. The word ""fairly"" is once more hard to define. All variables that are higher collected than a correlation coefficient of 0.9 are definitely redundant. Anything between 0.7 and 0.9 is suspicious
column3: and should ideally be also excluded
column4: that is one of the two variables. Correlation coefficients below 0.7 may be redundant
column5: yet this danger is clearly lower. A more integrated approach that has the benefit to be graphically appealing are ordinations
column6: with principal component analysis being the main tool for continuous variables. based on the normal distribution
column7: this analysis represents a form of dimension reduction
column8: where the main variances of datasets are reduced to artificial axes or dimensions. The axis are orthogonally related
column9: which means that they are maximally unrelated. Whatever information the first axis contains
column10: the second axis contains exactly not this information
column11: and so on. This allows to filter large datasets with many variables into few artificial axis while maintaining much of the information. However
column12: one needs to be careful since these artificial axis are not the real variables
column13: but synthetic reductions. Still
column14: the PCA has proven valuable to check for redundancies
column15: also since these can be graphically represented.

column1: The last way to check for redundancies within concrete models is the variance inflation factor. This measure allowed to check regression models for redundant predictors. If any of the values is above 5
column2: or some argue above 10
column3: then the respective variable needs to be excluded. Now if you want to keep this special variable
column4: you have to identify other variables redundant with this one
column5: and exclude these. Hence the VIF can guide you model constructions and is the ultimate safeguard to exclude all variables that are redundant.

column1: Once you thus created models that contain non-redundant variables
column2: the next question is how you reduce the model or models that you have based on your initial hypotheses. In the past
column3: the usual way within probability based statistics was a subsequent reduction based on p-values. Within each step
column4: the non-significant variable with the highest p-value would be excluded until only significant variables remain. This minimum adequate mode based on a subsequent reduction based on p-values still needs to be tested against the Null model. However
column5: p-value driven model reductions are sometimes prone to errors. Defining different and clearly defined models before the analysis and then compare these models based on AIC values is clearly superior
column6: and inflicts less bias. An information theoretical approach compares clearly specified models against the Null Model based on the AIC
column7: and the value with the lowest AIC is considered to be the best. However
column8: this model needs to be at least 2 lower than the second best model
column9: otherwise these two models need to be averaged. This approach safeguards against statistical fishing
column10: and can be soldiered a gold standard in deductive analysis.

column1: Within inductive analysis it is less clear how to proceed best. Technically
column2: one can only proceed based on AIC values. Again
column3: there is a brute force approach that boils the maximum model down based on permutations of all combinations. However
column4: this approach can be again considered to be statistical fishing
column5: since no clear hypothesis are tested. While an AIC driven approach failsafes against the worst dangers of statistical fishing
column6: it is clear that if you have no questions
column7: then you also have no answers. Hence a purely inductive analysis does not really make sense
column8: yet you can find the inner relations and main patterns of the dataset regardless of your approach
column9: may it bee inductive or deductive.

column2: any given dataset should reveal the same results based on this rigid analysis pathway and framework. However
column3: the scientific community developed different approaches
column4: and there are diverse schools of thinking
column5: which ultimately leads to different approaches being out there. Different analysts may come up with different results. This exemplifies that statistics are not fully unleashed yet
column6: but are indeed still evolving
column7: and not necessarily about reproducible analysis. Keep that in mind when you read analysis
column8: and be conservative in your own analysis. Keep no stone unturned
column9: and go down any rabbit hole you can find."

Multi-Criteria Decision Making in Python;"'''THIS ARTICLE IS STILL IN EDITING MODE'''
Decision-making processes are part of our everyday life. Some decisions require very little effort and thought. However
column2: there are real-life problems
column3: we would have to evaluate many criteria for making a decision. The situation becomes more difficult when these criteria conflict with each other!

column2: a student needs to consider different criteria to choose a subject for an undergraduate program at a university. These criteria include not only the student’s interest but also prospects
column3: location of the university
column4: size of the study program
column5: etc. But we should consider that each of these criteria would have different importance from our point of view.

column2: a decision-making process can be divided into 8 steps as follows:

column1: 1. '''Define the problem''': Accurate problem definition is very crucial for effective decision making and all the stakeholders must agree with its definition.
2. '''Determine requirements''': Requirements indicate what conditions must be met for any acceptable solution. If we want to explain it in mathematical form
column2: the constraints describing the set of feasible solutions are considered to be requirements of the decision problem.

column1: 3. '''Establish goals''': The goals we define can be inconsistent and conflicting. This is very common in the real world. For this reason
column2: various decision-making methods have been developed.

column1: 4. '''Identify alternatives''': As we collect information about our problem
column2: we would identify several possible alternatives which lead us to our desired conditions.

we determine the decision criteria that evaluate and compare our alternatives. Criteria should be chosen to represent the preferences of potential stakeholders. Criteria should have the following features:

column1: * Comprehensive and determined based on our goals
* Not be too large in number
column2: just a few!

column1: 6. '''Choose a decision-making tool''': To be able to choose the right tool and methods
column2: we must consider the definition of the problem and also the goals of the decision-makers.

column1: 7. '''Evaluate alternatives against criteria''': By using the decision-making tool
column2: it is possible to rank the alternatives or get a subset of the possible solutions.

column1: 8. '''Validate solutions against the problem statement''': In the last step
column2: we must check whether the chosen options meet the requirements and goals of the decision-making problem.
