'''In short:''' Narrative Research describes qualitative field research based on narrative formats which are analyzed and/or created during the research process.
[[File:Narrative Research.png|400px|thumb|right|'''SCOPUS hits per year for Narrative Research until 2020.''' Search terms: 'Narrative Research'
column2: 'narrative inquiry'
column3: 'narrative analysis' in Title
column4: Abstract
column5: Keywords. Source: own.]]

column1: '''[[Glossary|Storytelling]] has been a way for humankind to express
column2: convey
column3: form and make sense of their reality for thousands of years''' (Jovchelovitch & Bauer 2000; Webster & Mertova 2007). 'Storytelling' is defined as the distinct tonality
column4: format and presentation in which a story is told. The term 'narrative' includes both: the story itself
column5: with its dramaturgy
column6: characters and plot
column7: as well as the act of storytelling (Barrett & Stauffer 2009). However
column8: the term 'narrative' has been used used predominantly as a synonym for 'story' in academia for decades (Barrett & Stauffer 2009).

column1: '''Psychologist Jerome Bruner introduced the notion of 'narrative' as being one of two forms of distinct modes of thinking in 1984''' - the other being the 'logico-scientific' mode (Barrett & Stauffer 2009). While the latter is ""(...) more concerned with establishing universal truth conditions"" (Barrett & Stauffer 2009
column3: the 'narrative' mode represents the broad human experience of reality. This distinction led to further investigation on the idea that 'narratives' are a central form of human learning about - and [[Glossary|sense-making]] of - the world. Scholars began to recognize the role of analyzing narratives in order to understand individual and societal experiences and the meanings that are attached to these. This led e.g. to the establishment of the field of narrative psychology.

column2: Narrative Research - often just phrased 'narrative' - is a rather recent phenomenon''' (Barrett & Stauffer 2009; Clandinin 2006
column3: see Squire et al. 2014). Narratives have developed towards modes of scientific inquiry in various disciplines in Social Sciences
column4: including the arts
column5: anthropology
column6: cultural studies
column7: psychology
column8: sociology
column9: and educational science (Barrett & Stauffer 2009). This development paralleled an increasing role of qualitative research during the second half of the 20th Century
column10: and built on the understanding of 'narrative' as both a form of story and a form of meaning-making of the human experience. Today
column11: Narrative Research may be used across a wide range of disciplines and is an increasingly applied form in educational research (Moen 2006
column12: Stauffer & Barrett 2009
column13: Webster & Mertova 2007).

column2: there is a distinction to be made:''' 'Narrative' can refer to a form of Science Communication
column3: in which research findings are presented in a story format (as opposed to classical representation of data) but not extended through new insights. 'Narrative' can also be understood as a form of scientific inquiry
column4: generating new knowledge during its application. This entry will focus on the latter understanding.

column2: it should be noted that Narrative Research entails different approaches'''
column3: some of which are very similar to other forms of qualitative field research. In this Wiki entry
column4: the distinctiveness of Narrative Research shall be accounted for
column5: whereas the connectedness to other methods is mentioned where due.

column1: Narrative Research -  or 'Narrative Inquiry' - is shaped by and focussing on a conceptual understanding of 'narratives' (Barrett & Stauffer 2009
column2: p.15). Here
column3: 'narratives' are seen as a format of [[Glossary|communication]] that people apply to make sense of their life experiences. ""Communities
column4: social groups
column5: and subcultures tell stories with words and meanings that are specific to their experience and way of life. The lexicon of a social group constitutes its perspective on the world
column6: and it is assumed that narrations preserve particular perspectives in a more genuine form"" (Jovchelovitch & Bauer 2000
column7: p.2). '''Narratives are therefore not merely forms of representing a chain of events
column8: but a way of making sense of what is happening.''' Through the telling of a story
column9: people link events in meaning. The elements that are conveyed in the story
column10: and the way these are conveyed
column11: indicates how the story-teller - and/or their social surrounding - sees the world. They are a form of putting reality into cultural and individual perspective. Also
column12: narratives are never final but change over time as new events arise and perspectives develop (Jovchelovitch & Bauer 2000
column13: Webster & Mertova 2007
column14: Squire et al. 2014
column15: Moen 2006).

column1: Narrative Research is ""(...) the study of stories"" (Polkinghorne 2007
column2: p.471) and thus ""(...) the study of how human beings experience the world
column3: and narrative researchers collect these stories and write narratives of experience."" (Moen 2006
column4: p.56). The distinctive feature of this approach - compared to other methods of qualitative research with individuals
column5: such as [[Open Interview|Interviews]] or [[Ethnography]] - is the focus on narrative elements and their meaning. Researchers may focus on the 'narratology'
column6: i.e. the structure and grammar of a story; the 'narrative content'
column7: i.e. the themes and meanings conveyed through the story; and/or the 'narrative context'
column8: which revolves around the effects of the story (Squire et al. 2014).

column1: '''One common approach in Narrative Research is the usage of narratives in form of spoken or written text or other types of media as the data material for analysis.''' This understanding is comparable to [[Content Analysis]] or [[Hermeneutics]]. A second understanding focuses on the creation of narratives as part of the methodological design
column2: so that the narrative material is not pre-developed but emerges from the inquiry itself (Squire et al. 2014
column3: Jovchelovitch & Bauer 2000). In both approaches
column4: 'narrative' is the underlying ""frame of reference"" (Moen 2006
column5: p.57) for the research. An example for the latter understanding is the 'Narrative Interview'.

column1: [[File:Narrative Research Phases.png|400px|thumb|right|'''Basic phases of the narrative Interview.''' Source: Jovchelovitch & Bauer 2000

The Narrative Interview is an Interview format that ""(...) encourages and stimulates an interviewee (...) to tell a story about some significant event in their life and social context."" (Jovchelovitch & Bauer 2000
column2: p.3). 'Narrative Interviewing' ""is considered a form of unstructured
column3: in-depth interview with specific features."" (Jovchelovitch & Bauer 2000
column4: p.4) To this end
column5: it is a form of the [[Open Interview]]
column6: which - compared to [[Semi-structured Interview|Semi-structured]] and [[Survey|Structured Interviews]] - is relatively free from deductively pre-developed question schemata: ""To elicit a less imposed and therefore more 'valid' rendering of the informant's perspective
column7: the influence of the interviewer should be minimal (...) '''The [Narrative Interview] goes further than any other interview method in avoiding pre-structuring the interview.''' (...) It uses a specific type of everyday communication
column8: namely story-telling and listening
column9: to reach this objective."" (Jovchelovitch & Bauer 2000

Non-equilibrium dynamics;"'''In short:''' This entry revolves around (non-)equilibria in our world
column2: and how we can understand them from a statistical point of view.

column1: '''Frequentist statistics widely builds on equilibrium dynamics.''' Generally
column2: equilibrium dynamics are systems that are assumed to have reached a steady state
column3: and whose variability is either stable or understood. The last difference is already of pivotal importance and marks a pronounced difference in how models evolved over the last decades.

column2: steady state systems have been known for long in physics
column3: and their dynamics have equally long been explored by mathematics. However
column4: especially the developments in physics during the 20th Century made it clear that many phenomena in the natural world do not follow steady state dynamics
column5: and this thought slowly inched its way into other fields beyond physics. Computers and the availability of measures and numbers raised questions on why certain dynamics remain unexplained. Such dynamics were not necessarily new to the researchers
column6: yet they were never before in the focus of research. '''Weather models were one of the early breakthroughs that allowed for a view into dynamic systems'''. It became clear that beyond a certain amount of days
column7: weather prediction models perform worse than predicting the weather based on long term average records. Hence we can clearly diagnose that there are long-term dynamics that dominate short-term changes
column8: and allow for the calculation of averages. Nevertheless
column9: local dynamics and weather changes lead to a deviation from these averages. These dynamics are so difficult to predict over longer time stretches
column10: that today meteorologist rely on so-called 'ensemble models'. This approach looks at
column11: say
column12: one million runs of the same mathematical weather model which also contains a stochastic component and derives average weather conditions over a certain time period. In fact
column13: the statement that there is a 60% probability of rain at a certain day and time follows from the fact that
column14: in this example
column15: 60% of all model runs resulted in rain at that day and time.

column1: Knowledge about complex or chaotic systems slowly inched its way into other branches of science as well
column2: with cotton prices being a prominent example of [[Glossary|patterns]] that could be better explained by chaos theory
column3: at least partly. There seemed to be unexplained variance in such numbers that could not be tamed by the statistical approaches available before. From our viewpoint today
column4: this is quite understandable. Cotton is an industry widely susceptible to fluctuations by water availability and pests
column5: often triggering catastrophic losses in the production of cotton that were as hard to explain as long-term weather conditions. Cotton pests and weather fluctuations can be said to follow patterns that are at least partly comparable
column6: and this is where chaotic dynamics - also known as 'non-equilibrium dynamics' - become a valuable approach.

column1: The same can be said for humanly induced climate change
column2: which is a complex phenomenon. Here
column3: not only the changes in the averages matter
column4: but more importantly the changes in the extremes - in the long run
column5: these may have the most devastating effects on humans and the ecosystem. We see already an increase in both flooding and droughts
column6: which are often contradicting average dynamics
column7: leading to crop failures and other natural disasters. El Niño years are among the most known phenomena that showcase that such dynamics existed before
column8: but were seemingly amplified by global climate change
column9: triggering cascades of problems across the globe. Non-equilibrium dynamics hence become a growing reality
column10: and many of the past years were among the most extreme on record concerning many climatic measures. While this is a problem in itself
column11: it is also problematic from a frequentists statistics viewpoint. The world is after all strongly built and optimised by statistical predictions. Non-equilibrium dynamics are hence increasingly impacting our lives more directly. '''Future agriculture
column12: disaster management and climate change adaption measure will increasingly (have to) build on approaches that are beyond the currently dominating portfolio of statistics.'''

column1: This brings us now to the second point: what are current models that try to take non-equilibrium dynamics into account? The most simple models are [[Correlations]] and [[Regression Analysis|Regressions]]
column2: with 'time' as the independent variable in the case of regressions
column3: or just look at simple temporal correlations concerning temporal dynamics. Since such models either build on linear dynamics of blunt rank statistics
column4: it is clear that such approaches must fail when it comes to taking non-linear dynamics into account. '''Non-equilibrium dynamics are more often than not characterised by non-linear patterns
column5: which need us to step out of the world of linear dynamics.'''

column2: many types of [[Statistics|statistical]] models emerged that are better suited to deal with such non-linear dynamics. One of the most prominent approaches is surely that of Generalized Additive Models (GAM)
column3: which represents a statistical revolution. Much can be said about all the benefits of these models
column4: which in a nutshell are - based on a smooth function - able to compromise predictor variables in a non-linear fashion. Trevor Hastie and Robert Tibshirani (see Key Publications) were responsible for developing these models and matching them with [[Generalised Linear Models]]. By building on more computer-intense approaches
column5: such as penalized restricted likelihood calculation
column6: GAMs are able to outperform linear models if predictors follow a non-linear fashion
column7: which seems trivial in itself. This comes however with a high cost
column8: since the ability of higher model fit comes - at least partly - with the loss of our ability to infer [[Causality|causality]] when explaining the patterns that are being modeled. '''In other words
column9: GAMs are able to increase the model fit or predictive power
column10: but in the worst case
column11: we are throwing our means to understand or explain the existing relations out of the window.'''

column2: over the last decades
column3: parts of the statistical modelling wandered more strongly into the muddy waters of superior model fit
column4: yet understood less and less about the underlying mechanisms. Modern science has to date not sufficiently engaged with the questions how predictive modelling can lead to optimific results
column5: and which role our lack of explicit understanding play in terms of worse outcomes. Preventing a pandemic based on a predictive model is surely good
column6: but enforcing a space shuttle start when there is some lack of understanding of the new conditions at launch day led to the Challenger disaster. '''Many disasters of human history were a lack of understanding the unexpected.''' When our experience was pushed into the new realms of the previously unknown
column7: and our expactation of the likelihood of such an extreme event happening was low
column8: the impending surprise often came at a high price. Many developments - global change
column9: increasing system [[Agency
column10: Complexity and Emergence|complexity
column11: ]] growing inequalities - may further decrease our ability to anticipate infrequent dynamics. This calls for a shift towards maximizing the resilience of our models that may be needed under future circumstances. While this has been highlighted i.e. by the IPCC
column12: the Stockholm resilience center and many other institutions
column13: policy makers are hardly prepared enough
column14: which became apparent during the COVID-19 pandemic.

column1: From a predictive or explanatory viewpoint
column2: we can break the world of statistics down into three basic types of dynamics: Linear dynamics
column3: periodical dynamics
column4: and non-linear dynamics. Let us differentiate between these three.

column1: '''Linear dynamics''' are increasing or decreasing at an estimate that does not change over time. All linear relations have an endpoint which these patterns do not surpass. Otherwise there would be plants growing on the top of Mount Everest
column2: diseases would spread indefinitely
column3: and we could travel faster than the speed of light. All this is not the case
column4: hence based on our current understanding
column5: there are linear patterns
column6: which at some point cannot increase. Until then
column7: we can observe linear dynamics: you have a higher plant diversity and biomass under increasingly favourable growing conditions
column8: illnesses may affect more and more people in a pandemic
column9: and we can travel faster if we - simply spoken - invest more energy and wit into our travel vehicle. All these are current facts of reality that were broken down by humans into linear patterns and mechanisms.

column1: '''Periodical dynamics''' are recognized by humans since the beginning of time itself. Within seasonal environments
column2: plants grow in spring and summer
column3: diseases show increases and decreases that show up-and-down patterns
column4: and travel vehicles do not maintain their speed because of friction or gravity. Hence we can understand and interpret many of the linear phenomena we observe as cyclic or periodical phenomena as well. Many of the laws and principles that are at the basis of our understanding are well able to understand such periodic fluctuations
column5: and the same statistics that can catch linearly increasing or decreasing phenomena are equally enabling us to predict or even understand such periodic phenomena.

column1: '''Non-linear dynamics''' are often events or outlier phenomena that trigger drastic changes in the dynamics of our data. While there is no overarching consensus on how such non-linear dynamics can be coherently defined
column2: from a statistical standpoint we can simply say that such non-linear dynamics do not follow the linear dynamics frequentist statistics are built upon. Instead
column3: such phenomena violate the order of [[Data distribution|statistical distributions]]
column4: and are therefore not only hard to predict
column5: but also difficult to anticipate. Before something happened
column6: how should we know it would happen? Up until today
column7: earthquakes are notoriously hard to predict
column8: at least over a long-term time scale. The same is also true for extreme weather events
column9: which are notoriously hard to predict over longer time frames. Another example is the last financial crisis
column10: which was anticipated by some economists
column11: but seemingly came as a surprise to the vast majority of the world. The COVID-19 pandemic stands out as the most stark example that hardly anyone expected before it happened. Yet it was predicted by some experts. Their prediction was based on the knowledge that during the last hundred years the parameters after which a specific disease spread were not adding up to a germ that actually leads to a global pandemic that threatens the whole world. At some point - the experts knew - the combination of traits of a germ may be hence unfortunate enough to enable a pandemic. Since the flu - and some may also say
column12: HIV - there was no clear global threat occurring
column13: yet it has happened before
column14: and it may happen again.

column1: Such rare events are hard to anticipate
column2: and almost impossible to predict. Nevertheless
column3: many of the world leading experts became alarmed when the rising numbers from Wuhan were coming in
column4: and with the spread starting outside of China
column5: it became clear that we were in a situation that would take a while and huge efforts to tame. The world is facing such wicked problems at an increasing pace
column6: and while it is always under very individual and novel circumstances
column7: we may become increasingly able to anticipate at least the patterns and mechanisms of such non-linear dynamics. Chaos theory emerged over the last decades as an approach to understand the underlying patterns that contribute to phenomena being unpredictable
column8: yet which still follow underlying meachnisms that can be calculated. '''In other words
column9: chaos theory is not about specific predictions
column10: but is more about understanding how complex patterns emerge.''' [https://news.mit.edu/2008/obit-lorenz-0416 Edward Lorenz] put it best when he defined chaos: when the present determines the future
column11: but the approximate present does not approximately determine the future. The concrete patterns in an emergent chaotic system cannot be predicted
column12: because a later state of the system will always be difficult to foresee due to minute non-recognizable differences in the past. In statistical words
column13: we are incapable to statistically predict chaotic systems because we are incapable to soundly measure the past conditions that lead to future patterns. Not only may our measures be not sensitive enough to measure past conditions sufficiently
column14: but we are also unable to understand interactions within the system. '''In statistical terms
column15: the unexplained variance in our understanding of a past state of the system translates into an inability to predict the future state of the system.'''

column2: all statistical models are imperfect. Chaos theory is testimony that this imperfection can add up to us completely losing our grip or our understanding of a system altogether. To any statistical modeler
column3: this should not be surprising. After all
column4: we know that ''all models are wrong
column5: and some models are useful.'' It is equally clear that the world changes over time
column6: not only because of Newton's law of physics
column7: but because humans and life make the world a surely less normally-distributed place. Chaos theory does however propose an array of mathematical models that allow to understand the patterns that allow the repeating patterns and mechanisms that often explain the astonishing beauty associated with chaos theory. Many repeated patterns in nature
column8: such as the geometry of many plants
column9: or the mesmerizing beauty of turbulent flow can be approximated by mathematical models. While some branches of modelling
column10: such as weather forecasts
column11: are already utilizing chaos theory
column12: such models are far away from becoming part of the standard array in predictive modelling. As of today
column13: the difference between [[:Category:Inductive|inductive]] and [[:Category:Deductive|deductive]] models is often not clear
column14: and there is a feeble understanding of what causal knowledge is possible and necessary
column15: and which models and patterns are clearly not causal or explainable but instead predictive.

column1: What did however improve rapidly over the last decades are [[Machine Learning]] approaches that utilize diverse algorithmic approaches to maximize model fits and thus take a clear aim at predictive modelling. This whole hemisphere of science is partly strongly interacting and building on data originating in the Internet
column2: and many diverse streams of data demand powerful modelling approaches that build on Machine Learning. 'Machine Learning' itself is a composite term that encapsulates a broad and diverse array of approaches
column3: some of which are established since decades ([[Clustering Methods|Clustering]]
column4: [[Ordinations]]
column5: [[Regression Analysis]])
column6: while other methods are at the frontier of the current development
column7: such as artificial neural networks or decisions trees. Most approaches were already postulated decades ago
column8: but some only gained momentum with the [[History of Methods|computer revolution]]. Since many approaches demand high computational capacity there is a clear rise in the last years
column9: along with the rise of larger computer capacities. [[Bayesian Inference|Bayesian]] approaches are the best example of calculations that are even today - depending on the data - more often than not rather intense in terms of the demand on the hardware. If you are interested in learning more about this
column10: please refer to the entry on [[Bayesian Inference]].

column1: In contrast to a Frequentist approach
column2: the Bayesian approach allows researchers to think about events in experiments as dynamic phenomena whose probability figures can change and that change can be accounted for with new data that one receives continuously. However
column3: this coin comes with a flip side

column2: Bayesian Inference can overall be understood as a deeply [[:Category:Inductive|inductive]] approach since any given dataset is only seen as a representation of the data it consists of. This has the clear benefit that a model based on a Bayesian approach is way more adaptable to changes in the dataset
column3: even if it is small. In addition
column4: the model can be subsequently updated if the dataset is growing over time. '''This makes modeling under dynamic and emerging conditions a truly superior approach if pursued through Bayes' theorem.''' In other words
column5: Bayesian statistics are better able to cope with changing condition in a continuous stream of data.

column1: This does however also represent a flip side of the Bayesian approach. After all
column2: many data sets follow a specific statistical [[Data distribution|distribution]]
column3: and this allows us to derive clear reasoning on why these data sets follow these distributions. Statistical distributions are often a key component of [[:Category:Deductive|deductive]] reasoning in the analysis and interpretation of statistical results
column4: something that is theoretically possible under Bayes' assumptions
column5: but the scientific community is certainly not very familiar with this line of thinking. This leads to yet another problem of Bayesian statistics: they became a growing hype over the last decades
column6: and many people are enthusiastic to use them
column7: but hardly anyone knows exactly why. Our culture is widely rigged towards a frequentist line of thinking
column8: and this seems to be easier to grasp for many people. In addition
column9: Bayesian approaches are way less implemented software-wise
column10: and also more intense concerning hardware demands.

column1: There is no doubt that Bayesian statistics surpass frequentists statistics in many aspects
column2: yet in the long run
column3: Bayesian statistics may be preferable for some situations and datasets
column4: while frequentists statistics are preferable under other circumstances. Especially for predictive modeling and small data problems
column5: Bayesian approaches should be preferred
column6: as well as for tough cases that defy the standard array of statistical distributions. Let us hope for a future where we surely know how to toss a coin. For more on this
column7: please refer to the entry on [[Non-equilibrium dynamics]].

Normativity of Methods;"'''This sub-wiki is dedicated to deliberations
column2: open questions and new ideas about science.''' Often
column3: these highlight how the choice and application of [[Glossary|scientific methods]] and the interpretation of scientific results relate to values and norms
column4: the philosophy of science and the general question how science relates to the 'real world'.

column1: ''''Normativity' can be defined as any form of evaluation by humans.''' Some things are evaluated to be better than others. Normativity of methods hence deals with the question of the evaluation of methods by entities such as disciplines
column2: scientific communities
column3: civil societies
column4: schools of thinking etc. We try to link these reflections with a post-disciplinary agenda. In philosophy
column5: normativity is often associated to actions or mental states and the question what we ought to do

This article introduces the advantages and disadvantages of Object Relational Mapping (ORM) and the popular Python ORM solutions. This article uses SQLAlchemy
column2: one of the common packages for ORM

column1: ORM is a programming technique for mapping objects to relational databases. There is a significant difference between object-oriented and relational databases. Relational databases are organized in rows and columns where each row has a unique key
column2: and each column has a unique name. This way
column3: you have a very structured database. An object-oriented database relies on objects which contain data and methods. For example
column4: an object of Leuphana University might contain data about the staff employed
column5: the total number of students
column6: the number of courses offered
column7: yearly budget spending
column8: etc. But it can also contain methods
column9: such as a formula to calculate the average monthly spending on chemistry laboratory equipment. These two datatypes therefore follow different logics and are not fully compatible
column10: even though information from one database sometimes needs to be accessible from the other (for more information and comparison see [https://databasetown.com/relational-database-vs-object-oriented-database-key-differences/ here]).

column1: ORM creates an intermediate layer between the developer and the database
column2: converting the data into object entities in Python
column3: which shields the differences between different databases while making it very easy for the developer to manipulate the data in the database to use the advanced object-oriented features.

column1: Many components in Python provide ORM support
column2: each with a slightly different application field
column3: but the theoretical principles of database manipulation are the same. The following describes some of the more well-known ORM frameworks for Python databases.

column1: * '''SQLAlchemy'''is the most mature ORM framework in Python and has a lot of resources and documentation. As a result
column2: SQLAlchemy is considered to be the de facto ORM standard for Python.

column1: * '''Django ORM''' comes with the Django framework for simple or moderately complex database operations. However
column2: Django ORM is based on complex query operations transformed into SQL statements
column3: which are more tedious than those written directly in SQL or generated with SQLAlchemy.

column1: * '''Storm''' is a medium-sized ORM library that requires developers to write DDL statements for data tables and can not generate their table definitions directly from the data table class definition.
*'''SQLObject''' is a Python ORM that maps objects between SQL databases and Python. Thanks to its Ruby on Rails-like ActiveRecord model
column2: it is becoming increasingly popular in the programming community. It includes a Python-object-based query language
column3: which makes SQL more abstract and thus provides substantial database independence for applications.

column1: * Database details are shielded from developers so that developers do not have to deal with SQL statements
column2: which improves development efficiency.

column1: * Facilitates database migration. SQL-based data access layers often spend much time debugging SQL statements when changing databases because of the nuanced differences in SQL statements between each database. ORM provides a SQL-independent interface
column2: and the ORM engine handles the differences between databases
column3: so no code changes are required when migrating databases.

column1: *Applying techniques such as cache optimization can sometimes improve the efficiency of database operations.
* ORM libraries are not lightweight tools and require much effort to learn and set up

column1: Below you will find some guidance regarding personal conduct in video conferences and group chats. In general
column2: do make sure to pay attention to your language. This includes not only being polite
column3: but also being aware of who can read the language you're typing in.

column1: The following guidelines should be respected in online video conferences with tools such as Zoom
column2: Slack
column3: Microsoft Teams or Skype.

column1: # '''Before or at the beginning of every video conference
column2: a moderator is nominated'''. He*she is responsible for ensuring compliance with these rules. He*she is especially responsible to look for requests to speak.

column1: # '''All participants mute their microfone''' when joining a conference call. The microphone will solely be activated when the moderator gave allowance to speak and will be muted immediately afterwards.

column2: use the possibilities of the video conferencing software'''. Typically
column3: there is a chat or ""Raise hand"" function at your dispoal.

column1: # '''Audio transmission is to be prioritized'''. This means:
## Use headsets with a built-in microphone.
## Do not turn on video if unnecessary.
# '''Good practice for offline meetings should especially be followed in online meetings''' due to the limited possibilities of interaction. This refers especially to:
## Have an agenda including time-boxed agenda slots.
## Nominate a keeper of the minutes at the beginning. He*she will summarize the meeting at the end.
## Only discuss topics that are relevant for all participants. Individual consultations should happen before or after the meeting
column2: or - if need be - using the private chat function or mail during the meeting.

column1: The following guidelines especially apply to tools such as Rocket.Chat
column2: Slack or Microsoft Teams.

column1: # '''Be aware of the size of your audience.''' Many people might be able to read what you write and/or get notified.

# '''Use the built-in thread function (!).''' I can't stress this enough. Using threads makes communication structured and helps everyone keep an overview. Mindlessly writing directly into the chat windows clutters the chat history and makes everyone sad. A thread is when you directly answer to a chat message so that answers get grouped beneath the original message. The button for a thread typically appears when you hover your mouse over the message you want to reply to. It's usually a small speech bubble.
# '''It's okay to use punctuation and proper spelling in chat.''' It really helps your readers make sense of what you're writing.

column1: Interview methodology is perhaps the oldest of all the social science methodologies. Asking interview participants a series of informal questions to obtain knowledge has been a common practice among anthropologists and sociologists since the inception of their disciplines. Within sociology
column2: the early-20th-century urban ethnographers of the '''Chicago School''' did much to prompt interest in the method.” (Hamill 2014) '''Barney Glaser and Anselm Strauss''' are central figures regarding this method-and interviews and other methods in general- ever since they developed the [[Grounded Theory]] approach to qualitative data analysis in the 1960s. Their 1967 landmark book paved the road for the integration of methodologically conducted interviews into sociological research. While Glser & Strauss built on several previously explored approaches
column3: they widely triggered this branch of science
column4: and set off a change considering the role that interviews play ever since in research
column5: creating an altogether new arena in science (see Key Publications). Today
column6: qualitative interviews are abundantly used in gender studies
column7: social and political studies as well as ethnographics (2
column9: market research and other fields.

column1: * '''Interviews are a form of data gathering.''' They can be conducted in direct conversation with individuals or groups. This is also possible online or via the phone (1
column2: 2). It is possible for more than one researcher to conduct the interview together (2). The necessary equipment includes notes regarding topics of interest that help ask relevant questions
column3: a recording device and paper & pencil or a computer for note taking during the interview.

column1: * A wide range of formats is available for qualitative interviews. They may be distinguished in terms of a) the extent to which the interview questions are pre-formulated (for a stronger pre-formulation
column2: see [[Semi-structured Interview]])
column3: b) how broad or topic-specific the questions are and c) the focus of the interview - letting the interviewee narrate freely or purposefully extracting meanings and interpretations expressed by the interviewee (3).

column2: commonly used forms and fields of the open interview are clinical interviews to diagnose illnesses -anamnese- biographical interviews to ""gain access to life-histories"" (Hopf 2004
column3: p.205) or ethnographical interviews (see [[Ethnography]]) (3).

column1: * ""Interview methodology is particularly useful for researchers who (...) are concerned with the way in which individuals interpret and assign meaning to their social world."" (Hamill 2014) '''Interviews allow the researcher to gain insight into understandings
column2: opinions
column3: attitudes and beliefs of the interviewee''' (2).

column1: [[File:ResultVisualisationOpenInterview.png|500px|thumb|right|'''An exemplary interview transcript from an Open Interview.''' Source: own.]]
==== How to do an open interview ====

For an open interview - similar to the [[Semi-structured Interview]] - the researcher may prepare a set of questions ahead of the interview. These questions may result from the study design and research questions
column2: but also from literature or prior studies on the respective research topic and specific characteristics of the interviewee. However
column3: different from the [[Semi-structured Interview]]
column4: these questions are not strictly pre-formulated but rather represent general topics of interest to the researcher.

column1: Before the start of the interview
column2: the interviewer lets the interviewee sign a Voluntary Consent Form
column3: guaranteeing voluntary participation in the research. The interviewer should provide Full Disclosure (information about the main goal of the research and further use of the information)
column4: Confidentiality of the Data as well as the right of the interviewees to review the results before publication and to withdraw from the interview without any need for an explanation.

column1: The interviewer then opens the wider field around these topics by asking open questions
column2: listening to the answers given by the interviewee and developing new questions that arise from these responses. The interviewer tries to understand
column3: not to measure
column4: what the interviewee is saying (2).

column1: The interview should be video- or audio-recorded for later transcription. This transcription is preferably done by writing down the recorded speech either word by word (denaturalism) or including stutters
column2: pauses and other idiosyncratic elements of speech (naturalism). The chosen approach depends on the research design. In any case
column3: the form of transcription should not impose too much interpretation upon the interview data
column4: and allow for intersubjective data readability (7). The text may be structured and punctuations may be added to improve legibility. For ethical reasons
column5: the identity of the interviewee should be secured in the transcribed text (7). To allow for quotations
column6: the lines of the transcript should be numbered or time codes should be added at the end of each paragraph (6). The subsequent analysis of the gathered data relies on this transcription. Quite often
column7: the transcription is coded to map out a more systematic understanding of the interview. This may allow for a deeper qualitative analysis of the text
column8: upon which a sequential analysis that is integrated later may build (see [[Content Analysis]]). For more on Transcription
column9: please refer to the entry on [[Transcribing Interviews]].

column1: * Compared to the more restricted standardized format of [[Survey|surveys]]
column2: the qualitative interview allows for an open collection and investigation of self-interpretations and situational meanings on the part of the interviewees. This way
column3: theories from psychology and sociology can more easily be empirically explored (3)
column4: while also keeping the option open to work independently from initial theories.

column1: * Open interviews may reproduce existing power structures less strongly
column2: allowing for more open spaces where more information is shared. This highlights the importance of the overall settings
column3: and a clarification of the respective roles
column4: as well as the general research protocol
column5: including ethical concerns.

column2: due to this focus on the subjective position of the interviewee with regards to his/her/their feelings
column3: attitudes and interpretations
column4: the results gathered in qualitative interviews represent the perspective and context of an individual and hence differ in many aspects from data gathered by quantitative surveys (2)
column5: often offering what many consider to be a deeper perspective.

column1: * Language barriers impose problems in understanding the interviewee's statements during the interview and in the transcription process
column2: making it often necessary to hire native speakers
column3: since due to the qualitative nature and the sensitive interview setting a deep understanding of the respective cultural and social context is desirable.

column1: * '''Pitfalls during the interview:''' It is crucial that the interviewer is well-acquainted with the conceptual approach and design of the research
column2: which is crucial to maintain the general flow of the interview setting (8). This process imposes high demands on the interviewer. The interviewer must remain attentive and flexible throughout the interview in order to make sure all relevant aspects of the interview guide are profoundly answered. The quality and richness of the data depend on the proficiency in this process (1). In addition
column3: the interviewer must make sure not to impose [[Bias and Critical Thinking|bias]] on the interviewee. Therefore
column4: he/she/they should not ask closed yes/no-questions or offer answers for the interviewee to choose from. This open form can be lengthy
column5: at time
column6: which demands a lot of patience form the interviewer. Answers should not be commented or confirmed. The questions should not be judgemental
column7: unexpected or incomprehensible to the interviewee (3
column8: 5).  It is thus recommendable that the interview be rehearsed (as much as possible in view of the open structure) and the interview guide be tested before the first real interview so as to ensure the quality of the interview conduction.

column4: as opposed to the huge number results possible with standardized surveys. Open interviews therefore tend to rather small samples (1

Ordination techniques evolved already more than a century ago in mathematics
column2: and allowed fro a reduction of information that makes these analysis approaches timely up until today. Ordination techniques rely strongly on a profound knowledge of the underlying data format of the respective dataset that is being analysed. Since ordination allow for both inductive and deductive analysis
column3: they often pose a risk for beginners
column4: who typically get confused by the diversity of approaches and the answers these analysis may provide. This conduction is often increased by the model parameters available to evaluate the results
column5: since much of ordination techniques allows for neither probability based assumptions
column6: let alone more advanced information based techniques. What is more
column7: ordinations are often deeply entangled in disciplinary cultures
column8: with some approaches such as factor analysis being almost exclusive to some disciplines
column9: and other approaches such as principal component analysis being utilised in quite diverse ways within different disciplines. This makes norms and rules when and how to apply different techniques widely scattered and intertwined with disciplinary norms
column10: while the same disciplines are widely ignorant about other approach from different disciplines. Here
column11: we try to diver a diverse and reflected overview of the different techniques
column12: and what their respective strengths and weaknesses are. This will necessary demand a certain simplification
column13: and will in addition trigger controversy within certain branches of science
column14: and these controversies are either rooted in partial knowledge or in experiential  identity. Unboxing the whole landscape of ordinations is also a struggle because these analysis are neither discrete nor always conclusive. Instead they pose starting points that often serve initial analysis
column15: or alternatively enable analysis widely uncoupled from the vast landscape of univariate statistics. We need to acknowledge to this end that there is a vast difference between the diverse approaches not only in the underlying mathematics
column16: yet also how these may be partly ignored. This is probably the hardest struggle that you can fin neither in textbooks nor in articles. The empirical reality is that many applications of ordinations violate much of the mathematical assumptions or rules
column17: yet the patterns derived from these analyses are still helpful if not even valid. Mathematicians can choose to live in a world where much of ordination techniques is perfect in every way
column18: yet the datasets the world gives to ordinations are simply not. Instead
column19: we have to acknowledge that multivariate data is almost always messy
column20: contains a high amount of noise
column21: many redundancies
column22: and even data errors. Safety comes in numbers. Ordinations are so powerful exactly because they can channel all these problems through the safety of the size of the data
column23: and thus derive either initial analysis or even results that serve as endpoints. However
column24: there is a difference between initial or final results
column25: and this will be our first starting point here.

column1: Ordination are one of the pillars of pattern recognition
column2: and therefore play an important role not only in many disciplines
column3: but also in data science in general. The most fundamental differentiation in which analysis you should choose is rooted in the data format. The difference between continuous data and categorical or nominal data is the most fundamental devision that allows you to choose your analysis pathway. The next consideration you need to review is whether you see the ordination as a string point to inspect the data
column4: or whether you are planning to use it as an endpoint or a discrete goal within your path of analysis. Ordinations re indeed great for skimming through data
column5: yet can also serve as a revelation of results you might not get through other approaches. Other consideration regarding ordinations are related to deeper matters of data formats
column6: especially the question of linearity of continuous variables. This already highlights the main problem of ordination techniques
column7: namely that you need a decent overview in order to choose the most suitable analysis
column8: because only through experience can you pick what serves your dataset best. This is associated to the reality that many analysis made with ordinations are indeed compromises. Ecology and psychology are two examples of disciplines why imagined ordinations deeply enough into the statistical designs to derive datasets where more often than not assumptions for statistical analysis of a respective ordination are met. However
column9: many analyses based on ordinations are indeed compromises
column10: and from a mathematical standpoint are real world analysis based on ordinations a graveyard of mathematical assumptions
column11: and violation of analytical foundations that borderline ethical misconduct. In other words
column12: much of ordinations are messy. This is especially true because ordinations are indeed revealing mostly continuous results in the form of location on ordination axes. While multivariate analyis based on cluster analysis are hence more discrete through the results being presented as groups
column13: ordinations are typically nice to graphically inspect
column14: but harder to analytical embedded into a wider framework. More on this point later. Let us now begin with a presentation of the diverse ordination types and their respective origins.

column1: This ordination is one of the most original ordination techniques

column7: the correspondence analysis creates orthogonal axis that represent a dimension reduction of the input data

column11: yet for most datasets the first two axis may suffice. The correspondence analysis is today mostly negotiable in terms of its direct application

column16: the underlying calculation

column18: the basic reciprocal averaging was initially very relevant for scientific disciplines such as ecology and psychology.

column1: Hill can be credited with eliminating the arch- or horseshoe effect by a move that mathematicians will probably criticise until the end of time. What this analysis does is that it simply takes the geometric space that comes out of a Correspondence analysis and bends it into an even shape. In other words
column2: the loadings out of a CA are detrended. This has several benefits. For once
column3: you look at a dimension reduction that is visually more easy to interpret
column4: because it does not follow the horseshoe effect of the CA. The second benefit that the detrending has is that you can calculate a measure that is called a turnover. A full turnover in the data is defined as the two most extreme data points do not share ay joined information or data. This can be a highly useful tool to access the heterogeneity of a dataset

'''Outlier Detection in a nutshell:''' Outlier Detection includes methods identifying data points that deviate a lot from the rest of the data set.

'''What is an outlier?''' An outlier is a data point that is significantly different from the other data points in a dataset. Its value is mostly unexpected and deviates a lot from the mean of the dataset. The task of outlier detection is to detect these points. However
column2: one has to consider the context and the dataset when selecting a specific method for detecting outliers. Some examples of outliers include: 1. In a dataset of housing prices in a city
column3: a data point representing a house that is significantly more or less expensive than the others could be an outlier. 2. In a dataset of exam scores for a class
column4: a student who scores significantly higher or lower than the rest of the class could be an outlier. 3. In a dataset of consecutive GPS coordinates of sailing activities
column5: coordinates with high deviation from the data points beforehand could be an outlier.

column1: Why is it important to detect outliers?''' Outlier detection is important because it helps to identify unusual or anomalous data points that may not fit with the rest of the data and therefore will have an impact on further analysis of the data. For instance
column2: a linear regression model would be immensely affected by outliers and lose its ability to generalize well over the dataset.

column1: ''Where is outlier detection located in the analysis process?''' Outlier detection is typically a part of the data cleaning and exploration phase of the data analysis process. This is typically the first step in the process of analyzing a dataset
column2: and it involves identifying and addressing any issues or problems with the data. Once the data has been cleaned and prepared
column3: it can be analyzed using a variety of methods to draw conclusions
column4: make predictions
column5: or inform decisions

column1: '''What are reasons for outliers?''' There are many possible reasons why outliers may occur in a dataset. Some common reasons include: 1. Measurement errors: Outliers can occur due to errors in the measurement process
column2: such as incorrect readings or faulty equipment. 2. Data entry errors: Outliers can also occur due to errors in data entry
column3: such as transposing numbers or mistyping data. 3. Natural variations: In some cases
column4: outliers may occur naturally as a result of natural variations in the data. For example
column5: extreme weather events or rare occurrences may result in data points that are significantly different from the rest of the data. 4. Fraud: Outliers can also occur as a result of fraudulent activity
column6: such as attempts to manipulate data or hide certain transactions. 5. Sampling errors: In some cases
column7: outliers may occur due to sampling errors
column8: such as a sample that is not representative of the population being studied.

column1: It is important to carefully consider the possible causes of outliers in a dataset
column2: as this can help to identify and understand the underlying reasons for unusual data points. In some cases
column3: it may be necessary to exclude outliers from analysis
column4: while in other cases it may be important to include them to get a complete picture of the

column2: Why and When==

column1: It is perfectly normal to feel some kind of nervousness or excitement before an important exam or presentation. This will actually help you to stay focused during the test because of higher adrenalin levels in your body. However
column2: there are cases when the feeling of fear and worrying thoughts are so strong that they inhibit a persons ability to concentrate properly and create strong physical symptoms. These can include headaches
column3: an upset stomach
column4: feelings of fear and dread
column5: sweating
column6: shortness of breath
column7: overthinking
column8: black outs and more.

column1: Test anxiety most often occurs shortly before or during an exam or similar test situations. In severe cases it can negatively affect a students overall social life or emotional development
column2: and - of course - the academic career. Therefore it is important to know how to handle feelings of anxiety that may occur in your life as a student at university.

column1: * Overcome feelings and symptoms of anxiety before an exam or test in order to perform successfully
* Get to know strategies that help you stay calm and focused - at uni and in your day-to-day life
* Strengthen your confidence and learn to trust your own abilities

There are several strategies that can help you stay calm before or during an exam and you can practice them! This will help you to get out of the vicious cycle exam anxiety can create: Fear of failure and physical discomfort during an exam might lead to lower marks which can convince the student of his self-attributed inability to master the subject. In turn this can create even more anxiety.
Here is what you can do to create positive change:
* For some it might already help to pay more attention to their overall lifestyle. Getting enough sleep
column2: proper nutrition
column3: and regular exercise strengthen the body's resources and ability to deal with stressful situations
column4: which is not only beneficial for exams but for life in general

column2: mindfulness
column3: breath work and study routines will enable you to actively calm your mind and body in your day to day life. Using this knowledge before a test can help you get back into a quiet
column4: focused
column5: and calm state.

column1: * Be prepared! Even though exam anxiety does not necessarily result from poor preapration or lack of knowledge
column2: it can be helpful psychologically to know that you have revised and studied enough - maybe with a group of friends/peers or an advanced tutor.

column1: * Preparation also includes finding out about the location and procedure of the test
column2: the material you have to bring
column3: and
column4: of course
column5: the time frame.

column1: * Maybe you have already tried all these things and they did not offer you the relief you expected? Or your fear is to overwhelming to even get started? Exam anxiety is a very common fear among students of all backgrounds and it is not a fear to be ashamed of. It can already help to open up to someone you trust.

column1: '''In short:'''Partial Correlation is a method to measure the degree of association between two variables
column2: while controlling for the impact
column3: a third variable has on both. When looking at correlations
column4: they can often be misleading and must be treated with care. For example
column5: this [https://www.tylervigen.com/spurious-correlations website] provides a list of strongly significant correlations that do not seem to have a meaningful and direct connection. This undermines that correlation is not necessarily related to [[Causality_and_correlation|causality]]. On the one hand
column6: this may be due to the principle of null hypothesis testing (see [[Designing_studies#P-value|p-value]]). But in the case of correlation
column7: strong significances can often be caused by a relationship to a common third variable and are therefore biased.

column1: [[File:matthewsexample.png|300px|thumb|left|Fig.1: Stock populations and human birth across Europe. From Matthews (2001).]]
Let's consider this example from [https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1467-9639.00013 Matthews (2001)] on stork populations and human birth rates across Europe (Fig.1).

A correlation between both variables indicates a statistically significant positive relation of r = .62. But can we really make sense of this correlation? Does it mean that storks deliver babies? It is very likely that the connection can be explained by one (or more) external variable(s)
column2: for example by how rural the area of measurement is (see Figure 2). In a more rural area
column3: more children are born and at the same time there is more space for storks to build their nests. So how can we control for this effect in a correlation analysis?

column1: To use partial correlation and gain valid results
column2: some assumptions must be fulfilled. No worries if these assumptions are violated! There is often still a work-around that can be done to bypass them.

column1: # Both variables and the third variable to control for (also known as control variable or covariate) must be measured on a '''[[Data_formats#Continuous_data|continuous]] scale'''.
# There needs to be a '''linear relationship''' between all three variables. This can be inspected by plotting every possible pair of variables.
# There should be '''no significant outliers'''. Partial correlation is sensitive to outliers
column2: because they have a large effect on the regression and correlation coefficients. Determining if a point is really a significant outlier
column3: is most likely based on personal experience and can therefore be ambiguous

column1: # All variables should be '''approximately normally distributed'''.
To check if a connection between two variables is caused by a common third variable
column2: we test whether the relationship still exists after we have accounted for the influence of the third variable. This can be achieved by calculating two simple [Regression Analysis|linear regressions] to predict each of the two variables based on the expected third variable. Thus
column3: we account for the impact the third variable has on the variance of each of our two variables.

column1: That way we can now consider the left-over (unexplained) variance - namely the residuals of the regressions. To better understand
column2: why we are doing this
column3: let s look at an individual data point of the regressions. If this point exceeds the predictions for both regressions equally
column4: then there seems to be a remaining connection between both variables. So
column5: when looking back at the broad picture of every data point
column6: this means that if the residuals of both regressions are unrelated
column7: then the relationship of the two variables could be explained by the third variable.

column2: to control for the impact of a third variable
column3: we calculate the correlation between the residuals resulting from the two linear regressions of the variables with respect to the third variable. The resulting formula for partial correlation is:

column1: It is also possible to add more than one control variable. We then use another
column2: recursive [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partial_correlation#Using_recursive_formula formula]. However
column3: it is not recommended to add more than 2 control variables
column4: because more variables impair the [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m0W8nnupcUk reliability] of the test and the complexity of the recursive algorithm increases exponentially. When checking for the “unbiased” effect of multiple variables
column5: it might be better to use a multiple linear regression instead.

column1: == Partial Correlation vs. Multiple Linear Regression ==

column2: one might notice that the basic idea is similar to a multiple linear regression. Even though a correlation is bidirectional while a regression aims at explaining one variable by another
column3: in both approaches we try to identify the true and unbiased relationship of two variables. So when should we use which method? In general
column4: partial correlation is a building step for multiple linear regression. Accordingly
column5: linear regression has a broader range of applications and is therefore in most cases the method to choose. Using a linear regression
column6: one can model interaction terms and it is also possible to loosen some

column1: assumptions by using a [[Generalized_Linear_Models|generalized linear model]]. Nevertheless
column2: one advantage
column3: partial correlation has over linear regression
column4: is that it delivers an estimate for the relationship which is easy to interpret. The linear regression outputs weights that depend on the unit of measurement
column5: making it hard to compare them to other models. As a work-around
column6: one could use standardized beta coefficients. Yet those coefficients are harder to interpret since they do not necessarily have an upper bound. Partial correlation coefficients
column7: on the other hand
column8: are defined to range from -1 to 1.

''""PechaKucha™ is what “Show and Tell” always dreamed of becoming.""''<small> (as seen on the PechaKucha™ website)</small>

column2: Why & When ==

column1: PechaKucha™ is a 20x20 format for short presentations consisting of exactly 20 slides on auto-timer
column2: with each slide being displayed for 20 seconds. This results in a talk of 6 minutes and 40 seconds.

column1: A PechaKucha™ presentation is a great alternative to the classical
column2: plain slideshow
column3: and it is especially useful for [[Glossary|storytelling]] or for presenting creative portfolios. More generally
column4: it can be used for any subject when there is one clear idea to be communicated (e.g. a concise overview of your research results). The slides usually contain one full-width image or photograph each
column5: which makes this format very engaging for the audience. Because of the limited duration and the auto-timer
column6: the speaker is required to sharpen their message when preparing their talk
column7: and he is forced to stay on track when delivering it.

column1: PechaKucha™ means ""chit chat"" in Japanese. This format was invented by Tokyo-based architects Astrid Klein and Mark Dytham because they thought people in their industry talked too much. Instead
column2: they wanted to set an example by delivering presentations where the focus was on actually ''showing'' the work.
PechaKuchas™ became a global phenomenon
column3: with regular ""PechaKuchas™ events"" or nights being held in major cities from more than 140 countries. It is also used widely within the corporate world
column4: as well as in schools as universities as an educational tool.

column1: PechaKuchas™ are about helping you to:
* Present something in exactly 6 minutes and 40 seconds
* Engage your audience with compelling visuals
* Put your spoken message at the center (vs. slides with too much text)
You can prepare your PechaKucha™ by using a conventional presentation software (e.g. MS Powerpoint)
column2: but also simply as a .pdf to be presented with Adobe Reader (yes
column3: it seems Adobe Reader also has an auto-timer function
column4: see [https://www.cedarville.edu/insights/blog/pdf-turn-into-presentation.aspx here] how to do that).

column1: # Create a story line for 20 slides;
# Set the auto-timer so that it switches to the following slide after 20 seconds;
# Practice your presentation (don't underestimate the importance of this step!);

column2: you can also pre-record your voice and play it with the slideshow (or combine them into a movie).

** information about events around the world

column2: Why & When ==

column1: Persona Building is a tool that helps better understand the target group when designing a product or service. In Persona Building
column2: a specific fictional user is imagined with his or her experiences
column3: needs and characteristics
column4: and the prospective product or service can be developed more specifically for this persona. This is mostly done in business for marketing purposes
column5: where the personas are potential customers or people to pitch an idea to. It can nevertheless also be helpful for any design process that aims to fulfill the needs of a specific audience (see [[Design Thinking]])

column1: * Understand your target audience's needs and wishes and establish a common reference point in your design team.
* Facilitate and speed up design and decision-making processes.
* Make the outcome more user-focused and distinct.
Persona Building starts with the '''gathering of data''' about the target groups. This can be [[Glossary|data]] that already exists
column2: such as large-scale surveys
column3: information on potential user groups such as the [https://www.sinus-institut.de/sinus-loesungen/sinus-milieus-deutschland/ SINUS milieus]
column4: or observations made in terms of the audiences of comparable products and services. It can also emerge from knowledge and experiences within the team
column5: or be original data gathered for the specific design purpose
column6: if the resources are available for that.

column2: overlappings and trends about the targeted audience are identified.''' The persona that is subsequently built should represent these identified elements. Importantly
column3: a persona should not become a prototypical or stereotypical puppet. A persona is not the sum of survey data or a demographic group. Instead
column4: one should attempt to imagine an archetype of a potentially real person with flaws
column5: contradictions and different facets. No more than a handful (three to four) personas (if more than one at all) should be built at once in order to maintain a sharp idea.

column1: Each created persona should possibly include a '''drawing or picture''' of the imagined person and his or her '''name'''. This way
column2: the persona becomes more vivid and recognizable within the project. Furthermore
column3: the persona should be described in terms of his or her '''characteristics''': his or her background
column4: hobbies and job
column5: lifestyle
column6: family situation
column7: needs
column8: problems
column9: preferences and desires. This helps understand how and why the person would be interested in the to-be-designed product or service
column10: and how it can be adapted and improved to better fit the persona's circumstances. The designers should try to understand their offer from the persona's perspective.

column2: the persona should be '''implemented into the design process'''. From this point on
column3: all team members should know about the persona and speak in terms of his or her specific needs and actions instead of speaking about broad needs of a potential target audience. The persona can be thrown into imagined scenarios and situations to understand how he or she would react. This way
column4: the design process becomes more user-focused. Also
column5: all team members
column6: which may come from different disciplines or departments
column7: now have a common reference point to speak about.

column1: Let us develop an example. Imagine you are attempting to develop a solution for smart mobility in the city. You may be working in the city planning department
column2: or in a start-up that tries to develop new technologically or socially innovative solutions. You do know what the general service should be - something that makes cycling more attractive in cities -
column3: but you are unsure of the specificities.

column1: [[File:Cyclists Persona Building.jpg|200px|thumb|left|'''Cyclist Lisa is a result of Persona Building.''' Source: Pixabay.]]
'''Now Persona Building comes into play.''' You develop a handful of Personas based on the target audience you want to provide with new opportunities for a change in their mobility behaviour. So
column2: first of all
column3: we think of Lisa.

column1: Lisa is 30 years old and has a six year old daughter
column2: Nele. Lisa works at an insurance firm in a middle-sized town and rides the bike to work. She likes cycling
column3: also with her daughter
column4: but the city only has bikelanes for some parts of her commute and into town. So
column5: Lisa is frustrated about the stressful interactions with cars
column6: as well as concerned about her own and her daughter's safety. Lisa would be ready to pay some money for a good solution
column7: but she doesn't want to give up cycling.

column1: We must make sure not to make Lisa a hippie-eco-cyclist-stereotype
column2: but her situation is surely archetypical for many people in cities nowadays. You could think of more details in terms of Lisa's personality
column3: her hobbies
column4: her background and future
column5: but the most important points are set: You know Lisa's situation
column6: her problems
column7: desires and circumstances - at least those that concern your design process.

column2: Lisa is now your first persona. The solution that might fit her needs and circumstances might be different depending on your design context (More bike lanes? A product that makes cycling safer on streets?)
column3: but focusing on Lisa and her daughter makes it easier for you to make decisions and find a solution that fits her needs. By developing even more personas and incorporating their needs into your design process
column4: the product will become more and more graspable and finally
column5: you have a solution that is hopefully attractive for your target audience.

column1: Pie charts represent parts of a whole in a circle. This is done by dividing the circle into multiple slices. The area of each slice is proportional to the quantity it represents. These slices of the circle are reminiscent of a cake or a pie hence the name. 1801 was the oldest known pie chart published by William Playfairs in the book The Statistical Breviary.
Pie charts are frequently used in non-scientific journals. However
column2: the use of pie charts is especially in the scientific context discouraged. Often they contain so little information that one sentence in the text would have been sufficient instead. In other cases where they could contain more information
column3: (stacked) bar charts have proven to be superior.

column2: pie charts are slower to interpret and more mistakes are made when interpreting them. One explanation for this is the following: only the length of the individual parts of the bar chart have to be considered to determine their share of the whole while for pie charts the area of the slices has to be considered. Since the human eye and brain can more easily determine the lengths than the size of areas
column3: especially when one side of the area is curved as it is the case with pie charts
column4: stacked bar charts are superior.

column1: In a nutshell: The use of pie charts should be well considered and avoided in most cases.

The R documentation is not found of the pie chart either and advises against using it. The pie charts in R are not actual circles but polygons (by default with 200 edges) which approximate a circle. You can see by yourself that this circle does not look smooth.

A probability distribution summarizes the probabilities for the values of a random variable. The general properties/features that define a distribution include the four mathematical moments:
1.	'''Expected value E(X)''': This is the outcome with the highest probability or likelihood or an average or mean value for the variable X.

2.	'''Variance Var(X)''': Variance denotes the spread of the values from the expected value. The standard deviation is the normalized value of variance obtained by taking a square root of the variance. The covariance summarizes the linear relationship for how the two variables change with respect to each other.
3.	'''Skewness''': Skewness is the measure of asymmetry of a random variable X about the mean E(X) of a probability distribution. It can be positive (tail on the right side)
column2: negative (tail on left side)
column3: zero (balanced tail on both sides) or undefined. Zero skewness does not always mean symmetric distribution as one tail can be long and thin and the other can be short and fat.

column1: 4.	'''Kurtosis''': Kurtosis is the measure of ‘ *peaked-ness* ’ of distribution. It can be differentiating tool between distributions that have the same mean and variance. Higher kurtosis means a peak and fatter/extended tails.
Each random variable has its own probability distribution that may have a similar shape to other variables
column2: however
column3: the structure will differ based on whether the variable is discrete or continuous
column4: since probability distributions of continuous variables have an infinite number of values and probability functions of discrete variables assign a probability to each concrete data point.

column1: Poisson Distribution is one of the discrete probability distributions along with binomial
column2: hypergeometric
column3: and geometric distributions. The following table differentiates what applies where.

column1: | Binomial || It is used when there are two possible outcomes (success/failure) in a process that are independent of each other in n number of trials. The easiest example is a coin toss whereas a more practical use of binomial distribution is testing a drug
column2: whether the drug cures the disease or not in n number of trials

column1: | Hypergeometric || It calculates the number of k successes in n number of trials where the probability of success changes with each passing trial. This kind of distribution applies in Poker when drawing a red card from the deck changes the probability of drawing another red card after it.
| Poisson || It provides the probability of an event happening a certain number of times (k) within a given interval of time or space. For example
column2: figuring out the probability of disease occurrence m times in the next month given that it occurs n times in 1 year.

column1: | Geometric || It determines the number of independent trials needed to get the first successful outcome. Geometric distribution may be used to conduct a cost-benefit analysis of a certain decision in a business.
Poisson distribution can only be used under three conditions: 1. Data is counts of events i.e.
column2: they are non-negative integers. 2. The events are random and occur independently of each other. 3. The mean number of events occurring in a specific time frame is constant and known.

Poisson distribution is used by mobile phone network companies to calculate their performance indicators like efficiency and customer satisfaction ratio. The number of network failures in a week in a locality can be measured given the history of network failures in a particular time duration. This predictability prepares the company with proactive solutions and customers are warned in advance. For more real-life examples of Poisson distribution in practice
