column2: usually a large sheet of paper with a designed combination of text
column3: graphs
column4: color
column5: etc.
column6: is one of the cost-effective means used to convey information to a large audience. There are different types of poster for various settings
column7: such as advertising
column8: event
column9: politics
column10: for motivational and scientific uses and many more. You may encounter the need to create a poster for a presentation at University or at a Conference. Informative posters are oftentimes commercial ones of a product or services hung in front of stores
column11: whereas formative ones are to raise awareness or speak for a good cause.

column1: * Ability to stand out from the background and attract attention
== Essential elements of a good poster ==
If you design a poster for an event
column2: there are questions that should be clearly and concisely answered:

column1: * How to attend the event (tickets info
column2: etc.) / How to keep up with the event (social media portals
column3: etc.)

column1: The target audience should be at the center when designing a poster
column2: as not only the content itself but other elements in the poster can be tailor to best reach its recipients. [https://venngage.com/blog/poster-design/#Consider-your-target-audience An example] compares two different posters both advertising for a fundraising event.

column1: The poster on the left for the Pride Color Run event looks vibrant
column2: lively and is targeted to a younger demographic. The right poster is made for a charity dinner and has a more structured and professional layout
column3: which normally attracts the older
column4: established audience. Many differences in color scheme
column5: typography
column6: layout
column7: styling and image use can be spotted between these two posters of the same cause
column8: which emphasizes the importance of identifying who a poster should speak to and how to effectively draw their attention.

column1: As for educational and scientific posters
column2: keep in mind that the audience can be roughly divided into three categories: your field of specialization
column3: the fields closely related to yours
column4: and unrelated fields ([https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/0166223689900398 Woolsey
column5: 1989]). It is best to adjust your content accordingly and be mindful when using jargons and other field-specific vocabularies
column6: unless you are sure that everyone in the audience can understand them.

column1: * Each color creates a unique kind of energy that could reflect the poster’s message
column2: may it be bold
column3: subtle
column4: agony or ecstasy. Choosing the right color scheme will set a tone for your statement to shine
column5: help drawing attention from the audience from afar
column6: create a subliminal association between then and the topic even before they start reading the text.

column1: * The actual color shade is also very important. It may come to you as a surprise
column2: but not only gray has (more than) fifty shade. The point is
column3: it is important to take this into account when creating a color palette for your poster. Different shades combination will create different effects even though the rough colors stay them same.

column1: ===== '''4. Typography – It’s not just about the content''' =====
* Typography is an [[Glossary|art]] itself. There is so much more you can convey with the use of fonts and arrangement of texts
column2: sometimes incorporating illustrations and images. It is an integral part to the poster as a final product
column3: and if done right
column4: makes a unique lasting visual impact to the audience.

column1: ===== '''5. Negative & White space – Things gotta breathe''' =====
* A lot of times: less is more. With a poster you only have limited space
column2: so deciding what’s making it there and what not is crucial. Negative space
column3: or white space
column4: is the area of the layout that is purposefully left empty. It serves as a breathing room for all other elements on the poster. As mentioned at the beginning
column5: your message has to stand out. But if everything on the poster is so crowded in technicolor
column6: your message becomes a leaf in the forest. That’s why it is important to selectively pick out some crucial elements and make them eye-catching
column7: while creating a background with plenty of room for your message to pop.

column1: * High contrast between elements on a poster could help you catch the audience’s eyes with just a glance. Experimental
column2: bold use of colors and images are encouraged
column3: especially when your poster is among a dozen other ones
column4: each trying to scream for attention.

column2: but scalable''' =====
you need to make sure that people are able to read the key information with a glimpse of an eye. The font
column3: size and arrangement of text are therefore critical. The headline should be the main (and biggest) text element on the poster
column4: and you can play around of different fonts or typography ideas to make it as attractive as possible. Then come the detailed information as discussed above. They don’t need to be as dazzling
column5: since the audience will come a bit closer to read them through if they decide that the poster is relevant. Still
column6: the detailed information needs to be concisely and clearly displayed to make use of the short attention span an audience may have for your poster.

column1: * Oftentimes you will want to scale down and hand out your poster in the form of flyers. Thus
column2: the size ratio of the headline and the detailed information should not be too drastic
column3: as scaling down would make the details unreadable.

column1: * Have a look at the entry on [[Conceptual Figures]] - while these are not the same as Posters
column2: there are certain tips that may also be of relevance for your poster.

column1: Knowing the market value of an overnight stay in an Airbnb home is of high interest for both
column2: renters (or hosts) and guests. As a guest one might be a bit overwhelmed going through all the offers Airbnb nowadays contains (approximately 51.000 for the city of New York as of November 2018). Knowing exactly what drives prices of Airbnb listings could make the whole search process more enjoyable. Setting the right price on the other hand is a crucial tasks for the hosts
column3: as they want neither
column4: their listing not being booked
column5: nor to rent it out too cheap.

column2: this report aims at identifying the determinants of prices for Airbnb listings. More precisely
column3: the following questions will be answered throughout the analysis:

column1: # How do hosts promote their listing? How are expensive/cheap listings being promoted?
# What areas are the most expensive ones? Does this correlate with the location score?
# Are there any seasonal effects on the price?
# What are the overall most important determinants for the price?
Airbnb itself does only provide a very limited insight into their data
column2: but a separate group named [http://insideairbnb.com/get-the-data.html Inside Airbnb] scrapes and compiles publicly available information about many cities' listings from the Airbnb website. For this report
column3: data for the city of New York from the year 2018 was been analysed. The dataset can be accessed through [https://www.notion.so/Data-Airbnb-listings-and-calendar-2018-481e9fcdd55c4253adee68751f0268c3 this link]. Otherwise
column4: more up-to-date datasets from the same website can be used for this analysis
column5: making sure the features described and used for it appear in the tables.

[[File:PCA.png|400px|thumb|right|'''SCOPUS hits per year for Principle Component Analysis until 2020.''' Search terms: 'PCA'

column1: Principal Component Analyses are helpful when you have a lot of different [[Glossary|data]] samples with a variety of variables. For example
column2: the following dataset which contains different nutrient measurements in various pizzas from different pizza brands.

column1: * mois -- Amount of water per 100 grams in the sample
* prot -- Amount of protein per 100 grams in the sample
* fat -- Amount of fat per 100 grams in the sample
* ash -- Amount of ash per 100 grams in the sample
* sodium -- Amount of sodium per 100 grams in the sample
* carb -- Amount of carbohydrates per 100 grams in the sample
* cal -- Amount of calories per 100 grams in the sample
How can you represent this data as concise and understandable as possible? It is impossible to plot all variables as is onto a flat screen/paper. Furthermore
column2: high-dimensional data suffers from what is called the curse of dimensionality.

column1: This term was coined by Richard R. Bellman
column2: an American applied mathematician. As the number of features / dimensions increases
column3: the distance among data points grows exponential. Things become really sparse as the instances lie very far away from each other. This makes applying machine learning methods much more difficult
column4: since there is a certain relationship between the number of features and the number of training data. In short
column5: with higher dimensions you need to gather much more data for learning to actually occur
column6: which leaves a lot of room for error. Moreover
column7: higher-dimension spaces have many counter-intuitive properties
column8: and the human mind
column9: as well as most data analysis tools
column10: is used to dealing with only up to three dimensions (like the world we are living in). Thus
column11: data visualization and intepretation become much harder
column12: and computational costs of model training greatly increases. '''Principle Component Analysis helps to alleviate this problem'''.

column1: Principle Component Analysis is one of the foundational methods to combat the curse of dimensionality. It is an unsupervised learning algorithm whose goals is to reduce the dimensionality of the data
column2: condensing its entirety down to a low number of dimensions (also called principle components
column3: usually two or three).

column1: Although it comes with a cost of losing some information
column2: it makes data visualization much easier
column3: improves the space and time complexity required for machine learning algorithms tremendously
column4: and allows for more intuitive intepretation of these models. PCA can also be categorized a feature extraction techniques
column5: since it creates these principle components - new and more relevant features - from the original ones.

column1: The essence of PCA lies in finding all directions in which the data ""spreads""
column2: determining the extent in which the data spreads in those directions
column3: keeping only few direction in which the data spreads the most. And voila
column4: these are your new dimensions / features of the data.

column1: Oftentimes the features in the data are measured on different scales. This step makes sure that all features contribute equally to the analysis. Otherwise
column2: variables with large range will trump thoses with smaller range (for example: a time variable that ranges between 0ms and 1000ms with dominate over a distance variable that ranges between 0m and 10m). Each variable can be scaled by subtracting its mean and dividing by the standard deviation (this is the same as calculating the z-score
column3: and in the end
column4: all variables with have the same mean 0 and standard deviation of 1).

column1: The covariance matrix is a square d x d matrix
column2: where each entry represents the covariance of a possible pair of the original features. It has the following properties:

column1: * The size of the matrix is equal to the number of features in the data
* The main diagonal on the matrix contains the variances of each initial variables.

column2: since Cov(d1
column3: d2) = Cov(d1

column1: The covariance matrix gives you a summary of the relationship among the initial variables.
* A positive value indicate a directly proportional relationship (as d1 increases
column2: d2 increases
column3: and vice versa)

column1: * A negative value indicate a indirectly proportional relationship (as d1 increases
column2: d2 decreases
column3: and vice versa)

column1: Now we have the covariance matrix. This matrix can be used to transform one vector into another. Normally when this transformation happens
column2: two things happen: the original is  rotated and get streched/squished to form a new vector. When an abitrary vector is multipled by the covariance matrix
column3: the result will be a new vector whose direction is nudged/rotated towards the greatest spread in the data. In the figure below
column4: we start with the arbitrary vector (-1
column5: 0.5) in red. Multiplying the red vector with covariance matrix gives us the blue vector
column6: and repeating this gives us the black vector. As you can see
column7: the result rotation tends to converge towards the widest spread direction of the data.

column1: This prompts the questions: Can we find directly find the vector which already lies on this ""widest spread direction"". The answer is yes
column2: with the help of eigenvectors. Simply put
column3: an eigenvectors of a certain matrix is a vector that
column4: when transformed by the matrix
column5: does not rotate. It remains on its own span
column6: and the only thing that changes is its magnitude. This (constant) change ratio in magnitude corresponding to each eigenvector is called eigenvalue. It indicates how much of the data variability can be explained by its eigenvector.

column2: since there are two dimensions
column3: we get (at most) two egenvectors and two corresponding eigenvalues. Even if we only plot the eigenvectors scaled by their eigenvalues
column4: we will basically have a summary data (and its spreading). At this point
column5: the eigenpairs are be viewed as the principle components of the data.

column2: the eigenvectors are perpendicular to each other. This is no coincidence. You can think of it this way: because we want to maximize the variance explained by each of the principle components
column3: these components need to be independent from one another
column4: therefore their orthogonality.  Thus
column5: to define a set of principle components
column6: you find the direction which can explain the variability in the data the most: that is your first principle component (the eigenvector with the highest eigenvalue). The second principle compent will be percepdicular to the first
column7: and explain most of what is left of the variability. This continues until the d-th principle component is found.

column2: you are also sorting the ""importance"" of the principle components in terms of the information amount it contains what is used to explain the data. To be clear
column3: the sum of all eigenvalues is the total variability in the data. From here
column4: you can choose to discard any PCs whose percentage of explained variances are low. In many cases
column5: if around 80% of the variance can be explained by the first k PCs
column6: we can discard the other (d - k) PCs. Of course
column7: this is only one of the heuristics method to determine k.  You can also use thr elbow method (the scree plot) like in k-means.

column1: * PCA is a feature extraction technique widely used to reduce dimensionality of datasets.

* PCA works by calculating the eigenvectors and the corresponding eigenvalues of the initial variables in the data. These are the principle components. Number of PCs = number of eigenvectors = number of features.
* The PCs are ranked by the eigenvalues
column2: and iteratively show the directions in which the data spreads the most (after accounting for the previous PCs).

column1: * We can choose to keep a few of the first PCs that cummulatively explains the data well enough
column2: and these are the new reduced dimension of the data.

column1: * Standardization is a crucial step in data pre-processing to ensure the validity of the PCA results.

'''In short:''' The Q methodology is a qualitative
column2: inductive and exploratory method to identify groups of people concerning their preferences or dissimilarities about specific information.

column1: [[File:Q-Methodology scopus plot.png|400px|thumb|right|'''SCOPUS hits per year for Q-Methodology until 2022'''. Search term: ""q method"" OR ""q methodology"" in Title
column2: Abstract
column3: Keywords. Source: own.]]

column1: The Q methodology was developed in 1935 at the University of London by William Stephenson in an attempt to challenge the logic of “testing” that was and is predominant in psychology. However
column2: in Stephenson`s opinion
column3: psychology had not yet reached a “sophisticated theoretical status” (such as e.g. physics had) which would have enabled a deductive mode of theory-testing. Therefore
column4: he proclaimed a more inductive approach to derive new discoveries before moving on to testing theories (Watts and Stenner 2005). Therefore
column5: he developed the Q methodology as a qualitative and inductive method to identify groups of people who share the same points of view on a certain topic (Stephenson 1935; Watts & Stenner 2005).

column2: Q methodology was only used in psychology
column3: but recently it is used in various research communities
column4: e.g. nutrition research (see Dennis & Goldberg 1996)
column5: biodiversity management (see Hamadou et al. 2016) as well as research on the perceptions of ecosystem services (see Baral et al. 2017; Milcu et al. 2014).

column1: The Q methodology is applied to identify different perspectives on a topic that occur in a population. This is done by identifying groups of people who sort a pool of items in a comparable way (Watts and Stenner 2005). However
column2: this method does not allow generalised statements about the whole population the participants are from. Instead
column3: Q methodology only allows us to identify the main perspectives or perceptions that can be found in this population.

column1: The process of the Q methodology follows the standard process of research. First
column2: the data is gathered by letting participants sort a number of items called “Q items” (e.g. cards with statements or pictures) according to their preference from high to low. Second
column3: data is analysed by correlating the resulting configurations
column4: called “Q sorts”
column5: with each other and performing a factor analysis. Third
column6: the results of the factor analysis are interpreted.

column2: the procedure works as follows:

column1: The Q set is compiled of the Q items that the participants have to sort. The Q items can be statements that the participants agree or disagree with to a certain extent or pictures that they like more or less. The Q items can be everything that can be brought into an order of preference. In early studies
column2: Q methodology was even conducted with bottled fragrances (Stephenson 1936).

column1: The Q set is generated based on the research question. This means that the research question needs to be clear before generating the Q set. The research question should be straightforward and easily understandable for the participants. The Q set is supposed to enable the participants to answer the research question. Therefore
column2: the Q items need to be as heterogeneous as possible to cover a broadly representative range of perspectives. An ideal Q set comprises between 40 and 80 items (Stainton Rogers 1995). The Q items need to be selected very carefully to find items that do not overlap
column3: but at the same time no perspective should be missing. Therefore
column4: the selection process takes the most time and effort of all the steps of the Q methodology. It is suggested to first create an overly large set of Q items and then reduce this number by doing pilot tests.

column2: t 40 to 60 participants  in a Q methodological study are proposed to be an appropriate sample size (Stainton Rogers 1995). However
column3: Q studies can also be carried out with fewer participants. Being a qualitative method
column4: the number of participants is less important than the constitution of the participant group. To get a wide range of perspectives
column5: it might make sense to strategically sample participants from different backgrounds. For instance
column6: it makes sense to include experts who might have a pivotal opinion on a topic. The optimal relation between Q items and participants is described as 2:1 for classic Q studies (Watts & Stenner 2012
column7: cited after Burkhardt 2017).

column2: the distribution matrix follows a normal distribution from -6 to +6. In this case
column3: Q items that are ranked lowest by participants are placed at -6 whereas items that are highly preferred by participants are placed at +6. Items that are ranked at 0 would be the ones that the participants feel indifferent towards. Just as in a normal distribution
column4: the extreme values -6 and +6 can be assigned the lowest number of items and the middle value 0 can be assigned  the most (Figure 1).

column1: '''Figure 1'''. Example of a Fixed Quasi-Normal Distribution for 60 Q items according to Stenner & Watts (2005). Q items that the participant agrees most with or values the most are placed at +6 and the ones that the participant disagrees with most or values the least are placed at -6. The items that are out in the middle around 0 are the ones that the participant feels indifferent about. Important to note is that only the ranking on the x axis matters. The order in which the items are placed on the y axis is of no importance.
Apart from this “fixed” or “forced” distribution also completely “free” distributions are possible. In this case
column2: the participants can assign any number of items to any of the ranking positions. Statistical comparisons have shown that the kind of distribution does not make a noticeable contribution to the results. However
column3: the forced distribution is less work for the scientist and is more convenient for the participants (Watts & Stenner 2005).

column2: the sorting is conducted by only one participant at a time under the supervision of the researcher. In the beginning
column3: the researcher is giving the instructions on how to sort the Q items according to the participant’s preferences. It is important to state that there is no wrong or right kind of ranking
column4: but the ranking is just based on personal preference. Since the time people have for sorting influences the outcome
column5: the researcher should decide in advance if the participants should sort spontaneously or if they should have more time to think about the ranking. To influence the outcome as little as possible or at least to minimize the variance
column6: the researcher should not give any input after explaining the way the ranking should be done
column7: except for when urgent questions of understanding arise regarding the Q items. In the end
column8: the Q sort is documented
column9: e.g.
column10: by taking a photograph.

column2: but very helpful to understand the sorting)'''

column1: To get a better interpretation of the Q sorts
column2: it makes sense to do a post sort interview. The post sort interview can be used to ask the interviewee to explain their choices
column3: especially regarding the top and bottom items. Moreover
column4: basic demographic information should be collected from the interviewee such as age
column5: occupation and personal history (Milcu et al. 2014). For later analysis
column6: it is helpful to record the interview with the permission of the interviewee.

column1: If the Q sorting was done by manually sorting the items
column2: the Q sorts of each participant have to be manually typed into an analysis program. For analysis
column3: the freely available text-based statistics software R is proposed. The program R and the package “qmethod” (Zabala et al. 2021) implement diverse approaches of the method and can both be used for fixed and free distributions. The data can be imported as an Excel sheet. Additionally
column4: with PCQ for Windows (commercial) and PQ Method (free)
column5: clickable software is available
column6: too.

column1: Q-sample data are analysed through principal component analysis (PCA). Therefore
column2: the Q sorts are intercorrelated and factor analysed. The Varimax rotation is often suggested for this purpose (Milcu 2014; Watts & Stenner 2005). For the factor analyses
column3: the PCA function of the FactoMineR package in R is suggested. This analysis allows us to identify factors with eigenvalues above 1. This has the purpose to exclude factors that serve no data-reductive purpose. These are the factors that explain less of the variance than would any single Q sort (Watts & Stenner 2005). An interpretable factor must have at least two Q sorts that load significantly onto this factor alone. This means that at least two participants who share this factor must have produced very similar Q sorts. These participants make sense of the Q items in a similar way.

column1: For interpretation of the Q sorts
column2: possible solutions are chosen based on statistical as well as content-related aspects.  Q sorts are selected that are characteristic of a factor and significantly load onto this factor alone. These are called “factor exemplars”. They exemplify the configuration of Q items that is characteristic for this factor (Watts & Stenner 2005).  The factors exemplars are interpreted by using the information of the post-sort interview. By doing so
column3: the researcher can figure out if interviewees whose Q sorts significantly load onto the same factor also share other properties such as age
column4: occupation or interests.

column1: Q methodology  is often criticised since the outcome depends on the way the research question is stated and on the way the Q items are chosen and/ or formulated. Consequently
column2: the researcher needs to pay a lot of attention towards these two aspects to get meaningful results (Watts and Stenner 2005). This can be done by doing pre-tests. Moreover
column3: the interpretation of the results is rather subjective (Eden et al. 2005). Therefore
column4: the validity and reproducibility of the Q methodology is often under debate. However
column5: William Stephenson assures that the results of the repetitions of a Q method might not be identical
column6: but still reveal relatively similar patterns (Stephenson 1972). Consequently the main conclusion of the repetitions of a Q methodology should be the same.

column1: Due to the qualitative nature of the Q methodology
column2: it can only be used to identify points of view in a population
column3: but not by how many people these points of view are shared. Therefore
column4: it can only be used for exploratory purposes but not for hypothesis testing.

column1: Another challenge regarding this method is that it does not include temporal dynamics
column2: but portrays a temporally frozen image of viewpoints (Watts and Stenner 2005). Therefore
column3: it is crucial to interpret the results of Q methodology in relation to the point in time when the data was collected. For instance
column4: in the case of environmental questions and ecosystem services
column5: it is known that perceptions of a population change with the seasons (Greenland-Smith & Sherren 2016; van Berkel & Verburg 2014). An ecosystem service such as outdoor recreation might be more important to people in summer than in winter.

column1: The strength of the Q methodology lies in explorative studies in cases where there is not yet much data on a certain topic. In these cases
column2: it creates a good overview of different perspectives. Moreover
column3: it provides a large number of application opportunities as it can be used for various items such as statements
column4: pictures and all kinds of objects. For the participants
column5: it is more intuitive and fun to conduct a Q method-based interview than just answering questions or filling out a questionnaire. Since the implementation of the method is relatively straightforward compared to other methods
column6: it is applicable to collect perceptions of all kinds of different stakeholders.

column1: Q methodology is able to combine qualitative and quantitative aspects of knowledge
column2: as it combines a statistical design with intuitive sorting of items such as pictures and statements. Therefore
column3: this method has great potential for collecting data on stakeholders' perceptions on topics concerning the world's most disputed problems.

column2: the results are not representative for bigger populations as they are strongly dependent on the perspectives of the relatively few participants and their respective context. If the selection of participants is thus not representative
column3: important perspectives could be unintentionally excluded and
column4: as a result
column5: overlooked (Danielson et al. 2009). The reason for the low number of participants is that in traditional Q studies
column6: there used to be the rule that the number of participants should only be half the number of Q items. Otherwise
column7: the authors feared to lose the qualitative aspects of this method (Watts & Stenner 2005).

column2: the Q methodology might benefit from loosening this strict rule and allowing more participants to be included in the study. This would also allow more perspectives to be added and would therefore solve one of the main issues of this method. Additionally
column3: more insightful statistical analyses would be possible with a larger number of participants
column4: allowing not only a greater understanding of variance

column1: That a development of this method is possible and can be successful
column2: is illustrated by the factor analysis which in traditional Q studies used the centroid method. This method provides a theoretically infinite number of rotated solutions. In the long run
column3: this method proved to be too elaborate as the Q analyst has to consider a lot of different rotated solutions before they choose the most informative one. Instead
column4: nowadays the PCA method is often used for factor analysis. This works much faster as the PCA automatically chooses the mathematically superior solution. The results of the PCA are described as “equally satisfying” as the results of the centroid method (Watts & Stenner 2005).

column2: Q methodology should be improved even further and adapted to the purposes it is nowadays used for. Since it is already used in interdisciplinary research
column3: it makes sense to step away from the strict rules that it was associated with when it originated from qualitative psychology
column4: where these rules were more of a conflict point instead of a solution

Questioning the status quo in methods;"'''Note:''' The German version of this entry can be found here: [[Questioning the status quo in methods (German)]].
'''In short:''' This entry discusses why the status quo of scientific methods is insufficient to solve the problems of our time.
Building on the general recognition that current methods are not enough to approximate knowledge towards the solution needed for the wicked problems which we face
column2: the questions arises how we can meaningfully question the ''status quo'' in methods
column3: and do this in a way that moves us forward. Too many enthusiastic questions on the ''status quo'' in the realms of [[Glossary|scientific methods]] have been proposed without a clear understanding what is actually the problem
column4: or better
column5: which knowledge we are lacking. The current state of many lines of thinking urged us to move out of the dimensions of a normal science in the sense of Kuhn. However
column6: calling out a revolution does not mean that all problems are automatically solved. On the contrary: concerning many aspects
column7: we are still in a state of explicitly not knowing how to solve the wicked problems we face. Let us look at three examples.

column1: Climate change is a complex phenomenon: at first
column2: the realisation that human-induced climate change is happening was slowly emerging out of diverse scientific data sources and research approaches. While today
column3: the majority of society has accepted that human-induced climate change is real
column4: and that it is our responsibility to react and counteract
column5: there is no general agreement on a best way to do so. Instead
column6: there are calls for a globally orchestrated policy-response
column7: which takes place are on a totally different scale compared to local adaptation. Most importantly
column8: how can we convince citizens in countries which lead in terms of a negative contribution to climate change for decades to not only change their behaviour
column9: but actually to contribute to reversing its catastrophic effects? This is the current frontier in research
column10: and many promising suggestions and strategies are currently being investigated. However
column11: since we may only know in retrospect how this problem was at least approachable if not completely solvable
column12: after all
column13: we need to further diversify our research approaches
column14: and also consider the urgency of the problem. A 20-year longitudinal study won't do the trick - we need suggestions as soon as possible. The urgency and the wickedness of this problem showcase the need for novel methods to contribute to the approximation of solutions.

column1: Research about normative challenges - as well as research about joined problem framing between actors and researchers - has been on the rise. More and more studies engage in the new contract between science and society. However
column2: the roles and [[Glossary|power]] relations of different actors within a system are deeply contextual
column3: and so far the knowledge of such studies did not yet saturate into a more general understanding on how such study setting can be approached. While blueprints already exist and there is a growing understanding of relevant concepts
column4: such as social learning
column5: actor participation is still something that did not find its way into a broad diversity of textbooks
column6: and available approaches are far from unified. Most of the normal sciences actually dispute whether the recognition of actor knowledge is actually contributing to scientific progress
column7: and instead keep judging the difference between applied science and their own science. What is more
column8: actor participation is approached from all sorts of disciplinary backgrounds. This increases diversity in terms of methods
column9: but ultimately leads to more confusion because the different approaches rooted in diverse disciplines are often pitched as being either superior or inferior to each other. While it is clear that different methods have different values in a specific context
column10: a comparison of different methods which allow for actor participation is widely lacking to date. However
column11: only fair comparisons of diverse approaches may allow for a claim of which methodological approach has a higher validity in a respective context.

column1: The question how we shift our consumption towards being more sustainable is another thriving debate within sustainability science and beyond. While there is research focusing on global trade and its inequalities
column2: there is equally research on individual behaviour and the motivations of consumers. Understanding behavior - and even more so - driving behaviour change in terms of sustainable consumption is to date a diverse field
column3: with methodological roots in psychology
column4: social science and many other domains. On the other hand
column5: global supply chains and trade arrangements are part of totally different fields in sciences and these two scales are hardly matched. There is a clear gap between research focusing on supply and research focussing on demand. From a methodological standpoint
column6: integrating the global and the individual scale
column7: and supply and demand
column8: already poses a very complex challenge
column9: showcasing how a link between these diverse line of thinking will preoccupy research for the foreseeable future. Atomising challenges into smaller chunks that represent parts of the picture follows a long tradition in science
column10: yet integrating these diverse approaches will be vital in order to take the whole depth and width of the challenges into account.

column1: We can thus conclude that urgency
column2: wickedness
column3: normativity
column4: context
column5: scale integration and many other challenges are currently recognised in the community of sustainability science researchers
column6: and deserve more focus in order to generate solutions. This non-exhaustive list of problems already showcases that this is more easily proposed than actually done. Within sustainability science and beyond
column7: there is almost an obsession to question the ''status quo''
column8: and to proclaim what methods should do. It sounds so appealing to ""dance with the system"" - a sentence borrowed from Donella Meadows (I always asked myself what that actually means). But how do we take the normative burden off of all the proposals for transformation and take a first step as individual researchers? Here
column9: I propose three perspectives on how [[Glossary|innovation]] in terms of scientific methods could be more concretely approached.

column1: Inventing new methods surely sounds exciting. There is a whole world of knowledge that awaits us
column2: and new methods might be potentially able to unlock this new knowledge. Despite the spirit that motivates many researchers to this end
column3: I would like to highlight that in the past
column4: the invention of new methods often came out of a clear recognition of a lack of methods in order to solve a specific problems. The proposals of Interviews as a scientific method
column5: or [[Grounded Theory]]
column6: were rooted in the recognition of a lack of a suitable methodological approach for a specific problem. Take [[Open Interview|Open Interviews]] as an example
column7: which allowed for an inductive recognition of the perceptions of individuals. This type of knowledge as such did not exist before
column8: and the proposal of these new methods allowed for a gap to be closed. In order to close this gap
column9: I believe that this gap needed to be recognized
column10: which was rooted in the recognition of clear knowledge and experience with methods that were already there.

column1: Take Fischers Analysis of Variance as another example
column2: which basically took the implementation of systematic [[Experiments and Hypothesis Testing|experimentation]] onto a completely new level. Fischer saw existing research at the agricultural research center he was working at as a statistician
column3: and he saw a clear lack of a systematic method that allowed to generate knowledge in terms of pattern recognition based on the testing of a predominated hypothesis. Fischer knew the state of the art
column4: and he recognised a clear gap in the canon of existing methods. What is more
column5: he had experience in the already existing methods
column6: which was a precondition for his formulation of the Analysis of Variance. The invention of new methods is thus quite often a gradual process in a continuous development
column7: although historians of science often reduce it to one point in time. To this end
column8: I propose to recognise more of a continuum in which such new methods are being proposed. Such innovative settings typically build on experience regarding existing methods
column9: and through this a recognition of a gap within the already existing methods
column10: or better even
column11: of the knowledge which these methods can produce.

column1: Methodological innovation often build on existing methods
column2: if these are used in a different setting or context. For instance
column3: [[Semi-structured Interview|interviews]] were applied in the world value survey at a global scale
column4: allowing for a global comparison of people's values based on tens of thousands of interviews. The method of structured interviews existed long before that
column5: and one could argue that such larger surveys even predated the 1960 proclamation of Strauss and Glaser regarding interviews. However
column6: a global comparison was clearly unique. Another example is how the [[ANOVA|Analysis of Variance]] was once widely reserved for [[:Category:Deductive|deductive]] experiments
column7: until the [[History of Methods|rise of data science]] and the availability of more data though the Internet and other sources led to the application of the Analysis of Variance in purely [[:Category:Inductive|inductive]] settings. Another example would be the diverse applications of text analysis
column8: which were once postulated for very specific setting
column9: but are today applied in all sort of branches of science. The relocation of a method basically utilises an existing method in a different setting of context than it was original intended to be used. Again
column10: this does not only imply that experience with the existing method is a necessary precondition for its relocation
column11: but the real innovation potential comes out of the recognition of a gap
column12: and that the relocation of the existing method may close this gap by creating new knowledge.

column1: Another possibility of creating innovation in methodology is through the recombination of existing methods. For example
column2: with the rise of data becoming available through surveys
column3: statistics allowed for the utilisation of diverse methods to analyse data coming out of surveys
column4: and later also from structured interviews. Such innovation is rather gradual
column5: and less recognised by the scientific community. Another example would be the utilisation of statistical methods for coded items from a Grounded Theory approach. While originally this approach focused on qualitative research
column6: there are now examples how coded information is compiled in a table which is then statistically analysed. Such innovation is often a violation of the original rules or norms that were proclaimed with a method
column7: and thus have also attracted controversy and criticism in the past. Nevertheless
column8: recombining diverse methods builds on a deep understanding and even experience of a respective method
column9: showcasing yet again how researchers created new knowledge by building on already established methodological approaches.

column1: == Some remarks on innovation and experience ==
These three proposed possibilities of methodological innovation are clearly building on [[Design Thinking]]
column2: as the development of methodological applications can be understood as a design problem. Creating a methodological design is necessarily a commitment that may be criticised as static or even downright dogmatic by some researchers
column3: yet the here proposed approaches for innovation should rather be seen as a starting point than as a new dogma. Instead
column4: I propose a counterpoint to a hype for methodological innovation that may be appealing to many
column5: yet makes it very hard for researchers to start with their specific research in my experience. There is a tendency in sustainability science to reject all methodological dogmas in order to be unbiased and more creative. While this sounds appealing in theory
column6: I would counterargue in the spirit of [[Bias and Critical Thinking|critical realism]]: some observable realities can be accessed by existing methods
column7: and some new activated knowledge that we try to unravel may demand methodological innovation. All this implies that - following Roy Baskhar - we should clearly reject any claim of any knowledge being perfect
column8: independent of whether it is based on old or new methodologies. Knowledge can and most certainly will change.

column2: the urge for novel methodologies is so strong right now that experience in existing methodologies is rejected altogether. I consider this to be a dangerous new dogma
column3: and kindly ask future researchers to consider experience in empirical methodologies as an important basis for innovation. As I have clearly shown above
column4: there can be more than just theoretical considerations why methodological innovation can build on experience in existing methodologies. Such experience should always include a recognition of its limitations
column5: and in the long run there might be a greater recognition of new design approaches that shall drive methodological innovation.

column1: The interconnectedness of different forms of knowledge; reflexivity of researchers and other actors; the recognition of [[Agency
column2: Complexity and Emergence|complexity]] in systems; and the necessity of power relations in knowledge production are prominent examples of current challenges that methodologies as of yet have not solved. We are probably still far away from the creation of a solidified canon of knowledge to solve these riddles. One could argue that we will never solve these methodological problems altogether
column3: but that the joined action and interaction while working on these problems will be the actual solution
column4: and that a real solution as with past methods of normal science shall never be reached. This is unclear to date
column5: yet we need to become aware that when we question the ''status quo'' of knowledge production and methodologies
column6: we may not be looking for goals
column7: but more for a path. There are several examples in sustainability science that follow this path
column8: such as [[Transdisciplinarity|transdisciplinarity]] and [[System Thinking & Causal Loop Diagrams|system thinking]]. However
column9: according to critical realism
column10: it may be good to solidify innovative and novel methodologies to a point that enables as to take meaningful actions based on the knowledge we create.

column1: Regression analyses and assessment of correlation between different variables are common approaches when working with data in many different fields. Albeit it does not provide detailed insights into the mechanisms underlying the relationship of the variables investigated
column2: it is a good first analysis to get an overview of what is going on. Correlation describes a linear relationship between at least two variables. It ranges between -1 and 1
column3: which are called perfect positive and perfect negative correlation respectively. For example
column4: a correlation between income (in Euros) and education (in years of schooling) of 0.5 indicates that there is a positive linear relationship between an increase in education and income. The most common approach to assessing corelation is via regression analysis. In regression analysis
column5: a relationship between one dependent variable and at least on independent variable is assessed. With the help of the regression analysis
column6: the effect of a change in the independent variable(s) by one unit on the dependent variable is modelled. This model therefore tries to find the linear curve that is best representing the actual relationship between the dependent and the independent variable(s). Returning to the example of income and education
column7: we can set income to be the dependent variable and education as the independent variable. We can also add other variables affecting income
column8: such as average wages in the country of the workplace (GDP)
column9: or relevant working experiences (in months of experience). With the regression analysis
column10: we can then assess the change in income with a one unit increase of education and working experience
column11: and an increase in GDP when having an international dataset. One of the most used estimators for assessing correlation is the ordinary least squares estimator (OLS). The OLS aims to produce a linear curve whose values minimize the sum of the squared values of the dependent variable and the predicted values from the regression equation. The OLS estimator relies on a number of assumptions that cannot be discussed in detail
column12: but you can find them [https://towardsdatascience.com/assumptions-in-ols-regression-why-do-they-matter-9501c800787dXX here]. In the following
column13: we will have a look at a record of computer science exercises results from students. We will prepare the data
column14: do some analytic checks
column15: and finally apply the OLS estimator.

'''In short:''' Regression analysis tests whether a relation between two continuous variables is positive or negative
column2: how strong the relation is
column3: and whether the relation is significantly different from chance.

column1: '''Note:''' This entry revolves around simple linear regressions and the fundamentals of regression analysis. For more info
column2: please refer to the entries on [[Causality and correlation]] as well as [[Generalized Linear Models]].

column1: The question whether two continuous variables are linked initially emerged with the [[History of Methods|rise of data from astronomical observation]]. Initial theoretical foundations were laid by Gauss and Legendre
column2: yet many relevant developments also happened much later. '''At their core
column3: the basics of regressions revolved around the importance of the [[Data_distribution#The_normal_distributionnormal_distribution|normal distribution]].''' While Yule and Pearson were more rigid in recognising the foundational importance of the normal distribution of the data
column4: Fisher argued that only the response variable needs to follow this distribution. This highlights yet another feud between the two early key innovators in statistics - Fisher and Pearson - who seem to be only able to agree to disagree on each other. The regression analysis was rooted famously in an observation by Galton called ''regression towards the mean'' - which proclaims that within most statistical samples
column5: an outlier point is more likely than not followed by a data point that is closer to the mean. This proves to be a natural law for many dynamics that can be observed
column6: underlining the foundational importance of the normal distribution
column7: and how it translates into our understanding of [[Glossary|patterns]] in the world.

column1: Regressions rose to worldwide recognition through econometrics
column2: which used the increasing wealth of data from nation states and other systems to find relations within market dynamics and others patterns associated to economics. Equally
column3: the regression was increasingly applied in medicine
column4: engineering and many other fields of science. The 20th century became a time ruled by numbers
column5: and the regression was one of its most important methods. '''Today
column6: it is commonplace in all branches of science that utilise quantitative data to analyze data through regressions'''
column7: including economics
column8: social science
column9: ecology
column10: engineering
column11: medicine
column12: psychology
column13: and many other branches of science. Almost all statistical software packages allow for the analysis of regressions
column14: the most common software solutions are R
column15: SPSS
column16: Matlab and Python. Thanks to the computer revolutions
column17: most regressions are easy and fast in their computation
column18: and with the rising availability of more and more data
column19: the regression became the most abundantly used simple statistical model that exists to date.

column1: [[File:Linear Regression Example.png|450px|thumb|right|'''An exemplary linear regression. It shows the distribution of the data points alongside two axes
column2: and the regression line.''' Source: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regression_analysis#/media/File:Linear_regression.svg Sewaqu
column3: Wikipedia]]]

column1: Regressions statistically test the dependence of one continuous variable with another continuous variable. Building on a calculation that resolves around ''least squares''
column2: regression analysis can test whether a relation between to continuous variables is positive or negative
column3: how strong the relation is
column4: and whether the relation is significantly different from chance
column5: i.e. following a non-random pattern. This is an important difference to [[Correlations]]
column6: which only revolve around the relation between variables without assuming - or testing for - a causal link. Thus
column7: identifying regressions can help us infer predictions about future developments of a relation.

column2: a dependent variable is explained by an independent variable
column3: both of which are [[Data_formats#Continuous_data|continuous]].''' At the heart of any regression analysis is the optimisation of a regression line that minimises the distance of the line to all individual points. In other words
column4: the ''least square'' calculation maximizes the way how the regression line can integrate the sum of the squares of all individual data points to the regression line. The line can thus indicate a negative or positive relation by a negative or positive estimate
column5: which is the value that indicates how much the y value increases if the x value increases.

column1: '''The sum of the squares of the distance of all points to the regression line allows to calculate an r squared value.''' It indicates how strong the relation between the x and the y variable is. This value can range from 0 to 1
column2: with 0 indicating no relation at all
column3: and 1 indicating a perfect relation. There are many diverse suggestions of what constitutes a strong or a weak regression
column4: and this depends strongly on the context.

column2: the non-randomness of the relation is indicated by the p-value
column3: which shows whether the relation of the two continuous variables is random or not. If the p-value is below 0
column4: 05 (typically)
column5: we call the relation significant. If there is a significant relation between the dependent and the independent variable
column6: then new additional data is supposed to follow the same relation (see 'Prediction' bevlow). There are diverse ideas whether the two variables should follow a normal distribution
column7: but it is commonly assumed that if the residuals - which is the deviation of the data points from a perfect relation - should follow a normal distribution. In other words
column8: the error that is revealed through your understanding of the observed pattern follows a statistical normal distribution. Any [[Data_distribution#Non-normal_distributions|non-normally distributed pattern]] might reveal flaws in sampling
column9: a lack of additional variables
column10: confounding factors
column11: or other profound problems that limit the value of your analysis.

column1: '''[[A matter of probability|Probability]] is one of the most important concepts in modern statistics.''' The question whether a relation between two variables is purely by chance
column2: or following a pattern with a certain probability
column3: is the basis of all probability statistics (surprise!). In the case of linear relations
column4: another quantification is of central relevance: the question how much variance is explained by the model. These two things - the amount of variance explained by a linear model
column5: and the fact that two variables are not randomly related - are related at least to some amount. '''If a model is highly significant
column6: it typically shows a high r squared value.''' If a model is marginally significant
column7: then the r squared value is typically low.

column1: This relation is however also influenced by the sample size. Linear models and the related p-value describing the model are highly sensitive to sample size. You need at least a handful of points to get a significant relation
column2: even if the r squared value in this model with a small sample size may be already high. Therefore
column3: the relation between sample size
column4: the r squared value and the p-value is central to understand how meaningful a model is.

column1: '''Regression analysis may allow for predictions based on available data.''' Predictions are a common element of statistics. In general
column2: prediction means that we are able to foresee data beyond the range of our available data
column3: based on the statistical power of our model which we developed based on the available data. In other words
column4: we have enough confidence in our initial data analysis so that we can try to predict what might happen under other circumstances. Most prominently
column5: people predict data in the future
column6: or in other places
column7: which is called ''extrapolation''. By comparison
column8: ''interpolation'' allows us to predict within the range of our data
column9: spanning over gaps in the data. Hence while interpolation allows us to predict within our data
column10: extrapolation allows prediction beyond our dataset.

column1: '''Care is necessary when considering interpolation or extrapolation
column2: as validity decreases when we dwell beyond the data we have.''' It takes experience to know when prediction is possible
column3: and when it is dangerous.

column1: # We need to consider if our theoretical [[Glossary|assumptions]] can be reasonable expanded beyond the data of our sample.
# Our statistical model may be less applicable outside or our data range.
# Mitigating or interacting factors may become more relevant in the space outside of our sample range.

'''We always need to consider these potential flaws or sources of error that may overall reduce the validity of our model when we use it for interpolation or extrapolation.''' As soon as we gather outside of the data space we sampled
column2: we take the risk to produce invalid predictions. The ""[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Missing_Shade_of_Blue missing shade of blue]"" problem from Hume exemplifies the ambiguities that can be associated with interpolation already
column3: and extrapolation would be seen as worse by many
column4: as we go beyond our data sample space.

column1: A common example of extrapolation would be a mechanistic model of climate change
column2: where based on the trend in CO2 rates on Mauna Loa over the last decades we predict future trends. A prominent example of interpolation is the Worldclim dataset
column3: which generates a global climate dataset based on advanced interpolation. Based on ten thousands of climate stations and millions of records this dataset provides knowledge about the average temperature and precipitation of the whole terrestrial globe. The data has been used in thousands of scientific publications and is a good example of how open source data substantially enabled a new scientific arena
column4: namely Macroecology.

column2: in comparison
column3: are rather simple models which may still allow us to predict data. If our regression shows a significant relation between two variables
column4: and is able to explain a major part of the variance
column5: we can use the regression for extra- or interpolation - while respecting the limitations mentioned above.

column1: The main strength of regressions is equally their main weakness: Regression analysis examines the dependence of one continuous variable on another continuous variable. '''Consequently
column2: this may be either describing a causal pattern or not.''' The [[Causality and correlation|question of causality]] in regression can be extremely helpful if examined with care. More information on causality can be found [[Causality|here.]] The main points to consider are the criteria of Hume: If A causes B
column3: then A has a characteristic that leads to B. If C does not lead to B
column4: then C has a characteristic that differs from A. Also
column5: causality is build on temporal sequence: only if A happens before B
column6: then A can lead to B. All this is relevant for regressions
column7: as the dependence between variables may be interpreted as causality.

column1: The strongest point of regression models may be that we can test hypotheses
column2: yet this poses also a great danger
column3: because regressions can be applied both inductively and deductively. A safe rooting in theory seems necessary in order to test for meaningful relationships between to variables.

column2: and many people utilising regression analysis are next to obsessed with high r squared values. However
column3: the calculation of p-values can be problematic due to statistical fishing: '''the more models are calculated
column4: the higher the chance to find something significant'''. Equally difficult is the orientation along r squared values. There is no universally agreed threshold that differentiates a good from a bad model
column5: instead the context matters. As usual
column6: different conventions and norms in the diverse branches of science create misunderstandings and tensions

column1: Regressions strongly resolve around the normal distribution. While many phenomena that can be measured meet this criteria
column2: the regression fails with much of the available datasets that consist of [[Data_formats#Discrete_data|count (or 'discrete') data]]. Other distributions are incorporated into more advanced methods of analysis
column3: such as [[Generalized Linear Models|generalised linear models]]
column4: and we have to acknowledge that the regression works robustly for normally distributed data
column5: but only for these datasets where this criteria is met.

column2: it can be concluded that the regression is one of the most simple and robust model available in statistics
column3: yet the world moved on and spawned more complex models that are better able to take more diverse assumptions into account. '''The regression is still suitable for the original case for which it was proposed'''
column4: testing the dependence between two continuous variables
column5: and building on an understanding of such derived patterns that widely resolves around the normal distribution.

column1: The main problem for regression analysis is that these models are applied in cases that do not meet the necessary assumptions. Many problems that were derived from regressions models surfaced because users ignored the original assumptions resolving around normal distributions
column2: or tried to press patterns into a linear line of thinking that does not meet the reality of the data. '''Regressions can be seen as a main tool that led to the failure of positivism
column3: because regressions always analyse a snapshot in time
column4: and dynamics of data may change.''' The financial crisis is a good example
column5: where on one day all patterns deviated from the previous pattern that were analysed by most stock brokers
column6: thereby triggering a cascade of effects and patterns that can be predicted by regression models
column7: but only at a dramatically different time horizon. While before
column8: market shifts operated on a scale of months
column9: shifts in the market suddenly came to be in a matter of seconds. Both patterns can be explained by regressions
column10: but the temporal horizon of the analysis makes them almost incomparable. Such effects can be described as phase shifts
column11: and the standard regression is not able to meaningfully combine such changes into one model.

column1: An equally challenging situation can be diagnosed for spatial scales. Econometrics can be able to generate predictions about market shifts at a global scale
column2: but less can be said how an individual business operating at a much smaller scale will be affected. '''Regression model can be operationalised at one spatial scale
column3: but these models cannot be easily upscaled to a different scale.''' If I measure the growth of biomass at a plant scale
column4: it would be hard to upscale any assumptions based on these measurements and models of individual plants to a global scale. If I did
column5: I would assume that the conditions at the specific spots where I measure are the same across the globe - which is rarely the case. Regressions are thus very robust at the spatial scale at which they are operationalised
column6: but often can say very little beyond that scale.

column2: regressions are typically showing you a certain linear dependence that has an underlying variance. Especially in the public debate and its understanding of statistics
column3: this is often overseen. Very often
column4: people assume that a relation revealed by a regression is a very tamed relation. Instead
column5: most regressions show a high variance
column6: making predictions of future data vague. Many medical breakthroughs discuss matters that are based on models that explain less than half of the variance in the available data. In other words
column7: many data points do not strongly follow this pattern
column8: but instead show a high deviance - which we cannot explain. '''This creates a strong notion that statistics
column9: or even statisticians
column10: are lying'''. While this is certainly an overly bold conclusion
column11: we can indeed pinpoint many examples where scientists discuss patterns as if they were very precise
column12: although they are not.

column1: This is one of the main fallacies of positivistic science. Not only are their fundamental assumptions about the objectivity of knowledge wrong
column2: but positivists often fail to highlight the limitations of their knowledge. In the case of regressions
column3: this would be the variance
column4: and the less-than-perfect sum of squares that can highlight how much the model explains. This failure to highlight the limitations of a model is nowhere more drastic than in the complex statistics that are behind the word 'significance'. '''A significant relation is a non-random relation
column5: indicating a pattern that cannot be associated to chance'''. More often than not
column6: however
column7: this says very little about the strength of the relation. On the contrary
column8: for almost all but a small number cases
column9: regressions that are significant not necessarily respresent strong relations. Instead
column10: many significant relations can be quite weak
column11: with an explained r squared of 0.13 already being significant in large case examples. In other words
column12: the vast majority of the relation is unexplained. This would be perfectly alright if we understood it in this way
column13: and indicate the abilities of the model. With the rise of soft science and its utilisation of statistics
column14: however
column15: this limitation of statistical analysis is often overseen when it comes to the public debate of statistical relations
column16: and their relevance for policy decisions.

column1: Yet there are also direct limitations or reasons for concern within science itself. Regressions were initially derived to test for dependence between two continuous variables. In other words
column2: a regression is at its heart a mostly deductive approach. This has been slowly eroded over the last decades
column3: and these days many people conduct regression analysis that do not test for statistical fishing
column4: and end up being just that. If we test long enough for significant relations
column5: there will eventually be one
column6: somewhere in the data. It is however tricky to draw a line
column7: and many of the problems of the reproducibility crisis and other shortcomings of modern sincere can be associated to the blur if not wrong usage of statistical models.

column1: The last problem of regression analysis is the diversity of disciplinary norms and conventions when it comes to the reduction of complex models. '''Many regressions are multiple regressions
column2: where the dependent variable is explained by many predictors (= independent variables).''' The interplay and single value of several predictors merits a model reduction approach
column3: or alternatively a clear procedure in terms of model constructions. Different disciplines
column4: but also smaller branches of sciences
column5: differ vastly when it comes to these diversities
column6: making the identification of the most parsimonious approach currently a challenge.

column1: Regression models are rather limited in their assumptions
column2: building on the normal distribution
column3: and being unable to implement more complex design features such as random intercepts or random factors. While regressions surely serve as the main basis of frequentist statistics
column4: they are mostly a basis for more advanced models these days
column5: and seem almost outdated compared to the [[An initial path towards statistical analysis|wider available canon of statistics]]. To this end
column6: regressions can be seen as a testimony that the reign of positivism needs to come to an end. '''Regressions can be powerful and robust
column7: but regressions are equally static and simplistic.''' Without a critical perspective and a clear recognition of their limitations

column1: The question of model reduction will preoccupy statistics for the next decades
column2: and this development will be interacting with a further rise of Bayes theorem and other questions related to information processing. Time will tell how regressions will emerge on the other side

column1: ===What to write in a research diary===
The core goal of research diary is to document your own research and how you perceive it. While for instance the late Oliver Sacks started a new book every few weeks at time
column2: other may just document the main steps. What is relevant is that you take a step back and and look at your research like an outsider
column3: but with insider knowledge. It take trying to uncouple oneself from the own research process
column4: yet it is well worth it. In the following are some reasons how a research diary has proven valuable in the past.

column1: Documentation is key in science. While a certain systematic way of documentation has established itself over the last decades
column2: the latest data security laws have put a burden on many scientists when it comes to the proper documentation of science. Although this was done with the best of intentions
column3: a clear documentation considering all legal necessities is hard to achieve yet of course necessary. Here
column4: a research diary can open another level
column5: where beside the ""objective"" documentation of what was done in due course of our research
column6: a personal perspective prevails. Why did we make certain choices in our research
column7: and how did we feel about it. Having the possibility to come back to this can prove valuable
column8: since our memories are deeply constructed and often plain wrong. Coming back to your research diary may thus offer some surprises.

column1: Research is often a very emotional process
column2: which is not surprising. Whenever we spend a lot of time on something
column3: we are more often than not deeply emotionally invested. To this end
column4: it can be quite helpful to see how already are quite relaxed about parts of your research -say failure- about things that some months ago made you an emotional wreck. Looking back at the process has something liberating for many
column5: as it shows that we may after all gain some process
column6: if only at a forward inching scale.For other
column7: a diary may be a good source to learn to focus. What is the main dish of your research
column8: and what are side dishes? Research is a continuous endevour
column9: and documenting this continuously can be indeed very insightful.

column1: Gaining insight out of the own research process is also a potential data source. The question how we conduct
column2: perceive and ultimately facilitate research. While researchers by means of hermeneutics
column3: content analysis etc. have investigated diaries and letters of famous or influential researchers since a long time
column4: this is now also increasingly done while research is conducted. This allows for a clearer localisation within research
column5: and provides an embeddedness in one's own research. Greta care needs to be taken to have a clear understanding of the respective roles
column6: yet the potential outcome can be beneficial. Normal science may not always see the benefit in this
column7: and would highlight the need to focus. This links to the next point.

column2: this is what defines it. We may not know now how research will be in a few decades
column3: but the current societal development showcases the need to slow down and be more reflexive -and critical- of our actions. Many opportunities can be on the horizon for reflexive researchers
column4: and the still widely hierarchical scientific system that defends resources and fights for priority about specific aspects of knowledge. It is hard to imagine that this will always be like this. New modes of research may become more prevalent in the future
column5: and the currently mostly utilitarian way to conduct research may be replaced by more reflexive setting. A small research diary may be one step of each and every single one of us towards this goal.

Sampling for Interviews;"'''In short:''' This entry provides tips on how to sample participants for different forms of Interviewing Methodology. It includes tips and deliberations on defining the target population
column2: choosing the right sample size and applying different forms of sampling strategies. For more on Interviews
column3: please refer to the [[Interviews]] overview page.

column1: A sample is a selection of individuals from a larger population that researchers investigate instead of investigating the whole population
column2: which is not possible for a range of reasons. Sampling is a crucial step in research: ""[o]ther than selecting a research topic and appropriate research design
column3: no other research task is more fundamental to creating credible research than obtaining an adequate sample."" (Marshall et al. 2013
column4: p.11). This is also true for Interview methdology: the creation of a good sample directly affects the validity of the research results (7). How many people you ask your questions
column5: hand out your questionnaire to
column6: or invite to your Focus Groups directly influences the broadth and depth of the created insights. Inviting too few people might not deliver sufficient material to answer your research questions. An overly large sample
column7: then again
column8: might be superfluous
column9: i.e. increase the costs and organisational effort of your project without providing further insights. A sample of the study population that is not representative of the full breadth of possible viewpoints and experiences within the whole population will definitely influence your results
column10: and non-representative samples can happen no matter the sample size
column11: but are less of a problem for bigger samples than for small ones. Thus
column12: approaching the question of sampling can generally be guided by Ockham's Razor - you need a sample that is as big as necessary
column13: but as small as possible. However
column14: this is often easier to say than to apply.

column2: the more open an interviewing approach is
column3: the smaller the sample is going to - and needs to - be. The more structured the methodology
column4: the bigger the required sample. This is because of the depth of the created data in qualitative approaches
column5: which needs time to be qualitatively assessed. Quantitative surveys
column6: by comparison
column7: rely on responses that can be analyzed by means of statistical approaches. These do not only deal better with large samples than
column8: say
column9: qualitative content analysis approaches
column10: but even require larger numbers for valid insights. Still
column11: this general dichotomy does not directly guide an individual interview approach. So first
column12: let us have a look at the seletion of a study population
column13: before examining what the literature suggests for the topic of sample sizes. Last
column14: we will have a look at different forms of sampling (7).

column2: the 'sample universe' - also known as 'study population' or 'target population' - needs to be defined. To do so
column3: the researcher develops inclusion and / or exclusion criteria to guide the selection of all individuals that are theoretically of interest to answer the research question (see Figure). The inclusion and exclusion criteria that are applied will determine the characteristics of the sample universe. This universe can thus become very homogeneous as well as very heterogeneous (see Table). These criteria are mostly guided by theory
column4: in accordance to the research purpose
column5: questions
column6: and methodological design
column7: and potentially with regards to other work that has been done before. Further
column8: organisational elements already play a role here
column9: like geographical access
column10: or the level of access that the researcher has to the population. Within this population
column11: the sample will be drawn
column12: which will help answer the research questions.

column2: p.27.png|500px|thumb|center|'''Defining the Sampling Universe'''. Source: Robinson 2014

column1: The sampling universe can be designed to be rather homogenous
column2: or heterogenous. As you can see in the table below
column3: a homogenous sample may be of interest to enable research on more specific phenomena. As an example
column4: a researcher might be interested in how individuals with a specific position in an organisational context perceive a distinct topic. Therefore
column5: they will conduct expert interviews with such individuals
column6: and accordingly define the sampling universe more homogenously and strict (Meuser & Nagel 1991
column7: p.442f). By comparison
column8: ""[t]he rationale for gaining a heterogeneous sample is that any commonality found across a diverse group of cases is more likely to be a widely generalisable phenomenon than a commonality found in a homogenous group of cases. Therefore
column9: heterogeneity of sample helps provide evidence that findings are not solely the preserve a particular group
column10: time or place
column11: which can help establish whether a theory developed within one particular context applies to other contexts"" (Robinson 2014
