column1: The definition of the sampling universe further differs for qualitative and quantitative approaches. For qualitative interviews
column2: the general idea is to select interviewees in a way that promises ""information-rich"" interviews (1). The inclusion and exclusion criteria should be selected accordingly
column3: and focus on individuals that will likely provide deeper and highly relevant insights into the topic of interest. For quantitative approaches
column4: the inclusion and exclusion criteria may be less strict. While medical surveys may be interested in anyone with a specific disease
column5: more general sociological research might simply include everyone working at a specific company
column6: or every individual of a certain age in a selected city
column7: or every potential voter in a country. So overall
column8: the exclusion and inclusion criteria that define the sampling universe depend mostly on the intended methodological approach
column9: as well as the research questions.

column1: Before drawing the sample from the whole population within the sampling universe
column2: the next step is to clarify the amount of individuals that are planned to be interviewed. This differs between Interview formats.

column1: Qualitative Interviews rely on questions and answers that help the researcher thoroughly understand the interviewee's perspective on the respective topic in order to conclusively investigate the research questions. It is not the researcher's primary interest to be able to count the number of times a specific thing was said
column2: and to make a tally for the according code in the analysis. Indeed
column3: quantitative analysis approaches do exist also for qualitative data (see Content Analysis). Generally however
column4: qualitative interviews will be assessed qualitatively
column5: and focus on investigating and understanding what interviewees have said in order to get a broad and deep overview of all relevant aspects - opinions
column6: experiences - that the interviewees have on the topic of interest. Instead of a large number of cases
column7: the complexity and diligence of the interview conduction are relevant to the quality of the results (Baker & Edwards 2012
column8: p.39). To this end
column9: semi-structured interviews allow for larger sample sizes than open interviews
column10: since their analysis is more structured based on the pre-determined interview guide.

column2: the most important concept for the determination of the right sample size in research is 'saturation'. However
column3: while saturation is an often-used concept
column4: it is ill-defined (1; 2; 3). Commonly
column5: researchers justify their sample size by stating they have reached saturation
column6: but rarely explain what this means. Historically
column7: and methodologically
column8: ('theoretical') saturation emerged from [[https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Grounded_Theory|Grounded Theory]] research and refers to iterative
column9: qualitative research which after some times reaches the point when further increasing the size of the sample will not provide any more insights that could further amend the theory that has been developed so far (Malterud et al. 2016

column11: your sample - your ''N'' has been big enough (2). It is time to wrap up the Interview results; they likely cover all relevant facets. The expected point of saturation guides the planned sample size before starting the study

column1: Saturation as a guiding principle also relates to the quality of the selected interviewees (1). You can find more information on sampling strategies in the paragraph below. For now
column2: however
column3: we will focus on the conflict that emerges from the fundamental idea of saturation: you can only know if you have reached a saturation in your data by analyzing the data as you get it
column4: so that you could stop conducting interviews as soon as the results altogether lack new insights (Baker & Edwards 2012
column5: p. 18). However
column6: analyzing the data in-between interviewing more individuals is a logistical challenge
column7: since analysis takes time and should not be done in passing. Also
column8: researchers typically need to state their sample size before starting the research and not update it mid-gathering (1; 3;7). Interviewing costs money and requires resources
column9: which need to be granted and organized beforehand and can rarely be flexibly adjusted as necessary. Further
column10: this iterative approach can also influence your interviews. When you know how you will code the gathered qualitative interview data
column11: and maybe even have some results already
column12: this might consciously or unconsciously guide the way you conduct further interviews: you'd bias yourself. By comparison

column2: while saturation is often used and generally required
column3: there is no easy guide to determining it. There is no general accepted N that would suffice for every qualitative interview study (3). Marshall et al. (2013) propose three approaches to determining adequate sample sizes: first
column4: using recommendations from other researchers
column5: which
column6: as they show
column7: range from 6-10 interviews for phenomenological studies
column8: to 20-50 for [[Grounded_Theory|Grounded Theory]] studies. However
column9: as the authors highlight
column10: these recommended numbers are rarely explained by those other researchers. Second
column11: adopting the sample size from comparable studies
column12: which
column13: again
column14: may be quite arbitrary. Third
column15: by statistically assessing one's own study in terms of its thematic saturation. However
column16: very few to none of the studies they reviewed actually employed these three strategies
column17: but instead ""(...) made superficial references to data saturation or altogether omitted justification for sample size."" (Marshall et al. 2013
column18: p. 20). Eventually

column1: Hennink et al. (2017) follow the idea of statistically investigating saturation

Their findings thus '(...) underscore the need to collect more data beyond the point of identifying codes and to ask not whether you have ""heard it all"" but whether you ""understand it all"" - only then could saturation be claimed.' (Hennink et al. 2017

column1: What is important to keep in mind is that the number of interviewees is just one part of the equation. You can interview as many individuals as you like

column2: it becomes obvious that there is no simple answer to ""How many people do you need to ask?"" for qualitative Interviews. The aforementioned insights and criteria may guide the process

column1: Focus Groups are not comparable to Interviews in every aspect
column2: but also require a sample that is both informative and thematically exhaustive
column3: without burdening the research team with too much organisational effort. Generally
column4: many of the elements that can guide qualitative interview sampling may therefore also apply to Focus Groups.  More specifically
column5: however
column6: Focus Groups strongly focus on group-internal interactions and dynamics. Tang & Davis (1995
column7: p.474) highlight that the ideal group size for Focus Groups ""(...) maximizes output of information and minimizes group dissatisfaction. It is believed that valid and rich information can be generated as a result of participants' willingess to express without inhibition."" Because of this
column8: the size of the group influences the data that the researcher can gather in the first place. Tang & Davis (1995) generally recommend between four and twelve members in a Focus Group
column9: but express that bigger groups may inhibit maximized information output by every participant
column10: and may lead to competitive or inconsiderate group dynamics. However
column11: smaller groups might be too passive and constrained
column12: and were found to generate fewer ideas than bigger groups. They also highlight that the nature of the study
column13: the complexity of the topic
column14: as well as the diversity
column15: ability
column16: expectations and needs of the group members play critical roles in determining the best group size. Also
column17: organisational factors such as the format and length of the session
column18: and the number or duration of questions play a role. Overall
column19: they claim the biggest influencing factor to be the aim of the study: more explorational studies may need smaller groups
column20: while bigger groups are more suited to structured approaches.

column1: In addition to the size of each focus group
column2: the overall number of focus groups is of relevance. Based on an literature review
column3: Carlsen & Glenton (2011) highlight that the majority of studies held less than 10 focus groups in total. However
column4: the authors indicate a severe lack of reflection on this number. Of their reviewed 220 studies
column5: 183 did not justify the number of focus groups they held. Those who did referred to practical reasons or to recommendations by the available literature. Most (28 of 37) claimed to have reached saturation
column6: half of which did not 'convincingly' describe the process which led to this assessment (Carlsen & Glenton 2011
column7: p.5). Their results suggest that more methodological work on Focus Groups is needed to increase rigor in the determination of the adequate number of Focus Groups
column8: which may well also be the case for the size of each group.

column2: i.e. surveys based on questionnaires or structured interviews
column3: intend to represent the target population adequately
column4: and provide a sufficiently large sample for quantitative analyses. The sample chosen for the survey should make generalizations and statistical inferences about that population possible. Here
column5: broader samples are more relevant than choosing individuals that promise deep insights
column6: since surveys do not focus as much on understanding reasoning and perspectives in depth as much as qualitative interviews.

column1: When determining the sample for surveys
column2: **a bigger sample size is almost always better**. A bigger size will reduce skewness of the sample
column3: and even out statistical errors that would influence the quantitative analysis. However
column4: surveys also cannot cover the complete target population. You cannot sample endlessly
column5: as organisational and financial restrictions limit the possible amount of survey respondents: you cannot hand out surveys to bypassers on the street for years
column6: and you will never reach everyone in your target population via the Internet. Importantly
column7: a sample that is very big may always lead to some kinds of analysis results if you search long enough. This is called statistical fishing
column8: which is a common challenge in quantitative analyses. Therefore
column9: the sample should not be drawn all over the place but should relate to the study objective.

column2: the adequate sample size for a survey depends on the study objective
column3: the sampling universe and the sampling method. Importantly and contrary to popular belief
column4: the mere size of the target population is of little or no relevance unless the target population is relatively small
column5: i.e. only consists of a few thousand people. The composition of the sampling universe (target population) is of bigger importance. In case of simple random sampling
column6: for example
column7: the heterogeneity of the target population plays a role. Here
column8: also the confidence interval you aim for
column9: and how you want to analyze your data (e.g. analysis by subgroups
column10: type of [[Statistics|statistical analysis]]) are highly relevant to determine the adequate sample size.

Taking this multitude of factors into account

column1: After the sample universe is defined
column2: you can approach the third element in accordance with the sample size: the sampling strategy. This refers to the way that the researcher draws the (previously) defined number of individuals from the whole sampling universe. As shown before
column3: the sampling approach strongly influences the sample size
column4: and is itself strongly influenced by the research intent
column5: sampling universe
column6: and research methdology. There are various sampling strategies
column7: the most important of which will be presented below (based on Robinson 2014).

column1: Random sampling is a typical approach in surveys. In this approach
column2: individuals are drawn randomly: for example
column3: they are randomly approached with the survey or questionnaire on the street
column4: by randomly calling telephone numbers from a list
column5: or via e-mail newsletters online. This approach can still be systematic
column6: e.g. by choosing individuals in a specific interval from a list. It can also take the form of cluster sampling
column7: where specific groups within the overall population - e.g. a few schools out of all schools in a district - are randomly chosen to represent to the whole population of students (8). For surveys
column8: this random approach is common: since the sample size can be much bigger here
column9: the step of boiling down the study population to the actual sample is less sensitive to specific criteria. Validity in this approach emerges from numbers
column10: so differences between sampled individuals do not matter as much (8). However
column11: overly small samples
column12: especially for broadly defined study populations
column13: may make non-significant results hard to interpret. Were they not significant because there is no significant effect
column14: or was the sample too small? Random sampling is also imaginable for qualitative research
column15: but since the sample sizes are mostly small here
column16: there is a big risk of omitting important perspectives.

column2: convenience sampling refers to asking people which are easy to access
column3: for example people that you come across in a shopping mall. Be aware of the difference to random sampling: convenience sampling can potentially be as representative of the whole study population as any form of random sampling - or
column4: stochastically speaking
column5: even more so. Yet
column6: most commonly
column7: convenience sampling imposes a selection bias since it favors a specific group of people. In the shopping mall in the afternoon
column8: you'll mostly meet people who are not currently working
column9: who like to go to the Shopping Mall. Another example is the fact that psychology studies have famously often been conducted with psychology students
column10: who are easy to access for researchers
column11: but hardly representative of the whole country
column12: and do not really represent a random sample
column13: for that matter (7). Convenience sampling is also imaginable for qualitative research
column14: but the sampling bias imposed by this strategy weighs even heavier here. For both qualitative and quantitative approaches
column15: generalisations are hard to draw from convenience sampling-based research. If you still plan to go for convenience sampling
column16: the gap between the sampling universe and the actual sample should not be too wide. For example
column17: if the sample universe is defined as ""young university adults with interest in psychology""
column18: then conveniently sampling psychology students will be less of an issue than if your sampling universe was ""every citizen below the age of 30"" (7).

column2: snowball sampling is a form of random or convenience sampling. In snowball sampling
column3: the researcher initially selects few individuals to interview. After the interview
column4: the interviewee is asked to recommend further people that might be relevant to the research. This way
column5: the researcher widens the sample with every step. Unfortunately
column6: this approach may strengthen biases that existed with the initial interviewee selection
column7: and another bias can be imposed by the recommendation rationale of each interviewee. Snowball sampling is possible for quantitative research
column8: but mostly done for qualitative approaches where a specific group of individuals is of interest.

column1: Purposive sampling is directed strongly by theoretical pre-assumptions. The researchers assume that a specific kind of individual will represent an interesting perspective on the research topic
column2: and is therefore included in the sample. This is most common in qualitative research
column3: and includes a range of variations:

column2: several groups are created
column3: which are defined by shared characteristics of the individuals which are then assigned to these groups. For example
column4: you create groups with people from different educational backgrounds
column5: with different diseases
column6: or different age groups. The categories may also overlap
column7: like in a Venn Diagram (""cell sampling""). Then
column8: a fixed number of individuals are randomly drawn from each of these groups. This approach intends to provide a representative composition of different perspectives
column9: preconditions and experiences.

column1: Quota sampling works like stratified sampling
column2: but instead of fixed numbers of individuals per category
column3: there are minimum numbers of individuals
column4: which can be exceeded. This way
column5: the relevant groups are covered
column6: but the researcher is more flexible in gathering individuals.

column2: various approaches are imaginable: the researcher might be interested in extreme or deviant cases
column3: or individuals which promise to be very information-rich
column4: or plainly very typical representations of a specific phenomenon. These are identified and sampled.

column2: there are four major parts to sampling:

column1: 1) defining the sampling universe with exclusion and inclusion criteria in accordance with the intended methodology and the research question
2) defining the sample size in accordance with a demand for saturation (qualitative approaches)
column2: statistical significance (quantitative approaches)
column3: and representativeness regarding the research question

column1: 3) choosing the sampling strategy in accordance with the same criteria
column2: and all the while
so that your research is reproducible
column3: and other researchers understand how you worked.

column1: Sampling is a complex issue of Interview methodology which is not easily solved. As with many elements of scientific methodology
column2: sampling requires experience
column3: and there is room for learning from failed attempts. Further
column4: we encourage the exchange on sampling approaches and critical reflections upon one's own - and others' - sampling strategies. This way
column5: the validity of scientific claims will be improved
column6: and the different demands of qualitative and quantitative research
column7: as well as different forms of Interviews
column8: will be more adequately fulfilled. If you want to read more about the normativity of Sampling
column9: please refer to the entry on [[Bias in Interviews]].

'''In short:''' Scenario Planning is a systematic designation of potential futures to enable long term strategic planning.
[[File:Scenario planning.png|400px|thumb|right|'''SCOPUS hits per year for Scenario Planning until 2019.''' Search terms: 'scenario planning'

column4: 'scenario study' in Title
column5: Abstract
column6: Keywords. Source: own.]]

column1: '''The use of scenarios as a tool for structured thinking about the future dates back to the Manhattan Project in the early 1940s'''. The physicists involved in developing the atomic bomb attempted to estimate the consequences of its explosion and employed computer simulations to do so. Subsequently
column2: this approach advanced in three separate strands: computer simulations
column3: game theory
column4: and military planning through
column5: among others
column6: the RAND corporation that also developed the [[Delphi]] Method. Later
column7: during the 1960s
column8: scenarios were ""(...) extensively used for social forecasting
column9: public policy analysis and [[Glossary|decision making]]"" in the US. (Amer et al. 2013

column2: Scenario Planning was heavily furthered through corporate planning
column3: most notably by the oil company Shell.''' At the time
column4: corporate planning was traditionally ""(...) based on forecasts
column5: which worked reasonably well in the relatively stable 1950s and 1960s. Since the early 1970s
column6: however
column7: forecasting errors have become more frequent and occasionally of dramatic and unprecedented magnitude."" (Wack 1985
column8: p.73). As a response to this and to be prepared for potential market shocks
column9: Shell introduced the ""Unified Planning Machinery"". The idea was to listen to planners' analysis of the global business environment in 1965 and
column10: by doing so
column11: Shell practically invented Scenario Planning. The system enabled Shell to first look ahead for six years
column12: before expanding their planning horizon until 2000. The scenarios prepared Shell's management to deal with the 1973 and 1981 oil crises (1). Shell's success popularized the method. By 1982
column13: more than 50% of Fortune 500 (= the 500 highest-grossing US companies) had switched to Scenario Planning (2).

column2: Scenario Planning remains an important tool for corporate planning in the face of increasing complexity and uncertainty in business environments (5). Adjacent to [[Visioning & Backcasting]]
column3: it has also found its way into research. For instance
column4: researchers in [[Glossary|transdisciplinary]] sustainability science gather stakeholders' expertise to think about (un)desirable states of the future and how (not) to get there. This way
column5: companies
column6: non-governmental organizations
column7: cities and even national states can be advised and supported in their planning.

column1: Scenario Planning is the systematic development of descriptions of (typically multiple) plausible futures
column2: which are then called ""scenarios"". These descriptions of plausible futures may be illustrated with quantitative and precise details. However
column3: the focus lies on presenting them ""(...) in coherent script-like or narrative fashion."" (Schoemaker 1993
column4: p.195). The scenarios developed in a Scenario Planning process are all ""fundamentally different"" (Schoemaker 1993
column5: p.195) and may be contradictory and irreconcilable
column6: but there is no inherent ranking between them (2). The core idea is not to present the most probable version of the future
column7: but to get an idea about the range of possible developments of system variables and their interactions (2
column8: 5). Scenarios ""(...) are not states of nature nor statistical predictions. The focus is not on single-line forecasting nor on fully estimating probability distributions
column9: but rather on bounding and better understanding future uncertainties."" (Schoemaker 1993

column1: '''There is no ''one'' procedure for Scenario Planning''' (5). A commonly cited approach by Schoemaker (2
column2: 3) includes the following steps:
scope
column3: decision variables and major actors of the issue in question.

column1: 2) Identification of current trends and predetermined elements and how they influence the defined decision variables
column2: based on the knowledge of experts and the available data. It should be observed whether major trends are compatible with each other and which uncertainties exist.

column1: 3) Construction of extreme future states along a specific continuum (positive vs negative
column2: probable vs surprising
column3: continuous vs divergent etc.) for all the elements or variables. These extremes are then assessed for their internal consistency and plausibility in terms of stakeholder decisions
column4: trends and outcomes.

column1: 4) Elimination of implausible or impossible futures and
column2: based on the themes that emerged from these
column3: the creation of new scenarios. This process is repeatedly done until internally consistent scenarios are found. The number of scenarios developed depends on the scope and purpose of the planning process (1

column1: [[File:Scenario Planning Process.png|800px|thumb|center|'''Evaluation of the number of scenarios developed.''' Source: Amer et al. 2013. p.33]]
5) The preliminary scenarios are analysed in terms of which decisions would need to be taken by the key stakeholders to reach them
column2: and potentially revised again when further investigation of these scenarios brings up additional or contradictory knowledge about them. The scenarios may also be transferred into quantitative models to learn about the development and inherent uncertainties of individual variables.
these preliminary scenarios are re-iterated by going through the previous steps again
column3: checking for their applicability to the issue at hand
column4: until finally
column5: scenarios emerge that can be used for planning processes.

column1: [[File:Scenario Planning Example.png|800px|thumb|center|'''Exemplary scenarios for life in Australian cities.''' Source: Gaziulusoy & Ryan 2017
* Scenario Planning allows for any organization that deploys it to be more innovative
column2: flexible and thus better prepared for unforeseen disruptions and changes. In a corporate context
column3: this can reduce costs
column4: provide market benefits and improve internal communication (3

column1: * Scenario Planning broadens the structural perspective of an actor to think about the future (5). For example
column2: an oil company may well be able to assess risks in their technical processes of oil exploration and extraction
column3: but only through a more detailed scenario analysis they may be enabled to include economic
column4: political and societal trends into their planning (2).

column1: * Scenarios are psychologically attractive. They are a way of transforming seemingly disparate data into relatable
column2: coherent narratives. They present uncertainty across scenarios instead of providing probabilistic information for all elements within each individual one. In addition
column3: they reduce the complexity and uncertainty of the future into graspable states (2).

column1: * Scenario Planning differs from adjacent methodological approaches. While a ''scenario'' illustrates a possible state of the future
column2: a ''vision'' (see [[Visioning & Backcasting]] revolves around a desirable state of the future without taking its likelihood into consideration. Compared to Visioning
column3: Scenario Planning might therefore be more useful for actual [[Glossary|decision-making]] but might as well be too narrow to envision holistic systemic changes (6). Additionally
column4: a ''prediction'' as the classical method of economic ''forecasting'' describes likely states of the future as an extension of current developments
column5: without the openness for [[Glossary|change]] that is inherent to Scenario Planning.

column1: '''Good scenarios should fulfill a range of characteristics''' (3
* they need to be plausible and internally consistent
column2: i.e. capable of happening.

'''In short:''' This entry discusses how [[Glossary|scientific methods]] have influenced society - and vice versa.
== The role of scientific paradigms for society ==

column2: scientific [[Glossary|paradigm]]s were drivers of societal development. While much else may have happened that is not conveyed by the archaeological record and other accounts of history
column3: many high cultures of the antiques are remembered for their early development of science. Early science was often either having a pronounced practical focus
column4: such as in metallurgy
column5: or was more connected to the metaphysical
column6: such as astronomy. Yet even back then
column7: the ontological (how we make sense of our knowledge about the world) and the epistemological (how we create our knowledge about the world) was mixed up
column8: as astronomy also allowed for navigation
column9: and much of the belief systems was sometimes rooted
column10: and sometimes reinforced by astronomical science. Prominent examples are the star of Bethlehem
column11: the Mesoamerican Long Count calendar
column12: and the Mayan calendar. However
column13: science was for the most part of the last two millennia in a critical relation to the metaphysical
column14: as there was often a quest for ontological truths between religions and science. While the East was more open to allow science to thrive and made active use of its merits; in Europe
column15: many developments were seen as critical
column16: with Galileo Galileo being a prominent example. Since this changed with the [[History of Methods|Enlightenment]]
column17: science paved the way for the rise of the European empires
column18: and with it the associated paradigms.

column1: == Three examples for an active interaction ==
While the [[History of Methods|history of methods]] was already in the focus before
column2: here we want to focus on how the development of scientific methods interacted with societal paradigms. It is often claimed that science is in the Ivory Tower
column3: and is widely unconnected from society. While this cannot be generalised for all branches of science
column4: it is clear that some branches of science are more connected to society than others. Let us have a look at three examples.

column1: A prominent example of a strong interaction is medicine
column2: which has at its heart the care for the patient. However
column3: this naive assumption cannot hold the diverse paradigms that influenced and build medicine over time. Today
column4: ananmesis - the information gained by a physician by asking specific questions of a patient - gained in importance
column5: and the interdisciplinary conferences of modern treatments combine different expertise with the goal of a more holistic recognition of the diseases or challenges of the individual patient.

column1: Engineering is another branch of science which builds on a long tradition
column2: and has at its early stages quite literally paved the road for many developments of modernity. While factories and production processes are today also seen more critically
column3: it has become clear already since Marx that the working condition of modern production are not independent of questions of inequality. In addition
column4: production processes are shifting in order to enable more sustainable production processes
column5: indicating another paradigm shift in engineering.

column2: agricultural science
column3: is also widely built around positivistic methodology of modern science
column4: allowing of an optimisation of agricultural production in order to maximise agricultural yield
column5: often with dire consequences. The so-called [https://www.thoughtco.com/green-revolution-overview-1434948 'Green Revolution'] wreaked havoc on the environment
column6: destroyed local livelihoods across the globe
column7: and untangled traditional social-ecological systems into abusive forms that led ultimately to their demise in many parts of the world.

column1: These three examples showcase how the development of modern science led to abusive
column2: unbalanced
column3: and often unsustainable developments that would in the long run trigger new paradigms such as the post-modernity
column4: degrowths and other often controversially discussed alternatives to existing paradigms. Science was clearly an accomplice in driving many negative developments
column5: and willingly developed the basis for many methodological foundations and paradigms that were seen in a different light after they were utilised over a longer time.

column1: Equally did society drive a demand onto scientific inquiry
column2: demanding solutions from science
column3: and thereby often funding science as a means to an end. Consequently
column4: science often acted morally wrong
column5: or failed to offer the deep [[Glossary|leverage points]] that could drive transformational [[Glossary|change]]. Such a critical view on science emerged partly out of society
column6: and specifically did a view on empirical approaches emerge out of philosophy.

column1: Since the Enlightenment can be seen as an age of solidification of many scientific disciplines
column2: prominent examples of an interaction between scientific developments and societal paradigms can be found here
column3: and later. Since scientific disciplines explicitly look at parts of reality
column4: these parts are often tamed in scientific theories
column5: and these theories are often translated into societal paradigms. Science repeadtedly contributed to what we can interpret as category mistakes
column6: since scientific theories that attempt to explain one part of the world were and still are often translated into other parts of the world. The second mistake is that scientific progress can be seen as continuous (see Laudan: Progress and its Problems)
column7: while societal paradigms are often utilising snapshots of scientific theories and tend to ignore further development in the respective branch of science. This makes science in turn vulnerable
column8: as it has to claim responsibility for mistakes society made in interpreting scientific theories
column9: and translating them into societal paradigms. In the following message I will illustrate these capital mistakes of science based on several examples.

column1: The evolutionary theory of Charles Darwin can be seen as a first example that illustrates how a scientific theory had catastrophic consequences when it was adapted as a societal paradigm. Ideas that the poor in late Victorian England were unworthy of state intervention
column2: and that social welfare was hence a mistake were build on a misunderstanding of Darwins theory
column3: and Darwin opposed the application of his theory for societal debates. Furthermore
column4: he was horrified that his ideas was also taken as a basis to claim superiority of some races over other races
column5: a crude and scientifically wrong claim that paved the road for some of the worst atrocities of the 20th century.

column1: Another example is Milton Friedman's theory of shareholders
column2: which claims that corporations have first and foremost responsibility against their shareholders. While this seems like a reasonable thought
column3: the consequences for the global economy were considered to be catastrophic by many. Friedman's theory demanded privatisation at a country-wide scale
column4: also for many countries outside of the USA this was attempted and destroyed entire economies. Finally
column5: the stakeholder theory offered a sound development that could counter Friedman's doctrine
column6: and allowed for a recognition of resources
column7: market as well as other important factors such as corporate social responsibility. While the word 'stakeholder' is deeply ambiguous
column8: stakeholder theory and the relation to Friedman's doctrine showcases direct and drastic interactions between science and society.

column1: A last example to showcase how a new research paradigm can even become deeply entangled with social paradigms is the concept of 'Mode 2' research. This new paradigm proposed the systematic recognition of the context that is investigated by multidisciplinary teams in a mode of knowledge production aimed at the real world. By focusing on problems of civil society
column2: this new mode of research departs from basic research
column3: and attempts to develop an active interaction between science and society. While academia hence opened up
column4: gatekeepers criticised this new paradigm
column5: or claimed that it had existed long before it was officially proclaimed. What is clear is that this line of thinking grew in importance
column6: and that it showcases that interactions between academia and civil society gained a wider recognition
column7: and were increasingly institutionalised
column8: although most of academia is to this day organised in disciplines. Deep understanding in one branch of science is undeniably helpful
column9: but there is an ongoing debate whether academia should be problem- or even solution-orientated
column10: and whether many of the wicked problems society faces have to be addressed not only in collaboration between different disciplines
column11: but also together with society. From a methodological standpoint
column12: this posed new challenges
column13: since this type of new knowledge production demanded not only a new array of methodological approaches
column14: but also questioned the still widely dominating paradigm of positivism.

column1: == The grand abduction of science and society ==

column2: science and society have been in a continuous spiralling movement around each other. While scientific methods are shaped by their time
column3: the times are also shaped by scientific methodology. What is however necessary is the close and mutual interaction between empirical inquiry and the question how we ought to act based on our growing knowledge. Science is only starting to unlock the complicated relation between epistemology and ontology
column4: and the confusion between the two created many problems in scientific tradition to date. In order to develop a robust and critical theory of science
column5: learning from the past development of science offers a great chance. However
column6: between the recognition of positivism
column7: [[Bias and Critical Thinking|critical theory]] and Kuhn's recognition of scientific revolution
column8: there is also a more continuous understanding of the history of science
column9: which Larry Laudan coined 'a History of Ideas'. Laudan spoke of a 'History of Ideas' instead of a history of disciplines or scientists and criticized the focus on elites in the history of science. He highlighted that many people had similar ideas and that ideas can break through realities. Larry Laudan was deeply sceptical of disciplines whose alleged boundaries he did not see as strict. He preferred ideas as a unit of thought to understand concepts and the development process of solutions. A central element of his 'History of Ideas' was the question what is real and what was real in the past
column10: which is strongly connected to [[Bias and Critical Thinking|Critical Realism]].

column1: When looking at past developments in science
column2: there is a clash between rational views on past developments
column3: and the role of social
column4: cultural and societal factors that influenced the past developments of science. Laudan differentiated between the modes of organisation and institutional structures that science and scientists of the past had
column5: and differentiates these from their beliefs. Laudan made a distinction between 'cognitive and non-cognitive aspects'
column6: and thus claims that science is not always made in a rational conduct. Instead - Laudan argues - scientists often made bold but irrational decisions
column7: choose less convincing theories
column8: alienated traditions
column9: or even opted for non-progressive theories in their research. All this should be well understood as scientific dispute
column10: yet sociology of science has as of yet to come up with one or probably several explanations on why scientists have chosen to deviate from rational paths in the past. The myths that scientific progress
column11: and with it the formulation of knowledge that may be summarised as scientific revolutions
column12: is produced by rational agents should be seen critical at best.

column1: Concerning the tensions between new paradigms and the existing methodology
column2: an adaptation of existing methods or a development of new methods altogether may be needed. While for instance in the 1720
column3: following Locke and Bacon
column4: the approach to Newtonian theory was widely inductive
column5: the following decades saw a proclamation of heat
column6: electricity and phenomena of chemistry that could hardly be claimed to be inductively derived
column7: as they are not observable as such. In consequence
column8: a methodology was derived which enabled the hypothesis-forming deduction that should prevail and even dominate for quite some time to come. Lakatos offered a modification to Kuhn's ""revolutions""
column9: as he proclaimed that several alternative ""research programs"" can exists in parallel
column10: and these are interacting
column11: maybe even several theories that are built around a heuristic core. However
column12: Lakatos - equally like Kuhn - still considers empirical evidence or methodology as pivotal
column13: allowing only the measurable reality to be the measure of success of a new paradigm. Again
column14: Laudan introduced a new argument to add to the measure of the success of a theory: instead of relying on how many significant problems a new theory can solve
column15: he raises concern about the truth of theories
column16: and instead suggests to compare how one theory is more effective or progressive than another theory. Kuhn and Lakatos both claimed that a paradigm
column17: and with it the associated branch of science
column18: reaches maturity if it gains enough standing to ignore anomalies
column19: and becomes independent of outside criticism. Both Kuhn and Lakatos consider this to be positive
column20: as it makes this part of science more progressive.

column2: and considered their view on history of science widely flawed and constructed. In addition
column3: history of science looks at parts of reality
column4: beyond the illusion that it is rational agents acting as scientists. This notion of parts of reality can be linked to Roy Bhaskars view that all science can only unlock parts of reality that are not necessarily connected or can be meaningfully connected
column5: since some parts of reality cannot be observed. This is an important connection towards Laudan
column6: who claims that we have not yet understood rational scientific choice
column7: yet this understanding is a precondition to investigate the social background that the respective science is embedded in. What I call the ''grand abduction'' here is hence the seamless interaction between science and society
column8: where we have to recognise that these two realms are not two different entities
column9: but instead are often embedded
column10: integrated
column11: and at times cannot be differentiated at all. While much of positivism often claimed a deductive position
column12: societal development surely operates at longer time scales. Society has questions that science may answer
column13: and demands that science needs to fulfill. Science has willingly fulfilled many demands of society
column14: and has also contributed to many developments in society
column15: many of which are rightly criticised
column16: while other developments also lead to positive merits. However
column17: following Laudan we should not only question that scientists are objective
column18: but following Bhaskar we also have to question their claim of trying to explain objective reality. Neither is science rational
column19: nor can scientists be framed as rational actors
column20: nor can society claim a complete disconnect from the proposed ivory towers of science.

column1: == A way out of the current dilemma of societies doubt towards science
column2: and the arrogance of science towards society ==

column1: Why is this relevant today? Following Bhaskar we could argue that many parts of reality will never be unlocked by us
column2: despite being part of reality. These phenomena will never be part of our reality
column3: and shall not concern us further. This is the first obstacle societal paradigms and society as such face today
column4: since the overarching acceptance of the limitations of science does not exist. Instead
column5: the pendulum swings between criticism of science - often as a means to an end as for instance climate change deniers attempt - or a naive surprise whenever scientific results change
column6: calling the recognition of so-called 'facts' into question. The recognition of critical realism that permanent realities may not exist is especially quite alien from the current societal debate in the Western world
column7: where the distance between a acceptance or rejection of scientific paradigm grew larger of the last years. Regarding the changeability of paradigms
column8: we have to follow Bhaskar in recognising that it can be wise to act based on certain scientific results
column9: yet we also need to be critical. Blindly following everything that scientists claim does not work
column10: because as Laudan highlighted
column11: we cannot assume that scientific actors are always rational. Post truths and fake news are thus facets of knowledge that can be equally driven by irrational scientists or by an ignorant thrive for knowledge by societal actors. Surely
column12: many more complex phenomena are part of the reality of post truths
column13: fake news and associated challenges we currently face. Yet by blaming either scientists or society we will fail to overcome these challenges. Instead of claiming what science ought to be
column14: we should shift to the responsibility of the individual scientist
column15: and building on a critical 'history of ideas' will allow for a better understanding of how scientific [[Glossary|innovation]] happened in the past.

column2: science and society were never as disconnected as it was framed in the past. Instead
column3: such constructed realities were built with misleading purposes
column4: and during the last decades
column5: philosophy of science has increasingly tried to solve these problems. Considering the current state and validity of knowledge debates in science and society
column6: we can clearly claim that the responsibility of the individual researcher is a good starting point in order to further overcome these challenges. Current scientific methodologies still widely resolve around dogmas and rigid traditions that participated and built the challenges we currently face. Recognising these flaws is a first step in order to overcome these problems. Seriously engaging with this will be one of the leading challenges of our generation.

'''In short:''' Simple statistical tests encapsule an array of simple statistical tests that are all built on probability
column2: and no other validation criteria.

column1: Simple statistical tests statistics provide the baseline for advanced statistical thinking. While they are not so much used today within empirical analysis
column2: simple tests are the foundation of modern statistics. The student t-test which originated around 100 years ago provided the crucial link from the more inductive thinking of Sir Francis Bacon towards the testing of hypotheses and the actual statistical testing of [[Glossary|hypotheses]]. The formulation of the so-called null hypothesis is the first step within simple tests. Informed from theory this test calculates the probability whether the sample confirms the hypothesis or not. Null hypotheses are hence the [[Glossary|assumptions]] we have about the world
column3: and these assumptions can be confirmed or rejected.

column1: The following information on simple statistical tests assumes some knowledge about data formats and data distribution. If you want to learn more about these
column2: please refer to the entries on [[Data formats]] and [[Data distribution]].

column1: '''The easiest example is the [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VPd8DOL13Iw one sample t-test]''': it allows us to test a dataset (more specifically
column2: its mean value) versus a specified value. For this purpose
column3: the t-test gives you a p-value at the end. If the p-value is below 0.05
column4: the sample differs significantly from the reference value. Important: The data of the sample(s) has to be normally distributed.

column1: '''Example''': Do the packages of your favourite cookie brand always contain as many cookies as stated on the outside of the box? Collect some of the packages
column2: weigh the cookies contained therein and calculate the mean weight. Now
column3: you can compare this value to the weight that is stated on the box using a one sample t-test.

column1: For more details and R examples on t-tests
column2: please refer to the [[T-Test]] entry.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-04-26 um 17.57.43.png|thumb|With a two sample test we can compare the mean gross of both our groups - with or without fertilizer - and state whether they are significantly different.]]

'''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NkGvw18zlGQ Two sample tests] are the next step'''. These allow a [https://explorable.com/independent-two-sample-t-test comparison of two different datasets] within an experiment. They tell you if the means of the two datasets differ significantly. If the p-value is below 0
column3: the two datasets differ significantly. It is clear that the usefulness of this test widely depends on the number of samples - the more samples we have for each dataset
column4: the more we can understand about the difference between the datasets.

column1: Important: The data of the sample(s) has to be normally distributed. Also
column2: the kind of t-test you should apply depends on the variance in the parent populations of the samples. For a '''Student’s t-test'''
column3: equal variances in the two groups are required. A '''Welch t-test'''
column4: by contrast
column5: can deal with samples that display differing variances (1). To know whether the datasets have equal or varying variances

column1: Social Network Analysis;"[[File:ConceptSocialNetworkAnalysis.png|450px|frameless|left|[[Sustainability Methods:About|Method categorization]] for [[Social Network Analysis]]]]
'''In short:''' Social Network Analysis visualises social interactions as a network and analyzes the quality and quantity of connections and structures within this network.
[[File:Scopus Results Social Network Analysis.png|400px|thumb|right|'''SCOPUS hits per year for Social Network Analysis until 2019.''' Search terms: 'Social Network Analysis' in Title
column2: Abstract
column3: Keywords. Source: own.]]

column1: '''One of the originators of Network Analysis was German philosopher and sociologist Georg Simmel'''. His work around the year 1900 highlighted the importance of social relations when understanding social systems
column2: rather than focusing on individual units. He argued ""against understanding society as a mass of individuals who each react independently to circumstances based on their individual tastes
column3: proclivities
column4: and beliefs and who create new circumstances only by the simple aggregation of their actions. (...) [W]e should focus instead on the emergent consequences of the interaction of individual actions."" (Marin & Wellman 2010

column1: [[File:Social Network Analysis History Moreno.png|350px|thumb|left|'''Moreno's original work on Social Networks.''' Source: Borgatti et al. 2009
Romanian-American psychosociologist '''Jacob Moreno heavily influenced the field of Social Network Analysis in the 1930s''' with his - and his collaborator Helen Jennings' - 'sociometry'
column2: which served ""(...) as a way of conceptualizing the structures of small groups produced through friendship patterns and informal interaction."" (Scott 1988
column3: p.110). Their work was sparked by a case of runaways in the Hudson School for Girls in New York. Their assumption was that the girls ran away because of the position they occupated in their social networks (see Diagram).

column1: Moreno's and Jennings' work was subsequently taken up and furthered as the field of ''''group dynamics'
column2: which was highly relevant in the US in the 1950s and 1960s.''' Simultaneously
column3: sociologists and anthropologists further developed the approach in Britain. ""The key element in both the American and the British research was a concern for the structural properties of networks of social relations
column4: and the introduction of concepts to describe these properties."" (Scott 1988
column5: p.111). In the 1970s
column6: Social Network Analysis gained even more traction through the increasing application in fields such as geography
column7: economics and linguistics. Sociologists engaging with Social Network Analysis remained to come from different fields and topical backgrounds after that. Two major research areas today are community studies and interorganisational relations (Scott 1988; Borgatti et al. 2009). However
column8: since Social Network Analysis allows to assess many kinds of complex interaction between entities
column9: it has also come to use in fields such as ecology to identify and analyze trophic networks
column10: in computer science
column11: as well as in epidemiology (Stattner & Vidot 2011

column1: Social network analysis is neither a theory nor a methodology. Rather
column2: it is a perspective or a paradigm."" (Marin & Wellman 2010
column3: p.17) It subsumes a broad variety of methodological approaches; the fundamental ideas will be presented hereinafter.

column1: Social Network Analysis is based on the idea that ""(...) social life is created primarily and most importantly by relations and the patterns formed by these relations. '''Social networks are formally defined as a set of nodes (or network members) that are tied by one or more types of relations.""''' (Marin & Wellman 2010
column2: p.1; Scott 1988). These network members are also commonly referred to as ""entitites""
column3: ""actors""
column4: ""vertices"" or ""agents"" and are most commonly persons or organizations
column5: but can in theory be anything (Marin & Wellman 2010). The nodes are ""(...) tied to one another through socially meaningful relations"" (Prell et al. 2009
column7: which can be ""(...) collaborations
column8: friendships
column9: trade ties
column10: web links
column11: citations
column12: resource flows
column13: information flows (...) or any other possible connection"" (Marin & Wellman 2010
column14: p.2). It is important to acknowledge that each node can have different relations to all other nodes
column15: spheres and levels of the network. Borgatti et al. (2009) refer to four types of relations in general: similarities
column16: social relations
column17: interactions
column18: and flows.

column1: [[File:Social Network Analysis Type of Ties.png|800px|thumb|center|'''Types of Ties in a Social Network.''' Source: Borgatti et al. 2009
The Social Network Analyst then analyzes these relations ""(...) for structural patterns that emerge among these actors. Thus
column2: an analyst of social networks looks beyond attributes of individuals to also examine the relations among actors
column3: how actors are positioned within a network
column4: and how relations are structured into overall network patterns."" (Prell et al. 2009
column5: p.503). '''Social Network Analysis is thus not the study of relations between individual pairs of nodes
column6: which are referred to as ""dyads""
column7: but rather the study of patterns within a network.''' The broader context of each connection is of relevance
column8: and interactions are not seen independently but as influenced by the adjacent network surrounding the interaction. This is an important underlying assumption of Social Network Theory: the behavior of similar actors is based not primarily on independently shared characteristics between different actors within a network
column9: but rather merely correlates with these attributes. Instead
column10: it is assumed that the actors' behavior emerges from the interaction between them: ""Their similar outcomes are caused by the constraints
column11: opportunities
column12: and perceptions created by these similar network positions."" (Marin & Wellman 2010
column13: p.3). Surrounding actors may provide leverage or influence that affect the agent's actions (Borgatti et al. 2009)

column2: Social Network Analysts decide whether they intend to focus on a holistic view on the network (''whole networks'')
column3: or focus on the network surrounding a specific node of interest (''ego networks''). They also decide for either ''one-mode networks''
column4: focusing on one type of node that could be connected with any other; or ''two-mode networks'' where there are two types of nodes
column5: with each node unable to be connected with another node of the same type (Marin & Wellman 2010
column6: 13). For a two-mode network
column7: you could imagine an analysis of social events and the individuals that visit these
column8: where each event is not connected to another event
column9: but only to other individuals; and vice-versa.

column2: the approach to defining nodes needs to be chosen. Three ways of defining networks can be named according to Marin & Wellman (2010
column4: referring to Laumann et al. (1983)). These three are approaches not mutually exclusive and may be combined:

column1: ** ''position-based approach'': considers those actors who are members of an organization or hold particular formally-defined positions to be network members
column2: and all others would be excluded

column1: ** ''event-based'' approach: those who had participated in key events are believed to define the population

** ''relation-based approach'': begins with a small set of nodes deemed to be within the population of interest and then expands to include others sharing particular types of relations with those seed nodes as well as with any nodes previously added.

column2: which are pre-determined based on the research intent or theory which provide clearly specified entities of interest.
the researcher needs to decide on which kinds of ties to focus. There can be two forms of ties between network nodes: ''directed'' ties
column3: which go from one node to another
column4: and ''undirected ties''
column5: that connect two nodes without any distinct direction. Both types can either be [[Data formats|binary]] (they exist
column6: or do not exist)
column7: or valued (they can be stronger or weaker than other ties): As an example
column8: ""(..) a friendship network can be represented using binary ties that indicate if two people are friends
column9: or using valued ties that assign higher or lower scores based on how close people feel to one another
column10: or how often they interact."" (Marin & Wellman 2010
column11: p.14; Borgatti et al. 2009)

column1: * '''Data Collection''': When the research focus is chosen
column2: the data necessary for Social Network Analysis can be gathered in [[Survey Research|Surveys]] or [[Interviews]]
column3: through [[Ethnography|Observation]]
column4: [[Content Analysis]] (typically literature-based) or similar forms of data gathering. Surveys and Interviews are most common
column5: with the researchers asking individuals about the existence and strength of connections between themselves and others actors
column6: or within other actors excluding themselves (Marin & Wellman 2010
column7: p.14). There are two common approaches when surveying individuals about their own connections to others: In a ''prompted recall'' approach
column8: they are asked which people they would think of with regards to a specific topic (e.g. ""To whom would you go for advice at work?"") while they are shown a pre-determined list of potentially relevant individuals. In the ''free list'' approach
column9: they are asked to recall individuals without seeing a list (Butts 2008

column1: * '''Data Analysis''': When it comes to analyzing the gathered data
column2: there are different network properties that researchers are interested in in accordance with their research questions. The analysis may be qualitative as well as quantitative
column3: focusing either on the structure and quality of connections or on their quantity and values. (Marin & Wellman 2010
column4: p.16; Butts 2008
column5: p.21f). The analysis can focus on

column1: ** the quantity and quality of ties that connect to individual nodes

column2: or

column1: ** the structure of the network as a whole in terms of density
column2: average connection length and strength or network composition.

column1: * An important element of the analysis is not just the creation of quantitative or qualitative insights
column2: but also the '''visual representation''' of the network. For this
column3: the researcher ""(...) will naturally seek the clearest visual arrangement
column4: and all that matters is the pattern of connections."" (Scott 1988
column5: p.113) Based on the structure of the ties
column6: the network can take different forms
column7: such as the Wheel
column8: Y
column9: Chain or Circle shape.

column2: the actual distance between nodes is thus not equatable with the physical distance in a [[Glossary|visualisation]]. Sometimes
column3: nodes that are visually very close to each other are actually very far away. The actual distance between elements of the network should be measured based on the ""number of lines which it is necessary to traverse in order to get from one point to another."" (Scott 1988

column1: [[File:Social Network Analysis - Network Types.png|400px|thumb|right|'''Different network structures.''' Source: Borgatti et al. 2009
[[File:Social Network Analysis - Example.png|300px|thumb|center|'''An exemplary network structure.''' The dyads BE and BF - i.e. the connections between B and E
column2: and B and F
column3: respectively - are equally long in this network although BF appears to be shorter. This is due to the visual representation of the network
column4: where B and F are closer to each other. Additionally
column5: the central role of A becomes clear. Source: Scott 1988

column1: * There is a range of challenges in the gathering of network data through [[Semi-structured Interview|Interviews]] and [[Survey|Surveys]]
column2: which can become long and cumbersome
column3: and in which the interviewees may differently understand and recall their relations with other actors
column4: or misinterpret the connections between other actors. (Marin & Wellman 2010

column1: * The definition of network boundaries is crucial
column2: since ""(...) the inappropriate inclusion or exclusion of a small number of entities can have ramifications which extend well beyond those entities themselves"". Apart from the excluded entities and their relations
column3: all relations between these entities and the rest of the network
column4: and thus the network's structural properties
column5: are affected. (Butts 2008). For more insights on the topic of System Boundaries
column6: please refer to [[System Boundaries|the respective article]].

column1: * The structure of any network and thus the conclusions that can be drawn in the analysis very much depend on the relation that is observed. A corporation may be differently structured in terms of their informal compared to their official communication structures
column2: and an individual may not be part of one network but central in another one that focuses on a different relational quality (Butts 2008)
the choice of network boundaries as well as the underlying research intent can have normative implications. Also
column3: actors within the network may be characterized using specific attributes
column4: which may be a normative decision (such as for attributes of ethnicity
column5: violence
column6: or others).

column1: * The way in which a Social Network is visualized plays an important role. Researchers may choose from a variety of visualization forms in terms of symmetry

column3: see References) investigated the network ties between 32 NGOs driving sustainability initiatives in Southern Transylvania.''' Based on the [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5226895/ [[Glossary|leverage points]] concept]
column4: they attempted to identify how these NGOs contribute to systemic change. For this
column5: they focused on the positions of the NGOs in different networks
column6: with each network representing relations that target different system characteristics (parameters
column7: feedbacks
column8: design
column9: intent). As a basis for this
column10: the authors identified types of ties between the NGOs that contribute to each of these four system characteristics.

column1: [[File:Social Network Analysis - Lam et al. 2021 - Social Networks and Leverage Points.png|900px|frameless|center|Leverage Points and Social Network Analysis. From Lam et al. 2021]]

column2: they investigated the amplification processes the NGOs applied to their initiatives to foster transformative change
column3: grouped into four kinds of amplification processes: ''within''
column4: ''out (dependent)''
column5: ''out (independent)'' and ''beyond''.

column1: [[File:Social Network Analysis - Lam et al. 2021 - Social Networks and Amplification.png|750px|frameless|center|Survey questions on amplification processes by NGOs in Social Network Analysis on Leverage Points. Source: Lam et al. 2021]]

column2: '''the authors conducted an online survey''' in which 30 NGOs participated. In this survey
column3: the NGOs were asked about their relations to other NGOs in terms of the kinds of questions shown above relating to the four leverage points. The NGOs were asked to rate the strength of the respective relations to another NGOs over the past five years with either ""not at all"" (0)
column4: low extent (1)
column5: moderate extent (2)
column6: high extent (3)
column7: and ""I don't know"". Further
column8: the survey asked the NGOs four questions about the four kinds of amplification as shown above.

column2: the authors created four networks using [https://gephi.org/ Gephi] and [https://nodexl.com/ NodeXL] software
column3: one for each system characteristic. '''For each NGO (= node)
column4: they calculated three measures''' (Lam et al. 2021

column2: which measures the relations of the node to other nodes in the network
column3: taking into consideration the weight of the relations. This measure provides insights on each node's individual interconnectedness.

column2: which highlights how often a node links other nodes that would otherwise be unconnected. The higher the betweenness of a node is
column3: the more power it exerts on the network. (By the way
column4: the node with the highest betweenness is often called a 'broker').

column2: which measures the influence of a node in the network
column3: weighted by the influence of its neighboring nodes. This highlights the future influence of a node.

column1: They additionally tested for the influence of each NGO's amplification actions on these network measures by comparing those NGOs that applied a specific amplification action to those that did not
column2: using a Mann-Whitney U test (also known as [[Simple_Statistical_Tests#Wilcoxon_Test|Wilcoxon rank-sum test]]).
they ""(...) found that while some NGOs had high centrality metrics across all four networks (...)

column5: or eigenvector in one particular network."" (p.817)

Stacked Area Plot;"'''Note:''' This entry revolves specifically around Stacked Area plots. For more general information on quantitative data visualisation
column2: please refer to [[Introduction to statistical figures]].

column1: This entry aims to introduce Stacked Area Plot and its visualization using R’s <syntaxhighlight lang=""R"" inline>ggplot2</syntaxhighlight> package. A Stacked Area Plot is similar to an Area Plot with the difference that it uses multiple data series. And an Area Plot is similar to a Line Plot with the difference that the area under the line is colored.

A Stacked Area Plot displays quantitative values for multiple data series. The plot comprises of lines with the area below the lines colored (or filled) to represent the quantitative value for each data series.
The Stacked Area Plot displays the evolution of a numeric variable for several groups of a dataset. Each group is displayed on top of each other
column2: making it easy to read the evolution of the total.

column1: A Stacked Area Plot is used to track the total value of the data series and also to understand the breakdown of that total into the different data series. Comparing the heights of each data series allows us to get a general idea of how each subgroup compares to the other in their contributions to the total.
A data series is a set of data represented as a line in a Stacked Area Plot.
Limit the number of data series. The more data series presented
column2: the more the color combinations are used.

column1: Consider the order of the lines. While the total shape of the plot will be the same regardless of the order of the data series lines
column2: reading the plot can be supported through a good choice of line order.

column1: Stacked Area Plots must be applied carefully since they have some limitations. They are appropriate to study the evolution of the whole data series and the relative proportions of each data series
column2: but not to study the evolution of each individual data series.
let us plot an example of a Stacked Area Plot in R.

column1: R uses the function <syntaxhighlight lang=""R"" inline>geom_area()</syntaxhighlight> to create Stacked Area Plots.
The function <syntaxhighlight lang=""R"" inline>geom_area()</syntaxhighlight> has the following syntax:

column2: aes(x=x_variable
column3: y=y_variable
column4: fill=group_variable)) + geom_area()</syntaxhighlight>

column1: * Data: This parameter contains whole dataset (with the different data series) which are used in Stacked Area Plot.
* x: This parameter contains numerical value of variable for x axis in Stacked Area Plot.
* y: This parameter contains numerical value of variables for y axis in Stacked Area Plot.
* fill: This parameter contains group column of Data which is mainly used for analyses in Stacked Area Plot.

Stacked Barplots;"'''In short:''' Stacked bar plots show the quantitative relationship that exists between a main category and its subcategories. This entry helps visualise two different types of stacked bar plots
column2: ''Simple Stacked Plots'' and ''Proportions Stacked Plots''
column3: and explains the difference between them. For more on the basics of barplots
column4: please refer to the [[Barplots
column5: Histograms and Boxplots]] entry.

column1: Stacked bar plots show the quantitative relationship that exists between a main category and its subcategories. Each bar represents a principal category and it is divided into segments representing subcategories of a second categorical variable. The chart shows not only the quantitative relationship between the different subcategories with each other but also with the main category as a whole. They are also used to show how the composition of the subcategories changes over time.
Stacked bar plots should be used for Comparisons and Proportions but with emphasis on Composition. This composition analysis can be static for a certain moment in time
column2: or dynamic for a determined period of time.

column1: Stacked bar Plots are two-dimensional with two axes: one axis shows categories
column2: the other axis shows numerical values. The axis where the categories are indicated does not have a scale (*) to highlight that it refers to discrete (mutually exclusive) groups. The axis with numerical values must have a scale with its corresponding measurements units.

column1: ===When you should use a stacked bar plot===
The main objective of a standard bar chart is to compare numeric values between levels of a categorical variable. One bar is plotted for each level of the categorical variable
column2: each bar’s length indicating numeric value. A stacked bar chart also achieves this objective
column3: but also targets a second goal.

column1: We want to move to a stacked bar chart when we care about the relative decomposition of each primary bar based on the levels of a second categorical variable. Each bar is now comprised of a number of sub-bars
column2: each one corresponding with a level of a secondary categorical variable. The total length of each stacked bar is the same as before
column3: but now we can see how the secondary groups contributed to that total.

column1: 1. '''Simple Stacked Plots''' place the '''absolute value''' of each subcategory after or over the previous one. The numerical axis has a scale of numerical values. The graph shows the absolute value of each subcategory and the sum of these values indicates the total for the category. Usually
column2: the principal bars have different final heights or lengths.

column1: We use simple stacked plots when relative and absolute differences matter. Ideal for comparing the total amounts across each group/segmented bar.

column1: 2. '''Proportions Stacked Plots''' place the '''percentage''' of each subcategory after or over the previous one. The numerical axis has a scale of percentage figures. The graph shows the percentage of each segment referred to the total of the category. All the principal bars have the same height.
In proportions stacked plots the emphasis is on the percentage composition of each subcategory since the totals by category are not shown; in other words
column2: they are used when the key message is the percentage of composition and not the total within the categories. We use proportions stacked plots only when relative differences matter.
