Sustainability Research is a research field that aims at tackling societal problems by developing systemic understandings of these problems and oftentimes collaboratively solving them through [[Glossary|transdisciplinary]] research designs. In this context
column2: the [[Glossary|concept]] of stakeholders is a crucial component. Stakeholders are people that are directly affected by sustainability problems and can contribute to their solution. '''Mapping-out these stakeholders is a common entry-point''' to gaining an understanding of the system and problem at hand
column3: and is further important to gather an overview of the relevant stakeholders in this context.

column1: * Gain an overview of relevant stakeholders and their positionality towards a real-world problem
* Get a methodological starting point for subsequent transdisciplinary research
* Enable the development of strategies for jointly developing solutions
Stakeholder Mapping is a part of stakeholder analysis
column2: which are often used as interchangeable terms. While stakeholder analysis is also relevant in business contexts
column3: for our purpose
column4: we will refer to its usage in transdisciplinary research.

column1: 'Transdisciplinary research' refers to a research mode that is common in sustainability science
column2: focusing on the collaboration of academic and non-academic actors with a solution-oriented perspective towards real-world problems. Please refer to the entry on transdisciplinarity for more details.
groups of individuals or institutions that have an interest in
column3: or are affected by
column4: decision-making related to a specific issue or problem. The stakeholders' interest in the respective decision-making may stem from being affected by the problem itself and thus the consequences of potential solutions to it
column5: or from the intention of influencing the decision for any other reason. '''The relevant stakeholders in transdisciplinary projects are typically non-academic actors
column6: such as NGOs
column7: citizens
column8: politicians
column9: economic actors.''' However
column10: academic actors may also be identified as stakeholders. Stakeholders can be distinguished more broadly
column11: e.g. when everyone in a region is a potential stakeholder
column12: or more narrowly
column13: depending on the issue (Lelea et al. 2014). An example is the installation of wind turbines in a village. Researchers may be interested in investigating success criteria for social acceptance of renewable energies and therefore accompany this process. In this example
column14: relevant stakeholders would likely be the local administration
column15: citizens
column16: farmers
column17: the energy company and environmentalists.

column1: The initial collection of relevant stakeholders can be based on a mere brainstorming by the research team. These individuals may be further investigated
column2: e.g. through questionnaires or interviews
column3: or based on available external information. In this '''snowball-sampling''' approach
column4: more and more actors are identified that are related to the initial actors. However
column5: '[g]oing beyond the ‘usual suspects’ to find stakeholders that you had not already thought about
column6: or stakeholders who are further removed from your research can seem like an impossible task.' (Research to Action 2015). A systematic approach to an initial identification of actors based on a questionnaire is provided by Leventon et al. (2016
column7: see References).

column1: 'Mapping' refers to the '''visual representation and structured arrangement of the identified actors''' in preparation to a transdisciplinary research project. Such a 'map' can take various forms. One approach is to categorize all relevant stakeholders according to their position towards the researched problem
column2: or towards solutions to this problem. For example
column3: in the Conviva project in Brazil
column4: stakeholders were mapped in a 2x2 matrix according to their support or resistance towards nature conservation efforts.

column1: [[File:Stakeholder Mapping Template CONVIVA.jpg|600px|thumb|right|'''A template for stakeholder mapping.''' Source: [https://conviva-research.com/stakeholder-mapping-as-a-transdisciplinary-exercise-lessons-learned-from-the-conviva-brazilian-team/ Conviva]]]
Further types of matrices are possible. It can be helpful to compile a mere list of stakeholders
column2: with information on their influence
column3: needs and interests
column4: potential contributions and possible strategies for engagement (tools4dev 2021). Another form of visually representing stakeholder positionality is a [[Venn Diagram]]
column5: which shows overlapping interests between stakeholders. [https://netmap.wordpress.com/about/ Net-Map] is a form of positioning
column6: defining and linking stakeholders in a network structure. Ultimately
column7: the visual form depends on the research project at hand. Maybe the connection between actors is of utmost interest
column8: maybe their influence and power
column9: maybe their interests and needs.

column1: Through the process of stakeholder mapping
column2: the research team is enabled to identify all relevant actors for the given issue. This helps '''plan next steps'''
column3: i.e. the conduction of interviews to gather further insights
column4: or provides an overview on which individuals to invite to workshop formats or further methods of [[Transdisciplinarity|transdisciplinary research]]. This way
column5: all important actors are involved in the process
column6: which is important for the success of the envisioned solutions. A Leventon et al. (2016) highlight: ""Researchers in natural resource management consistently find that stakeholders should be included in solution-finding in order to facilitate negotiation and mutual learning; reduce conflict; and increase support and actor buy-in for decisions made."" Apart from these advantages
column7: stakeholder mapping also '''ensures that all relevant knowledge and perspectives are included''' and no key aspects of the topic at hand are neglected. Especially the perspectives of marginalised groups are important to this end (Leventon et al. 2016).

column2: the mapping already includes an initial analysis of the stakeholders position. Therefore
column3: it '''helps assess their existent roles
column4: interests and needs'''. Based on this
column5: the research design and the process of jointly developing solutions can be adapted to the specific context (Learning for Sustainability 2021). Not all stakeholders will share the same aims and target the same outcomes from the getgo. Through mapping
column6: strategies may be identified to bring actors together towards a common goal (Research to Action 2012) and ""create an environment for good decision-making"" [https://conviva-research.com/stakeholder-mapping-as-a-transdisciplinary-exercise-lessons-learned-from-the-conviva-brazilian-team/ (Conviva 2021)]. Stakeholder Mapping / Analysis should be done at the start of the research project
column7: but can also be done continuously to track developments of the relevant stakeholders and their positions.

column1: === How to find the right statistics method ===

column2: you know which kind of data you want to analyze

column1: Do not worry. The following interactive page asks you simple questions about your [[Glossary|data]] and guides you to the best statistical analysis method for your research.

column1: '''Much in modern science is framed around statistics
column2: for better or worse.''' Due to the arrogance of ""the scientific method"" being labeled based on deductive approaches
column3: and the fact that much of the early methodological approaches were biased to and dominated by quantitative approaches. This changed partly with the rise or better increase of qualitative methods during the last decades. We should realise to this end
column4: that the development of the methodological canon is not independent but interconnected with the societal paradigm. Hence the abundance
column5: development and diversity of the methodological canon is in a continuous [[Glossary|feedback loop]] with changes in society
column6: but also driven from changes in society. Take the rise of experimental designs
column7: and the growth it triggered through fostering developments in agriculture and medicine
column8: for better or worse. Another example are the severe developments triggered by [https://www.thoughtco.com/critical-theory-3026623 critical theory]
column9: which had clearly ramifications towards the methodological canon
column10: and the societal developments during this time. Despite all these ivory towers is science not independent from the Zeitgeist and the changes within society
column11: and science is often both rooted and informed from the past and influence the presence
column12: while also building futures. This is the great privilege society gained from science
column13: that we can now create
column14: embed and interact with a new knowledge production that is ever evolving.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-06-14 um 17.59.31.png|1000px|center|thumb|'''This picture shows a brief history of statistics and its most important methods.''' For a more detailed look look at their [http://www.statslife.org.uk/images/pdf/timeline-of-statistics.pdf website]]]
'''Mixed methods are one step in this evolution.''' [https://www.theguardian.com/science/2012/aug/19/thomas-kuhn-structure-scientific-revolutions Kuhn] spoke of scientific revolutions
column2: which sounds appealing to many. As much as I like the underlying principle
column3: I think that mixed methods are more of a scientific evolution that is slowly creeping in. The scientific canon that formed during the enlightenment and that was forged by the industrialisation and a cornerstone of modernity. The problems that arose out of this in modern science were slowly inching in between the two world wars
column4: while methodology and especially statistics not only bloomed in full blossom
column5: but [https://blog.udemy.com/importance-of-statistics/ contributed their part to the catastrophe]. Science opened up to new forms of knowledge
column6: and while statistics would often contribute to such emerging arenas as psychology and clinical trials
column7: other methodological approaches teamed up with statistics. [https://www.simplypsychology.org/interviews.html#structured Interviews] and surveys utilised statistics to unleash new sampling combined with statistics. Hence statistics teamed up with new developments
column8: yet other approaches that were completely independent of statistics were also underway. Hence
column9: new knowledge was unlocked
column10: and science thrived into uncharted territory.

column1: From a systematic standpoint we can now determine at least three developments: 1) Methods that were genuinely new
column2: 2) methods that were used in a novel context
column3: and 3) methods that were combined with other methods. Let us embed statistics into this line of thinking. Much of the general line of thinking in statistics in the last phase of modernity
column4: i.e. before the two world wars. While in terms of more advanced statistics of course much was developed later and is still being developed
column5: but some of the large breakthroughs in terms of the general line of thinking were rather early. In other words
column6: in terms of what is most abundantly being applied up until the computer age
column7: much was already developed early in the 20th century. Methods in statistics were still developed after that
column8: but were often so complicated that they only increased in application once computers became widely available.

column1: What was however quite relevant for statistics was the [[Glossary|emergence]] into diverse disciplines. Many scientific fields implemented statistics into their development to a point that it was dominating much of the discourse (ecology
column2: psychology
column3: economics)
column4: and often this also led to specific applications of statistics and even genuinely new approaches down the road.

column1: Where statistics also firmly extended their map on the landscape of methods was in the combination with other methods. Structured Interviews and surveys are a standard example where many approaches served for the gathering of data and the actual analysis is conducted by statistics. Hence new revolutionary methods often directly implemented statistics into their utilisation
column2: making the footing of statistics even more firm.

column1: For more on the development of new methods
column2: please refer to the entries on [[History of Methods]] as well as [[Questioning the status quo in methods]].

column1: [[File:Multiple-perspectives.gif|thumb|right|This wonderful picture from [https://proswrite.com/2013/02/26/what-is-plain-language-part-four-putting-it-all-together-in-a-process/ prowrite.com] shows how different methods can help to illuminate different aspects of a phenomenon. Triangulation is about bringing the different perspectives together
column2: use them in harmony.]]

column1: [https://ebn.bmj.com/content/22/3/67 Triangulation] is often interpreted in a purely quantitative sense
column2: which is not true. I would use it here in a sense of combination of different methods to triangulate knowledge from diverse sources. '''Ideally
column3: triangulation allows to create more knowledge than with single method approaches.''' More importantly
column4: [http://www.qualres.org/HomeTria-3692.html triangulation] should allow to use methods in harmony
column5: meaning the sum of the methods that are triangulated is more than the sum of its parts. To this end
column6: triangulation can be applied in many contexts
column7: and may bring more precision to situations where mixed methods are not enough to describe the methodological design to enable for a clear communication of the research design or approach.

column1: Not least because of the dominating position that statistics held in modern science
column2: and also because of the lack of other forms of knowledge becoming more and more apparent
column3: qualitative methods were increasingly developed and utilised after the second world war. I keep this dating so vague
column4: not because of my firm belief that much was a rather continuous evolvement
column5: but mostly because of the end of modernity. With the enlightenment divinely ending
column6: we entered a new age where science became more open
column7: and methods became more interchangeable within different branches of science.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-06-14 um 18.03.39.png|thumb|This picture emphasizes the main differences between quantitative and qualitative research. But do we really need to either decide for the one or the another?]]

The opening of a world of quantitative knowledge started a discourse between [https://www.simplypsychology.org/qualitative-quantitative.html quantitative and qualitative research] that has effectively never ended. Pride
column2: self esteem and ignorance are words that come to my mind if I try to characterise what I observe still today in the exchange between these two lines of thought. Only when we establish [[Glossary|trust]] and appreciation
column3: we can ultimately bring these two complementary types of knowledge together. From the standpoint of someone educated in statistics I can only say that it is my hope that words such as [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Misunderstood_concepts_in_statistics ""significant""
column4: ""correlated""
column5: ""clustered""] are not used unthoughtfully
column6: but as the analysis approaches and associated concepts that these words stand for. What is even more difficult to me is when these concepts are rejected altogether as outdated
column7: dogmatic
column8: or plain wrong. Only if we can join forces between these two schools of thought
column9: we may solve the challenges we face.

column2: it is not sound that many people educated in statistics plainly reject qualitative knowledge
column3: and are dogmatic in their slumber. '''I consider the gap between these two worlds as one of the biggest obstacles for development in science.''' People educated in statistics should be patient in both explaining their approaches and results
column4: and being receptive and open minded about other forms of knowledge. There is still a lot of work in order to bridge this gap. If we cannot bridge it
column5: we need to walk around the gap. Connect through concrete action
column6: and create joined knowledge
column7: which may evolve into a joined learning. Explain statistics to others
column8: but in a modest
column9: and open approach.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-06-14 um 18.07.47.png|thumb|The Leuphana and also many other research institutes conduct a board of ethics before a study starts.]]

A fairly similar situation can be diagnosed for the difference between [https://conjointly.com/kb/deduction-and-induction/ inductive and deductive approaches]. Many people building on theory are on a high horse
column2: and equally claim many inductive researchers to be the only ones to approach science in the most correct manner. '''I think both sides are right and wrong at the same time.''' What can be clearly said for everybody versatile in statistics is
column3: that both sides are lying. The age of big data crashed with many disciplines that were once theory driven. While limping behind the modern era
column4: these disciplines are often pretending to build hypotheses
column5: merely because their community and scientific journals demand a line of thinking that is build on hypotheses testing. Since these disciplines have long had access to large datasets that are analysed in an inductive fashion
column6: people pretend to write [[Glossary|hypothesis]]
column7: when they formulated them in fact after the whole analysis was finalised. While this may sound horrific to many
column8: scientists were not more than frogs in the boiling pot
column9: slowly getting warmer. This system slowly changed or adapted
column10: until no one really realised that we were on the wrong track. There are antidotes
column11: such as [https://www.cos.io/our-services/prereg preregistration] of studies in medicine and psychology
column12: yet we are far way from solving this problem.

column2: many would argue that researchers claim to be inductive in their approach
column3: when they are in fact not only biased all over the place
column4: but also widely informed by previous study and theory. Many would claim
column5: that this is more a weak point of qualitative methods
column6: but I would disagree. With the wealth of data that became available over the last decades though the internet
column7: we also have in statistics much to our disposal
column8: and many claim to be completely open minded about their analysis
column9: when in fact the suffer also from many types of biases
column10: and are equally stuck in a dogmatic slumber when they claim to be free and unbiased.

column2: statistics may rise to a level where a clearer documentation and transparency enables a higher level of science
column3: that is also aware of the fact that knowledge changes. This is a normal process in science
column4: and does not automatically make previous results wrong. Instead
column5: these results
column6: even if they are changing
column7: are part of the picture.

column1: This is why it is so important to write an outline about your research
column2: preregister studies if possible
column3: and have an ethical check being conducted if necessary. We compiled the [https://www.leuphana.de/forschung/transparenz-in-der-forschung/gute-wissenschaftliche-praxis.html application form for the board of ethics from Leuphana University] at the end of this Wiki.

Statistics can be utilised basically across all spatial and temporal scales. Global economic dynamics are correlated
column2: experiments are conducted on plant individuals
column3: and surveys are conducted within systems. This showcases why statistics got established across all spatial scales
column4: but instantly also highlights once more that statistics can only offer a part of the picture. More complex statistical analysis such as [https://www.statisticssolutions.com/structural-equation-modeling/ structural equation models] and [https://www.jessesadler.com/post/network-analysis-with-r/ network analysis] are currently emerging
column5: allowing for a more holistic system perspective as part of a statistical analysis. The rise of big data allows us to make connections between different data sources
column6: and hence bridge different forms of knowledge
column7: but also different spatial scales. While much of these statistical tools were established decades ago
column8: we only slowly start to compile datasets that allow for such analysis.

column2: with the increasing availability of more and more data
column3: an increasing diversity of temporal dimensions are emerging
column4: and statistics such as panel statistics and [https://ourcodingclub.github.io/tutorials/mixed-models/#what mixed effect models] allow for an evolving understanding of change like never before. Past data is equally being explored in order to predict the future. We need to be aware that statistics offers only a predictive picture here
column5: and is unable to implement future changes that are not implemented into the analysis. We predict the future to the best of our knowledge
column6: but we will only know the future
column7: once it becomes our presence
column8: which is trivial in general
column9: but makes predictions notoriously difficult.

column2: statistics needs to be aware of its own limitations
column3: and needs to be critical of the knowledge it produces in order to contribute valid knowledge. '''Statistical results have a certain confidence
column4: results can be significant
column5: even parsimonious
column6: yet may only offer a part of the picture.''' [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Non-equilibrium_dynamics#The_world_can_.28not.29_be_predicted  Unexplained variance] may be an important piece of the puzzle in a mixed method approach
column7: as it helps us to understand how much we do not understand. Statistics may be taken more serious if it clearly highlights the limitations it has or reveals. We need to be careful to not only reveal the patterns we may understand through statistics
column8: but also how these patterns are limited in terms of a holistic understanding. However
column9: there is also reason for optimism when it comes to statistics. Some decades ago
column10: statistics were exclusive to a small fraction of scientists that could afford a very expensive computer
column11: or calculations were made by hand. Today
column12: more and more people have access to computers
column13: and as a consequence to powerful software that allows for statistical analysis. The rise of computers led to an incredible amount of statistical knowledge being produced
column14: and the internet enabled the spread of this knowledge across the globe. We may be living in a world of exponential growths
column15: and while many dangers are connected to this recognition
column16: the rise in knowledge cannot be a bad
column17: at least not all of it. More statistical knowledge bears hope for less ignorance
column18: but this demands as well the responsibility of [[Glossary|communicating]] results clearly and precisely
column19: also highlighting gaps in and limitations of our knowledge.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-06-14 um 18.16.39.png|thumb|Scenario planning is a popular method in interdiscplinary and transdisciplinary research. It combines systemic knowledge about the current state and normative target knowledge of the desired future state.]]
We only start to understand how we can combine statistical methods with other forms of knowledge that are used in parralel. Sequential combination of other methods with statistics has been long known
column2: as the example of interviews and their statistical analysis has already shown. '''However
column3: the parallel integration of knowledge gained through statistics and other methods is still in its infancy.''' [https://www.forbes.com/sites/stratfor/2015/01/08/scenario-planning-and-strategic-forecasting/#766d057e411a Scenario planing] is a prominent example that can integrate diverse forms of knowledge; other approaches are slowly investigated. However
column4: the integrational capability needed by a team to combine such different forms of knowledge is still rare
column5: and research or better scientific publications are only slowly starting to combine diverse methods in parralel. Hence many papers that claim a mixed method approach often actually mean either a sequential approach or different methods that are unconnected. While this is perfectly valid and a step forward
column6: science will have to go a long way to combine parralel methods and their knowledge more deeply. [[Glossary|Funding]] schemes in science are still widely disciplinary
column7: and this dogma often dictates a canon of methods that may have proven its value
column8: some may argue. However these approaches did not substantially create the normative knowledge that is needed to contribute towards a sustainable future.

column1: One of the nicest metaphors of interlinking methods is the japanese word Bokeh. Bokeh means basically depth of field
column2: which is the effect when you have a really beautiful camera lens
column3: and keep the aperture - the opening of the lens - very wide. Photographs made in this setting typically have a laser sharp foreground
column4: and a beautifully blurry background. You have one distance level very crisp
column5: and the other like a washed watercolour matrix. A pro photographer or tec geek will appreciate such a photo with a ""Whoa
column6: nice Bokeh"". Mixed method designs can be set up in a similar way. While you have one method focussing on something in the foreground
column7: other methods can give you a blurry understanding of the background. Negotiating and designing this role in a mixed method setting is central in order to clarify which method demands which depth and focus
column8: to follow with the allegory of photography. Way too often we demand each method having the same importance in a mixed method design. More often than not I am not sure if this is actually possible
column9: or even desirable. Instead
column10: I would suggest to stick to the Bokeh design
column11: and harmonise what is in the foreground
column12: and what is in the background. Statistics may give you some general information about a case study setting and its background
column13: but deep open interviews may allow for the focus and depth needed to really understand the dynamics in a case study.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-06-14 um 19.34.30.png|thumb|Disciplines in science differentate themselves in many many subcategories. Thinking in disciplines can be seen as double-edged sword. They create specific knowledge but on the other hand not looking behind your own horizon is problematic.]]
Statistics are deeply embedded in the DNA of many scientific disciplines
column2: and strangely enough is the rejection of statistics as a valid method by many disciplines that associate themselves with critical thinking.

column1: '''I think statistics should be utilised when they provide a promising outcome.''' Due to the formation and [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YvtCLceNf30&list=PL8dPuuaLjXtNppY8ZHMPDH5TKK2UpU8Ng&t=0s development of scientific disciplines]
column2: this is however hardly the case. Instead
column3: we have many disciplines that evolved around and based on statistics
column4: such as psychology
column5: ecology
column6: (empirical) social science or parts of economics. All these scientific disciplines sooner or later encountered struggles with statistics. Examples are models when better statistics becoming more and more complicated
column7: hence violating parsimony which led to the crisis questioning the value of probability driven statistics. Many disciplines evolved from deductive schools of thought
column8: but with more and more data becoming available
column9: this closed into a mishmash of inductive and deductive thinking
column10: which I have mentioned before. Yet another problem is embedded into [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Causality causality]
column11: as many studies from economics can not rely on causal links
column12: yet inform policy and politics as if they are investigating nothing but causal links.

column1: Many scientific disciplines question the value of statistics
column2: which is important. However
column3: while statistics only offer a piece of the puzzle
column4: rejecting statistics altogether is equally harsh. Instead
column5: we ought to add precision in communicating the limitations of statistical results and evolve the utilisation of approaches to build trust between disciplines into our agenda and learning. A more fundamental question is most deeply embedded in philosophy
column6: if I were to name a discipline. Philosophy still deals with the most fundamental questions such as ""Is there an objective way to act?"" or ""Are there normative facts?"". These questions illustrate why statistics will ultimately need to team up more deeply with philosophy to solve these questions. [https://lux.leuphana.de/vufind/Record/1696677149 ""Making comparisons count""] is an example for a work from philosophy that clearly informs statistics
column7: and more importantly
column8: the results that are reported from statistical analysis.

column1: '''Methods are at the heart of the disciplinary dogma.''' I postulate that the method that started them all - philosophy - will be able to solve this problem
column2: but it is not clear when this will happen. Sustainability science is an example of a solution oriented and diverse arena that tries to approach solutions to this end
column3: yet this is why many scientists that define themselves through their discipline reject it. [[Glossary|Dialogue]] will be necessary
column4: and we need to understand that deep focus is possible even for diverse approaches. Learning a method truly takes about as much time as learning a musical instrument
column5: hence thousands of hours of hours at least. Yet while some researchers will be pivotal in integrating diverse approaches to research
column6: the majority will probably commit to a deeper focus. However
column7: appreciation and respect for other forms of knowledge should become part of the academic curriculum
column8: or should be on the agenda even earlier.

column1: To cut a very long story short
column2: scientific disciplines arose out of a need for a specific labour force
column3: the need for specific types of knowledge
column4: and the surplus in resources that came out of the colonies
column5: among many other reasons. I hope that we may overcome our differences and the problems that arise out of disciplinary identities
column6: and focus on knowledge and solutions instead. Time will tell how we explore this possibility.

column2: Why & When ==

it is important to follow the current discussions in science. Staying on top of research is an essential skill that will enhance your science game significantly. Because that's the gist: There is more to science than searching for terms in Google Scholar. Henrik did an [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yDuS-ugfa_0 entire video] on how he does research and stays up to date - saying I wasn't inspired by his take on the topic would be a lie.
fellow scientist. In the game of science
column3: ultimately
column4: you want to:

column1: * identify '''key papers''' that are relevant for your research and read the papers that cite these key papers
* identify '''key authors''' in your field and follow whatever they publish next
* identify '''key [[Glossary|journals]]''' in your field that have a high rating (so are being cited frequently) and therefore publish the most important news in your field

You have just started out with your study program and want to understand research as such. You may have recently found out that journals exist and that journal ratings are a thing. This stage is all about you gaining knowledge about research and also discovering what interests you most. On this level
column2: you could follow:

column1: * The journals [https://www.nature.com ""Nature""] and [https://www.sciencemag.org ""Science""] are very basic newspapers of science. They tend to have rather sensational titles
column2: feature mostly short papers but also report the main news. Follow them to get the latest of the scientific world.

column1: * If you are new to reading research and papers
column2: there's a bunch of help out there to get you started. What's important is that papers are the main way of communicating and this ''primary literature'' is the ultimate go-to for science. Secondary sources can only scarcely account for the complexity of a paper. Your professors and instructors pinpoint you to resources in their lectures
column3: and your text books reference papers as well. Knowing and having scanned these basic resources is already helpful as such and at this stage
column4: you don't to follow all authors you read about.  You approach papers always in the same way: scan the abstract
column5: understand the basic method the authors are using and dig into the parts that are relevant for you.

column1: You've understood the game of science and have written your first few papers for your degree program. This means you levelled up! column1: SQL is the standard database language for relational databases. It is used for retrieving and manipulating data. When analyzing data
column2: SQL is great to retrieve and organize data. It is used by many different institutions

column1: A relational database is a collection of data elements having specified relationships following the relational model. This model for data organization was developed by E. F. Codd in 1970 and pursues the goal of making data from large databases accessible without knowledge about its structure and location in the database.
The relational model allows data to be organized into tables. Each table contains one type of record which is described by a set of attributes. In the tables
column2: each attribute is represented by a column whereas each record is represented by a row. Relationships between the records of different tables are established using primary and foreign keys. Primary keys are unique identifiers for each row of a table. Foreign keys contain the primary key of another table and thus link the rows of the tables (Codd 1970).

column1: Figure 1 shows an exemplary relational database that could be applied in a hospital. Its first table contains the patients of the hospital (rows) which are described by patient_id
column2: name
column3: address
column4: and insurance_number (columns). In the second table
column5: the treatments (rows) are stored
column6: described by treatment_id
column7: drug
column8: intakes_per_day
column9: and patient_id as attributes (columns). The first column of both tables contains a unique identifier for each record which is the primary key. The patient ID in the treatments table is a foreign key since it contains a primary key from the patients' table and thus allows to link each treatment to a patient.

column1: The following sections provide an overview of the main SQL elements used for querying relational databases. Code examples based on the exemplary database shown above are used to illustrate the use of the language elements in typical query structures.
Remark: SQL is standardized by an ISO norm (ISO/IEC 2016). Nonetheless
column2: the use of the language slightly varies between database systems.

column1: The SELECT statement is used to retrieve data from a relational database. You can either specify a list of columns that should be selected from a table or select all columns using a “*”. Furthermore
column2: the source table has to be defined using the FROM clause. Instead of the SELECT statement the SELECT DISTINCT statement can be used in order to show only unique rows in the output table.

column1: The query would return a table containing the name
column2: address
column3: and insurance number of all patients.

column1: Aliases can be assigned to tables and columns using the AS keyword. Renaming columns can help to make output tables more readable (code example 5); aliases for tables are used to make queries shorter and clearer (code example 4).
Data can be filtered by using the WHERE clause. It is followed by a boolean function that outputs “True” for all records which should be included and “False” for those which should be excluded.
Such Boolean functions usually contain comparisons of attributes with fixed values or other attributes. Comparisons are expressed using comparison operators (table 1).
Missing values can be identified by the IS NULL operator returning “True” for all records having a null value in the data field of interest. IS NOT NULL is the negation of this operator.
Expressions can be linked with the logical operators AND and OR. AND returns ""True"" if both linked expressions are true; OR returns ""True"" if one of those is.
===Code example 2: WHERE clause and filter condition===
The query would return a table with all treatments where ibuprofen is taken more than one time per day and the patient_id is not missing.
The rows of the output table can be sorted using the ORDER BY keyword. The keyword is followed by the columns by which the output should be sorted. Thereby
column2: the order of the columns determines the priority with which they are considered. The keywords ASC and DESC after a column determine whether the values are put in ascending or descending order.

column1: The query would return all treatments and order them by descending intakes_per_day.

Joins are used to connect rows from different tables based on matching attributes. Different types of joins are differentiated by the rows contained in the output table. Common join clauses are the (INNER) JOIN
column2: LEFT (OUTER) JOIN
column3: RIGHT (OUTER) JOIN
column4: and FULL (OUTER) JOIN. Inner joins only return rows that match a row from the other table. Full joins return all rows of both tables. Left joins return all rows from the left table and the matching rows from the right table. Right joins work vice versa. Thereby
column5: the table mentioned before the join clause is considered to be the left table. Join clauses are used in conjunction with the ON keyword which is followed by the join condition defining one or more attributes that will be checked for matching.

column1: Remark: In case of similar column names in two or more source tables
column2: column names must be supplemented by table names. Aliases can help to make those references shorter (code example 4).

column1: The query would return all treatments
column2: described by drug and intakes_per_day as well as the patient's name and insurance_number if there is an entry with a matching patient_id in the patients' table.

column1: Aggregation functions aggregate the values of a specified column over several rows. Common aggregation functions are listed in table 2.
| SUM() || returns the sum of the values
| AVG() || returns the average of the values
The GROUP BY clause is used to define attributes that form the groups whose values will be aggregated (see table 2). If such attributes are not defined
column2: the whole table gets aggregated into one row.

The query would count the different drugs administered and sum up the intakes per day over all drugs per patient_id.

column1: Studying is about learning. Learning will be the main focus of your whole day
column2: and sometimes even beyond the day. Learning to learn is a key goal that schools still miss out on big time
column3: even if the situation has already greatly improved. I only learned to learn properly at university in a structured and self-motivated way. Balancing your learning efforts against your motivational levels is something that you develop and learn
column4: and different people learn differently
column5: which is a trivial detail but important to consider given the pressure that many people perceive. Being in academia means tinkering with the skills you need as an academic
column6: often your whole life
column7: even if you do not remain in academia.

column1: Academia is first and foremost about reading. Reading a lot is inevitable
column2: and in addition you need to learn to cross-read large chunks of text and fast. Quite often it is not about getting every bit of the text
column3: but instead the bigger picture. This is not some ability that you are being born with
column4: but it will take years to evolve. Still
column5: reading you must
column6: and a lot

'''In short:''' Surveys are highly systematized and structured forms of data gathering through written or oral questioning of humans. This entry includes Structured Interviews and Questionnaires as forms of Survey Research. For more Interview forms
column2: and more on Interview methodology in general
column3: please refer to the [[Interviews|Interview overview page]].

column1: Surveys were first applied in research in the field of sociology in the 1930s and 1940s (1
column2: 2). Back then
column3: the sociologist Paul Lazarsfeld used surveys to study the effects that the radio had on the public's political opinions in the US (1). Today
column4: surveys are considered a '''widespread quantitative method in the social sciences''' (1).

column2: i.e. survey research
column3: is a set of research methods which uses “standardized questionnaires or interviews to collect data about people and their preferences
column4: thoughts
column5: and behaviors in a systematic manner” (Bhattacherjee 2012
column6: p. 73; 2). Surveys are commonly applied in “descriptive
column7: exploratory
column8: or explanatory research” (Bhattacherjee 2012
column9: p. 73). They are used to “investigate social phenomena and understand society” (Brenner 2020
column10: p. 2) as well as “to inform knowledge
column11: challenge existing assumptions
column12: and shape policies” (Gideon 2012

column1: Survey research can be divided into an 'exploratory' and an 'explanatory' type (8). Explanatory survey research
column2: which is typically seen as more important
column3: “is devoted to finding causal relationships among variables. It does so from theory-based expectations on how and why variables should be related. […] Results then are interpreted and in turn contribute to theory development.” (Malhotra & Grover 1998
column4: p. 409). By comparison
column5: exploratory survey research is an inductive approach and is not based on theories or models. It rather aims at understanding a topic or measuring a concept better. This type can thus be especially helpful in early research stages and can prepare the ground for explanatory survey research and hence for studying the variables in-depth. (8). Even though more and more researchers follow an inductive approach by e.g. applying exploratory survey research to contribute to theory development
column6: the deductive explanatory approach still predominates survey research (88).

column1: Survey types can further be distinguished according to their mode
column2: their target population
column3: the data they collect
column4: and the number or duration of data collection activities
column5: among other variables (3). The survey mode
column6: i.e. how the information is collected
column7: exists in two types: '''questionnaire surveys and structured interview surveys'''. Questionnaires
column8: also called self-completion surveys
column9: are filled out independently by the participants either online or on a piece of paper e.g.
column10: after having received them by mail or handed out on the street. By comparison
column11: an interview survey has an interviewer present the questions of the questionnaire to the participant
column12: either in person (face-to-face)
column13: via the telephone or in the context of a focus group (1; 3). Interview surveys might be the mode of choice “when the survey is long [...] or when additional information has to be collected” (Gideon 2012

column1: Surveys can also be distinguished based on the times or duration of data collection (3). Surveys which involve a single data collection activity are called 'cross-sections'. Surveys that are repeated regularly by addressing a different sample of the target population every time are called 'repeated cross-section' or 'longitudinal' surveys. Here
column2: the latter term emphasizes the survey’s comparative nature over time. A survey that targets the same sample with each regular repetition is called a 'longitudinal panel' and allows for examining “change at an individual level” (Gideon 2012
'''a population of interest – the target population – needs to be identified
column3: of which only a proportion – the sample – is asked to participate''' (3). A survey is used “to obtain a composite profile of the population” (Gideon
column6: but neither intends “to describe the particular individuals who
column7: by chance
column8: are part of the sample” (Gideon 2012
column10: nor covers the entire target population as is done in a census (3). The latter is often not possible due to a lack of feasibility and funding (1).

column1: The sample chosen for the survey should represent the target population so that generalizations and “statistical inferences about that population” (Bhattacherjee 2012
column2: p. 65) can be made based on the results of the survey (1). To ensure the representativeness of a sample
column3: different strategies can be applied
column4: including simple random sampling
column5: stratified sampling
column6: and cluster sampling
column7: among others (3).

column2: '''a bigger sample size is almost always better'''. A bigger size will reduce skewness of the sample
column3: and it takes a sufficiently large sample to reach a normal distribution within the sample. Of course
column4: you cannot sample endlessly
column5: as organisational and financial restrictions limit the possible amount of survey respondents: you cannot hand out surveys to bypassers on the street for years
column6: and you will never reach everyone in your target population via the Internet. Also
column7: the adequate sample size for a survey depends on many different factors
column8: such as the study objective and the sampling method. In case of simple random sampling
column9: for example
column10: the heterogeneity of the target population plays a role
column11: as does the confidence interval you aim for
column12: and how you want to analyze your data (e.g. analysis by subgroups
column13: type of statistical analysis). Contrary to popular belief
column14: the size of the target population is of little or no relevance unless the target population is relatively small
column15: i.e. only consists of a few thousand people (3). Taking this multitude of factors into account
column16: sample size calculators on the Internet
column17: such as [https://www.surveymonkey.com/mp/sample-size-calculator/ this one]
column18: can help to get an idea of which sample size might be suitable for your study. Keep in mind that when determining the sample size
column19: the estimated response rate needs to be accounted for as well
column20: so you most likely need to invite more people for the survey than the calculated sample size indicates (see below; 3).

column1: Survey research is commonly used as a quantitative method (8) for studies “that primarily aim at describing numerical distributions of variables (e.g. prevalence rates) in the population” (Jansen 2010
column2: The Qualitative Survey section
column3: para. 4). This can be done for survey responses that are qualitative in nature (nominal
column4: ordinal) as well as for quantitative responses (see Data formats below). However
column5: survey responses can also be analyzed qualitatively
column6: making it a qualitative method which “does not aim at establishing frequencies
column7: means or other parameters but at determining the diversity of some topic of interest within a given population. This type of survey does not count the number of people with the same characteristic (value of variable) but it establishes the meaningful variation (relevant dimensions and values) within that population.” (Jansen 2010
column8: The Qualitative Survey section
column9: paragraph 5). The differentiation of both approaches is most relevant when it comes to the subsequent analysis. Check out the wiki entry on quantitative and qualitative [content analysis](https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Content_Analysis) to learn more about the analysis of survey data.

column2: an important aspect of survey research is the '''highly standardized procedure''' when collecting information
column3: which means “that every individual is asked the same questions in more or less the same way” (Gideon 2012
column4: p. 8). The design of a survey is moreover highly dependent on its purpose e.g.
column5: how fast the data need to be collected
column6: how precise the results should be or if responses must be comparable between different target populations.

column2: different types of questions can be included (3). Note that the questions asked in the survey (questionnaire items) are not the same as the ones you aim to answer with your research (internal questions). The internal questions usually have to be broken down into several questions to encompass the entirety of the research question or reformulated to be comprehensible for the survey participants and to produce answers suitable for analysis (65).

one distinguishes between 'objective' and 'subjective' questions as well as unstructured (also called 'open-ended') and structured (also called 'closed') questions.''' Objective questions refer to topics such as one’s employment
column3: living situation
column4: education level
column5: or health condition. Subjective questions correspond to personal opinions and values (3).

column1: Open-ended questions require the respondents to formulate their answer freely and “in their own words” (Krosnick 1999
column2: p. 543). This is especially “suitable for exploratory
column3: interviewer-led surveys” (Kasunic 2005
column5: as its response format is less restrictive
column6: but comes with its own challenges (see “Strengths & Challenges”).

column2: subjective question.''' Source: Kasunic

column1: The more common closed questions provide participants with a set of prescribed answer options. These questions can have ordered
column2: [[Data_formats#Ordinal_data|ordinal]] answer options in form of a “graduated scale along some single dimension of opinion or behavior” (Kasunic 2005
column3: p. 42). Typically
column4: this is done by using a 5-point [[Likert Scale]]. However
column5: these answer options can also have 3-point answer options (e.g. Yes
column6: Maybe
column7: No) or be dichotomous ([[Data_formats#Binary_data|binary]])
column8: e.g. yes/no
column9: agree/disagree (Bhattacherjee 2012
column10: p. 75; Kasunic 2005
column11: p. 44). When using ordinal scales
column12: an appropriate range
column13: i.e. number of answer options
column14: needs to be chosen so that participants can find an option that suits their perspective (6).

column2: subjective question with ordinal answer options'''. Source: Kasunic

column1: Closed questions can also offer unordered answer options in form of [[Data_formats#Nominal_data|nominal]] data
column2: like distinct categories in a list (6). In this case
column3: the researcher can choose how many answers can be checked by the respondents for each question (6). Further
column4: closed questions can also have a continuous response format
column5: “where respondents enter a [[Data_formats#Quantitative_data|continuous (ratio-scaled)]] value with a meaningful zero point
column6: such as their age or tenure in a firm. These responses generally tend to be of the fill-in-the blanks type.” (Bhattacherjee 2012

column2: objective question with unordered response options (nominal)''' Source: Kasunic

column1: Examples for different question types and response formats (including Likert-type scales) are offered by Bhattacherjee (2012) on page 75 and by Kasunic (2005) in section 4.2.1 and appendix D. Additionally
column2: the wiki entry on [[Data formats]] can help you understand the different response formats in surveys better.
further aspects regarding the question design include the number and order of questions as well as corresponding answers
column3: the wording and “the context in which the question is asked” (Gideon 2012
column4: p. 30). Moreover
column5: the “introduction
column6: framing
column7: and questionnaire designs” (Gideon 2012
column8: p. 30) need to be thoroughly devised to appeal to the target group and avoid biases. All these decisions can influence the survey results in terms of the “response rate
column9: response accuracy
column10: and response quality” (see below; Gideon 2012 p. 30).

column1: '''Before the actual conduction of a survey
column2: it is usually pretested.''' The pretest is designated to identify items in the survey which are biasing
column3: difficult to understand or misconceived by the participants e.g.
column4: because of their ambiguity (1; 3; 7). Further
column5: the validity of the survey items can be evaluated through a pretest (3). The people participating in the pretest are ideally drawn from the target population of the study
column6: while time constraints or other limitations sometimes only allow for resorting to a convenience sample (1; 3). After the pretest
column7: necessary adaptations in the survey are made (1).

column1: Different pretesting methods exist which “focus on different aspects of the survey data collection process and differ in terms of the kinds of problems they detect
column2: as well as in the reliability with which they detect these problems” (Krosnick 1999
column3: p. 542). Cognitive pretesting – also called “’thinkaloud’ interviews” (Gideon 2012
column4: p. 30) – is one such method. It “involves asking respondents to ‘think aloud’ while answering questions
column5: verbalizing whatever comes to mind as they formulate responses” (Krosnick 1999
column6: p. 542). By getting to know the cognitive processes behind making sense of and answering the survey questions
column7: “confusion and misunderstandings can readily be identified” (Krosnick 1999

column1: ==== Response Rate and Data Quality of a Survey ====
'''A high response rate is always desirable when conducting a survey.''' A good sampling strategy won't do much if no one answers to the survey. Also
column2: a stratified sampling strategy won't work if there are skewed responses. There are multiple strategies that can be applied to increase the response rate. First
column3: the chosen topic of the survey should be of interest or relevance for the target population under study. Then
column4: “pre-notification letters
column5: multiple contact attempts
column6: multi-mode approaches
column7: the use of incentives
column8: and customized survey introductions” (Gideon 2012
column9: p. 31) are further strategies which can help increase the response rate. In case of interview surveys
column10: a thorough training of the interviewers can be effective in motivating the interviewees to share their answers openly (3).

column1: The response quality is influenced by the personal interest and intrinsic motivation of the participants
column2: too (3). Unwilling respondents who want to go through the survey as quickly as possible might “engage in satisficing
column3: i.e. choosing the answer that requires least thought” (Gideon
column5: p. 140). Further
column6: the attention span and motivation level of the participants might decrease over the course of the survey
column7: which is referred to as respondent fatigue and negatively affects the data quality (108). Indicators for respondent fatigue and a limited response quality in general are an increased number of “don’t know”-answers
column8: short and superficial responses to open-ended questions
column9: “’straight-line’ responding (i.e. choosing answers down the same column on a page)” and ending the survey prematurely (3; 10).

column2: a good survey is also measured by its validity (the degree to which it has measures what it purports to measure) and reliability (the degree to which comparable results could be reproduced under similar conditions) (3).

column1: Surveys – especially self-completion questionnaires – are often associated with economical advantages such as savings in time
column2: effort
column3: and cost when compared to more open [[Interviews|interviews]] (1; 3). Further
column4: (digital) surveys allow to collect information which would otherwise be difficult to observe
column5: e.g. because of the size or remoteness of the target population or because of the type of data
column6: such as subjective beliefs or personal information (1). To this end
column7: survey research allows for larger samples compared to more qualitative open or semi-structured interviews. Furthermore
column8: “large sample surveys may allow detection of small effects even while analyzing multiple variables
column9: and depending on the survey design
column10: may also allow comparative analysis of population subgroups” (Bhattacherjee 2012

column1: A strength of questionnaire surveys and the reason why they are sometimes preferred by survey participants compared to interview surveys is their “unobtrusive nature and the ability to respond at one’s convenience” (Bhattacherjee
column3: p. 73). Interview surveys
column4: by contrast
column5: make it possible to reach out to difficult-to-reach target populations e.g.
column6: homeless people or illegal immigrants (1).

column1: Among the biggest challenges related to survey methods are the multitude of biases that can occur
column2: as those biases can “invalidate some of the inferences derived” (Bhattacherjee
column4: p. 80) from the collected data. Those biases include
column5: among others
column6: non-response bias
column7: sampling bias
column8: social desirability bias
column9: recall bias
column10: and common method bias. While the different biases are discussed briefly in the Wiki article [[Bias in Interviews]]
column11: you can find a more detailed explanation of those biases as well as strategies on how to overcome them in Bhattacherjee (2012).

column1: Further challenges in survey research include the avoidance of respondent fatigue and the assurance of the validity and reliability of the gathered data and analyzed results (3; 10).
A number of challenges also come with the increased reliance on the Internet for the implementation of surveys (3)
column2: such as safeguarding data protection (4). Participants may also engage in Internet surveys only to receive a promised incentive at the end
column3: which can “lead to […] false answers
column4: answering too fast
column5: giving the same answer repeatedly […]
column6: and getting multiple surveys completed by the same respondent” (Hays et al. 2015
column7: p. 688). Ways to avoid such incidents are e.g.
column8: the provision of feedback to the respondents while they are filling out the survey by pointing out that they seem to be rushing or giving the same answer for many questions in a row
column9: or the verification of their e-mail and IP address to “to ensure the identities of individuals that join and to minimize duplicate representation on the panel” (Hays et al. 2015
column10: p. 688). Moreover
column11: before analyzing the survey results
column12: those survey submissions can be excluded which exceed a certain number of missing answers
column13: which were submitted faster than a minimum time span defined
column14: or which contain identical answers for a defined number of consecutive questions (4).

column2: the use of each question type comes with challenges. For example
column3: “a closed-ended question can only be used effectively if its answer choices are comprehensive
column4: and this is difficult to assure” (Krosnick 1999
column5: p. 544). Also
column6: “respondents tend to confine their answers to the choices offered” (Krosnick 1999
column7: p. 544) instead of adding their own response if no fitting answer option is listed. Including open-ended questions in a survey can lead to a time-consuming analysis
column8: as the individual answers need to be sorted and interpreted. Further
column9: the interpretation of the open responses – especially in self-completed surveys – and thus the assurance of validity is considered challenging as no follow-up questions can be asked (6). Further
column10: “meaningful variables for statistical analysis” (Kasunic 2005
column11: p. 40) can hardly be extracted from open-ended answers.

column1: Designing and conducting a survey entails several ethical challenges (3). One main concern is the avoidance of biases. First
column2: the answers of the survey participants must not be influenced to fit the researchers’ hypothesis or a research client’s desired outcome e.g.
column3: by formulating or presenting the questions in a certain way. Second
column4: the results need to be generated and presented to “accurately reflect the information provided by respondents” (Gideon 2012
column5: p. 23). In addition
column6: the data and response quality should be critically reflected on during and after data collection (3). Furthermore
column7: data privacy as well as the protection of the survey participants from any other type of abuse needs to be ensured (3).

column1: Gideon (2012) points out that with regard to quality control of survey research
column2: many sources of error and bias have not received enough attention in the past. The author highlights that (early career) researchers have placed much focus on sampling errors
column3: which are comparatively easy to detect and resolved by adapting the sample size. However
column4: non-sampling errors
column5: such as response and non-response errors and their underlying challenges
column6: have often been insufficiently dealt with
column7: even though their negative impact on the survey quality and results is substantial. Such errors can occur at several stages in the survey research process and are usually characterized by a higher complexity than sampling errors; they cannot be resolved by simply increasing the sample size or by ensuring the representativeness of the sample (3). Therefore
column8: Gideon (2012) calls for the total survey error – which takes sampling as well as non-sampling errors into account – to be “the dominant paradigm for developing
column9: analyzing
column10: and understanding surveys and their results” (Gideon 2012
column11: p. 4) in the future.

column2: one main challenge for future survey research consists in sustaining sufficient response rates. As more and more people have declined their participation when invited to a survey during the past years
column3: both the risk of nonresponse bias and the costs allocated for participant recruitment increase (9). How well survey research can adapt to further changes in communication technology (e.g. through the Internet) will play an important role in this regard (9). However
column4: more research on the causes of and possible solutions for the decline in survey participation needs to be conducted (9).

column1: Another development which is likely to affect the use of survey research and its results in the future is the blending of data
column2: i.e. the combination of different data sources (9). According to Miller (2017)
column3: “blending survey data with other forms of information offers promising outcomes and technical challenges” (p. 210) at the same time.

column1: Despite the challenges survey research might face during the decades to come
column2: Miller (2017) concludes that survey research will continue to be relevant by providing important (statistical) information for academia as well as policymaking.

column2: Cotton et al. (see References) used a digital survey to explore lecturers’ understanding of and attitudes towards sustainable development and their beliefs about incorporating sustainable development into the higher education curriculum.''' The study was conducted at the University of Plymouth
column3: where lecturers from different disciplines were invited to participate.

column1: The methodical approach consisted of two stages
column2: the first one being an online questionnaire survey and the second one being in-depth semi-structured interviews. '''The questionnaire survey had two main objectives.''' First
column3: it was used “to establish baseline data on support for sustainable development across the university’s faculties and provide lines of enquiry for further research” (p. 584). Second
column4: it should allow for a systematic selection of survey participants who could be interviewed in the second stage of the research by calling for volunteers.

column1: The questionnaire contained both '''closed and open-ended questions'''
column2: where the latter question type was used “to complement quantitative data where it was felt useful to elicit more detailed information” (p. 584). The software SPSS was used for the analysis of the quantitative data
column3: while Pearson’s [[Simple_Statistical_Tests#Chi-square_Test_of_Stochastic_Independence|Chi-Square test]] functioned as the “test for association between certain variables
column4: with significance accepted where p < 0.05” (p. 584). The analysis of the qualitative data was conducted “using thematic analysis employing the [https://delvetool.com/blog/ccm constant comparative method] (Silverman

column1: The questionnaire was repeatedly '''pre-tested and revised''' before it was piloted with researchers and lecturers from different fields. For the pilot test
column2: two versions of the questionnaire were chosen which differed with regard to their terminology. While one version referred to “sustainability”
column3: the other version used the term “sustainable development”. This was done to find out which of the two terms was understood better by the potential respondents and resulted in the use of “sustainable development” for the final questionnaire version. However
column4: as lecturers from different disciplines and with a different background knowledge on the topic were targeted with the survey
column5: unfamiliarity with different terminologies was still difficult to avoid.

column1: The '''recruitment of participants''' for the online questionnaire was done via e-mail to the academic staff of the university
column2: which included a link to the online survey that was accessible for a month. With 328 responses received
column3: the response rate consisted of 29 percent which the authors consider comparable with similar online surveys. Moreover
column4: the respondents were found to be “broadly representative of university lecturers as a whole in terms of gender
column5: age and contract status (full/part time)” (p. 585). However
column6: the authors do not discount “the probability that those who responded had a better understanding of
column7: or perhaps stronger opinions on
column8: sustainable development than non-respondents” (p. 585)
column9: which is of particular relevance with regard to the interpretation of results.

column1: The authors present their '''findings''' in three main sections: (1) Understandings of sustainable development
column2: (2) Attitudes towards sustainable development
column3: and (3) Beliefs about incorporating sustainable development into the higher education curriculum.

column1: The following table (p. 586) shows the results for the '''lecturers’ interpretation of the concept of sustainable development'''
column2: i.e. the percentage of respondents who “agree” and “strongly agree” to the listed propositions. For this closed-ended question
column3: a five-point [[Likert Scale|Likert scale]] was used. The participants further had the possibility to give an open-ended response to this question. While many viewed the somewhat oversimplified tickbox definitions as problematic and elaborated on their opinions further
column4: “others admitted that they struggled to make sense of the options offered” (p. 587). This shows the varying levels of knowledge in the group and moreover indicates  “the immense difficulties of designing a questionnaire to examine views on a multifaceted and contested concept like sustainable development” (p. 587).

The next diagram (p. 588) presents the responses to the question on the '''lecturers’ attitudes towards sustainable development'''. While the quantitative data shows a “fairly strong agreement amongst respondents in support of sustainable development” (p. 588)
column2: the authors acknowledge the challenges when it comes to the interpretation of “such a general statement” (p. 588): “[W]ere respondents commenting favourably on the idea of sustainable development per se
column3: or was this simply a convenient proxy for a range of environmental
column4: social and economic concerns?” (p. 588).

column1: [[File:Survey Research Exemplary Study Cotton et al. 2007 Results-Attitudes SD p.588.png|500px|frameless|center|Survey Research Exemplary Study Cotton et al. 2007 Results-Attitudes SD p.588]]
Regarding the lecturers’ beliefs about incorporating sustainable development into the higher education curriculum
column2: “[o]ver 50% of respondents predicted including elements of sustainable development in their teaching in the coming year” (p. 589). The authors point out that this number can be the result of overreporting
column3: as the questionnaire is self-reported and does not observe actual behaviors and actions. In addition
column4: the authors clarify that “what constitutes ESD remains a matter of personal interpretation
column5: and may include changes to either content or process (approaches to teaching the subject)” (p. 589)
column6: which further complicates the interpretation of the quantitative data.

System Boundaries;"'''In short:''' Based on the idea of System Thinking
column2: this entry discusses how to properly draw boundaries in systems.

column1: '''[[System Thinking & Causal Loop Diagrams|System thinking]] has emerged during the last decades as one of the most important approaches in sustainability science.''' Originating in the initial system theory
column2: several conceptual frameworks and data analysis methodologies have been developed that aim to generate a better understanding of the interactive dynamics within a typically spatially bound system. While much attention has been hence drawn to a better theory development and subsequent application within a defined setting
column3: less attention has been aimed at a definition of system boundaries.

column1: While boundaries of some isolated systems as well as simple theoretical models can be rather clearly defined
column2: much attention of the recent literature has actually focussed on the effects that systemic interactions create across distances
column3: which have historically been considered separate (see for example [['https://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/teleconnections/'|'teleconnections']] in atmospheric research). It is now evident that inland watersheds are linked to oceangraphic processes through freshwater and nutrient inputs
column4: although these have historically and disciplinarily been examined separately. Furthermore
column5: the nestedness of systems is another challenge - the idea that smaller systems are contained within
column6: and are the constituent components of
column7: larger systems such as organs within the larger integrated functionality of the human body. Some organs can be removed or replaced
column8: but only in relation to the overall functions they provide and how they fit or match the context of the overall body (i.e
column9: blood type or immune response). Government jurisdictions give other clear examples
column10: where countries may contain several provinces as part of a federal system
column11: which in turn can contain smaller administrative units
column12: creating a multi-level administrative whole.

column1: The debate often resonates around a void between the global and the local levels of social and ecological [[Glossary|scales]] such as space
column2: jurisdiction
column3: administration and even time (e.g.
column4: slow to fast). While the global level of most scales is trivial to define
column5: the local level of a scale is less clear. What becomes clear in the definition process between global and local
column6: is the ambiguity and often arbitrary nature of defining what the reality of the system being examined is. Normative choices have to be made
column7: especially for defining research questions and hypotheses
column8: i.e.
column9: what is a part of the specific system
column10: what is not considered to be a part of it
column11: and what is an important element that you want to know about? This has implications for the relationships and outcomes you want to investigate. '''Standardization of system definitions
column12: or system defining [[Glossary|processes]]
column13: would also be a useful consensus activity to increase comparability and exchange within system science.''' Entire fields of research have thus emerged around normative understandings of what the optimal system level unit to examine might be
column14: such as rural sociology
column15: landscape ecology
column16: coastal governance or micro-economics. What is evident - and becomes unclear - is the spectrum of definitions and choices between the two ends of a scale
column17: and the degree to which the categorical differences in system boundary definitions are meaningful for how we analyse and interpret their functionality.

column1: [[File:System Boundaries - Farm.png|600px|thumb|center|'''Defining the system boundaries influences the scope and content of analysis'''. Source: [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/323959122_D11_Report_on_resilience_framework_for_EU_agriculture Meuwissen et al. 2018.]]]
Out of these challenges to define system boundaries we recognize a clear gap on how to approach a globally coherent definition
column2: which can recognize the wide array of contextual differences in how systems are defined and measured. We need to consider that some systems are either divided from larger or parallel systems
column3: or that smaller systems are nested into other systems.

column1: '''System boundaries can be defined based on a variety of parameters.''' For the simplicity of the argument
column2: we focus on one parameter out of several
column3: yet prefer not to discuss in depth the interaction of different parameters. Many people would define such interactions as [[Agency
column4: Complexity and Emergence|complexity]] within systems thinking
column5: but the examination of system complexity is premised on a coherent understanding of what is in and out of the system being examined. This is an inherent precondition for analysis
column6: which is often discussed or taken as an assumption that is often not clearly defined. For example
column7: spatially explicit parameters are an intuitive aspect of many defining processes
column8: and therefore shape our perceptions of what an appropriate system boundary might be. To use a spatial example: '''a larger city can be divided into smaller neighbourhoods
column9: while neighbourhoods can be defined based on different parameters
column10: such as function
column11: ethnic groups or cultural settings.''' While the definition of 'neighbourhoods' can be also informal
column12: it is also well established within urban planning. There is an evident awareness that system boundaries exist
column13: yet many would not be able to define why two systems differ. It is overall easier to define system boundaries based on spatial parameters
column14: such as structural elements
column15: ecosystems
column16: or the design of a city
column17: while informal parameters such as those based on normative dimensions are less clearly definable. Being initially clear within a research project about the boundaries of a system may help to clarify a ranking of what relevant parameters of the system are in terms of its boundaries
column18: but also considering the variance of these parameters within a system. Basically
column19: some parameters can be dramatically different within a system than outside
column20: have no relevance within a system
column21: or can have only relevance within the system. All [[Glossary|assumption]]s are plausible parameters to serve as system boundaries.

column2: we propose that both the state and the variance can be clear delimiters in defining boundaries between systems.''' When looking at a larger system
column3: it can have an overall average value as well as an overall variance regarding a system parameter. If we would now divide the larger system into two smaller parts
column4: it might be that the two systems have a different average value regarding this parameter. However
column5: two smaller systems could also be different regarding their variance
column6: where one smaller system has an overall large heterogeneity
column7: and the other one a small heterogeneity.

column1: A good example of this could be two neighbourhoods within one city. One could be very heterogeneous in terms of green infrastructure
column2: having many smaller parks
column3: trees
column4: and green rooftops. The other one could be highly homogenous
column5: being widely dominated by houses without any green infrastructure. Clearly
column6: both systems vary both in terms of the average value
column7: as well as the variance. Thus
column8: where boundaries are drawn to define those neighbourhoods in that city will dictate the analysis and conclusions about its variance and values.

column1: Another example would be two smaller systems
column2: one again being highly heterogeneous
column3: and the other consisting of one half that is a park
column4: and another half that are large apartment houses. Many would opt to divide the second smaller system into two sub-systems. This example illustrates how different parameters allow for a different division of systems according to the habitat recognition. However
column5: the park could be functionally related directly to the apartments
column6: constituting its own unit in an urban planning context. This illustrates how system boundaries depend on the parameters we observe

column2: system boundaries can also differ regarding the average value of a parameter but can show different [[Glossary|patterns]] when looking at the variance. This difference is often associated with the grain size of parameters. Grain size can be defined as the resolution at which a parameter is observed. A parameter can be for instance very homogenous at a large scale
column3: yet very heterogenous at a small scale. The question of grain size is often associated with nestedness
column4: yet grain size and nestedness are only indirectly connected

column2: the functions of neighbourhood can be very homogenous at a coarse grain
