column4: that is the scale at which the average as well as the variance of a parameter do not change any more. The smallest definable unit could hence be defined as the smallest local unit of a system. This is especially relevant since different disciplinary perspectives and approaches are often determined by method
column5: and therefore often also by grain. While for instance a method might not find any relevant patterns based on one differentiation of sub-systems

column1: Much of the currently published analysis in scientific publications is determined by system descriptions yet enabling transformation of systems demands a clear definition of the unit of analysis
column2: i.e. a system
column3: where common boundaries of those systems are not collectively agreed upon by all who are measuring and drawing conclusions about them. If a system being investigated is too large
column4: relevant patterns of a parameter might be lost against its constituent internally contained parts. If a system is bound to small

column1: This opens the door to criticism that could be raised regarding this line of thinking: '''Should the system boundaries be determined by the overall results that can be gained?''' From an [[:Category:Inductive|inductive]] perspective

column4: and as complex as necessary.''' This can be directly applied to the question of system boundaries
column5: since these would clearly enable an overly simplistic or an overly complex analysis. While it is clear that system analysis cannot opt for trivial outcomes that are hard to understand

column1: This is an important basis in order to enable the transformation of systems. The normative dimensions or parameters in systems are challenging to analyse and even more difficult to transform
column2: yet building on two examples we show how the average as well as the variance of systems can allow for a clear analysis of how cultural difference can define system boundaries over time. For example
column3: inheritance laws during the middle ages in Germany differed by religion. In Catholic regions
column4: the eldest son inherited farms in rural areas; while in protestant areas
column5: farms were divided into subsequent smaller units among the family. This had a dramatic impact on land use patterns as well as social dimensions within the given systems over time. Reflected in architecture and the landscape

column1: '''Another example is the process of political gerrymandering.''' This process depicts the manipulation of administrative boundaries for voting in the United States
column2: with the goal to favour one political party over the other by drawing the lines around those neighbourhoods who will vote for your political party to be in the district
column3: and those who won’t as out of it. This is a prominent example of how through the altering of system boundaries the normative characteristics of a system are altered. This is done with the rationale to diminish the variance in terms of some factors
column4: for instance with the goal to represent a minority. De facto
column5: is this rational often misused to influence the average
column6: or in other words to construct majorities. This highlights how system boundaries are already actively recognized
column7: even on such a deep normative dimension such as the political value system.

column1: Hence system borders can extend beyond biophysical spatial system entities and can also include the difference in mindsets and cultural settings. The most important question when defining system boundaries then becomes
column2: which variables determine or influence the system dynamics the most. When trying to define system boundaries
column3: we are hence looking at a multiverse of multidimensional parameters. We of course acknowledge the interactions between these parameters - which is often coined as complexity - but let us [[Big problems for later|not discuss this further]] at this point.

column1: Instead we conclude by shortly discussing the importance of a ranking or the development of hierarchies of different system parameters to guide systems analysis. '''Some parameters might be more important than others regarding the dynamics within one system. On the other hand
column2: some parameters may be more important in one system than in others.''' Based on these two assumptions
column3: any definition of system boundaries
column4: which can be defined as an early step in systems analysis and transformation
column5: can be approaches as an iterative approach. Ideally
column6: when defining system boundaries
column7: we would propose a parsimonious approach
column8: which we define as being as simple as possible and as complex as necessary.

column1: In an example where three systems neighbour each other

column7: then the boundary between S2 and S3 is the strongest. These types of boundaries

column1: This example underlines the importance of defining system boundaries by similarities and dissimilarities
column2: which can be defined both by the average value of parameters
column3: as well as by the variance of parameters. The additional layer of the social value we assign to those parameters then provides a means by which we can make analytical choices based on how we view order such parameters into value hierarchies.

column1: We propose that instead of relying on informal or non-reproducible definitions of system boundaries
column2: '''it is vital to pre-analyse system dynamics to define system boundaries

System Thinking
column3: System Analysis & System Dynamics ====

column1: A system is a ""(...) network of multiple variables that are connected to each other through causal relationships""
column2: based on which the network ""(...) expresses some sort of behaviour
column3: which can only be characterized through observation as a whole"" (Haraldsson 2004
column4: p.11). This behavior remains persistent in a variety of circumstances. More simply put
column5: a system is a ""(...) collection of connected things (...) that influence one another."" (Toole 2005
column6: p.2) Both the collection of elements and their interactions are important elements of the system which is emphasized by saying that a system is 'more than a collection of its parts' (Arnold & Wade 2015

column1: Every system is ""(...) defined by its boundaries"" (Haraldsson 2004
column2: p.13). The borders we draw for our system analysis influence which level of detail we apply to our view on the system
column3: and which elements we investigate. System elements can be animate (animals
column4: humans) or inanimate (rocks
column5: rain)
column6: conceptual (motivation) or real (harvest)
column7: quantifiable (money) or rather qualitative (well-being) (2). For example
column8: a system could be a tree
column9: with the leaves
column10: the stem and such elements interacting with each other
column11: but also the forest in which our tree interacts with the soil
column12: the weather
column13: other plants
column14: animals and inanimate objects. The system could also be the globe
column15: where this forest interacts with other ecosystems
column16: or the system in which Planet Earth interacts with the rest of the universe - our solar system. For more background on the definition of System Boundaries
column17: please refer to [[System Boundaries|this entry.]]

column1: '''The system is at the basis of System Thinking.''' System Thinking is a form of scientific approach to organizing and understanding 'systems' as well as solving questions related to them. It can be said that every creation of a (scientific) model of a system is an expression of System Thinking
column2: but there is more to System Thinking than just building and working with system models (1). System Thinking revolves around the notion of 'holistic' understanding
column3: i.e. the idea that the components of a system can best be understood by also observing adjacent components and attempting to understand their connections. Among diverging definitions of the term
column4: recurring characteristics of System Thinking are the acknowledgement of non-linear interrelationships between system elements
column5: including [[Glossary|feedback loop]]s
column6: that lead to dynamic behavior of the system and make it necessary to examine the whole system instead of only its parts (6). Further
column7: System Thinking assumes that ""(...) all system dynamics are in principle non-linear"" and that ""(...) only non-linear equations are capable of describing systems that follow non-equililbrium conditions"" (Haraldsson 2004

column1: '''Peter Checkland introduced the notion that there are two main types of System Thinking:''' hard and soft. Hard System Thinking (HST) includes the earlier forms of applied System Thinking that could be found in technology management or engineering. It assumes that the analyzed system is objectively real and in itself systemic
column2: that it can be understood and modeled in a reductionist approach and intervened by an external observer to optimize a problematic situation. HST is defined by understanding the world as a system that has a clear structure
column3: a single set of underlying values and norms and a specific goal (9). We could think of a machine as a 'system' in this sense.

column2: by comparison
column3: considers a 'system' an ""(...) epistemological concept which is subjectively constructed by people rather the objective entities in the world"" (Zexian & Xuhui 2010
column4: p.143). SST is defined by a systemic and iterative approach to understanding the world and acknowledges that social systems include diverse sets of worldviews and interests (9). In SST
column5: the observer interacts with the system they observe and cannot optimize it
column6: but improve it through active involvement. In this view
column7: a social organisation could be a 'system'.

column1: [[File:Causal Loop Diagram - Hard vs Soft.png|450px|thumb|right|'''Hard System Thinking and Soft System Thinking''' according to Checkland. Source: Checkland 2000
System Thinking (especially HST) finds concrete applications in science through two concepts that it builds upon: ''System Analysis'' and ''System Dynamics'' (1).

''System Analysis'' ""(...) is about discovering organisational structures in systems and creating insights into the organisation of causalities. It is about taking a problem apart and reassembling it in order to understand its components and feedback relationships."" (Haraldsson 2004
column2: p.5). ''System Analysis''
column3: thus
column4: focuses on understanding the system and being able to recreate it. This is often done through the application of Causal Loop Diagrams
column5: which will be explained below. For more information
column6: refer to the entry on [[System Analysis]].

column2: then
column3: focuses on the interaction part of the system. It ""(...) refers to the re-creation of the understanding of a system and its feedbacks. It aims at exploring dynamic responses to changes within or from outside the system. (...) System Dynamics deals with mathematical representation of our mental models and is a secondary step after we have developed our mental model."" (Haraldsson 2004
column4: p.5). System Dynamics
column5: as the name suggests
column6: enables the researcher to observe and measure the behavior of the system. The interactions between the individual elements are not just recreated
column7: but the consequences of these interactions are quantified and assessed.

column1: System Thinking allows for a shift in the perception of [[Causality|causality]]. Instead of assuming linear causality (A causes B
column2: B causes C) it allows for the integration of further influencing factors
column3: as well as a more neutral depiction of the system at hand. C may now be seen as a property that [[Agency
column4: Complexity and Emergence|emerges]] from the relation between A and B
column5: instead of perceiving it as a direct consequence of B. Haraldsson (2004
column6: p.21) provides an illustrative example here: ""We start by asking the initial question: ""I want to understand how water flows into the glass and what I do to fill it up."" Instead of looking at the action from an individual point of view
column7: where the ""I am"" is the active part and at the centre of focus
column8: we shift our perception to the structure of the action. The ""I am"" simply becomes a part of the feedback process
column9: not standing apart from it. Suddenly we have shifted out attention to the structure of the behavior and we can observe that the structure is causing the behavior. (...) We have now transformed the traditional linear thinking into a circular argument.""

column1: Causal Loop Diagrams (CLDs) are a crucial method for System Analysis since they allow for the modelling of systems. They make it possible ""(...) to 'map' the complexity of a problem of interest"" (McGlashan et al. 2016
column2: p.2). A CLD allows us to not suppose a linear relationship between system elements
column3: but rather understand cause and effect (1). It makes it possible to ""(...) understand how a behavior has been manifesting itself in a system so we can develop strategies to work with
column4: or counteract the behavior. We also want to know to what extent and how the problem is connected with other 'systems'"" (Haraldsson 2004
column5: p.20). By developing a CLD
column6: one can visualize and thus better understand the feedback mechanisms that happen in a system (1). Therefore
column7: they enable both a look at the structure as well as the processes in a system. The CLD also helps transfer system understanding (1). CLDs ""(...) provide a language for articulating our understanding of the dynamic
column8: interconnected nature of our world. (...) By stringing together several loops
column9: we can create a coherent story about a particular problem or issue."" (Team TIP 2011

column1: '''A Causal Loop Diagram consists of rather few elements:''' Variables
column2: Causal Relationships and Polarity.

column1: '''Variables''' represent the individual elements of a system
column2: but are adapted to the research intent underlying the creation of the CLD. They are ""(...) dynamic causes or effects of the problem under study"" (McGlashan et al. 2016
column3: p.2). For example
column4: in a CLD that recreates a forest ecosystem
column5: the system element may be the soil
column6: whereas the variable that we use in the CLD would be
column7: for example
column8: the change in the amount of carbon in the soil - if this is of interest for the research.

column2: the CLD depicts '''causal relationships'''. Causal relationships ""(...) are represented by arrows that represent a directed cause from one variable to another"" (McGlashan et al. 2016
column3: p.2). When a number of causal relationships (i.e. arrows) connects two or more variables to a circular structure
column4: a loop constitutes.

column1: Each of these causal relationships has one of two polarities (or 'feedbacks'): positive or negative. Note that these are not equal to growth or decline! If the polarity is positive (exhibited by a '+')
column2: the causally related variables change in the same direction: if the first variable grows in size
column3: the other does
column4: too; and if the first variable decreases
column5: so does the second one. Negative polarity ('-') works into opposite directions: if the first variable decreases
column6: the second one increases - and if the first one increases
column7: the second one decreases (1
column8: 3). The polarities influence the outcome of the systemic processes.

column2: which arise when an output of a system is circled back and used as one or more inputs
column3: through direct or indirect causal links. '''When there is an even number of negative polarities in a loop
column4: the loop is called 'amplifying' or 'reinforcing'
column5: indicated by an (R).''' This includes the case where there are only positive polarities
column6: since this is an even amount of negative polarities
column7: too (zero
column8: to be precise). In a reinforcing loop
column9: some variables may be ever-increasing and others ever-decreasing (this is the case when there are some negative polarities)
column10: or all variables are ever-increasing or decreasing (only positive polarities).

column1: '''When there is an odd number of negative polarities in a loop
column2: it is a 'balancing' loop
column3: indicated by a (B).''' You can check whether a loop is reinforcing or balancing by choosing one variable
column4: assuming that it is increasing (or decreasing) and going through the loop. If the behavior of this element leads to the same behavior
column5: again (e.g.
column6: an increase in A leads to an increase in A)
column7: the loop is reinforcing. If the behavior switches (e.g. an increase in A leads to a decrase in A)
column8: it is balancing.

column1: [[File:Causal Loop Example 1.png|200px|frameless|left|This is a '''reinforcing loop''' where each variable decreases (or increases) the other one. The (R) in the middle highlights this reinforcing process. Source: Made with Loopy.]]

'''Let's look at an example of a reinforcing loop''' with positive polarities only: A student's motivation to learn ahead of an exam is causally  - and positively ('+') - linked to the amount of learning they get done. If they are not motivated
column2: they will not get much done. And the less they get done
column3: the less motivated they are... and so on. On the other hand
column4: if they are very motivated
column5: they will get a lot done
column6: which motivates them to do even more. In an ideal world
column7: that is. We all know that this is not always the case
column8: don't worry.

column1: [[File:Causal Loop Example 2.png|200px|frameless|left|This is a '''reinforcing loop''' where all variables influence each other into '''opposite directions.''' The overall result for each variable is still escalation. Source: Made with Loopy.]]
If we substitute the purely positive polarities with purely negative
column2: we have a reinforcing loop (with an even number of negative links!) where one variable skyrockets
column3: and the other one diminishes. Say
column4: we substitute 'Motivation' with 'Stress Level': an increase in the stress level decreases the amount of studying
column5: which further increases the stress level
column6: which further decreases the studying. While the stress level escalates into therapeutically dangerous heights
column7: the amount of studying approximates zero. On the other hand
column8: a low stress level allows for a lot of studying
column9: which provides a good feeling and further decreases the stress level.

column1: [[File:Causal Loop Example 3.png|250px|frameless|left|This is a '''balancing loop''' where each variable decreases (or increases) the other one. The (B) in the middle highlights this balancing process. Source: Made with Loopy]]

column2: there is the self-regulating or 'balancing' (B) loop where the odd number of negative polarities hinders the loop from escalating.''' For example
column3: our exemplary student takes coffee breaks now and then
column4: because - let's admit it - they are a coffee junkie. The less they are motivated
column5: the more coffee they drink (positive link)
column6: which motivates them to study more (positive link). Studying more increases their motivation (positive link). We have now gone full circle
column7: and the initial decrease in motivation ultimately led to an increase in motivation through the cycle. Now
column8: if we do another round
column9: their newly increased motivation decreases their coffee consumption; without coffee
column10: they won't get anything done - and her motivation decreases again. That's a bummer
column11: but it shows how the balancing loop works both ways.

column1: [[File:CLD 4.png|250px|frameless|left|'''A reinforcing causal loop.''' Source: Made with Loopy]]

column2: let us have a look at another re-inforcing loop (R). Here
column3: one more variable in the loop led to an even number of negative links - there are now two negative and two positive polarities. If we follow the loop
column4: we see that a decrease in the motivation leads to an increase of coffee consumption
column5: which leads to an increase of coffee shopping
column6: which leads to a decrease in studying
column7: which leads to a decrease in motivation. Less motivation led to less motivation. The longer we pursue this loop
column8: the more the motivation will decrease
column9: as will the amount of studying. Meanwhile
column10: the student hoards and drinks coffee like a maniac. Of course
column11: this could go the other way around if the motivation increased in the beginning.

column1: === Causal Loop Diagrams: Step by Step ===
'''So how does one create a Causal Loop Diagram?''' The process consists of the following steps (from 1

column2: the time horizon and the question to be answered with the Causal Loop Diagram. The time horizon and system boundaries influence the design of the CLD because some elements may not play a role in short or long time horizons
column3: or in a more narrow or wider perspective on the system.

column1: 2) Place the variables that are relevant to the system
column2: starting with just a few very important ones (based on knowledge about the system
column3: e.g. through an initial system analysis). The level of detail (e.g. if your variable is the forest
column4: the individual tree
column5: or its leaves) depends on the research interest and the defined system boundaries. An overly detailed CLD will unnecessarily complicate the latter analysis of the system.

column1: 3) Determine the causalities between these variables - which of them are linked with each other? - and draw the respective arrows.
4) Attach the polarities (feedbacks) - either positive or negative - to each linkage.
5) Identify loops in your system and evaluate how each develops over time - does it escalate or regulate itself? Mark them as either balancing (B) or reinforcing (R)
column2: accordingly. Note that a loop might include a larger number of variables. Remember: if it is not circular
column3: it is not a loop!

column1: 6) Re-iterate. The CLD will not be perfect from the start
column2: so you may change and add variables
column3: decrease or increase the system boundaries and time horizon. However
column4: you should not change the polarities if their original placement was based on sound and data-based knowledge of the interactions.

column1: 7) A few additions may be made to this process.

* There may be further linkages between variables of the loop and external variables that are not immediately part of the loop but still influence the loop's behavior. A generally reinforcing loop can still have balancing behavior if the external feedback prevents escalation (1).
* There may be delays in the feedback. These delays can be signified by drawing to lines across the respective arrow (1)
[[File:Causal Loop Delays.png|600px|thumb|center|'''An example of a delayed feedback loop.''' Source: Haraldsson 2004

column2: one of the loops in a CLD may be more important for the dynamic of the whole system. This loop (or also a single feedback) may be drawn bolder to highlight its weight (1). This highlights how a subsequent quantitative analysis of the loop's behavior
column3: e.g. through appropriate software
column4: can shed light on more details of the system's behavior.

column1: * The loops may also follow a sequence
column2: i.e. one or more of the loops is predominant until a specific event happens (e.g. when a certain threshold is passed). Afterwards
column3: another loop is more relevant. This can get complicated - if you want to learn more about these cases
column4: see Haraldsson 2004 in the Key Publications.

column1: * Causal-Loop Diagrams may depict systemic interactions over [[Time|time]]
column2: as well as across [[:Category:Global|spatial scales]]. For example
column3: a local system may be influenced by global developments
column4: and this interaction can be included and visually highlighted in a CLD.

column1: System Thinking provides advantages over linear analyses that do not do complex problems justice.
* System Thinking helps find the real roots of problems instead of applying 'end of pipe' solutions that only fix symptoms
column2: not causes. It also helps not to disimprove things by fixing one element but worsening another one while doing so (1).

column1: * Human thinking often tends to fall into simple cause-and-effect patterns that make it easier to understand the world. Applying System Thinking and the creation of Causal Loop Diagrams may be seen as solutions to this tendency of the human mind to simplify complex relationships where several variables influence each other. System Thinking makes it easier to get a feeling for how things really interact
column2: as opposed to a very simplified model that neglects too many interactions. However
column3: one should keep in mind that any model is just a (more or less detailed) approximation of the real world
column4: and sometimes
column5: problems are not as complex as they seem.

column2: there are some potential pitfalls when developing Causal Loop Diagrams.

column1: * The variables in the CLD must be quantitatively increasable or decreasable states of elements
column2: not the elements themselves. For example
column3: a variable should not be ""attitude towards something""
column4: which cannot be increased or decreased but only described. Instead
column5: the CLD should work with ""tolerance towards something"". The variables should also be self-explanatory and neutral
column6: because ""the action is in the arrows"" (Haroldsson 2004

column1: * The communicative purpose of a CLD can only be seen as accomplished when the reader / viewer understands the thinking behind the model and the principles that guide the system (1). This is especially relevant since Causal Loop Diagrams can become huge
column2: which makes it increasingly difficult to find root causes for developments and not lose the overview (see Figure above).

column1: Chu (2011) raises concerns about the notion of 'systems'. In her view
column2: common definitions of systems (especially those which Checkland would consider 'hard' systems) imply that the 'real' world existed of systems and non-systems
column3: and that the complexity of each system model (which CLDs are a form of) was dependent on how the system 'is'. Instead
column4: she suggests to realise that the complexity of any system model depends on how complex the researcher decides to develop the model: ""How much detail one takes into account in models depends entirely on the perspective one takes that is on what needs to be taken into account."" (Chu 2011
column5: p.184). Mitchell (2004) claims equally: ""The idealized and partial character of our representations suggests that there will never be a single account that can do all the work of describing and explaining complex phenomena. Different degrees of abstraction
column6: attention to different components of a system
column7: are appropriate to our varying pragmatic goals and conceptual and computational abilities."" (p.1)

column1: Developing a CLD does include the steps of [[System Boundaries|setting system boundaries]] and defining the research interest and thus the necessary elements to be included. In this regard
column2: these concerns highlight that a CLD (and any form of system modelling) is always dependent on the previously made decisions and simplifications and any results of the system analysis must acknowledge this. Chu therefore dismisses the idea of quantifying the complexity of systems based on the properties of system models; and Mitchell suggests not to attempt to break down the world into singular reductionist models that do not represent real complexity
column3: but rather to endorse 'integrative pluralism' that combines different models of the same phenomenon and thus allows for more realistic representations. This critique is in line with Checkland's 'soft' system understanding that offers an alternative to the assumption that systems are objectively real and independent from the observer's relation to it (9).

column1: * While Causal Loop Diagrams are a simplified form of [[System Analysis]]

column1: A Systematic Literature Review follows a set of steps that is similar to any scientific research process (1

column1: Data (= literature) is searched and acquired. There may exist a wide range of documents of relevance to the research endeavour

column1: * A literature review is a helpful starting point for any research: it provides a structured overview of the current knowledge and open questions in the respective field and may lead to new research questions that had not been obvious to the researcher before. The strength here is the systematic nature of the literature review: by not only reading randomly through literature
column2: but instead following a systematic and reproducible approach
column3: the researcher generates a more objective overview of the literature. Of course

column5: but if this process is properly reasoned and documented
column6: the bias may be reduced compared to a non-systematic review.

column1: Potential mistakes and thus challenges in the review process include (4):
* not clearly relating the findings of the literature review to the researcher's own study
* not taking sufficient time to identify the best (primary!) sources
* not critically reflecting upon the studies' research designs and analysis
* reporting isolated statistical results instead of meta-analytic or [[Simple Statistical Tests|chi-square]] methods
* not considering contrary findings or alternative interpretations when synthesizing quantitative literature

T-Test;"'''In short:''' T-tests can be used to investigate whether there is a significant difference between two groups regarding a mean value (two-sample t-test) or the mean in one group compared to a fixed value (one-sample t-test).
This entry focuses on two-sample T-tests and covers the concept and purpose of the t-test
column2: underlying assumptions
column3: its implementation in R
column4: as well as multiple variants for different conditions. For more information on the t-test and other comparable approaches
column5: please refer to the entry on [[Simple Statistical Tests]].

column1: Let us start by looking at the basic idea behind a two-tailed two-sample t-test. Conceptually speaking we have two hypotheses.
H0: Means between the two samples do not differ significantly.
H1: Means between the two samples do differ significantly.
In mathematical terms (μ<sub>1</sub> and μ<sub>2</sub> denote the mean values of the two samples):

'''Here is an example to illustrate this.''' The farmers Kurt and Olaf grow sunflowers and wonder who has the bigger ones. So they each measure a total of 100 flowers and put the values into a data frame.
Our task is now to find out whether means values differ significantly between two groups.

column1: The "I" in this wiki;"Using the first person is usually discouraged in scientific writing. In a nutshell
column2: I disagree with this notion
column3: and explain in this text
column4: why we use the first person - both ''I'' and ''we'' - in this Wiki
column5: and how you should read and understand this.

column1: '''I perceive the norm of writing in a third person as a scientist as a clear indicator of the arrogance of science that is deeply rooted in the fallacy of positivism.''' By writing in the third person
column2: many scientists [https://www.editage.com/insights/is-it-acceptable-to-use-first-person-pronouns-in-scientific-writing claim they convey objective information] that can be reproduced by anyone
column3: while [https://www.sciencemag.org/careers/2012/03/how-write-scientist the first person humanises our work].

column1: I think that by clearly indicating something as our personal opinion or to be based on our personal experience we give the information more value
column2: and not less. This is rooted in me defining myself as a [[Bias and Critical Thinking|critical realist]]. I think there is higher value information in ethics that help us make sense of the world and find meaning
column3: and these are ontologically objective [[Glossary|assumptions]]. However
column4: when it comes to epistemological knowledge - and this is what sciences is mostly preoccupied with - we only have subjective information at our disposal.

column2: it is possible to clearly differentiate between activated observations that I made
column3: and observations that are shared by the scientific community.''' For the latter
column4: I would clearly use the third person. By doing this
column5: I clearly acknowledge that our knowledge may change in the future
column6: but there is a scientific canon that currently agrees on specific knowledge. An example of such knowledge would be the continuous development of life through evolution. Our knowledge about the mechanisms which we understand that are behind these [[Glossary|processes]] still continuously change (consider for instance the impact of epigenetic on our lives). Still
column7: we can widely agree that there are processes such as natural selection and mutations that drive the adaptation and further development of living organisms. It is thus justified to say that science generally accepts evolution as the mechanisms behind the diversity of life. This is different from information that is conveyed by a sub-community within the wider arena of science. Altruism is a good example where you have basically two principal sub-communities: the scientists that view altruism as a trait of evolutions
column8: and scientists who look for something beyond a mere kinship advantage perceived through altruism. I count myself to the latter group. I do no want to act altruistically because evolution tells me to
column9: but look instead for higher reasons that are independent of my genes. Another example would be in statistics. I am more interested in parsimonious models
column10: and many scientists would agree that these are preferable to full models. However
column11: some researchers believe that full models - without any model reduction towards a parsimonious model - deserve our attention
column12: and hence publish full models. An increasing number of researchers within frequentist statistics consider that this approach is wrong. Consequently
column13: when I say ""we propose that model reduction is preferable to reporting full models""
column14: I mean myself and likeminded scientists. This is a deeply normative statement rooted in my experience and the experience of other scientist
column15: and therefore ideally deserves further explanation. Consequently
column16: I might write something to the end of ""by avoiding p-values and building my model reduction on AIC values
column17: the reported statistic model are more robust under the criteria of parsimony"".

column1: '''The use of third person is to me a great destroyer of scientific discourse since it makes the way we conduct discourse less precise.''' I think the scientific community made a grave mistake when it shifted to the third voice almost exclusively
column2: since this took away any possibility to clearly indicate whether you speak of widely accepted knowledge
column3: knowledge accepted by a specific community
column4: or your own experience. The last sentences are all written in the first person
column5: because I wrote down my opinion. It is ""I"" who has this opinion
column6: and while I am sure and even vaguely know that I am not the only person that has this opinion
column7: the norms of the scientific community widely reject my opinion. I have no precise knowledge about other scientists who share my opinion. Hence I verbalised a new thought
column8: and this deserves the first person. It is I who has this thought
column9: and I offer this thought to the scientific community as a basis for discourse.

column1: A word on opinions. An opinion can be defined as a statement rooted in a personal believe or perceptions that is neither supported by evidence
column2: nor cannot be tested. All I write on this Wiki is clearly supported by evidence
column3: and can be indeed tested and thus be confirmed or rejected. It is up to the readers to do this
column4: but all written here is not about my opinions. People have confused this in this past
column5: hence it seems reasonable to clarify this.

column2: this wiki will use three different perspectives in terms of statements.''' The widest most general agreement includes knowledge that is accepted by the majority of scientists - written in the third person. The second category is knowledge by a scientific sub community - ""we"". The third - innermost - category is knowledge that is proclaimed by me as a curator of this Wiki
column3: on this Wiki
column4: marked by ""I"". All three categories are normative
column5: since the knowledge within all three categories may change."

column1: The Academic System;"Academia is equally an opportunity and a challenge
column2: and many times we cannot even say which is which. Some of its elements date back into the ages
column3: and on the other end is academia defined by creating knowledge that evolves
column4: pushing our insights and the way we act based upon them forward
column5: ideally radically changing the world for the better. Academia originated in a resource surplus of early societies
column6: which could suddenly afford to have citizens that concentrated on nothing but knowledge with all its facets. Over time
column7: academia became subsequently more focussed
column8: and scientific disciplines emerged out of schools of thinking. Today
column9: there is a dendritic network of disciplines that divides into ever smaller units with strong identities
column10: which are often defined by their focal topics
column11: underlying concepts and theories
column12: and the associated canon of specific methods. Finding your roles and more importantly your vector of strategies and reflection points in the modern academia is a key challenge that serves as an initial building block of your career. Whole books are available on how to make it in academia
column13: yet such approaches are somewhat beyond the point. If there was a recipe that everybody can follow
column14: then we would reproduce the same academics all over. Academia is defined by evolvement and diversity
column15: or at least it should be. Scientific disciplines often counteract this baseline. Out of the enlightenment and the industrial age
column16: scientific disciplines were initially designed to produce workers of the mind that would administer economic development and colonial abuse. In the 20th century
column17: knowledge became more and more compartmentalised
column18: and ever finer layers of disciplines developed. To this date
column19: the system is strongly competitive and resembles mostly a social Darwinist funnel. While all countries to this day build on a hierarchical system where professors are the highest caste
column20: this system has lately been drastically changed in many countries. Germany is at the forefront of a movement where you have an overall higher number of full professors
column21: but in comparison less assistant professors and lecturers. While in the past much of the teaching was long-term shouldered by these mid-level academia workers
column22: most of these increasingly vanished today
column23: and much of the remaining positions are limited to a maximum of six years. This limited time frame is often one of the main breaking points in modern academia. You have 6 years for your PhD
column24: and 6 years as a postdoc. If you do not have a permanent contract after 12 years
column25: you are legally out. Other countries have comparable mechanisms
column26: and after such a long time it is anyway clear for most people if you can make it
column27: or not. There is however still a larger convolute of lecturer positions in Scandinavian and English-speaking countries. However
column28: even these positions are now characterised by an expectation that often goes beyond excellence in teaching and includes usually a research impact and the deep commitment towards management tasks and development of the institution. Yet way before the question how to gain a permanent position
column29: other puzzles cross your way: different hierarchies
column31: tacit barriers and simply too many unknowns to find your way into the system. There are mainly two ways that can help prospering young academics to find their way into a successful career: A solid peer-network and one or few mentors. Without a mentor
column32: life in academia and more importantly life into academia is almost impossible. May it be the medieval apprenticeship in the style of ""The Sword in the Stone""
column33: shall it be the Kung Fu disciple just as in the ""36th chamber of the Shaolin""
column34: or may it be ""Mulan"". Having someone see the raw germ and unleashing its full potential is a collaborative act of learning
column35: and current professors can thus become one of the best bets that future professors will be better. One of my first mentors did actually always say that he only accepts disciples that are better than he is. A mentor ideally helps a learner to deal with all the challenges you face in the system
column36: and does not only explain all cliffs
column37: but also the path how to let them pass. Finding a mentor is like finding any other social relationship
column39: and then it may play out in your favour. Beside the knowledge may the serendipity space of your mentor also translate into a larger space of opportunities for yourself. What is most important for any mentorship is that it actually works both ways at the same time
column40: since good students question aspects of the professors
column41: and push the system to evolve
column42: and also ideally turn the teacher into a learner
column43: which is vital. Professors may have more experience
column44: but the innovative drive often happens on the lower ranks
column45: and certainly much of the wider workload. What is almost more important is a peer network
column46: because this is your emotional safety net and lifeline. Joined suffering creates strong bonds
column47: and many of the strongest bonds were formed over a solid network of early career peers suffering together and helping each other out. Such a network can also grow over time
column48: and link into existing networks and create beneficial connections that help you get your career going. More often than not it is not so much about knowing people
column49: it is more about knowing information. Thus
column50: beside the emotional coping is a network a living body of knowledge that helps you to overcome obstacles. The most important information is often that your struggle is not unique
column51: but indeed many people face similar issues. A peer network is also relevant for one main movement: If a lot of lower ranks talk about the same stuff
column53: and professors will become more interested in what gets the young folks around.

column1: Academic institutions are deeply committed to integrate diversity into their DNA
column2: and they should
column3: because diversity clearly thrives innovation. However
column4: there is ample evidence that institutions still fail to this end
column5: not on all fronts
column6: but there are too many prominent cases and hard information which more than underline that there is a lot to be done to recognise
column7: appreciate and integrate diversity. While institutions are deeply committed to have gender and diversity offices
column8: responsible colleagues to support people with disabilities
column9: to aid international students and so on
column10: it is clear that academic institutions are strongly biased in many directions. Emotions run high to this end
column11: and many non-minorities currently create backlashes against the necessary pushes towards more diversity. However
column12: I have a perspective spanning over decades now
column13: and what most people are not aware of is that changes are happening. They are not fast enough
column14: which is more than clear. Recent generations are not ok with that kind of a slow adaptational evolutionary process
column15: and the demand for more revolutionary changes is currently creating tensions yet also triggering the necessary changes. Future academics finding their way under the assumption of diversity and bias has an unmountable level of layers
column16: and it is hard to evaluate what to concretely suggest on how to deal with the system.

column1: Having a dedicated and committed group of people who have experiences on a specific issue or topic is again pivotal
column2: because members of such an in-group can learn tricks on how to deal with the systemic failures. If you know the pressure points and highlight the demands within the respective situation
column3: every institution will increasingly try to implement change for the better. While there is still a long way to go
column4: it is surely worthwhile to team up
column5: share the burden
column6: and drive change. However
column7: there is one point about diversity that is also highly relevant for academic institutions. Having a minority perspective can be a strong motivation to drive change. Deep emotional experiences can be – as sad as they are in a personal hemisphere of experience – be a driver to change the system away from underlying wrongs. If for instance someone has strong experiences about being bullied
column8: then there is a chance that this person will not tolerate bullying in the future. If then again someone has a strong experience how majorities dominate minorities
column9: then this person may draw conclusions that cut deeply into the status quo of science. Experiences about identity constructs may translate into more inclusive or deconstructive assumptions about constructs in science. Diversity breeds diversity
column10: and being tolerant and inclusive will be ultimately the better way beyond any dimensions we all single-handedly could ever imagine.

column1: Academia faces just like all work environments and increasing demand to balance the work life and the life after hours. Being part of the great acceleration
column2: academia was not spared from becoming increasingly competitive over time
column3: and thus pushing people into higher and more dense working hours. Psychological challenges are increasingly recognised in academia as well
column4: both as a diagnosis and as an epidemic. Creating a balance is often proclaimed
column5: but hardly achieved. In a system that is resource limited
column6: the pressure that is being put on individuals is mounting
column7: and people willing to make sacrifices are still supported by the clandestine and tacit design that is deeply engrained in academia. This creates many injustices that were increased by the pandemic
column8: and we are at a point in time where we need to take stock and look not only at the bigger picture
column9: but first and foremost at the demand and capabilities of the individual. While more work creates more output it should become critical how much output and change people can drive within the work time. The rest should be reserved for friends
column10: family
column11: or other elements to spend the time. The agency to thrive in your personality and to use the time to relax and reflect is increasingly recognised as pivotal
column12: and a paradigm shift concerning work-life balance is slowly emerging. Yet there are very diverse approaches and models how people deal with time within academia. Most academics these days are completely cluttered and slaves of their calendar. There are no mincing words here
column13: many people do not have free time for weeks. We became drowned in tasks
column14: and often need to relearn how to prioritise. The system throws tasks at us scientists at a rate that has become hard to bear. There is more and more administration
column15: safeguards and tasks that are means yet not ends. An academic today has a much more diverse portfolio of tasks as compared to decades ago. This creates a social Darwinist funnel that we need to escape from. It is a clear challenge not only of academia but also other spheres of society that strangely evolved into more control and less action. There are more parts of academic institutions that control us compared to the amount or capacity that can create action. This is rooted in good intentions
column16: because the control tries to prevent injustices. Out of this urge
column17: we created an even bigger injustice that punishes the commons in trying to safeguard the system. It is clear that ""safety first"" is a mantra to first and foremost protect minorities that face injustices
column18: yet many of these cannot cope with the rising and mounting workload. For instance is it difficult to square the care work as a parent with the schedule and pressure of an academic career
column19: to name just one challenge. To this day the border between public and private life in academia is deeply blurred
column20: and there remain many open questions. While continuous education should be a mantra of academics
column21: many do this in their private time. Our social circle is often an equivalent of the work folks that surround us all day
column22: making is even more difficult to differentiate work from private life if we want to. Shifting work places due to the precarious hiring situation lead to a constant turnover of our social circles. Relationships have to catch up or compromise with a constant mobility. If you look to stay at the same place throughout your career
column23: academia might not be your ideal turf. Continuity is then often designed to take place in the digital work. Social media and other digital skills are these days part of the standard portfolio of academics
column24: yet these new media forms also led to an increasing crumbling of the of the border between work and private life. Being online 24/7 is technically not expected
column25: yet while other branches of our work system try to carve out non-work time more clearly
column26: academia is on the edge of always dragging you into the Maelstrom of more and more work all the time. Stringing boundaries may be a survival skill for many. I have a good friend who works strictly 9-5
column27: and indeed very successfully. He just makes the time he does work really count
column28: and uses the rest of his time to reboot and re-energise. Mapping out the border between academic work time and the rest of your life is a challenge
column29: though. There are too many who love their work so much
column30: that they literally never stop. I count myself among them. Others need time to rest and balance their day more strongly. This creates again injustices
column31: but it is of course difficult to stop people from working who just love their work
column32: and who would find it troubling to stop. After all it is really hard to not think about something if you are excited about it
column33: and many academics are hyped by their work all the time. This creates a penalty for people who need explicit time to recover. This is a problem that is slowly changing
column34: yet will create inequalities and injustices for decades to come. We need to be openly honest
column36: and aware of the normative dimensions of academic evaluation
column37: otherwise we will not be able to change academia towards a better state.

column1: Academia is a funnel which starts extremely broad and becomes more and more restrictive. There are for instance almost three million students in Germany right now
column2: a number which was rising sharply over the last decades. While there are about 250000 Bachelor degrees per year in Germany
column3: there are way less Master degrees (ca 150000). A fraction of those go on for a PhD
column4: and also external students join German academia. There are about 29000 PhD degrees per year. Overall
column5: there are about a total of 50000 professors in Germany
column6: and considering age and retirement structure
column7: there are professor positions for less than 20 % of the PhD students
column8: and in some disciplines certainly way less. This pyramid structure of the different hierarchical levels of academia brings several challenges with it. First
column9: students feel next to invisible for most professors. Given that there is one professor for about 60 students at an average
column10: it is clear that this notion is more often than not a reality. While this can be argued in a resource limited system
column11: there is an increasing demand to more deeply recognise the demands of the students. 3 hour non-stop lectures in the form of full frontal lobotomies – which equal the professor talking non-stop without any interaction – are increasingly questioned. On the other end
column12: students are increasingly driven by the hunt for credits and other optimisations of their CVs. It becomes a rising challenge to have a convincing CV that does not equal a CV of everybody else
column13: which again links to a higher workload and associated inequalities. The grading system is clearly in dire need of reform
column14: yet without any grades is it still a challenge to evaluate students. Creative collaborative formats such as group work are not fully explored yet
column15: and many lectures still build on frontal learning with few reflexive or interactive elements. Worse still
column16: all the learning is hardly contextualised concerning concrete goals and the associated challenges. For instance does academia need to seize a superior role concerning responsibility for and with society
column17: yet this brings several challenges with it that are often ignored. Trying to drive change in a system that is often changing or even characterised by failures is difficult within the increasingly normative agenda of many scientific arenas. For instance is environmental science often a field that links science with activism
column18: and this mutual link creates challenges for individuals that are widely ignored by academia to date. Yet also professors are framed in a form that can be seen critical
column19: because most professors are still to this day a reflexive surface that is supposed to equal endless competence
column20: ubiquitous knowledge and a capacity to be always failsafe. No person can live up to these standards
column21: and the urge for perfectionism serves as breeding ground to reconsider the role of authority and authoritative knowledge in academia. Deep changes are needed to properly designate and relocate the role of leaders and educators in academia
column22: and this process is slow and will need even more time.

column1: While much more can be reflected about academia
column2: for better or worse
column3: the above text is a mere starting point to reflect about the academic system and structures. It is clear that all constructed institutions are forever changing. Academia is defined by change and supposed to drive change. Knowledge evolves
column4: and so do knowledge structures. The rise of Western science did however lead to a diminishing of other forms of knowledge. Thus
column5: while disciplines evolved and become ever more branching into finer domains
column6: whole other forms of knowledge were ignored or neglected. Academic structures need to decolonize and take all inequalities into account
column7: better today than tomorrow. Future academics need to reflect and position themselves in order to become drivers and amplifiers of such change. On the other hand do future academics also need to recognise their limitations concerning which changes can be implemented in which time frame. If we try to drive change concerning aspects that are static
column8: frustration may arise. For instance are the resource limitations in academia a fact of our current reality. I do not expect that we will get way more positions any day soon
column9: although I would more than welcome this. Wanting to change this notion is if at all only possible in the long run. On the other end can several changes be in a shorter time window. For instance did we move the welcome lecture of new professors into the afternoon
column10: allowing people with family to attend
column11: who before could not make such gatherings if these were in the evening. While such changes seem minute yet obvious
column12: they represent important shifts in the wider landscape that designs and locates academia. Learning the difference between short-term changes and long-term changes is a key goal in the reflection of how you locate yourself in academia. Which aspects do you want to change? Where do you believe your energy is worthwhile to drive fast change? Where you can focus your limited energy and resources? There are often people who try to throw all their might against injustice that we have to change in the long run. It is up for everybody on their own to evaluate this
column13: yet many negative emotions yield whenever unchangeable or at least only long-term changeable challenges are attacked head on
column14: with an expectation to change theses now. All perceived injustices should be always called out and if identified attacked head on. Yet we need to be gentle with our head
column15: and make sure we do not endanger ourselves in this process. I invite you all al sit down and reflect:

column1: 1. What do you want to change in the wider academia in the short term?
2. What do you want change in academia in the long run?
3. Which challenges in academia – but also for yourself – do you consider to ignore for the time being?
4.	Which challenges do you ignore for now
column2: but plan to engage later on?

column1: Academia is both place-based and non-physical at the same time. We always speak of norms
column2: tacit knowledge and practices
column3: mechanisms and processes that are part of the wider hemisphere that makes all of academia a non-physical entity. On the other end is academia being practiced and changed in places that have a clear location
column4: and it is here that we need to understand and evolve our impact to begin with. We may be able to drive change in academic places
column5: and if these prove their worth
column6: the change will spill over to other places. In the long run
column7: this may change academia as such. Take your time and consider what you want to change and what you chose to ignore or change later. Be mindful of your energy and capacity. No one needs more frustration or yet another overworked academic. Be the academic you want to see in the world."
