'''We drown in meetings.''' When the end of humanity comes
column2: it will probably happen in a meeting. We humans are creatures that thrive through communication and collaboration
column3: and meeting can - at least in theory - be prime places to identify goals
column4: clear obstacles
column5: and energise a team towards a joint goal. Instead
column6: however
column7: many of us cement ourselves into an endless track of useless meetings that are dull
column8: aimless and numbing. Here
column9: I will outline my perception why it came to this
column10: and propose my attempts how to make it out of this conundrum.

column1: '''1) Meetings without an agenda or established norms.''' Meetings should either have a clear agenda or follow an established norm. Ideally
column2: the agenda is either sent around before
column3: or there is a central repository that contains the items to be discussed. Ideally
column4: an agenda needs to be shared early enough to allow for a proper preparation. Within my role as a dean we established as a team a central document where everybody can add agenda items. This is to me really helpful as it is both empowering and also helps participants to prepare themselves for the meeting. More often than not
column5: items can already be cleared beforehand
column6: and an agenda helps structure a meeting. Fist
column7: the group focuses on items that are relevant for everybody
column8: and then make a smaller circle focusing on a subset of items. In an ideal world
column9: each item should be solved in the end
column10: and it should be clear from the beginning to everybody how this will be achieved.

column1: '''2) Unprepared Meetings.''' Unprepared meetings are not only due to a lack of an agenda
column2: but also because participants did not clarify their role and manage their own expectations. If I decide to join a meeting I would ideally want to either trust the person leading the meeting
column3: or alternatively prepare my own agenda. The latter is a strategy with which I actually made some good experience in the past. Writing your own agenda if an actual agenda is missing is a good move to ultimately turn a dull meeting into something that at least contributes to your own goals or to the parts of the institution you represent. I have great admiration for some specific colleagues who prepare diligently for meetings
column4: which can make even the most minor or junior role a raving success.

column1: '''3) Wrong composition of people.''' Any given meeting will gain its dynamics out of the composition of participants. To me
column2: the composition of team members in a meeting is so relevant since group identity is built over time. Resilience is built out of diversity
column3: and it is quite important to enable people to have their say in a given meeting. Though some people are missing at some times - or may have colliding obligations - I came to the conclusion that in the long run
column4: those people participating in meetings are the ones who build and propel the team spirit further.

column1: '''4) Lack of facilitation.''' Facilitation can be defined as a designed support structure by one or several people to foster constructive integration within a specific setting. Facilitation is currently somewhat of a holy grail in academia and beyond
column2: and rightly so
column3: as we were widely missing out on this dimension beforehand. Facilitation done right can be a form of art
column4: and facilitation can be prove that a path can surely be more important than the actual goals. One could write a whole book on all aspects of facilitation
column5: yet since it is experience based
column6: the most important advice is to encourage people to try it out for themselves. While some are clearly naturals
column7: other may struggle. Still
column8: gathering this initial experience can help everybody understand the struggles and challenges of the role of a facilitator.

column1: '''6) Lack of balance.''' Lack of balance can manifest in many ways within meetings. Often
column2: one or few people totally dominate a meeting. This can be ok if the goals are still achieved
column3: and other participants do not feel disempowered. In my experience
column4: it can however be quite a negative experience if a substantial amount of talking time is monopolised by one person. While this can be an indicator of some underlying problems in the team
column5: it makes the meeting often a frustrating experience. Like commitment and facilitation
column6: this is something where you need to build an identity as a group and openly reflect upon such a disbalance with the respective person afterwards. Another disbalance can be created if one agenda item dominates the meeting
column7: which is often in coherence with one person dominating the scene. To this end
column8: it is most important to highlight when you are not gaining some ground on the respective item
column9: or you start going in circles. While this is a matter of experience and diplomacy
column10: in my perception it is often these situations where you end to step in and suggest to have another - maybe smaller - meeting later to focus on the respective issue. Time in a meeting is shared time
column11: and this should take the interests of all people present into account.

column1: '''7) Meetings are not work sessions.''' Lack of balance links to a common mistake we all face: when a meeting becomes a brainstorming session. This can be ok if a meeting is designated as such
column2: yet more often than not it defeats the purpose of a meeting
column3: and throws the time off balance
column4: and creates an setting that is focused on few people. Brainstorming sessions are already hardly good in a large group and with a generous time budget
column5: but many meetings are even larger
column6: and have limited time available. This makes leadership and facilitation a core challenge. It should be already clarified before the meeting how the meeting will go down
column7: or this can be manifested with a good [[Code of Conduct|code of conduct]] within a team. If it is part of the norms of a group what such meetings are made for and what should be avoided
column8: then you can really gain some ground.

column1: Having clear action items at the end is another often forgotten cornerstone of any successful meeting. While this demands commitment and team spirit
column2: I made very positive experience in a less hierarchical setting
column3: as people do not only feel empowered
column4: but also want to show their worth
column5: especially but not exclusively if you include early career students. Who will do what
column6: and until when? While this seems trivial
column7: it is often moving to the background
column8: and people tend to leave meetings and never think about what was being said or discussed. The best meetings I was in were always the ones that made me think about the next steps
column9: and others as well. A meeting is an exchange of a current status of a a group's thought process
column10: yet time goes on
column11: and so should our thinking. Importantly
column12: complex challenges will evolve over time
column13: and it may take some time to come to conclusions that then translate into the next step. Often
column14: a single meeting is insufficient to make progress
column15: and it takes several meetings to become something good. By showing investment inbetween meetings you may show the participants how valuable the meeting time is for you
column16: and thus value the other people's time best.

column1: '''9) Group identity voids.''' Building team spirit takes time. Put that in a fortune cookie! I remember how when I was young
column2: I felt that these team meetings sometimes waste my time
column3: yet people were patient with me
column4: and in the midrun I learned that building a joint identity does not happen overnight. Especially the informal time spots before and after a meeting are the times that are most relevant. Being part of a larger institution with many diverse meetings can equally help you to establish your profile
column5: and proves to other your value by contributing to the greater good. Not all meetings are sources of instant gratification
column6: and we should always remember how the others feel. Within an ideal meeting
column7: you become a mirror for the other people
column8: and through your reflection they move the agenda forward together. In my experience
column9: people understand your agenda and solutions best when they actually think they came up with them themselves.

column1: '''10) Dare to differ.''' There are quite some established norms and procedures when it comes to meetings
column2: yet it is not always the case that all these things were well planned and designed
column3: but often such settings just kind of happened. While I would always advise you to basically say nothing in a setting where you are new - unless you are leading the meeting - after some sufficient amount of time
column4: maybe some ten meetings
column5: you may want to discuss ideas to improve the setting if need be. Typically you should not raise this in the big group
column6: but instead to the person that has the right ratio of open-mindedness and experience to consider your suggestion. If you are in the right group for you
column7: things may change over time
column8: yet never forget to be patient.

column2: I believe that writing a [[Code of Conduct|code of conduct]] is the single most important step you may consider as a team to build a joint meeting culture. It is good to discuss these things within the group
column3: agree on certain rules
column4: certainly not too many
column5: and then write these down. Nothing will bring you faster and more reliably to a good meeting culture. Always start with why you have the meeting
column6: who is present
column7: and what potential outcomes or goals are. I have one colleague who I greatly admire who starts every meeting like this
column8: guides you gently but diligently through the meeting
column9: and ultimately summarises all conclusions and next steps at the end
column10: and sends you an e-mail about it as a last step. What a difference it would make if we would all find the strengths and stamina to do this!

column1: Another core point worthwhile considering is the different types of meetings we have at our disposal. Most meetings are a handful or more of people
column2: and these should have clear guidance structures
column3: an unbiased facilitation
column4: and a good time management. However
column5: there are other types of exchanges that we should check out in order to differentiate from such ordinary meetings

column1: This setting is the most intense
column2: personal
column3: and focused type of meeting. It also has a great flexibility
column4: which makes it tempting to get distracted
column5: but can also be great to create a joint identity. Being a mentor
column6: it can be great to structure your thoughts beforehand
column7: and to identify tangible goals that you want to reach. Two-person meetings without a goal can often be a pain
column8: and I am often very insistent towards myself to derive goals in such personal settings
column9: if only for myself. Yet we also have to acknowledge that just like any other meeting
column10: such exchanges may build over a longer timeline. Having regular meetings i.e
column11: with PhD students can be a beacon of hope
column12: and are often the most fun. Since such settings are deeply personal
column13: as a mentor I feel you need to adapt to each and every single person. Still
column14: honesty goes a long way. Pushing people out of their comfort zone can be hard
column15: but necessary if you are thriving towards a continuous development. I am often taking notes afterwards
column16: yet try not to come to obviously back to prevoious points in a follow up meeting. Another key point is that within such meeting you may want to focus your attention without any compromises
column17: yet be also clear when it comes to expectations and the time frame. If someone goes into such a meeting with a challenged mindset
column18: you may not shift that within one hour
column19: but it can be good to make that visible
column20: and reflect about it. Things take time.

column1: 2) '''Brain storming sessions''' are an altogether different beast. Here
column2: the timeframe should be more or less long
column3: and you will not necessarily reach tangible goals
column4: but only start to develop ideas and a follow-up structure. Different people act in different ways in such settings
column5: thus adapting speed and making sure that the individual gains are shared is essential. More often than not I get so carried away in such a process that I need to remind myself to regularly check if the other people are still with me. Similarly is it important to clearly indicate if your are lost
column6: or feel disconnected. Brainstorming sessions are about trust and joint identity. A whiteboard is often the key tool
column7: or maybe working in a shared document. I spent a lot of trial and error until I got my brainstorming session to work best for me
column8: and this seems to be a reoccurring challenge among many people. Building experience to this end demands patience.

column1: 3) '''Emergency calls''' can be a lifeline when people are at their wits' end. Within a team
column2: establishing such safety nets that help people that are stuck in their mind can most rewarding
column3: as it catches people when they are most desperate. Asking for help is - sadly - still difficult in our society
column4: yet all the while so important. Often
column5: it already helps to just get it all out to clarify your thought process. Within such situations
column6: a healthy peer-network can be a lifesaver
column7: and often builds on informal structures. Within a team
column8: great care should be thus taken to leave no one behind
column9: and to consciously seek out whether people are stuck or shifting into crisis. Remember that any team is only as strong as its weakest link.

column1: 4) The last meeting type are '''informal meetings'''. The corona crisis exemplified how much we miss the casual exchange in the hall or at a coffee place
column2: often without any goal whatsoever
column3: where suddenly ideas begin to develop. Our team has informal games nights that are often gold for the team spirit at least for some people
column4: and a recent barbecue after a long corona hiatus showed how much a joint evening can do for the team. If there is one part where we still have to learn the most
column5: it is tacit knowledge. There are all sorts of informal meetings
column6: and these are at the heart of institutional knowledge. I consider informal meetings to be most relevant of all
column7: often the most fun
column8: yet hardest to tame and just get right. We all know how it is to be in an informal meeting where do not want to be. Honesty and clear communication goes a long way to this end.

column1: I recognise within our team a great effort to make meetings worth our while. We often differentiate in our meetings how we worked regarding research
column2: teaching and management. These are the three elements that allow us to have a more clear structure in our meetings. Also
column3: I recognise that we have a strong set of norms where new people that join the team are introduced to. Over the last years
column4: a lot of informal knowledge and experience accumulated
column5: which made the meetings continuously better. We have weekly team meetings
column6: project meetings
column7: smaller meetings
column8: informal exchanges
column9: meetings with individual PhDs or Postdocs
column10: mentoring sessions
column11: writing day meetings
column12: and so much more.

column1: I believe that what defines us humans the most is our interconnectedness
column2: and how we want to explore this. The 21st century will be most focused on making a difference to this end
column3: and I look forward to a future where the connections between us will be way more important than the differences that define our individual identities. I invite you to reconsider the way you meet people
column4: and to try out new ways to facilitate meetings. I hope in a not too far future we will all be more versatile to this end
column5: at least this is what I am thriving for.

column1: The [[Table of Contributors|author]] of this entry is Henrik von Wehrden."
The future of statistics?;"'''In short:''' This entry revolves around the future of statistics. Which issues need to be solved
column2: and which role can and should statistical analyses play in science and society in the next years and decades? For more on statistics
column3: please refer to this [[Statistics|overview page]].

column1: ==What will be the future of statistics?==
Quite some people apply statistics these days
column2: and it has become a staple of many diverse branches within science. However
column3: [[Limitations of Statistics|critical perspectives]] increased as well over the last decades
column4: and the computer revolution and the vast increase of peer-reviewed publications triggered a diversification in statistics. Sadly
column5: the critical perspective is often a more of an add-on or afterthought
column6: or settles into universal rejection
column7: but has hardly triggered a deeper critical reflection or even revolution within statistics and the people who apply it regularly. '''Because of this
column8: the benefits of these critical perspectives are often restricted to some few branches of science
column9: or to a level of theory of science
column10: yet do not translate into the empirical knowledge production where statistics is still so pivotal.''' The increasing diversity of statistics as such has also increased the mess
column11: as it led to a increasing loss of linguistic coherence in the diverse disciplines
column12: and led to developments where knowledge production or the testing of theories is relying on a small canon of statistical methods.

column1: Statistics hence added to the ever-spiraling specialisation of the scientific disciplines
column2: and contributed to the demise of the old kingdoms. This is reflected in the role that statistics have played [[History of Methods|in the 20th century and even before]]
column3: where the analytical view on numbers was a willing accomplice to the injustices and inequalities of human thriving. The current culture wars are a reflection of these same unsolved problems where statistics contributed to
column4: yet there is hope for the future. Statistics may be able to contribute to a better world for all people
column5: but we need to overcome several struggles that are within the branch of statistics itself
column6: within science
column7: and in the contribution that statistics through science can have [[Scientific methods and societal paradigms|towards society.]]

column2: I will propose my current view on how statistics may evolve in the future
column3: how statistics may grow up into something better
column4: and how it shall overcome the haunting  problems it faces today. This text will thus first look at the future developments within statistics
column5: trying to anticipate what could happen to evolve the arena of statistics. The second section will critically examine the role of statistics across disciplines
column6: and which problems may be solved in the future. The last section will paint a picture of the future contributions of an evolved arena of statistics and its role in society. It is in the nature of this endeavour that this text is not only offering a highly subjective [[Glossary|vision]]
column7: but also a bold one. However
column8: since next to no one dares to dream about the future of statistics
column9: I shall give it a try.

column1: The question I get asked the most as a statistician is: '''How much does the model explain
column2: and is that good or bad?''' Of course this is a loaded question that cannot be answered. Imagine the following example. You are terminally ill
column3: and the doctors told you to settle your affairs. Suddenly a cure for your condition is discovered
column4: but it only cures 10% of all patients. Do you take the shot? Sure you will. Now imagine you are in a different setting. You are perfectly healthy while planning your travels to the town of Samarra. Suddenly
column5: Death knocks on your door
column6: and tells you that you have a 10% chance of dying if you travel to Samarra. Would you follow through with your travel plans? Most certainly not. Yet one time you have a slim chance of survival
column7: and the other time you have a slim chance of dying
column8: which is also at 10 %. This highlights that the validation criterion of [[A matter of probability|probability]] is context-dependent. Thus
column9: instead of focussing on absolute criteria
column10: relative context-dependent criteria seem more helpful. While [[Bayesian Inference|Bayesian statistics]] would in theory bring us much closer to such a relative measure
column11: it still relies on validation criteria familiar from frequentist statistics. Still
column12: Bayes theorem may pose an answer for a relative validation criteria. Unfortunately
column13: this would demand everybody to understand Bayesian statistics
column14: which is where we may talk about the rather distant future.

column2: today
column3: there is a tendency to use more [[Agency
column4: Complexity and Emergence|complex]] models as a sells pitch
column5: as well as too simple models due to lack of experience. In the long run however
column6: knowledge and experience may spread
column7: and people may use the most appropriate models. '''I think a starting point for this will be pursuing different models at the same time
column8: not in an ensemble way where the model results are put together and averaged
column9: but in a reflexive way.''' Imagine I see a weather development that may have ramifications for the nomads in an area
column10: being a foreshadow of a drought that may affect their livestock. I could not use [[Regression Analysis|simple linear models]]
column11: which would not help me to grapple such an extreme event
column12: but would allow me to see some long-term trend statistics and get some explanation of what might happen in terms of the big picture. Then I might focus with a finer grain on the actual weather data right now
column13: comparing climate and weather in a nested way
column14: using non-linear statistics to focus on the actual prediction. Next
column15: I could ask myself what happens if I take a fresh look
column16: using a Bayesian approach to allow myself to only grapple the current data with real time updates. All these models unravel different aspects of the same phenomena
column17: yet today -more often than not - statistics decide for one way of analysis
column18: or combine all ways (e.g. ensemble models) as an average. Yet I propose that much knowledge is like an onion
column19: and [[Statistics and mixed methods|different statistical models]] can help us to peel of the different layers.

column1: Much of the knowledge that science produces is driven by scientific demand
column2: and this can be a good thing. However
column3: our growth-driven economy shows the catastrophic shortcoming of a line of thinking that focuses on one aspect of knowledge
column4: all the while actively rejecting or denying other parts of knowledge or reality. '''Empirical knowledge depends on the questions we ask.''' A manager of an organisation that attempts to maximise their profits may or may not ask the right questions for their goal
column5: as focussing on growth may be the main reason for the organisation's demise or prosperity in the future. To the manager
column6: focusing on growth seems plausible
column7: so they pursue it. If it is reasonable
column8: they might misjudge. Plausibility is closely linked by definition with people being reasonable
column9: and plausible questions have some probability of being worthwhile our investigation. Following Larry Laudan
column10: however
column11: it is clear that scientists of the past were not always reasonable. Larry Laudan thought that many events and discoveries in the history of science were not as rational or reasonable as we think these scientific discoveries were. Future changes such as a more tightly-knit exchange culture in science or more pronounced ethical checks of research proposals may foster more plausible research questions
column12: but this may not the right way to more plausible research questions. Instead
column13: society may shift in the future
column14: and people may just not come to the conclusion to investigate questions that are implausible. This may sound like a very distant future
column15: but if we compare us today to people or even researchers 100 years ago or even 500 year ago
column16: it become clear that we already came a long way
column17: and shall go on.

column1: Statistics was born out of the urge to understand and control system dynamics
column2: partly with a purely non-materialistic focus such as in Astronomy - a motor of early statistics - or with a total focus on materialistic gain
column3: as was the case in early econometrics. With the rise of the Internet
column4: our inflict of data increased at an exponential pace - following Moore's law - triggering both positive but also devastating effect on the global dynamics we witness today. '''Access to information has become on of the most important privilege people have today
column5: and much has been gained
column6: but much was also lost in translation.''' Examples such as information spreading from activists showcase what can be gained
column7: yet terrorists and insurgents are coordinating themselves equally in the digital age. Data security is stronger shifting into the focus of societal debate
column8: but we are far away from real data security
column9: and in many aspects seemingly only a step away from a Black Mirror episode. All the while is is clear that we have no idea of which [[To Rule And To Measure|types of data]] may be available in the future. Movement patterns of elderly risk patients can predict a risk of a heart attack weeks before it would actually happen. Research can trigger a tilt towards fairer income distribution
column10: or support the notion of a universal basic income. Detection systems of weather
column11: oceans and the upper crust of Earth may prevent countless losses of life in in case of disasters. However
column12: all these examples are still connected to our reality today
column13: and we have to assume that future people will utilise data in ways that will be hard to imagine for us today.

column2: Complexity and Emergence|Complexity]] is almost like a holy grail in terms of current debates about system dynamics
column3: because many use complexity either as an argument why change might happen
column4: or to underline our limitations in understanding system dynamics. I believe that both lines of thinking are capital mistakes
column5: as they may lead to false argumentations or to inaction in investigating system dynamics. What is complex for us may be simple to future people. Also
column6: while there will most likely always be dynamics or patterns that we do not understand
column7: in the future we may have mapped out which dynamics can be understood
column8: and which dynamics follow other principles such as chaos theory
column9: and can thus not be predicted. '''Complexity is not an ontological truth
column10: but a buzzword that frames our current limitations.''' Once we have mapped out what we cannot understand
column11: we will be much better able to act within the remaining rest of reality. Many people frame complexity and knowledge about it right now as a privilege
column12: which they have access to
column13: but other people do not. I can declare something to be complex
column14: and thus mark this pattern to be not understandable. A good example are weather dynamics
column15: which beyond a certain time window become unpredictable. While our current thinking dictates us that this will always be the case
column16: we are different people today than we were once more 100 years ago. We have weather forecasts
column17: ensemble models
column18: satellites in orbit
column19: and many means to at least predict the weather for the next 1-2 weeks
column20: which would have been unthinkable at a planetary scale some centuries ago.

column1: The gap between [[Causality and correlation|causal links]] and predictive pattern detection is one of the largest missed opportunity of statistics to establish a proper link to philosophy. While many philosophers such as Hume explored matters of causality deeply
column2: this is still widely ignored in large parts of the everyday life of research. The unlocking of [[Machine Learning|machine learning]] and associated analytics even led to an outright rejection of any causal link
column3: focussing on prediction instead. This can be a good thing
column4: as a life saved through a good prediction is surely better than a life being lost
column5: yet a post mortem helps us to understand why the person died. Anyone would surely prefer a life based on a blur prediction
column6: compared to an explainable death. Mapping out this difference is of pivotal importance
column7: because prediction can inform us so that we may decide how to act
column8: yet causal explanation can help us understand why we should act. '''Causality is thus key to decisions and intentional acts.''' Without causality
column9: we may be doomed to act based on our external senses alone
column10: or on a prediction of some machine
column11: yet it is our reflection based on causal information that may give our actions meaning and reason. It is part of human nature that some of our actions may always be not explainable
column12: and it is part of statistics that some patterns and mechanisms will never be explainable. Still
column13: a proper embedding of causal information and how we define may give us reasons to act
column14: and not only our actions matter
column15: as well as reason alone does not matter
column16: but the combination of acting reasonable based on causal information may matter deeply.

column1: Untangling the crisis of Western science for good is like the moonshot on this list. The perceived [[Bias in statistics|ghost of positivism]] that is still haunting us to this day
column2: and the counter-revolutionary movements that emerged out of it triggered a division that left much of current research still being stuck in an illusion of objectivism
column3: while some are lost in their maze of universal rejection or critical reflection. '''Critical realism with its subjective view of scientific knowledge
column4: and its possibility for ontological truths still being out there
column5: may have solved the current dilemmas of theory of science.''' Unfortunately
column6: most researcher are not aware of this
column7: or reject or ignore it. The errors of the past
column8: and the [[Bias in statistics|biases]] these errors create inside of us as individuals as well as within the scientific community deserve a critical perspective on science. Equally
column9: we need to create knowledge to continue the path of this human civilization
column10: since we unleashed many wicked problems that need to be solved. Otherwise all may be in vain
column11: and science needs to acknowledge that. Statistics is probably one of the branches of science that is furthest away from critical realism
column12: yet if we change our education systems to enable a reflexive humanism as a baseline for our education
column13: I cannot see why critical realism should not spread
column14: and ultimately prevail. From a current viewpoint
column15: it looks like our best ticket to the moon
column16: and beyond.

column1: Scientific disciplines are a testimony of the oppressive evolving of science out of the [[History of Methods|Enlightenment]]
column2: leading to silos of knowledge that we call scientific discipline. '''While it is clear that this minimises the chances of a more holistic knowledge production
column3: scientific disciplines are still necessary from a perspective of depth of knowledge.''' Medicine is a good example where most researchers are highly specialised
column4: because there is hardly any other way to contribute to the continuous evolution of knowledge. We may thus conclude that focus in itself is necessary
column5: and often helpful. There are however also other factors about the existence of scientific disciplines that are important to raise. First of all
column6: scientific disciplines are in a fight about priorities of knowledge and interpretation. Many disciplines claim that their knowledge is indeed of a higher value than the knowledge of the other discipline. It is clear that this notion needs to be rejected once we take a step back and look at the whole picture
column7: since such claims of superiority do not make any sense. Yet from a perspective of [[Bias and Critical Thinking|critical realism]]
column8: one could claim that ethics and maybe even philosophy are on a different level
column9: because the can transcend epistemological perspective
column10: and may even create ontological truths. While other disciplines thus vanish in the future
column11: philosophy
column12: and more importantly [[Ethics and Statistics|ethics]]
column13: are about our responsibility as researchers
column14: and may thus play a pivotal role. I would propose that statistics could contribute to this end
column15: because statistics is at its heart not disciplinary. Instead
column16: statistics could provide a reflexive link between different domains of knowledge
column17: despite it being almost in an opposite position today
column18: since statistics is often the methodological dogma of many scientific disciplines.

column1: Statistics today is stuck between a rock and a hard place. Statistics can help to test hypotheses
column2: leading to a accepting or rejection of our questions that are rooted in our theories
column3: making [[:Category:Deductive|deductive]] research often rigid and incremental. At the extreme opposite end
column4: there is the [[:Category:Inductive|inductive]] line of thinking
column5: which claims an open mind independent of theory
column6: yet often still looks at the world through the lens of a theoretical foundation. '''Science builds on theory
column7: yet the same theories can also lock us into a partial view of the world.''' This is not necessarily bad
column8: yet the divide between inductive and deductive approaches has been haunting statistics just as many other branches of science. Some approaches in statistics almost entirely depend on deductive thinking
column9: such as the [[ANOVA]]. Other approaches such as [[Clustering Methods|cluster analysis]] are widely inductive. However
column10: all these different analyses can be used both in inductive and deductive fashion
column11: and indeed they are. No wonder that statistics created great confusion. The ANOVA for example was a breakthrough in psychological research
column12: yet the failure to reproduce many experiments highlights the limitations of the theories that are being pursued. Equal challenges can be raised for ecology
column13: economy
column14: and many other empirical branches of science. Only when we understand that our diverse theories offer mere partial explanations
column15: shall these theories be settled in their proper places.

column1: '''[[Bias and Critical Thinking|Bias]] has been haunting research from the very beginning
column2: because all humans are biased.''' Statistics has learned to quantify or even overcome some biases
column3: for instance the one related to sampling or analysis are increasingly tamed. However
column4: there are many more biases out there
column5: and to this day most branches of science only had a rather singular focus on biases. In the future we may pool our knowledge and build on wider experience
column6: and may learn to better reflect our biases
column7: and through transparency and open communication
column8: we may thus reduce them. It seems more than unclear how we will do this
column9: but much is to be gained.

column1: '''How can we compare different dimensions of knowledge?''' To give an example
column2: how much worth in coin is courage? Or my future happiness? Can such things be compared
column3: and evaluated? Derek Parfit wrote that we are irrational in the way how we value the distant future less as compared to the presence
column4: even if we take the likelihood of this distant future becoming a reality into account. This phenomenon is called temporal discounting. Humans are strangely incapable of such comparisons
column5: yet statistics have opened a door into a comparability that allows to unravel a new understanding of the comparisons in our head with other comparisons
column6: or in other words
column7: to contextualise our perspectives. Temporal discounting is already today playing less of a role because of teleconnections and global market chains. What would however be more important
column8: is if people gained - through statistics - a deeper insight into their existence compared to everybody else. Such a radical contextualisation of ourselves would surely change our perspective on our role in the world.

column1: While frequentist statistics evolve around [[A matter of probability|probability]]
column2: there are other ways to calculate the value of models. Information theory is - in a nutshell - already focusing on diverse approaches to evaluate information gained through statistical analysis. The shortcoming of [[Simple Statistical Tests|p-values]] have been increasingly moved in the focus during the last one or two decades
column3: yet we are far away from alternative approaches (e.g. AIC) being either established or accepted. Instead
column4: statistics are scattered when it comes to analysis pathways
column5: and model reduction is currently at least in the everyday application of statistics still closer to philosophy than our way of conducting statistics. The 20th century was somewhat reigned by numbers
column6: and probability was what more often than not helped to evaluate the numbers. New approaches are emerging
column7: and probability and other measures may be part of the curriculum of high school students in the future
column8: leaving the more advanced stuff that we have no idea about today to higher education.

column1: ==The future contribution of statistics to society==
It is highly likely to assume that even advanced statistics may become part of the education of young schoolchildren. After all
column2: today's curriculum is vastly different from what was taught 100 years ago. Statistics could be one stepping stone towards a world with a higher level of reflection
column3: where more and more people can make up their own mind based on the data
column4: and can take reflected decisions based on the information available. '''Inequalities can only be diminished if they are visible
column5: and statistics are one viewpoint that can help to this end
column6: not as a universal answer
column7: but as part of the picture.''' The COVID-19 pandemic has shown how the demand for data
column8: patterns and mechanism went through the roof
column9: and more people got into the data and analysis
column10: and acted accordingly - given that they had the capability. The greatest opportunity of a more dispersed statistical education is surely within other cultures. While Europe and North America are widely governed by knowledge gained from statistics
column11: much could be learned ensuring these approaches with different knowledge from other cultures. We only started to unravel the diversities of knowledge that is out there. Statistics may also be a staple in the future
column12: yet knowledge become more exciting if it is combined with other knowledge.

column1: In order to become able to meaningfully contribute to a societal as well as cross-cultural dialogue and joined learning
column2: statistics would need to learn better ways to tell stories. '''Ultimately
column3: it is joint stories that create identity and unite people.''' We should not be foolish and consider a so-called ""objective"" worldview propelled by statistics to be a meaningful goal
column4: because this would surely deprive us of many dimensions of cultural diversity. Instead
column5: statistics needs to emerge into an arena that can tell stories through data
column6: and engage people
column7: and thus help to create identities that are reflexive
column8: immersive and ultimately aimed at understanding different perspectives. If statistics became less about privileged knowledge and instead take the understanding of all people as a baseline
column9: we would have an ambitious yet tangible long-term goal.

column2: the general understanding of statistics is vastly different. '''Few people actually understand statistics
column3: and often this is the small privileged group being able to get a higher education.''' If statistics is presented
column4: then most people do not understand it
column5: or understand only parts. Gaining a broader understanding about the different valuations of statistical results is hardly ever done in a societal debate
column6: hence citizens rely on the translation and condensation by the media. In the future
column7: qualifying statements that allow for a contextual understanding of statistics shall be commonplace
column8: and more efforts need to go into building a broader understanding what this actually means. Selective presentation of statistics will be a mistake of the past.

column2: the selective presentation of statistics is part of our current reality. The media
column3: politicians and other institutions present statistics often in a partial form to literally sell their view of the world. More often than not
column4: a look at the whole data or other sources reveals a different picture - not just in nuances
column5: but altogether different and sometimes even reversed. '''Much of the information that is ultimately presented publicly is designed to be palatable and to divide people.''' While there is surely a lot of good journalism already out there
column6: much information is wrong
column7: and political wars are waged about selling information
column8: and how to utilise the partial realities for a political agenda. The Internet
column9: which was originally set to realise the vision of global knowledge exchange
column10: became a breeding ground for the great divide we currently face. We need to return to the vision of a free information flow
column11: and educate people
column12: and allow them to form their own picture
column13: maybe even without the media as mediators.

column1: Much of the current conflicts are about resources
column2: albeit often indirectly. Statistics enables or fuels these conflicts
column3: as it allows for comparisons that ultimately have a utilitarianism purpose
column4: often for an in-group
column5: thereby excluding other people that are designated as out-groups. Hence statistics are - besides cultural identities - one of the origin points of current conflicts. This may change in the future. Resources may become less sparse
column6: i.e. through a different harnessing of energy. If we were not limited by energy constraints
column7: many conflicts might be overcome. Equally
column8: future societies may avoid singular aims of materialistic values
column9: consumption and growth-driven economies. This would tilt the way statistics is embedded into society
column10: yet would certainly make it not less important. '''Instead
column11: statistics would shift to brighten our knowledge
column12: instead of fueling inequalities.'''

column1: Fundamental for overcoming inequalities between different people would be a different mode of transparency when it comes to data security
column2: as well as the way people demand data
column3: depend on it
column4: and ultimately utilise it. '''''Power to the people'' is from this viewpoint not enough: we also need to give data and means of analysis to the people.''' Consequently
column5: people also need to raise the question which data they need to reflect and take decisions. Which data is being created is right now decided by a small elite of people
column6: thereby excluding the vast majority of people. This could be changed already now
column7: since more data is being created by the people thanks to smartphones
column8: the Internet and other technology. This data should however not be used to manipulate people
column9: but to empower them. Incredible amounts of data can be expected in the future
column10: and science needs to work with citizens to focus on the data that is most needed to overcome the problems we may still face
column11: and the solutions we need.

column1: Much of the bad reputation within statistics is because it is hardly explained what statistics cannot do. Today
column2: much emphasis in the media is put on what statistics can do
column3: and remarkably often
column4: the media does not get the point. To this end
column5: limitations are not about individual statistics and results
column6: but are about [[Limitations of Statistics|statistics in general]]. We know for instance that some statistical tests and models reveal different results than other models. All models are wrong
column7: some models are useful. '''Society needs to understand and learn the value of statistics
column8: but also the limitations.''' Otherwise
column9: populistic leaders will continue to devalue statistics with clever selective criticism rooted in the fear of some voters. It is in the nature of science that scientific results change
column10: and nothing else can be expected from statistics.

column1: Changing statistical results may be one of the greatest changes we shall see in the future. Up until the recent past
column2: much of statistical results that are presented are temporal slices. However
column3: there is an increasing temporal continuity being merged by dashboards in the Internet
column4: leading to ever-changing results
column5: which often gain in precision. '''Constant updates in statistical data and analysis will in the future enable us better and better to react to changes and anticipate challenges.''' Through an integrated data continuity
column6: we will finally come to a view that does justice to the world
column7: with little more fix points beside our cultural identity and our moral principles. Anything beyond this may be a constant fluctuation of data
column8: which is nothing but a testimony of the interconnectedness of all people. This will not only enable new information age
column9: but ultimately lead to a different dominion of insights
column10: where we leave much of the static worldview that still closes in on us
column11: and even traps us
column12: today. Instead
column13: we will become relative dots of information in space and time
column14: where the interconnections between us are what ultimately matters
column15: and we are able to see and feel this more than ever before.

column2: yet some say that much is lost. Derek Parfit claimed that the future could be wonderful
column3: and I would agree. We may - to follow Dereks line of thinking- not be able to imagine how future humans might be
column4: act and think. '''However
column5: it is hard to imagine a future of humanity where numbers do not matter at all.''' For all I care
column6: they may matter less - proportionally - but will still be important.

column2: there is another aspect to it. '''Statistics could even contribute to make us more free.''' If you make hundreds of models that all show you patterns and mechanisms of diverse data sets
column3: yet also show you that there are always limitations
column4: and there will always be unexplained variance
column5: this may even be able tilt your worldview. Seeing order in the chaos
column6: finding patterns
column7: unlocking mechanisms
column8: and ultimately also mapping the limitations of our knowledge may be a step from knowledge to experience that can change us as a people
column9: at least this is my naive hope. Many aspects I raised here seem to be unrealistic
column10: or at least far-fetched. To this end
column11: I would always consider how we were 100 years ago. What did we know about statistics? What about reason? What was causal knowledge back then? And how was the situation some 500 years ago? [[History of Methods|Or 2000 years ago?]] We have changed dramatically over the past decades and centuries
column12: and out trajectory of change is on an exponential path right now. Who knows how it will go on
column13: but I will always settle for hope. I am all with Martha Nussbaum on this one: “Hope really is a choice
column14: and a practical habit.”

column1: The [[Table of Contributors|author]] of this entry is Henrik von Wehrden."
The great statistics recap;"'''Annotation:''' This entry concludes the Introductory class on statistics for Bachelor students at Leuphana. It is not an autonomous entry on its own.

column2: we focused on learning simple statistics. '''Understanding basic [[Descriptive statistics|descriptive statistics]] allows us to calculate averages
column3: sums and many other measures that help us grasp the essentials about certain data.''' [[Data formats]] are essential in order to understand the diverse forms that data can take. We learned that all data is constructed
column4: which becomes most apparent when looking at [[To Rule And To Measure|indicators]] which can tell some story
column5: yet without deeper knowledge about the construction - i.e.
column6: the context of an indicator - it is hard to grasp.

column1: Once you get a hold of the diverse data formats
column2: you can see then how data can represent different [[Data distribution|distributions]]. While much quantitative data is normally distributed
column3: there are also exceptions
column4: such as discrete data of phenomena that can be counted that is often showing a skewed distribution. Within frequentists statistics
column5: statistical distributions are key
column6: because these allow form a statistical standpoint to [[Experiments and Hypothesis Testing|test hypotheses]]. '''You assume that data follows a certain distribution
column7: and that is often one important preconditions for the test or model you want to conduct.''' Whether your data then shows non-random patterns
column8: but whether a hypothesis can actually be accepted or rejected
column9: depends actually more often than not on the p-value. This value is the calculation whether your results are random and follow mere chance
column10: of whether there is a significant pattern that you tested for. This is at its core what frequentist statistics are all about.

column1: The most [[Simple Statistical Tests|simple tests]] can test for counts of groups within two variables (chi-square test)
column2: comparisons of two distributions (f-test) and the comparison of the mean values of two samples of a variables (t-test). Other tests avoid the question of statistical distribution by breaking the data into ranks
column3: which are however less often applied (Wilcoxon test). '''A breakthrough in statistics was the development of the [[Correlations|correlation]]
column4: which allows to test whether two continuous datasets are meaningfully related.''' If one of the variables increases
column5: the other variable increases as well
column6: which would be a positive correlation. If one variable increases
column7: and the other one decreases
column8: we speak of a negative correlation. The strength of this relation is summarised by the correlation coefficient
column9: which ranges from -1 to 1
column10: and a values furthest from 0 indicates a strong relation
column11: while 0 basically indicates complete randomness in the relation. This is tested again by p-values
column12: where once more a values smaller than 0.05 indicates a non-random relation
column13: which in statistics is called a significant relation.

column1: While correlation opened Pandoras box of statistics
column2: it also raised a great confusion concerning the question whether a relation is [[Causality and correlation|causal]] or not. There are clear criteria that indicate causality
column3: such as similarity in features of phenomena that have the same effect onto a variable. '''In order to statistically test for causal relations
column4: [[Regression Analysis|regressions]] were developed.''' Regressions check for relations between variables
column5: but revolve around a logical connection between these variables to allow for causal inferences. In addition
column6: they allow to test not only the relation of one continuous variable in relation to another dependent variable. Instead
column7: several independent variables can be tested
column8: thus allowing to build more complex models and test more advanced hypotheses. Again
column9: the relation is indicated to be significant by the p-value. However
column10: the strength of the model is not measured in a coefficient
column11: but instead in the r-square value
column12: which is the sum of squares of the individual data points distance from the regression line. A regression line is hence the line that represents the regression model
column13: which best explains the relation between the dependent and independent variable(s).

column1: While regressions were originally designed to test for clear hypotheses
column2: these models are today utilised under diverse contexts
column3: even in [[:Category:Inductive|inductive]] research
column4: thereby creating tensions when it comes to the interpretation of the model results. A significant regression does not necessarily indicate a causal relation. This is a matter of the [[Normativity of Methods|normativity]] of the respective branch within science
column5: and ultimately
column6: also a question of philosophy of science. This is comparable to the [[ANOVA|analysis of variance]] (ANOVA)
column7: which unleashed the potential to conduct [[experiments]]
column8: starting in agricultural research
column9: yet quickly finding its way into psychology
column10: biology
column11: medicine and many other areas in science. '''The ANOVA allows to compare several groups in terms of their mean values
column12: and even to test for interaction between different independent variables.''' The strength of the model can be approximated by the amount of explained variance
column13: and the p-value indicates whether the different groups within the independent variables differ overall. One can however also test whether one groups differs from another groups
column14: thus comparing all groups individually by means of a posthoc test (e.g. Tukey).

column2: great care needs to be taken to have sufficient samples to allow for a critical interpretation of the results. Subsequently
column3: ANOVA experiments became more complex
column4: combining several independent variables and also allowing to correct for so called random factors
column5: which are elements for which the variance is calculated out of the ANOVA model. This allows for instance to increase the sample size to minimise the effects of the variance in an agricultural experiment which is being conducted on several agricultural fields. In this example
column6: agricultural fields are then included as block factor
column7: which allows to minimise the variance inferred by these replications. Hence
column8: the variance of the agricultural fields is tamed by a higher number of replicates. This led to the ANOVA becoming one of the most relevant methods in statistics
column9: yet recent developments such as the reproducibility crisis in psychology highlight that care needs to be taken to not overplay ones hand. Preregistering hypotheses and more recognition of the [[Limitations of Statistics|limitations]] of such designs currently pave a path towards a more critical future of statistical designs.

column1: Another development that emerged during the last decades is the conducting of so called real-world experiments
column2: which are often singular case studies with interventions
column3: yet typically less or no control of variables. These approaches are slowly being developed in diverse branches of research
column4: and allow to open a [[Meta-Analysis|meta-analytical]] dimension
column5: where a high number of case studies is averaged in terms of the research results. The combination of different studies enables a different perspective
column6: yet currently such approaches are either restricted to rigid clinical trials or to meta-analyses with more variables than cases.

column1: Real-world experiments are thus slowly emerging to bridge experimental rigour with the often perceived messiness of the problems we face and how we engage with them as researchers
column2: knowing that one key answer involving these is the joint learning together with stakeholders. This development may allow us to move one step further in current [[System Thinking & Causal Loop Diagrams|systems thinking]]
column3: where still many phenomena we cannot explained are simply labeled as complex. We will have to acknowledge in the future which phenomena we may begin to understand in the future

column1: Everything up until now was only pretext
column2: and now we come to the real deal: Coding. Writing code in R is like writing a language. You have dialects
column3: different capabilities of the tongue
column4: and even these little minute details that make us all different when we write and talk. '''You need to find your own way of writing code in R
column5: ''' yet there are many suggestions and norms how people write code in R. Generally
column6: when thinking in code
column7: I thinking in a nested structure of at least four different levels: 1) Scripts
column8: 2) Sections
column9: 3) Lines and 4) Commands. Let's break these down individually.

column1: You should develop a clear procedure how you name your files. If they have the name of the folder they are in
column2: it does not make any sense. If they all have the same name within each folder
column3: it also does not make any sense. Searching your hard drive for the ""main_analysis"" file will not bring you anywhere
column4: if you call the central file like this in every folder. I tend to name it after the different steps of methods
column5: which could be as an example data preparation and the project name ""data_prep_gobi_plant_diversity"". It can be good to add a timestamp
column6: which should be something other than the date you last saved within the file
column7: because this information is anyway available. I tend to just label files into starting
column8: pending and finished.

column2: I always have the same structure. I start with all libraries I need to load
column3: and then continue with the data I am loading. Then I proceed with data preparations and reformatting. The typical next steps are initial data inspection commands
column4: often intermingled with some simple plots that serve more as a data inspection. Then I shift to deeper analysis
column5: and also to some final plots. It is important to label every section with a hashtag-label-structure
column6: and to divide the sections by some empty lines. I often tend to copy code towards the end of the script if it has proven to be important in the beginning but then maybe shifted out of the main focus. Sometimes you wish you could go back
column7: which why it can be helpful to keep different versions of your base code. In this case
column8: I recommend that you save the files with the date
column9: since names just as ""test""
column10: ""test_again""
column11: ""once_more""
column12: ""nonsense""
column13: ""shit""
column14: ""shitoncemore""
column15: ""nowreally""
column16: ""andagain"" have proven to be emotionally fulfilling at first
column17: but confusing down the road.

column1: What is most relevant to me within the script is to clearly indicate open steps if you need to take a break
column2: or want to continue to code later. Writing a little line to your future self can be really helpful. Also
column3: clearly describe all steps that were part of your final report or publication. You may think you remember all this
column4: but if you need to redo an analysis after you get a revision for a manuscript
column5: you might not remember what you did six months ago. Some label which code creates which figure - this can be essential to avoid this challenge. Lastly
column6: write into the Code which version you used
column7: and when you last updated R. At rare occasions packages change
column8: and sometimes even the analysis may reveal different [[Glossary|patterns]]. While this may sound alarming
column9: this is a normal process of science evolving. So far
column10: this has happened three times to me
column11: but I can clearly state that these three occasions were all very special in their own wonderful way.

column1: A last word on the length of one script. I think every script should be like a poem
column2: and thus should be longer than a Haiku
column3: but shorter than - say - a thousand lines. If the code is too long
column4: you will have trouble finding things. Even the two longest scripts I ever complied did not exceed a thousand lines. However
column5: if this may be the case
column6: build a nested structure
column7: and try to divide the code into data crunching
column8: analysis and plotting
column9: or other steps. Make your code like a poem
column10: hence it should not be too long
column11: and it should be elegant. Take this advice from someone who could not be further away from an elegant code. More on this later.

column1: I already mentioned to label all different code sections. However
column2: we should not forget about the poetry of the code itself.

column1: '''Different sections in code are like different verses in a poem.''' They should be consistent
column2: and contain some inner logic and flow. As I already mentioned
column3: each section should have a label line that describes what the section is about. I try to balance sections
column4: and when they get too long
column5: I divide them into different sections. This is however less guided by their lengths
column6: but more by the density of information they contain. If a section is long
column7: but repetitive
column8: it is ok as the information density is comparable to shorter sections that are more complicated. I guess everybody needs to find their own rhyme scheme. Nothing would be worse than if we all coded the same way
column9: as [[Glossary|innovation]] might become less and less. Therefore
column10: I propose you experiment with your section composition
column11: and try to find your own style. This is also the part where one can learn much from other people. Their solutions might give you a better diversity of approaches that you can integrate for yourself. If you have repeated structures in your code
column12: it might be good to find a way to keep repeating sections in a way that makes it easy to adapt whenever necessary. Using tabs to make nested structures can be very helpful to define an inner logic on how sections are nested within each other. For instance
column13: you can have the larger steps as main tabs
column14: smaller subsection with one tab
column15: and then within that individual steps with 2 tabs. Sections are the unit of code that can be quickly exchanged between people
column16: as it is often enough to understand what this specific step is about
column17: yet not too long so that it takes too long to understand everything. Hence exchange code snippets with others to get feedback
column18: and to learn from each other. A really elegant section of code can be like a Haiku.

column1: While it is easy to label sections with hashtags
column2: and you may add an explanation to a line of code
column3: this is only advisable if it is short and not self-explanatory. If you want to add a hashtag explanation to every line
column4: it would probably look a bit clumsy. What is however often the case is that lines become too long. Personally
column5: I think this should be avoided. Some graphic command may go over several lines
column6: but then it is about specifications
column7: and these should become part of your intuitive understanding in the long run. However
column8: many learners want to show off in the beginning and make super long code lines
column9: and these are hard to grasp for others
column10: and also for you after a long time. Try to contain your lines
column11: so they do not become dragons. Code lines are like poetry - they should make sense instantly. '''I think a good line solves exactly one problem.''' Also
column12: a good line should look effortless. Try not to impress anyone
column13: least yourself. You need to find your own rhyme scheme and rhythm
column14: but lines should ideally flow in the long run. You might need to reconsider and think every now and then
column15: but the majority of your lines should be part of your repertoire.

column2: R can be learned and has different dialects and accents. Just as there are wonderful words such as Serendipity and bamboozlement in the English language
column3: there are fantastic words in R. You need to become a connoisseur of R commands and specifications. Many of the lesser important arguments can be the most relevant ones for shortcuts
column4: and a loop or a reduction can bring you a long way when doing repetitive tasks. There are differences in terms of grammar
column5: which often also depend on packages. However
column6: especially data crunching is something where a small loophole can bring you a long way. Luckily
column7: today there are many many resources in the Internet

column1: There is also much new knowledge that is evolving
column2: as data science is a thriving arena. Being versatile in the basics is one thing
column3: but a true master in data science needs to equally rely on the ancients as well as the revolutionary renegades. They all offer knowledge
column4: and we should perceive their knowledge and experience as pure gold that is potentially true. Some methods are established
column5: and it is a good thing to know these. Other methods are evolving
column6: and it is equally good to know the latest tricks and developments. Much [[Glossary|creativity]] however comes from also combining the old and the new schools of thinking. Innovation within scientific methods is often rooted in the combination of different scientific methods. These unlock different types of knowledge
column7: and this can be seen as often appropriate to acknowledge the complexity within many datasets. Combination of approaches is the path to new knowledge
column8: and new knowledge is what we need these days quite often
column9: since the old knowledge has not solved the problems we face
column10: and new problems are emerging. When you want to approximate solutions to these problems
column11: you have to be like water.

column1: Non-duality in data science relates to the difference between predictive power and explanatory power. Any given dataset can be seen from these two perspectives
column2: and equally from none of these perspectives. This is what non-duality of data science is all about. You need to learn to see both in data
column3: and also none. Predictive power and explanatory power are one and the same
column4: and they are not. As the ancients said
column5: it is bad if one thing becomes two. The same is true for data analysis. Many guide their analysis through predictive power
column6: and they become obsessed by the desire to have what they call ""the best model"". Thoughts on the goodness of fit circulate in their heads like wild dragons
column7: and they never manage to see anything but the best model they can possibly achieve
column8: and hence they fail. Many compromises have been made by people to find the best model
column9: and sadly
column10: the best model may never be found. As the Ancient Ones said: '''all models are wrong
