column1: '''The Thought Experiment may well be the oldest scientific method.''' The consideration of potential futures was a vital step when our distant ancestors emancipated themselves and became humans. Asking themselves the ''What if'' questions was a vital step in the dawn of humankind
column2: and both in the West and the East many of the first thinkers are known to have engaged in Thought Experiments. Methodologically
column3: Thought Experiments provide a link between the metaphysical - or philosophy - and the natural world - i.e. natural sciences. Ancient Greece as well as Buddhism and Hinduism are full of early examples of Thought Experiments. Aristoteles remains a first vital step in the West
column4: and after a long but slow growth of the importance of the methods
column5: he represents a bridge into the early [[History of Methods|enlightenment]]. Galileo and Newton are early examples of famous Thought Experiments that connect theoretical considerations with a systematic reflection of the natural world. This generation of more generalisable laws was more transgressed with the ''Origin of Species'' by Charles Darwin. This theory was initially one epic Thought Experiment
column6: and although DNA initially confirmed it
column7: the role of epigenetics was another step that proved rather problematic for Darwinism. Mach introduced the term ""Thought Experiment""
column8: and Lichtenberg created a more systematic exploration of thought experiments. Many ethical Thought Experiments gained province in the 20st century
column9: and Derek Parfit is a prominent example how these experiments are used to illustrate and argument cases and examples within ethics.

column1: Thought Experiments are the philosophical method that asks the ""What if"" questions in a systematic sense. Thought Experiments are typically designed in a way that should question our assumptions about the world. They are thus typically deeply normative
column2: and can be transformative. Thought Experiments can unleash transformation knowledge in people since such experiments question the status quo of our understanding of the world. The word ""experiment"" is insofar slightly misleading
column3: as the outcome of Thought Experiments is typically open. In other words
column4: there is no right or wrong answer
column5: but instead
column6: the experiments are a form of open discourse. While thus some Thought Experiments may be designed to imply a presumpted answer
column7: many famous Thought Experiments are completely open
column8: and potential answers reflect the underlying norms and moral constructs of people. Hence Thought Experiments are not only normative in their design
column9: but especially in terms of the possible answers of results.

column1: The easiest way to set up a Thought Experiment is to ask yourself a ""What if"" question. Many Thought Experiments resolve around decisions
column2: choices or potential states of the future. A famous example is the Trolley experiment
column3: where a train rolls towards five train track workers
column4: who would all be killed be the oncoming train
column5: unaware of their potential demise. You can now change the direction of the train
column6: and lead it to another track. There
column7: one worker would be killed. Uncountable numbers of variations of this experiment exist (see Further Information)
column8: as it can teach much about choice
column9: ethics
column10: and responsibility. For instance
column11: many people would change the train direction
column12: but hardly anyone would push a person onto the track to derail the train. This would save the other five
column13: and the outcome would be the same. However the difference between pushing a lever or pushing a person has deep psychological ramifications that resolve around guilt. This exemplifies that the Thought Experiment does not necessarily have a ''best'' outcome
column14: as the outcome depends - in this example - on your moral choices. Some might argue that you should hurl yourself onto the track to stop the train
column15: thereby not changing the countable outcome
column16: but performing a deeply altruistic act that saves everybody else. Most people would probably be unable to do this.

column1: '''Such deeply normative Thought Experiments differ from Thought Experiments that resolve around the natural world.''' Dropping a feather and a stone from a high building is such an example
column2: as this experiment is clearly not normative. We are all aware that the air would prevent the feather to fall as fast as the stone. What if we take the air now out of the experiment
column3: and let both fall in a vacuum. Such a Thought Experiment is prominent in physics and exemplifies the great flexibility of this method. Schrödinger's Cat was another example of the Thought Experiment
column4: where quantum states and uncertainty are illustrated by a cat that is either dead or not
column5: which depends on the decay of some radioactive element. Since radioactive decay rates are not continuous
column6: but represent a sudden change
column7: the cat could be dead or not. The cat is dead and not dead at the same time. Many argue that this is a paradox
column8: and I would follow this assumption with the supporting argument that we basically look at two realities at the same time. This exemplifies again that our interpretation of this Thought Experiment can also be normative
column9: since a definitive proof of my interpretation is very difficult. This is insofar relevant
column10: as seemingly all Thought Experiments are still based on subjective realisations and inferences.

column2: we see that there are Thought Experiments that resolve exclusively about a - subjective - human decision
column3: and other types of Thought Experiments that are designed around setting in the physical world. The difference between these two is in the design of the experiment itself
column4: as the first are always focused on the normative decisions or people
column5: while the second focuses on our normative interpretation of anticipation of a design that is without a human influence. This distinction is already helpful
column6: yet another dimension is about time. Many Thought Experiments are independent of time
column7: while others try to reinterpret the past to make assumptions about a future about which we have no experience. Thought Experiments that focus on re-interpretation of the past (""What if the assassination of Franz Ferdinands failed? Would the first World War still have happened?"") look for alternative pathways of history
column8: often to understand the historical context and - more impotantly - the consequences of this context better. Most Thought Experiments are independent of a longer time scale. These experiments - such as the Trolley experiment - look at a very close future
column9: and are often either very constructed or lack a connection to a specific context. Thought Experiments that focus on the future are often build around utopian or at least currently unthinkable examples that question the status quo
column10: either form an ethical
column11: societal
column12: cultural or any other perspective. Such desirable futures are deeply normative yet can build an important bridge to our current reality through backcasting (""What if there is no more poverty
column13: and how can we achieve this?"").

column1: All this exemplifies that Thought Experiments are deeply normative
column2: and show a great flexibility in terms of the methodological design setup in space and time. Some of the most famous Thought Experiments (such as the [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teletransportation_paradox tele-transportation paradox]) are quite unconnected from our realities
column3: yet still they are. This is the great freedom of Thought Experiments
column4: as they help us to understand something basically about ourselves. '''Thought Experiments can be a deeply transformational methods
column5: and can enable us to learn the most about ourselves
column6: our choices
column7: and our decisions.'''

column1: The core strengths of Thought Experiments is to raise normative assumptions of about the world
column2: and about the future. Thought Experiments can thus unleash a transformative potential within individuals
column3: as people question the status quo in their norms and morals. Another strength of Thought Experiments is the possibility to consider different futures
column4: as well as alternatives of the past. Thought Experiments are thus as versatile and flexible as people's actions or decision
column5: and the ''What if'' of Thought Experiments allows us to re-design our world and make deep inquiries into alternative state of the world. This makes Thought Experiments potentially time-saving
column6: and also resource-efficient. If we do not need to test our assumptions in the real world
column7: our work may become more efficient
column8: and we may even be able to test assumptions that would be unethical in the real world. '''Schrödinger's Cat experiment is purely theoretical
column9: and thus not only important for physics
column10: but also better for the cat.''' This latest strength is equally also the greatest weakness of Thought Experiments. We might consider all different option about alternative states of the world
column11: yet we have to acknowledge that humankind has a long history of being wrong in terms of our assumptions about the world. In other words
column12: while Thought Experiments are so fantastic because they can be unburdened by reality
column13: this automatically means that they are also potentially different from reality. Another potential flaw of Thought Experiments is that they are only as good as our assumptions and reflections about the world. A four-year-old making up theThought Experiment ""What if I have an unlimited amount of ice cream?"" would consequently drown or freeze in the unlimited amount of ice cream. Four-year-olds are not aware of the danger of the ""unlimited""
column14: and may not be the best Thought Experimenters. The same holds true for many other people
column15: and just as our norms and values change
column16: the value of specific Thought Experiments can change over time. Thought Experiments are like a reflection
column17: and any reflection can be blurry
column18: partly
column19: bended
column20: or plain wrong - the last case
column21: if we cannot identify our reflection in the mirror of Thought Experiments.

column1: Thought experiments are as we have already learned as normative as are our assumptions about the world. Hume argued that Thought Experiments are based on the laws of nature
column2: yet here I would disagree. While many famous Thought Experiments are about the physical world
column3: others are only made up in our minds. Many Thought Experiments are downright impossible to be matched with our reality
column4: and are even explicitly designed to do this
column5: such as Thomas Nagels Encyclopaedia of the Universe. It is therefore important to realise that basically all Thought Experiments are in essence normative
column6: and one could say even downright subjective. Building on Derek Parfit
column7: I would however propose a different interpretation
column8: and propose that we should not measure the normativity of Thought Experiments through the design and setting
column9: but instead by their outcome. Many people might come to the same conclusions within a given Thought Experiment
column10: and some conclusion drawn from Thought Experiments may matter more than others. Consequently the penultimate question - also for Derek Parfit - is whether there are some Thought Experiments that are not normative.

column1: Much of [[Glossary|art]] and the media can be seen as a Thought Experiment
column2: and there are ample examples that Thought Experiments in the media and the arts triggered or supported severe societal transformations. Thought Experiments are of equal importance in ethics and physics
column3: and the bridge-building of the methodological approach should not be overestimated. Examples from the past prove that Thought Experiments can enable a great epistemological flexibility and diversity. This flexibility is even so large that Thought Experiments serve as a bridge between the epistemological and the ontological
column4: or in other words between everything we know - and how we know it - and everything we believe. By enabling the transformation of our own most individual thoughts
column5: Thought Experiments may provide a boat or a bridge to link the metaphysical with the world of knowledge.

column1: When you start thinking about '''variations of the famous Trolley experiment'''
column2: you can dive into normative questions of all sorts. Here are some versions that our students came up with (remember: in the classical version
column3: a trolley threatens to kill five people on the tracks
column4: and you have the choice to divert the train towards one other person instead).

column1: * The trolley can also be diverted towards five cows who are standing on the tracks. How do you value animals' lives compared to human lives?
* The trolley threatens to kill one child
column2: but can also be diverted towards three healthy
column3: old people. Which role does age play for your decision?

column1: * The trolley might stop automatically. There is a 25% chance that it stops before it reaches three people that it is on track to kill
column2: and a 75% chance of stopping when you divert it towards a single individual. How do probabilities influence the decision?

column1: * Instead of the option to divert the trolley to one individual instead of five
column2: you have the option to push another person onto the tracks
column3: which would stop the trolley. How does letting someone die differ from actively pushing them onto the tracks?

column1: * You are tied to the tracks
column2: but can also divert the train down a cliff
column3: killing the (unspecified number of) passengers. Would you?

Time;"'''In short:''' This entry revolves around the history of Time as a concept
column2: and its implications for scientific inquiry. Please refer to the [[Design Criteria of Methods]] entry for a general overview on all design criteria.

column1: Time is one of the greatest misconceptions in terms of methods (and humans in general)

column3: or grain) poses one of the key challenges in methodological aspects of science. Here

column1: '''We humans are known to be a mere glitch in the long cosmic developments that lay already behind us.''' Much time has already passed

column3: and we as humankind have only been here for a few thousand or a few hundred thousand years

column9: and these debates will likely not end anytime soon. There exist diverse flavours to make sense of our presence
column10: and while I invite everyone to participate in this great abyss of a debate

column12: we may agree that our future could be much better than our past
column13: and it would be worthwhile in this spirit to go on

column16: yet personally

column2: let us focus on the main obstacle to this bright future that we have faced ever since we began: ''Temporal autocorrelation.'' This principle defines that we humans value everything that occurs in the close past or future to be more relevant than occurrences in the distant future or past. This is even independent of the likelihood whether future events will actually happen. As an example
column3: imagine that you want to have a new computer every few years
column4: and you can pay 5€ to have a 50% chance to get a new computer tomorrow. If you actually needed one
column5: you would surely do that. However
column6: even adjusted for inflation
column7: many people would not pay the same 5€ to have a 50 % chance to win the latest computer in 10 years. What difference does it make? It is the latest tech in any case. '''Temporal discounting is one of the main ways how people act unreasonably'''. This even extends well beyond the point where we are dead already
column8: although this also plays a role. Our unreasonable inabilities to transcend temporal discounting extend likewise into the past. The strongest argument to this end is how many people insist that they are worse off today when compared to the past - in the 'good old days'. The mistake that is typically made is that some aspects in the past were better
column9: while many other aspects were worse. People hence have a tendency to value the time period closer to them different from the time periods more distant. For the past
column10: only the good things are remembered

Examples are several approaches known under the term [[Machine Learning]] which allow for a data-driven anticipation of future developments
column6: often with a focus on [[Correlations|correlative]] patterns. Another development in science is the inclusion and joint learning of science and society together. Methodological approaches such as [[Visioning & Backcasting|Visioning]] allow for a more integrational perspective of potential futures based on the diverse knowledge of involved actors. Often applied in sustainability and futures research
column7: they also hold normative implications for the kind of future we want
column8: and the ones we don't.

column1: Rooted in the agricultural experiments about 100 years ago
column2: so-called longitudinal studies investigate in a designed methodological setting how changes can be quantified over time. Rooted in the [[Experiments|experimental]] approaches of the [[ANOVA|Analysis of Variance]]
column3: these [[Statistics|statistical]] methods became the gold standard in clinical trials
column4: and enabled such different disciplines as ecology and psychology to systematically [[Designing studies|design studies]] to quantify changes over time. However
column5: such approaches have increasingly been considered to be too rigid to adequately consider the diversity of parameters that characterise real world dynamics. The Corona pandemic is an example where many dynamics can be anticipated
column6: such as the increase in numbers
column7: and other dynamics are investigated in longitudinal studies
column8: such as the effectiveness of vaccines. However
column9: some changes can also not be instantly anticipated or investigated
column10: which highlights that in order to explore future dynamics
column11: longitudinal studies may enable some focal points to investigate
column12: yet more [[Agency
column13: Complexity and Emergence|complex]] dynamics may demand other approaches.

column1: Longitudinal studies may deserve an own Wiki entry in the long run
column2: yet what is most relevant here is that designing such studies demands a clear recognition of the time intervals and anticipated hypotheses that are being investigated. While more and more temporal data becomes available
column3: most prominently through the Internet
column4: and this data can be analysed by diverse methodological approaches
column5: it is a general rule of thumb that temporal analyses of quantitative data demand a high level of expertise. This can be related to four main challenges within research that investigates more than one current snapshot in time:

column1: A general awareness of the different ways how changes can manifest themselves over time is a precondition for a selection of a specific method. '''To this end
column2: we can distinguish between three general patterns within changes over time: Linear changes
column3: non-linear changes
column4: and repeated patterns.''' Many patterns that can be derived from changes are following linear dynamics. A lack of such linear dynamics or changes may be rooted in a low data density
column5: yet human perception is also often following non-linear dynamics. We are for instance able to perceive a light to be on or off
column6: yet the fine change between these two states is too rapid to be visually perceived by humans. This is different from fire
column7: where a smouldering fire is not really burning
column8: but it is also not cold. A pile of wood will start to burn
column9: the fire will eventually spread
column10: and then slowly fade away. Thus
column11: an electric light being switched on is a non-linear pattern
column12: while a fire burning is more linear. Examples of sudden changes are prominent in physics
column13: yet also found their way into theories in economy or ecology. Within psychology or social science this is even more complex because of the peculiarity of human perception
column14: much of which is not linear
column15: but instead we think in groups or levels. This may be the reason why it is so difficult for us to actually establish a gradual line of perception. Take the example of being happy
column16: or being sad. We can often say when we are either happy or sad
column17: but what about some in-between state? Can you define when you are half happy and half sad? Hence the 'glas-half-empty-and-half-full'-allegory. Such normative groups tend to force us to think in categories
column18: often in dualities
column19: which is deeply embedded in Western culture
column20: yet also beyond. This is the point when we should acknowledge the value of a critical perspective at least as much as the value of qualitative methods when it comes to perceptions. This testifies one of the direct peers of [[Bias and Critical Thinking|critical realism]]
column21: and the associated shrinking importance of personal identity but not of personal perception. Researchers should want to understand more about subjective perspectives
column22: and try to integrate them
column23: and realise especially how these may change over time. Exciting research emerges to this end
column24: and new methods allow to unravel human perception from a qualitative perspective
column25: thereby allowing for a more critical viewpoint on many of the categories through which we tend to see the world. However this does not only depend on the constructs in which we tend to group the world from a quantitative or qualitative categorical viewpoint
column26: but also the temporal grain that we establish in our perspective.

column1: == Temporal grain and measures of time ==
Temporal grain can be defined as the temporal resolution at which we observe a certain phenomenon. Take again the example of the electrical lightbulb. If we switch it on
column2: we see that it is instantly on. This can be - sometimes - different in a Neon tube
column3: which in some occasions needs a few seconds until it is filled with plasma and becomes bright. Here
column4: there is a delay between the off state and the on state - an in-between state. If I now close my eyes for five seconds
column5: and only open them at a regular interval every five seconds
column6: and then close them again
column7: then this in-between state would be missed by me. '''Such temporal grain effects are crucial in our view of the world
column8: since we can only observe what is within the frequence of our observations'''. Within quantitive analysis
column9: this is also closely related to the question of statistical power
column10: since each time step needs to be sufficiently supported by data. If you conduct repeated [[Interviews]] with the same people
column11: one missing interview may make the whole data point useless
column12: depending on the analysis method that is being used. Equally important is temporal grain in qualitative approaches
column13: where repeated observations or gathering of information may hold a key to human perceptions and their change. If you want to inquire the mood of a participant in a study
column14: then '''it is clear that you do not want to ask the person every minute how they feel
column15: yet you equally do not want to ask the person every month
column16: because more often than not
column17: moods shift quickly'''. Another good example of the relevance of temporal grain in qualitative approaches is the analysis of the paintings of an artist. When we look at Picasso there are clear periods that are widely accepted today
column18: and Georgia O'Keeffe is yet another example where periods are well known. While typically there is a close process in the analysis of the work of artists with the biography
column19: a special role falls to the critique of art in this context
column20: which - in a nutshell - demands not only to recognise but also to transcend the context
column21: including the social and societal circumstances surrounding the origin and influences of the art. Since this make the critique an methodological approach well beyond the mere reflection on the art itself
column22: it creates new knowledge
column23: and is often a highly relevant analysis of societal developments. This impact of temporal grain is often overseen or not contextualised in the recognition of scientific methods
column24: and will surely increase even more with a more diverse and less disciplinary science.

column1: The aspect of temporal perception is closely linked to the fact that time is normative. '''Since we perceive time differently
column2: it is not objective.''' Consequently
column3: everything that can be associated with time is equally not objective. We should not confuse this with the mere fact that some aspects of time are more precise than others. The invention of the chronograph as a means to locating a ship in the vastness of the oceans allowed not only for a more precise navigation
column4: but also for a more efficient abuse of the regions known as colonies back then. Hence
column5: even the mere consequences of time or its more precise utilisation are relative and normative. Yet what about time itself
column6: as a physical entity? Since Einstein it became clear that under a clever experimental settings
column7: twins may have a different age
column8: depending on their relative travels through the Universe being different. That does not mean that everything is relative
column9: but it can be. The discovery of gravitational waves is another example of a physical postulate that has been proven by a precise calculation of time. Within such experimental settings time is of the essence. If the 20st century was the period of Utilitarianism and its failures
column10: then this regime ran more often than not on a strict time regime. Just as the results of science rooted in positivism were increasingly criticised and questioned
column11: there is an equally strong urge to question scientific results once time has passed. While it is unclear how much time leads to sufficiently different circumstances to make results questionable
column12: the same process can even be - counterintuitively - reverse. Many of the models and results predicting the effects of climate change have been more severe in reality than predicted years of decades before. Climate change became
column13: sadly
column14: a classic example where many models were actually too conservative compared to reality. It is a weird plot twist that this fact has become an argument of climate change deniers
column15: which showcases that the means justify all ends
column16: even our own. This links to the ultimate end
column17: or at least how it is potentially proclaimed. Since Nostradamus and probably long before
column18: the end of human kind as predicted by prophets and later scientists has been used as threat to make people submit
column19: or at least leave them in awe
column20: if not fear. The end of time (or at least humankind) has been a continuous motivation for all sorts of actions
column21: and uncountable apocalypses came to pass once the due date went by. Once more
column22: time proves its normative capacity
column23: at least until some point. How strongly people feared these ends showcases the normative strengths time can encapsule
column24: and more methodological dimensions of time may unlock in the future.

column1: Instead of glancing to the horizon
column2: let us take a step back and look at the main points we should all agree upon when it comes to time concerning the nexus of scientific methods.
documentation is key.]] Scientific studies should either produce knowledge that is reproducible
column3: or the documentation of the knowledge production process should enable a seamless understanding of the overall process that led to the scientific result. The methodological design is often deeply rooted within the norms of scientific disciplines
column4: making it a highly normative process. Concerning time
column5: this is insofar relevant that researchers need to clearly document when
column6: for instance
column7: data gathering and analysis were conducted. The Internet is a good example of an often unstable data source
column8: hence the date when you accessed specific information may be the key to the results you got often much later based on your analysis. On the other hand
column9: the date of your analysis also reveals whether you took the latest information into account. While next to no one does that - myself included - the Corona Pandemic is a prominent example how rapid knowledge emerges and even changes. To this end
column10: [[Citations|citations]] are like indirect time stamps since they allow the reader to understand which knowledge went into the conclusions you had. This helps however very little if the knowledge you used is primary data
column11: for example a database with numbers of infected people. Yet just as you would clearly document the date on which you conducted specific Interviews
column12: it is advisable to have a meta-file that contains information about the time stamps of your research. Natural science often have lab books for this
column13: and ethnographic research has equally clear examples how such emerging data and knowledge can be documented. '''Research diaries should thus emerge as more important in the coming years
column14: because they allow for a critical examination of the temporal dimensions of our own research processes and conducts in retrospect.''' These existing accounts will allow us deeper insights into research processes and mechanisms that many people assume to be rational
column15: yet as [[Scientific methods and societal paradigms|Larry Laudan]] rightly concluded
column16: research is often not exactly rational. Instead we talk about perceptions
column17: interactions and often also serendipity
column18: making the documentation of our research processes a key endeavour where more possibilities
column19: norms and standards will continue to emerge.

column1: Another key aspect where time patterns within research conduct is workload. It is almost a cliche how much people underestimate the time that needs to be put into research to arrive the respective results
column2: and again this is often a deeply personal process. How many people finished their [[How to write a thesis|thesis]] in time? Me
column3: certainly not. Making a time plan and overview of milestones for your research is surely worth your while
column4: yet you should not feel bad if this then changes later on  - it almost always does. Planning your research is the ultimate joke that time plays on us folks
column5: and learning to become realistic to this end is something one may thrive for a whole life. So why should it be different when it comes to the perception of time?

column1: == Temporal aspects of the combination of methods ==
A crucial aspect that deserves more reflection when it comes to scientific methods and time is the sequence in which research is conducted. While this was already mentioned before
column2: a more detailed account is necessary in order to present general principles in the temporal sequence in which methods are conducted. The concept of triangulation is one example
column3: where for instance quantitative and qualitative methods are combined and the respective results are being compared. Ideally
column4: this could also be process where the sequence of methods being used is enabling a higher specificity in order to answer the research question. An example would be to make a broad survey within a community
column5: become more focussed with semi-structured interviews
column6: and then gain really deep knowledge in [[Ethnography|ethnographic observations]] of some key actors in the community. Reversing this order would make hardly any sense. Still
column7: in medicine it is often single cases from clinical practice that may inspire larger complex investigations through clinical trials
column8: thus while in the first example the specificity increases
column9: in the second example it is actually reversed. A key challenge when increasing specificity is to maintain validity
column10: which is often scattered in the beginning
column11: but becomes more focused in a later stage.

column2: different methodological approaches are often used in parallel instead of a sequential order. While one branch of a project may make workshops
column3: another branch may focus on ethnographic observation
column4: and yet another part revolves around an experiment with an intervention. More often than not
column5: there is little anticipation how these different forms of knowledge are integrated
column6: as the united goal is not always straightforward. To this
column7: end
column8: integration is a frontier that is not always in focus
column9: and it will be a challenge how to find a consensus within most interdisciplinary fields of research beyond medicine. Interestingly
column10: in medicine such temporal sequences or parallel conducts are more established and follow clearer guidelines and also practicalities within clinical practice. The united goal to help the patient may serve a strong integration purpose to this end
column11: with the overall goal being less clear in other research let alone practice.

column1: Another often overseen aspects regarding time in the combination of methods are the aspects of long term observations. Due to the funding in research hardly exceeding some few years
column2: long-term research is rare. Especially maintaining longer experiments or investigating a larger dataset e.g. within the arts
column3: it is often difficult to generate knowledge that can deviate from knowledge synthesised in a rather short period. More focus on long-term research is needed in order gain the knowledge necessary when facing the problems we need to overcome. Climate change is a rare example where institutions such as the IPCC make sure that enough momentum and coherence was generated to create a body of knowledge that integrates millions of working hours of researchers
column4: looks at incredible large and diverse dataset
column5: and creates an integration and synthesis of these often long-term datasets that allows for clear policy recommendations.

column1: == The future of temporal aspects in methods ==

The problems we still face regarding temporal aspects of research may all come to pass in future research. The last decades have already shown how dense the available data become in many aspects of science
column2: and how digital communication and means of documentation led to a new era of research when it comes to temporal aspects of scientific methods. Analytical methods allow for longitudinal analysis unheard of some decades ago
column3: and [[Machine Learning|machine learning]] unravels altogether new ways of research. Online libraries of art allow a broader access to data
column4: yet all these exciting technologies cannot lead us to ignore the key challenge: '''Long-term research and funding are to date rare
column5: and the role of academia within society will need to change in order to allow for research that is more continuously embedded.''' This would allow us to learn from past mistakes
column6: and utilise more diverse approaches to gather knowledge about the different futures
column7: and how we may reach these.

column3: trends
column4: or periodicity. There are multiple approaches to detecting and dealing with outliers in time series data. We will have a look at detecting outliers first: 1. Distribution-based outlier detection: This detection method relies on the assumption that the data follows a certain known distribution. Then all points outside this distribution are considered outliers. (Hoogendoorn & Funk 2018) 2. Distance-based outlier detection: This method computes the distance from one point to all other points. A point is considered “close” to another point when the distance between them is below a set threshold. Then
column5: a point is considered an outlier if the fraction of points deemed close to that point is below a threshold. (Hoogendoorn & Funk 2018) 3. Local outlier factor (LOF): The local outlier factor (LOF) is a measure of how anomalous an object is within a dataset
column6: based on the density of its local neighborhood. The LOF is computed by comparing the density of an object's neighborhood to the densities of the neighborhoods of its nearest neighbors. If the density of an object's neighborhood is significantly lower than the densities of its neighbors' neighborhoods
column7: then it is considered an outlier (Hoogendoorn & Funk 2018).

column1: Digital lectures have been common for years
column2: but especially during the COVID-19 crisis
column3: we saw the challenges - but also benefits - that came with presenting content and having seminars in online formats. This entry provides a list of tips for both teachers and students in online sessions.

column1: * Make more out of online sessions as a student.
==== Tips for better (video) lectures and Zoom sessions ====
* It is tempting to record yourself in front of the camera
column2: talking over slides. While this may be useful for many lectures
column3: sometimes
column4: it might be easier for your students to understand and engage with your content when you '''record your lecture as a conversation''' with a relative
column5: a colleague
column6: or someone from your household to which you explain the lecture's content. Don't stage this - if you listener does not understand your lecture
column7: you students probably won't
column8: either. Let your listener ask questions
column9: and explain things in more detail
column10: if necessary.

column2: such as small tasks or questions for the students
column3: which you come back to during or after the lecture
column4: or in a Zoom session.

column2: '''use [http://mentimeter.com Mentimeter]'' to facilitate participation for your students. You can create quizzes or ask for thoughts and let students rank items
column3: but also show them slides or videos. You can also host Q&A sessions via Mentimeter
column4: where students can upvote questions
column5: which brings order into Q&A. However
column6: a Q& A may best be supported by letting students raise their hands in the Zoom call so they can also speak and listen to fellow students
column7: and not just read
column8: type and click.

column2: '''use breakout rooms''' for the students to discuss questions that you posted
column3: or questions that came from the students themselves. After some minutes
column4: you can let the students share their thoughts
column5: for example via Mentimeter. The breakout rooms also make some students keep their camera on
column6: which may improve the atmosphere in the session.

column2: '''use gimmicks''' to maintain a positive atmosphere. Hold a contest about the best virtual background
column3: or let students share their favorite snacks during a short break. It always helps when as many students as possible have their cameras turned on
column4: so think of ways to achieve this.

column1: ==== Some ways to jumpstart and foster an open and collaborative atmosphere when teaching a class or leading a team ====

column2: give participants the opportunity to briefly (e.g. 5-10 mins.) talk with you one-on-one. You can offer an open Discord channel for this
column3: or a Zoom room
column4: in which you are approachable during pre-determined timeslots. Here
column5: let students and team members join you individually. This fosters a more personal relationship and gives everyone the possibility for the type of interaction that is more spontaneous and less guarded (and therefore more personal). Give it the atmosphere similar to an exchange during a coffee break
column6: while walking down a hallway
column7: or similar situations to break the behaviour patterns that are typically prevalent during a class or a formal meeting.

column1: Start and end sessions with giving the participants the possibility to say a one-sentence statement about their current (subjective) personal status/mood/thougths/feelings without anyone commenting on them or referring to them (in the sense of a non-judgmental environment). The participants should be free to say whatever they feel like (it is not a round of feedback on the subject matter or the class
column2: but more a statement of ""where each person is"" at the moment).

column1: This requires a certain amount of trust and openness in the group and needs a bit of getting used to (risk-taking).
Encourage each participant - in a smaller seminar
column2: or workshop - to bring a personal object into the class
column3: or meeting
column4: and ask them to place it so that everyone in the digital room can see it. Encourage to choose a different object sponanteously  each time based on instincts (e.g. while they are preparing for the meeting or while they are leaving their place to attend the class). These objects can foster dialogue and enjoyment as well as express the person's attitude and mood which are vital clues to socially connect - especially in online meetings (but also in in-person gatherings). It can be a good starting point when getting to know new people. Optionally
column5: you can introduce a game variant (that should be non-competitive) by asking participants to take into consideration previously chosen objects introduced by other participants - in that way reacting to them.

column1: Being a student in home office times is rough
column2: and even when the COVID pandemic is over
column3: you will still encounter online lectures
column4: seminars
column5: conferences and MOOCs. To some extent
column6: luckily
column7: being at home instead of in a lecture hall also has its merits. That being said
column8: the following are some (not so) obvious tips for you to improve your online learning experience.

column1: * '''Always have something to drink''' (water/tee/coffee/mate/...) or to a snack with you. You could also have proper meals while listening to someone talk
column2: or even prepare food
column3: but be aware that this might distract you and result in you not really taking away much from the online session.

column1: * Wear comfortable clothes and '''create a nice atmosphere in your room''' or wherever you study at the moment. In Home Office situations
column2: you do not necessarily have to sit at your desk
column3: although it can create a more 'official' atmosphere and stimulate learning and engagement. For some
column4: however
column5: other spatial arrangements work
column6: too
column7: so find the spot in your apartment - or even outside - that does not distract you
column8: but supports a comfortable learning experience.

column1: * '''Put your phone away from you''' so you do not get easily distracted from messages or tempted to do something else. We are all used to having second or third screens
column2: and it is already tempting to browse on the computer while in a Zoom session - so don't burden yourself with the temptation of another device. Check your phone regularly
column3: if you want to
column4: but do so in breaks between sessions.

column1: * Make sure you '''have a system to organize yourself''' that works for you and helps you to structure your everyday life during online classes. For this purpose
column2: we can highly recommend [[Notion]]
column3: which allows you to organize pretty much everything
column4: presumed that you prefer digital documentation. For analoguous notes
column5: you might want to consider a DIN A3 sheet to summarize your courses
column6: or a specific course's content.

column1: * Try to use the breaks in between classes to do things that do not require much brain power
column2: such as walking outside
column3: doing the laundry or dishes
column4: talking to your room mate etc. Especially some '''physical activity''' - a walk
column5: a jog
column6: yoga
column7: or some workout at home - can do wonders between online sessions.

column1: * Make sure you ""zoom"" away from your screen every now and then. Your eyes aren't too happy to be kept in the same position for too long
column2: and sometimes this might even result in a headache. So make sure to '''sometimes look out of the window'''
column3: or - as mentioned above - go into nature without any screens.

column1: * If you have to read a lot for your studies
column2: '''consider printing texts on paper'''. Reading on paper can be a nice alternative to reading on the screen. Or - fancy - take a walk to the library and lend the book.

column1: * Though we all try to avoid too many distractions
column2: using the chat function in Zoom may help to refocus your attention from time to time. If you write a short message to your friend taking the same seminar
column3: exchanging on how you are
column4: and how you perceive the class
column5: you emulate the classroom experience to some extent
column6: which can help an follow the content afterwards more easily. We cannot stay focused in 4 Zoom sessions à 90 min. a day
column7: so it is ok to allow us '''some pleasant distractions every now and then'''.

column1: To Rule And To Measure;"'''Note:''' The German version of this entry can be found here: [[To Rule And To Measure (German)]].
'''In short:''' This entry illustrates different types of data units and approaches to measuring our world.

column2: humans have developed myriads of tools and units that help measure
column3: categorize
column4: compare
column5: analyze and understand things
column6: processes and people - in short
column7: the world. '''We have measured space and time
column8: sound and light
column9: the movement of atoms and molecules
column10: and there is no end in sight'''. You use measurements every day - stepping onto the weighing scale in the morning (don't do that!)
column11: calculating the time you need to get to university
column12: the amount of sugar you need for the cake
column13: or the money you spent last weekend. You may even (unconsciously) reflect on the amount of fun different potential activities might be
column14: or think about your level of satisfaction with your last meal.

column1: Some units of measurement are very strongly connected to the physical world
column2: such as measuring weights or lengths
column3: despite the existence different units to do so. Others are very much socially constructed
column4: such as the Human Development Index (HDI)
column5: which puts a number to the whole quality of life. And then
column6: there is a wide range in between
column7: like the Beaufort scale which does measure something physical (wind)
column8: but is quite an arbitrary form of doing so.

column1: The same can be said for tools that enable the translation of physical or social phenomena into such units: some
column2: like a ruler
column3: are very much related to physical properties
column4: while others
column5: such as IQ tests
column6: are based on so many assumptions about how intelligence should or could be measured
column7: that there is no denying strong normative implications. There is no judgement to be made here
column8: but one should be aware of the fact that units of measurement may imply specific assumptions about the world and how much we can know about it. There are things we can measure
column9: things we can measure but are not necessarily like that
column10: and things we cannot measure at all.

column1: '''The following entry provides examples on units of measurement and tools to measure.''' There will be more additions over time. All of these represent major breakthroughs and have consolidated over time. All these diverse data formats and tools should strengthen our understanding that we look at parts of the picture. The emergence of new measures does not only unlock new knowledge
column2: it also highlights the limitations of our total knowledge. As [[Bias and Critical Thinking|critical realism]] claims
column3: we may never be able to fully understand all aspects of all mechanisms of reality that are real. For instance
column4: many institutions are riddled by [[Glossary|tacit]] knowledge that we only now start to slowly unlock. We thus have to acknowledge that the examples given here have limitations
column5: and that there are many forms of knowledge that cannot be tamed or constructed into numbers.

column2: this entry is not only an example of diverse possibilities
column3: but also highlights how several different data formats may even contradict other forms of knowledge
column4: or may even hamper a different but necessary understanding of certain mechanisms. The 20th century was in many aspects dominated by numbers
column5: which informed policy and management
column6: and served as a baseline for diverse aspects of emerging [[Scientific methods and societal paradigms|societal paradigms]]. Especially economic thinking was widely based on such understanding
column7: and equally was positivism mostly built around numbers and measures. '''What is often overseen to this end is the fact that these numbers are not objective
column8: but also normative.''' For instance
column9: measures of IQ are not only deeply constructed
column10: but also deeply contested. While much of empirical research still claims to create objective knowledge
column11: it becomes increasingly clear that such claims are often falsifying each other. If we however clearly recognise the limitations of all these diverse measure
column12: we may also be better enabled to understand the value of these measures.

column1: Please refer to the [https://sustainabilitymethods.org/index.php/Data_formats entry on Data formats] for more general information on how data can be formatted.

column2: Fahrenheit and Kelvin represent the most common temperature scales used today. While Celsius is used in most places in the world
column3: the USA and associated territories still use the Fahrenheit scale. Kelvin is based directly on Celsius and is most commonly used by scientists to communicate their results (e.g. when speaking about a temperature increase of 2K)
column4: but not really used in everyday practice in any country.

column2: Celsius and Kelvin.''' Source: [https://cryo.gsfc.nasa.gov/introduction/temp_scales.html NASA]]]
water freezes at (~) 0°C and boils at (~) 100°C. -273
column3: 15°C represents the lowest possible temperature a gas can (theoretically) reach
column4: and can be translated into 0 Kelvin. Kelvin is thus always 273
column5: 15 higher than Celsius. The unit of Fahrenheit is based on a thermometer using a mixture of water
column6: ice and ammonium chloride - the minimum temperature that could be reached with this mixture was set as 0°F. Fahrenheit can be translated into Celsius as follows: °F = (°C)x(9/5) + 32

column1: The Richter Scale is used to measure the strength of Earthquakes. It was developed in 1935 by US American seismologists Richter and Gutenberg. It is based on the logarithm of the amplitude of the largest seismic wave of an earthquake event. Each increase of one unit on the scale signifies a tenfold increase in the magnitude of an earthquake
column2: and a 31 times higher amount of energy released. While today's technologies can measure seismic waves below what was possible with the Richter scale
column3: and are better to measure very strong earthquakes
column4: the Richter scale is still often used
column5: especially in the media. (Source: britannica.com/science/Richter-scale)

column1: [[File:To Rule and To Measure - Richter Scale.png|400px|thumb|center|'''The Richter Scale.''' Source: [https://www.britannica.com/science/Richter-scale Britannica]]]
The Beaufort Wind Scale was created by British Admiral Sir Francis Beaufort in 1805. It allows to assess the speed of winds based on their effects on both land and oceans. It goes from 0 to 12
column2: with 12 being the strongest winds (Source: weather.gov./mfl/beaufort)

column1: [[File:To Rule and To Measure - Beaufort.png|600px|thumb|center|'''The Beaufort Scale.''' Source: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaufort_scale Wikipedia]]]

column2: as well as Bel (1 Bel = 10dB) are dimensionless physical units that refer to the relation between two measurements (measured and reference) on a logarithmic scale. They were first publicized in 1931 and still used in various fields of application; however
column3: dB still most commonly referred to when speaking about the loudness of sounds. However
column4: it is important to note that dB does not indicate the absolute loudness of something
column5: but only the logarithmic (not linear!) relation to a reference point
column6: which
column7: for sound
column8: is the point where the human ear can no longer perceive any sound. (Source: https://www.elektronik-kompendium.de/sites/grd/0304011.htm
column9: https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bel_(Einheit) )

column1: Measuring the well-being of people and progress thereof has been subject of debates for a long time. While GDP is the most widespread approach to measure human (presumable) well-being on a nation-wide or global level
column2: there is an increasing demand for alternative indicators. One of those under discussion is happiness
column3: with Bhutan being the first and so far only country to prioritize 'Gross National Happiness' in their decisions.

column1: Happiness - being a very subjective unit of measurement - is difficult to evaluate. The 'World Happiness Report' attempts to do so over 200 pages. It has been published regularly since 2013 and uses representative
column2: self-reported data from (mostly) the [[https://www.gallup.de/182606/gallup-world-poll.aspx Gallup World Poll]]. Here
column3: participants answer questions about over 100 aspects of life
column4: including their average life evaluation on a scale from 1-10. The World Happiness Report
column5: then
column6: tries to understand how different aspects of life explain variations in this self-reported life evaluation. In the 2020 report
column7: for example
column8: they focus on how the elements GDP
column9: Social Support
column10: Life Expectancy
column11: Freedom to make life choices
column12: Generosity and Perception of orruption influence it. Other elements that are analyzed are inequality
column13: worry and anger
column14: discrimination
column15: income
column16: trust in society
column17: systems and the policy
column18: intimacy and many others. Overall
column19: the report states Finland
column20: Denmark and Switzerland to be the countries with the happiest people (on average)
column21: while Zimbabwe
column22: South Sudan and Afghanistan mark the bottom three. You can find out more about this report on the [https://worldhappiness.report/ respective website.]

column1: [[File:To Rule and To Measure - Happiness.png|500px|thumb|center|'''Results of the World Happiness Report 2020'''. Source: World Happiness Report 2020

The image shows the average global happiness between 2017 and 2019. Life evaluation is measured by the Cantril ladder question that asks respondents to evaluate the quality of their lives on an 11-point ladder scale

Positive affect is measured by a two-item index asking respondents whether or not they frequently experienced (1) enjoyment and (2) laughter on the day before the survey. Negative affect is measured by a three-item index asking respondents whether they frequently experienced (1) worry

column2: short for intelligence quotient
column3: is a common metric to indicate and compare human intelligence. There is no standard definition of intelligence and a variety of normalized IQ tests exist. Their choice needs to be considered when speaking about the IQ value itself. Generally
column4: an IQ test covers questions from different fields
column5: including general logical understanding
column6: understanding of language
column7: general knowledge
column8: mathematical skills and others. After conducting an IQ test
column9: each participant receives a numeric value to indicate his or her intelligence.

column1: The average result is defined to be 100
column2: with a standard deviation of 15. Because of this
column3: IQ test norms have to be updated regularly. This was not done in the 20th century
column4: leading to ever-increasing average IQ values
column5: which has been called the Flynn effect and cannot be explained. Commonly
column6: anyone with an IQ <70 is considered witless
column7: while anyone with >130 is considered highly talented. Importantly however
column8: there is severe scientific criticism concerning the IQ
column9: since a person's results to an IQ test are very dependent on his or her daily form
column10: and the test does not cover all relevant aspects of intelligence. Also
column11: the societal discourse around the IQ is problematic since it might lead to wrong assumptions and inferences about people's abilities and value. (Source: https://flexikon.doccheck.com/de/Intelligenzquotient
column12: https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligenzquotient)

column1: The Human Development Index (HDI) is an index published by the United Nations since 1990. It calculates a value between 0 and 1 based on three aspects of life: life expectancy at birth
column2: quality of education as measured in the number of years a person visits school
column3: and income per capita. Each country can reach a value between 0 and 1
column4: with 1 being the best possible result. In the 2019 report
column5: the countries with the highest HDI were Norway
column6: Switzerland and Ireland which all reached values above 0
column8: whereas the bottom was marked by Chad
column9: the Central African Republic and Niger.

column1: The HDI is a fairly simple measure
column2: focusing only on those three elements. There is also the IHDI
column3: which acknowledges and and respects inequalities within these criteria (with the same top and bottom three). The 2019 report revolved around inequalilties within and across nations
column4: indicating an increasing recognition of more integrated evaluation of the HDI. For equality
column5: the GINI coefficient is also of relevance
column6: indicating financial (in)equality within a nation  - for more on this
column7: see [https://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/gini-index.asp here].

column1: ==== United States customary units vs the Metric System ====

column2: the United States (as well as Liberia and Myanmar) use a system of measurements (the USC) that differentiates from the Metric System that the majority of countries use. The USC is based on English units and was formalized in 1832
column3: whereas Britain went on to use the Imperial and later the Metric system. The US rejected any metric system
column4: stating that these were not 'acceptable to the Lord'. In 1975
column5: the Metric Conversion Act made the common Metric System the preferred system for trade and commerce
column6: and it is the standard in
column7: among other sectors
column8: science and military
column9: but the USC is still commonly used in everyday practice in the US
column10: especially in consumer products and industrial manufacturing.

column1: ==== The weight of the soul (21 grams) ====

column2: physician Duncan MacDougall attempted to prove the existence of the human soul - scientifically. He chose six individuals which were about to die and placed them on a precise scale. The moment they died
column3: he claimed in the publication of his results
column4: they lost 21 grams in body weight
column5: which were not explainable by any other processes other than the test subjects losing their soul as they died. Naturally
column6: there was criticism to this study
column7: and other explanations were raised. However
column8: the idea that the human soul weighs 21 grams - and therefore exists - has been popularized and even influenced movie director Alejandro González Iñárritu
column9: who named a 2003 movie just that: ""21 Grams"". To this day
column10: the experiment raises the question what science can
column11: and cannot
column12: know. (Source: https://www.thevintagenews.com/2018/11/30/21-grams-experiment/)

column1: Depth sounding is a method to measure the depth of water. It was already applied in Ancient Greece and Rome
column2: and still finds use for hobby fishing and as a backup for today's standard echo sounding in case of malfunction.

column1: In Depth Sounding (which has nothing to do with 'sound' as in 'noise')
column2: a thin rope is combined with a plummet
column3: i.e. a weight
column4: that hangs at the end of it. This rope is then dropped into the water until it reaches the ground surface. By looking at marks made at the rope
column5: one can quickly measure the depth of the water.

column2: the author Mark Twain got his artist's name from this technique. In Depth Sounding
column3: the depth of the water can be indicated by saying ""By the mark"" and adding the number that is met by the water surface. In Mississippi in the 1850s
column4: the number 'two' would be called 'twain'
column5: so when the leadsmen measured the depth of the river and it was two fathoms (one fathom is 1
column7: they would say ""by the mark twain"". (Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Depth_sounding)

column1: A Thermometer is based on the fact that liquids (and gases) expand and contract depending on the temperature. While the first steps towards modern thermometers were made in Ancient Greece and later again during the 16th and 17th century
column2: major breakthroughs were the thermometers invented by Fahrenheit in 1714 and Celsius in 1742 (see Celsius vs Fahrenheit vs Kelvin).
units and liquids (or gases) used in thermometers throughout time; today
column3: most classic thermometers rely on mercury
column4: and despite the differences in measuring units
column5: there is an internationally agreed range of temperatures to be displayed by a thermometer. (Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermometer)

column1: [[File:To Rule and To Measure - Sextant.png|250px|thumb|left|'''A Sextant'''. Source: [https://www.brighthubengineering.com/seafaring/31615-marine-navigational-equipment-the-sextant Bright Hub Engineering]]]

A Sextant is a nautical tool to identify a ship's position. It is based on measuring the angular distance between astronomical objects and was invented by Newton and Hadley around 1700. A Sextant consists of a circular sector with a mirror
column2: a half-mirror and a telescope. One looks at one specific point (at a star
column3: the sun or the horizon) through the telescope and moves the mirror until a second reference point is reflected onto the half-mirror
column4: which makes the objects ultimately overlap. Based on the movement of the mirror
column5: one can read off the angle on the scale of the sextant. The angle between a star above the horizon
column6: in combination with the time of day
column7: helps identify the geographical latitude with the help of astronomical tables. The angle between the moon and a star leads to the geographical altitude.

column2: https://www.spektrum.de/lexikon/physik/sextant/13240)

column1: [[File:To Rule and To Measure - Trigonometry.png|400px|thumb|right|'''The Six Trigonometric Functions.''' Source: [http://www.gradeamathhelp.com/image-files/trigonometry-functions.gif Grade A Math Help]]]
Trigonometry is one of the oldest forms of calculating and measuring
column2: with its origins spanning across Sumer
column3: Babylon
column4: Greece
column5: Egypt
column6: India and other early civilizations up until 4000 years ago. The word means ""triangle measuring"" and refers to the usage of side lenghts and angles of triangles for calculations. By knowing the sizes of enough sides and angles of a triangle
column7: it is possible to calculate the size or length of the remaining sides and angles. Trigonometry has been used historically in geodetic measurements
column8: astronomy
column9: navigation and many other fields of application
column10: allowing for the development of many relevant technologies and inventions throughout history.

column1: While trigonometry can become quite elaborate
column2: the most basic planar trigonometry as we know it today is based on the work of Rheticus and his student Otho in the 16th Century
column3: and includes six fundamental trigonometric functions: sinus
column4: cosinus
column5: tangens
column6: as well as cosecant
column7: secant and cotangent. By knowing two variables of the triangle
column8: the third can be calculated with the use of a calculator
column9: or historically with a table book or slipstick. (Source: https://math.wikia.org/wiki/History_of_trigonometry)

column1: [[File:To Rule and To Measure - LiDAR.png|300px|thumb|right|'''The principle of LiDAR technology.''' Source: [https://archaeologicalphotorelief.files.wordpress.com/2014/07/how_lidar_works.jpg Archeological Photo Relief]]]

LiDAR is short for ""light detection and ranging"". It is a technology that measures the distance between LiDAR sensor and any object in its visible range. LiDAR can be applied in plane or satellite based measuring
column2: as well as near the surface. The sensor sends out a light impulse with a laser and detects the light that is reflected from each object. Based on the time the light needed
column3: it calculates the distance to the object. The objects may be solid
column4: but can also be liquid or even gaseous. This way
column5: the LiDAR sensor is able to construct a 3D image of
column6: for example
column7: the Earth's atmosphere or surface. LiDAR technology can help create maps and has recently be used to identify aerosols in the air
column8: temperature profiles or trace gas concentrations. (Source: https://www.dlr.de/rd/desktopdefault.aspx/tabid-5626/9178_read-17527/)

column1: [[File:To Rule and To Measure - Chinese Finger Counting.png|400px|thumb|center|'''Chinese Finger Counting'''. Source: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_number_gestures Wikipedia]]]

column2: there is a system to indicate the numbers from 1-10 with only one hand (as opposed to the Western custom of indicating one unit per finger

column1: [[File:To Rule and To Measure - Hubble Space Telescope.png|250px|thumb|right|'''The Hubble Space Telescope'''. Source: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_telescope Wikipedia]]]
A Space Telescope is a telescope in outer space. Different from from satellites that image Earth
column2: it points into outer space in order to map or survey distant stars
column3: planets and other astronomical objects. Space observations have the benefit not to be affected by filtering and distortions through Earth's atmosphere as well as light pollution on Earth. Therefore
column4: they enable scientists to better observe space despite the difficulties to maintain and high costs to build space telescopes. (Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_telescope)

column1: Gas Chromatography (GC) and Liquid Chromatography (LC) are the two main forms of Chromatography
column2: which describes an analysis technique used to quantify compounds in a mixture
column3: for example in quality control in industrial contexts
column4: in forensics
column5: or in environmental sciences. The term 'Chromatography' was coined by Russian botanist Tswett in 1906
column6: whereas the method itself was first used in 1952.

column1: A Chromatography has two main components: a stationary phase
column2: and a mobile phase which moves along the medium within the Chromatograph. For Gas Chromatography
column3: the mobile phase consists of an inert gas
column4: like helium or nitrogen
column5: while the stationary phase consists of a liquid. For Liquid Chromatography
column6: the mobile phase is a liquid and the stationary phase solid. The sample that is to be analyzed is inserted into these phases. Those compounds that interact more strongly with the stationary phase (""like-dissolves-like"" rule
column7: i.e. chemically similar compounds stay together) remain in this phase for a longer time
column8: while those compounds that interact less with the stationary phase move with the mobile phase. The distribution of compounds inbetween both phases can be analyzed using different forms of detectors
column9: leading to insights about the composition of the initial sample. (Source: http://www.chem.ucla.edu/~bacher/General/30BL/gc/theory.html
column10: https://microbenotes.com/chromatography-principle-types-and-applications/)

column1: [[File:To Rule and To Measure - Chromatography.png|400px|thumb|center|'''The principle of Chromatography'''. Source: [https://microbenotes.com/chromatography-principle-types-and-applications/ Microbenotes]]]
Many of these measures are often defined by researchers as scientific methods. We would disagree
column2: because these measures do not create knowledge in itself
column3: yet are often an important basis for data gathering and the structuring of the gathered knowledge. We have to acknowledge that there is a wealth of data available
column4: and the here presented examples showcase the great diversity that highlight the challenge to integrate different data. This will be one of the main methodological challenges of the 21 century
column5: and underlines both the importance of the recognition of qualitative methods as well as the deep normativity that is part of the diverse datasets that we have.

column1: Die Richterskala wird zur Messung der Stärke von Erdbeben verwendet. Sie wurde im Jahr 1935 von den US-amerikanischen Seismologen Richter und Gutenberg entwickelt. Sie basiert auf dem Logarithmus der Amplitude der größten seismischen Welle eines Erdbebenereignisses. Jeder Anstieg um eine Einheit auf der Skala bedeutet eine Verzehnfachung der Stärke eines Erdbebens und eine 31-fach höhere freigesetzte Energiemenge. Obwohl die heutigen Technologien seismische Wellen unterhalb dessen messen können
