Transcribing Interviews;"'''In short:''' This entry revolves around Transcription
column2: which is the reconstruction of recorded audio into written text for the analysis of Interviews. For more on Interview Methodology
column3: please refer to the [[Interviews|Interview overview page]].

column1: Transcription is not a scientific method in itself
column2: but an important step between the conduction of Interviews and the Coding process and subsequent analysis. '''Transcription entails the process of writing down what has been said in an Interview based on video or audio recordings.''' Transcription has become common practice in qualitative research (1). The transcription process is an analytical and interpretative act
column3: which influences how the transcript represents what has actually been said or done by the interviewee(s) (1
column4: 3). A well-conceived transcription process will support the analysis
column5: and a bad transcription may lead to an omission or distortion of important data. This entry revolves around important elements of the transcription process. For more details on Interviews and the subsequent analysis of the transcripts
column6: please refer to [[Interviews]] and [[Content Analysis]].

column1: '''Transcriptions are mostly relevant for qualitative Interview approaches'''
column2: such as [[Open Interview]]s
column3: [[Semi-structured Interview]]s
column4: [[Narrative Research|Narrative Interviews]]
column5: [[Ethnography|Ethnographic Interviews]] or [[Focus Groups]]. It may also be relevant for [[Video Research]]
column6: or serve as a source for supplementary data when conducting [[Surveys]]. Transcripts enable [[Glossary|researchers]] to analyze what Interviewee's or observed individuals said in a given situation without the risk of missing crucial content. Knowing that the data will be there later on allows for the researcher to engage with the Interview situation instead of imposing the need to write everything down right away. Recorded material can be re-visited long after the data gathering process and transcribed.

column2: the recorded speech is written down word by word.''' Denaturalized transcription revolves mostly around the informational content of the interviewee's speech. Denaturalism ""(...) suggests that within speech are meanings and perceptions that construct our reality"" (Oliver et al. 2005
column3: p.1274). '''This approach is more about ''what'' is said
column4: than ''how'' it is said
column5: ''' and is mostly relevant to research interested in how people conceive and communicate their world
column6: for example in Grounded Theory research (although there are also exceptions here) (Oliver et al. 2005

column1: '''Naturalized transcription is as detailed as possible
column2: ''' including stutters
column3: pauses and other idiosyncratic elements of speech. It attempts to provide more details and a more 'realistic' representation of the interviewee's speech. The idea is to reduce a loss of information
column4: be more 'objective' and true to the Interviewee(s)
column5: and thus impose less assumptions through the researcher. Naturalized Transcription is
column6: for example
column7: of interest when a conversation between individuals is recorded (in a group interview
column8: or a Focus Group)
column9: and the way in which these individuals interact with each other is of interest (overlapping talk
column10: turn-taking etc.) (Oliver et al. 2005
column11: p.1275.) Grammatical or spelling mistakes are not corrected in the transcript for naturalistic transcription (1). Also
column12: verbal cues that support the spoken word may elicit more insights for the researchers
column13: such as dialects
column14: increasing or decreasing volumes and specific emphases for individual words
column15: or pauses. For this purpose
column16: the transcript may include textual symbols to provide more information despite the words themselves:

column1: [[File:Transcribing Interviews - Naturalized textual symbols.png|700px|thumb|center|'''Textual symbols in naturalized transcription.''' Source: Oliver et al. 2005
'''Naturalized transcription concerns itself more with ''how'' individuals speak and converse.''' However
column2: the researcher needs to weigh whether this level of detail is necessary for the specific research intent
column3: since it leads to a considerable increase in transcription effort.

column1: No matter the approach to transcription
column2: it is important to acknowledge that any transcript is a re-construction of the Interview done by the researcher. As Skakauskaite (2012
column3: p.24) highlights: ""Transcribing (...) is a form of analysis that is shaped by the researchers' examined and unexamined theories and assumptions
column4: ideological and ethical stances
column5: relationships with participants
column6: and the research communities of which one is a member"". '''A researcher that bases his or her analysis on Interview transcripts needs to acknowledge this role he or she imposes on the data in the subsequent analysis and interpretation.''' A lack of reflexivity in this regard may distort the research results
column7: and impede interpretation especially in-between different research communities. Oliver et al. (2005) therefore suggests researchers to reflect upon the chosen approach and which challenges emerge based on it.

column2: Skakauskaite (2012
column3: p.25) calls for more transparent information on the construction of transcripts in research publications: ""What we can learn and know about human activity and interaction depends on how we use language data and what choices we make of how to turn audio (and/or video) records into written texts
column4: what to represent and not represent
column5: and how to represent it. Given that there is no single way of transcribing
column6: making transparent transcribing decisions and theories guiding those decisions
column7: can provide grounded warrants for claims researchers make about observed (and recorded) human actions and interactions."" Therefore
column8: a proper documentation of the chosen approach
column9: the underlying rationale
column10: and the challenges that were recognized is advisable. Also
column11: asking peers to assess the transcript
column12: or attempting member checking - i.e.
column13: interviewees check the transcripts for accuracy - may improve the transcript to this end (1).

column1: Oliver et al. (2005) list a range of challenges in the translation of recorded speech to text. These include technical issues
column2: such as bad recording quality. Further
column3: transcribers may mis-interpret pronunciation
column4: slang or accents
column5: and write down incorrect words. Also
column6: involuntary vocalizations
column7: such as coughing or laughing
column8: may provide additional information to supplement speech
column9: but also not be of meaning
column10: which may be hard to decide. Lastly
column11: non-verbal cues such as waving or gesticulations may add information to the spoken word
column12: but are only analyzable if recorded on video and/or noted down during the interview
column13: and subsequently added to the transcript.

column1: '''The act of transcription may prove cumbersome.''' Typically
column2: the transcription of recorded text may take between 5-10 times as long as the Interview
column3: although this may differ between researchers and depending on the transcription approach. In any case
column4: the time needed for transcription needs to be factored into the research schedule. Further
column5: long sessions of transcribing Interviews are exhaustive
column6: and may lead to inaccuracies in later datasets. Researchers should therefore consider transcribed Interviews right after they were conducted
column7: if possible.

column2: with several interviews conducted possibly in different regions
column3: there will typically be more than one transcriber
column4: and '''the transcriber may not always be the researcher'''. Therefore
column5: to maintain accurate and comparable transcripts
column6: and provide intersubjective data readibility
column7: the approach to transcribing and a clear denomination of what is important
column8: what is not
column9: and how to deal with specific data
column10: is important to define and discuss prior to the process
column11: and whenever issues emerge (Oliver et al. 2005).

column1: The most crucial point for a smooth transcription is the '''quality of recording'''. The researcher should pay great attention to producing a high quality recording during the interview situation
column2: or later in working with the recorded material
column3: to save time in the transcription process. This includes
column4: for example
column5: proper handling of the recording device
column6: avoiding or filtering out background noises
column7: or
column8: if necessary
column9: asking interviewees to repeat phrases that were not understandable during the interview itself.

column2: it is advisable to transcribe data not too long after gathering it
column3: in case certain phrases are not understandable in the recording
column4: and memory can better help recall. However
column5: a '''time lag between recording and transcription''' can help the researcher distancing themselves from the interview situation and allow for greater objectivity in listening. If the data gathering took time long before the transcription
column6: it is recommendable for the transcriber to listen to the complete recording again before starting the transcription in order to recall the conversation as a whole
column7: and be able to pay attention to details and the informational content
column8: which can be helpful to properly create the transcript (1).

column2: it is advisable to '''play the recorded text at a slower speed and type simultaneously''' - the author of this entry has made good experiences with a 0.7x speed for denaturalistic transcription. However
column3: the preferable speed depends on the speed that the transcriber can type at (see [[Speed Typing]])
column4: and while slower replays of the recordings will extend the transcription process
column5: a quicker replay is more prone to mistakes and misunderstandings. This is especially relevant for fast speaking interviewees
column6: heavily accented speech
column7: or naturalistic transcription approaches
column8: where more time will be needed to perceive all details. The replay should be done using a device or software that can easily be accessed
column9: like a phone
column10: recording device
column11: or second screen on the computer. This is because sections of the recording may be necessary to replay several times. A single skip should be possible by the press of a button
column12: and adjusted to a preferable time span
column13: e.g. 2 seconds back
column14: to simplify this.

column2: the text may be structured and punctuations may be added to improve legibility
column3: while the impact this act has on the transcript should be acknowledged. The same is true for the use of paragraphs and line-breaks in the text
column4: which are advisable for turn-by-turn dialogic interactions or longer monologues
column5: but also influence the way the expressed arguments are represented in the written text. To allow for quotations
column6: the lines of '''the transcript should be numbered''' or time codes should be added at the end of each paragraph (2). A transcript template may be advisable to help standardize the transcripts (1).

column2: f4transkript or the transcription function of MAXQDA offer a range of settings to easily handle different of the above mentioned aspects. Autotranscription programs can also be used
column3: albeit only for the denaturalistic approach. However
column4: the time saver effect is limited because training the program for voice recognition takes time
column5: and transcription accuracy still has to be validated and corrected by hand.

column2: the '''identity of the interviewee should be secured''' in the transcribed text by attributing a number
column3: pseudonym or code to the interview (1). This should be done in a way that supports easy data management and file access. If member checking is planned
column4: the transcriber should leave space in the transcript file for potential comments (1).

Transdisciplinarity;"'''Note:''' The German version of this entry can be found here: [[Transdisciplinarity (German)]]
'''In short:''' Transdisciplinarity is a research approach that is commonly applied in Sustainability & Transformation Research
column2: focusing on the collaboration of academic and non-academic actors with a solution-oriented perspective. The following entry introduces the approach
column3: its characteristics and prevalent challenges
column4: and illustrates the use of methods with examples.

column2: Inter- and Transdisciplinarity ==

it should first be distinguished from multidisciplinarity and interdisciplinarity. This is especially relevant when comparing German-speaking and English-speaking resources: the US-American understanding of transdisciplinarity is rather comparable to interdisciplinarity
column3: while the German-speaking discourse is based on the following distinctions.

column1: * '''Multidisciplinarity''' revolves around the cooperation between different academic disciplines for one research endeavour. The researchers study the same topic in a parallel structure and all have their distinct goals and research questions. They share knowledge and compare their findings and may also combine their results in one big report
column2: but the disciplinary boundaries generally remain intact. (Stock & Burton 2011)

column1: * '''Interdisciplinarity''' is a research mode that deploys a higher level of cooperation between researchers from different
column2: often rather unrelated disciplines. Disciplinary viewpoints are crossed and integrated to develop new perspectives in order to create new knowledge or re-assess existing
column3: disciplinary knowledge. As an example
column4: political scientists and ecologists may come together to jointly study a eco-political issue.  (Stock & Burton 2011)

column2: then
column3: can be seen as the next higher step. Transdisciplinarity is ""a reflexive
column4: integrative
column5: method-driven scientific principle aiming at the solution or transition of societal problems and concurrently of related scientific problems by differentiating and integrating knowledge from various scientific and societal bodies of knowledge."" (Lang et al. 2012
column6: p.26f). The most important features here are

column1: ** the collaboration of academia and society in a mutual learning and research process where stakeholders (politicians
column2: entrepreneurs
column3: NGO representatives
column4: citizens etc.) are involved at all stages
column5: i.e. in the framing of the problem
column6: the development of possible solutions and the creation of new scientific knowledge
column7: with a focus on these stakeholders contributing their specific knowledge and experiences to broaden the research perspective;

column2: such as questions of sustainable development
column3: that strongly affect and interest not only the academic sphere
column4: but also the economy
column5: culture and politics; as well as

column1: ** the development of solutions to the studied problems that are transferable both into scientific and practical discourses and action. (Stock & Burton 2011
column2: Lang et al. 2012
column3: Arnold & Piontek 2018
column4: Mauser et al. 2013; Ruppert-Winkel et al. 2015).

column1: == Why should (Sustainability) Science engage with the public? ==
Throughout the last centuries and decades
column2: the differentiation and [[Glossary|institutionalisation]] of scientific disciplines allowed academia to develop and deepen specified conceptual and methodological expertise and create distinct language and topics that have enabled these disciplines to provide plenty of insightful knowledge and guidance for society (Stock & Burton 2011). However
column3: '''there has been an increasing recognition that disciplinary viewpoints and approaches may no longer be sufficient to solve prevalent challenges''' that span across several scientific and societal spheres. Examples for this are ecological threats such as biodiversity loss or socio-technological challenges such as digitalisation which demand the creation of new theoretical and empirical scientific insights
column4: but also action-oriented solutions that can be applied in policy
column5: business
column6: education
column7: culture and such. With his landmark 1994 publication
column8: Michael Gibbons introduced the term ""Mode 2 research"" which highlights this emerging form of scientific inquiry that is ""characterised by closer interaction between scientific
column9: technological and industrial modes of knowledge production
column10: by the weakening of disciplinary and institutional boundaries
column11: by the emergence of more or less transient clusters of experts
column12: often grouped around large projects of various kinds
column13: and by the broadening of the criteria of quality control and by enhanced social accountability."" (Gibbons 1994

column2: multi- and interdisciplinary research modes (see above) are research modes that already cross disciplinary boundaries to some extent
column3: sharing knowledge or jointly creating it
column4: but transdisciplinary research best represents this new form of knowledge production. Mode 2 research and transdisciplinary research have therefore often been used synonymously. Transdisciplinary research facilitates the creation of not only system knowledge (the current state) and target knowledge (the intended state)
column5: but especially of transformational knowledge (how to get there) that considers the demands and preconditions of all relevant stakeholders. Thus
column6: transdisciplinary research is of particular interest where there is a lack of practical knowledge about a specific problem
column7: solution pathways are not yet known and there is a need for societal negotiation throughout the development of solutions. (Arnold & Piontek

column1: '''Transdisciplinary research is of special importance to Sustainability Science and has received immense recognition in this field in the last years.''' This is because ""[s]ustainability is also inherently transdisciplinary"" (Stock & Burton 2011
column3: as it builds on the premise of solving real-world problems which are deeply nestled in ecological
column4: political
column5: economic and social processes and structures and therefore cannot be understood and solved without engaging with these spheres (Kates et al. 2015). column1: == How to do TD in Sustainability Science ==

column2: we will refer to the ideal-typical model presented by Lang et al (2012). It introduces a conceptual guide
column3: structured into three phases
column4: on how transdisciplinary research for sustainability science should ideally be conducted. The relevant steps of each phase as well as general principles for the whole process will be listed below. The presented process is recursive: Problems emerging in scientific as well as societal practice are integrated in the transdisciplinary research approach. After its three phases have been realized
column5: the newly generated knowledge and solutions are re-integrated into these two spheres
column6: where they are applied and consolidated. Ultimately
column7: new challenges emerge that demand renewed transdisciplinary collaboration.

The choice of methods for TD research is also relevant for the level of [[Glossary|agency]] and participation that is provided to the non-scientific stakeholders in the process. One may differentiate four levels of [[Agency
column2: Complexity and Emergence|agency]] on which societal actors are involved in scientific research (see also Brandt et al. 2013):

column2: most commonly in form of questionnaires and interviews
column3: which provides input or feedback to proposed or active research. Stakeholders provide information
column4: which is of interest to the researchers
column5: but are not actively involved in the research process.

column3: and/or are directly involved in the decision-making process at the collaboration level. Empowerment surpasses mere collaboration since stakeholders are enabled to engage with existing problems themselves
column4: rather than relying on research for each individual issue anew.

german/ ""Besatzfisch""] is a good example of a long-term transdisciplinary research project that engages with different methodological approaches. This four year project attempted to '''understand the ecological
column3: social and economic role and effects of stocking fish in natural ecosystems.''' First
column4: fish was introduced to ecosystems and the subsequent population dynamics were qualitatively & quantitatively measured
column5: much of this jointly with the cooperating anglers (''Cooperation''). Second
column6: anglers were questioned about fish population sizes and their economic implications (''Consultation'') before the data was analyzed using monetary modelling. Third
column7: decision-making processes were modelled based on conversations with anglers
column8: and their mental models about fishing were evaluated (''Consultation''). Fourth
column9: participatory workshops were conducted to help anglers optimize their fishing grounds (''Empowerment''). Fifth
column10: social-ecological models were developed based on the previous empirical results. (''Consultation'') Sixth
column11: the project results are published in different forms of media for different target groups (''Information'').

column1: '''In short:''' A treemap is a rectangle-based visualization method for large
column2: hierarchical data sets. Originally designed to visualize files on a hard drive and developed by Shneiderman and Johnson. They capture two types of information in the data: (1) the value of individual data points; (2) the structure of the hierarchy.

column1: Treemaps display hierarchical (tree-structured) [[Glossary|data]]. They are composed of a series of nested rectangles (tiles) whose areas are proportional to the data they represent. Each branch of the tree is given a rectangle
column2: which is then subdivided into smaller rectangles representing sub-branches. The conceptual idea is to break down the data into its constituent parts and quickly identify its large and small components.

column1: 1. To study data with respect to two quantitative values:
– positive quantitative value standing for the size of the rectangle (area cannot be negative) and
– second or categorical quantitative value standing for the color of the individual rectangles.
2. To display very large amount of hierarchial data in a limited space.

column2: high-level summary of the similarities and differences within one category as well as between multiple categories (not precise comparisons).

column1: The efficient use of physical space and the intelligent color management make treemaps powerful visualization technique applied to a wide variety of domains. They are used to display significant amounts of information in financial
column2: commercial
column3: governmental and similar fields. The treemap on Fig.1 shows Switzerland imports in 2017.

column1: [[File:Motorbikestreemap.png|300px|thumb|right|Fig.2: Category-wise sales figure for motorbikes. Source: www.fusioncharts.com]]
'''Adding new Dimensions.''' With the intelligent use of colors
column2: new dimensions can be added to the diagram. The usual practice is to use color in different rectangles to indicate a second categorical or quantitative value. If color is used to express a quantitative value
column3: it’s strongly encouraged to use only one color (if all the numbers are positive) or two colors (one for negative and one for positive)
column4: and vary the intensity of the color to express precise value.

column1: The following treemap (Fig.2) illustrates the category-wise (Street
column2: Cruiser and etc.) sales figure for motorbikes. The size of the rectangles within each category indicates the relative number of sales. Different colors and color intensities show growth and declines of the motorbike sales. “Static” shows that sales neither grew nor declined. Very intense orange indicates a big shift downward
column3: and very intense green indicates a big shift upwards.

column1: From Fig.2 it can be concluded that appropriate use of color enables us to use tree maps to represent losses
column2: declines in sales or other non-positive values. The second quantitative value is not represented by the area of the rectangle.

column1: The way the rectangle is divided and arranged into sub-rectangles depends on '''the tiling algorithm''' used.
Many tiling algorithms have been developed and here are some of them:
'''Squarified''' - keeps each rectangle as square as possible. It also tries to order the consecutive elements of the dataset (blocks
column2: tiles) in descending order from the upper left corner to the lower right corner of the graph.

column1: '''Slice and Dice''' uses parallel lines to divide a root into branches (large rectangles). Then they are subdivided into smaller rectangles representing sub-branches again by using parallel lines. At each level of the hierarchy the orientation of the lines is switched (vertical vs. horizontal).

''' In short:''' Mental maps are a visual representation of how people perceive their daily environment and how people orient themselves in it. The ''Walking Exercise'' makes use of this strategy to initially build sustainability competencies in higher education settings.
[[File:VisualisationMentalMapsWALKINGEXERCISE.png|thumb|right|mental maps of Phoenix (a + b) and Hamburg (c + d). Source: (1)]]
The world and environment are in a critical state as there are certain sustainability challenges
column2: such as biodiversity loss
column3: global warming
column4: limited resources
column5: and increased inequalities. From this
column6: the need to react to them arises
column7: both locally and globally. Developing certain sustainability competencies (skills
column8: abilities) can be a start to learn how to do so. Wiek et al. (1) have sketched out five competencies that should be considered for academic program development. These are as follows: systems thinking
column9: anticipatory competence
column10: normative competence
column11: strategic competence
column12: and interpersonal/collaborative competence. Based on these
column13: Caniglia et al. (2) have worked out a method
column14: aiming at building some of the aforementioned competencies
column15: which is called ''Walking exercise''. The method combines mental mapping and exploratory walking.

column1: '''Mental mapping''' stems from the field of behavioural geography and was especially coined by Kevin Lynch and his work “The Image of the City” (3). It captures how people perceive their urban environment. Practically speaking
column2: a person’s image of a city is their mental map of it. The map usually entails the following characteristics:

column1: * paths: routes along which people move throughout the city;
* edges: boundaries and breaks in continuity;
* districts: areas characterized by common characteristics;

Why statistics matters;"'''In short:''' This entry provides a very brief overview on why you should care about statistics.

'''I consider statistics to be very powerful.''' Statistics became established over the last decades as one of the most important and abundantly used methods in modern science. Due to the development of modern computers and the manifestation of smartphones in the individual's daily life
column2: there is a wealth of information available today. This triggered an almost co-evolutionary pattern where statistics evolved further in tandem with the increase of available data. While initially statistics focused on the calculation in astronomy and was widely preoccupied with testing hypotheses
column3: this has vastly changed today. Much of the data that is available today is not harvested through [[Experiments|systematic experiments]]. Instead we all generate data. There is a swarm intelligence of data being formed. The most popular example is the internet which is basically one big junk of data including many datasets about us people as well as our planet that is not analysed to date. More analysis emerge out of the wealth of information and many of them are based on statistics.

column1: Statistics thus enable us to find [[Glossary|patterns]]
column2: building on large datasets we can aim to find relation and meaning within complex issues and maybe even sometimes reason and explanation. While it is widely a question of the epistemological development of science as well as a clear domain of philosophy the approximation of facts is something that is at the heart of statistics as well. It is within the power of statistics to unravel what we can understand of a given system or dataset. However
column3: it should also be clear what we cannot understand. Very often this is a crucial point: Statistics does not only allow us to be critical of our analysis but also of our understanding and ultimately ourselves. The power of statistics can thus be also framed as the power of understanding our own limitations. Very often the most vital understanding is that we do not understand a lot after all. Here qualitative science and some other would argue first and foremost statistics are often associated with a certain arrogance. Out of that arrogance of statistics to provide answers and
column4: I would argue
column5: also the missing opportunity of researchers to experience societal phenomena
column6: there is often a large scepticism towards statistics. It should be in our power now to hear these misunderstandings and to start building bridges between the conflicting parties. Scientists building on statistics are not only widely disconnected from qualitative researchers
column7: but also from the dominating discourses in society. Only if statistics is integrated into the broader diversity of knowledge that science currently unfolds
column8: we can unleash its full potential.

column1: '''We should aim to maximise our understandings based on statistics if it is possible
column2: but we also need to be aware of the mere fact that statistics will not provide us with all the answers.''' Most statisticians are well aware of that
column3: but science went a little bit on the wrong track when results derived from statistical analysis were communicated. The confidence of the statistical results is overall very clear when it comes to numbers
column4: although these numbers mean different things to different people. Furthermore
column5: numbers have context in certain settings
column6: and this makes it highly implausible that the same number will always mean the same under any given circumstances. If I would proclaim a thought experiment where you have a 10% chance of dying then everybody would be quite unhappy to hear that they have a certain chance of sudden death. If you have on the other hand a lethal disease but a 10% chance of survival
column7: you would probably want to hold onto that 10%. In our desperation
column8: many would hope and take the 10% chance. Quite often our recognition of numbers is flawed. Imagine that you could join a lottery for a fantastic new computer. 10 Euros today buy you a 10% chance to win this computer tomorrow. Many would probably join in and try to take their chance in this thought experiment. However
column9: not too many would join in if they could get a 10% chance with the same amount of money in 10 years. The chances in this example did not change at all. However a 10% chance tomorrow is just different to most people then a 10% chance in 10 years.

column1: Humans are constructed in a sense where the distant future
column2: the distant past
column3: but also distant places are unreasonably less important to us then they should be. On the other hand
column4: are things close to us unreasonably more important for most people (Parfit
column6: pp. 56–57). Statistics do not have that floor. They are of course [[Bias in statistics|biased]] through the people that conduct them. However
column7: the predictive power of statistics may enable us to do more guided actions. If more people would be able to find structures and patterns in data
column8: they could take more informed decisions. This might be one steppingstone to overcome unreasonable behaviour at least partially. If we would be able to route our decisions more deeply in the rigorous analysis of statistics
column9: then many of their perceptions and approximations that people have of reality might be quite different
column10: and this may influence our behaviour. Right now
column11: the actions of the majority of people are mostly disconnected from statistical data. If more people would have the possibility to understand at least a glimpse of statistics
column12: then transparency and reflexivity could be potentially achieved. It is within our power now to cease the possibilities of statistics
column13: and to translate them into a better understanding of our world.

column1: '''Science creates knowledge.''' This knowledge production follows certain principles. Being a statistician with all the experience I had the privilege to perceive to date
column2: I recognize this as one of the biggest challenge of statistics. Many people
column3: especially those new to statistics
column4: feel a strong urge towards freedom. I think this is wonderful. Radical thinking moves us all forward. However
column5: because of this urge for freedom already existing knowledge is often not valued
column6: as the radical thought for the new is stronger than the appreciation of the already established. This is
column7: in my experience
column8: the first grave challenge that the field of statistics faces. People reject the principles of statistics out of the urge to be radical. I say
column9: be radical
column10: but also [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standing_on_the_shoulders_of_giants stand] [https://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/learningenglish/movingwords/shortlist/newton.shtml on the shoulders] [https://www.bookbrowse.com/expressions/detail/index.cfm/expression_number/504/on-the-shoulders-of-giants of giants].

column1: The second grave challenge of statistics is numbers per se. Most people are not fond of numbers. Some are even afraid. Fear is the worst advisor. Numbers are nothing to be afraid of
column2: and likewise
column3: statistics are nothing to be afraid of either. Yet learning statistics is no short task
column4: and this is the third obstacle I see.

statistics became a launchpad for much of the exponential development we observe up until today. While correlation and the Analysis of Variance ([[ANOVA]]) are a bit like the daily bread and butter of statistics
column3: the research focus of the inventor of the ANOVA -[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A8gD3CcbDTY Ronald Fisher] - on Eugenics is a testimony that statistics can also be misused or used to create morally questionable or repugnant assumptions. Despite these drawbacks
column4: statistics co-evolved with the rise of computers and became a standard approach in the quantitative branch of science.

column2: long-standing theories such as [https://www.countbayesie.com/blog/2015/2/18/hans-solo-and-bayesian-priors Bayes Theorem] could be tested
column3: and many new statistical methods developed. Development of statistics led also to new developments in science
column4: as for instance
column5: multivariate statistics paved the road to look at messy datasets
column6: and machine learning revolutionised the way we approach information in the age of computers.

column1: For another perspective on the history of statistics
column2: we can highly recommend you the [https://www.wnycstudios.org/podcasts/radiolab/episodes/91684-stochasticity Radiolab Podcast about Stochasticity] as well as the longer entry on the [[History of Methods]].

column1: Statistics is about simplification of complex realities
column2: or about finding patterns in more or fewer complex data. Such simplifications are often called [https://jamesclear.com/all-models-are-wrong models].

column1: According to the statistician Box ""..all models are wrong
column2: but some models are useful. However
column3: the approximate nature of the model must always be borne in mind."" This famous quotation (Box and Draper 1987
column4: page 424) is often misunderstood. Box talked about specific - in this case polynomial - models. These represent approximations or simplifications and are hence inherently all wrong. Still
column5: some of these specific models can be useful. With this
column6: Box highlights the previously known ''principle of parsimony''.

column2: however
column3: often used to reject the idea of models altogether
column4: which is simply a mistake. There is another famous quote that is associated with Winston Churchill [http://howtogetyourownway.com/statistics/deception_with_statistics.html ""I only believe in statistics that I doctored myself""]. Most likely this sentence was never said by Churchill but was associated with him by Goebbels to discredit him (Barke
column5: 2011). This showcases that the discussion about the approximation of truth through statistics is a controversial one. Never forget that statistics can generate approximations of truths
column6: but I would argue it cannot generate fundamental truths.

column1: Is that a problem? NO! '''In most cases
column2: approximations will do.''' In other words
column3: it is quite easy to prove something as a fact
column4: but it is much harder to prove that something is not a fact. This is what any good conspiracy theory is built upon. Try to prove that flying saucers do not exist. Yet if one would land in front of you
column5: it is quite evident that there are flying saucers.

column1: This debate about truths has preoccupied philosophy for quite some time now
column2: and we will not bother ourselves with it here. If you look for generalisable truths
column3: I advise going to [https://www.philosophynews.com/post/2015/01/29/What-is-Truth.aspx philosophy]. But if you look for more tangible knowledge
column4: you are in the right place. Statistics is one powerful method to approximate truths.

column1: If we would want to understand everything through statistics
column2: we would need to sample everything. Clearly
column3: this is not possible. Therefore
column4: statisticians work with samples. [https://www.thoughtco.com/what-is-statistical-sampling-3126366 Samples] allow us to just look at a part of a whole
column5: hence allowing to find patterns that may represent a whole.

column1: Take an example of leaf size in a forest that consists of Beech trees. You clearly do not need to measure the leaves of all trees. However
column2: your sample should be ''representative''. So
column3: you would want to sample maybe small trees and large trees
column4: trees at the edge of the forest
column5: but also in the center. This is why in statistics people tend to take a ''[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A7fcdRhSp8k&feature=youtu.be random sample]''.

column2: since otherwise
column3: your analysis may be flawed. Much in statistics is dealing with sample designs that enable representative samples
column4: and there are also many analytics approaches that try to identify whether samples are flawed
column5: and what could be done if this is the case. Proper sampling is central in statistics. Therefore
column6: it is advisable to think early within a study about your sample design.

column1: [[File:R Logo.png|thumb|right|300px|R is a powerful tool for statistical analysis.]]
'''Analysing data takes experience.''' While computers and modern software triggered a revolution
column2: much can go wrong. There is no need to worry
column3: as this can be avoided through hard work. You have to practise to get good at statistical analysis. The most important statistical test can be learned in a few weeks
column4: but it takes time to build experience
column5: enabling you to know when to use which test
column6: and also how to sample data to enable which analysis.

column2: statistical analysis is made in specific software tools such as R
column3: SPSS or Stata
column4: or even programming languages such as Python or C++. Learning to apply these software tools and languages takes time. If you are versatile in statistical analysis
column5: you are rewarded
column6: since many people will need your expertise. There is more data than experienced statistical analysts in the world. But more importantly
column7: there are more open questions than answers in the world
column8: and some of these answers can be generated by statistical analysis.

column1: [[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-03-31 um 10.35.59.png|right|400px|thumb|left|The ""Sonntagsumfrage"" in Germany asks on weekly basis which party citizens would vote for if there would be elections on Sunday. The results are always presented in '''barplots'''.]]

[[File:Bildschirmfoto 2020-03-31 um 10.35.47.png|thumb|400px|Another form of presenting election results is the '''pie chart'''. In this example it visualizes the results of the state election in Hessen in 2009.]]
Within current media as well as the Internet
column2: the most dominating forms of presenting statistical results are the barplot and the pie chart. The first can have some merits in illustrating simple numbers; the second one is often considered to be misleading if not manipulative. However
column3: these two graphics represent the current baseline of knowledge of civil society when it comes to the [https://www.datapine.com/blog/misleading-statistics-and-data/ presentation of statistical results]. Sometimes certain newspapers as well as the Internet present simple correlation plots that are rather intuitive and therefore also understandable for people with some background in science. A prominent example is the [https://www.investopedia.com/ask/answers/042215/what-are-some-examples-positive-correlation-economics.asp Economist]
column4: which due to its topical focus quite often relies on correlation plots.

column2: most mainstream graphics that represent statistical results have more of an [https://www.open.edu/openlearn/science-maths-technology/mathematics-and-statistics/statistics/statistics-and-the-media aesthetic value] instead of a true representation of statistical results. When it comes to the actual numbers
column3: only people with an education in science are more or less able to interpret terms such as significance
column4: estimate or correlation. Here
column5: it can be hoped that the landscape will change in the mid-term. Since the dawn of the personal computer and with a broader access to [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4008059/ knowledge] through our mobile phones and the Internet
column6: many people have the possibility to explore statistical results
column7: or at least get in touch with statistical results
column8: even if indirectly.

column1: While software for analysing statistical data was in the past widely restricted to experts
column2: the computer revolution even offers [https://www.r-project.org/ open source solutions] available to many people. Hence the proportion of people that are able to code
column3: do statistical analysis
column4: and understand the presentation of statistical results is dramatically increasing. If everybody would be able to interpret correlations and box plots
column5: and would have clear understanding of statistical significance
column6: we would be able to talk of progress.

column1: [https://fs.blog/2015/11/map-and-territory/ ""The map is not the territory""] basically means that maps are a [http://www.nlpls.com/articles/mapTerritory.php generalisation] and therefore reduce the detailed richness/the richness of details of the territory. It took me very long to get this sentence. While it simply suggests that reality is different from the representation in a map
column2: I think the sentence puzzled me because in my head it is kind of the other way around. The territory is not the [[Geographical Information Systems|map]]. This is how a statistician would probably approach this matter. Statistics are about generalisation
column3: and so are maps. If you would have a map that would contain every detail of the [https://wiki.lesswrong.com/wiki/The_map_is_not_the_territory reality] how you perceive it
column4: it would not only be a gigantic map
column5: but it would be completely useless for orientation in the territory. Maps are so fantastic at least to me because they allow us through clever and sometimes not so clever representation of the necessary details to orientate ourselves in unknown terrain. Important landmarks such as mountains and forests
column6: rivers or buildings allow us to locate ourselves within the territory.

column1: Many maps often coined thematic maps include specific information that is represented in the map and that follows again a generalisation. For example
column2: land-use maps may contain information about agriculture pastures
column3: forests and urbanisation
column4: but for the sake of being understandable do not differentiate into finer categories. Of course for the individual farmer this would not be enough in order to allow for nuanced and contextual land use strategy. However
column5: through the overview we gain an information that we would not get if the map would be too detailed.

column1: Statistics works kind of in the same way. If we looked at any given data point within a huge dataset we would probably be incapable of understanding general patterns. Likewise statistics does draw conclusion from the complicated if not complex data and are able to find meaning or explanations in the plateau of data. Hence I agree that if I want to get a feeling about a specific city that I visit then a map would probably not bring me very far in terms of absorbing the atmosphere of the city. Yet without a map it would be tricky to know where I would be going and how I find my way home again. Our individual data points are often very important to -you guessed it- individuals but the overall patterns are important to many of us. Or at least they should be
column2: I think. But this is [[Big problems for later|another matter]]. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x9BCsy77mlU The map is not the territory]
column3: but the territory is also not the map.

column1: Wordcloud is a cluster of words or visualisation of the most commonly or frequently used terms within a given dataset of words. The basic principle is that the higher the frequency
column2: the more prominent the word is in the figure. Wordcloud is a relatively easy and quick text-mining tool which allows to get a rough overview of the word usage within the dataset
column3: which can give further ideas when studying word usage frequency. Wordclouds can also help get first impression of the differences or similarities when working with two textual datasets.

column2: wordclouds rarely need additional explanation of the visualised results.

column1: * Straightforward and colourful figure can be often used for aesthetic purposes and in order to quickly get one’s point across.
[[File:HarryWordCloud.png|300px|thumb|right|'''A Wordcloud of the most commonly used words in the Harry Potter book series.''' Unfortunately
column2: this gives little insight since the result of the visualisation is quite predictable. [https://public.tableau.com/app/profile/dave.andrade/viz/WordCloudsandWizardry/HarryPotterWordCloudDashboard Source]]]

column1: * If your data set is not prepared and cleaned you might get little to no insight into the data. In this context
column2: ""cleaning"" refers to the deletion of double spaces
column3: numbers
column4: punctuation
column5: fill words (""and""
column7: ""but""
column9: ""at"" etc.) and shifting all words to lowercase
column10: among other measures.

column1: * It is important to have a clear idea why this method is being applied and for which purposes. Otherwise the wordcloud will simply visualise evident or common words with no use for research.

* A general disadvantage of wordclouds is caused by the so-called [https://www.data-to-viz.com/caveat/area_hard.html “area is a bad metaphor”] phenomenon. Human eyes can have difficulty visually identifying the size of an area
column2: in this context
column3: a word’s size compared to the other words around it. Analytical accuracy of such visualisations can be especially compromised if the words have different lengths: wordclouds tend to emphasise long words over short words as shorter words need less space and thus might appear smaller.

column1: * Wordclouds consider one word at a time. So
column2: for example
column3: if customers often describe the product they purchased as “not good” in their reviews
column4: the wordcloud will be likely to visualise it as “not” and “good” separately. Taken into account that the words are allocated randomly in the cloud
column5: this only further impairs an accurate analysis of the visualisation.

column2: wordclouds can be a good intro exercise when getting familiar with text mining and neural language processing. It offers a simple and comprehensible visualisation
column3: however its features are quite limited if a thorough textual analysis is required. As an alternative
column4: it might be better to use a [[Barplots
column5: _Histograms_and_Boxplots#Barplots|barplot]] or [https://www.data-to-viz.com/graph/lollipop.html a lollipop chart]
column6: since they also make it possible to rank words by usage frequency. For example
column7: you can easily allocate the tenth most common word in a barplot
column8: whereas in a wordcloud you might struggle to see the difference in sizes after identifying the first 5 most commonly used terms.

column2: Why & When ==

column1: The World Café is a method for facilitating discussions in big groups. With many participants
column2: discussion rounds tend to be sprawling
column3: slow and dominated by strong speakers. If you want to facilitate a discussion that is more effective
column4: energetic
column5: and inclusive
column6: the World Café is a helpful technique. It divides participants into moderated subgroups
column7: who then wander together through a parcours of stations with different questions
column8: all the while the atmosphere is relaxed and casual like in a café.

column1: Splitting big groups into subgroups fosters inclusive
column2: energetic
column3: effective and in-depth discussions:

column1: * reserved speakers can feel more comfortable speaking in a smaller group
* the parcours format allows people to physically move through the room in between discussions
* the moderator can steer the discussion towards unexplored issues with every new subgroup
* every participant contributed to the collective results in the end

column2: room capacities and questions you want to discuss
column3: different stations are set up (can be tables
column4: boards
column5: flipcharts etc.) with a moderator who will introduce the question and lead the discussion. The participants will be divided into as many subgroups as there are stations. Each subgroup will visit every station. The moderator welcomes the subgroup participants and introduces the question. Within a given time slot
column6: the subgroups will discuss the question and write down their ideas and insights
column7: before they then wander to the next station. The moderators remain with their station and welcome the next group. They present the question plus a broad overview of the insights of the former group and deepen the discussion with the new group. After the parcours has been completed by all subgroups
column8: the moderators present the collective discussion results of each question to the full group.

column1: It is helpful to have one moderator who is in charge of the clock and who manages the parcours direction.

column2: you will find a range of material that is hopefully useful to you when you prepare your paper.

column1: The target audience is research students and other early career researchers
column2: especially (but not only) in the environmental sciences and sustainability. My own background is in the natural sciences
column3: but I have also worked with social scientists a fair bit. My suggestions are necessarily biased by my own experience. If you work in a field that is very different from mine
column4: you may find that some of my suggestions are not as useful to you as others: but hopefully you will still find that some of the material is useful.

column1: Before you write an article for publication in a journal
column2: there are a few basic things that are good to think about.

column1: ''Content:'' You need to know what it is that you are planning to write about. Once you know what you want to write about
column2: there is still the question of how to best present the content. Many papers with solid content could have been published in much more highly ranked journals if they were presented slightly differently. The issue in such cases is not so much the main content as such
column3: but how it is prioritized
column4: structured
column5: at which length and level of depth it is communicated
column6: how it is embedded in current debates
column7: and how it is framed.

column1: ''Your target journal:'' You need to understand your target journal – what will appeal to the readers
column2: to the editors
column3: and what kinds of particular policies does the journal have. There are papers that are very good but are rejected because they are submitted to the ‘wrong’ journal. Moreover
column4: there are brilliant papers that are accepted in a good journal – but then nobody reads them! That can happen if the paper is a poor fit relative to what the journal overall is about. Study your journals a bit
column5: flick through recent tables of contents
column6: find out something about the editors
column7: read how the journal presents itself in its ‘scope’ section
column8: and so on. You will find that the same content might fit quite different journals
column9: depending on how it is structured and presented.

column1: For a given quality of science
column2: how the paper is framed probably makes the biggest difference for where it is published
column3: and how well read and cited it will be. Framing
column4: essentially
column5: is how you fit your paper into the ‘bigger picture’
column6: or if you prefer a less neutral term
column7: it is how you sell your paper. My general advice is that you choose the largest plausible frame for your paper that is reasonable. In other words
column8: to make sure you’re widely read it makes sense to find a big hook off which to hang your paper – but you have to be careful not to oversell your work. This is subjective.

column1: Typical choices for framing papers are current global issues
column2: big theories and new theories
column3: particularly those that are controversial. The trick then is to make the link from the ‘big issue’ to your study as swiftly and directly as possible at the beginning; and back to the same big issue (plus sometimes additional ones) near the end of the study. A good frame is one that appears reasonable and can be directly linked to your work
column4: and one that your work directly speaks to. A bad frame is one that takes a lot of imagination to see how your study fits in with it
column5: and that your results don’t have a lot to do with.

column1: Often but not always your framing is partly determined by how you planned your study (as opposed to your paper) in the first instance.
* Brainstorm a list of possible frames. Initially
column2: don’t be too selective — just write down lots of possible frames  that might be connected with your paper.

column1: * Read your discipline: where are things at? What’s currently a hot topic? What kinds of topics have recently been published in the most prestigious journals? Does your work fit in with any of those topics?
* Generally: can you use a certain bandwagon for your benefit
column2: and jump on it for a bit? Don’t actually change your focus too much — but can your focus be twisted ever so slightly so that it becomes interesting to a broader audience?

column1: I suggest several phases to a paper:
# Think about what you want to write. When I say ‘think about’
column2: this thinking could take many different forms. Ironically
column3: some people only think clearly when they write
column4: others need a whiteboard
column5: others need to talk things through with their friends. No problem! The strategy does not matter
column6: as long as you come up with a sound logic. Note
column7: however
column8: that if you do write at this stage
column9: don’t become too attached to your writing. This first step is really about clarifying your flow of the argument in your head. Communicating it effectively on paper is a separate step.

column1: # Think about where you want to publish your work. This is an iterative process
column2: with two main consequences. One
column3: you may need to re-think how you choose to frame your paper (see section on framing)
column4: and therefore you might have to go back to the previous step. Two
column5: you will find that there is a particular word count you need to fit within.

column1: # Now that you know the word count
column2: you need to fit the content to the length specifications that you need to work with.

column1: It is important that you prioritise what goes into your paper
column2: and what you leave out. Especially when you start out in research
column3: it seems appealing to pack in as much information as possible into your first few papers. After all
column4: you did a lot of research
column5: which was hard work – and you gained a lot of insights! Now surely it’s worthwhile communicating these insights as completely as possible.

column1: That logic holds only in part. Especially if you need to write a short paper (e.g. because that’s what the journal requirements are) it is critically important you set yourself some clear priorities about what matters
column2: and what doesn’t.

column1: But even when the word count is not a problem
column2: more is not necessarily better. Imagine a paper with three really good points (each of which makes you go “wow
column3: very clever”)
column4: two quite good points (which make you go “that’s a fair point”)
column5: and two reasonable points (which make you go “sure
column6: but not particularly exciting”). And now imagine an alternative
column7: shorter paper
column8: which just makes the three really good points. Which paper will leave a stronger impression on you?

column1: This might depend on what sort of a reader you are. But it stands to reason that the short paper
column2: with only really good points
column3: will keep a reader engaged for every single paragraph. The longer version of the same thing
column4: by contrast
column5: might have the reader drift off
column6: flick pages
column7: or skip on to a different paper. So
column8: don’t just think about the marginal contribution of an extra thought or extra text: of course
column9: more text always means more insight. But also think about the average quality of your thoughts: sometimes
column10: additional thoughts that are not particularly interesting just dilute the quality of your work
column11: leaving the reader to feel your paper is “just average” when in fact you had some very good points – but those may have got lost among the less good points.

column1: It is important that those bits of content that are really important to you are not overshadowed by other bits of content
column2: which actually are less important to you. If the important parts are overshadowed
column3: this effectively means they get lost among other
column4: less important parts. Overshadowing of important content most commonly happens because the good points receive too little space in the paper relative to other
column5: less important points.

column1: Two main strategies can help with this problem at a general level. First
column2: see my suggestions for prioritizing your content – the gist is to focus on your most exciting ideas
column3: and perhaps just leave some of your other thoughts untold. Second
column4: you can sometimes use supplementary online material to explain things that are not of central interest to all readers.

column2: I suggest you write a dot-point outline of your paper
column3: with all headings and sub-headings included; and dot point summaries of the main content below. Such a skeleton outline can be very helpful because it’s all about the logic and the flow. The wording is completely irrelevant at this stage
column4: because this outline needs to make sense only to you (and perhaps your co-authors).

column2: think about which sections are particularly important to you. The relative importance of a section should – to the extent possible – be mirrored by its length. In other words
column3: it is not a good idea to have 2000 words of background material
column4: followed by 200 words of brilliance
column5: before a 500 word conclusion. Much better
column6: in this example
column7: would be to have 700 words of background material
column8: followed by (well-structured) 1000 words of brilliance
column9: followed by a 250 word conclusion.

column2: and the general steps for planning a paper
column3: several times in an iterative fashion. What you end up with is a dot-point outline summarizing your headings and main argument
column4: including an indicative word count that each section will occupy. You can also add key references to this outline.

column1: Such an outline is an incredibly powerful way to start ""writing"" properly. The idea is to leave the actual writing until the content is completely clear. This has the advantage that you now know precisely what you want to say – you just have to put it into words. Sections that are too long
column2: rambling
column3: or don’t fit become virtually impossible if you follow this approach.

column2: again
column3: that if you are the kind of person who develops their thoughts as they write
column4: that’s not a problem. But don’t think your initial writing (even if it’s nicely worded prose) should be the same as the paper in the end. Once you have done your first bout of writing
column5: it’s still a good idea to condense things back into an outline
column6: and then write again.

column2: with practice
column3: you may not need this elaborate process
column4: but it is a pretty fail-safe approach.)

column1: * Write and re-write an outline for your paper until the logic is smooth

column2: consider different journal options — what does this mean for which content you may have to leave out
column3: and how many words would you devote to different sections if you were to submit to different journals?

column1: The content-to-length ratio accurately summarises what more and more high-end journals are all about: cramming as much exciting
column2: new information into as little space as possible. Not all journals make this a high priority
column3: but it is increasingly common. Journals that pride themselves of rapid turnaround
column4: have short papers
column5: have ‘Letters’ in the journal name
column6: regularly use supplementary online material
column7: and have high impact factors are very likely to like a high content-to-length ratio – whether they explicitly state this or not. If you get the sense that a high content-to-length ratio is expected of you
column8: it is particularly important that you prioritise your content and fit your content to the prescribed length. Your writing style also becomes more important
column9: because there is no room for extra words.

column2: you need to think about structure. Most people think of structure as something that applies to the paper as a whole. However
column3: structure is also important at finer scales
column4: such as the level of sections
column5: paragraphs
column6: and sentences.

column1: No matter what type of paper you write
column2: it needs to have a clear thread through it
column3: and sections need to clearly link. One of the challenges is that writing is linear – it has a start point and an end point. By contrast
column4: much academic content is complex – more like a website
column5: where things are related in many different directions. The challenge of writing is to turn the multi-facetted nature of the content (where everything is related and linked to everything else
column6: like the internet) into a simple
column7: one-directional argument.

column1: Some general principles hold. At the most general level
column2: it’s a good idea to start your paper broad
column3: have specific aims at the end of your introduction
column4: and then have a detailed ‘meaty’ part in the middle. Towards the end
column5: you need to get back to the big picture
column6: preferably the same context that you started with. The other general principle is that you must not assume background knowledge beyond the obvious in your discipline. In other words
column7: your chain of argument must not leave out steps that are actually important for the reader. Ask yourself how you would need to explain the general gist of your paper to your friend who studies a different discipline
column8: or to your aunt. A good structure tends to make sense even to ‘uninformed’ people. If they don’t get the basic structure you’re proposing
column9: it’s likely that you have left out important steps in your logic.

column1: I distinguish between a few different types of papers. Standard empirical papers tend to follow a standard structure: introduction
column2: methods
column3: results
column4: discussion
column5: conclusion
column6: acknowledgements
column7: references. Sub-headings are common (and useful) within methods and discussion
column8: in particular
column9: but sometimes also in the results section.

column1: Essay papers are fundamentally different. They have no set rules
column2: which makes it even more important that they follow a logical
column3: and clearly understandable thread. Often
column4: it’s a good idea to outline what this thread is specifically at the end of the Introduction. Also
column5: even though it’s an essay
column6: sub-headings can be immensely useful. Check your subheadings – if
column7: without any further information
column8: they tell a logical story
column9: you’ve probably worked out a useful structure.

column1: Review papers are different again. Again
column2: there is a lot of flexibility for how exactly those are prepared
column3: and it depends a lot on which journal you’re writing for. It’s worth noting that in ecology and conservation science
column4: journals are increasingly keen on quantitative reviews or meta-analyses (a statistical approach to extract patterns out of multiple case studies).

column1: No matter which kind of paper you write
column2: headings are critically important. Typically
column3: you will want to use 2-3 heading levels. You need to clearly differentiate these in style
column4: so that it’s easy for readers to see what you’re doing. E.g. use a bold 15 point font for main headings
column5: a bold 13 point font for subheadings
column6: and an italics 12 point font sub-sub-headings. It’s a good idea to match the journal style.

column1: * What type of paper are you planning to write?
* What is a logical sequence of headings?
A section consists of several paragraphs. The ‘rules’ that apply to structuring sections and paragraphs are pretty similar.

The first sentence and last sentence are disproportionately important. The first sentence needs to be as clear as possible about what the paragraph is about. Avoid first sentences that are just background
column2: or pick up the idea from the previous paragraph. If
column3: for example
column4: your paragraph is about limitations of a particular conceptual model
column5: a good first sentence might be:

column1: “The xxx conceptual model has several inherent limitations.” Or
column2: if your heading already says as much
column3: your first sentence can potentially go one step further
column4: such as: “Inherent limitations of the xxx conceptual model arise from factor X
column5: factor Y
column6: and factor Z.” In both cases
column7: the first sentence makes it very clear what must come next
column8: namely details about the limitations. This helps the reader in several ways. First
column9: she will know what the section will be all about; and second
column10: this helps her decide whether to read the paragraph or skip straight to the next one. The importance of allowing readers to skim-read cannot be overstated. A good document is one that enables us to quickly grasp the content. First sentences of paragraphs help immensely
column11: if they are well written.

column1: The last sentence of a paragraph or section has to fully wrap up the content. Make sure that your thought is not left hanging
column2: only 90 % complete. You need to fully finish your thought so the reader has no doubt about your intended ‘so what’. So
column3: when you think your paragraph is finished
column4: ask yourself: ‘So what?’ If you just need to read out the last sentence again
column5: you included the so-what. If
column6: however
column7: you need to come up with a new
column8: additional sentence
column9: it shows you hadn’t quite finished your thought. This little exercise won’t always work
column10: but it may help you to test yourself whether your take-home message would actually get through to the reader.

column1: Apart from the first and last sentences
column2: many paragraphs list things
column3: explain things
column4: discuss causal relationships
column5: or contrast things. In all cases
column6: simple phrases can help to make the argument clearer. Don’t be afraid of listing things as “First
column7: …” and so on
column8: or starting sentences with “Although …”. Simple words like these at the beginning of sentences can make it much easier for your reader to find the thread of your argument.

column2: and in your own draft
column3: check the first and last sentences of several paragraphs and sections. Do they introduce the content
column4: and wrap up the content? Or are thoughts left hanging?

column1: * Can you structure your argument within a paragraph more clearly? For example
column2: by using numbered lists
column3: or simple words that link your sentences causally?

column1: Direct sentences are easy to understand
column2: whereas indirect ones are difficult to understand.

column1: This was an example of a very direct sentence. It has a few properties:
# The most important notion comes first and tells you what the sentence is about.

column2: in this case two parallel phrases with identical grammar.

column1: # It uses simple words and avoids jargon. I used ‘direct’
column2: because it is a short and simple word. And to contrast it with something else
column3: I used ‘indirect’. I could also have used ‘convoluted’ or some other word
column4: but the simplest word is the one that creates the sharpest
column5: clearest
column6: black-and-white contrast to the other one. Note that the era of big words is finished
column7: at least in scientific writing! The simpler the better. You don’t come across as smart if you use (unnecessarily) big words
column8: but as overly complicated.

column1: # It uses unambiguous words. For example
column2: I used ‘whereas’
column3: which has only one meaning – I avoided ‘while’ because this has a temporal meaning as well as a contrasting meaning. Similarly
column4: I used ‘difficult’ and not ‘hard’
column5: because hard has multiple meanings.

column1: # It is short! Many short sentences are much easier to follow than few long ones.
Two additional questions concern tense and voice. Most academic writing is in past tense
column2: unless you report generic facts not related to your findings or other recently reported empirical findings. Most importantly
column3: make sure you do not accidentally jump between tenses.

column1: The use of passive voice was common in academic writing in the past. For example
column2: an ecologist might have reported “All animals heard or seen were recorded by two experienced observers”. Today
column3: this sentence would probably read “We counted all animals heard or seen”. Although writing in active voice is now preferred by many journals (some have it in their style guide!)
column4: this is not to be mixed up with necessarily using the first person. In the example above
column5: ‘we’ is the first person plural
column6: and so in this case
column7: indeed
column8: the active voice wording also uses a first person perspective. But take a typical sentence from a results section
column9: such as “Companies used a variety of strategies to market their green credentials”. This is an active voice sentence (in third person plural)
column10: and there is absolutely no need to somehow try to turn it into a first-person sentence. For example
column11: adding “We found that…” at the beginning of sentences is not necessary (though you will find that some authors now do just that) – in fact
column12: it makes the sentence longer and unnecessarily complicated.

column2: a warning for those operating in a German academic context…: modern academic writing in English is very different from classic academic writing in German. Avoid nested sentences
column3: long sentences
column4: hidden meanings or clever metaphors.

column2: you will develop your own writing style
column3: and that’s a good thing. However
column4: there are certain phrases that help in writing
column5: and others that should be avoided. Here is a short list of them; presumably very incomplete
column6: but nevertheless a starting point.

column1: |Etc. || spell out and end the list with ‘and’ or ‘or’
|A number of || Several or many; ideally list the actual number if possible
|… while … || … whereas … (use ‘while’ only in a temporal context)
|… as … || … because … (use ‘as’ only in a temporal context)

column2: … || By contrast
column3: … (though ‘in contrast’ is not technically wrong)
