roughly || Approximately
when and where?===

column1: One important aspect of academic work (as opposed to popular writing) is that you need to acknowledge where various ideas came from. As a tutor of mine once said: whatever you don’t wake up just knowing one day
column2: needs to be either referenced or arise directly from your results. But with so many papers out there now – what does this mean? What about citing multiple papers for the one statement? When should you cite how many papers
column3: and which?

column1: One approach to this is to cite a lot of other papers. The idea is (I guess) that you somehow ‘prove’ that you really know the literature. In this school of thought
column2: even relatively obvious statements often get three or even more references to other work. This approach is very common
column3: but I don’t think it’s very elegant.

column1: An alternative approach is to focus on the most important citations. A good choice is to focus on the ‘classic’ papers on a given topic
column2: as well as the most recent
column3: high-impact papers on that topic. A good way of finding the ‘classics’ on a given topic is to search in online databases
column4: and sort the findings by the number of times a paper has been cited. The ‘classics’ tend to be highly cited.

column2: the latest ‘high impact’ papers make for good sources to cite. Those are basically the ones that will be relatively highly cited in the future
column3: but are not highly cited yet – it typically takes about 1-2 years for a paper to get cited after it is published. To find the latest important papers in your discipline
column4: you need to be aware of which are the most important journals in your field
column5: and it’s a good idea to (regularly) read the table of contents of these journals
column6: so that you’re up to date.

column1: Key parts of a paper where most of the citations end up are the introduction (where you demonstrate how your work fits in with others
column2: and that you know who else publishes in your domain)
column3: and the discussion (where you relate your findings to other people’s findings). Note that with very few exceptions
column4: there are no citations in the abstract.

column1: Although there are many different types of papers
column2: some types of sections occur in most papers.

column1: The abstract is the first thing your reader will see. It’s also the first impression that editors will get of your paper. A good abstract will leave people satisfied that they know what you did
column2: why you did it
column3: and what you found out. A good abstract most likely means people will want to read the rest of the paper
column4: and it greatly increases the chances of people remembering your paper later on. This
column5: in turn
column6: means a good abstract is important for people to cite your paper. If your main message is clear from the abstract
column7: others are much more likely to recall what your paper was all about when they pick it up a year after first reading it – for example when they are in the process of writing a paper of their own and are looking for appropriate citations.

column2: in both style and length. It is critically important that you follow the instructions for authors for your particular journal. Here is an overview of some of the differences that you might encounter.

column1: Descriptive abstracts give some background information
column2: and summarise some of the argument. Their analogue in the movie world is a trailer. They tell you enough about what the paper is all about so that you want to keep reading it – but they don’t give it all away. They often don’t give you the final take-home messages
column3: but rather
column4: they end in statements such as: “The implications of these findings for policy development are discussed.” Some disciplines use these kinds of abstracts a lot
column5: but personally
column6: I find them frustrating. Take my previous example just above. If there are important policy implications
column7: wouldn’t it be much nicer to know what they actually are
column8: rather than just knowing that there are implications? My sense is that descriptive abstracts should be avoided
column9: unless you are dealing with a journal and discipline where it is expected of you to write such an abstract. Otherwise
column10: readers get a lot more out of ‘real summaries’.

column1: Real summaries is my slightly clumsy term for the more common type of abstract
column2: which tells you about what you did
column3: why you did it
column4: what you found
column5: and what the implications are. It’s really the latter that sets them apart from descriptive abstracts. Real summaries fully reflect the scope of the paper from motivation to take-home-messages. So
column6: for example
column7: a last sentence of a real summary might be: “Our findings suggest that a more participatory approach is needed to improve citizen acceptance of the suggested reforms to water policy.” This doesn’t just tell you that there are policy implications
column8: but it tells you something (of course only very briefly) about what those implications actually are: in this case
column9: the need for more citizen participation.

column1: Structured abstracts are a type of abstract that some journals use. They tend to use a series of sub-headings or numbers; and authors are supposed to follow this structure when they write their summaries. The Journal of Applied Ecology is a good example of such a format. Typically
column2: the different parts of the abstract refer to different sections of the paper. For example
column3: there might be one part of the abstract that summarises the background and motivates the paper
column4: one point that summarises the aims and study location
column5: one for the methods
column6: and so on. In the case of the Journal of Applied Ecology
column7: the last sentence needs to be a clear summary of the take-home messages.

column1: Although structured abstracts are relatively uncommon
column2: almost all abstracts work well if they are first written as if they were structured abstracts. Typically
column3: abstracts will mirror the structure of the overall paper. It is particularly important to have a clear first sentence that motivates the need for the paper and gives background information; and it is particularly important to have clear take-home messages. Perhaps the least important part of an abstract (in terms of length) is the methods. A summary of methods should be included
column4: but often this can be quite short. Given that not everything can be included in an abstract
column5: the methods can be dealt with relatively briefly
column6: whereas it is critical that the motivation and take-home-messages are long enough that they are clear.

column1: Abstracts vary widely in length. Some journals allow as little as 120 words
column2: whereas others go up to 400 or so. Longer is not necessarily better
column3: or easier to write. In all cases
column4: it’s important to try to appropriate fit the content within the prescribed length.

column2: it works best if you write your abstract last – to summarise your document
column3: you first need to have your document finished.

column1: * Collect several abstracts from existing papers
column2: both within your own expertise and outside your own expertise.

column1: * Analyse these abstracts: Do they follow a clear structure? Which abstracts tell you a lot
column2: and which tell you very little? Which do you like
column3: and why? Which are easy to follow
column4: and why? Is the ‘so-what’ clear?

column1: * Write a short list of attributes that you found frustrating in other people’s abstracts
column2: and a list of things you found really useful.

column1: * When you write your own abstract
column2: use this list as a reference point.

column1: The introduction of a paper is critically important. Even if your results are quite good
column2: unless you introduce your work well
column3: interesting results can come across as boring or meaningless. This issue is related to that of framing
column4: which I discuss separately elsewhere.

column1: Introductions need to start with a broad motivating statement
column2: which takes up one or two sentences. The scheme for these sentences typically is something like this: “XYZ is a really important issue because of A
column3: B
column4: and C.”

column2: there is usually some review of existing knowledge. This serves two purposes. One
column3: you need to embed your work in the context of other people’s work. Two (a more political reason)
column4: you need to demonstrate that you know about other important players in the area in which you are publishing. Reviewers get very annoyed if you have missed their very important work
column5: even though it’s on a related topic. You can’t (and shouldn’t!) cite everything
column6: but it’s a good idea to be familiar with who else is working in your area
column7: and give them credit for their work.

column2: like a funnel. At the very end
column3: you present specific aims. The logic of an introduction thus typically flows something like this:

column2: it has these effects
column3: and these other effects

column1: * These have been investigated in a number of ways
* Author A came up with this explanation
* Author B proposed an alternative explanation

column2: it is unknown what the role of the phenomenon Z is.

column1: * Phenomenon Z could be important because of this
column2: that
column3: and something else.

column2: we investigate the role of phenomenon Z in the context of …
we addressed three aims:
we tested whether …
we compared our findings …
we applied our insights to …

column1: * Optional last sentence to summarise the key finding: “We show that …”
The last optional sentence wraps up the introduction. It basically states the main finding. While that might seem unusual
column2: it gives a strong ending to the introduction
column3: and makes it very clear for the reader in which direction you are heading. Some leading journals now encourage a summary sentence at the end of the introduction.

column1: How long should an introduction be? This depends on the discipline and journal you are writing for
column2: and on your overall strategy to fit your content within the prescribed length. You might want to copy and paste the introductions from some papers that you like (which are broadly similar)
column3: and do a word count on them to get a rough idea for what is appropriate.

column1: * Collect the introductions from several published papers
column2: both from your own area of expertise and from outside your own expertise.

column1: * Analyse these introductions: Do they follow a clear structure? Which introductions lead you clearly to key aims? Which take big detours? Do you think those detours are useful (because they add depth)
column2: or are they a distraction? Why? After the introduction
column3: are you inspired to read the rest of the paper? Are the aims clear — do you know what’s coming?

column1: * Write a short list of attributes that you found frustrating in other people’s introductions
column2: and a list of things you found really useful.

column1: * When you write your own introduction
column2: use this list as a reference point.

column1: Many papers don’t have conclusions. My personal view is that this is not a good trend – I think it’s a good idea to have a short conclusion that summarises your key finding
column2: and key take-home message. This shouldn’t be too long or repetitive
column3: but is worth having so that your argument is not left unfinished. Importantly
column4: don’t start any new thoughts in your conclusion.

column1: * Find recent papers that are relevant to your own work. Do they even have conclusions?
* If there was just one thing that you want your reader to remember from your work
column2: what is it? What if there were two
column3: or three things? List these things: they probably should be in your conclusion.

column1: The referencing style differs between different journals. No matter which journal you submit to
column2: you save yourself a lot of work if you use specialized software for managing your references and for formatting them (such as Endnote or RefWorks). This software can do three things for you: (1) make sure you don’t cite things that then are missing in the reference list
column3: and (2) format all your references consistent with a particular journal style
column4: and (3) re-format your references for a different journal style should you want (or have) to submit your work elsewhere. Like all software this takes a little time to learn
column5: but if you intend to write several papers
column6: the learning curve is absolutely worth it.

column2: you should list your acknowledgements. This includes funding sources
column3: colleagues who helped you (but are not authors)
column4: and it also includes referees if they gave you useful suggestions for how to improve your paper. For example: “Comments by two anonymous reviewers greatly helped to improve an earlier version of this manuscript.”

column1: Some sections are particularly relevant to empirical papers.

column2: the methods section describes everything the reader needs to know to replicate what you did. This means that all procedures need to be described in sufficient detail that somebody else could implement them again. Methods are usually written in past tense. The only references in the methods section tend to be to previous
column3: related work (which the reader needs to know about) or technical papers outlining particular protocols. In the latter case
column4: it is appropriate to summarise the technical procedure briefly
column5: as well as point to a specific reference for further details. The only procedures that need no references are those that are accepted as ‘standard techniques’. It will depend on your discipline what is considered a standard method. An example might be simple linear regression. If you say that you used simple linear regression in an empirical science context
column6: nobody will expect you to provide a reference. If you say
column7: for example
column8: that you used canonical correspondence analysis
column9: however
column10: people probably will want you to give a reference
column11: so they can look up the details. So what is considered a standard technique and what is not is context-dependent.

column1: * Do you have  lot of methods? If so
column2: you probably need to think of a series of sub-headings.

column1: * What can you assume is general background knowledge in your discipline
column2: and what requires explanation? Hence
column3: which of your methods can you describe briefly (perhaps with a reference)
column4: and which need more space?

column1: The results section of a (non-essay) paper is where the findings are presented. This is typically done in past tense
column2: and without any references to other work. You simply summarise key points from your figures and tables
column3: and explain additional findings in the text. You provide no interpretation of findings. The results section is purely descriptive.

column2: prioritise them
column3: and decide which to include in your paper

column1: * How can you best communicate your particular results: in text
column2: tables
column3: or figures? (Figures work best for many readers.)

column1: Standard (non-essay) papers have discussion section after the results. This section is about interpreting the findings
column2: placing them in a bigger context
column3: relating them to other work
column4: and presenting take-home messages.

column2: you have a lot of freedom how you write your Discussion section – probably even more so than for the Introduction. Broadly speaking
column3: there are two types of discussion.

column1: The ‘boring’ type of discussion goes through your main results
column2: one after the other
column3: interprets the result
column4: and relates it to other literature. The method goes something like this:

column2: e.g.:) “Many large companies integrated sustainability considerations in their daily operations.”
e.g.:) “This may be because of X
column3: or because of Y.”

column2: e.g.:) “These findings underline the importance of ZZZ (reference)
column3: as also shown in Japan (reference) and the USA (reference).”

column2: and so on)

column1: Most discussions have at least some sections that follow this boring format. There’s nothing wrong with this
column2: other than that it is
column3: well
column4: boring…

column1: Towards the end of your discussion
column2: and if you’re bold all the way through
column3: you need a more creative way of putting things together. Even if you’re using the ‘boring’ format
column4: you still need to get to the bigger picture
column5: the big so-what messages. That is very hard to do unless at some point
column6: you go for a more creative format.

column2: but more interesting
column3: to start with a more creative format from the outset. A freely structured discussion needs to make a clear argument
column4: and it can be very useful to use sub-headings to structure this argument. Even though the structure might be free and creative
column5: you still need to draw on your own results under each sub-heading
column6: not just on other literature – a discussion is NOT a literature review
column7: but your work must be at the centre of the argument.

column1: A discussion often picks up similar themes as discussed in the Introduction

column3: a Discussion focuses on your results initially

column1: Most people find it easier to read figures than tables. Figures therefore are an effective means of summarizing key findings. A convention is to describe the overall pattern in your findings in the text
column2: and then refer to a figure for details.
you might write: “Species composition changes systematically along a gradient of land use intensity (Fig. 2)” – and Figure 2 would then show the details of this gradient.

column1: Or you might write: “Large companies often had explicit policies in place to enhance sustainability (Fig. 3a). By contrast
column2: many small companies had policies for various aspects of sustainability (e.g. governing social issues) but these were rarely combined in an explicit framework for sustainability (Fig. 3b).”
the text tells you the basics
column3: and you can look at the figures to find out more.

column1: Here’s a couple of bad examples:
“Figure 2 shows changes in species composition” – Figure 2 should not be the central part of the sentence
column2: but something referred to at the end.

column1: “Large companies had different ways of dealing with sustainability than small companies (Figure 3)” – this doesn’t tell you enough about what those different ways actually were.

column2: there is too little emphasis on writing good text to go with a good figure.

column1: There are a few things to consider when preparing the figures themselves:
* Use simple fonts (sans serif) and avoid ‘graph clutter’. So
column2: for example
column3: Times New Roman is not a good font for graphs
column4: whereas Arial is a good font. Similarly
column5: three-dimensional bar charts like Microsoft Excel can produce are full of graph clutter. Keep things minimal – whatever doesn’t contain information shouldn’t be in the graph.

column1: * Keep your things black and white
column2: unless you are writing for a journal that uses colour figures (and note those often cost extra!)

column1: * Keep in mind the size of your figures. Make your figures as small as possible
column2: and make sure that the fonts are readable in the size the figure will ultimately be printed in. Also
column3: think about how many columns the table should take up. Journals tend to arrange their text in one
column4: two or three columns. If you write for a two-column journal
column5: it makes sense to come up with a figure that either takes up one column in width
column6: or two columns in width.

column2: figures need to have informative legends. Good legends are often quite long. Try to write legends
column3: which (together with the figure) can pretty much stand alone. Legends that are very short often contain too little information. Especially for somebody who reads your paper quickly
column4: it is very useful if your legend contains quite a lot of information. Note that legends for figures are placed below the figure. In a manuscript
column5: they typically go on a separate page from the figures themselves.

column2: don’t worry about software. Draw by hand what you want your figure to look like.

column1: * Then ask yourself if you can implement this figure yourself
column2: or if you would need additional technical skills

column1: * If your ideal figure can’t be done easily
column2: ask yourself if there is a slightly simpler version that you can do
column3: which is almost as good. Don’t waste too much time on ‘the perfect figure’!

column1: Tables are an effective means to summarise summary information
column2: both numerical and otherwise. When you prepare a table
column3: also consider the alternative – figures. Figures tend to take up more space for the same information
column4: but some patterns can be summarized much more effectively in pictures than in a table. But especially when the data you are trying to visualize is quite simple
column5: tables are sometimes almost quite as good as figures
column6: but take up a lot less space.

column1: Once you have decided a table is what you want
column2: think about how to present your information within the table.

column1: Most journals will allow multiple nested column names
column2: but otherwise
column3: note that the formatting in published tables is usually pretty minimal. So
column4: while in your word processor you can use different types of highlighting or colours
column5: this is not the case in most journals. The best is to format your table using only horizontal lines (like in published tables) – and then make sure the information is clearly understandable.

column1: Keep in mind the size of your tables. While you can fit a lot into a table in your word processor
column2: journals typically have less space – so make your tables as small as possible. Also
column3: you might want to think about how many columns the table should take up. Journals tend to arrange their text in one
column4: two or three columns. If you write for a two-column journal
column5: it makes sense to come up with a table format that either takes up one column in width
column6: or two columns in width.

column2: tables need to have informative legends. Good legends are often quite long. Try to write legends
column3: which (together with the table) can pretty much stand alone. Legends that are very short often contain too little information. Especially for somebody who reads your paper quickly
column4: it is very useful if your legend contains quite a lot of information. Note that table legends go above the tables (unlike figure legends).

column1: Not many journals allow boxes. In case you write for a journal that does have boxes
column2: they are really useful for a few things.

column1: Examples. A classic use of boxes is to provide short case studies or examples of a concept
column2: theory or situation that you outline in the text.

column1: Additional depth. If there is something you find exciting
column2: but it’s not really central to your argument
column3: a box can be good for that.

column1: Cross-linkages throughout your text. Sometimes boxes can help to link different sections of a paper in the one point. For example
column2: if you have several sections that build different parts of an overall argument or theory
column3: a box can be an effective way to summarise how those parts come together.

column1: If your journal does allow boxes
column2: check carefully how they are formatted. Some contains figures and tables as well
column3: others include just text. Also check the typical word count in a box in your target journal; this varies widely
column4: depending on the page layout of the particular journal.

column1: Supplementary online material is now being used by many journals for things that will only be of central interest to a small number of readers
column2: but nevertheless should not be left out. It is essentially what used to be appendices. Supplementary material often can be several additional pages of text
column3: and sometimes up to 10 additional figures. Different journals have different restrictions on this.

column1: Typical items that can go into the supplementary material are things such as (1) in-depth methods
column2: (2) additional results
column3: (3) further justification for a particular approach
column4: or (4) photographs related to the study. In all cases
column5: the main text needs to refer to the supplementary material (e.g. “see supplementary online material for further details”
column6: or by referring to “Fig. S1”). It is also a good idea to summarise briefly the supplementary material in the text. For example “A null model was used to test whether communities were randomly assembled (see supplementary online information for details)”
column7: or “Additional scenarios were explored and showed broadly similar patterns (Figures S1-S5)”
column8: or “Our study assumes that communities are influenced by institutions at multiple scales
column9: including local
column10: state and federal governments (Fig. S1)”.

column1: Supplementary online material should not be seen as a deposit for everything that didn’t otherwise fit. Rules of prioritizing your material and fitting the content to the prescribed length still apply. Rather
column2: supplementary material is for things that are necessary or informative
column3: but not of central interest to the majority of readers.

column1: * Collect supplementary material from a few different journals that are relevant to you. Get a feeling for what people put into their supplementary material. Which kind of format is useful for you
column2: the reader
column3: to understand how the material is organised?

column1: It’s helpful to understand the process of publishing. Writing a good paper is probably the most important
column2: but it’s also helpful to understand some of the peripheral issues surrounding the process of publishing.

column1: Most journals expect that your manuscript is formatted in the following way:
First page is a cover page
column2: containing title
column3: keywords
column4: author names and institutional affiliations
column5: plus the email address of the corresponding author.

column1: Second page is where the abstract should start.
Third page onwards comes the manuscript text
column2: WITHOUT any tables
column3: figures
column4: or table or figure legends.

column1: At the end of the text
column2: list your Acknowledgements
column3: followed by References.

column1: On a new page after the references
column2: list your figure legends.

column1: On separate new pages after that
column2: present your tables. The table legends go directly above the tables.

column1: On separate new pages after that
column2: list your figures
column3: one figure per page. Some journals also want you to upload the figure files separately (in which case you need to follow their instructions file type and resolution).

column2: your entire manuscript should be double-space. It is also helpful if you add line numbers
column3: for example every fifth line
column4: consecutively throughout the entire manuscript. This makes it much easier for referees to comment on your work.

column1: If you find your work worthwhile
column2: you will have an inherent interest that many people read it. This means you need to place your paper in the right journal (e.g. matching the topic with what else is in the journal)
column3: and preferably in a widely read journal. The impact factor of a journal is a measure of how widely cited recent articles from the particular journal are. In this sense
column4: it does matter. In addition
column5: a high impact factor publication will look better on your CV than a low impact one.

column2: the most important thing is that you publish in a journal that is highly visible to your target audience. A certain journal might have a slightly lower impact factor than another one
column3: but if it is still among the ‘standard leading journals’ in your field
column4: it’s not worthwhile worrying too much about the impact factor.

column2: think of the impact factor as a means – to measure if a journal is widely read. Publishing in a good journal
column3: by contrast
column4: is the ultimate objective. The impact factor will help you make an informed decision where to submit your paper
column5: but it should not be the only criterion.

column1: Cover letters have become quite important in some academic disciplines. Ask around in your discipline how common it is for papers to be rejected without peer review. If that is a common phenomenon
column2: this suggests that editors themselves have a lot of power – they might decide that a lot of papers don’t even go for peer review. Rejections without peer review tend to be quick
column3: but are frustrating because you get virtually no feedback why your paper was rejected.

column1: Cover letters are intended to convince the editors that they should send the paper out for peer review. If you are dealing with a journal that sends almost everything out for peer review
column2: a minimalistic cover letter is fine. But if you are dealing with journals that reject a lot of work without peer review
column3: you need to explain why your particular paper is worth considering.

column1: In a (more than minimalistic) cover letter
column2: you might want to explain:

column1: * That you’re submitting the work to the journal for consideration for publication;

column2: exciting and important;

column1: * Why you think the particular journal is suitable;
* Any additional information that is important to the particular journal.
Many journals have additional specific requirements for their cover letters. For example
column2: they may require a statement that all co-authors have read the manuscript and agree to its submission; or they may ask you to suggest potential referees. Check the journal’s instructions for authors to make sure you follow the instructions.
it’s a good idea to contact the editor by email before you submit your paper to ask if the paper might be suitable for a journal. This is not something that all journals are happy with
column3: but some actually encourage such pre-submission enquiries. If you do write a pre-submission enquiry
column4: it’s a good idea to keep it brief; send the abstract
column5: and maybe a key figure; and explain why you think it might be suitable for a particular journal. Make sure you specifically ask whether the editor thinks the work may be suitable for the particular journal. Sometimes editors get back to you with a helpful hint: for example
column6: they might say that your work sounds interesting
column7: but needs to have a clearer international relevance for it to be considered. If that’s the case
column8: you already know that there’s something you should work on some more before even submitting to that particular journal.

column2: I think a cover letter should be about one page
column3: and if possible
column4: it looks better if you write it on the official letterhead of your institution.

column2: you need a subscription to read the articles. This costs money
column3: and it is one of the key reasons why people in poor countries do not have very good access to primary scientific literature.

column1: In an effort to make scientific literature available more widely
column2: an increasing number of journals offers an ‘open access’ option
column3: and some journals are entirely open access. Both typically require the author to pay money (out of research grants
column4: typically) when a paper is accepted for publication. However
column5: both types of model typically also have an option that stipulates that if you truly cannot afford the so-called page charges
column6: they will still take your paper.

column1: Some people have speculated that making your paper open access might increase your citation rates. Whether that’s true or not
column2: it is certainly easier to access a paper if it is open access. I suggest whether you choose an open access journal or not should depend on who you think your main audience is (and hence what the benefits of open access are)
column3: and whether you can find a journal that has a good reputation and is open access in your field. My personal view is this: If you have two equally prestigious journals
column4: one allows you to make your paper open access while the other does not
column5: and you have funds to pay for this – then you may as well make your paper open access because you have nothing to lose
column6: and you might gain extra readers. If your work is directly relevant to poor countries or to institutions who typically do not have access to journals (e.g. in the business sector)
column7: you might place an even higher priority on publishing your work open access.

column1: When you first write your paper
column2: of course you hope for it to be accepted. But reality is that many papers are rejected
column3: and those of those that are not
column4: many require revisions
column5: often major. As an example
column6: leading international journals in applied ecology now reject 80% of papers – if you look at leading journals like Nature
column7: the percentage of rejections is much higher still. Given this situation
column8: being asked to submit a revised version
column9: even if the revisions are major
column10: is often a ‘success’. How can you make sure that when you are asked to submit a revised version
column11: you maximize the chances of your revised paper being accepted?

column1: The first general rule is that you take the criticisms of all reviewers seriously. As the author
column2: it’s your job to communicate your ideas clearly. Even in cases where the criticism you received seems unjustified
column3: ask yourself “What can I do better so that this same reviewer will be more likely to buy into my argument next time around?” Even if you are completely satisfied that your argument holds
column4: ask yourself if you can do a better job of communicating it clearly.

column1: You then need to go through the comments by the editor and all reviewers one by one
column2: and address every single one of them. Broadly speaking
column3: you have three options for how to respond to a particular criticism:

column2: upon reflection
column3: you agree with the reviewer: You implement a change that does what the reviewer asked for. For example
column4: she may have asked for additional explanation
column5: an additional reference
column6: or the complete re-write of a section
column7: including a different conclusion.

column2: despite reflection
column3: you disagree with the reviewer: You might not want to implement some particular suggestions
column4: especially if they relate to subjective matters
column5: which you simply feel differently about. (For minor suggestions
column6: I suggest just do as the reviewers suggest
column7: because there’s nothing to lose; but if you truly disagree
column8: just implementing the suggestions is not a satisfactory solution.) Still
column9: in this case
column10: you can often communicate more clearly what your position on the issue is. So re-write your text in a way that might convince the reviewer of your position
column11: lends more weight to your argument
column12: or is simply easier to follow. In this case
column13: you’re still making the same argument as before
column14: but you explain it more clearly.

column2: despite reflection
column3: you think a reviewer is simply wrong: In this case
column4: you change nothing in the text
column5: but you explain in your cover letter to editor why you did not make the change.

column1: As a general rule of thumb
column2: if you want your paper to be accepted
column3: and especially if it goes back to the same reviewers
column4: your response to most criticisms needs to be type 1
column5: followed by type 2 – only rarely will you get away with response type 3 above.

column1: Your revision ultimately consists of the changed manuscript
column2: as well as a detailed letter outlining point by point your responses to the reviewers. Put yourself in the position of the editor: she wants to understand as easily as possible what you changed or did not change
column3: and why. Making this job as easy as possible for the editor is what your response letter needs to do.

column2: which follows a logic like this:

column1: ** Thank you for your decision letter from xyz.
** We greatly appreciate the constructive comments.
** We have now addressed these comments
column2: and this has strengthened the paper.
we outline point by point responses to the comments by the reviewers (and the associate editor
column3: if applicable).

column1: ** We hope our revised version will be received favourably and look forward to hearing from you in the near future.

column2: detailed point by point responses
column3: to each of the comments
column4: in a format as follows:

column1: ** Paste in a given reviewer’s comment in italics
** Then explain how you have addressed it
column2: e.g.:

column1: *** ''“The authors assert that biodiversity is declining in their study area
column2: but they do not substantiate this claim. At the very least
column3:
this statement requires a reference.”''
Response: We appreciate this concern and have now added a reference (Smith et al. XXX; see page 4 of the revised manuscript)

column1:
*** “The methods used on page 6 are unclear. Which type of regression model was used?”
Response: In the first paragraph of page 6 of the original manuscript
column2: we had actually specified that we used generalized linear models. Arguably
column3: our statement was hidden among other information
column4: which is why the reviewer may have missed it. We have now moved our statement to a more prominent position at the beginning of the section on ‘Data analysis’ (page 5 of the revised manuscript). This should make it more obvious which methods we used.

column1: Don’t be surprised that response letters sometimes end up very long! Still
column2: it is better to explain too carefully what you have changed and why
column3: than not carefully enough. The objective of a response letter is to show the editor that you are taking the review process seriously
column4: and that you have put in a very genuine effort to address the comments
column5: including the difficult ones. It’s a good idea to approach this process from a position of intellectual humility
column6: while also making sure that you stay true to your core argument.

or other journals with unusual formats: Nature and Science often mix results and discussions

Writing an outline;"With the completion of an outline you take one first step of what your research could be all about. One should never forget that research is an evolving and iterative process
column2: though. Still
column3: writing an outline makes you settle for what you want to focus on in this moment
column4: and more importantly
column5: also allows your supervisors as well as your peers to give you structured feedback. This is why any research project should start with the landmark of writing an outline. Different branches in science have different focal points and norms that an outline is build upon. Here
column6: we present an approach that tries to do justice to the diversity of approaches that are out there
column7: yet it is always advisable to ask your supervisors for modification if need be.

column1: All research starts with a  title. Personally
column2: I read hundreds of titles of research papers each month
column3: and only a small portion are appealing to my specific focus and interest to invite me to read further. Titles are the door-opener for most researchers
column4: which is why titles should be simple and to the point. If a title is too long it will lack clarity and crispiness. If a title is too short
column5: it will surely not give away enough information needed to know what the research is all about. Often people try to make a fancy title that is supposed to be witty or funny and contains some sort of wordplay or inside joke. Avoid this. You may go for such a title later once the research is done and the paper is written
column6: yet such titles need to be earned. Hence especially in an outline it is best for a title that is walking the fine line of giving away enough information but not too much.

column2: it is going to be you who will do the research. You will sit at your desk
column3: you will gather the data and look at the literature
column4: you will get deeper into the topic
column5: thus it is you who will basically write the research. To this end
column6: it has proven of immense value to have a network of peers. More often than not
column7: this is an informal network for critical reflection
column8: but also for support. Such a peer network will not be mentioned here if it is not actively involved in conducting the research. Beside your supervisors actually very few people will be involved in your research. You may have someone helping with the analysis or being experienced in the topic if you are a PhD student
column9: yet in a Bachelor or Master thesis the focus is stronger on proving that you can conduct independent research. While in a PhD this is also the goal
column10: it is on a more sophisticated level
column11: where because of the longer timeline and thus deeper focus collaboration may be of greater importance. It is also quite important to clarify roles and expectations at the beginning. Remember that a thesis is your work.

column1: The topical focus and its background are often what drives people. Most researchers are very exited about their topics
column2: and it is valuable to have something that can fuel your energy while you work on your thesis. There will be ups and downs surely
column3: yet it is still good to focus on something that not only drives you
column4: but also current research. Timely topics are ideally embedded into a longer development that led to the emergence of the topic. You do not want to work on a topic where thousands and thousands of paper were already published
column5: but ideally you should also not work on something that is so new that there are no shoulders to stand on. Researchers do really stand on the shoulders of giants
column6: and despite the thrive to make innovative and timely research
column7: we should never forget that we are part of a bigger movement. Within this movement
column8: we will add one tiny step. A friend once said that we are drops in a wave - a fitting allegory when looking how research evolves. Still
column9: our contribution matters
column10: and may move the research landscape forward. What it does however more importantly is that it moves us forward. A thesis is first and foremost a prove that you can conduct research
column11: and that you are thus able to contribute to the scientific community. Because of this
column12: the topic is less important than most people think it is
column13: because research is a transformational experience for the research. Do not misunderstand me
column14: all topics of past people I supervised were really important to me. What is however even more important is that they learned to overcome themselves
column15: and slay the dragon that is their thesis.

column1: Once you found a topic that excites you
column2: it is advisable to iterate it with your peers. Write down why your topic is timely
column3: how it contributes to the wider research
column4: and what  the current state of the art is. You want to make a thorough assessment yet have to be careful because reading too much may confuse you. Do not expect that everything is coherent and there are no contradictions. Research is discourse
column5: and these discourses evolve over time. Often researchers disagree
column6: and not everything makes sense. Be prepared to be confused. It is your job to evolve a critical perspective of the state of the art of the literature
column7: and identify landmark papers. Also
column8: try to find previous research that aimed in the same direction and learn how they approached the topic. What were the methodologies
column9: where did the researchers struggle
column10: and what were their recommendations. Lastly
column11: try to develop an elevator pitch on why this topic is important to you. If you can explain in short why you think this research needs to be done
column12: you are onto something.

column1: Just as topics are embedded in the current scientific discourse
column2: such research looks at partials of reality. In order to generate such a specific view of reality
column3: research builds on theories. Theories in science can be operationalized at different scales. Some theories are on a conceptual level
column4: which is basically very theoretical and often restricted to non-empirical research such as much of philosophy. Other researchers may build on frameworks
column5: and is very applied. In between are paradigms
column6: which are the types of theories that branches of research are for some time built upon. Examples for concepts would justice or peace
column7: examples of paradigms would be effective altruism or ecosystem services
column8: and examples for frameworks would be concrete assessment schemes or the sustainable development goals. Much confusion in theory work is because these three levels are confused
column9: which is why it is important to localise your theory in your work clearly.

column1: Another common problem when writing an outline is to settle for a low number of theories. If you ask me
column2: one theory can be enough
column3: and two can be exciting. More than two theories are more often than not impossible to tame. Hence you need to remember that you look at a version of reality
column4: and that theories enable you to either test hypothesis or create research questions that are open and specific at the same time. You may not want to know how everything works
column5: but how it works under a specific viewpoint or theory of reality. This is what theories are all about. Researchers theorize how mechanisms in the world might work
column6: how patterns emerge
column7: why people act
column8: and why societies fail. There is a plethora of theories
column9: and it is important to be familiar with the literature of the theories that are within your realm.

column1: Most topics are associated with certain theories
column2: such as mainstream economics often resolves around utilitarianism. While you can operate on safe ground if you follow suit with these associations
column3: it can also be exciting yet daring to superimpose a theory onto a topic that has never been exposed to it. Yet this should ideally be discussed with your supervisor
column4: because while it can be exciting
column5: it may be prone to challenges that are hard to anticipate by the uninitiated. This is one of the key points where you should build on the experience of others. Lastly
column6: while it may be exciting to work on a scientific theory
column7: always remember that you look at a snapshot. Theories are often proposed
column8: and then in subsequent years applied. Based on this
column9: they are revised
column10: scrutinized
column11: and often the research community becomes divided about specific theories. While many researchers question or even reject evolutionary altruism for example
column12: others may work based on this theory for their whole career. Choosing a theory is a normative responsibility
column13: you decide to take on a specific perspective
column14: and this is a key responsibility as a researcher. While you should choose wisely
column15: I would also say: Do not overthink it. Most early researchers tend to think way too much about it
column16: in fact I never saw anyone thinking too little about it. And after all
column17: at this point your supervisors should give you feedback.

column2: you can at this point already identify the main references that your research is being based upon. Make sure to reference the sources that are most recognized by the research community
column3: but also closest to what you think are the best sources. Often this may be one and the same
column4: but sometimes it differs. What is crucial is to focus on the main sources. Especially early career researchers are so happy that they read so much stuff that they want to quote it all. While this sounds like a great idea
column5: remember that not everybody is as deeply embedded as your are
column6: thus focus on the most important sources. On a less dramatic note
column7: make sure that your quotations are in the same style. Settle early on one citation style
column8: use a software to guarantee coherence
column9: and never change it from then on.

column1: The next point is a very delicate one: Research questions vs. hypotheses. Let us start with the more simple point. How much of those should you have? It is really difficult to answer one question. This is something that philosophers may do

and...""-thinking is a technique used in improvisation. It originates from and is most commonly known in improvisational theater
column3: but it can also be applied in any other context where new ideas shall be developed. Spontaneous improvisation building on ""Yes
column4: and..."" can improve [[Glossary|brainstorming]] processes and encourage team members to better cooperate and listen to each other in the process of idea generation. You may call it a proper philosophy on how to work and communicate with each other.

column2: and..."": the ""Yes!"" and the ""and..."".

column1: The ""Yes"" means not to immediately judge other people's ideas and decline them if they do not seem suitable
column2: but rather be positive about them. The ""and...""-element encourages the addition of new information and thoughts which can lead to more complex ideas.
and..."" does not necessarily mean that every new sentence has to begin with the words ""Yes
column3: and"". Instead
column4: it is about the mental attitude of accepting whatever other people offer and continuing or expanding upon their line of thought. It means going with the flow instead of blocking ideas and losing the dynamics of an ongoing discussion. ""Yes
column5: and"" is about losing one's ego and fostering positivity in a group. For a theatre audience
column6: this is more fun to watch; and for team members at work (in any field
column7: really)
column8: it is both more fun to engage with and more productive than being overly critical and blocking ideas as soon as they are formulated.
